title: OFFER TO TAIWAN RENEWED BY CHINA
description: Prime Minister Zhao Ziyang today reiterated China's offer to let Taiwan retain its capitalist economic and social system if it reu nited with the Communist mainland.

title: Some Coal Miners Work Without New Contract By United Press International
description: Miners reported for work as usual today at some A.T. Massey Coal Company mines in southern West Virginia, although their contract expired and negotiators failed to reach agreement on a new one with the independent operator.

title: 'PASSIONS' AND 'BOOKER' ON TONIGHT
description: Televison does have its moments, and an impressive number of them can be found on the schedule this evening. An ordinary television movie on CBS at 9 is given substance and sensitivity through the performances of Joanne Woodward and Lindsay Wagner. And a new family-entertainment series on public television at 8 gets off to a beautifully affecting start with a story about the childhood of Booker T. Washington.

title: REMEMBERING VIETNAM
description: Take what they have left and what they have taught you with their dying and keep it with your own. . . And in that time when men decide and feel safe to call the war insane, take one moment to embrace those gentle heroes you left behind. . .

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.

title: French Account Deficit
description: France's current account showed a deficit of 33.8 billion francs, or about $3.61 billion, in 1983, down from 79.3 million francs in 1982 but deeper than previous Government forecasts, the Bank of France said Friday. A country's current account measures international transactions in trade of both goods and services.

title: Gale Halts Nuclear Salvage
description: A gale halted salvage work on the wrecked French freighter Mont Louis today with one of 30 barrels of uranium hexafluoride still to be recovered, a salvage company spokesman said. The last drum had not been located when the salvage crew was forced to stop work because of strong winds, but the spokesman said it was probably concealed in debris in the front of the hold.

title: DIM SALES OF BUSINESS PLANES
description: During the recession, the Eaton Corporation cut back the number of its business jets from seven to five. Now profits have rebounded at the auto industry supplier, but it has no plans to replace the planes.

title: Bristol Reassignment
description: Bristol-Myers has gone to its existing agencies, Grey Advertising and Laurence, Charles & Free, with products resigned by Kenyon & Eckhardt.

title: NAVRATILOVA TAKES 65TH
description: Martina Navratilova won her 65th straight match today, defeating Zina Garrison, 6-4, 6-3, in the final of the $150,000 Virginia Slims tournament stop here.

title: WHADDYAMEAN ACCENT? SHE TALKS QUEENS!
description: The candidate was asked why Walter F. Mondale would be more successful than Ronald Reagan in a parley with the Soviets.

title: Bridge Closed by Accident
description: A 28-year-old Brooklyn man was charged with driving while intoxicated yesterday after his van hit a car on the Williamsburg Bridge, injuring three people in the car and closing the bridge in both directions from 1 to 5 P.M. The driver was identified as Sherman Williams of 475 Vermont Street.

title: When a Developer Becomes a Retailer
description: With a decline in available sites for new shopping centers, what could be more natural than for a shopping center developer to turn back from the suburbs and take over a department store chain in a major city?

title: Four Are Beatified In St. Peter's Square
description: Pope John Paul II beatified four people today. They were a Belgian cook for a religious order, a Spanish mother of seven children, a chaplain to Italy's royal family and a northern Italian priest.

title: 16 Die as Communists Fight Filipino Soldiers
description: Sixteen people, including a constabulary company commander, were killed in a 30- minute gun battle between Government forces and Communist guerrillas in southern Surigao del Sur Province, the military said today.

title: AN E.R. DOCTOR'S VOTE ON SEAT BELT LEGISLATION
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: Extra Musicians Ratify Contract With the Met

title: 49ERS DOWN FALCONS TO GO 5-0
description: Joe Montana, adjusting quickly to the new flak jacket protecting his ribs, threw a pair of touchdown passes in the second period as the unbeaten San Francisco 49ers defeated the Atlanta Falcons, 14-5, today.

title: 7 Refused Citizenship For Inadequate English
description: A Federal district judge has refused to swear in seven people as United States citizens because they could not speak adequate English, even though they apparently were exempt from the language requirement, an immigration official says.

title: Gas Fires Force Evacuation
description: Fires preceded by explosions raged through a natural gas processing plant today, forcing dozens of people from their homes in this southwestern Louisiana town, the authorities said. No injuries were reported. The main fire at the 20- acre complex of the Texas Gas Transmission Corporation was brought under control.

title: 'OUT BETTER INSTINCTS' VS. APPEALS TO SELF-INTEREST
description: Candidates for President and Vice President vary their remarks from place to place, but in most speeches there is a common body of material.

title: Saints 27, Oilers 10
description: Richard Todd sparked New Orleans to a 17-0 halftime lead and directed his team close enough for a 27-yard, fourth-quarter field goal by Morten Andersen to brunt a Houston comeback attempt.

title: CONGRESS BUYING TIME TO MEET FUNDS DEADLINE
description: The House of Representatives is expected to approve on Monday a two-day extension of current spending levels for most Government agencies.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Oct. 1, 1984 GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: METS DROP FINALE BUT FINISH SOLID 2D
description: The Mets ended their best season in 15 years with a 5-4 loss to the Montreal Expos today, and fired some long parting shots: a pair of home runs by Darryl Strawberry and a home run and triple by George Foster.

title: Chargers 27, Lions 24
description: Dan Fouts directed San Diego to 24 first-half points, and the Chargers withstood a furious second-half rally.

title: LET THE ELDERLY EARN COST-FREE SUNY CREDITS
description: To the Editor:

title: SPORTS NEWS BRIEFS ; ;  U.S. Soccer Team In a Scoreless Tie
description: The World Cup soccer team of the United States played the Netherlands Antilles to a scoreless tie Saturday night in Curacao in the opening match toward qualifying for the 1986 World Cup in Mexico.

title: TESTS USING HUMAN GENES IN ANIMALS SPUR LEGAL MOVE
description: The Humane Society of the United States and Jeremy Rifkin, a critic of genetic engineering, are accusing the Agriculture Department of violating ''the moral and ethical canons of civilization'' by conducting experiments in which human growth genes are being transferred into pigs and sheep.

title: Rush to Protectionism In its haste to satisfy as many pressure groups as it can before Election Day, Congress is packaging a catch-all foreign trade bill riddled with favors, mostly protectionist. House and Senate conferees could still restore its respectability.
description: The law would help, among others, grape growers, shoemakers and the copper industry - all losers in their appeals for import curbs through regular channels. Apple and pear juice producers would gain from an obscure clause that puts a one- tenth of one percent tariff on competing imports.

title: AIR FORCE WEAPONS: CHEAP IS NOT THE FIRST PRIORITY
description: To the Editor:

title: APPARENT RESURGENCE OF AIR SAFETY HAZARDS WORRIES EXPERTS
description: Concern has been mounting among safety experts over an apparent resurgence of air traffic hazards, underscored by the fatal collision of a commuter airliner and a private plane in California in August and by two close calls in the New York metropolitan area in the last two weeks.

title: ;  Christ the King Bows to Stepinac
description: Rudy Mitchell ran for 172 yards on 10 carries and scored touchdowns from 46 and 23 yards to lead Stepinac to a 31-0 trouncing of Christ the King yesterday in the Catholic High Schools' Football League.

title: A Trade Post Finally Filled
description: Vacant for nearly a year, the post of Assistant Secretary of Commerce (Trade Administration) has just been filled by a Texas businessman close to Vice President Bush and White House Chief of Staff James A. Baker.

title: BRAZILIAN IN UPHILL BATTLE TO SUCCEED THE GENERALS
description: When Paulo Salim Maluf announced his candidacy for the governorship of Sao Paulo State in 1978, the ruling generals opposed him, but he won anyway.

title: NEW STUDY ON CHILDREN WHO SET FIRES
description: Jerry was 8 years old when he set fire to his father's pictures, nearly a year after his mother's death. At night, Jerry dreamed about his mother. His daydreams were about fire. Only a year ago, everyone agreed, Jerry had been outgoing, verbal, surrounded with friends. But in recent months, especially since his father remarried, Jerry had become increasingly withdrawn. He had fought frequently with his sister, had disobeyed his stepmother and had received poor grades for the first time since entering school.

title: Uncertainty On Seabrook
description: The Public Service Company of New Hampshire, which has had legal problems in selling new securities, was working yesterday to avoid a default on $125 million in loans, a spokesman for the utility said.

title: IN AFRICA, TRADITION AND MUSIC
description: Africa's contemporary music sometimes seems an amalgam of influences, some Western, others indigenous, and to be struggling, still, for an identity of its own, caught between disco and a distant echo of ancient drums.

title: A Presidential Convention
description: The most unusual if not the most

title: A FIRST ON MOSCOW BEAT: NEWS WITH A HUMAN FACE
description: Nikita S. Khrushchev liked to do it from time to time. Andrei A. Gromyko is a master at it on rare occasions. For Marshal Nikolai V. Ogarkov, the former Chief of Staff, a virtuoso performance may have contributed to his downfall this month.

title: Annals of Broadway: Extra for One-Woman Play
description: Fred Kolo, who is producing a one-

description: To the Editor:

description: THE smart commander when

title: OUT TO LUNCH
description: BOSTON President Reagan's attempt to blame anyone and everyone but himself for the security failure at the American Embassy in Beirut has discomfited even some of his admirers. But they have not allowed themselves to see the real point of the contemptible episode. That is that Ronald Reagan

title: Nestle Asks Merger Step
description: Nestle, a Swiss-based company that makes food products throughout the world, asked the Federal Trade Commission Friday to approve its acquisition of the Carnation Company.

title: RUTGERS' SURPRISING SURGE
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J.

title: Topics ; Fiscal Fiction and Fact Problem Solver Peter Goldmark, executive director of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey for the last seven and a half years, has spent nearly all of his career in important government posts at times of unusual stress and change. When he announced his intention to resign last week, some admirers were inclined to hope he finds many difficult problems in his next incarnation, since he seems to function best when dealing with them. As budget director of New York State, a post he held throughout most of New York City's fiscal cliff-hanging, Mr. Goldmark managed Albany's own expenditures so efficiently that it was able to stretch resources to aid the city without fatally endangering itself.
description: As the operating head of the bi- state Port Authority, he broadened it from a builder of bridges and tunnels to a provider of assistance to economic development - a big task that Mr. Goldmark brought off without encumbering the authority's reputation for fiscal soundness.

title: Chiefs 10, Browns 6
description: Todd Blackledge threw a 9-yard touchdown pass to Billy Jackson, and the Kansas City defense sacked Paul McDonald 11 times for 78 yards in losses.

title: ; HOW TO TOLL THE BELL FOR A MEN'S CLUB
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. IMPOSES FREEZE ON PHYSICIANS' MEDICARE FEES
description: The Federal Government will impose a one- year freeze on Medicare payments for physicians starting Monday, despite a court challenge by the American Medical Association.

title: 7 Children Among Dead In Pennsylvania Fire
description: A woman and seven children died today in a fire that destroyed a two-story house, officials said.

title: Consultant Wed To Jane Sanders
description: Jane Jonas Sanders, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Norman Sanders of West Nyack, N.Y., was married yesterday to Leland Stanford Englebardt 2d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley L. Englebardt of Westport, Conn. Rabbi Morris Goldberg performed the ceremony at the Plumbush Restaurant in Cold Spring, L.I.

title: Blaze at a Fort Worth Hotel Briefly Traps Some Guests
description: A fire broke out in an 11th-floor closet at a downtown hotel tonight, forcing more than 400 guests to leave, officials said.

title: A WEEK IN THE LIFE OF A JOINT CHIEF
description: By the time the Chief of Naval Operations, Adm. James D. Watkins, rolls into his unpretentious office in the Pentagon at 0700 every morning, he has started to build a head of steam. Having read the Pentagon's packet of press articles on the 10-minute ride from his quarters in the Washington Navy Yard, the admiral flips through a sheaf of messages from the fleet and listens to aides brief him on the day's activities.

title: Heatherten Wins Ruffian Handicap
description: Heatherten, a winner of seven straight stakes races this year before finishing dead last in two of her last three starts, recaptured her old form and the leadership of the nation's older fillies yesterday with a 1 1/4- length victory in the $172,200 Ruffian Handicap at Belmont Park.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: HALF MOON STREET: Two Short

title: DEBUT OF 2-PIANO 'AMERICAN IN PARIS'
description: United States audiences over the weekend finally heard the 1928 two-piano version of George Gershwin's ''American in Paris,'' with Katia and Marielle Lab eque playing it at the Library of Congress here Saturday night and at New York's Carnegie Hall today.

title: 'VIOLENCE FACTOR' OF TV IS EXAMINED
description: Nuf8420The argument over the relationship between television and violence goes on, not so much because it is unsettled as because no one seems able to do much about it. The networks may deny that television violence stimulates violent behavior, but the people who have looked at the problem most closely disagree. What is there to do? Watch ''On Television: The Violence Factor,'' for one thing. The public-television program, on WNYC tonight at 8 o'clock, offers some answers. It will be seen on broadcast Channel 31 and on Channel 3 on Manhattan Cable.

title: MUSEUM SALE: JEWELRY OF 30'S
description: An exhibition of evening wear by Alix Gr es is reminding visitors to the Brooklyn Museum that the Paris couturier's designs are quintessentially classic. Her draped jersey dresses from the 1930's, among a collection of 15 in the show, look as timeless as those of 1984.

title: GIANTS TROUNCED
description: The Jets answered one question but created another today in their 28- 21 loss to the New England Patriots, a game in which three of their key performers were sidelined with injuries.

title: ;  Rockwell's Batboy
description: A mention in this space a few weeks ago of Norman Rockwell's famous 1948 Saturday Evening Post cover, ''The Dugout,'' depicting a glum collection of Chicago Cubs during their worst season since 1925, turned out to be of special interest to Frank W. McNulty, a 52-year-old New York business executive.

title: REAL WAR ON DRUGS
description: To the Editor:

title: Gregory Kaster Wed To Kate Wittenstein
description: Kate Elizabeth Wittenstein, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Wittenstein of Brooklyn Heights, was married yesterday to Gregory Lawrence Kaster, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore Kaster of Park Forest, Ill. The ceremony was performed at the home of the bride's parents by Justice Joseph Dowd of the New York State Supreme Court.

title: West German Arrested In Export Violation
description: Department of Commerce agents today arrested a West German businessman in Los Angeles and charged him with violating United States national security export controls, a Commerce Department spokesman said.

title: AT CEREMONY IN BRONX, FORDHAM INSTALLS ITS 31ST PRESIDENT
description: Thirty-six years after he left the streets and playgrounds where he grew up in the Bronx, the Rev. Joseph A. O' Hare was installed yesterday as the 31st president of Fordham University.

title: Steven H. F. Williams Weds Louise G. Moore
description: Louise Gale Moore, a daughter of Mrs. Peter Gale Moore of Larchmont, N.Y., and the late Mr. Moore, was married yesterday to Steven H. F. Williams, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John H. Williams of Larchmont. The Rev. Edmund Parrakow, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. Michael Drake, a Presbyterian minister, at SS.

title: Walesa at Outdoor Mass For Poland's Workers
description: Lech Walesa joined more than a dozen other senior figures of the outlawed Solidarity labor movement today at an outdoor mass here for Polish workers.

title: More Losses at Renault
description: State- owned Regie Nationale des Usines Renault probably faces major layoffs and greater losses in 1984 than a year ago, Renault's president, Bernard Hanon, said in an interview with a company publication.

title: NEW YORK STATE GETS 2 PLANS FOR FASTER HELP IN DISASTERS
description: New York State officials have made two proposals to sharpen emergency responses to such disasters as tornadoes, blizzards, hurricanes, toxic spills and radiological contamination.

title: Beth Dallis the Bride Of Timothy Manners
description: Beth Dalis and Timothy George Manners were married yesterday at the Sands Point, L.I., home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Mandell Dalis.

title: TAX SHELTER CRACKDOWN BEGINS TO HAVE AN EFFECT
description: New tax law provisions intended to identify abusive tax shelters and punish violators more severely are bolstering efforts by the Internal Revenue Service and the Justice Department to curb unwarranted deductions.

title: SCULPTURE COMMEMORATES HOLOCAUST VICTIMS
description: The people are hunched and are walking aimlessly to a destination they do not want to reach. Large hands grip tightly the tiny fingers of children they will never touch again.

title: PADRE-CUB DEBUT FEATURES NEW CASTS
description: The Chicago Cubs and San Diego Padres, stocked with imports, exiles and travelers, will make twin debuts in playoff baseball tomorrow when they open their series for the National League pennant in Wrigley Field.

title: CURRENT INTEREST RATES
description: Tax-Exempt Bonds*10.15

title: Reagan Signs Wilderness Bills
description: President Reagan has signed bills designating millions of acres of land as wilderness area, ending a decade-long struggle in Congress and making California second only to Alaska in amount of wilderness.

title: Honduras and the U.S. Hold Joint Maneuvers
description: Honduran troops and United States Special Forces began a series of counterinsurgency exercises here today, Honduran Army sources said.

title: Norstar Acquires Bank
description: Shareholders of the Bank of Maine Corporation have approved the $13.7 million acquisition of Bank of Maine by the Albany-based Norstar Bancorp, Norstar announced Saturday. Norstar, a $7.2 billion bank holding company, will acquire all 250,000 outstanding shares of Bank of Maine common stock for either $55 a share or for debentures with a principal amount of $55, Norstar said. Bank of Maine has nine offices and assets of $94.2 million as of June 30.

title: PRISON CROWDING INSPIRES NEW CONSTRUCTION IDEAS
description: Down the long driveway past the cornfields at the Leesburg prison farm in southern New Jersey stands the prototype of an instant prison.

title: MIMIEUX PRODUCES A MOVIE FOR TV
description: In recent years a number of actresses who found their movie roles dwindling have revitalized their careers on television. Joan Collins is probably the prime example of a faded movie queen turned television superstar, but many other actresses, such as Lee Remick and Ann-Margret, have also found expanded opportunities on the small screen.

title: Sikhs Celebrate Golden Temple's Return
description: Thousands of Sikhs today celebrated the end of a 115-day army occupation of the Golden Temple, their holiest shrine, as religious leaders called for a new era of peace in India's state of Punjab.

title: Brian Dean Is Married To Melanie Kay Foster
description: Melanie Kay Foster, a corporate banking representative for the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company, and Brian Christopher Dean, an assistant treasurer of the Chase Manhattan Bank, were married yesterday. The Rev. Valentine de Souza performed the ceremony in the Roman Catholic Church of the Resurrection in Rye, N.Y.

title: Josephine Bayne Weds David Boorstin
description: Josephine Ashley Bayne, a daughter of Edward A. Bayne of Rome and New Haven, Conn., and the late Sophia Morris Koelle, was married yesterday to David West Boorstin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel J. Boorstin of Washington. Rabbi Ronald B. Sobel performed the ceremony in his study at Temple Emanu-El in New York.

title: STAGE: AT PERRY STREET, 'ENTER A FREE MAN'
description: It doesn't take long to sense that

title: FILM LOOKS AT THE '39 WORLD'S FAIR
description: Why would anyone spend nearly five years making a film that is unlikely to bring either cold cash or glory?

title: U.S. OFFICIALS REFUSING TO TESTIFY ON RULES FOR CARE OF NEEDY
description: Federal officials have declined to appear at a Senate hearing Monday to defend themselves against charges that they have not enforced a law forbidding nursing homes to discriminate on the basis of ability to pay.

title: HOPES FADING IN GROVES BEYOND CANKER'S REACH
description: When Joe and Jewel Symmes put a down payment on a 15-acre orange grove here five years ago, they felt as though they were putting a down payment on life.

title: Oudone Sananikone, 63, Dies; Former Defense Chief in Laos
description: Oudone Sananikone, a former director general of the Laotian Defense Ministry who settled in the United States in 1975 after the Communist takeover of his country, died Thursday after a brief illness, his family said today. He was 63 years old.

title: Edging Out the Schooners In the Mayor's Cup Race
description: ''It's a wonderful breeze,'' Capt. Peg

title: SIX SOUTH AFRICAN FUGITIVES ASK ABROAD FOR 'SANCTUARY'
description: Six political fugitives who have taken refuge in the British Consulate in Durban appealed over the weekend to the United States and other Western governments to offer them sanctuary.

title: Restaurant Introduces Eating and Cooking Verite
description: Cooks cooking. Eaters eating.

title: Futures/Options; How to Help Industry Image
description: BEFORE the commodity industry introduced financial and stock index futures and options a few years ago, its members seemed inured to their public image as devil-may-care gamblers. While most were vexed by that image, it was generally attributed to the then esoteric nature of their trade. Not any more.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: American Fletcher National Bank, Indianapolis, has elected E. Lowell Dinius president of its American Fletcher Leasing Corp. subsidiary.

title: OPERA: FIRST 'RIGOLETTO' OF MET SEASON
description: Big-league opera casting takes place, apparently, in two stages: one three to five years before the event; the other weeks, days or minutes before the curtain goes up. The Metropolitan Opera scheduled four works for its opening week, and announced the leading tenors as follows: Placido Domingo, Neil Shicoff, Nicolai Gedda, Dano Raffanti.

title: Market Place; Stocks Suited to Rate Trend
description: THE stock market scored slight

title: POP: BANGLES AT THE RITZ
description: The Bangles, an all-female rock quartet from Los Angeles, belong to the Southern California musical genre that has been called the ''paisley underground.'' The term refers to a contemporary rock style colored with 60's ''psychedelic'' touches.

title: PRAYER, CIRCA 1926
description: Has anyone ever noticed that this rise of Sunday schools in the United States has been exactly coincident with a general decay in piety? How are we to account for this backsliding? Is it due to the influence of Darwin and his accursed hypothesis of evolution? Is the blame to be put upon Nietzsche, the Kaiser, or the Bolsheviks? Is it a product of jazz, or golf, or the automobile, or the radio, or the immoral movies that come out This is excerpted from ''The Last Refuge of a Soundrel,'' an essay on patriotism and religion, in ''The Best in the World: A Selection of News and Feature Stories from 1921 to 1928,'' edited by John K. Hutchens and George Oppenheimer. of Hollywood the damned, or smoking by women, or Prohibition, or Sunday baseball, or yellow journalism? All these agents and agencies of the devil have been blamed, and sometimes by eminent experts in the moral sciences. But I choose to believe that the true villain is the Sunday school. Millions of Americans, sent into it in youth unwillingly, have come out of it in their teens full of rebellion. I was also instructed in morals and theology, and here I soon ran aground. The teachers told off to belabor me were all manifestly idiots, even to the eyes of a boy of ten. The net result of this instruction was that, at the age of twelve, I was a violent atheist, and so were most of the other boys.

title: HUSSEIN DEFENDS MOVE TO RESTORE LINKS WITH CAIRO
description: King Hussein of Jordan tonight defended his decision to restore full diplomatic relations with Egypt, and challenged Syria, Libya and other critics of his action to come to a summit meeting to debate this and other issues that have divided the Arabs.

title: ;  Atop the Ivy
description: The ''help wanted'' advertisement that appeared last spring in The N.C.A.A. News and The Chronicle of Higher Education peaked Jeffrey Orleans's interest. But he thought no more about it until a friend telephoned to tell him he would have a spectacular time doing that job and he ought to apply for it. ''And the more I thought about it,'' he said, ''the more I thought she was right.''

title: ASHE PLAYS DIFFICULT CUP ROLE
description: Neale Fraser, the Australian Davis Cup captain, kneeled at Pat Cash's feet during each changeover, talking rapidly, gesturing wildly, and forcing his young charge to tune out the recorded rock music on the Memorial Coliseum loudspeaker and heed advice on how to beat John McEnroe.

title: DISNEY NAMES MOVIE AND TV HEAD
description: Just one week after being appointed chairman and chief executive of Walt Disney Productions, Michael D. Eisner moved to strengthen that beleaguered company's motion picture division. Mr. Eisner and Frank G. Wells, Disney's president and chief operating officer, announced today that they had named Jeffrey Katzenberg as Disney's president of motion pictures and television.

title: A GOOD JUNE FOR WEDDINGS
description: Americans married in June at the highest rate in six years, new Government statistics indicate.

title: Dolphins 36 Cardinals 28
description: Dan Marino threw for 424 yards and three touchdowns to lead Miami.

title: Kovics & Ciociola Gets Sanrio Toys of Japan
description: The Sanrio Company of Japan, a maker of toys and other fun things, has assigned its United States advertising business to Kovics & Ciociola.

title: Concert With a Cause
description: The Kennedy Center concert tonight for the benefit of the Disability Rights Education and Defense Fund is bringing together a number of public figures with a personal stake in the cause.

title: STOCKS UP ABROAD DESPITE STRONG DOLLAR
description: After a desultory second quarter, stock prices on major foreign exchanges rebounded in the last three months, once again following the lead provided by American equities.

title: Videotaping the Romance Of Julio Iglesias
description: A Vuitton steamer trunk sat by the

title: FOR METS, SEASON OF SHOCK AND SUCCESS
description: It was a year that began with

title: NEW RULES FOR LETTERS OF CREDIT
description: New rules take effect today intended to streamline the process of writing commercial letters of credit, the principal means of payment in international trade.

title: ISRAELIS BAR BEIRUT-BASED PRESS FROM SOUTH
description: The Israeli military authorities have established a new policy of refusing to allow Beirut-based Western correspondents to enter occupied southern Lebanon.

title: Alicia Marie Costello Married to E. J. Stein
description: Alicia Marie Costello, a daughter of Capt. and Mrs. Harry J. Costello of Convent Station, N.J., was married yesterday to Elliott Jonathan Stein, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Reuben Hartenstein of Dumont, N.J. The ceremony was performed at Christ the King Roman Catholic Church in New Vernon, N.J., by the Rev. Patrick Rice.

title: No Headline
description: MONDAY, OCTOBER 1, 1984 International Preliminary talks with Moscow on arms control and other issues are expected to begin within a few weeks as a result of conversations with Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko, Reagan Administration officials said. But they said they doubted actual negotiations would resume before the end of this year or early next year. (Page A1, Column 6.) Jordan's renewal of ties with Egypt was defended by King Hussein. He challenged Syria, Libya and other critics of his decision to restore full diplomatic relations to come to a summit meeting to debate this and other issues that have divided Arab ranks. Syria turned down the King's invitation. (A1:2.)

title: Plaza Shows Preview Of Personal Investor
description: Plaza Communications of Newport Beach, Calif., already the publisher of Registered Representative magazine, has just printed a preview issue of Personal Investor, which is scheduled to begin regular monthly publication in March.

title: Steady Fed Is Seen for Now
description: While credit market participants disagree about the fundamental direction of interest rates, there is widespread agreement that the Federal Reserve is unlikely to make any major changes in monetary policy at Tuesday's meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee.

title: U.S.O.C. PLUNGES INTO THE BIG-TIME BUSINESS WORLD
description: Last November, Col. F. Don Miller announced that he planned to retire as executive director of the United States Olympic Committee after the 1981-84 quadrennium, so that he could pursue ventures in private business.

title: LESSON FROM THE BEST
description: any hunter who comes home from a disappointing day in the field carrying a brace of empty shotgun-shell boxes knows hitting birds on the wing isn't easy. Although it is a skill that can be taught, expert instruction in wing shooting is hard to come by in this country.

title: HURT IN THE LOCKER ROOM
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.

title: G.S.A. Purchase Is Criticized
description: The General Services Administration is under fire for purchasing titanium for the strategic stockpile from producers in Japan and Britain at unfairly low prices - deemed by the Commerce Department in preliminary findings to be well below the cost of production.

title: WITT PITCHES PERFECT GAME
description: Mike Witt, whose brief major league career has been dotted with many imperfections despite his talent, today became only the 13th pitcher in major league history to toss a perfect game when he pitched the California Angels to a 1-0 season-ending victory over the Texas Rangers.

title: 3 HOLDUP MEN FATALLY SHOOT QUEENS WOMAN IN PARKED CAR
description: An 18-year-old woman was shot to death by three holdup men early yesterday as she sat in a friend's parked car in Rosedale, Queens, the police said.

title: G.O.P. TV Commercial Will 'Beef' About Taxes By United Press International
description: The Republican National Committee this week will begin a $2.9 million television advertising campaign criticizing Walter F. Mondale's promise to raise taxes if elected President. The two- week campaign will run in 110 cities across the nation, reaching about 75 percent of the country and most of the House districts the Republicans have targeted for victory.

title: SPORTS NEWS BRIEFS ; ;  Strange Is Victor By Shot in LaJet
description: Curtis Strange, never really threatened, shot a 1-under-par 71 for a 2-stroke victory today in the LaJet Golf Classic today.

title: PESSIMISM MARKS GATHERING OF BLACK LAWMAKERS
description: Pessimism bordering on desperation, but lightened by moments of political celebration, marked the four-day meeting of the 14th Annual Congressional Black Caucus Legislative Weekend that ended today.

title: A Month of Disobedience
description: The Community for Creative

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: PINTER PATTER Harold Pinter has written more than 30 plays, including ''The Birthday Party,'' ''The Caretaker,'' ''The Hothouse,'' ''The Homecoming'' and ''Betrayal.'' His films include ''The Pumpkin Eater,'' ''The Last Tycoon'' and ''The French Lieutenant's Woman.'' He has also directed plays and is associate director of the National Theater in London.

title: Debt Issues
description: Albuquerque Federal Savings and Loan Association, a unit of Ameriwest Financial Corp., said it had filed a shelf registration for the sale of up to $100 million in collateralized mortgage obligations through underwriters led by Raucher Pierce Refnes.

title: 2 TEEN-AGERS SEIZED IN AIR-GUN SHOOTING ON UPPER WEST SIDE
description: Two Bronx teen-agers were arrested yesterday and charged with shooting a pedestrian with an air pistol Thursday night at 97th Street and West End Avenue.

title: SPORTS NEWS BRIEFS ; ;  Athletes' Hospital Opens in Georgia
description: The nation's first hospital devoted to the treatment of athletic injuries opens Monday in this west Georgia city where, 35 years ago, Dr. Jack Hughston began his small orthopedics practice.

title: Addendum
description: * Sports Illustrated magazine increasing its circulation rate base 2.9 percent and its advertising rates 8.9 percent with the Jan. 7 issue.

title: MONDAY SPORTS Football
description: Steelers vs. Cincinnati Bengals , at Pittsburgh. The Bengals did not win a game in September.

title: ISRAEL WELCOMES JORDAN'S MOVE ON TIES TO EGYPT
description: Israel said today that it welcomed the resumption of diplomatic relations between Jordan and Egypt as a potential contribution to peace in the Middle East.

title: AMERICAN LEAGUE

title: YARD PREVENTS NAVY FROM MOVING A SHIP IN CONTRACT DISPUTE
description: Blocked by locked gates and dockside equipment, the Navy today postponed plans to repossess a frigate from the Boston Shipyard Corporation, whose $8.5 million contract to overhaul the ship was canceled for what the Navy called substandard work.

title: MOROCCO, WHERE KING IS KING AND NEW WAYS NEW
description: It seemed a medieval scene in a fairy-tale kingdom. Princess Lalla Meriem, the daughter of King Hassan II, was marrying, and subjects from all around the Kingdom of Morocco came to pay tribute.

title: U.S. Export Violation Is Charged
description: A West German businessman was arrested at Los Angeles International Airport today for allegedly attempting to export a United States-manufactured electronic circuit board system without a license, the Commerce Department said.

title: POLICE RAIDS IN ITALY SEIZE DOZENS AFTER A MAFIA CHIEF'S REVALATIONS
description: The police rounded up dozens of organized crime suspects over the weekend in what officials described as one of the most sweeping anti-Mafia operations ever conducted in Italy.

title: NATO GIVES HIGH PRIORITY TO WAR IN AIR
description: With NATO holding major exercises in this country, alliance commanders seem reasonably confident that their forces have the capacity to engage and halt an initial conventional attack on Western Europe. The immediate problem, they suggest, would be holding off the subsequent waves of attackers. The commanders, who spoke in separate interviews in mid- September, said that if there should be a Soviet attack on Western Europe, the second wave of attacking divisions would be supported by surface-to-surface missiles and would have ample air support from bases in East Germany and Poland.

title: SPORTS NEWS BRIEFS ; ;  Ballesteros Takes Match-Play Title
description: Seve Ballesteros curled in a nine-foot putt on the 35th hole today and scored a narrow 2-and- 1 victory over Bernhard Langer to win the $183,000 Suntory World Match Play golf championship.

title: A Heavy Schedule of Convertibles
description: A deluge of convertible bond offerings this week is partly the result, investment bankers said, of a record September volume of debt financings by major corporations in the Eurobond market. The stronger stock market and the high level of interest rates also encouraged the offerings of the securities, which are convertible into stock.

title: BOGGS IS RE-ELECTED TO HOUSE IN LOUISIANA VOTING
description: There was no jazz band, no crawfish and no oyster bar, but without question it was a New Orleans party and without question it was a Boggs family party.

title: Hart Bids Reagan Take Some Blame in Bombing
description: Senator Gary Hart, the Colorado Democrat who unsuccessfully challenged Walter F. Mondale for the Democratic Presidential nomination, today called on President Reagan to take some blame for the recent attacks on United States installations in Lebanon.

title: SYRACUSE CELEBRATES AND LOOKS AHEAD
description: A happy celebration's debris was scattered along Marshall Street from the Varsity eatery at the corner of South Crouse Avenue to Archie's pizza shop at the corner of University Avenue. Syracuse students and faculty waded through the litter from Saturday night's happiness as they went to Siegel's stationery store for the Sunday newspapers and the big headlines and long stories about the cause of the celebration: Syracuse's shocking 17-9 upset of Nebraska, the No. 1-ranked team, in the Carrier Dome.

title: Let Them Eat Charity In line with his taste for smaller government, President Reagan has urged the substitution of private charity for government social spending, on the assumption that private efforts can substitute for public subsidies. But most private charities actually enjoy an interdependent partnership with government that has flourished for a century. Reduced government spending therefore leaves many of their clients in the lurch. That disturbing point is well made in a new study from the Urban Institute, a Washington-based research group.
description: About two-thirds of all the Federal money spent on domestic social programs goes to third parties, mainly community-based nonprofit organizations that deliver the services. Such payments from Washington, supplemented by state and local funds, constitute the largest share - 38 percent - of the resources of nonprofit charities.

title: FLOOD OF HEALTH KITS WIDENS HOME TESTS FOR EARLY SYMPTOMS
description: Not too many years ago, pretty much the only thing a person could check about his health without visiting his doctor was his temperature or his pulse.

title: Washington Watch; Farm Exports Threatened
description: WASHINGTON

title: PURCHASERS CITE FALLOFF IN ORDERS
description: A survey of purchasing managers shows that new orders for materials and services declined in September for the first time since December 1982. The monthly survey, released yesterday by the National Association of Purchasing Management, also showed that expansion in employment had halted.

title: THE CALDENDAR
description: Monday

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Now there is somehow this notion that in response to this, somebody's head has to roll.

title: A Career Highlight For Cubs Executive
description: Andrew J. McKenna, chairman of the Chicago Cubs, is presiding over more than just a business success these days. He is at the head of a community catharsis.

title: CONGRESS IS EXPECTED TO SLASH FUNDS FOR YORK GUN
description: The Pentagon's decision to request that funds be slashed for the Army's Sergeant York antiaircraft gun will meet little opposition on Capitol Hill, Congressional sources in both political parties said yesterday.

title: Oil Venture Set in Sudan
description: The Sudanese Government and a company owned by the Saudi billionaire Adnan Khashoggi announced plans today for a joint venture to explore and develop oil in the Sudan.

title: EGYPTIAN COURT SENTENCES 107 MOSLEM MILITANTS IN A 1981 REVOLT
description: A judge sentenced 107 Moslem extremists to prison today for trying to overthrow the Government in the aftermath of the 1981 assassination of President Anwar el- Sadat. He acquitted 174 others.

title: DUBLIN SAYS THE U.S. HELPED IN SEIZURE OF ARMS SHIPMENT
description: Irish security sources asserted today that the seizure of an arms-laden trawler over the weekend resulted from a two-year undercover operation by security agents on both sides of the Atlantic that included both the Central Intelligence Agency and the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ; Libbey-Owens-Ford Names a President
description: Darryl F. Allen has been elected president and chief operating officer of the Libbey-Owens-Ford Company, a major glass maker for the auto industry.

title: RELIEF SHIPS FROM NORTH DOCK IN INCHON
description: Four North Korean cargo ships loaded with relief supplies sailed into this port today, an unprecedented event that went unnoticed by virtually everyone who lives here.

title: BRONCOS SET BACK RAIDERS
description: A reserve running back, Gerald Willhite, darted 4 yards for a third-quarter touchdown and Rich Karlis kicked three field goals, powering the Denver Broncos to a 16-13 upset over the previously unbeaten Los Angeles Raiders today.

title: CAMBODIAN INSURGENTS IN CLASH
description: Vietnamese troops and the Pol Pot guerrilla group traded artillery and mortar fire in Cambodia for at least four hours today in the heaviest fighting of the rainy season, Thai military sources and guerrilla spokesmen said.

title: Donna Zaccaro Is Booed For Speech at Party
description: Geraldine A. Ferraro's 22-year-old daughter, Donna Zaccaro, was heckled and booed when she criticized President Reagan's policies at a fund-raising party to welcome back the ''Doonesbury'' comic strip, an organizer said today.

title: People
description: * John P. Hayes Jr. named vice president and general manager of radio station WNBC.

title: The Governor's Provincial Promise Governor Cuomo's decision to close the prison at Pilgrim State Hospital on Long Island won't force any immediate crisis in the state correctional system. Prison expansion plans are on schedule with more than enough new cells opening elsewhere to accommodate the 500 prisoners there. But it's still a troubling decision. So clear a victory for the prison's opponents can only complicate future efforts to find sites for other unpopular but necessary facilities.
description: It was Governor Carey who decided to house prisoners in empty buildings of the Long Island psychiatric hospital. Protesting neighbors organized an articulate, determined pressure group.

title: DANCE: A NEW CAST FOR HARLEM TROUPE'S 'GISELLE'
description: Frederic Franklin's staging of ''Giselle'' for Dance Theater of Harlem is a noteworthy example of how a balletic classic may be given an untraditional setting without destroying its traditional choreography or dramatic values.

title: Panel Backs Broker Funds
description: Federal regulators have overstated the threats posed to banks that grow rapidly through the use of deposits placed by brokers, the commerce subcommittee of the House Committee on Government Operations said today.

title: WITT PITCHES PERFECT GAME
description: The thing Don Mattingly wanted to do most yesterday, other than get a bunch of hits, was relax. ''When I woke up this morning,'' he related, ''my wife gave me a big smile and said 'I love you.' I couldn't ask for more than that.''

title: U.S. AIDES EXPECT TALKS WITH SOVIET IN SEVERAL WEEKS
description: Senior Reagan Administration officials said today that as a result of conversations with the Soviet Foreign Minister, Andrei A. Gromyko, they expected preliminary talks to begin within a few weeks on arms control and other issues.

title: OF CHECKS, A BRIDGE AND RADIO
description: At first, it sounded like an old joke: The checks were in the mail. This time, they were - thousands of buff-colored tax refund checks from the Ohio State Treasurer's office. But so were 400,000 buff-colored facsimiles mailed by Republicans in key state Senate districts.

title: Colts 31, Bills 17
description: Randy McMillan gained 114 yards and scored two second-half touchdowns to lead Indianapolis and hand Buffalo its fifth straight loss.

title: Most Incumbents Won In the Primary Contests
description: The power of incumbency proved itself a formidable advantage in the primary season, with no incumbent governors or senators losing primary races and just three members of the House of Representatives falling to challengers.

title: 3D-QUARTER STOCK SCOREBOARD
description: Stocks of companies targeted for acquisition, including one whose management sought to take it private, were prominent among the best-performing stocks in a resurgent third quarter on the nation's three major stock markets.

title: DANCE: 3 WORKS BY JAPANESE SOLOIST
description: The three solos performed by the experimental Japanese dancer Junko Kikuchi at the Asia Society Saturday night were as meticulously detailed and spare as the setting and lighting designed for them.

title: SHULTZ ANGERED IN INTERVIEW ON BEIRUT ATTACK
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz, his voice rising in anger, said today that if ''somebody's head has to roll'' because of the Sept. 20 bombing of the United States Embassy in Beirut, ''I'm willing to have it be my head anytime anyone wants.''

title: Mild Growth Is Forecast
description: World economic growth will slow next year, but only modestly, provided the dollar weakens, the London Business School said in a report today.

title: Topics ; Fiscal Fiction and Fact
description: Empty Vote

title: WORK SET ON LAST TRADE CENTER UNIT
description: Ground is to be broken tomorrow for a 47-story office building that will be the seventh and last of the World Trade Center's buildings.

title: AlexanderJ.Allen,68;Headed Urban League
description: Alexander J. Allen, a former executive director of the Urban League of Greater New York, died of cancer at his home in Jamaica, Queens, on Friday. He was 68 years old.

title: REDSKINS STYMIE EAGLES, 20-0
description: John Riggins rushed for 104 yards and a touchdown and Joe Theismann ran for 56 yards and threw a 51-yard touchdown pass to Art Monk to lead the Washington Redskins to a 20-0 victory over the Philadelphia Eagles today.

title: Husband of a Murder Victim Admitted to Mental Hospital
description: A New Jersey man whose wife was slain at a Garden State Parkway rest stop on Sept. 6 has been admitted to a psychiatric hospital, his attorney said.

title: LAPSES BY REAGAN PLEASE DEMOCRATS
description: The unexpected sight of President Reagan struggling with political problems created by his impromptu remarks on foreign policy has made some Democratic leaders hope Walter F. Mondale can claw his way back into contention in the Presidential race.

title: REAGAN'S RISKY CUBAN POLICY
description: Twenty-two years ago this month, John F. Kennedy and Nikita S. Khrushchev reached an understanding that ended the Cuban missile crisis, and the world, which had stood at the brink of war, heaved a sigh of relief. Since then, every American President has taken that understanding as a deadly serious matter. Now, however, the Reagan Administration seems intent on questioning its validity.

title: Personnel Changes At World Tennis
description: Thomas Brennan, Eastern sales manager of CBS Magazines' World Tennis magazine, has been named ad director, replacing Tod Boersma, who is leaving the company. Also departing is David Lott, marketing director, who will not be replaced.

title: NATIONAL LEAGUE
description: EASTERN DIVISION WLPct. GB *Chicago9665.596- Mets9072.556*6 1/2St. Louis847 8.51912 1/2Philadelphia8181.50015 1/2Montreal7883.48418 Pittsburgh7587.46321 1/2

title: MONDALE STEPS UP ATTACK ON REAGAN
description: Walter F. Mondale today criticized President Reagan's Soviet initiative as a failure that was ''a basis for apprehension'' should Mr. Reagan be re-elected.

title: TORRE MAY BE OUT
description: Paul Owens resigned as manager of the Philadelphia Phillies on the last day of the regular season yesterday, and Joe Torre of the Atlanta Braves said that his dismissal was imminent. The Phillies ended with nine consecutive losses.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Oct. 1, 1984: MONDAY Carolina FreightJewel CosCentl Vt Pub ServNevada PowerGordon JewelryXerox Corp TUESDAY MGM/UA EntertainSouthwest Gas WEDNESDAY Lukens IncMurphy OilMGM Grand HotelsRite Aid THURSDAY Clevepak CorpSearle (G D) & CoFederal-MogulSun CoMercantile StoresSupermarkets Genl FRIDAY Aluminum Co AmerTravelers CorpCarter Hawley HaleUniversal Foods

title: THE BOSS IS BACK
description: ''This is not announcement day,'' George Steinbrenner said yesterday, but it was bargain day, with drama all over Yankee Stadium on the last day of the season.

title: PUGET SOUND CITIES ORDERED TO CLEAN UP SEWAGE
description: Protests have swept this area because pollution from urban sewers is threatening Puget Sound.

title: ; VIETNAM VETERANS' WORDS ARE CREATING A MEMORIAL
description: If you are able, save for them a place inside of you . . . In Vietnam, on New Year's Day 1970, Maj. Michael Davis O'Donnell began a poem with those words. Three months later, the 24-year-old helicopter pilot was reported missing in action.

title: THE NEW HITCHHIKING: WHITE COLLARS AND TRUST
description: Early each weekday morning, cries of ''Pentagon,'' ''Capitol Hill'' and ''Federal Triangle'' ring out from the parking lot of a restaurant in Springfield, Va., about 20 miles from the capital.

title: BRIDGE ; THE WINNERS ARE CROWNED IN METROPOLITAN TOURNAMENT
description: Sectional tournaments in New York City used to be three-day affairs that began on Friday. The tendency now is toward slimmed-down, two-day tournaments. For example, the time- honored Metropolitan Tournament began Saturday at the Prince George Hotel, 14 East 28th Street, following a charity event held in clubs Friday night.

title: SALOMON HEADS UNDERWRITING LIST
description: In the race to bring stock and debt issues to market, Salomon Brothers Inc. continued its domination in the third quarter. It acted as lead underwriter for 51 offerings of securities totaling $6.56 billion.

title: Pandas Extend Coast Visit
description: Two pandas lent to the Los Angeles Zoo by China for the summer Olympics will stay two weeks past their scheduled return date of Oct. 15 because of the heavy turnout of spectators, zoo officials say.

title: ;  St. John's Victor
description: Pat Fogarty of St. John's shot rounds of 74, 74 today and won medalist honors for the third straight year in the Big East Conference golf championships at the Concord Hotel. The Redmen captured the team title for the fourth straight year with a two- day score of 623, followed by Connecticut with 642.

title: A SETBACK FOR COALITION AGAINST KOCH
description: For more than a year, the fragile coalition that was projecting Basil A. Paterson as its mayoral candidate had two goals: to defeat Mayor Koch and at the same time to elect New York City's first black mayor. Mr. Paterson's sudden decision last week not to challenge Mr. Koch has jolted political leaders who were motivated primarily by the second goal. But with the Democratic mayoral primary nearly a year away, some politicians suggest that it is premature to assess the impact of Mr. Paterson's decision on the first goal.

title: Surplus of Words at I.M.F.
description: More than 70 often repetitious speeches were given by finance ministers and central bank governors last week at the 39th joint annual meeting of the World Bank and International Monetary Fund.

title: PAYTON GAINS 155, BUT COWBOYS WIN
description: Walter Payton, the Chicago Bears' running back, caught up with Jim Brown in one race today. Payton ran for more than 100 yards in a game for the 58th time in his career, the same number of times Brown did it.

title: Yankees Records FINAL BATTING
;  Kallur's Log House
description: Mention a shipment of new lumber in a hockey dressing room and players will expect to see a fresh batch of sticks. Not Anders Kallur.

title: A PLUM FOR GROMYKO?
description: WASHINGTON We have been permitting the Democratic candidates to sell us a wholly false idea: that the ''harsh rhetoric'' of Ronald Reagan caused the frigidity between the superpowers.

title: Mine Found in Red Sea Is Called Soviet-Made
description: A mine found by British divers in the Red Sea is a new, advanced device made by the Soviet Union, the Egyptian armed forces said today.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: MONDAY, OCTOBER 1, 1984

title: The Fox and the Press
description: Washington tends to be sensitive about preserving its Government buildings, which are deemed history, and profligate in destroying its business buildings, which, after all, represent only tawdry commerce. But the National Press Building, in the course of an exhaustive renovation now nearing completion, is retaining an old architectural ornament amid its modern office space to commemorate a downtown monument, the Fox Theater.

title: One Dies When Team's Bus Collides With 2 Cars on I-84
description: One person died and five others were hospitalized tonight when a bus carrying about 40 lacrosse players back to Lafayette College in Pennsylvania after a match at West Point collided with two cars on Interstate 84 and flipped on its side.

title: 'CIVILIZATION AND THE JEWS' SERIES ON CHANNEL 13
description: Who are the Jews? Where did they come from? They are not a race, says Abba Eban, the host and narrator of ''Heritage: Civilization and the Jews,'' they are ''a people,'' sustained and renewed by 3,000 years of tradition. ''Heritage,'' a nine-hour series, beginning on Channel 13 at 9 tonight, explores the meaning of the tradition.

title: AFTER STRONG FINISH, YANKS LOOK TO '85
description: The Yankees finished their 1984 schedule yesterday with the best record in the major leagues since the All-Star Game break. Their problem was that the major leagues did not play a split season this year.

title: Mormon Center Damaged
description: A 23-year-old man who ''apparently had some hostilities'' toward the Mormon Church slashed furniture and threw trash cans through windows at a church visitors' center, the police said. Bill Herron was being held in jail pending further investigation.

title: BUSH SAYS FORD MADE 'SENSE' ON BEIRUT BLAST
description: Vice President Bush said today that ''in the final analysis'' it made ''some sense'' for President Reagan to accept responsibility in the terrorist bombing of the United States Embassy in Lebanon 10 days ago.

title: RELATIONSHIPS ; WHEN PETS GET OLD AND SICK
description: Rex has been the family mutt all his life. He's 15 years old now, and he doesn't see or hear too well and is incontinent on occasion. But looking at him through the family's eyes these days, you would think he was two different dogs.

title: QUESTION BOX
description: QUESTION: Did Representative Jack Kemp ever play for the Giants? How good a quarterback was he as a pro?

title: LURING PUPILS TO PUBLIC SCHOOLS
description: SOME parents who chose to send their children to Public School 6 on the Upper East Side of Manhattan instead of to one of the neighborhood's many private and parochial schools were having second thoughts last week.

title: B. & W. Tobacco Accounts to D.D.B.
description: Doyle Dane Bernbach International has received four different cigarette assignments from the Brown & Williamson Tobacco Company, nicely replacing the one small brand moved out a week ago by Philip Morris. The assignment is effective Dec. 31.

title: 2,000 Coal Miners Strike Independent Companies
description: More than 2,000 miners today struck two independent coal companies that refused to sign a new contract with the United Mine Workers, but 110,000 others went to work under the first strike-free national settlement in 20 years.

title: Concerts Plus Program Set for Merkin Hall
description: The third season of Concerts Plus, a program of music and commentary, begins on Oct. 25 with a performance of works by Liszt and Mozart at Merkin Concert Hall, 129 West 67th Street.

title: CUMO RESOURCES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
REAGANOMICS'S LURE FOR THE YUPPIES
description: Republican strategists have pinned great hopes on us men and women under 30 years old. They dream that we will make the Grand Old Party the nation's majority party once again - and they may well be right.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an error by a research group, the Retirement Migration Project, an article on the Style page April 2 about the mobility patterns of the elderly was incorrect. There has been no significant reversal in the migration of those over 60 to small towns and rural regions. An article explaining the error appears on page C12.

title: BUSH GIVES RECIPE FOR SUCCESS IN JOB
description: After four years in the job that Vice President Bush recalled was once described by a predecessor as ''not worth a bucket of warm spit,'' he laid out his terms today for success in the role in the present age.

title: 5 Schools Named Alzheimer Centers
description: Five medical schools have been designated Alzheimers' disease research centers and the Government has granted $16.6 million for study of the progressive and incurable brain disease, Secretary of Health Margaret Heckler said today.

title: 'EXTREMIST RIGHT WING' IS CASTIGATED BY FERRARO
description: Geraldine A. Ferraro struck out today at Senator Jesse Helms and an ''extremist right wing'' element that she contends has got ''totally out of line'' in this country.

title: FOLK-ROCK: ARLO GUTHRIE AT THE BEACON
description: ARLO GUTHRIE'S performance at the Beacon Theater on Saturday had a special poignancy. The week before last, Steve Goodman, the author of his biggest hit, ''The City of New Orleans,'' died of complications surrounding a bone marrow transplant.

title: IRANIAN DENOUNCES ISREAL AND EGYPT IN U.N. SPEECH
description: The Foreign Minister of Iran called today for expulsion of Israel from the United Nations and condemned Egypt, ''which hoists the Zionist flag in its capital,'' as the ''shame of the Islamic world.''

title: Du Pont's Controller Adds Top Finance Title
description: John J. Quindlen has been named chief financial officer at E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, the chemical concern announced. The appointment is effective Dec. 1.

title: FrankP.Satenstein,Director Of 'The Honeymooners,' Dies
description: Frank P. Satenstein, a director of such pioneering television shows as ''The Honeymooners,'' ''Your Show of Shows,'' ''I've Got a Secret'' and ''What's My Line,'' died Sunday at his home in Manhattan after a long illness. He was 59 years old.

title: CONCERT: CHAMBER SYMPHONY OPENS SEASON AT Y
description: TWO American pieces with very different personalities helped begin the Y Chamber Symphony's new season at the 92d Street Y Sunday afternoon. Gerard Schwarz conducted them, along with the Schubert Fourth Symphony, and he and his orchestra joined the French trumpet player Maurice Andre in Haydn's E flat Concerto and the Telemann ''Sonate de Concert'' in D.

title: DISMAL DIPLOMACY
description: -tinted bifocals

title: METS RELEASE JERRY MARTINThe Mets announced yesterday that they were releasing
description: -year-old

title: Federal Dogs Wanted
description: The United States Park Police

title: SUN COAST PLASTICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $23,407. c-After an extraordinary credit of $142,651. The latest year loss reflects a retroactive reduction of income of $125,000 and $25,000 in the second and third quarters, respectively, due to reversal of certain licensees previously recorded as income in those quarters.

title: No Planning Cited in Heckling
description: Student heckling of Walter F. Mondale at the University of Southern California last month was spontaneous, not organized, and those involved will, at most, be reprimanded, a university official said today.

title: IMMIGRATION AND THE RANDOMNESS OF ETHNIC MIX
description: Immigration to the United States from Asia was severely restricted for 80 years, starting with the Chinese Exclusion Act in 1882. From 1820 to 1979, only 6 percent of all immigrants came from Asia.

title: Movie Theater Tests TV Technique
description: A Chicago- based movie theater chain has introduced television technology, which could offer more flexibility than films, into the schedule of one of its theaters for a month to test audience acceptance.

title: Baldwin-United Disclosures
description: The Baldwin-United Corporation said in a Securities and Exchange Commission filing that its ''extremely serious'' problems might bar stockholders from recovering any of their investments. The company also disclosed that the S.E.C. was ''likely'' to bring an enforcement action against it and that ''some form of an adverse outcome'' was also likely.

title: MONDALE ASSAILS REAGAN ON ARMS
description: Walter F. Mondale today accused President Reagan of having the capacity only to ''dream'' of arms control initiatives that are ''doomed'' because of his ignorance of the issue and his failure to master Presidential leadership.

title: CHICAGO WATCHES AS 10 SCULPTURES GROW
description: R. SHIPP

title: BONES TELL TALE OF BIZARRE CREATURES IN AUSTRALIA'S PAST
description: ZOOLOGISTS, wildlife experts and other visitors to Australia have long been enchanted by the unique wallabies, bandicoots, kangaroos, emus, wombats, koala bears, platypuses and other strange creatures that live in that land.

title: CHINA DISPLAYS ITS BIG MISSILES ON ANNIVERSARY
description: China showed off its arsenal of modern missiles for the first time today in celebrating 35 years of Communist rule.

title: CAPE TOWN SEEMS TO END BID TO KEEP AREA FREE OF BLACKS
description: South Africa's white Government, reversing a policy spanning almost three decades, has decided to allow black people in the Western Cape region to take out 99-year leases on their homes rather than rent them.

title: Japan Leads Output Gains
description: Industrial production moved ahead faster in Japan than in the United States last spring, but dropped in West Germany and France, the International Monetary Fund reported today.

title: SENATE SUBPOENAS DATA ON SHIPBUILDING INQUIRIES
description: A Senate subcommittee ordered the Justice Department today to turn over documents related to past Federal investigations of allegations of fraud in the Navy shipbuilding industry.

title: IMMUNO NUCLEAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
PHARMAKINETICS LABORATOIES reports earnings for Year to June 30
UMPIRES SET TO STRIKE PLAYOFF GAMES TODAY
description: The attorney for the Major League Baseball Umpires Association said yesterday that a work stoppage by his members ''appears inevitable'' for today's American League and National League playoff games.

title: INTERNATIONAL THOROUGHRED BREEDERS INC reports earnings for Year to June 30

A Lemon the Size of the Pentagon The saga of the Sergeant York air-defense gun illustrates nearly everything that's wrong with the way the Pentagon buys weapons. Though each gun costs $6.3 million, the weapon is so ineffective that even Congress, which can usually swallow any major weapon system, has finally choked.
description: The Sergeant York is a pair of radar-guided guns mounted on a tank chassis. Its purpose is to protect against low-flying aircraft and helicopters.

title: HIGH COURT AGREES TO HEAR APPEALS ON SPEECH RIGHTS
description: The Supreme Court, opening its new term, turned its attention today to the First Amendment's guarantee of freedom of speech.

title: BERTRAND TAVERNIER'S 'SUNDAY IN THE COUNTRY'
description: BERTRAND TAVERNIER'S ''A Sunday in the Country'' is exquisite - purposefully and almost painfully so - from beginning to end. Set at the turn of the century, on a single day at the country home of an elderly French gentleman, it records the particulars of a visit from his children.

title: OPERA: NEIL SHICOFF IN MET 'HOFFMANN'
description: NEIL SHICOFF, whose illness Tuesday night precipitated a parade of tenors at the Metropolitan Opera's ''Tales of Hoffmann,'' returned to the cast Friday obviously in much better health.

title: IMM ENERGY SERVICES & TECHNOLOGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including a tax credit for discontinued operations of $166,349 for the quarter, a loss of $1,774,489 from discontinued operations for the year and a gain of $4,432,205 for the year from the sale of the energy services group. c-Net loss after losses from discontinued operations of $6,549,320 for the quarter and $8,194,394 for the year.

title: 28 ARE ORDERED ARRESTED IN U.S. IN MAFIA INQUIRY
description: United States Justice Department officials, acting under a new extradition treaty with Italy, yesterday ordered the arrest of 28 Americans and Italians wanted in connection with Italy's major crackdown on the Sicilian Mafia.

title: HINCKLEY 'IMPROVEMENT' REPORTED BY DOCTOR
description: John W. Hinckley Jr.'s ''clinical condition and judgment'' have improved enough so that he will be given more mail privileges, but he should still be kept securely locked up and barred from giving interviews, according to officials at St. Elizabeths Hospital here.

title: A PROGRAM ON POLITICS AND CIVICS
description: THE Constitution says nothing about political parties, and not very much about the electoral process. The parties and the process have evolved, adapting to, and shaping, one another. The relationship is examined on the third installment of ''The Constitution: That Delicate Balance,'' a first-rate public television series, on Channel 13 at 10 tonight.

title: HARTMARX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Bridge ; METHOD OF SCORING AFFECTS METROPOLITAN EVENT'S RESULTS
description: The Metropolitan tournament of the Greater New York Bridge Association ended Sunday night at the Prince George Hotel in a Swiss Team victory for a quartet that consisted of Ellie Lewis, Margie Gwozdzinsky, Dorothy Truscott and Paul Kramer, all of New York.

title: A Campaign to Begin For Eyewitness News
description: Posters should be going up all around town today, in subways, at their entrances, on commuter stations and in bus-stop shelters, letting the Big Apple know that with the Eyewitness News Team on Channel 7, ''You get more involved with our news. Because we do.''

title: TV SPORTS ; ; Poignant Film of Olympics
description: The numbers reflect the enormity of Bud Greenspan's

title: EGYPTIANS CANCEL FOOD-PRICE RISE AFTER RIOTS IN AN INDUSTRIAL TOWN
description: The Egyptian Government announced rollbacks in food prices today, a day after rioting swept a mill town near Alexandria.

title: TREATY IMPASSE VIEWED AS OMEN OF NEW U.S.-NICARAGUA TENSIONS
description: The United States and Nicaragua have reached an impasse over a peace plan for Central America and appear headed into a period of increased tension, Reagan Administration and Nicaraguan officials said today.

title: BRAVES DROP TORRE
description: Joe Torre was dismissed today as manager of the Atlanta Braves after a three-year stint in which he steered the team to one divisional championship and two second-place finishes.

title: GRAPHIC SCANNING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
TOWARD A CLEAN AND BUDGETED ENVIRONMENT
description: The report, its cover a pretty, abstract drawing of bright flowers and blue water, is called ''Environmental Progress and Challenges: an E.P.A. Perspective.''

title: ROYAL RESOURCES CORP reports earnings for Year to June 30
FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ; State Power Agency In $350 Million Offering
description: A $350 million financing for the New York Power Authority was tentatively priced with a maximum yield of 10 3/8 percent for bonds due in 2016, according to underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: BROADCASTERS HELPING TO GET OUT THE VOTE
description: To the Editor:

title: 9 on Italian School Bus Die
description: A truck collided with a bus full of children going home from school in northern Italy today, killing nine people, most of them children, and injuring 20, the police said.

title: BANK RESCUE PROTECTS GOLD MARKET
description: The Bank of England today took over the banking subsidiary of Johnson Matthey P.L.C., one of the world's leading gold traders, to prevent disruption of the internationally important London Gold Market.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''This is a historical case, making it possible to rip apart the Sicilian Mafia.

title: Who Is Tying Up Congress Members of Congress who are eager to adjourn and hit the campaign trails find the Civil Rights Act of 1984 in the way. But it's not, really. The true obstructionists are a few senators led by the filibustering Orrin Hatch of Utah.
description: Large majorities of both houses want to make clear that the great civil rights laws of the last two decades apply with full force to institutions receiving Federal funds. The Supreme Court, construing Title IX of the 1972 Education Act, said last February that Grove City College could discriminate against women in one department, say athletics, yet receive Federal aid in another.

title: PATENT MEASURE PROMPTS CRITICISM
description: One week after President Reagan signed a law designed to make low-cost unbranded drugs more widely available, the House this evening passed a patent measure that would, according to opponents, make those drugs virtually unavailable.

title: FARM FRESH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 8
BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE OLD MAN. By Yuri Trifonov. Translated by Jacqueline Edwards and Mitchell Schneider. 267 pages. Simon & Schuster. $16.95.

title: Report on Bank Failures
description: Criminal misconduct by bank officers plays a part in roughly 25 to 50 percent of the banking failures in the country, a Congressional study charged today.

title: 3 L.I. Chains File Price-Fixing Pleas
description: Three supermarket chains have pleaded no contest to Federal criminal charges that they fixed prices by conspiring to stop redeeming discount coupons at double and triple their face value at their Long Island outlets during 1981 and 1982.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ; Sports Executive Leaving ABC Post
description: John T. Lazarus, vice president of sports marketing and sales at the ABC Television Network, has resigned his position, the network said yesterday.

title: Shipyard Removes 2 Cranes Barricading a Navy Frigate
description: A shipyard that had prevented the Navy from repossessing a frigate today removed equipment that had blocked the vessel, just 15 minutes before a contempt hearing was to be held in Federal District Court.

title: Reagan at the Bat
description: President Reagan, asked yesterday what team he planned to root

title: REAGAN'S BURDEN IN THE BEIRUT EMBASSY BOMBING
description: To the Editor:

title: FORGOTTEN TV AUDIENCE: CHILDREN
description: CHILDREN are television's forgotten audience. The networks have virtually abandoned children's programs, except for Saturday mornings' nonstop cartoon shows and occasional afterschool ''specials.'' Public television which continues to offer a few good children's programs suffers from a severe financial drought.

title: REAGAN'S BURDEN IN BEIRUT EMBASSY BOMBING
description: To the Editor:

title: TWO TEEN-AGERS GUILTY IN MURDER OF PRATT STUDENT
description: Two Brooklyn teen-agers were convicted last night of murdering a Pratt Institute student who was found beaten and drowned in the bathtub of her apartment near the campus last November.

title: PLEASE VOTE, BUT NOT SO FAST
description: Every politician makes speeches

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Emerson Electric Co. , St. Louis, announced that William A. Rutledge, vice chairman, had assumed the additional title of chief operating officer.

title: Bassett, VF Set to Merge The VF Corporation said it
description: had reached an agreement in

title: HIGH COURT TAKES NEWSLETTER CASE
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether the Securities and Exchange Commission can prohibit publication of an investment newsletter on the basis of past misconduct by the newsletter's publisher.

title: ACCEPTING THE SANDINISTAS
description: The negotiations taking place between the United States and Nicaragua in Manzanillo, Mexico, have progressed far more rapidly than either side expected. Conceived in both cases as little more than election ploys, the talks of late have fastened on issues of real substance. If past behavior is any guide, however, the negotiations seem destined to founder on one major point: the Reagan Administration's apparent inability to live with the Sandinista Government.

title: Chemical Bank Venture
description: Chemical Bank of the United States and Mitsui Bank of Japan plan to join with Industrial Enka Holding in establishing a bank in Turkey, an Enka official said today. He declined to give details.

title: ;  Avellini Pays the Price The veteran Chicago Bears' quarterback,
description: Bob Avellini, who fell out of favor with Coach Mike Ditka for changing a play two weeks ago against Seattle, was placed on waivers yesterday. His departure clears the way for activating Steve Fuller, who may start Sunday against New Orleans because of Jim McMahon 's injuries.

title: Dow Off 7.73 in Slower Trading
description: Stock prices fell broadly yesterday in slower trading, with issues responding to specific news developments the biggest movers.

title: NICARAGUANS TALK OF ELECTION DELAY
description: Nicaraguan Government and opposition leaders met here today to negotiate a possible postponement of the country's general election as a way of insuring the participation of a key opposition alliance.

title: SWEET SECRET OF SURVIVAL ON LITTLE WATER
description: WATER is vital to all life on earth, but some plants and animals can survive extremes of long-term dehydration.

title: Notes, Bonds Fall Slightly
description: Note and bond prices fell modestly yesterday as securities dealers searched for levels they hope will attract institional buyers to the heavy supply of Treasury issues expected later this month.

title: MUSIC: JORMA HYNNINEN, BARITONE
description: At intermission in the Carnegie lobby Sunday afternoon the talk was mostly in tones of unguarded enthusiasm: ''what a voice''; ''incredible energy''; ''best baritone since (name your recent favorite)!''

title: HOWARD CORNING Jr.
description: Howard Corning Jr., a retired foundation executive and former educator, died of pneumonia Friday at Community Hospital in Glen Cove, L.I. He was 79 years old and lived in Laurel Hollow, L.I.

title: French Deal for Honda
description: The Honda Motor Company said today that it would acquire 25 percent of Societe Mechanique du Haut-Rhin, the engine-making subsidiary of Cycles Peugeot, a French motorcycle manufacturer. The price was not disclosed.

title: ITALY SEEKS TO EXTRADITE 28 FROM U.S. AS MAFIA FIGURES
description: The Italian police continued their roundup of organized- crime figures today as the authorities hailed the confession of an important Mafia figure as a political and psychological breakthrough in the fight here against racketeering.

title: 'LOPSIDED' MATCHUP COULD BE EVEN ONE
description: Never in the 16-year history of baseball's division-playoff system has there been such a lopsided matchup as the American League has this week. If the Royals, who are hosts to Detroit in the first game of the three-of-five-game championship series tonight, had played in the same division as the Tigers, Kansas City would have finished 20 games behind.

title: Salvador Army Reports Gains Over Guerrillas
description: Soldiers killed five guerrillas and dismantled a rebel camp in a sweep through rebel-held portions of Chalatenango Province, an army spokesman said today.

title: Oct. 12 Deadline Set in Ford Talks
description: Negotiators for the United Automobile Workers and the Ford Motor Company today set Oct. 12 as an informal deadline for reaching agreement on a new labor contract.

title: ;  Clippers Sign 2
description: Bill Walton , the Los Angeles Clippers' veteran center, and Lancaster Gordon , the first-round draft pick from Louisville, have signed contracts with the team. The signings of Walton and Gordon comes after the Clippers acquired the veteran all-star forward Marques Johnson Saturday.Terms of contracts for Walton and Gordon, a guard, were not announced.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Malta Church Is Heeded; Private Schools Deserted
description: Private schools in Malta were deserted on the first day of the school year today as 20,000 students and teachers heeded a call by the Roman Catholic Church to stay home in the face of Government plans to enforce free education.

title: FABRIC WHOLESALERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
DODGERS' MANAGER 23 YEARS
description: Walt Alston, who guided the Dodgers of Brooklyn and then Los Angeles to seven National League pennants and four World Series championships during his 23 years as their manager, died yesterday in Oxford, Ohio, after a long illness. He was 72 years old.

title: THE MIRACLES SOUGHT BY MANILA'S BISHOP
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 MANILA POLICEMEN ARRESTED FOR FIRING GUNS DURING RALLY
description: An army general told the National Assembly today that two policemen had been arrested for firing their guns during a clash with anti-Government demonstrators that left scores of people wounded.

title: CALDOR GETS TOP RETAIL EXECUTIVE
description: In a shift that startled the retailing industry, James M. Guinan resigned yesterday as president of Bloomingdale's after only six months in the job to become chairman and chief executive officer at Caldor Inc., the big Connecticut-based discount store chain.

title: No Headline
description: TUESDAY, OCTOBER 2, 1984 International China displayed its first ICBM's in a military parade in Peking marking the 35th anniversary of Communist rule. The military section of the parade included intercontinental missiles capable of delivering nuclear warheads, submarine-launched missiles and self-propelled howitzers never shown before in public. (Page A1, Column 3.) Nicaragua's rejection of changes in a peace plan for Central America has led to an impasse with the United States that threatens a period of increased tension between the two countries, Reagan Administration and Nicaraguan officials said.
