Nicaragua's head of state, Daniel Ortega Saavedra, said in an interview in New York that the Sandinistas were unwilling to accept any modifications in a regional peace treaty proposed by four Latin American nations last month and endorsed by Nicaragua 10 days ago. (A1:1.)

title: Building Outlays Up By 0.2%
description: Spending on new construction rose a mere two-tenths of 1 percent in August after two months of declines, the Government reported today.

title: SOUTH AFRICA WARNS U.S. ON ASYLUM
description: South Africa's Foreign Minister warned the United States and other Western governments today not to respond favorably to a request for sanctuary by six political fugitives.

title: SEARCH IS PRESSED FOR WAYS BESIDES CONSTRUCTION TO EASE PRISON CROWDING
description: New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, seeking alternatives to costly prison construction programs, have intensified their search for other ways to ease their critical problems of prison overcrowding.

title: ;  Ex-Guard Loses Plea
description: Charlie Johnson, a former guard with the San Francisco Warriors and the Washington Bullets, lost his attempt to avoid paying $110,000 in Federal back taxes.

title: Shipyard Contract
description: United States Cruises Inc. has hired a shipyard here to perform the most expensive mercantile shipping conversion ever - a $131 million order to rebuild the luxury liner United States into a cruise ship, the yard said. Howaldtswerke- Deutsche Werft A.G. said the contract was signed in Seattle Saturday.

title: Fannie Mae Mortgage Plan
description: A new type of mortgage, designed to have the combined advantages of fixed monthly payments and adjustable interest rates, is being introduced by the Federal National Mortgage Association.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY ; Jeane Kirkpatrick Honored
description: The National Committee on American Foreign Policy gave its Hans J. Morgenthau Award, for exemplary contribution to foreign policy, to Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, the chief United States delegate to the United Nations.

title: Security Pacific
description: The Security Pacific National Bank said that it had acquired Hoenig & Company, a stockbroker for major institutional money managers. Terms of the deal, which has been approved by the Comptroller of the Currency and the New York Stock Exchange, were not announced. The acquisition of Hoenig and its wholly owned Stock and Trade subsidiary, a New York discount brokerage, was the bank's first purchase of a wholesale stockbroker.

title: GREAT ATLANTIC & PACIFIC TEA CO OF AMERICA (A&P) (N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 8
description: b-Including tax credits of $7,680,000 for the quarter and $12,930,900 for the 6 months and a $135 million gain from the reversion of surplus pension funds for the 6 months. c-Including tax credits of $4 million for the quarter and $8 million for the 6 months.

title: An Abstract Party
description: It may not be a world first, but it is

title: A PROFIT AT G.& W.
description: Gulf and Western Industries reported yesterday that in the fourth quarter, ended July 31, it earned $74.3 million, or $1.05 a share, in contrast to a loss of $401.6 million for the comparable period a year ago. Sales rose 16.4 percent, to $1.1 billion, from $945 million a year ago.

title: Not-Guilty Pleas In 6 Flags Deaths
description: The general manager of the Six Flags Great Adventure amusement park in Jackson Township and his predecessor pleaded not guilty today to manslaughter charges in the deaths of eight teen-agers in the Haunted Castle fire last May.

title: Wallace Given Antibiotics
description: Gov. George C. Wallace's doctors began giving him antibiotics intravenously today for a urinary tract infection and declined to speculate when he might be released from the hospital. Billy Joe Camp, the Governor's press secretary, said an evaluation of weekend tests at University Hospitals showed Wallace's infection was of ''a serious nature but very treatable.''

title: Countdown on Westway
description: With about six weeks until what

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, a dispatch from Dublin yesterday on the seizure of a trawler included a sentence that misstated the position of the Irish Northern Aid Committee, known as Noraid, which was accused of financing the vessel's cargo of arms. The passage should have read: In New York, Martin Galvin, publicity director of Noraid, said the group ''categorically rejects the false suggestion'' that committee funds were involved in the shipment of arms or ''for any purpose other than for supporting the victims of British violence.''

title: O'Neill Says Reagan Fiddles While 'Our Embassies Burn'
description: Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., the Speaker of the House, accused President Reagan today of failing to take responsibility for the bombing of the United States Embassy in Lebanon, saying Mr. Reagan is ''fiddling while our embassies burn.''

title: HANNA SCHYGULLA IN WAJDA'S 'LOVE IN GERMANY'
description: AS she demonstrated in Ettore Scola's witty meditation on the French Revolution, ''La Nuit de Varennes,'' Hanna Schygulla will survive the death of Rainer Werner Fassbinder. It was Fassbinder who originally discovered her and for whom she made a whole series of extraordinary films, from the early ''Katzelmacher,'' through ''Effi Briest'' and, perhaps the best of them all, ''The Marriage of Maria Braun.''

title: DISCOVERY HINTS AT NEW WAY TO LOOK AT DISEASE
description: a deadly form of liver infection produced by two viruses acting in concert in a manner never previously detected - has renewed the challenge to scientists to find previously unknown infectious agents as the cause of human diseases. The cause of most human diseases is unknown.

title: CONGRESS EXTENDS SPENDING LEVELS FOR 3 DAYS TO KEEP AGENCIES OPEN
description: The House and Senate agreed today to extend current spending levels for most Government agencies for three days, averting a threatened shutdown on the first day of the new fiscal year.

title: 3d Teen Accused In Shooting Spree
description: A third teen-age suspect in a series of air-gun shootings in Manhattan and the Bronx was arrested yesterday and charged in one of the crimes, the police said.

title: The EditorialNotebook ; The Reason for Biking to Work
description: Ride a bicycle to work? It sounds like outmoded environment chic, like putting a brick in your toilet tank. Yet the number of cyclists on New York's streets grows. City officials and bike groups estimate 60,000 people a day now use bicycles for commuting, deliveries and messenger service. A few weeks of going to work on two wheels shows why.

title: Opener to Sting, 2-1 CHICAGO, Oct. 1 (UPI) - Manny Rojas scored off a pass from Seninho with less than five minutes to play tonight, giving the Chicago
description: Sting a 2-1 victory over the Toronto Blizzard in the opener of the North

title: MIGRATION TREND OF THE AGING
description: A recent study asserting that increasing numbers of the elderly moved to metropolitan areas during the last decade was based on a misinterpretation of 1980 census figures. The research findings, which were to be published in a leading scholarly journal, have been withdrawn. A revised study stating that the migration trend among the elderly to nonmetropolitan areas continued as in previous decades will appear in a future issue.

title: U.S. Announces Default For a Grain Warehouse
description: A Texas grain warehouse was declared in default on its multimillion-dollar Government contract today after its owner did not come up with 966,000 bushels of missing Government-owned corn, Agriculture Department officials said.

title: TRANZONIC COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Business and the Law; New Firms On Top in City
description: SHEARMAN & STERLING has been the largest law firm in New York for at least three decades - and probably longer, but no one seems to have kept track in the early part of the century. The 120-year-old Wall Street firm has led the way as commercial law practices evolved from small groups of partners to the megafirms of today.

title: GAMBLERS' DOCTOR MAKES CASINO CALLS
description: After gambling for hours, the elderly woman collapsed and slid unconscious to the floor amid a throng of gamblers at Bally's Park Place casino here.

title: U.S. BUDGET IMPACT OF CONTINENTAL
description: David A. Stockman, director of the Office of Management and Budget, must decide soon whether $3.5 billion that the Government lent the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company of Chicago a few months ago to keep it from failing should be included in the budget results for the fiscal year 1984, ending Sept. 30.

title: EMOTIONAL OUTBURSTS PUNCTUATE CONVERSATIONS BY COMPUTER
description: COMPUTER buffs call it ''flaming.'' Now scientists are documenting and trying to explain the surprising prevalence of rudeness, profanity, exultation and other emotional outbursts by people when they carry on discussions via computer.

title: ;  Comings and Goings
description: Campy Russell , who sat out the last two season because of a knee injury, passed his physical examination yesterday and has begun working out with the Cleveland Cavaliers, who Saturday aquired him from the Knicks. . . . Clark Kellogg , the Indiana Pacers' leading scorer the last two seasons, will undergo athroscopic surgery on his left knee today and is expected to miss at least 10 days of practice. . . . Michigan State's basketball coach, Jud Heathcote , who suffered a heart attack last week, is in satisfactory condition and improving, according to the school.

title: BROADCASTERS HELPING TO GET OUT THE VOTE
description: To the Editor:

title: GIANTS AND JETS ASSESS THEIR DAMAGES
description: The Giants' 33-12 loss to the Los Angeles Rams Sunday was like a page out of ''The Twelve Days of Christmas.''

title: RIVERSIDE CHURCH GIVES SANCTUARY
description: A couple who fled Guatemala with their infant son were officially granted sanctuary by Riverside Church last night.

title: WHEN THE COACHES GO INTO THEIR ACTS
description: The post-game news conference of a National Football League coach can be anything from high drama to low comedy. After victories, many of them smile, credit the opposition and pass around verbal bouquets like Christmas gifts. After losses, they tend to snort and stew and suggest that they can't explain why such-and- such happened until they look at the films.

title: DCNY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
The U.N. Today
description: Oct. 2, 1984 GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: ODE TO SPONGES: A GREEK ISLE'S HERITAGE DRIES OUT
description: Prosperity and the rise of nationalism are inexorably diminishing an adventurous craft that was sung by Homer and mentioned in the New Testament and has flourished here in the Aegean through the ages.

title: Public Use Upheld For Jersey Beach
description: The Supreme Court today let stand a New Jersey appeals court ruling that said the public should have access to a beach run by a ''quasi-public'' association of community residents.

title:
PLAYERS;
DREAM ENDS AS SUMMER DOES
description: All around him, two weeks ago tonight, the Detroit Tigers were

title: Debt Issues
description: Chi-Chi's Inc., Louisville, Ky., has filed for an offering of $50 million of convertible subordinated debentures due in 2009.

title: Steel Output Off Last Week By The Associated Press Steel production fell to 1.364
description: million tons in the week ended

title: JAPANESE DANCER MIXES BUDDHISM AND FLAMENCO
description: The Japanese dancer Yasuko Nagamine has long delighted in mixing styles. When she presents the dance-drama ''Mandara'' tomorrow night at Carnegie Hall, the stage will be filled with 58 Japanese Buddhist monks intoning traditional chants. In addition, the production will embrace the ritual solemnity of Japanese no theater and the emotional fervor of Western modern dance, as well as elements of Spanish flamenco, Miss Nagamine's specialty.

title: No Headline
description: Exhibition Documents Ballet Theater's History

title: Ellsworth Bunker Is Buried Near His Home in Vermont
description: Ellsworth Bunker, the diplomat who served seven Presidents and became a symbol of the United States intervention in Vietnam, was buried today in the rolling Vermont countryside he adopted as his home.

title: LENS HOLDS COMPANY'S FATE
description: The Staar Surgical Company, a two-year-old concern based in Monrovia, Calif., has a limited history, distinguished by modest sales and awesome losses. It faces heavy research expenses, and it is banking on a first- of-its-kind product that will not reach the market for another three years, if ever. The first six months this year, Staar lost $890,000 and had revenues of only $329,000.

title: One China, Two Systems? Though there may be trouble in the fine print, the Hong Kong bargain struck by China and Britain seems a salutary triumph for common sense. No doubt compelling economic reasons persuaded Peking to promise the old colony a half-century of capitalist autonomy after Britain's lease expires in 1997. The Chinese also have an obvious political purpose: to strengthen their bid for a similar settlement with Taiwan one day.
description: All to the good, if these overtures signify a genuine evolution in China's diplomacy. When a Communist giant makes ''one country, two systems'' its controlling principle for regaining lost territory, that's a landmark of accommodation.

title: JOHN HEMMINGER John Hemminger, the husband and manager of Cynthia Gregory, the American Ballet Theater principal dancer, died Sunday at his home in Manhattan. He was 42 years old.
description: The cause of death was undetermined pending an autopsy, according to a ballet company spokesman.

title: SOUTH KOREA SAYS NORTH BOLSTERS ITS ARMED FORCES NEAR TRUCE LINE
description: As North Korean ships continued to deliver relief supplies to his country, South Korea's President charged today that the North at the same time was strengthening its military forces near the demilitarized zone.

title: TEXAS LEADER DEFIES FEDERAL ADMONITION ON ENROLLING VOTERS
description: Gov. Mark White walked through state office buildings today handing out voter registration cards to state employees in defiance of a warning from Washington authorities.

title: CSX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SAFETY OFFICIAL CITES CONCERN OVER THREAT OF AIR COLLISIONS
description: The vice chairman of the National Transportation Safety Board said today that inquiries into nine recent aircraft collision hazards had increased the agency's concern about potential saturation of the air traffic system. One collision resulted in the crash of a small airliner.

title: ; REAGAN'S BURDEN IN BEIRUT EMBASSY BOMBING
description: To the Editor:

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: THE week was full of surprises,

title: 14 Die in Indian Theater
description: At least 14 people were crushed to death and 45 were injured today when a wall of a movie theater collapsed in the southern Indian state of Tamil Nadu, the Press Trust of India said.

title: Another Birthday
description: The way Dot Helms figures it,

title: VON BULOW RULING IS LEFT STANDING
description: The Supreme Court today refused to reinstate Claus von B"ulow's conviction of twice trying to murder his rich wife so he could inherit $14 million and marry his lover, a former actress.

title: The Mighty Muse
description: Not often does an issue so stir a Congressman that he is moved to verse on the floor of the House. But this happened with Representative Silvio O. Conte, the Massschussetts Republican, on what he described as ''a billion-dollar bailout bill for a few Western timber companies.'' Without apologies to Longfellow, or anyone else, Mr. Conte began ''Under the Federal money tree/ the timber company stands/ A business married to Adam Smith/ With large and outstretched hands . . .'' and continued in similar style.

title: Plea of Guilt in Abuse At Children's Theater
description: John Clark Donahue, the founder and former artistic director of the Children's Theater Company and School of Minneapolis, pleaded guilty today to three counts of criminal sexual conduct with students.

title: Awacs Plane for Greece
description: The North Atlantic Treaty Organization will station a United States-built Awacs reconnaissance plane in Greece before the end of next year, Greek military and NATO officials said today. The plane will survey East European air activity from the Preveza air base on the Ionian Sea. The stationing of the Awacs plane is part of a NATO project to deploy 18 such aircraft in NATO countries by the end of 1985.

title: INVESTIGATION OF DONOVAN DATES TO 1981
description: Following are important dates in the government investigations of Labor Secretary Raymond J. Donovan:

title: 'OBSESSIVE LOVE,' MOVIE WITH YVETTE MIMIEUX
description: MORE than 20 years ago, a Hollywood starlet named Yvette Mimieux appeared on the cover of a national magazine wearing a bikini. She then went on to a modest acting career in largely forgettable films. Tonight at 9 o'clock on CBS, Miss Mimieux can be seen in a television movie called ''Obsessive Love'' and, sure enough, having co-written the story, she manages to appear once again in a bikini. One of the more positive remarks that can be made about this production is that age has hardly withered her fragile beauty.

title: SEARCH CONTINUES FOR 2D SHIP LINKED TO I.R.A. GUNRUNNING
description: An international search was under way today for a second vessel involved in shipping arms from the United States to the Irish Republican Army. An Irish trawler, believed to be ferrying the arms ashore from the mother ship, was captured on Saturday.

title: Tourism in Singapore
description: Singapore's earnings from tourism in 1983 rose 3.7 percent, to $1.93 billion, although the number of visitors shrank 3.5 percent, to 2.8 million, the Tourist Promotion Board said today.

title: APL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a loss of $808,000 from discontinued operations and an extraordinary loss of $518,000. c-The company broke even after income from discontinued operations of $438,000 and a tax credit of $505,000. d-Including income from discontinued operations of $728,000, a gain of $12,203,000 from the sale of discontinued operations and a tax credit of $675,000. e-Including income from discontinued operations of $1,954,000 and a tax credit of $614,000.

title: THAI PREMIER REPORTED ILL AGAIN
description: Prime Minister Prem Tinsulanonda of Thailand, who returned less than a week ago from a medical trip to the United States looking fit and saying he was ready to resume work, has been admitted to a Bangkok hospital for what the army describes as a lung problem.

title: Weaver Wants To Come Back
description: Earl Weaver, the former Baltimore Orioles' manager, said today he would like to return to baseball, and indicated ''there are several clubs who have made me offers.''

title: A READING AT THE Y STARRING PINTER
description: He started with one of his recent works and moved back through time to one of his first. He did not explain his choices. Nor did he do much talking between scenes.

title: SHAKEOUT IN COMPUTER STORES
description: The corner of Devonshire and Water Streets, in the midst of this city's cramped financial district, is a kind of heaven for the computer shopper.

title: S.E.C. SUES 4 EMPLOYED BY TEXAS INSTRUMENTS
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday charged four employees of Texas Instruments Inc. with using non-public information to trade in the company's stock in June 1983.

title: 250 Nigerians Are Freed On Independence Day
description: Maj. Gen. Mohammed Buhari marked Nigeria's independence day today by announcing the release of 250 people detained since the coup that put him in power nine months ago.

title: GULF & WESTERN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b- Including income of $100,000 for the quarter and a loss of $3.4 million for the year from discontinued operations. c-Net losses after writeoffs of $467.2 million for the quarter and $454.7 million for the year.

title: No Headline
description: Piano Prize AwardedJon Kimura Parker, a doctoral candidate in piano at the Juilliard School, is the winner of this year's Leeds International Pianoforte Competition in Britain. The award features a cash prize, a medal and playing engagements around the world. Mr. Parker will give a recital at Queen Elizabeth Hall in London on Nov. 29.

title: Bombing of Pakistan Is Denied by Afghans
description: The Afghan Government today denied Pakistani allegations that Afghan planes had bombed a Pakistani border town, killing 33 people and wounding 48 others, the Kabul radio said.

title: AROUND THE WORLD ; Bangladesh Official Reported Out in Dispute
description: A Cabinet member accused by opposition groups of responsibility for attacks on their supporters during a national strike last week was dismissed today, officials said.

title: ISRAELI CRITICIZES JORDANIAN STAND
description: Prime Minister Shimon Peres, reacting to a speech today by King Hussein, criticized the King for his rejection of Israel's call for peace talks.

title: CLASS ACTION SET IN ASBESTOS CASES
description: A Federal district judge in Philadelphia has approved a suit against 55 asbestos manufacturers on behalf of the nation's primary and secondary schools. It would be the first nationwide class action for property damage arising out of a product liability question.

title: TUESDAY SPORTS Baseball
description: Cubs vs. San Diego Padres , at Chicago, opener of National League three-of-five-game championship series. It has been a long wait for Cub fans.

title: Lurie for Selling Giants SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 1 (UPI) - Robert A. Lurie, the owner of
description: the San Francisco Giants, said today he would sell the National League

title: REAGAN SHARPLY CONTRASTS HIS VISION WITH MONDALE'S
description: President Reagan said today that the nation was ''in the midst of the best economic expansion in over 30 years'' and charged that Walter F. Mondale's policies would ''put us back on the path toward defeatism, decline and despair.''

title: Cook United Files Under Chapter 11
description: Cook United Inc., a Cleveland- based operator of discount stores, said that it filed yesterday for protection under Chapter 11 of the Federal bankruptcy laws.

title: Continental Illinois Strategy
description: -The assets of the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company will shrink by $1.7 billion and the staff will be cut by nearly 2,000 employees next year, according to a strategic plan being circulated among Continental executives, it was learned today.

title: ABOUT BOSTON
description: In the ebb of day not long ago, Judge Paul Garrity sat in the stately calm of Boston's Plaza Bar, reflecting on the administration of the law, and on how he and his Federal colleague, Judge W. Arthur Garrity Jr., go about it.

title: Voter Registration, With Music and Owl
description: Area, a discoth eque on Hudson

title: Dart & Kraft Acquiring CFS CHICAGO, Oct. 1 - Dart &
description: Kraft Inc. announced a definitive agreement under which it

title: SUPERIOR CARE INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 29
description: b-Net income after income from discontinued operations of $95,259, or 1 cent a share.

title: Jack H. Pollack, 69, Author Of Books and 1,000 Articles
description: Jack Harrison Pollack, the author of three books and more than a thousand magazine articles, died of cancer Sunday at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan. He was 69 years old and lived in Westhampton Beach, L.I.

title: WAR ON PESTS IN AFRICA MERGES NATURE AND HIGH TECHNOLOGY
description: IBADAN, NIGERIA

title: HUSSEIN SCORNS ISRAELI CALL FOR TALKS AS A 'SUBTERFUGE'
description: King Hussein of Jordan said today that a recent Israeli call for Jordan and other Arab governments to join in peace negotiations was ''an exercise in subterfuge and deception.''

title: Co-Chairman Resigns From Herzfeld & Stern
description: Steven A. Seiden has resigned as co-chairman of Herzfeld & Stern, the brokerage house acquired last year by Josephson International Inc., the talent agency and television production company.

title: SCIENTIFIC INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Two Moderators Chosen For Presidential Debates
description: Barbara Walters of ABC News and Edwin A. Newman, who is retired from NBC News, are to moderate the two debates between Walter F. Mondale and President Reagan on Sunday and on Oct. 21, the League of Women Voters announced today.

title: ;  Austin Leaves Generals
description: Bill Austin , the Generals' offensive coordinator, resigned yesterday to pursue other interests. Chris Palmer , the receiver coach, will move into Austin's job. John D'Ottavio, a scout, will direct the receivers, and an offensive-line coach will be named.

title: A New Parks Mascot
description: A carousel horse has been given a

title: Birthdays
description: Associate Justice William H. Rehnquist of the Supreme Court became 60 years old yesterday but gave no indication that it was his birthday as he worked through the opening of the Court's new term. The birthday had some statistical significance.

title: TROOPS ENTER SIKH SHRINE TO QUELL MELEE
description: Only days after they had been withdrawn, Indian security forces returned to the Golden Temple in Amritsar today to put down a disturbance by militant Sikhs. About 300 people were reported arrested.

title: HOPE GROWS FOR VIGOROUS OLD AGE
description: FROM King David who is said to have wooed young virgins in the hope of absorbing their vitality to modern-day enthusiasts for fetal lamb cell injections and vitamin E megadoses, people have been trying to stave off aging and death.

title: 4 WHO ROSE FROM THE ASHES
description: In each's previous job as a major

title: Thrift Unit Offers $1 Billion of C.D.'s
description: The American Savings and Loan Association, a subsidiary of the Los Angeles-based Financial Corporation of America, is offering up to $1 billion of certificates of deposit through a group of securities dealers led by Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. Proceeds of the issue will be used to help repay loans from the Federal Home Loan Bank of San Francisco and for general purposes.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: TUESDAY, OCTOBER 2, 1984

title: CSX Earnings Surge
description: The CSX Corporation today reported a profit of $126.2 million, or 86 cents a share, for the third quarter, compared with a profit of $68.9 million, or 54 cents a share, a year ago.

title: Grain Unit In Default
description: A Texas grain warehouse was declared in default on its multimillion-dollar Government contract today after its owner did not come up with 966,000 bushels of missing Government- owned corn, Agriculture Department officials said.

title: DONOVAN INDICTED AND GIVEN A LEAVE TO DEFEND HIMSELF
description: A Bronx grand jury has indicted Labor Secretary Raymond J. Donovan, the Secretary confirmed this evening.

title: SHULTZ SAYS ISRAELI DEPARTURE FROM LEBANON ISN'T AT HAND
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said yesterday that the results of a mission to the Middle East by a high-ranking State Department official last week showed that there was ''a long way to go'' before an agreement on Israel's withdrawal from southern Lebanon could be achieved.

title: HARD DISKS SAVE TIME AND SPACE
description: IT has become hard to conceive

title: Key Rates
description: * split rate, 12.50-12.75 ** Kenny Index, Kenny Information Systems Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: ERROR BY CREW IS BLAMED IN CRASH OF B-1 BOMBER
description: The crash of a prototype B-1 bomber last Aug. 29 in the Mojave Desert was caused by error by the crew, an Air Force official said today.

title: 2 SHUT TRUST UNITS SUED BY UNINSURED
description: Uninsured depositors of two Oklahoma financial institutions that closed last week have filed a lawsuit seeking $72 million in damages, and calls are ''flooding in'' from other depositors seeking to join the suit, an attorney for the plaintiffs said today.

title: Boy, 15, Accused Of Killing Girl, 12
description: A 15-year-old youth here was charged today with strangling his 12- year-old cousin and leaving her partly clad body in a gully near their home, the police said.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: TALKING ABOUT WOMEN Women are the subject of this evening's 6 o'clock lecture in the series on censorship at the New York Public Library. Questions include how women are represented in the media, how they have been portrayed, who created the images, are they accurate or distorted, and should the images be changed. Female artists and art and film critics will participate, and Linda Nochlin, an art historian, will moderate.

title: People
description: * James Spanfeller Jr. was named publisher of Newsweek On Campus magazine.

title: KARAJAN AND BERLINERS SIGN ACCORD,PLAY BACH
description: The dispute between the Berlin Philharmonic and its chief conductor, Herbert von Karajan, was muted last weekend by the soaring cadences of Bach's B minor mass and a four-point agreement that amounted to a triumph for the musicians.

title: State Ballot Restriction Upheld By High Court
description: The Supreme Court today let stand a ruling that a state may require a minor political party to get the signatures of 3 percent of the state's registered voters before placing its candidates on the ballot.

title: 'DRIVEL' ABOUT THE K.A.L. FLIGTH 007 INCIDENT
description: To the Editor:

title: Walking for Joy
description: Maurice Lentzer of Brooklyn is among 1,287 messengers who walk 2,960 miles - a 2.3-mile average - during a four-hour workday delivering packages and documents of a legal or financial nature for Archer Services Inc.

title: CLOTHES THAT OUTSMART IN-BETWEEN DAYS
description: It was not easy to determine when summer ceased and fall began this year. The autumnal equinox was during a hot, humid spell suitable for the middle of July. Then hardly a week had gone by before the rains came and the temperature dropped into the 50's. Still, whether it was fair weather or foul, the way women dressed indicated that a new fashion season had begun.

title: Goldblatt Purchase
description: Household International Inc., based in Prospect Heights, Ill., announced that its merchandising subsidiary, Household Merchandising Inc., had agreed to sell its furniture operations to a unit of Goldblatt Brothers Inc. of Chicago. A spokesman for Goldblatt's said the purchase price was ''between $35 million and $40 million.'' According to a Household International statement, the furniture operations, with sales of $167 million in 1983, include 35 stores in four chains: Huffman-Koos in New Jersey and New York, Colby's in the Chicago area, Barker's in the Los Angeles area and American Furniture in the El Paso, Tex., area.

title: ACCOUNTING MERGER DISCUSSED
description: Alexander Grant & Company, the nation's 11th-largest accounting firm, and Fox & Company, the 13th largest, announced yesterday that they are discussing a possible merger.

title: Howard L. Tiger Dies; Invented Desalting Kit
description: Howard L. Tiger, a retired chemical engineer and inventor who developed a desalting survival kit for American airmen during World War II, died Saturday at the Beth Israel Medical Center in Newark after a long illness. He was 86 years old and lived in West Orange, N.J.

title: A.& P. Profit Rises 73.2%
description: The Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company said today that its profit for the latest quarter rose 73.2 percent, partly because of a one-time gain from the sale of securities and the strong performance of its newly acquired Kohl's subsidiary.

title: Coffee Gets New Accord
description: Forty-eight countries that produce coffee and 25 countries that consume it agreed today on price and quota goals for the next 12 months. They are members of the International Coffee Organization, accounting for 99 percent of all the world's coffee exports and 90 percent of imports.

title: RIO GRANDE INDUSTRIES MERGER
description: After an extensive search for a merger partner, Rio Grande Industries, owner of a Western railroad, said yesterday that it had agreed to be acquired by the Anschutz Corporation, a privately held energy and real estate company, for $496.5 million, or $50 a share.

title: Montana Court Rejects A Balanced Budget Bid
description: The Montana Supreme Court today ruled that an initiative on the state's Nov. 6 ballot for a constitutional amendment requiring a balanced budget must be removed.

title: GIANTS' PUNTS BLOCKED BY INTELLIGENCE AND LUCK
description: In his 10 previous seasons with the

title: REAGAN'S BURDEN IN THE BEIRUT EMBASSY BOMBING
description: To the Editor:

title: SCHOOL PICTURES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $732,849 on the sale of a California plant and land.

title: 3 ADMIT KILLING HOMOSEXUAL
description: Three teen- agers charged with murder in the death by drowning of a homosexual man who was thrown into a stream pleaded guilty to manslaughter today in a proceeding that drew protests from homosexual rights activists.

title: FAMILY SHOWTIME THEATRES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: GRAB BAG OF BILLS PASS HOUSE IN BID TO ADJOURN
description: The House of Representatives approved a grab bag of bills today, including one that would establish a national policy for economic regulation of cable television and another intended to improve security at United States embassies around the world.

title: KEVEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 27
description: b-Including a benefit of $1,141,000 for the quarter and year on export sales previously deferred.

title: Court Upholds 'Insider' Case
description: The key legal theory that the Securities and Exchange Commission has relied on in a string of recent trading cases was upheld today by the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit.

title: Driver Is Charged In Crash on I-84
description: The driver of a car that collided yesterday with a bus carrying members of a college lacrosse team was charged with speeding and improperly changing lanes, the state police said.

title: Market Place; Campbell Soup Takeover Talk
description: TAKEOVER talk is apparently what is causing

title: PERSISTENT DOUBTS CLOUD THE FUTURE OF THE LINCOLN WEST PROPOSAL
description: If everything had gone according to plan, the first apartment tower in the enormous housing and office project known as Lincoln West would now be rising on the south side of West 72d Street.

title: German Green Party Gains in Local Voting
description: The Green Party made big advances in municipal elections Sunday at the expense of the parties in Chancellor Helmut Kohl's federal coalition Government.

title: Transitions
description: New York politicians who read the

title: FEDERAL JUDGE BLOCKS THE CLOSING OF THE STATE PRISON AT BRENTWOOD
description: A Federal judge blocked the state from closing its 1,000-bed prison in Suffolk County today, granting a full hearing on inmates' contention that their transfer to upstate prisons would be ''cruel and unusual punishment'' because of overcrowding.

title: ;  Rangers Cut 10
description: The Rangers cut 10 players from their training-camp roster, including Mario Proulx, a goaltender; Chris Renaud, a defenseman; Cam Connor, Randy Heath and Steve Martinson, left wings; Jim Malone and Mark Morrison, centers, and Mike Backman and Kurt Kleinendorst , right wings. All were sent to the New Haven Nighthawks of the American Hockey League.

title: Payments To Women By Allstate
description: The Allstate Insurance Company said today that it had agreed to pay $5 million to about 3,100 women currently or formerly employed as sales agents or trainees in settlement of a class action lawsuit accusing the company of discrimination.

title: THOSE CRUEL TASKMASTERS OF THE SENATE
description: When the Rev. Richard C. Halverson, the chaplain, opens the daily Senate sessions with prayer, he often prompts a good- natured exchange with Howard H. Baker Jr., Republican of Tennessee, the Senate majority leader.

title: SORG PRINTING CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Advertising; Economist Plans New Magazine
description: BECAUSE of the popularity of its science and technology section, The Economist, the 141-year- old British news weekly, is going to start another magazine.

title: Chrysler Unit's $200 Million Notes
description: The Chrysler Financial Corporation is offering $200 million of 13 1/4 percent notes due in 1999 at a price of 100 through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc. At the option of the holder, the notes may be redeemed at a price of 100 after five years.

title: U.S.-ITALY PANEL TO MEET IN DRIVE AGAINST CRIME
description: Attorney General William French Smith will meet here this week with Italian officials as part of a new group's drive on organized crime in both countries.

title: SHUTTLE AIMS FOR STRIKING NEW IMAGES OF EARTH
description: THE next flight of the space shuttle Challenger, an eight-day mission scheduled to begin Friday, is intended to provide one of the most intensive and multifaceted surveys of the earth's surface ever undertaken from space.

title: ; Kasparov Postpones Eighth Chess Game
description: Gary Kasparov has taken his second timeout in the world chess championship match, postponing his eighth game with Anatoly Karpov until Wednesday, Soviet chess officials said today.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption Friday with an article about Queen Elizabeth visiting Canada was incorrectly dated. The picture, showing the Queen in Fredericton, New Brunswick, was taken last Tuesday.

title: Skeleton Found Off Wards Island
description: Police divers searching for the body of a missing state police investigator off Wards Island yesterday discovered the skeletal remains of another person in the trunk of a sunken automobile.

title: Mayor Is Critical Of Transit Unions
description: Mayor Koch said today that constrictive labor union rules had stymied management's efforts to make the New York City mass transit system more efficient.

title: I.B.M., Thomson
description: Thomson-CSF's semiconductor division signed a three-year agreement worth about $100 million to provide I.B.M. France with some 60 million memory circuits, the division, Thomson Semiconducteurs, said. Thomson-CSF, a member of the Paris-based Thomson Group, is one of the biggest electronic companies in Europe. I.B.M. France said the memory chips would be used in the fabrication of diverse I.B.M. material produced in the company's European plants.

title: REAGAN'S BURDEN IN THE BEIRUT EMBASSY BOMBING
description: To the Editor:

title: BACK HOME
description: In his first four years with the Los Angeles Dodgers, Pedro Guerrero played the outfield and his batting average never dropped below .300. But when Ron Cey was traded after the 1982 season, Guerrero became the starting third baseman.

title: Gavilan Filing
description: The Gavilan Computer Corporation, a closely held manufacturer of lap-model personal computers, said that it filed for protection under Chapter 11 of the Federal bankruptcy laws in San Jose, Calif.

title: LABOR PARTY IN BRITAIN ACCUSES POLICE OF VIOLENCE AGAINST MINERS
description: The Labor Party's annual conference, which formulates party policy, overwhelmingly approved a resolution today accusing the police of perpetrating violent acts against striking miners. It made no mention of violence on picket lines.

title: LATIN ACADEMICS VOICE CONCERN ON U.S. ROLE
description: A group of university presidents and student leaders from Central America have been touring the United States to press their concern about the prospects of American military intervention.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * The Allen Group , Melville, L.I., a manufacturer of automotive diagnostic equipment and parts, has agreed to sell the assets of its automotive accessories divisions, Hollywood Accessories and Cal Custom Hawk, to Mr. Gasket Co. of Cleveland.

title: REDKEN LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
The Fading, Dying Sea ; ''Why,'' wonders Anne Simon, ''is the human race so unwilling to think about the long term?''
description: OF all those who have had their say about the sea, none was more succinct than the grizzled denizen whom the peripatetic writer William Least Heat Moon encountered along the Outer Banks off North Carolina. The ancient gent deplored the stupidity of man's building too close to the water's edge. He questioned the future of a motel built on land that in the not too distant past had been an inlet. ''The sea,'' he said ominously, ''never forgets where it's been.''

title: Doubleday to Buy Mutual's WHN
description: The Mutual Broadcasting System said it had agreed to sell WHN-AM in New York for $13 million to Doubleday Broadcasting Inc., a subsidiary of the publishing concern of Doubleday & Company. The sale would complete a process begun by Mutual last fall of selling its radio station properties to focus solely on the operation of its radio network.

title: LATIN PEACE PLAN: WHY THE U.S. BALKS
description: The Reagan Administration's cool response to a Central American peace plan endorsed by Nicaragua stems from both substantive objections to the treaty and underlying hostility toward the Sandinista Government, according to Administration officials. The officials said the negative American reaction was in part a result of the belief among many senior officials that the United States should not accept any sort of agreement with Nicaragua and that stability in Central America cannot be achieved while the Sandinistas remain in power.

title: TWO SENATORS DEFEND EFFORT TO PROTECT AN ALASKAN INDUSTRY
description: To the Editor:

title: WHEN 'EXTRA MEASURES' MERELY PROLONG DYING
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;
description: Three Out of Four

title: Ship Aground Off Bermuda
description: A supertanker carrying 196,000 tons of crude oil ran aground 10 miles off Bermuda late Monday. The Mexican-registered Aguilla Azeteca was carrying crude oil from Mexico to Rotterdam. A freighter ran aground near the same place two weeks ago.

title: WHEN 'EXTRA MEASURES' MERELY PROLONG DYING
description: To the Editor:

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: WHOLE EARTH SOFTWARE CATALOG. Stewart Brand, editor in chief. 208 pages. Illustrated. Quantum/Doubleday. $17.50.

title: Lavinia Dudley, 93, Ex-Editor Of Encyclopedia Americana
description: Lavinia P. Dudley, former editor in chief of the Encyclopedia Americana, died last Friday at Community Hospital in Montclair, N.J. She was 93 years old and lived in Bloomfield, N.J.

title: NOW IT'S SCONES, AND IN BEVY OF FLAVORS
description: LATELY it seems that the place to find those traditionally Scottish tea cakes known as scones is right here in New York. Scones are being sold all over town, the latest in the international catalogue of baked goods to catch the fancy of the restless new palate. In bakeries, fancy food shops, coffee shops, department stores, supermarkets and delicatessens, they share space with bagels, croissants, Danish, muffins, pita bread and kaiser rolls.

title: ; Operaworks Presents A New Davies Piece
description: New York's small opera companies are a half-noticed, undervalued resource. They prod the artistic conscience of our established houses with their unusual or neglected repertory, and they give aspiring singers a first big chance on stage - a winnowing process by which the talented can be separated from the merely ambitious.

title: LABORITE CHIEF ASSAILS MINE STRIKE VIOLENCE
TULSA DEMOCRAT RUNS A WARY RE-ELECTION RACE
description: Representative James R. Jones is chairman of the House Budget Committee and a longtime opponent of President Reagan's tax and budget policies. But only rarely, and then only mutedly, does he criticize the President here as he conducts what many consider the toughest campaign of his 12-year career in the House.

title: OPPENHEIMER & CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31

YEMENI MEETS SOVIET LEADER MOSCOW, Oct. 2 (Reuters) - Konstantin U. Chernenko, the Soviet leader, attacked United States policies in the Middle East and the Persian Gulf today during talks with the leader of Southern Yemen, Ali Nasser Mohammed.
description: The official press agency Tass said the two men agreed that Washington and Israel were ''stepping up their aggressive course'' in the Middle East.

title: BRIEFS ;  Debt Issues
description: Citicorp sold $100 million of 91-day commercial paper at an average rate of 10.95 percent, unchanged from a week ago, and $50 million of 182-day paper at an average of 10.934 percent, down from 10.94 percent.

title: AUTOCLAVE ENGINEERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: Foreign Investment Declines
description: Foreign investment in the United States declined in 1983, for the second consecutive year, restrained by sluggish economies abroad, high interest rates and the strong dollar, the Commerce Department said today.

title: JUSTICES HEAR ARGUMENTS ON SCHOOL SEARCHES
description: The Supreme Court heard argument today on whether the Constitution limits public school teachers in searching students they suspect of violating school rules.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;
description: Honesty on the IRT

title: OCCIDENTAL RAISES OIL ESTIMATE
description: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation has sharply increased its estimate of reserves in its Cano Limon oilfield in northeastern Colombia, Armand Hammer, Occidental's chairman, said here today.

title: SYNTHETIC FUEL FUNDS DEBATED
description: Congress is debating a bill that would give the Synthetic Fuels Corporation a new lease on life, not by giving it more money but by taking money away.

title: SWEATERS TO ORDER AND TOY-CAR CLOCK
description: 1.*Custom Sweaters

title: IACOCCA EXPOSES SCARS OF FORD ERA
description: Although Lee A. Iacocca has become a folk hero in this capital of the auto industry, he bears the scars of old wounds and is not above settling old scores.

title: SANTA MONICA BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Accounts
description: * Wendy's International, Dublin, Ohio, to Mendoza, Dillon & Asociados, Los Angeles, and Lockhart & Pettus of New York.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Sodium in Baby Food

title: FERRARO DISCLOSURE DATA AMENDED TO FIX ERRORS
description: Representative Geraldine A. Ferraro, the Democratic Vice-Presidential nominee, has amended her financial disclosure statements for the last six years to correct previous mistakes and to reflect data uncovered in the recent audit of the finances of Mrs. Ferraro and her husband, John A. Zaccaro.

title: LOSING TIMES SQ. BIDDER CHARGES FAVORITISM
description: A losing bidder on the $1.6 billion plan to rebuild Times Square yesterday charged that the selection of developers for the project had been marked by ''pervasive evidence of political favoritism and impropriety.''

title: Sunbeam's President Looks to New Products
description: Thomas J. Albani, the new president of the Sunbeam North American Appliance Group, said that Sunbeam, after having taken ''painful'' steps to cut costs, was developing new products to help maintain ''our role as industry leader.''

title: ;  Early TV Opposed
description: International Olympic officials say that revenues from American television rights for the 1988 Games in Seoul could reach $700 million - but only if they agree to stage some key finals as early as 8 A.M., something they say they are reluctant to do. ''It is impossible to set finals at 8 A.M. just to be paid $200 million to $500 million more,'' said Juan Antonio Samaranch , the president of the International Olympic Commitee, who added that the health of the athletes would be the committee's first concern.

title: The Editorial Notebook; Better Brakes
description: Some types of auto accident are the stuff of nightmares. You jam on the brakes to avoid an obstacle on the road. The right wheels lose traction on a patch of ice, their brakes lock and, rudderless, the car swerves left toward oncoming traffic. Highly skilled drivers compensate by lightly pumping the brakes and momentarily steering in the direction of the skid. Most of us only manage to grip the steering wheel a little tighter and pray it's all a bad dream.

title: 4 Blacks Are Killed In South Africa Clashes
description: Four blacks, including three teen- agers, were killed today in South Africa's segregated townships, and the police said dozens of black youths were arrested nationwide.

title: F.G.I.C. Is Rated Aaa by Moody's
description: The Financial Guaranty Insurance Corporation, an insurer of tax-exempt bonds based in New York, received the highest rating from Moody's Investors Service yesterday.

title: SOUTH CAROLINA KEEPING SHARP EYE ON ITS DEFENSE
description: Any member of the South Carolina defense who is camera-shy may be in trouble with the coaching staff. The word to those players is, ''Get your picture taken, or else run laps.''

title: FOR A FOOTBALL FAMILY, FEAR AND PRAYERS
description: In Room 656 at Sacred Heart General Hospital - one floor above the intensive-care unit, where their 19-year-old son fights for life - Ed and Pat Reinhardt wrestle with excruciating grief and fear, pray for a miracle and take solace from the kindness of strangers.

title: CITY GUIDE TO WINE COURSES, FOR BOTH NOVICE AND EXPERT
description: NEARLY three dozen wine courses are being offered in New York City this fall, with a range broad enough to encompass both the novice and the seasoned enophile as well as those in between. The schools are listed in alphabetical order. Classes meet once a week and, unless otherwise stated, the instructors have been observed through one complete session.

title: Governor Expects Dismissal Of 2 World's Fair Executives
description: Gov. Edwin Edwards said today that the New Orleans World's Fair had turned into a ''disaster'' and predicted that the top administrators of the debt-ridden exposition would soon be dismissed.

title: E.P.A. PROPOSES NEW LIST OF HAZARDOUS SITES
description: The Environmental Protection Agency today proposed adding 244 new sites to its list of the nation's most dangerous waste dumps. For the first time, the list would include Federal installations and areas contaminated with pesticides.

title: JULES KOLODNY, TEACHER, DIES
description: Jules Kolodny, a teacher who was a founder and later a leader of the United Federation of Teachers, died yesterday at Beth Israel Hospital from injuries that he suffered when he was struck by a bus while crossing a street in London last May. He never regained consciousness. Mr. Kolodny was 73 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Slain Trooper's Body Found in East River
description: The body of Richard B. Snyder, a state trooper missing since he was shot on Sept. 20, was found yesterday in his unmarked police car at the bottom of the East River.

title: SFN Accepts Bid Of $466.4 Million
description: The SFN Companies said it had reached a definitive agreement for a leveraged buyout valued at about $466.4 million. The investor group is led by E.M. Warburg, Pincus & Company, Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. and senior management.

title: WHEN 'EXTRA MEASURES' MERELY PROLONG DYING
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: On a mundane night of preseason hockey, the Rangers checked off a few necessary items on their agenda. Glen Hanlon, their goalie, played a full game for the first time and knocked away 42 of 46 shots. Mike Blaisdell solidified his quest to stay with the team as a right wing.

title: Market Place; Time Inc. As a Target
description: ANYONE who has been following Time Inc. lately can hardly help but wonder why its stock has been bouncing around so much.

title: HOUSE VOTES RISE IN SOCIAL SECURITY
description: The House of Representatives passed a bill today to guarantee that Social Security benefits would increase in January, even if inflation remained low.

title: WIRED FOR SLUMBER
description: I read not long ago that the judge

title: EISENHOWER FELLOWSHIP GROUP BRINGING THE WORLD TO AMERICA
description: The house is as unpretentious as the old city where it was built nearly 150 years ago. The brick front with its stone stoop shows little to distinguish it from adjoining buildings.

title: MUTUAL FUNDS TRAIL S.& P. 500
description: Mutual funds, in part promoted for their professional management, have again failed to give investors an advantage in the stock market. For the fifth consecutive quarter, the average gain for equity funds failed to match the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks, the benchmark against which most money managers are usually measured.

title: People
description: * William J. Case and Edwin Mammen have been named senior vice presidents, group management supervisors, at W. B. Doner & Company, Detroit.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: Parolee Pleads Guilty To Shooting 3 Officers
description: A 24-year-old parolee pleaded guilty yesterday to killing a police officer and wounding two others in a shooting last February in the Bronx.

title: ALMOST ONE IN 5 MAY HAVE MENTAL DISORDER
description: Almost one adult American in five has a mental disorder and the rates are about equal for men and women, according to a federally sponsored survey, the most comprehensive ever done of psychiatric problems in the United States.

title: ;  Olympic Bonus
description: Peter Ueberroth has been given a $475,000 merit bonus by the Los Angeles Olympic Organization Committee. Ueberroth served as president of the L.A.O.O.C. without pay from Jan. 1 until taking over Monday as baseball commissioner, a job in which he will be paid $400,000 a year. The Los Angeles Olympics realized a surplus of about $150 million.

title: HOW QUICKLY A DRIVE WAS FORGOTTEN
description: Whatever happened to the Republican Party campaign to lift the 55-mile-per-hour speed limit?

title: Dow Declines 7.62 on Rate Worries
description: The stock market finished moderately lower yesterday as investors remained concerned that interest rates would stay high in the near term. Trading was more active.

title: Adams Drug Backs $100 Million Offer
description: The Adams Drug Company, which operates about 420 drugstores in the Northeast, said yesterday that it had agreed in principle to be acquired for $24.39 a share, or almost $100 million. The buyer was not identified.

title: WEDNESDAY SPORTS Baseball
description: Cubs vs. San Diego Padres, National League championship series, second game, at Chicago. A matchup of left-handers: The Padres' Mark Thurmond goes against Steve Trout, who must have learned a thing or two about pitching from his father, Dizzy Trout, a former standout in the American League.

title: IN FRANCE, HARVEST DAYS ARE GLOOMY
description: It's been raining over much of France, and the low, gray sky that seems to hover just above the chimney pots of Paris reflects the spirit of wine makers from Bordeaux to Beaune, from St.-Emilion to Epernay, from Vouvray to Riquewihr.

title: BRIDGE: FINAL DEAL IN TOURNAMENT DECIDES THE CHAMPIONSHIP
description: Unlike those in virtually all other competitive activities, a bridge player reaches the final crunch in a tournament without knowing his own score, let alone the scores of his rivals. But in some rare circumstances he can have a very good idea.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Advertising Column in Business Day Sept. 21 incorrectly reported an advertising assignment made by the Charles of the Ritz Group to Lord, Geller, Federico, Einstein Inc. It was for the Charles of the Ritz brand and the Alexandra de Markoff cosmetics line.

title: 2-WEEK COUNTDOWN TO A REAGAN RALLY
description: Gia Catchot did not want to see President Reagan at a political rally here Monday evening, but her mother made the 12-year-old go.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE ; ;  Van Pelt Ends Holdout
description: Brad Van Pelt was booked on a flight to Minneapolis today, signaling the end of the 74-day holdout of the Minnesota Viking linebacker. Van Pelt, a 12-year veteran who played in five Pro Bowls, was traded by the Giants in July.

title: Corporate Women
description: What do the American Stock Exchange, Avon Products, Coca-Cola, Control Data Corporation, Esmark, Gulf Oil, Hallmark Cards, Hershey Foods and St. Joe Minerals have in common? In the wide corporate world, perhaps not much, but, confronting the Government, they share the distinction of having Washington offices headed by women. These trend-setting chief lobbyists are among 13 who to be honored tonight at a Capitol Hill reception by the National Women's Economic Alliance, an educational group dedicated to promoting broader entrepreneurial opportunities for women in business and finance.

title: Family's Move to Sell CFS Continental Stake
description: ''Since we went public in 1970, we haven't really considered this as a family company,'' said Philip Cohn, chairman and chief executive officer of CFS Continental Inc. ''But agreeing to sell our interests was nevertheless a tremendously emotional decision.''

title: ALEC MCCOWEN TALKS OF KIPLING AND VANITY
description: ''I guess it's vanity,'' replied Alec McCowen when a visitor asked him why he appeared in so many one-man shows.

title: Health Field Acquisition The Republic Health Corporation agreed to acquire Health
description: Resources of America, both

title: Knicks' Webster Hospitalized;  Blood Tests Ordered
description: The Knicks' problems at the center position mounted today when Marvin Webster was hospitalized for more extensive blood tests. Webster's pre- training camp physical examination, including various blood tests taken last week, revealed what the Knicks called ''some abnormalities in his blood chemistry.''

title: A Campaign Fever
description: They say national campaigns are

title: A.M.C. to Import Renault Mini-Van
description: The American Motors Corporation said it would import a mini-van for the 1986 model year from Regie Nationale des Usines Renault of France. A.M.C. said it would bring in 15,000 models a year of the front-wheel-drive Renault Espace.

title: Episcopal Priest in Maryland Is Found Stabbed to Death
description: An Episcopal priest was found stabbed to death today at his renovated rowhouse here, police officials said.

title: County Official Wins Florida Runoff Election
description: Pat Glass, a Democrat, overcame a low voter turnout today to win a runoff election and the right to challenge Representative Andy Ireland for his 10th Congressional District seat.

title: Study Warns Surgeons To Wait on Bypasses
description: A new study warns surgeons to avoid performing coronary bypass operations if the arteries to be bypassed are less than 50 percent blocked by fatty deposits.

title: ON INDIAN SUMMER, OLD FARMER'S ALMANAC AND OTHER THINGS
description: WHEN early fall weather turns sunny and balmy, most people are quick to call it Indian summer. But Indian summer occurs only between Nov. 11 and Nov. 20.

title: AN EAST GERMAN IS ARRESTED AS SPY
description: A 67-year-old East German woman was arrested at Kennedy International Airport Monday night as she was about to board a flight for Czechoslovakia with a tape recording of classified United States military information hidden in a cigarette pack, Federal authorities said yesterday.

title: Arabs Clash With the Police During Protest in Jerusalem
description: Israeli mounted policemen and border patrolmen armed with riot sticks broke up a demonstration of some 200 Arabs outside the United States Consulate in a former Jordanian sector of Jerusalem today.

title: HAITI REPLENISHING A MOST VALUABLE ASSET: THE PIG
description: -AU-PRINCE, Haiti - Until recently, pigs were the most often-seen animals in the impoverished countryside of Haiti, where most peasants kept them as kind of living savings accounts. But they are rarely seen now.

title: DANCE: 'KUTZTOWN CONNECTION'
description: '' THE KUTZTOWN CONNECTION,'' presented Friday night at Symphony Space, made it clear that the arts are alive in Kutztown, Pa. The event was the first in a series of three weekend benefit performances for the New Arts Program which, under James F. L. Carroll's direction, has brought artists to Kutztown since 1974.

title: GREEKS TO BE IN CREW OF U.S. AWACS PLANES NEXT YEAR, ATHENS SAYS
description: Greece announced today that joint Greek-American crews would begin flying American Awacs reconnaissance planes on regular missions to ''control the airspace'' over Greece next year.

title: Cold Peace Around Israel
description: Israel and its neighbors are backing away from both war and diplomacy toward a new equilibrium of forces. As Secretary of State Shultz wisely recognizes, the most useful immediate American response is to stand clear of the process.

title: Playoff Marks Tumble The Chicago Cubs' 13-0 rout of the San Diego Padres in the first game of the National League playoffs yesterday marked more than a Wrigley field day for triskaidekaphiles in the Second City.
description: The 13-run differential also represented the largest winning margin in a playoff game since the playoffs were established in 1969, exceeding an 11-run margin in the Los Angeles Dodgers' 12-1 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates in 1974 and a 10-run margin in the Yankees' 13-3 victory over the Oakland A's in 1981.

title: Harris Poll Gives Reagan 13-Point Lead in Race
description: President Reagan holds a lead of 13 percentage points over Walter F. Mondale, the Democratic nominee, but is vulnerable on the issues of the bombing of the American Embassy in Lebanon and religion in politics, a new nationwide Harris poll indicated today.

title: CUOMO MANSION ROBBED WHILE FAMILY IS ASLEEP
description: The Executive Mansion in Albany was broken into early yesterday and several objects were taken while Governor Cuomo, his wife and two of their children were asleep.

title: POLAND SAYS CHURCH IS MISUSING RELIGION FOR POLITICAL AIMS
description: The Government accused Poland's Roman Catholic Church today of using religion for political purposes and indicated it was delaying a high-level church-state meeting as a consequence.

title: ISRAEL PUTS CURB ON LUXURY GOODS
description: The Israeli Government announced a six- month ban tonight on imports of some 50 ''luxury'' products ranging from cosmetic pencils and beer to air conditioners and automobiles.

title: PACT TO DELAY VOTE ELUDES NICARAGUANS
description: Nicaraguan Government and opposition leaders announced tonight that they had failed to reach agreement on postponing next month's general elections as a step toward insuring the participation of a leading opposition coalition.

title: SCOUTING;
description: Helping Hand For Hearns

title: ;  A Word for the Defense TO THE LIVING SECTION:
description: Just had to write in defense of Pierre Franey, who, I feel, was unfairly criticized by a reader concerning his selection of recipes for the ''60- Minute Gourmet'' column on Aug. 29 (grilled lamb steaks with parsley and zucchini au gratin).

title: DRUG TIE GAVE INFORMER MUCH TO TELL
description: Tommaso Buscetta, the gangster whose revelations have spurred dozens of arrests in Italy and the United States, was able to help investigators because of his strategic position in the international drug trade.

title: A PUZZLE FOR PARENTS: GOOD TOUCHING OR BAD?
description: HARDLY a day seems to pass without news that someone has been arrested on charges of sexually abusing children. Staff members at a day-care center in Manhattan Beach, Calif., teachers at day- care facilities in New York, adults in Jordan, Minn. - all are being prosecuted in incidents involving child molestation.

title: SPECTRO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 12
description: The net for the latest periods includes a non-taxable gain of $898,000 from life insurance proceeds.

title: Samoan Governor Ineligible
description: Interior Secretary William P. Clark said today that he would not interfere with an American Samoan court ruling that declared Gov. Peter Tali Coleman ineligible for a third consecutive term. The Samoan court ordered the chief election officer to strike the Governor's name from the Nov. 6 ballot. Governor Coleman had petitioned the Interior Secretary, who is authorized to intervene in such matters because of certain jurisdiction over the Pacific Islands, which are a United States possession.

title: COURIER DISPATCH GROUP r to June 30 reports earnings for 1984
description: b-Including an extraordinary gain of $355,000.

title: TAKEOVER IS PRAISED IN LONDON
description: The London financial community today began the long process of deciding what to make of Monday's emergency takeover of the banking and bullion trading operations of Johnson Matthey P.L.C. by the Bank of England.

title: In Slow Motion
description: The awesome Federal deficit is

title: HEALTH INFORMATION SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: FERRARO CONFRONTS ILLINOIS WORKERS ABOUT THEIR SUPPORT FOR REAGAN
description: Geraldine A. Ferraro, with union leaders hovering around, toured a Chrysler assembly line this morning in Rockford, Ill.

title: 2 HOUSE PANELS APPROVE A RESOLUTION TO MOVE U.S. EMBASSY TO JERUSALEM
description: Over the objections of the Administration, two House Foreign Affairs subcommittees in Washington approved a nonbinding resolution yesterday to move the United States Embassy in Israel from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem.

title: STATUS GAME CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
MONDALE URGES REAGAN TO MAKE DONOVAN QUERY
description: Walter F. Mondale, terming the Reagan Administration ethically ''tacky,'' called on the President today to make his own inquiry into the indictment of Labor Secretary Raymond J. Donovan and to dismiss him if he found ''reasonable grounds'' that the charges were valid.

title: OPEC Export Outlook
description: The combined oil export revenues of OPEC's 13 members will rise to $170.1 billion this year from $157 billion in 1983, the OPEC Secretariat forecast today. The forecast, published in the latest bulletin of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, said OPEC's combined trade deficit is forecast to narrow to $11 billion this year from $16.8 billion in 1983.

title: CONNA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 19
No Headline
description: WEDNESDAY, OCTOBER 3, 1984 International Egypt's President accused Libya of having plotted to attack Egypt's Aswan High Dam and the Suez Canal. President Hosni Mubarak was quoted in an Egyptian newspaper as saying that after learning of the plots, he had sent a letter to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader, containing what he called an ''unequivocal warning.'' (Page A1, Column 3.) President Reagan took responsibility as Commander in Chief of the recent bombing at the United States Embassy in Lebanon. While campaigning in Texas, he told reporters that ''I'm not going to deliver somebody's head up on a platter, which seems to be the request of so many when things like this happen. (A11:1.)

title: INTERNATIONAL LEASE FIANCE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
CHECKPOINT SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 23
GTE Liquidates Part of Phone Inventory
description: The GTE Corporation has sold 500,000 low-cost residential telephones - an estimated one-quarter of its telephone inventory - to a liquidator who paid fire sale prices.

title: BASIC AMERICAN FOOD COMES BACK TO THE TABLE
description: '' IT'S incredible how people soothe themselves with food from the past,'' said Lynne Bien, who turns out one of the most soothing chicken potpies around at her restaurant and carryout called Pie in the Sky on Third Avenue near 17th Street. ''Our taste buds are formed in our early years and no matter how sophisticated we become in dining, we always seem to have a hankering for those foods. I can see it in the reaction of our customers.''

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: AN editor in the home-furnishings field had a lunch date with a Japanese architect and his wife. The editor arrived at the Edwardian Room of the Plaza to find the couple standing outside, looking nonplussed. The architect, who was fashionably dressed in a beige shirt and pants by Issey Miyake, had been told that he could not enter without a jacket. The Plaza had provided a jacket - ''a drab, drippy, dark-colored thing,'' the editor told us - but the architect could not bring himself to wear it.

title: Court Will Not Allow Nuclear Plant to Open
description: A Federal appeals court has declined to allow the Diablo Canyon nuclear power plant to go into immediate operation on the California coast.

title: KAUFMAN & BROAD INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Including tax credits of $2.6 million for the quarter and $5 million for the 9 months. c-Including a tax credit of $800,000 for the quarter and 9 months.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;
description: 'Diaries' on Tape

title: OVERSEAS ARM OF MAFIA TIED TO U.S. CRIME
description: Federal prosecutors said yesterday that investigators had uncovered evidence of a previously unknown United States arm of the Sicilian Mafia that operated independently of American organized crime.

title: A RUNAWAY PENTAGON
description: At a recent internal Pentagon briefing concerning the fiscal 1986 defense budget, the Air Force speaker raised irony to a new level. A tentative budget of ''only'' $109 billion, he said, placed ''severe fiscal constraints'' on the Air Force. This conviction, shared equally by the Army and Navy, is as unconvincing as the kid who laps down a three- scoop ice cream cone and says he's ''still hungry.'' But the remark is revealing. Despite the biggest sustained budget growth since the World War II mobilization, the Pentagon still regards a shortage of money as the main obstacle to a full renaissance of American military power.

title: COUNTIES PRESS STATE TO PAY FOR HOUSING STATE PRISONERS
description: Five counties around New York City today moved to force the state to reimburse them for the costs of housing inmates sentenced to state prisons.

title: WHEN 'EXTRA MEASURES' MERELY PROLONG DYING
description: To the Editor:

title: SUMMIT ENERGY INC reports earnings for Year to July 31
description: The latest period's earnings include a gain of $715,801 from the sale of property in Denver.

title: EQUITY IN TALKS FOR NEW OFF BROADWAY CONTRACT
description: Negotiations are under way between Actors Equity and the League of Off Broadway Theaters and Producers on a new contract to replace one that expires Oct. 7.

title: Polysilicon Plant
description: The Wacker Siltronic Corporation said it would build a polysilicon production plant in Portland, which would be the world's largest. Polysilicon is a major component in the wafer chips used in transistorized electronic equipment. An official said shipments should begin by 1987.

title: PLAYERS' SUPPORT FOR UMPIRES SEEN
description: Richie Phillips, the general counsel for the major league umpires, yesterday raised the specter of the players' lending support to the umpires' strike of the league championship series. However, there was no immediate indication from the players as to whether they would become involved.

title: REAGAN ASSUMES RESPONSIBILITY FOR EMBASSY
description: President Reagan said today that, as Commander in Chief, he accepted full responsibility in the recent explosion at the United States Embassy in Lebanon.

title: Texas Instruments' Symbol Computer
description: Texas Instruments introduced its first computer designed for the development of artificial intelligence programs.

title: EASY GAME FOR THE UMPIRES
description: They had all heard what they were called: Amateurs. A strike of major league umpires today caused the first game of the National League championship series, the most significant baseball game the North Side has seen in nearly four decades, to change hands from a crew of six league umpires chosen on merit to a four-man crew whose experience consisted mostly of high school, college and American Legion games.

title: AMPAD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 1
CAST-IRON MUFFIN MOLD
description: THE Pennsylvania ''Deutsch,'' or Pennyslvania Dutch as they are commonly known, came to this country in the 18th century with a yearning for religious freedom. Their other passion was baking. Muffins, cookies, shortbreads and all varieties of fruit pies, from the now-standard apple and cherry to more esoteric creations such as shoofly pie (made with molasses) and funeral pie (with lemon and raisins), were their specialties.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: Vitaman C enthusiasts, move over. Garlic may be at least as effective as your chosen nostrum in warding off the common cold. People throughout the world have used it for years as a ''blood cleanser'' and cold preventive.

title: Advertising; Making A Name In Wine
description: BEHIND those bottles of Amburu wine that appeared in television advertising for the first time over the weekend are a pair of Peruvian-born brothers with strong marketing backgrounds.

title: Chicago Politicians Resolve Airport Dispute
description: Mayor Harold Washington, yielding to pressure from the City Council majority bloc, has agreed to the creation of a board to review no-bid contracts, clearing the way for work to continue on a $1.4 billion expansion of O'Hare Airport.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Oct. 3, 1984 GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In million of barrels except refinery utilization

title: MUSIC/NOTED IN BRIEF;
description: St. Luke's Ensemble In Evening of Bach

title: GRANDMA LEE'S INC reports earnings for Year to June 30
ABOUT NEW YORK
description: He wishes he had more time, but he must be on his way. Philip Copp says he is possessed by demon steel serpents that clatter through the earth below and will not let him be.

title: MDS HEALTH GROUP LTD reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
GELBART HOLDS SEMINARS ON COMEDY AT MUSEUM
description: Larry Gelbart, who wrote television jokes for Bob Hope's first video monologue during the Truman Administration but imprinted his name in the medium by developing the television series ''M*A*S*H,'' sat under a screen at the Museum of Broadcasting last night.

title: MERGER MOVES IN ACCOUNTING
description: These days the partners at Price Waterhouse and Deloitte Haskins & Sells are making the rounds in Washington and huddling with clients across the country to ease any apprehensions over the prospective marriage of the two huge accounting firms.

title: A PLACE FOR VANS IN NEW YORK CITY TRANSIT
description: To the Editor:

title: BERGEN BRUNSWIG CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $644,000 for the quarter and $2,444,000 for the year. c-After a loss of $5,178,000 from discontinued operations.

title: NEW-HOME SALES SLIP 8.1 PERCENT
description: New-home sales fell for the second consecutive month in August, dropping 8.1 percent as all parts of the country reported downturns, the Government reported today.

title: A NEW CROP OF WHITE ITALIAN TRUFFLES ARRIVING IN NEW YORK
description: THE first white truffles are arriving in New York's restaurants and markets. These expensive Italian tubers have an intense perfume and a glamour and excitement utterly belied by their appearance, which is not unlike a collection of old, dirty and misshapen Ping-Pong balls. But shave them raw over a creamy risotto or a plate of homemade taglierini or gently scrambled, buttery eggs and they transform this homely fare into something opulent.

title: Guinea Marks Independence For the First Time in 14 Years
description: Guinea celebrated Independence Day today for the first time in 14 years.

title: China Fights Textile Rules
description: China has asked the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade to intervene in a dispute between Peking and Washington over United States textile import restrictions, the New China News Agency reported today.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Becton, Dickinson & Co., Paramus, N.J., a manufacturer of health care products, has appointed Robert W. Alpers corporate vice president of manufacturing; Robert E. Flaherty president of the Becton-Dickinson division, and Alfred J. Battaglia president of the Becton-Dickinson Vacutainer Systems division.

title: Hill & Knowlton To Open Peking Office
description: China is about to receive the ultimate in recognition from the communicators of the West - its first office of an international public relations firm.

title: Navy Plane Job For McDonnell
description: The Navy has awarded the McDonnell Douglas Corporation a contract for 300 new training planes, based on a British design, at a cost of $438 million, the Navy said today.

title: SPY PHOTOS' SALE LEADS TO ARREST
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation said today that it had arrested a United States naval analyst and charged him with selling classified satellite photographs of a Soviet ship to a British weekly defense publication.

title: MILLER, HERMAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 1
Savio Back at Berkeley 20 Years After Big Rally
description: Mario Savio, the ''silver tongued orator'' who helped begin the Free Speech Movement 20 years ago, marked its anniversary today by urging students to prevent a ''blood bath'' in Central America.

title: 11 CENTURIES OF JAPANESE CALLIGRAPHY
description: A borrowed art that profoundly affected Japanese culture is on rare display starting today at the Japan and Asia Societies. The exhibition, ''Masters of Japanese Calligraphy: Eighth to 19th Century,'' is said to be the first in this country to present a comprehensive survey of the subject.

title: HOMEMADE DANISH PASTRY ISN'T EASY, BUT IT IS REWARDING
description: GOOD cooks always take it as a compliment when someone who has just tasted their handiwork says, ''You simply must give me the recipe for that.'' In certain cases the eager would-be imitator finds the granting of such a request rather more than was bargained for. There are some culinary triumphs that are at least three- fourths technique. Acquiring the recipe is hardly even the start of the prologue to the beginning of the dish.

title: U.S. ATTORNEY IN CLEVELAND IS DISCHARGED BY PRESIDENT
description: President Reagan has ordered that the United States Attorney in Cleveland, J. William Petro, be dismissed from office immediately, White House officials said today.

title: Economic Scene; Slowing Trend In '85 Forecast
description: Is the economy heading for a recession in 1985?

title: No Headline
description: Nikolais/Louis Alumni To Give Benefit Dance

title: NEW YORK'S INFLUENTIAL PEOPLE CELEBRATE MILESTONE FOR A MAN OF INFLUENCE
description: Early this year, Diana Ross faced a public-relations problem that was assuming huge proportions.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: ON TOP OF TAPS For many years it seemed as if taps had sounded for tap dancing, which decades ago was a staple on the shelf of show business. But tap, particularly jazz tap, has clacked its way back to public favor more recently, returning to the spotlight many of the old-time greats and spawning a new generation of practitioners.

title: CUOMO AND OPTIONS
description: Governor Cuomo put himself - and some of the state's other Democrats as well - in a difficult political position with his statement that he would not run for re-election in 1986 if he decided to run for President in 1988.
