The comment, in an interview, was so strongly worded that it seemed to leave Mr. Cuomo with fewer options than a politician would want to have this far from the elections in question. It also led other Democrats to wonder whether they should start preparing their own races for the office that Mr. Cuomo might be giving up.

title: MEROLA'S 12 YEARS IN JOB MARKED BY CONTROVERSY
description: District Attorney Mario Merola of the Bronx, who sought and got an indictment of Labor Secretary Raymond J. Donovan, is among the most controversial of New York City's five District Attorneys.

title: MUSIC/NOTED IN BRIEF;
description: Wise Feline of 'Cats' In Freddy's Cabaret Act

title: Tandem-S.E.C. Accord
description: Tandem Computers Inc. of Cupertino, Calif., said yesterday that it had reached an agreement with the Securities and Exchange Commission that ends an S.E.C. investigation in connection with the company's restatement of earnings for the fiscal year 1982.

title: DONOVAN SUBMITS A NOT-GUILTY PLEA TO BRONX CHARGES
description: Labor Secretary Raymond J. Donovan pleaded not guilty yesterday to a 137-count indictment charging him with participation in a multimillion- dollar scheme to defraud the New York City Transit Authority.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ; Intermountain Power In $350 Million Offering
description: The Intermountain Power Agency is offering $350 million of adjustable- rate electric revenue bonds through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc.

title: Cellular Phone Lottery
description: More than 100 companies that applied to build cellular mobile phone systems in 60 of the nation's larger cities negotiated partnerships to avoid licensing lotteries scheduled for Wednesday and Oct. 23. The Government said today that it was canceling Wednesday's lottery for licenses in cities ranked 31 to 60 in size, because competitors in 29 of the 30 cities had forged settlement agreements.

title: TV NEWS: EFFORT TO BALANCE PRESIDENTIAL PICTURES WITH WORDS
description: There is, pervading the Presidential contest between Ronald Reagan and Walter F. Mondale this year, a different struggle of historic importance.

title: RENEWING A 1910 BUILDING ON MADISON
description: When the new owners of the 21- story office tower on the southwest corner of Madison Avenue and 42d Street scraped through layers of old paint last summer to check the condition of the windows, they made a discovery - the window frames throughout the 74-year-old building were made of copper.

title: Executives From Folio Acquire Magazine Age
description: The people behind Folio magazine, the trade publication for the magazine industry, have established a new company, M.P.E. Inc., which has acquired Magazine Age, a five-year-old magazine that covers the industry for the advertising business.

title: 4 KILLED ON I-95 AS TRUCK CRASHES INTO 2 CARS
description: Four people were killed and five others injured today when a tractor-trailer jumped a median divider and crashed into two cars on the Connecticut Turnpike here, engulfing the truck and the cars in flames.

title: Irresolute Congress, Continued Having labored for eight months right up to the start of a new fiscal year, Congress has just delivered itself of a joint resolution to pay for another three days of Government operations. Budgeting so late and for 72-hour intervals is wasteful and irresponsible.
description: It was to avoid such waste that Congress 10 years ago pushed back the start of the fiscal year from July to October, leaving more time for its work on spending and tax bills. Evidently that's still not time enough. At the end of fiscal 1984 last Sunday, only 4 of the 13 appropriation bills for fiscal 1985 had been adopted. Funds for the rest of Government are lumped together in a $500 billion omnibus bill called a ''continuing resolution.'' But even that has been trapped in other controversies, so the three-day reprieve became necessary.

title: Careers; Openings For Math Majors
description: DR. GERARD LALLEMENT, head of the mathematics department at Penn State University, has a mission - to increase the number of students majoring in mathematics.

title: Ferry and Tug Collide In Hamburg Harbor
description: A chartered ferry carrying more than 40 people on a birthday cruise sank tonight after a collision with a tug towing a barge in rain-swept Hamburg harbor.

title: Fake Apple Computers Lead to Indictment of 2
description: An indictment was unsealed yesterday charging two Silicon Valley computer importers with smuggling counterfeit Apple computers into the country, according to the United States Attorney's office in San Francisco.

title: ;  Rich Pact for Aguirre
description: -scoring forward for the Dallas Mavericks, has come to terms on an 11-year contract extension that will reportedly bring him more than $11 million, make him one of the top five earners in the National Basketball Association and keep him in Dallas through the 1996-97 season. Aguirre, who has two years to go on a $2 million contract he signed in 1981 as a rookie from DePaul, signed a letter of agreement with the Mavericks on Saturday, according to club officials.

title: PENNSYLVANIA U. ECOLOGIST GETS $100,000 PRIZE
description: Dr. Daniel H. Janzen, an ecologist at the University of Pennsylvania, yesterday was named winner of the $100,000 Craaford Prize by the Swedish Academy of Sciences.

title: LITTLE EFFECT SEEN AT THE LABOR DEPT.
description: For sharply differing reasons, admirers and detractors of Labor Secretary Raymond J. Donovan said today that his leave of absence to combat a criminal indictment would have little impact on the Labor Department.

title: Burlington Signs Pacts to Haul Coal
description: The Burlington Northern and Western Fuels Association, a supplier of coal to rural cooperatives and municipal utilities, have signed four coal transportation contracts, each for 20 years.

title: A Rockefeller Appeal
description: Gov. John D. Rockefeller 4th of West Virginia has told potential contributors to his campaign for the Senate that, financially speaking, ''I cannot and should not go it alone.'' Today the Democratic Governor is holding his first local fund- raiser at the Madison Hotel, and his appeal to supporters in the Washington area urging them to attend says that his fund-raising goal in the next five weeks in $150,000.

title: FILM: BY JILL GODMILOW, 'FAR FROM POLAND'
description: JILL GODMILOW'S ''Far From Poland'' is a curiosity - a full-length apology for not creating the film she set out to make. Four years ago, Miss Godmilow happened to be in Poland at the time of the Gdansk shipyard strikes that precipitated the Solidarity movement. Seized by the prospect of filming history in the making, she rushed home to New York and raised the money to take a camera crew back to Warsaw. But they were denied visas.

title: Taiwan Buys Wheat
description: A trade mission from Taiwan formally signed contracts today to buy 50,000 metric tons of Wyoming wheat - 22 percent of the crop - for nearly $7.9 million. It was Wyoming's first direct trade with Taiwan, which has sent a group on a 21-state buying campaign to balance its trade with the United States. Last year, Taiwan sold $4 billion more to the United States than it bought, a Taiwan official said.

title: INTER-TEL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: ;  Braves Appoint Haas
description: Three years after a search committee had unanimously recommended him for the job, Eddie Haas , a former minor league manager, instructor and coach, was named the manager of the Atlanta Braves yesterday.

title: Federal Judge's Move For New Trial Denied
description: Federal District Judge Harry E. Claiborne lost his bid for a new trial today when Judge Walter E. Hoffman rejected assertions by the defense that it had been denied access to important Government evidence.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;
description: Saying 'Brace'

title: WASHINGTON ; IN PRAISE OF HECKLING
description: WASHINGTON Fritz Mondale has complained

title: NON-NEWS NONCONFERENCE
description: Ronald Reagan and his aides controlled press coverage of the first three and a half years of his term to the point of making him the least accessible President in modern history. Now that the candidates and political parties are conducting their campaigns for the Nov. 6 election, one might expect to see some sign of change. It has yet to appear.

title: No Headline
description: If surroundings can create a mood, then the bright new international pavilion seemed to augur bright prospects for the top publishers and editors gathering here this week to attend the largest international book fair.

title: SCOUTING;
description: Another Rookie

title: SPORTS PEOPLE ; ;  Esiason Getting Chance
description: His team has taken quite a beating in losing its first five games, and as a result the rookie quarterback Boomer Esiason , a former high school star on Long Island, will move into the Cincinnati Bengals' starting lineup when they meet the Houston Oilers this weekend. ''It's time to give Boomer a chance,'' said Coach Sam Wyche , who announced sweeping lineup changes after the Bengals' 38-17 loss to the Pittsburgh Steelers Monday night.

title: JETS PUZZLED BY 26,938 WHO DIDN'T SHOW
description: Officials of the Jets and the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority are wrestling with the question of why, after three games at its new Giants Stadium home, the team has had 26,938 fans who had tickets but did not appear on game day.

title: Prelate Urges Filipinos To Broaden Protests
description: The head of the Roman Catholic Church in the Philippines urged professionals and business leaders today to join demonstrations against the Government of President Ferdinand E. Marcos.

title: People Express
description: People Express Airlines said it would begin daily nonstop flights between Newark and Cleveland on Oct. 18. The low-cost carrier said it would charge $45 for a one-way off-peak fare and $65 for travel at peak times.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: American Financial Corp., Cincinnati, said it had sold its 687,275 common shares of American Bankers Insurance Group, Miami.

title: Continental Illinois
description: The Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company issued a denial that it had ''reached specific conclusions'' on cutting its staff or reducing its assets.

title: CORVUS SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
EXPORT BILL CONFEREES BACK PRETORIA CURBS
description: House and Senate conferees on a long- stalled export control bill have agreed on provisions that would ban American bank loans to the South African Government and to companies it owns, and set new constraints on American corporate involvement in South Africa.

title: NAVY ASKS G.E. TO SHARE CONTRACT
description: In an effort to introduce more competition into Pentagon procurement, the Navy has proposed that the General Electric Company be required to share with its chief rival, Pratt & Whitney, the technology for an aircraft engine that the Navy expects to buy for the next 20 years, according to an internal memorandum.

title: George Johnson Glad for a Chance
description: The athlete's transition from his comfortably sheltered world of renown and adulation to the real world is rarely easy. The differences are so drastic that often he is unprepared to handle the sudden drop in income and loss of recognition, especially when those changes occur sooner than he expects.

title: COMMUNICATIONS CORP OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
THE POP LIFE ; GUITAR BANDS, AN OLD FORMULA REMAINS VIBRANT
description: IN pop music, fashions change:

title: PAKISTANI, IN U.N. CRITICIZES SOVIET'S AFGHAN ROLE
description: Pakistan's Foreign Minister said today that the Soviet Union's military intervention in Afghanistan had ''radically altered the security environment in the region'' and created a ''direct and tangible danger'' to his nation.

title: Colombian Cargo Plane Is Hijacked to Cuba
description: A Colombian cargo plane was hijacked to Cuba today and the hijacker was taken into custody along with two women and two children accompanying him, a Cuban airport official said.

title: ANALOGIC CORP reports earnings for Year to July 31
YES, IT WAS ADIOS
description: CHICAGO Uneasy on the pillow lay the head of the Cubs' manager. This was on the eve of his team's first appearance in postseason play since World War II and Jim Frey awoke at 4 A.M. yesterday morning in his North Side apartment. He rose and immediately padded over to the window.

title: FOR GALIBER, CAREER AGAIN HIT BY CRISIS
description: The political career of State Senator Joseph L. Galiber has been pockmarked by legal problems and controversies, the lastest being the indictment announced yesterday in the Bronx.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Scouting column in Sports Pages on Sept. 22 incorrectly described Aaron Krickstein. The youngest player ever chosen for the United States' Davis Cup team was Wilbur F. (Junior) Coen, in 1928. He was 16 years old, a year younger than Krickstein.

title: WOMEN RUNNING FOR HOUSE FIND RAISING MONEY IS EASIER
description: Women running for seats in the House of Representatives are able to raise money as easily as their male counterparts, contary to a commonly perceived belief, a study released today asserted.

title: ABU DHABI WARNS THAT IT MAY CUT OIL PRICE
description: The oil minister of the United Arab Emirates says Abu Dhabi may act on its own to reduce oil prices to cope with intense competition for oil sales in a period of sluggish demand.

title: Presidential Women
description: It falls somewhat short of an ardent

title: INTERMETRICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Treasury Rates Are Little Changed
description: Interest rates were little changed for Treasury issues yesterday as market participants said there were no substantial new developments pointing toward higher or lower interest rates.

title: RESEARCH INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Year to June 30
BASS STAKE IN DISNEY UP TO 16%
description: The billionaire Bass brothers of Texas almost doubled their holdings in Walt Disney Productions yesterday to nearly 16 percent.

title: MUSIC: OPERAWORKS PERFORMS 3 PIECES BY CRUMB
description: GEORGE CRUMB'S music abounds in vivid, haunting images, and invites theatrical experimentation. The adventurous new Operaworks troupe takes up the invitation with a triptych of his works that had its first performance Monday night at the Larry Richardson Dance Gallery.

title: New Chairman at Columbia
description: An architect and author, Klaus Herdeg, has been named chairman of the division of architecture at Columbia University's Graduate School of Architecture and Planning. Mr. Herdeg, 47 years old, has been a member of the Columbia faculty since 1973. He wrote ''The Decorated Diagram: Harvard Architecture and the Failure of the Bauhaus Legacy,'' a critique of the teaching of architecture at Harvard University in the 1940's. His latest book, ''Formal Structure in Islamic Architecture of Iran and Turkestan,'' will be published next year.

title: Bowater Offering Set at $75 Million Bowater Inc., the largest producer of newsprint in the United States, is offering $75 million of 9 percent convertible subordinated debentures due in 2009 at a price of 100 through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.
description: The debentures may be converted into common stock at any time before maturity at a price of $26 3/8 a share. Bowater common stock closed yesterday at 22 1/8, down 7/8 point.

title: SYRIA SAID TO SOLVE KIDNAPPINGS
description: A Lebanese newspaper reported today that the Syrian authorities had identified the people who kidnapped two Americans and a Saudi diplomat in mainly Moslem West Beirut early this year.

title: U.S. INQUIRY ON DONOVAN REPORTED MORE LIMITED THAN NEW YORK'S
description: Labor Secretary Raymond J. Donovan cites a special prosecutor's report in 1982, which concluded that there was ''insufficient credible evidence'' that he committed any Federal crime, as evidence for his assertion that there was no basis for his prosecution by the Bronx District Attorney.

title: Italian Inflation Eases
description: Italian consumer prices rose seven-tenths of 1 percent in September from August, giving the nation a 12-month increase of 9.8 percent - the first time in a decade that inflation has fallen below 10 percent, the Government reported today. Inflation peaked at an annual rate of 23 percent in 1977.

title: EGYPT SAYS LIBYA PLOTTED ATTACKS
description: President Hosni Mubarak accused Libya today of having plotted to attack Egypt's Aswan High Dam and the Suez Canal.

title: Report Asserts Reagan Cut Growth of Spending on Aged
description: The Reagan Administration has reduced the growth of spending on programs for the elderly by nearly $24 billion, or $900 for every American over 65 years old, according to a private analysis released today.

title: Chad Releases 121 Sudanese Captured in a 1983 Offensive
description: Chad handed over 121 Sudanese prisoners of war today to the Sudan's Interior Minister, Ali Yacine, a Government communique said.

title: Billy Goodman Is Dead at 58;A Batting Champion in 1950
description: Billy Goodman, whose .354 batting average for the Boston Red Sox in 1950 led the American League, died Monday night at Sarasota Memorial Hospital. He was 58 years old and had suffered from cancer for the last year.

title: SCHIAVONE CO. HELPED BUILD SUBWAY LINE
description: The Schiavone Construction Company is perhaps best known to New Yorkers for digging the 63d Street subway line, which is being built to link West 57th Street with Queens, going under Central Park and through a new East River tunnel.

title: ASSESSING THE DAMAGE
description: The indictment of Labor Secretary Raymond J. Donovan has jolted President Reagan's re- election campaign, but officials said today that they hoped any damage would be eased by Mr. Donovan's decision to take a leave of absence. Both James A. Baker 3d, the White House chief of staff, and Edward J. Rollins, Mr. Reagan's campaign manager, directed subordinates not to discuss the matter with reporters.

title: GTECH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 25
description: b-Net loss

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: MARINADES are prepared and used in all sorts of ways. The combinations of liquids and seasonings vary and they can be cooked or uncooked. Some chefs prefer to marinate meat, fish or poultry from an hour to five or six hours to let the full flavor assert itself, others allow their foods only a brief time in the marinade.

title: FOOK MUN GOON
description: Fook Mun Goon, an editor and writer, died Saturday at St. Luke's Hospital following cancer surgery. He was 67 years old and lived in Long Island City, Queens.

title: HEAD OF I.R.A.'S POLITICAL WING ARRESTED IN ULSTER
description: The president of Sinn Fein, the political arm of the Irish Republican Army, and seven other members of the group were arrested in a predawn raid today and questioned about how a New York lawyer had managed to enter Northern Ireland illegally last August.

title: ;  U.S.F.L. Getting Star
description: Mossy Cade , the Texas defensive back who was the San Diego Chargers' first-round draft choice last spring, is near agreement on a four- year contract with the Memphis Showboats of the rival United States Football League. The Memphis pact would reportedly bring Cade about $2.25 million, some $600,000 more than the Chargers had offered.

title: KOSHER FOODCOSTS HOLD FIRM
description: Contrary to expectations, prices for kosher food products remained stable throughout New York State in the week before Rosh ha-Shanah, and the some items were lower than they were earlier this year. The State Consumer Protection Board has been monitoring prices in response to incidents of gouging, especially in the weeks before major Jewish holidays.

title: DONOVAN ISSUE TRAILS REAGAN IN TEXAS
description: With flags, balloons and buoyant crowds, President Reagan surged into Texas today on a campaign visit chilled by the indictment of Secretary of Labor Raymond Donovan.

title: J. DAVID COURT DATE IS PUT OFF
description: J. David Dominelli may not go to trial until next year on charges that he defrauded investors of as much as $60 million through his currency trading company, his lawyer, Gilbert Athay, said today.

title: Financier Denies Guilt
description: Jerry Dominelli, a financier whose investment firm went bankrupt in February, pleaded not guilty today to 20 new Federal counts of bankruptcy fraud in connection with the demise of his La Jolla, Calif., financial empire, J. David & Co. Mr. Dominelli has been in jail here on four original counts of fraud and one of contempt.

title: ARAB-JEWISH CONSENSUS
description: To the Editor:

title: AIR FORCE SEEKS MISSILE BASE DEEP UNDERGROUND FOR 1990'S
description: The Air Force wants to build a vast nuclear missile base deep underground that could survive a nuclear attack, Defense Department officials said today.

title: 3 RUSSIANS RETURN AFTER RECORD 237 DAYS IN SPACE
description: Three Soviet astronauts who made history's longest space flight returned to the earth safely today and were pronounced well after almost eight months in weightless conditions, the official Soviet press agency Tass said.

title: DONALDSON CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It's a rough strip. When you have 80,000 to 90,000 vehicles traveling through here each day, any one thing goes wrong and things like this will happen.''

title: Boesky-Southland
description: A group of companies controlled by Ivan F. Boesky, a New York investor, told the Securities and Exchange Commission that it had acquired 5.7 percent of the common stock of the Southland Financial Corporation. The group said it acquired its 953,723 shares last month for $33.7 million. It said the purchase was made for investment purposes and not to acquire control of the company.

title: Muhammad Ali Switches His Support to Reagan
description: Muhammad Ali, the former heavyweight boxing champion, who endorsed the Rev. Jesse Jackson's unsuccessful run for the White House, has announced he is switching to President Reagan.

title: Who'll Set the Beat for 42d Street?
description: This was to be the week when New York's Board of Estimate held its sole hearing on the redevelopment of 42d Street, clearing the way for attack on the decay and decadence that have stained the city's center for a generation.

title: Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 12.50-12.75 ** Kenny Index, Kenny Information Systems Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Chilean Communists' View
description: Chile's outlawed Communist Party today reaffirmed, in a rare public statement from its Central Committee, its policy of violent struggle against the military Government of President Augusto Pinochet. The nine-page document, addressed to the leaders of all opposition parties and distributed to reporters, defended all forms of violent protest.

title: APPELLATE COURT HALTS STATE PLAN TO ENROLL VOTERS
description: The Appellate Division of State Supreme Court ordered a halt today to the use of state agencies for voter registration by Governor Cuomo.

title: CONCERT: PHILHARMONIC
description: IF music were ever to be reinstated as a competitive Olympic event, Pinchas Zukerman would be a good bet to carry off a gold medal for versatility. He manages to keep afloat at least three careers simultaneously, as violinist, as violist and as conductor. Far from showing any strain as he pursues his own version of the triathlon, Mr. Zukerman seems to grow more relaxed and insouciant with the years, performing not only with phenomenal fluency but an ease that sometimes borders on the absent-minded. As a violinist, for instance, he conveys the impression that he could run through the entire standard repertory from memory, if only an audience hardy enough to survive the test could be kept in place for a week or so.

title: Big Loss for Renault
description: Renault, the state-owned car maker, announced at a news conference today that it had a $390 million loss through the first six months of 1984, about double what it lost through all of 1983.

title: MUSIC/NOTED IN BRIEF;
description: Northern India Singer At Alternative Museum

title: CBS AIRS TWO SITCOMS
description: FOR years, a situation comedy called ''Happy Days'' gave ABC a ratings stranglehold on the Tuesday night schedule. It was the most popular kid show on television. Now that ''Happy Days'' has gone to cancellation heaven, CBS is quickly moving forward to fill what it perceives as a promising gap. With an eager eye on the Wednesday schedule, the network is bringing forth two new situation comedies aimed at young audiences: ''Charles in Charge'' at 8 P.M., and ''Dreams'' at 8:30.

title: NICARAGUAN, AT U.N., ASSERTS U.S. PLANS TO INVADE HIS NATION SOON
description: Nicaragua's head of state told the United Nations General Assembly today that the United States had plans to mount a military offensive against his nation on Oct. 15 to prevent elections set for Nov. 4. United States officials called the assertion nonsense.

title: COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
SOME FOND FAREWELLS
description: Nothing makes a senatorial heart grow fonder or wax more nostalgic than the imminent departure of colleagues.

title: CIVIL RIGHTS PLAN SHELVED AS SENATE MOVES ON SPENDING
description: The Senate Tuesday night capped a dramatic session by shelving a civil rights measure that supporters sought in vain to attach to a catchall spending bill needed to finance most Government agencies beyond midnight tonight.

title: H.U.D. CLEARED ON BORROWING By Reuters President Reagan has given
description: the Department of Housing and

title: WEDNESDAY, OCTOBER 3, 1984
description: Companies

title: 2 Acquisitions in Texas
description: Tarmac P.L.C., a producer of building and road-making materials, said today that it had acquired two Texas companies for $16.5 million to expand its American operations. The deal involved Chico, a limestone quarry operator based in Bridgeport, Tex., and Cen-Tex, which runs a trucking and concrete supplier in Killeen.

title: F.D.I.C. Studies Shift
description: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation is looking into a proposal to raise banks' capital requirements to 9 percent, from about 5.5 percent, an F.D.I.C. spokesman said today. Confirming published reports, the spokesman noted that the concept of a higher capital requirement has long been favored by the agency's chairman, William Isaac, as a tool to generate greater discipline in the banking system.

title: Gladys A. Tillet Dies; An Activist Democrat
description: Gladys A. Tillet, who was an official in the Democratic Party and a former United States representative to the United Nations commission on women, died Sept. 21 in Charlotte, N.C. She was 92 years old.

title: MUSIC/NOTED IN BRIEF;
description: Galt MacDermot Leads New Pulse Jazz Band

title: Power Failure Affects 725,000 in the West
description: A ''major disturbance'' in electrical transmission lines briefly cut power today to about 725,000 people in parts of eight Western states, officials said.

title: SCOUTING;
description: No Complaints

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ; Executive Retiring From General Mills
description: Donald F. Swanson, vice chairman at General Mills Inc. since 1980 and a member of the company's senior management since 1969, said yesterday he plans to retire on Jan. 1.

title: DRUGS DON'T FUND P.L.O. ACTIVITIES
description: To the Editor:

title: PLAYOFFS OPEN WITH ROUTS BY CUBS AND TIGERS
description: The Chicago Cubs played their first postseason game in 39 years today, and saluted the occasion with a record-breaking burst of five home runs and a 13-0 thrashing of the San Diego Padres in the opening game of the playoff for the National League pennant.

title: AMERICAN MEDICAL INTERNATIONAL INC(a) reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: The results for the latest year exclude merger costs.

title: Jewel Divestiture
description: The Jewel Companies is putting its White Hen Pantry convenience stores up for sale, company officials said.

title: BLISTER WON'T HAMPER MORRIS
description: Jack Morris was limited by a blister on the middle finger of his right hand to pitching only seven innings in the Detroit Tigers' 8-1 victory over the Kansas City Royals tonight. But the injury was not expected to prevent the 29-year-old right-hander from starting the fourth game of the American League championship series.

title: DONATING LABOR DOLLARS: GROUPS PICK CLOSE CALLS
description: By most estimates, Representative Larry Smith, a liberal first-term Democrat from the Miami area, is heavily favored to win re-election in November. No one would have guessed it, though, from his frantic appeal last summer to panel of union political directors.

title: ISRAELI URGES U.N. TO UNITE AGAINST TERRORISM
description: Yitzhak Shamir, Israel's Foreign Minister, challenged the United Nations today to join in a struggle against terrorism rather that spend time on ''contrived and counterproductive'' reviews of the Arab-Israel conflict.

title: Transactions
description: Sent Paul Hartzell and Jack Lazorko, pitchers, to Vancouver of the Pacific Coast League. Acquired Paul Householder, outfielder, and Jim Adduci, outfielder-first baseman, from the St. Louis Cardinals for Rich Bounantony, pitcher; Jim Koontz, catcher, and Ron Koenigsfeld, infielder.

title: ;  Charge of Rowdyism
description: The University of Virginia has opened an investigation into complaints by visiting Clemson officials and fans that they were cursed, subjected to vandalism and pelted by garbage while attending the Clemson-Virginia football game in Charlottesville Sept. 8. ''If all these things happened, we're certainly embarrassed,'' said Virginia's athletic director, Richard Schultz .

title: SURGE IN SAFE-DEPOSIT CENTERS
description: The Zurich Depository Corporation, a private safe-deposit company in Manhasset, L.I., will not mark its first year of operation until November. Unlike most start-up companies, however, Zurich has begun to register marginal profits, giving Robert D. Steinfelder, the company's executive vice president and one of the six private investors who pooled the initial capital four years ago, little worry that the venture will fail.

title: New Voting Is Ordered On Secession Question
description: The South Carolina Supreme Court today nullified the results of a July referendum that prevented the predominantly white town of Hemingway from seceding from heavily black Williamsburg County, and ordered a new election.

title: IN CHAD, TROOPS COME AND GO, BUT MISERY LINGERS
description: At Ndjamena's most fashionable night spot, on the Rue Charles de Gaulle, the French soldiers begin arriving at about 10 o'clock.

title: CUBAN, IN U.N., SAYS THE U.S. PLANS CENTRAL AMERICAN WAR
description: The Foreign Minister of Cuba told the General Assembly today that there was danger of a generalized conflict in Central America and he urged the United States to join talks for a peaceful solution.

title: Pakistanis Say Afghans Are Massing on Border
description: Afghanistan has concentrated troops on its border with Pakistan's southwestern province of Baluchistan, the Pakistan Press International news agency reported today.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: W OOD chisels are versatile cutting tools for shaping and trimming and for creating interlocking joints. They are long-handled, sharp knives with a narrow cutting edge at the end of the blade, and for many jobs they are used in the same way a whittler uses his knife. Like that knife, the chisel must be razor sharp to do its job effectively and safely.

title: Tokyo Aide Sees NATO Chief
description: Defense Minister Yuko Kurihara of Japan had a 45-minute meeting today with NATO's Secretary General, Lord Carrington, a spokesman for the alliance said. Although Japan has no formal links with the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, cooperation has grown closer in the handling of economic and political relations with the Soviet Union and its allies, diplomats said.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The key thing that makes national law firms work is synergy; with the right combinations, one and one can make three.'' - Steven Kumble, managing partner of Finley, Kumble, Wagner, Heine, Underberg, Manley & Casey. (D1:5.)

title: SAY INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 1
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $73,000.

title: RELTRON CORPORATION reports earnings for Year to June 24
description: b-After a net charge of $56,729 resulting from the early retirement of AMF notes and the related penalty provision.

title: SCHACHER GREENTREE & CO reports earnings for Year to May 31
description: b-Net income.

title: GROUPS STEPPING UP EFFORT TO COMBAT FLU
description: Two public health groups will stress increased use of immunization and antiviral treatment, including immunizing of doctors and nurses, in the fight against influenza this year.

title: CHATTEM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: Results for the year-ago quarter are restated to reflect the sale of a subsidiary.

title: Cochrane Chase Acquired by Saatchi
description: The acquisition of Cochrane Chase, Livingston & Company, Newport Beach, Calif., has been completed by the Saatchi & Saatchi Company, the publicly held British agency network.

title: ISRAELIS RULE OUT U.S. AID AS STOPGAP
description: Prime Minister Shimon Peres will not ask the United States for any stopgap economic aid during his visit to Washington next week, senior Israeli officials said today.

title: GALA OPENING FOR SHOW OF HORST PHOTOS
description: P AULINE TRIGERE'S nose hovered a quarter of an inch from the face of a Horst photograph hanging in the gallery while a photographer told her to hold that pose. In another room, a group of button-down art dealers and decorators discussed, between sips of white wine, the virtues of Horst, not sure, however, whether his name was just Horst or Horst Something. In a third room, a cross section of New York's society milled shoulder to shoulder, glanced at Horst's work and avoided serious talk.

title: Key Rates
description: * split rate, 12.50-12.75 ** Kenny Index, Kenny Information Systems Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: New Mexico Sale Of Housing Issue
description: The New Mexico Mortgage Finance Agency is raising $86 million with an offering of housing revenue bonds through underwriters led by Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company.

title: COUNTDOWN BEGINS FOR SHUTTLE LIFTOFF
description: The countdown began today for the launching of an ambitious eight-day space shuttle mission in which an American woman will walk in space for the first time. She will practice techniques for refueling satellites.

title: FEAR OF FREEDOM
description: WASHINGTON A Federal official was talking

title: UNEXPECTED INCREASE IN STUDENTS PUZZLES COLLEGES
description: When Boston University opened its doors this fall its officials spent $200,000 to house 300 freshmen it did not expect in the Sheridan- Boston Hotel for two weeks while scurrying to rearrange dormitory facilities.

title: CAMPAIGN NOTES ; Cuomo Says Reagan Might Carry New York
description: Governor Cuomo said today that President Reagan might carry New York State next month and that trying to get Walter F. Mondale's message to the voters was ''frustrating.''.

title: BAD LOANS CAUSE SURPRISING LOSS AT CHICAGO'S FIRST NATIONAL BANK
description: The First National Bank of Chicago, the nation's eighth-largest bank, shocked the financial community today with the announcement that it would report a loss for the three months ended Sept. 30. The loss, the first ever reported by the big Chicago bank, was attributed to bad loans in energy and agriculture.

title: No Headline
description: The Doctor Was Out, in the Bleachers

title: ASPECTS OF AALTO IN DESIGN SHOW
description: ''A LVAR AALTO: Furniture and Glass'' is meant to show ''not only the masterpieces, but the way in which Aalto thought through a number of design problems,'' according to J. Stewart Johnson, curator of design at the Museum of Modern Art.

title: High Court Bars J. B. Stoner
description: The Supreme Court has permanently removed J. B. Stoner from the roster of lawyers who may appear before it. The Court suspended him in May but gave him time to argue why he should not be permanently barred. He did not respond and the Court acted Monday. Mr. Stoner, who had headed the National States Rights Party, was convicted in 1980 of bombing a predominantly black church in Birmingham, Ala., in 1958, and sentenced to 10 years in prison.

title: CUOMO PLANS UNIT ON 'RIGHT TO DIE'
description: Governor Cuomo announced today that he was establishing a task force on ''life and the law'' to recommend state policies on such issues as when terminally ill patients should be allowed to die and the legal rights of embryos formed outside the womb.

title: 9 SHIFTED IN JETS' DEFENSE
description: Most of the Jets' defensive players were left stunned today - some happily, others not - as Coach Joe Walton made sweeping changes affecting 9 of the 11 positions on their unit.

title: SYMPOSIUM STUDIES CHILD MOLESTATION
description: The United States Justice Department today called child molestation one of the country's most frequent, least understood crimes and said that it might be affecting as many as one out of four children.

title: AERO SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
RICHARDSON ELECTRONICS reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
No Headline
description: U.S. and Italy PledgeCooperation on Mafia

title: ;  Comings and Goings
description: The Rangers signed Ron Greschner , the highest-scoring defenseman in their history, to a two-year contract. . . . Barry Pederson , the Boston Bruin center, underwent successful surgery for a broken hand in Boston and will miss at least two months of the season. He was injured in an exhibition game against Quebec Monday night. . . . Pam and Paula McGee , the twin basketball stars from the University of Southern California, have signed contracts with the Dallas Diamonds of the new Women's American Basketball Association. . . . Marques Johnson , acquired by the Los Angeles Clippers last Saturday, suffered a fracture of the little finger on his right hand and will be out for three exhibition games. . . . Geoff Huston , the Cleveland Cavalier guard, was free on $700 bond yesterday following his arrest on charges of sexual imposition, disorderly conduct and resisting arrest in Painesville, Ohio, the Lake County sheriff's office reported. Huston was arrested Tuesday on charges of causing a disturbance in a convenience store. . . . Louis Lipps , the rookie wide receiver for the Pittsburgh Steelers, will miss the game Sunday against the Miami Dolphins because of a sprained ankle.

title: JORDAN'S MOVE: DISPUTES UNDERLINED
description: Jordan's resumption of diplomatic relations with Egypt has brought to the surface the profound divisions in Arab ranks and has stirred debate about the probable impact of King Hussein's unexpected move, according to Arab and Western officials and Middle East specialists. In interviews in Cairo and Amman in the last week, most officials and Middle East experts concluded that Jordan's decision was above all a major foreign policy victory for Egypt, which under President Hosni Mubarak has sought reconciliation with Arab countries while adhering to the Camp David peace accords and its peace treaty with Israel.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Black & Decker Canada Inc. , Ontario, a subsidiary of Black & Decker Manufacturing Co., said it would close its Barrie plant, a housewares manufacturing unit recently purchased from Canadian General Electric Co.

title: PKS COMMUNICATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SCOUTING;
description: Rowers Reunited

title: Consumers Halts Its Dividend
description: Directors of the Consumers Power Company voted to eliminate its fourth-quarter dividend of 10 cents a share on the company's common stock to save $35 million.

title: CANADA SOUTHERN PETROEUM LTD reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: Results are in Canadian dollars. The company is listed on the Pacific, Toronto, Montreal, Boston, and Philadelphia stock exchanges.

title: Chesebrough Promotes Two Top Executives
description: Two top executives at Chesebrough-Pond's Inc. were promoted yesterday, the company announced.

title: KILEY SETS GOAL OF 1985 FOR A CLEANER SUBWAY
description: About a third of the city's subway cars and a fifth of its subway stations will be kept ''clean'' and free of graffiti by the end of 1985, the chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority said yesterday.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;
description: A Documentary On 'Nisei Soldier'

title: TWO GREEKS FACE WIRETAP CHARGES
description: The publisher and the editor of Ethnos, the newspaper with Greece's largest circulation, will be tried in December on charges of tapping the office telephone of a Cypriot- born journalist in Athens and of publishing a transcript, lawyers in the case said today.

title: Charge at Corning
description: The Corning Glass Works said it was taking an after-tax charge of $13.2 million, or 62 cents a share, against third-quarter earnings because of the repositioning of its North American sunglasses business. It said it would be concentrating on high-performance sunglasses and would supply Sunsensor Photochromic lenses to other manufacturers. The company declined to comment on overall results for the third quarter, but said sales had not been as strong as earlier in the year.

title: SCOUTING;
description: Good Medicine

title: CAMPAIGN NOTES ; Reagan and Bush Hold Lead in New Gallup Poll
description: President Reagan and Vice President Bush continue to hold a commanding lead over Walter F. Mondale and Geraldine A. Ferraro, according to a Gallup Poll completed Sunday.

title: CHRYSLER INCREASES '85 CAR PRICES 1.2%
description: The Chrysler Corporation said today that it was increasing the price of its 1985 model cars by an average of 1.2 percent, or $125 a unit. However, the price of the company's hot-selling mini-van, which is classified as a truck, will increase an average 4.1 percent, or $485.

title: South Korean Debt
description: South Korea will need about $6 billion in fresh foreign loans and investment in 1985 to help repay foreign debts and finance exports, Finance Ministry officials said today. The officials put Korea's repayment of principal at $3.6 billion and export financing needs at $1.9 billion in 1985.

title: EVENTS: PRUNING
description: Street Tree Pruning and Maintenance , Urban Center, 457 Madison

title: No Headline
description: DISCLOSING THE PAST: An Autobiography. By Mary Leakey. Illustrated. 224 pages. Doubleday. $15.95.

title: MONDALE BLAMES REAGAN ON VOTE AGAINST RENEWAL OF CLEANUP FUND
description: The Democratic Presidential nominee, Walter F. Mondale, joined Congressional Democrats today in blaming President Reagan for Tuesday night's defeat of an effort to renew and enlarge the program for cleaning up hazardous waste sites.

title: EXHIBITION OF STEUBEN GLASS TO OPEN
description: It is the land of the Cat and the Butterfly, the Walrus and the Owl; the Cathedral, the Pyramid and the Chinese Pavilion; the Snowflake, the Teardrop and the Stars. It is the sparkling universe of Steuben Glass, and much of it will be on display beginning tomorrow at the company's Manhattan shop, which is celebrating its 50th year on Fifth Avenue.

title: THE REGION ; ;  Bristol-Myers Planning a Move
description: The Bristol-Myers Company announced plans today to transfer a substantial portion of its operations here to Puerto Rico and Italy.

title: THE REGION ; ;  Park Monument Is Begun in Jersey
description: Ground was broken today in Liberty State Park here for a 15-foot bronze memorial to American soldiers who served in Europe in World War II.

title: China Opens Records Of Confucius Family
description: The records of the family of Confucius, kept private for 2,400 years, will be made available to all Chinese and foreign scholars who wish to use them, The China Daily said today.

title: The Burden in the Donovan Case Despite its length and predictable political importance, the 137-count indictment of Labor Secretary Raymond Donovan and his former business associates discloses little about the alleged crime or, if there was a larceny, whose money was stolen. That makes it especially important to bear in mind the obligation of the prosecution to prove its charges beyond a reasonable doubt. It's a burden too often forgotten in the court of public opinion, especially when a grand jury accuses such a prominent official at the climax of an election campaign.
description: The burden rests squarely now on Mario Merola, the Bronx District Attorney. He charges that Mr. Donovan, and others in the construction company he served before joining the Cabinet in 1981, are guilty of grand larceny, false bookkeeping and false filings with the New York Transit Authority.

title: GRANDPARENTS SEEK RIGHTS TO VISIT WITH A GRANDCHILD
description: ''I HAVE four grandchildren - my younger daughter's I can see, but my older daughter's I can't,'' said Edith S. Engel of Larchmont, N.Y. Mrs. Engel and her husband, Henry, saw their elder daughter's children several times a year when their mother was married and living in Mexico. But seven years ago their daughter had a nervous breakdown, left her family and moved to Tennessee. The couple was divorced; the husband was given custody of the children, a boy and a girl. He remarried and moved to the United States without informing the Engels of his whereabouts. When the Engels finally located their former son-in-law on Long Island, they set up a meeting to discuss seeing their grandchildren. ''He was adamant that we couldn't see them,'' Mrs. Engel said. ''I didn't want to go to court, but finally I thought, 'I'm damned if I'll let these kids think we've turned our backs on them.' We love them.''

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: TAX-FREE BENEFITS MAY BE REDUCED
description: Treasury Secetary Donald T. Regan said today that he was exploring proposals to curb the tax-free benefits that many companies allow senior management.

title: THOUSANDS OF CARIBOUS DIE IN QUEBEC RIVERS
description: More than 7,000 migrating caribous drowned crossing two rivers in northern Quebec over the weekend, Quebec government officials said today. Some Eskimo leaders blamed a public utility for letting too much water spill over a dam.

title: JAZZ: GARY BURTON AT LUSH LIFE
description: G ARY BURTON'S polished talents as a jazz vibraphonist and his imaginative skill as a composer have become, in recent years, supplementary elements to the knowledgeable overview of jazz that gives his programming an unusually provocative balance.

title: THE CITY ; ;  2 Slain in Bronx; Roommate Held
description: A 24-year-old Bronx man, apparently angered over an unpaid $500 debt, stabbed one man to death yesterday, fatally shot another and shot and critically wounded a third victim, the police said.

title: 3 New Products From A.T.& T.
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company introduced three products that it said would enable its personal computer to produce television-quality images: a circuit board to produce the images; a second board enabling the machine to display television-quality images from a video recorder, and a third board and software allowing the machine to produce television-quality images when linked to a videotex system.

title: Bank Rates Mostly Down
description: Continuing a three-week downward trend, average annual yields on all but two deregulated accounts declined in the week ended yesterday, The Bank Rate Monitor reported.

title: No Headline
description: ''A LOT of editors have become like migratory workers,'' the book publisher Victor Weybrigh once said. ''You never know where you'll find them next.''

title: TEEN-AGER TELLS SENATORS OF SUICIDE ATTEMPTS
description: Susan Smith, 16 years old, leaned toward the microphone in the Senate hearing room today and said of her three suicide attempts, ''It really isn't worth it.''

title: PANEL SAYS COMPUTERS IMPAIR SOCIAL SECURITY WORK
description: A House Committee asserted today that improper handling of a $115 million computer contract had undermined the Government's ability to serve the millions of Americans who receive Social Security benefits.

title: Bombing at Plant in Belgium
description: -BIJGAARDEN, Belgium, Oct. 3 (AP) - Three bombs exploded today in the parking lot of a subsidiary of M.A.N.-Volkswagen, a West German automobile company that does work for the military, causing minor damage but no injuries, the police said. The Communist Combatant Group, a left-wing organization that said it bombed a subsidiary of a United States defense contractor in Brussels on Tuesday, said it was responsible.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;
description: Restaurant Dish: Saigon Knish

title: 'CAMMINA CAMMINA' FROM ERMANNO OLMI
description: E RMANNO OLMI'S ''Cammina Cammina'' (Keep Walking, Keep Walking) opens with a good deal of exuberant promise as the peasants in a small village in northern Italy prepare to celebrate the Nativity by re- enacting the pilgrimage to Bethlehem of the wise men. There's a lot of rude pushing, shoving, laughing and general high spirits as the members of the pagaent's cast search for the right costumes and props. Says one little boy to his friend, ''You look like a girl dressed like that.''

title: Baldwin Plan Talks Stalled
description: State insurance regulators and representatives of the securities brokerage and life insurance industries failed to agree yesterday on a plan to make limited refunds to holders of single-premium deferred annuities sold by the Baldwin- United Corporation, which is now seeking to reorganize.

title: Sale to Japan Of Oil Backed
description: A senior State Department official said today that the Reagan Administration favored selling Alaskan oil to Japan as a way to offset the growing trade deficit between Japan and the United States.

title: Big Gain Seen For Computers
description: Sales of personal computers worldwide will top $80 billion by 1988, up from about $26 billion this year, an official of Dataquest Inc., an American research concern, said at a seminar today.

title: LOSS TAKES INDUSTRY BY SURPRISE
description: At 7 A.M. yesterday, Barry F. Sullivan, chairman of the First National Bank of Chicago, and Richard L. Thomas, president, began calling the senior officers of about 20 of the nation's largest banks.

title: THURSDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Padres vs. Chicago Cubs, National League championship series, third game, at San Diego. The Cubs come back with Dennis Eckersley (10-8), another of their midseason acquisitions.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Oct. 4, 1984 GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Students Will Vote on Suicide
description: Brown University students will vote next week on whether they want the campus health center to stock cyanide pills so students can take their lives in the event of a nuclear war, rather than die from the effect of fallout.

title:
Market Place;
Bank Stocks And Write-Offs
description: TWO unrelated developments this week seem

title: A NEWSPAPER WAR, SORT OF
description: Commuters who glanced this morning at the white and orange machines that dispense The Washington Times were greeted by an unusual enticement: a black-lettered sign inside the machine's window that asked ''Guess who owns stock in the Post???''

title: VOTING BOARD STRUGGLES WITH REGISTRATION LOAD
description: With thousands of new voters registering every day, the City Board of Elections is struggling to get its records in order for Election Day.

title: BUSH MADE A $198,000 PAYMENT TO I.R.S. IN JUNE FOR BACK TAXES
description: Vice President Bush paid the Internal Revenue Service $198,000 in back taxes and interest last June after the service ruled that he had failed to report about $500,000 in income from the sale of his house on his 1981 tax return and improperly used $29,000 in leftover campaign funds.

title: ;  Coup for U.S.F.L.
description: Two of the National Football League's first-round draft choices this year will be playing together in the same defensive backfield - in the United States Football League. Mossy Cade , the Texas back who had been the first-round choice of the San Diego Chargers, signed a contract with the Memphis Showboats Tuesday night, joining Leonard Coleman , the former Vanderbilt star who had already signed with the Showboats. Coleman had been the top pick of the Indianapolis Colts.

title: NEW RULES VOTED ON TEACHERS' EDUCATION IN JERSEY
description: The New Jersey Board of Education gave final approval today to new rules governing undergraduate education of teachers, a key element in its plan for improving public schools.

title: Yamani's Cairo Visit
description: The Saudi Arabian oil minister, Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani, today called on Egypt to cooperate with OPEC in propping up oil prices in the face of a world glut. After meeting with President Hosni Mubarak, Sheik Yamani told reporters that as an envoy of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, to which Egypt does not belong, ''I was able to explain the situation and the need for a kind of coordination or cooperation between OPEC and Egypt.''

title: SAGE DRILLING CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
BRIEFING;
description: Ode on a Budget

title: Exposition Panel Suggests Fair President Be Dismissed
description: The debt-ridden New Orleans World's Fair should dismiss its president and either cut its executives' salaries in half or dismiss half of the administrators, a committee overseeing the exposition's finances said today.

title: A BIG SEASON FOR TROUT
description: CHICAGO Dick Williams had baked halibut for dinner Tuesday

title: Brockway Closing
description: Brockway Inc., a maker of plastic and glass containers, said it would close a glass container plant in Rosemount, Minn., at the end of the year, laying off about 450 workers. Brockway attributed the shutdown to bottle deposit laws in nine states and heightened competition among makers of plastic containers.

title: FEDERAL JUDGE GETS 2 YEARS FOR EVADING INCOME TAXES
description: A two-year prison term and a $10,000 fine for tax evasion were imposed today on Federal District Judge Harry E. Claiborne of Las Vegas, the first sitting Federal judge in the nation's history to be convicted of a felony.

title: A PROFILE OF THE AMERICAN MAFIA: OLD BOSSES AND NEW COMPETITORS
description: The revelations of an organized crime leader have offered investigators a detailed view of the structure of the Sicilian Mafia that points to a clear hierarchical structure, with deep roots in virtually all of Sicily.

title: SYMPOSIUM SCHEDULED ON AESTHETIC MOVEMENT
description: A growing number of museums and galleries now label artwork ''aesthetic style,'' but many visitors do not know what the term means.

title: 'RUMKOWSKI AND THE JEWS OF LODZ
description: ''T HE Story of Chaim Rumkowski and the Jews of Lodz,'' the fine documentary on Channel 13 at 10 tonight, raises one of the agonizing moral questions of the Holocaust: Was it right to sacrifice, say, 100 lives to try to save 1,000 lives, and who had the authority to make the calculation? Rumkowski, a Jew, cooperated with the Nazis and took the authority onto himself.

title: GARDENING: WHAT TO DO IN OCTOBER
description: Hardy Bulbs Instead of planting one-of-a-kind bulbs in separate spaces, combine them. A double planting makes the spring bulb display splashier and can also extend the blooming season. One attractive combination is daffodil and crocus. The crocuses bloom first, then come the daffodils. Squills team up with early tulips. Anemones and puschkinias are perfect together and so are hyacinths and waterlily tulips. To plant the bulbs in tandem, arrange them on the ground and tuck them in place. Or if a large planting is planned, dig an open trench and arrange the bulbs.

title: ANIMAL CARRIER FOR AIR TRAVEL
description: W HILE larger dogs have to travel cargo class on most major airlines, small dogs and cats can sometimes be carried under the seat. Airlines require that carry-on boxes in which pets are kept be ''hearty, not flimsy,'' have a window and supply adequate room for the pet to move around.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;
description: A Goldin Signature Is News to Goldin

title: Insider Reports
description: The New York and American stock exchanges issued yesterday their latest reports of changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and large stockholders in companies whose shares are listed on the exchanges.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY ;
description: Golda Meir Square And Dempsey Corner

title: British Laborites Vote to Scrap Arms
description: The opposition Labor Party voted today for a policy of expelling United States nuclear weapons and dismantling the British nuclear arsenal.

title: STRENUOUS EXERCISE REDUCES HEART ATTACK RISK, STUDY SAYS
description: Men who regularly jog, chop wood or engage in other strenuous exercise reduce their overall risk of heart attack, although their chances of suffering cardiac arrest are greater during such workouts than at other times, a study has found.

title: THE PREFERABLE WAY OUT OF A RECESSION
description: To the Editor:
