Cuisine Magazine Ceasing Publication
description: CBS Inc. announced yesterday that it was closing down Cuisine magazine, which was operating under Chapter 11 of the Federal bankruptcy laws when it was acquired for $2.7 million in April 1982. CBS sold the Cuisine subscription list to Conde Nast, publisher of Gourmet.

title: 'Millions More' Could Be More Still Thousands of volunteers are fanning out today all over the country to register voters. Their effort is noble but will be inadequate, because of political and bureaucratic obstacles.
description: The ''Millions More/October 4'' blitz is sponsored by hundreds of nonpartisan organizations: the League of Women Voters, the Gray Panthers, churches, students, civil rights activists. There have been drives all year by both major parties. By Election Day, millions will have signed up. But tens of millions will remain eligible but unregistered.

title: BRELAND'S PRO DEBUT FREE
description: It's official. After months of not-so- secret planning, Mark Breland of Brooklyn will make his professional debut Nov. 15 at Madison Square Garden, and the fans will be allowed in free.

title: RIGOLETTO'S NIGHTMARE, THE WAY VERDI WROTE IT
description: H AVE you ever had a nightmare in which the one thing you desperately wanted to do was cry out, but you couldn't make a sound? Almost everyone has that dream, apparently. I do not know whether it happens in life, but in one of his boldest dramatic strokes Giuseppe Verdi put it on the stage in ''Rigoletto.'' At the end of the second scene the hunchback's nightmare is upon him: the daughter he has kept in secret, and from whom he has kept secret his poisonous life as a court jester, has been abducted by the very courtiers he mocks and despises. ''He tears his hair, tries to cry out, and cannot,'' the stage direction reads; ''after many efforts,'' and a page of tense, agonizingly irresolute music, he wrings from his throat a recollection of the curse laid on him, and faints.

title: ORDERS TO FACTORIES FALL 0.7%
description: Orders to United States factories dipped seven-tenths of 1 percent in August, with gains in steel, communications equipment and military hardware not enough to offset widespread declines, the Government reported today.

title: N.A.S.L. Title to Sting
description: Pato Margetic scored his second goal of the game with 8 minutes 27 seconds remaining tonight to lift the Chicago Sting to a 3-2 victory over the Toronto Blizzard and a sweep of the North American Soccer League championship series.

title: A HOUSE UNDER $60,000: IT TAKES WORK
description: T HEY spent weekends in blue jeans putting up walls, pouring cement and staining floors. In the beginning they were willing to live in primitive conditions or amid the debris of construction. And though the process took a bit longer because they were novices, the two couples who recently finished houses in the Berkshires were determined to participate in their own building.

title: GROUP SEEKS OUSTER OF JUDGE IN 'BABY DOE' CASE
description: Two years after the Indiana courts allowed a deformed infant to die without surgery, a group of activists favoring the rights of the handicapped is calling on voters to oust the state's chief justice because the high court refused to intervene.

title: ABORTION: A CRUCIAL DIALOGUE...
description: To the Editor:

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: A $50 million issue of 10 percent tax- exempt bonds backed by the Ohio Edison Company was tentatively offered yesterday at a price of 99 1/4, to yield 10.12 percent for bonds maturing in 1994, through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Company.

title: Adams Silent On Buyout Bid The Adams Drug Company
description: declined comment on an Associated Press report quoting

title: Auto Workers and Ford Discuss Labor Contract
description: Bargainers for the United Automobile Workers and the Ford Motor Company held meetings today on individual contract issues in a new pact for 114,000 hourly workers.

title: Woman Dies in New Rioting Among South African Blacks
description: Hundreds of young people blocked roads and set fire to a post office today, apparently killing one woman, on a second day of rioting by blacks east of Johannesburg, the police said.

title: ; BEHIND THE ROSY PICTURE OF CONNECTICUT'S ECONOMIC GROWTH
description: To the Editor:

title: SUSPECT IN MANSION BURGLARY TRIED TO RETURN TO STATE JOB
description: A man who was charged with breaking into the Executive Mansion early Tuesday tried to see Mr. Cuomo on Monday about getting back his state janitor's job, officials said.

title: BEVERLY CLUB SHIFTS HOTELS BUT KEEPS THE SAME FLOOR
description: Three decades of bridge history came to end Sunday when the Beverly Hotel, at Lexington and 50th Street, ceased to be a home for the game. Virtually all New York's experts, and a high percentage of the lesser lights, at one time or another played there on the third floor.

title: EAST GERMANS SEEK REFUGE IN A PRAGUE EMBASSY
description: At least 43 East Germans have taken refuge in the West German Embassy in Czechoslovakia demanding to be released to West Germany, West German newspapers reported today.

title: QUILTING AND OTHER COURSES
description: Crafts courses on jewelry, patchwork quilts, clothing, furniture and other items are being offered beginning this month. Among them are the following:

title: Petrie Debentures Are Exchangeable
description: The Petrie Stores Corporation is offering $200 million of 8 percent exchangeable debentures at a price of 100 through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: U.S. Is Urged to Give Asylum To 6 South Africa Dissidents
description: Operation Push, the civil rights group founded by the Rev. Jesse Jackson, urged the United States yesterday to grant asylum to six South Africans who took refuge in the British consulate in Durban. The Chicago-based group offered its headquarters as a sanctuary for them.

title: FLORIDA HIGH COURT BARS VOTE ON LIMITING LAWSUIT AWARDS
description: The Florida Supreme Court today ordered a proposed Constitutional amendment that would have limited damages awarded in civil lawsuits taken off the November general election ballot.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ; Anschutz Founder Shuns Limelight
description: Like many extremely wealthy men, Philip F. Anschutz does not like publicity. And, for the record, people close to him do not say much about him either.

title: OGDEN WHITE, 75, EX-BANKER AND MEMORIAL HOSPITAL HEAD
description: Ogden White, a retired investment banker who was active in charities and public service in the health and hospital field in New York, died Tuesday at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. He was 75 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: House Ethics Panel to Meet But Topics Are Not Disclosed
description: Members of the House Ethics Committee have been called to a meeting Friday to discuss pending business, the committee staff director said today.

title: MONDALE PROPOSES ANTIDRUG PROGRAM
description: Flanked by Democratic mayors and representatives, Walter F. Mondale today accused President Reagan of failing to ''match tough talk with tough action'' in fighting illicit drug traffic.

title: AMERICAN RECREATION CENTERS reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 29
description: b-Net income.

title: AID DEBTOR NATIONS' ECOLOGY
description: The international debt crisis should remind us of the ecological as well as the the economic links between rich and poor. For among the hidden casualties of that crisis are the fragile natural environments of the developing countries.

title: HAJI-SHEIKH SEEKS AN ANSWER
description: A year ago, as a rookie, Ali Haji- Sheikh of the Giants set a National Football League record of 35 field goals in a season, missing on only 7 attempts. He also tried 23 points-after and missed only once.

title: Short-Term Rates In Slight Decline
description: Short-term interest rates fell slightly yesterday, while yields for notes and bonds rose modestly.

title: OLANA: SCALED TO SUIT AN IMPERIAL VISION
description: I T was in the early 1870's that a large

title: Sale by Chase
description: National Australia Bank Ltd. said it had agreed in principle to acquire Chase Manhattan Bank's 50 percent interest in Australian Merchant Bank Chase NBA Group Ltd. for an undisclosed sum. National Australia, which already held 50 percent of Chase NBA, also agreed to purchase the other 50 percent of Chase NBA Securities Ltd. The two operations have combined assets of just under $835 million (United States).

title: No Headline
description: On Sept. 26 clerical and technical workers went on strike against Yale University. The workers are members of Local 34 of the Federation of University Employees, a unit of the Hotel Employees and Restaurant Employees International Union.

title: NETS PIN HOPES ON SAPPLETON
description: In virtually every training camp in any professional sport, the players competing for the limited places on the roster can be divided into three groups.

title: ;  Try, Try Again The owner of the Arizona Wranglers, Dr.
description: Ted Diethrich said yesterday that he had talked with the Oklahoma Outlaws about a possible merger of the two United States Football League teams, but the discussions are only in the early stages right now. ''No. 1, it is true we've talked and we are aware they are talking with several other franchises,'' Diethrich said. ''No. 2, from a geographical standpoint, the fact that we have a strong franchise and a good football team, we are attractive to several teams who are looking toward a merger.'' Diethrich added that ''any type of merger has to take into account what the league desires are and the economic aspects involved.

title: KNICKS SEE CHANCES FOR 2 LOW DRAFTEES
description: The college basketball draft has been limited to 10 rounds, but the chances of a player who was drafted after the fourth round making a National Basketball Association team's permanent roster are slim. Sedale Threatt, the Philadelphia 76ers' sixth choice, and Dane Suttle, taken on the seventh round by the Seattle SuperSonics, defied the odds in the 1983 draft. They were the only players drafted past the fourth round to play last season.

title: THE REGION ; ;  Day-Care Controls Outlined by State
description: The State Social Services Department, attempting to prevent child-abuse scandals such as those that have occurred in New York City, today announced new screening procedures for day- care employees.

title: Devils Win, 4-3
description: A rookie defenseman, Bruce Driver, broke a tie with a power-play goal on a 60-foot slap shot early in the third period tonight, enabling the Devils to beat the Pittsburgh Penguins, 4-3. Mitch Wilson, recalled earlier in the day from Maine of the American Hockey League, gave the Devils a 1-0 lead on a power-play goal in the first period.

title: No New Labor Talks In Disneyland Strike
description: Striking workers today greeted Disneyland visitors at the the amusement park entrance but honored a court order forbidding them to picket on private property near the ticket booths.

title: VISA LIMITS ANNOUNCED AT SOVIET CHESS MATCH
description: A press spokesman for the Soviet Government announced tonight that journalists covering the world championship chess match here would, from now on, receive only a two-week visa with perhaps the option of renewing for an additional 10 days.

title: 4 MORE CARS FOUND OFF WARDS ISLAND
description: The police yesterday removed four more sunken cars from the East River off Wards Island, near where the car and body of a slain state police investigator were found on Tuesday.

title: NEWS SUMMARY;
description: THURSDAY, OCTOBER 4, 1984 International The U.S. Embassy in Lebanon was vulnerable to attack last month because officials responsible for security there paid insufficient attention to warnings of potential terrorist attacks, according to a report by the House Select Committee on Intelligence. The report concluded that ''there is no logical explanation for the lack of effective security'' at the embassy. (Page A1, Column 3.) The Sicilian Mafia is a hierarchy, with roots in virtually all of Sicily, according to a view of the organization offered by an organized crime leader. Tomasso Buscetta's revelations accord with the classic view of the Mafia as an organization of small groups governed by a ''commission,'' the leader of which has power over the Mafia throughout Sicily. (A1:6.)

title: MORE SECURE THAN 4 YEARS AGO
description: It has become fashionable to depict American- Soviet relations as tumbling to their lowest point ever in the postwar era. It is sometimes even suggested that we are on a road to nuclear war in the not-too-distant future. But is it all really true?

title: THE CITY ; ;  Helmsley Loses Tudor City Ruling
description: The real-estate developer Harry Helmsley yesterday lost another battle in his attempt to build two high- rise co-operative apartment buildings on the site of two Tudor City parks.

title: James B. Conlisk Jr., 85, Dies
description: James B. Conlisk Jr., the Superintendent of Police in the period of racial and and political strife here in the late 1960's, died Saturday at the Loyola University Medical Center, Maywood, Ill. He was 85 years old.

title: ALPHA MICROSYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 26
No Headline
description: Sicilian Is Found Slain; Linked to Drug Trade

title: CABARET: SARAH VAUGHAN AT BLUE NOTE
description: T O hear Sarah Vaughan in a small club rather than a concert hall is to be made doubly aware of the massive size and resilience of this much beloved jazz voice. Miss Vaughan, who is appearing at the Blue Note through Sunday with a trio that includes the pianist George Gaffney, the bassist Andrew Simkins and the drummer Harold Jones, filled the club with her rich, vibrant alto in the opening-night set Tuesday.

title: WORLD SOCIALISTS PRESSING SANDINISTAS ON ELECTION
description: The Socialist International will try again to obtain the inclusion of a key opposition coalition in Nicaraguan elections scheduled for next month despite the breakdown of negotiations between Sandinista and opposition leaders on Tuesday night.

title: MILLIONS IN FEDERAL FUNDS FOR THE HOMELESS REMAIN UNSPENT
description: Saying that the United States treated stray pets better than homeless people, a New York Congressman complained today that the Government has not made a full- fledged effort to provide shelter for those who need it.

title: Technology; Circumventing Memory Limits
description: IN the world of computers, appetites are insatiable. No matter how fast the latest machine,

title: BRIEFING;
description: An Eager Beaver

title: ACADEMY OF DRAMATIC ARTS AT 100
description: From Cecil B. De Mille (Class of 1900) to Robert Redford (Class of 1959), the graduates of the American Academy of Dramatic Arts have put their stamp on films and theater throughout this century.

title: Pershing 2 in Final Test
description: A Pershing 2 missile was launched on its final test flight today, hurling a dummy nuclear warhead toward an ocean target 981 miles away. The Army Missile Command said both stages of the 35-foot missile had fired and had released the warhead on schedule. Dave Harris, an Army spokesman, said it would be several days before complete test results were known.

title: BRIEFING;
description: For the Record, a Tape

title: THE NEW NATIONAL LAW FIRMS
description: For years, the legal community has paid lip service to the idea of the national law firm. But now a few leading law firms are actually beginning to make good their boasts of having a national presence - usually by acquiring, or merging with, smaller groups of partners in other cities.

title: YALE STUDENT BODY MAJORS IN SURVIVAL AS STRIKE GOES ON
description: For the 10,000 students at Yale University, the week-old strike by clerical and technical workers has meant curtailed library hours, no cleaning help in the dormitories and a diet consisting largely of fast food.

title: YOUNG FRITZBUSTERS ARE REINED IN
description: Their trademarks are a red circle with a fretful ghost inside, a snappy rock song and the phrase, ''Who ya gonna call?''

title: BANCO POPULAR DE PUERTO RICO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
AROUND THE NATION;
description: Postal Service officials today unveiled a $1.5 billion program to build new post offices, buy mail trucks and cars and make other capital improvements.

title: Companies Cite Supplies In Coal Miner Layoffs
description: As 3,000 striking coal miners received support from their union president today, companies moving to reduce stockpiles laid off 2,000 miners who are under contract.

title: Thad Holt of Birmingham, 86; Former Broadcast Executive
description: Thad Holt, a former radio and television executive in Alabama and a figure in the New Deal's emergency agencies in the 1930's, died Sept. 24 at the home of his son, Samuel C. O. Holt, in Washington. He was 86 years old and lived in Birmingham, Ala.

title: BRIEFING;
description: A Piece of the Prop

title: ZACCARO INVOLVED IN LOAN-DEAL INVESTIGATION
description: John A. Zaccaro and the counsel to the Port Authority employees' credit union were to share a $100,000 commission in a property sale involving a loan of at least $475,000 from the credit union, a lawyer for the sellers said yesterday. The lawyer, Stephen M. Raphael, said the commission had not yet been paid.

title: MOZAMBIQUE TRUCE ACCORD REACHED
description: Mozambique's Marxist Government and the insurgents seeking to overthrow it have agreed to a cease-fire that will be policed, according to accounts here, by South African troops.

title: MARATHON PAYMENT REVEALED
description: Fred Lebow, the director of the New York City Marathon, has publicly acknowledged for the first time what has long been an open secret - that the marathon defies Mayor Koch by making substantial, prize payments to the top finishers in the annual event.

title: DONOVAN INVESTIGATION STARTED WITH A TRUCK HIJACKER AND A TELEPHONE CALL
description: The investigation that led to the indictment of Labor Secretary Raymond J. Donovan began when a convicted truck hijacker, bolstered by a guarantee of immunity for other crimes, began telling prosecutors what he knew about a rivalry in the Bronx construction industry.

title: MR. CUB AT HOME IN WRIGLEY
description: -field

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ; Bonn Acts to End Tax On Foreign Investors
description: The West German Government today proposed legislation to abolish a 25 percent withholding tax on interest paid to foreign holders of German securities. Approval by Parliament is considered virtually certain.

title: No Headline
description: 2 Talks Held on Umpires By The Associated Press Richie Phillips, the attorney for major league umpires, met Tuesday night with Bobby Brown, the American League president, in Kansas City and yesterday with Chub Feeney, the National League president, in Chicago as the league championships continued with amateur

title: Work Starts on Site For Carter's Library
description: Former President Jimmy Carter broke ground for his $25 million Presidential library Tuesday despite a continuing controversy over plans for a parkway that would lead to the site in northeast Atlanta.

title: CHECK OF TRUCK IN I-95 CRASH YIELDS NO CLUES TO ACCIDENT
description: State police investigators today began mechanical tests on a tractor-trailer that crashed into two cars on Interstate 95 here Tuesday, killing four people.

title: U.S. TIES LIBYA TO MIDEAST MINES
description: The State Department said today that ''persuasive circumstantial evidence'' indicates that Libya mined the entrances to the Red Sea, causing explosions which have damaged at least 19 ships.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THURSDAY, OCTOBER 4, 1984

title: REAGAN AND MONDALE POLISH DEBATE STRATEGY
description: President Reagan and Walter F. Mondale today intensified their preparations for the first of two nationally broadcast 90- minute debates this month. Strategists in both political parties view them as crucial to Mr. Mondale's struggle to ignite his campaign before election day.

title: HOUSE BACKS STEEL CURB AND ISRAELIS TRADE ZONE
description: The House, taking up the most important trade legislation of the 98th Congress, voted today to authorize creation of a free-trade zone with Israel, as part of an election-year package of measures that would liberalize some sectors of the nation's commerce and restrain others.

title: STAGE: 'THE MYSTERY OF IRMA VEP'
description: CHARLES LUDLAM'S latest Ridiculous Theatrical Company escapade, ''The Mystery of Irma Vep,'' begins at Mandacrest on the moors, in the manner of ''Rebecca,'' then, after wuthering heights of hilarity, it slinks off to Egypt for scenes spliced from ''The Mummy's Curse.'' The evening winds up with a howler, courtesy of ''The Wolf Man.'' Naturally, the entire collage is filtered through the eclectic memory and perfervid imagination of Mr. Ludlam as author, director and star.

title: XICOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 9
description: b-Includes tax credits of $705,000, or 6 cents a share, for the quarter and $1,539,000 for the 9 months. c-Net loss.

title: Dominelli Hospitalized SAN DIEGO, Oct. 3 (UPI) -
description: -time

title: Dow Off by 8.50 in 4th Loss in a Row
description: Stock prices fell for the fourth consecutive session yesterday in heavier trading, with some bank issues among the biggest losers.

title: A PROFILE OF THE AMERICAN MAFIA: OLD BOSES AND NEW COMPETITORS
description: Disclosures that an arm of the Sicilian Mafia has been operating independently in the United States reflect the challenges facing the traditional structure of the American Mafia families that have dominated organized crime in the United States, law enforcement officials say.

title: OUR TOWNS
description: What follows is a paean to blandness, an unabashed testimonial to predictability, the unchallenged final word on 53 years of roast chicken.

title: Japanese Steel Exports
description: Japan's steel exports to the United States may fall 12.5 percent in the October- December period from the July-September quarter, a Tokyo business newspaper said today. Nihon Keizai Shimbun reported that shipments might total 1.4 million tons in October-December, down from an estimated 1.6 million tons in the previous quarter. Major Japanese steel producers attributed the anticipated declines to both seasonal factors and high inventories in the United States, the newspaper said.

title: Key Rates
description: * split rate, 12.50-12.75 ** Kenny Index, Kenny Information Systems Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: ...FOES' 'HYPOCRISY' ON SEX EDUCATION
description: To the Editor:

title: ECHLIN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Shifts in Fund Report
description: Donoghue's Money Fund Report said yesterday that it would compile and release its weekly funds table on Wednesdays rather than Thursdays, effective immediately.

title: SCOUTING;
description: Baseball Ritual Has Local Roots

title: 'SHIVERS', ON POLISH ADOLESCENT IN '55
description: The Polish film ''Shivers'' is a tacit account of the making of a monster. It follows the process by which an adolescent boy named Tomasz (Tomasz Hudziec) is transformed from a quiet, shy student into a budding ideologue in the Poland of 1955.

title: CHARLOTTE CHARLES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
FERRARO-JACKSON TEAM ROUSES MEMPHIS RALLY
description: As chants of ''JES-se'' and ''GER-ry'' mingled, the Rev. Jesse Jackson paired with Geraldine A. Ferraro today to offer a rousing assault on President Reagan's character.

title: Heroin Traffic Rising, Sri Lanka Official Says
description: Sri Lanka has become a major transit point for heroin trafficking to Western Europe, a senior Government official said today.

title: PENTAGON PLAN TO SEEK PUBLIC SUPPORT IS TOLD
description: The Department of Defense today held the second in a series of pre-election news conferences on weapon buying, described by a Pentagon memorandum as part of a plan to build popular approval of military management.

title: PARISH REINSTATES STUDENTS WHOSE PARENTS MISSED MASS
description: A Roman Catholic priest suspended 200 pupils from his South Side parish school Tuesday because their parents failed to attend Sunday mass, but after meeting with the parents today he said most children were being reinstated.

title: TII INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 29
description: b-After losses from equity in an affiliate of $232,000 for the quarter and $869,000 for the year, and a tax credit of $30,000 for the year. c-After a loss of $333,000 from equity in an affiliate and a tax credit of $12,000. d-Net loss after a loss of $698,000 from equity in an affiliate and a tax credit of $50,000.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;
description: An Unusual Kind Of New York Hello

title: Indonesia Raises Official Toll To 18 Dead in a Moslem Riot
description: The Indonesian Government has doubled the official death toll to 18 in a Moslem riot in northern Jakarta last month, and has blamed agitation by extremists.

title: HERS
description: ''M RS. TOLSTOY is your basic L.O.L. in N.A.D., admitted for a soft rule- out M.I.,'' the intern announces. I scribble that on my patient list. In other words Mrs. Tolstoy is a Little Old Lady in No Apparent Distress who is in the hospital to make sure she hasn't had a heart attack (rule out a myocardial infarction). And we think it's unlikely that she has had a heart attack (a

title: BRIEFS ;  Debt Issues
description: Chi-Chi's Inc., Louisville, Ky., is offering $50 million of 9 percent convertible debentures at a price of 100 through underwriters led by Shearson Lehman/American Express.

title: TIGERS, IN 11, AND CUBS TAKE 2-0 PLAYOFF LEADS
description: Willie Hernandez and Dan Quisenberry, who may finish one-two in this season's most-valuable-player voting, both failed at their specialty tonight in the second game of the American League playoff. Hernandez's failure, though, created only temporary discomfort for Detroit. Quisenberry's could be fatal for Kansas City.

title: KIRKLAND, WORRIED BY POLLS, PLANS TOUR TO AID MONDALE
description: The A.F.L.- C.I.O., concerned by evidence that its own members are not backing Walter F. Mondale nearly as strongly as they hoped when the union leadership endorsed him for President a year ago, is gearing up a last-minute effort to reverse President Reagan's gains among union voters.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: SOYER AT COOPER UNION

title: U.S. CHARGES JERSEY COMPANY
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission charged today that a New Jersey company committed securities fraud by distributing reprints of newspaper and trade publication articles that contained erroneous statements about the company's operations.

title: Islanders Lose To Flyers, 5-4
description: With Billy Smith, the usually reliable goaltender, allowing 4 goals on 13 shots in the 30 minutes he played, the Islanders were defeated by the Philadelphia Flyers tonight in an exhibition game at Nassau Coliseum, 5-4.

title: Advertising; McCall's Tries New Medium
description: THE management of McCall's

title: AMERICAN SYMPHONY GETS A MUSIC DIRECTOR
description: -based ensemble founded by Leopold Stokowski in 1964, has appointed John Mauceri to be its first music director since Mr. Stokowski's departure in 1971.

title: KARPOV AND KASPAROV DRAW EIGHTH CHESS GAME
description: Anatoly Karpov and Gary Kasparov drew the eighth game of their world championship chess match tonight in 20 moves.

title: The Editorial Notebook; The Rent Dilemma for Stores
description: No wonder so many storekeepers and elected officials demand ''commercial rent control.'' Owners with stores as tenants in reviving areas are free to ask exorbitant rents whenever their leases expire. Stores providing important neighborhood services go out of business. Prices charged by those that remain rise formidably. Besides the hardships suffered by many businesses and their customers, whole neighborhoods suffer a drastic loss of amenity.

title: STAGE: PARTISAN REVUE, 'RAP MASTER RONNIE'
description: I F Ronald Reagan prayed that

title: FROM ELLIS ISLAND TO A PASTA EMPIRE
description: Sixty-four years after Joseph Pellegrino, 13 years old, stepped off a ship to Ellis Island armed with $20, a worn picture of his father and a knowledge of pasta, a special train brought him today to these low hills northwest of Boston where the Harvard University Band was drawn up in plum jackets awaiting him.

title: Ethiopia Gets Loan
description: The World Bank said today that it would lend Ethiopia $96 million to help that drought-ridden nation improve economic planning and education, and expand agricultural research. The loan is being made available through the International Development Association, which charges no interest.

title: VW-China Pact
description: Volkswagenwerk A.G.'s chief executive, Carl Hahn, will travel to China with Chancellor Helmut Kohl this weekend to sign a major contract for the joint production of VW cars and engines in Shanghai, industry sources said. Mr. Kohl's office would not comment on the report, but a VW spokesman said Mr. Hahn was expected to sign the deal sometime next week. The contract calls for an assembly line plant turning out 20,000 Santana Saloon cars and an engine plant producing 100,000 engines annually, and VW and China will each take a 50 percent share in the project, the sources said.

title: THE CITY ; ;  City Faces Inquiry OnBiasComplaint
description: The State Division of Human Rights announced yesterday that it had found ''probable cause'' for a complaint that New York City discriminated against predominantly nonwhite operators of the Police Department's 911 emergency phone line.

title: DESIGNED FOR MASS PRODUCTION
description: C HRISTOPHER WILK, assistant curator of decorative arts at the Brooklyn Museum, says that ''Eva Zeisel: Designer for Industry'' is an exhibit that ''shows the remarkable achievement of a designer who devoted virtually all her life to designing ceramics for mass production.'' The exhibit - 154 pieces of tableware by the Hungarian-born designer - opens at the museum Saturday and continues to Nov. 16. Included are a covered tureen, above, in the 1946 Red Wing Pottery ''Town and Country'' pattern; stacking dishes, top, in Hall China's 1956 Hallcraft Century Earthenware pattern, and Zsolnay Porcelain's vases with iridescent glazes that were made in Hungary in 1983, above left.

title: Legal Notice 5-2 For Messenger
description: Legal Notice, who paced to a world-record time of 1:53 3/5 for a half-mile track in winning the second heat of the Little Brown Jug last month, drew the No. 4 post position today for the senger Stakes. He was listed as the 5-2 morning-line favorite for the race at Roosevelt Raceway on Saturday night.

title: NETWORKS WON'T ALTER VOTE REPORTS
description: Representatives of the nation's three major television networks told a Congressional subcommittee today that, despite criticism, they would not change their election day practices of speculating on the outcome of political contests before voting in those contests ends.

title: IRANIAN VOWS HELP TO THE OPPRESSED
description: Iran's Foreign Minister says Iran will continue to give physical and moral support to the causes of oppressed peoples around the world, including those in Lebanon.

title: MONDALE TACTICS: SHIFT TO NEW ARENA
description: After failing to make visible headway with attacks on the deficit issue, Walter F. Mondale has shifted to foreign policy in the past 10 days to try to undercut President Reagan's popular appeal on the critical issue of leadership. ''The leadership thing is just beginning to come through,'' commented Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, after greeting Mr. Mondale on his arrival in Little Rock on Tuesday. ''Until the last few days it was as if the race was over. Now people are starting to pay attention.''

title: Washington State Offers 10.8% Yield
description: The State of Washington is offering $163.9 million of general obligation bonds with yields ranging from 7 percent for bonds due in 1985 to 8.5 percent in 1989, 10.3 percent in 1999 and 10.8 percent in 2009 through underwriters led by Citibank. Bonds backed by the state's full faith and credit have been rated A by Moody's Investors Service and AA- by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.

title: SEPT. 21-30 CAR SALES OFF 7.8%
description: Sales of new American-made autos fell 7.8 percent in the last 10 days of September, compared with the daily rate from the same period a year ago, auto makers reported today. Sales for the entire month, however, were up from those of a year ago.

title: DIGITAL COMMUNICATIONS ASSOCIATION reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results for the latest quarter include a nonrecurrring gain of 5 cents a share related to a tax reversal.

title: Gas Heat Ad Irks Utilities The full-page ad showing a
description: mother and daughter, with the

title: Lutheran Bishop Wary Of Religion in Race
description: Bishop James Crumley Jr., head of the 2.9 million-member Lutheran Church in America, warned today that the heated language of the debate over religion and politics could lead to ''sectarian violence.''

title: General Dynamics
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission has begun an informal investigation into whether the General Dynamics Corporation adequately disclosed to its shareholders cost overruns in the company's nuclear submarine construction program, company sources said. They said S.E.C. attorneys had interviewed two General Dynamics executives. A company official said the investigation was a preliminary one.

title: A Smarter Way to Buy Weapons
description: The Navy is leading the Pentagon in experimenting with a novel way to buy weapons. It's called capitalism.

title: CHINA VOWS TO HONOR HONG KONG PACT
description: The Chinese Government, responding to skepticism about its intentions toward Hong Kong, has stressed that it will not renege on a pledge to leave the British colony's capitalist system and life style undisturbed for 50 years after China reclaims sovereignty in 1997.

title: ;  Sam Bowie Injured
description: Sam Bowie , the fragile former Kentucky star who had passed up the Olympics trials to keep himself healthy for his professional career, suffered a cracked rib in a scrimmage with his Portland Trail Blazer teammates Monday and will miss up to two weeks of practice, the club announced yesterday. ''I got hit in the back, right between the shoulder blades,'' said Bowie, who is no stranger to injuries.

title: BARNES ENGINEERING CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After extraordinary tax credits of $24,000 for the quarter and $44,000 for the year. c-Net loss after losses from discontinued operations of $250,000 for the quarter and $165,000 for the year.

title: REQUIEM FOR THE GILIBUSTER
description: ''I think the Senate is beginning to look like a bunch of jackasses,'' Senator Barry Goldwater, the Arizona Republican, told his colleagues in a floor debate last week.

title: SENATE WORKS PAST DEADLINE ON CATCHALL GOVERNMENT SPENDING BILL
description: Legal authority for spending by most Federal agencies expired early today as the Senate, struggling toward adjournment, continued work on a catchall bill to finance operations of the Federal Government for the next 12 months.

title: Nicholas Kiwi Approves Bid
description: Nicholas Kiwi Ltd.'s board has approved a $241 million offer from the Consolidated Foods Corporation of Chicago for about 78 percent of the company, rejecting two earlier bids for the Australian pharmaceutical and household products concern.

title: SALANT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 1
description: b-Net income.

title: GROUP WITHDRAWS BID FOR SOUTHLAND FINANCIAL
description: The Southland Financial Corporation said yesterday that the Carpenter family group was withdrawing its previously announced proposal to acquire the company ''in view of current stock market conditions.''

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Cigna Corp., Philadelphia, has named Norman M. Wayne president of its INA Reinsurance company.

title: ALAN AGITATOR GETS A STAGE
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo.

title: Walter J. Sidor, Retired Judge In Connecticut, Is Dead at 72
description: Walter J. Sidor, a retired Connecticut Superior Court judge, died Monday at St. Francis Hospital and Medical Center in Hartford after suffering a heart attack at his home in West Hartford. He was 72 years old.

title: FRIGITRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
F.B.I. CITES CASH WOES AS MOTIVE
description: It was probably money problems, more than his relationship with a Russian woman, that led a veteran agent to give Government secrets to Soviet spies, officials of the Federal Bureau of Investigation said here today.

title: CARIBBEAN CELEBRATED IN FESTIVAL
description: Kings met kings and queens at City Hall yesterday. The Mighty Sparrow, acclaimed as Trinidad's king of calypso, shook hands with Tito Puente, the Puerto Rico-born king of salsa. Celia Cruz, the Cuban-born queen of salsa, embraced Beth Carvalho, a top Brazilian samba singer. These leading musicians from around the Caribbean Basin were together for what turned into a summit meeting and an autograph session.

title: THEODORE WHITE-TIME BOOK PROJECT DISSOLVES
description: A publishing partnership between Theodore H. White and Time magazine, fashioned last year to produce ''The Making of the President 1984'' for publication next spring, has dissolved a third of the way toward completion of the book.

title: ILL-CONCEIVED PRESCRIPTIONS FOR THE THIRD-WORLD DEBT CRISIS
description: To the Editor:

title: NUCLEAR DATA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: GREEK SEES PLOT IN K.A.L. DOWNING
description: Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou charged today that a Korean Air Lines Boeing 747 that was downed over Soviet territory by a Soviet warplane last year was on a spy mission for the United States.

title: Widow Is Denied Benefits
description: The wife of a factory worker who was killed when he stuck his head in a machine as a practical joke, is not entitled to worker's compensation, the Wisconsin Supreme Court ruled Tuesday. According to court records, the worker, Eugene Nigbor of Wautoma, placed his head in a molding machine on Aug. 19, 1978, at the McQuay Perfex plant in Berlin and accidentally activated the machine when he hit a lever.

title: Nekoosa's President Named to 2 Top Posts
description: William R. Laidig, president of the Great Northern Nekoosa Corporation, was named chairman and chief executive yesterday, succeeding Robert Hellendale..

title: NEW FRONTIER PETROLEUM reports earnings for Year to June 30
AGENT OF THE F.B.I. ACCUSED OF GIVING SECRETS TO SOVIET
description: An agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation and two Soviet emigres were arrested Tuesday night in California and accused of espionage. It is the first time such charges have been lodged against an F.B.I. agent.

title: Ban on Honda Mopeds
description: Japan's Foreign Minister, Shintaro Abe, has asked the European Economic Community to press Italy to refrain from imposing a ban on imports of mopeds produced in Belgium by the Honda Motor Company of Japan, a ministry official said today. Italy will ban the mopeds, starting in January, because it contends they are essentially Japanese-made products. Honda Benelux NW shipped 4,000 of the 51,000 mopeds it produced in 1983 to Italy.

title: DEATH TOLL IS 19 IN HAMBURG PORT
description: Investigators said today that they had found no life preservers aboard a chartered ship that sank Tuesday after a collision in Hamburg harbor, killing 19 revelers on a birthday champagne cruise.

title: ON BEING 'EVENHANDED' TOWARD ARAB EXTREMISM
description: To the Editor:

title: WILMINGTON, N.C., IS PROMISED NEW HIGHWAY
description: For four decades, residents here have been lobbying their elected officials for a four-lane highway to link North Carolina's largest port to the state's industrial center 90 miles inland.

title: HOUSE COMMITTEE SAYS U.S. EMBASSY INGNORED WARNINGS
description: The House Select Committee on Intelligence said today that officials responsible for security at the United States Embassy in Lebanon paid insufficient attention to warnings of potential terrorist attacks before the building was bombed last month.

title: GREEKS REJECTING OFFICIAL ANTI-AMERICANISM
description: Americans living in Greece report a wide gap between the frequent anti-American pronouncements of the Socialist Government of Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou and the general amiability in their everyday relations with Greeks from varied walks of life.

title: CITY OFFICIALS DEBATE INTENT OF RULE ON ETHICS
description: A dispute has broken out among top New York City officials over whether they are exempt from a requirement that municipal employees report to their superiors all meals, gifts and entertainment worth more than $5 and received from people who do business with the city.

title: TIPS FOR DEBATERS
description: WASHINGTON The referee has just told the contestants to shake hands, break

title: Bass Brothers' Stake in Kaufman
description: Bass Brothers Enterprises, controlled by the Bass family of Fort Worth, told the Securities and Exchange Commission that it holds 52,000 common shares of Kaufman & Broad Inc., or 6.5 percent of the shares outstanding.

title: Trout & Ries Campaign For Trump Casino
description: Some TV viewers today might be ready to swear that the private eye Peter Gunn is back after an absence of almost a quarter century. And they will be partly right, since the show's exciting theme music by Henry Mancini will be returning as background for the first television advertising for Trump Plaza Hotel and Casino in Atlantic City.

title: PANEL FAVORS NEW OPEN-AIR STADIUM
description: A state panel yesterday recommended that an open-air 78,000-seat football stadium be built near Shea Stadium in Flushing, Queens, but only if two professional teams agreed to become tenants.

title: Students Are Restricted After One Dies in Crash
description: More than 10 percent of the students at Olivia High School have been suspended from extracurricular activities, including football, cheerleading and band, because they were at a beer party after which a student was killed in a car crash.

title: MAGNA INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Year to July 31
KINDER-CARE LEARNING CENERS INC reports earnings for Year to Aug 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $5,100,000 related to the early extinguishment of debt. Share earnings have been adjusted for a 3-for-2 stock split paid last month.

title: Ex-Biafran Among 250 Freed by Nigerians
description: The former Biafran secessionist leader, Odumegwu Ojukwu, and several former Nigerian Cabinet ministers are among 250 detainees ordered freed by the military Government, Mr. Ojukwu's associates said today.

title: NESTLE BOYCOTT ENDS
description: An international lobbying group said today that it was ending a seven-year boycott of Nestle products because the giant Swiss food company had adopted international marketing standards on baby foods.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: FRIDAY, OCTOBER 5, 1984

title: Rates Post a Modest Decline
description: Encouraged by a lower-than-expected rate for overnight bank loans, interest rates fell modestly yesterday for both short- and long-term securities.

title: IMMUNOMEDICS INC reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: Year-ago results are for the period from the company's inception on July 6, 1982 to June 30, 1983.

title: Papandreou's Remark On Airliner Is Modified
description: A Government spokesman said today that Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou did not approve of the shooting down of the Korean Air Lines passenger jet by the Russians last year, despite his assertion Wednesday that the plane was on an ''espionage operation for the American C.I.A.''

title: 'FLASH OF GREEN,' A BRIBE AMID HONOR
description: In certain parts of the world there's a spectacular but rare phenomenon that, on Florida's west coast, is known fondly as ''the green flash,'' something that happens only if the western horizon is absolutely free of haze. Just as the upper rim of the setting sun disappears beneath the Gulf of Mexico, there can occur, for a fraction of a second, a brilliant emerald illumination of the entire western sky, so bright and brief that it seems as if an hour's worth of the aurora borealis has been condensed into this one dazzling explosion of light.

title: Peugeot Sees Loss
description: Peugeot S.A., the parent company of the Peugeot-Citr"oen Group, expects to cut its losses this year after suffering a consolidated net loss in 1983 of 2.59 billion francs, or the equivalent of about $278.5 million, Jacques Calvet, the auto maker's chairman, said. ''Our objective of breaking even this year will not be achieved, but I have good grounds for thinking we shall have improved results in 1984 compared with 1983,'' he stated.

title: K Mart Plans Financial Units
description: The K Mart Corporation said it plans to open financial-services departments in 10 of its San Diego-area stores. The new services will be provided by First Nationwide Savings, a California-based savings and loan association, and will include money market accounts, Individual Retirement Accounts and certificates of deposit.

title: HIPOTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 1
STAKES CALENDAR IS BULGING
description: Future stallion buyers beware: A horse that finishes in the money in a Grade I stakes this fall may not be all that he seems.

title: THE CUBS FAN WHO OWNED THE PADRES
description: SAN DIEGO Had he lived to see the San Diego Padres win, 7-1, last night in the National League championship series, Ray Kroc would have found himself on the golden arches of a dilemma - to root for the Padres he purchased with his millions as McDonald's fast-food entrepreneur or to root for the Cubs he cherished ever since he was a youngster in Chicago.

title: Ruling Bars Candidate From TV Debates
description: The Presidential nominee of the Citizens Party has no right to demand inclusion in the forthcoming Presidential debates between President Reagan and Walter F. Mondale, the staff of the Federal Communications Commission ruled Wednesday.

title: SHULTZ CONFERS WITH EAST GERMAN AIDE
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz held what were described as ''warm and cordial'' talks in New York yesterday with Foreign Minister Oskar Fischer of East Germany.

title: THE MAGIC OF JAPANESE CALLIGRAPHY
description: IT'S not at all surprising that Oriental calligraphy, an art of expressive gesture,

title: NEBRASKA DEATH ROW INMATE SWITCHES PLACES WITH TWIN
description: A death-row inmate swapped places with his identical twin who is also a prisoner at the state penitentiary, but a sharp- eyed supervisor noticed the switch because one weighs more than the other. The authorities said they did not know whether the switch was a prank or part of an escape attempt.

title: UNITED AIRCRAFT PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Includes $666,500, or 32 cents a share, gain from a tax law change.

title: PSST! GEM OF WATTEAU HAS SLIPPED INTO THE MET
description: IT seems to be something of a secret that now and through Oct.

description: b-Including an extraordinary gain of $159,722.

title: BUSH SEES HIMSELF AS VICTIM OF I.R.S.
description: Vice President Bush resumed campaigning here this afternoon as his staff portrayed him as an ordinary taxpayer at war with the Internal Revenue Service.

title: BUSH'S 'SHALLOW PROMISE' TO APPALACHIAN MINERS
description: To the Editor:

title: LEBANON CHIEF RULES OUT TALKS WITH THE ISRAELIS
description: Prime Minister Rashid Karami of Lebanon, discussing the withdrawal of Israeli troops from his country, said yesterday that his Government wanted to substitute some form of United States diplomacy for direct negotiations with Israel.

title: No Headline
description: Robot as ArtA functioning robot is among the art pieces on view through Oct. 28 at the Clocktower Gallery, Stanford White Building, 108 Leonard Street, between Broadway and Lafayette Street.

title: A Tri-Star Stock Offering Is Seen
description: Tri- Star Pictures, Hollywood's new movie studio, plans to make an initial common stock offering, The Los Angeles Times reported.

title: CONFEREES RECESS WITHOUT AGREEING ON A SPENDING BILL
description: House and Senate negotiators, trying to compromise on a spending measure to finance the Government for the next 12 months, adjourned tonight without reaching agreement. They plan to resume talks Friday morning.

description: Three weeks ago, a Chicago polygraph examiner flew to Washington to attach his straps and electrodes to the body and fingertips of Labor Secretary Raymond J. Donovan.

title: GILLETTE GIVES UP ON CRICKET
description: The Gillette Company, the big consumer products concern, yesterday gave up on its Cricket, the cleanly designed throwaway lighter that caught America's fancy a decade or so ago.

title: WHY GROMYKO SAW REAGAN AND MONDALE
description: Americans should have no illusion about the purpose of Soviet Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko's visit to the United States. The timing of the visit, some five weeks before the election, was hardly accidental. The Russians may not have a very shrewd understanding of the American electorate - if they did, why would they risk enhancing Ronald Reagan's chances by allowing him to claim that he is deftly managing relations with the Kremlin? - but they clearly hoped to influence the Presidential race.

title: MANY TACKS TRIED IN VOTER REGISTRATION
description: There was an insistence in her voice as Heather Peck approached people moving along Fifth Avenue in front of the New York Public Library.

title: Swedish Jobless Rate
description: Sweden's unemployment rate dropped to 3.2 percent in September from 3.4 percent in August and 4.1 percent a year earlier, the Government said today. It said 140,000 people were jobless in September, down from 153,000 in August and 177,000 in September 1983.

title: BURNHAM SERVICE CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
German Steel Output
description: German crude steel production climbed 12.5 percent, to 3.45 million metric tons, in September from August, the federal Statistics Office said today. A metric ton is equal to about 2,205 pounds.

title: Braniff Gate Sale to United Reported
description: Braniff Inc. is selling three gates to United Airlines for $16 million, according to a company source. The sale would give the revived carrier an important infusion of cash during a traditionally slow period for the airline industry.

title: THE DEMOCRATS NEED A UNIFYING THEME
description: The Democratic Party desperately needs a unifying and mobilizing theme - something that has has eluded it ever since the Great Society ran out of public support. We will not find such a theme until we learn the difference between style and substance - and start to think more clearly about what really concerns the American people.

title: AUSTRIA'S FOREIGN MINISTER VISITS KOCH AND GETS DEBATE ON P.L.O.
description: Austria's Foreign Minister paid a courtesy call on Mayor Koch at City Hall yesterday, but the customary formalities for a visiting foreign dignitary quickly dissolved into an argument over Austria's policy toward the Palestine Liberation Organization.

''I always loved old things.''

title: LIBYA DENIES EGYPT'S ACCUSATION OF PLOT TO ATTACK DAM AND CANAL
description: Libya today denied Egyptian charges that it plotted to bomb the Aswan High Dam and block the Suez Canal. It called the accusations a pretext for aggression.

title: Banking Styles: A Swiss Triptych
description: Few people would call Nikolaus Senn a picture-book Swiss banker. And yet in personal style, Mr. Senn, stocky and powerful with a rough- and-ready manner, is emblematic of the bank he heads, the Union Bank of Switzerland.

title: Amerifin's Assets To Be Distributed
description: The Amerifin Corporation, which is involved in commercial finance and banking, domestic and international factoring, mortgage banking and consumer finance, said it would distribute its assets to holders of its common stock at $36 a share cash on Oct. 31.

MET APPOINTS CRAWFORD TO BE MANAGER IN '86
description: Bruce Crawford was formally appointed general manager-elect of the Metropolitan Opera at a board meeting yesterday afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: CHESS: EACH HAD A REASON TO DRAW
description: Who wanted the draw in the eighth game of the world championship chess match in Moscow - Anatoly Karpov, the champion, or Gary Kasparov, the challenger?

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Acme-Cleveland Corp. has acquired Communications Technology Corp. for $33 million cash.

title: BROADWAY
description: THE WPA Theater is currently represented Off Broadway and on national tour by ''Little Shop of Horrors,'' so it's natural for all concerned to hope that lightning is up there somewhere, waiting to strike again, maybe on Oct. 17. That's when the nonprofit troupe, which won a special Drama Desk award for outstanding achievement last year, will present a new musical, ''Feathertop,'' in the WPA Theater at 138 Fifth Avenue and 19th Street. Written by Skip Kennon and Bruce Peyton, and directed by Susan H. Schulman, ''Feathertop'' is based on a short story by Nathaniel Hawthorne, set in 18th-century New England, and designed by Edward T. Gianfrancesco, who is credited with ''Little Shop of Horrors.''

title: TURK URGES CYPRIOTS TO TALK
description: The Foreign Minister of Turkey today urged direct negotiations between Turkish and Greek Cypriots while giving support to the current United Nations-sponsored talks on the Cyprus problem.

title: Transactions
description: BASKETBALL

title: ARGENTINES AWAIT ANTITERROR ACTION
description: In Argentina, two different reports have created conditions for decisive Government action that could help prevent state-directed terror from recurring. One is from a special commission appointed by President Raul Alfonsin to document human rights violations. The other one is from the Armed Forces Supreme Council, in charge of trying the nine members of the first three military juntas that ruled from 1976 to 1983.

title: RUIZ'S 'THREE CROWNS,' IN FRENCH
description: RAUL RUIZ'S ''Three Crowns of the Sailor,'' at the New York Film Festival, should delight students of semiotics and probably no one else. Filled with signs, symbols, letters, forms of currency, impenetrable aphorisms and images that are deliberately self- contradictory, it had easily the highest walk-out rate (at the press screening, anyhow) of any festival selection thus far.

title: NATIONAL INTERGROUP IN MERGER
description: National Intergroup Inc., in a transaction that would take it further afield from steel, yesterday announced plans to merge with the Bergen Brunswig Corporation, a fast- growing drug and electronics distributor.

title: SWISS BANKS AVOID THE STORM
description: While most big international banks have been buffeted in recent years by the world financial crisis, Switzerland's Big Three have been quietly scoring success after success.

title: Discrimination Found In Voter Registration
description: Despite passage of the 1982 amendments to the Voting Rights Act, voter registration procedures continue to be discriminatory in many parts of the country, a Congressional study reported Wednesday.

title: ESTIMATE BOARD GIVES EXTENSION TO LINCOLN WEST
description: An agreement between the city and the developer of Lincoln West on how the project's street system would be built was approved unanimously last night by the Board of Estimate, which also gave the developer four extra months to secure financing.

title: THE REGION ; ;  3 at Jersey School Accused of Abuse
description: The owners of Mrs. Muldoon's Kindergarten and Nursery School and a teacher's aide were charged today with abusing children at the center.

title: GREEN TURNS FROM TV TO TABLOIDS IN HOUSE RACE
description: Representative Bill Green has dropped his television and most of his radio advertising and is concentrating on campaign literature in his bid for re- election in the 15th Congressional District, on the East Side of Manhattan.

title: ;  Spanarkel Departs
description: Jim Spanarkel , the pro guard who had signed a one-year contract with the Milwaukee Bucks only Tuesday, left their training camp yesterday, and team officials quoted him as saying only that he had other options he'd rather pursue. Spanarkel, who has a law degree, apparently returned to his home in Secaucus, N.J. . . . The Indiana Pacers released the second- year guard Sidney Lowe and the second-year forward Leo Rautins , a former Big East star at Syracuse.

title: POPE WARNS AGAINST CLASS STRUGGLE
description: Pope John Paul II issued a clear criticism of liberation theology today, warning a delagtion of Peruvian bishops against ''class struggle, violence and games of power.''

title: BISHOP LINKS ABORTION TO THE KILLING OF INFANTS
description: The legalization of abortion in the United States has led to an ''arrogant cynicism'' about life that has permitted ''the deliberate killing of handicapped infants'' in hospital nurseries, Bishop Francis J. Mugavero charged in a pastoral letter to be read this weekend at Roman Catholic masses in Brooklyn and Queens.

title: DYNAMICS RESEARCH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 8
description: Share earnings reflect a 5-for-4 stock split in September.

title: HUNDREDS ON IND IN BROOKLYN ARE EVACUATED IN SMOKY FIRE
description: A smoky third-rail fire in a Brooklyn subway tunnel yesterday caused the removal of hundreds of people, transit officials said. They said 58 people suffered from smoke inhalation.

title: MORE REVELATIONS SEEN FROM MAFIA
description: Press reports here asserted today that a second organized crime leader might be preparing to cooperate with investigators. United States officials denied the reports.

title: PHIBRO-SALOMAN CO-CHAIRMAN QUITS
description: David Tendler, pushed aside two months ago as co-chief executive of Phibro-Salomon Inc., announced his resignation last night from the large Wall Street investment banking and commodity trading house that he had assembled.

title: THEATER: 'AFTER THE FALL' IS REVIVED
description: IF Arthur Miller's ''After the

title: YUGOSLAVIA'S ALBANIANS: POOR, PROUD AND PROLIFIC
description: The Saturday market in this town near Albania is aswirl with primary colors and athrob with oriental hubbub, with town dwellers and country folk haggling over bags of yellow peppers, soap and gold filigree.

title: FERRARO ATTACKS G.O.P. ADVERTISING
description: For weeks Geraldine A. Ferraro has been drawing ever larger and ever more adoring crowds. And for weeks polls have shown the ticket's popularity, and hers, stuck at low levels.

title: ;  Interest in Weaver
description: Earl Weaver , the former manager of the Baltimore Orioles, will be talking to the Montreal Expos during the World Series about the possibility of returning to the dugout, according to the Expos' general manager, Murray Cook . ''Anytime you have a person of his stature available, you certainly can't dismiss it,'' said Cook, who has been seeking a successor to Bill Virdon and Virdon's interim replacement, Jim Fanning .

title: THOMPSON MEDICAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31

Conferring Humanity on Other Species The gene that produces growth hormone in humans is being integrated into sheep and pigs to make them grow larger. That offends Jeremy Rifkin, of the Foundation on Economic Trends, who this week filed suit against the Department of Agriculture to halt the experiments. But why shouldn't pigs grow as big as humans, or indeed elephants, with a little genetic help?
description: Transferring human genes to animals, Mr. Rifkin says, threatens the ''biological integrity of each species, and represents a new and insidious form of cruelty toward animals by robbing them of their unique genetic makeup.'' These are interesting issues, and even though not clearly raised by the experiments here questioned, they could be posed by the future advances of genetic engineering.

title: GUARANTY COMMERCE reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Ziff-Davis in Talks To Sell Divisions
description: The privately held Ziff-Davis Publishing Company is in negotiations to sell its consumer, and business and trade publications divisions, which make up the majority of the company. Word of this circulated quickly through the publishing community yesterday after Ziff-Davis employees received a memo to that effect from William B. Ziff, their chairman.

title: Court Delays CSX In Barge Takeover
description: A Federal appeals court in Cincinnati has temporarily stopped the CSX Corporation from taking control of American Commercial Lines, the country's largest commercial barge company, CSX said today.

title: TOASTS CARY GRANT
description: Metro- Goldwyn-Mayer celebrated its diamond jubilee Wednesday night with 400 of Hollywood's top celebrities crowding into the studio lot theater for its formal dedication as the Cary Grant Theater.

description: William S. Farish has met Queen Elizabeth II only once, but he is about to get to know her very well.

description: Pantry Pride has confirmed that it has agreed in principle to buy the Adams Drug Company for $24.39 a share, for a total of almost $100 million.

title: Article 248968 -- No Title
description: It has escalators, air-conditioning and up-to-date sound equipment. It has dance studios, two cafeterias and ceramic shops with terra-cotta floors.

title: Renault Accord
description: All the plants of state-owned Regie Nationale des Usines Renault are working normally as a 10-day wave of strikes came to an end, company managers said. The strikes ended after Renault agreed to a 1 percent pay increase and a bonus, and to abandon plans to change holidays. Renault's president, Bernard Hanon, also promised to handle any staffing problems through retraining and job transfers.

title: FREDRICK EATON, A LAWYER, IS DEAD
description: Fredrick McCurdy Eaton, a Wall Street lawyer who took on various Government assignments, died Wednesday at his home in Dublin, N.H.. He was 79 years old.

title: G.O.P. FOCUSES ON HOUSE RACE IN WESTCHESTER
description: Joseph J. DioGuardi, a Republican- Conservative who is running for the 20th Congressional District seat, stopped to campaign at a downtown bus shelter here this week.

title: Home Loan Rate Down
description: The interest on fixed-rate mortgages in September dropped below 15 percent for the first time in three months, the Government said today. Fixed-rate loans for new homes fell to an average of 14.91 percent, the lowest since May. Although fixed-rate mortgages were down, analysts showed little enthusiasm because rates on the more widely used adjustable-rate mortgages were unchanged in September at 12.89 percent.

title: POLITBURO ENDORSES GROMYKO'S TALKS
description: The ruling Politburo said today that it was looking for some demonstration of President Reagan's stated willingness to improve relations, and that the Soviet Union stood ready to respond positively.

description: Richard W. Miller had a record of discipline problems at the Federal Bureau of Investigation long before his arrest on charges of selling secrets to Soviet spies, according to law-enforcement sources here.

description: A diver today found the last container of uranium hexafluoride trapped in the wreck of a French freighter, ending a six-week search for the radioactive cargo.

AFRICAN, IN U.N., DEMANDS RIGHTS FOR THIRD WORLD
description: The leader of Bourkina Fasso, formerly Upper Volta, said in the General Assembly today that, while his country was part of what has been ''maliciously baptized'' as the third world, ''we won't be the world left behind by the West.''

title: Mexican Road Crimes Alarm U.S. Diplomats
description: The United States Embassy here is weighing whether to recommend that travel advisories be issued for American tourists on several Mexican highways.

title: HOME FANS GIVE PADRES A MUCH-NEEDED BOOST
description: Even when the Padres were breezing to the National League West title by 12 games this season, their fans didn't get that excited. And even before tonight's third game of the National League championship series, Dick Williams, the Padre manager, used that familiar California phrase, ''laid back,'' to describe the Padre followers.

title: Hanoi Says It's Open To Emigration Proposal
description: Vietnam said today that it agreed in principle to an American proposal for the emigration of some 40,000 Vietnamese to the United States, including some 10,000 political prisoners and 8,000 American soldiers' children and their mothers.

title: FINGERPRINTING OF CHILD CARE AIDES PLANNED TO PREVENT CASES OF ABUSE
description: The Koch administration, seeking ways to screen child-care workers, is moving to fingerprint the tens of thousands of people in and out of government who work with children. The fingerprints would then be checked against criminal records.

title: ;  Spurs Obtain Bailey
description: The San Antonio Spurs traded the veteran guard John Lucas to the Houston Rockets for the forward James Bailey and a future second- round draft choice.

description: The Senate tonight approved a long-stalled bill that would release to the states about $5 billion for highway projects from the Federal Highway Trust Fund.

title: U.S. AGENCIES LINK A MOSLEM GROUP TO BEIRUT BLASTS
description: United States intelligence agencies have evidence that a Moslem militant group in Lebanon known as Hezballah, or the Party of God, was responsible for the car bombing last month at the United States Embassy near East Beirut, Reagan Administration officials said today.

description: Their season stopped with such abruptness, and ''just like that'' the Rangers crashed into an invisible panel, one they had not anticipated, not given the way they had played.

description: A crew of five men and two women are set to soar into space on an eight-day mission in which they will launch a heat-sensing satellite, snap photographic and radar images of the planet and carry out the most ambitious set of earth observations in a decade.

description: Vice President Bush has no significant legal ground that would support his decision to claim a tax exemption on a $500,000 gain from the sale of his Houston house in 1981, tax experts said yesterday.

title: Student at Tulane U. Killed
description: An 18-year-old Tulane University student from Armonk, N.Y., was found bound and strangled on the floor of her New Orleans apartment and the university has offered a $10,000 reward for information leading to the conviction of her killer. The victim was identified as Karin Minkin by the Orleans Parish Coroner's Office. The police said her boyfriend found the body Wednesday.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article last Saturday on a Federal official's order that three Democratic Governors explain the use of state agencies to encourage voter registration misidentified a spokesman for the Federal Office of Personnel Management. He is Mark Tapscott.

description: A doctor was charged with murder today after the authorities said he had illegally tried to perform an abortion and denied care to the baby, which died.

description: Strong Sell

title: ART: EXPRESSIONISM AND GEORGE MCNEIL
description: GEORGE McNEIL'S career is an object lesson and, in the end, a triumph. This New York painter, whose recent paintings seem to be the work of someone who has been independent and irreverent all his life, spent years trying to keep up with currents of European abstraction and Abstract Expressionism. It is only in the last 10 years that the 76-year old artist has been able to liberate himself from a sense of artistic obligation and begin cavorting and frolicking about in the funny, unpredictable, Dionysian waters that are his alone.

title: 150 WOMEN ARE INVITED TO DINNER ON AMEX FLOOR
description: The final bell had signaled an end to the day's trading, and the marble floor, which had been ankle-deep with a ton of order sheets and other debris, had been plowed clean. But instead of being left dark and empty for the night as usual, the American Stock Exchange was bustling after hours with talk about the status and future of women in business.

title: UPSTATE SQUARE DANCERS DO-SI-DO TO A MODERN BEAT
description: They were triple- scooting, exploding the line and spin- chaining the gears.

title: Jobless Claims Decline
description: New applications for unemployment insurance compensation totaled 377,000 in the week ended Sept. 22, down 4,000 from the preceding week, the Labor Department reported today. In the week ended Sept. 15, it said, 2,351,000 people were drawing regular state jobless benefits, usually lasting 26 weeks, down 50,000 from the previous week. The statistics are adjusted for normal seasonal variations.

title: EDITORS' NOTE
description: Under this heading, The Times amplifies articles or rectifies what the editors consider significant lapses of fairness, balance or perspective.

title: Nine Afghan Rebels To Die for Airport Blast
description: Nine Afghan rebels have been sentenced to death and one to 15 years in jail for setting off a bomb at the Kabul airport Aug. 31 that killed 13 people and wounded 207, the official Kabul radio reported today.

title: FILM: SCI-FI FARCE, 'BUCKAROO BONZAI'
description: WATCHING ''The Adventures of Buckaroo Banzai'' from beginning to end is like coming into the middle chapters of some hilariously overplotted, spaced-out 1930's adventure serial, neither the beginning nor the end of which ever comes into sight. At its best, which it frequently is, it's a lunatic ball, an extremely genial, witty example of what is becoming a movie genre all its own. That is, the science-fiction farce, which includes the current ''Repo Man'' and the virtually seminal ''Liquid Sky.''

title: APPEAL OF FALCONRY REMAINS STRONG
description: For generations, rulers of the Arabian sheikdom of Bahrain have enjoyed hunting with falcons. In neighoring Abu Dhabi, the oil-rich emir, Sheik Zayed, is such an avid falconer that he once sponsored an international congress of falcon experts.

title: F.B.I.'S DISCIPLINE IS DEFENDED IN THE WAKE OF AGENT'S ARREST
description: Present and former officials of the Federal Bureau of Investigation insisted today that espionage charges against a bureau agent represented an isolated event and not a broader security problem.

title: IMPACT OF PROBLEM LOANS BEYOND CHICAGO IS SEEN
description: Officials of the First National Bank of Chicago indicated yesterday that the problem loans responsible for First Chicago's third-quarter loss could lead to write-downs at banks elsewhere in the country as well.

title: Failed Repair for Civil Rights Conventional wisdom holds that an undesirable Supreme Court reading of a law is less serious than such a reading of the Constitution because Congress can always change the law. But the death this week of the Civil Rights Act of 1984 belies such assurances. It died by filibuster despite the desire of nine- tenths of the House and three-fourths of the Senate to revive four civil rights laws eviscerated by a Supreme Court decision.
description: The overwhelming majorities failed because the Senate ran out of energy, time and ultimately the will to outlast Senator Orrin Hatch and his small band of diehard opponents. The Administration helped the obstructionists.

title: 20 SEIZRED FOR BIG GAME POACHING AFTER 3-YEAR OPERATION IN 9 STATES
description: Federal and state wildlife agents in nine states today completed a three-year undercover investigation into big game poaching. Predawn raids led to the arrests of more than 20 people and Federal charges against 34.

title: KOCH TO REVIEW MARATHON STAND
description: City officials said yesterday that Mayor Koch was preparing to review his policy against cash prizes for the top finishers in the New York City Marathon, but the Mayor, himself, made clear that he was still firmly opposed to what he calls ''commercialization'' of the annual event.

title: THE SOPHISTICATED SPONTANEITY OF GILBERTO GIL
description: WHEN Gilberto Gil performs in Brazil or in Europe, he sings to packed stadiums. In New York, he will appear in the more intimate confines of a club when he begins a stint at Sounds of Brazil on Sunday.

title: FROM ROOSEVELT'S OUTINGS TO REAGAN'S GREETINGS

title: FILM: 'TEACHERS,' WITH NICK NOLTE
description: '' TEACHERS'' is Arthur Hiller's attempt to do for public education what he did for medicine in ''The Hospital,'' and the results are very uneven. Whenever ''Teachers'' begins to seem a realistic appraisal of the public school system - and there are many scenes in which it does - the film is apt to break its own mood with false-sounding dialogue, conspicuous miscasting or a very broad gag.

title: MONDALE ASSAILS BUSH OVER HIS TAXES
description: Walter F. Mondale zeroed in on the newly disclosed tax returns of Vice President Bush today, saying it was unfair for such a wealthy person to pay only 13 percent of his income in taxes, as he did last year, when people earning less have to pay proportionally more.

title: 9 INDICTED IN INQUIRY INTO PHONY MEDICAL DEGREES
description: Nine people were indicted yesterday in Manhattan on felony charges of possessing or attempting to buy forged medical degrees for as much as $20,000.

;  Never Say Die
description: A third of his nine teams have folded before his new league has even played its first game, and only one Olympian has signed up. But, with a cable television contract and a legacy of interest from the Olympics to bank on, Bill Byrne , the founder of the Women's American Basketball Association, is convinced that the league's first season will be a success this fall.

title: HOMECOMING FOR MARINO IN PITTSBURG

title: Johnson Bank Officials Quit

title: PADES BEAT CUBS AND CUT PLAYOFF LEAD TO 2-1
description: The San Diego Padres staged a dramatic revival tonight when they mauled the Chicago Cubs, 7-1, averted a three- game sweep and prolonged the playoff for the National League pennant.

title: A SKILLFUL MANAGER BRUCE EDGAR CRAWFORD
description: With his appointment yesterday as general manager-elect of the Metropolitan Opera, Bruce Crawford is fulfilling an interest in opera that goes back 40 years. Mr. Crawford will bring sophisticated managerial skills to his new job, sharpened through his experience of running a worldwide advertising agency, BBDO International, and in negotiating with major talent in the entertainment industry.

description: ''I would love to go into outer space,'' Lester O. Krogh, vice president of research and development at the Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company, said yesterday. ''But I'm afraid I'll have to leave that to younger scientists.''

title: NO DANGER TO CHICAGO BANK SEEN
description: The chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, William M. Isaac, said today that the First National Bank of Chicago was in no danger of failing. The bank announced Wednesday that it would report a third-quarter loss of as much as $74 million.

description: The gold Rolex watch he used to wear has been sold to pay overdue bills, he says. Close advisers have deserted him, and C.I.A. financing has been cut off along with the telephones in his San Jose headquarters.

description: To the Editor:

title: End Run for New York Power The prospects for fairer distribution of New York's low-cost hydropower seemed to suffer a setback last month. A Federal court ruled that the state's tiny municipal utilities, which already take a fifth of all the hydropower, had a valid claim to even more. The Legislature, eager to avoid a controversial issue, cited that decision as an excuse to postpone debate of a much more equitable distribution plan endorsed by Governor Cuomo.
description: But thanks to canny legal maneuvers by John Dyson, chairman of the state Power Authority, the municipal utilities may yet lose much of their windfall. Indeed, unless Federal regulators upset his plan, the great majority of New Yorkers may soon begin to see the benefits.

title: Abdullah Ibrahim

Sets begin at 10 and 11:45 P.M. and 1:30 A.M.. There is an $8 cover and a $6 minimum.

title: Diner's Journal
description: THERE is probably no Italian dish that is more abused in New York restaurants than risotto, the northern Italian preparation of rice that is slowly simmered with chicken stock, seasonings and such ingredients as mushrooms, cheese and so on. It is a labor-intensive recipe that must be made to order, and when it is done right, it is a delight of texture and flavor. If a restaurant tries to make it in advance and reheat it before serving, however, it is reduced to a consistency resembling mortar.

title: Hinckley Loses Bid For More Privileges
description: John W. Hinckley Jr., confined to a mental hospital after shooting President Reagan in 1981, may not receive the greater privileges he was seeking, a Federal district judge ruled today.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ; Exxon Plans Auction Of Zero Coupon Notes
description: The Exxon Corporation yesterday announced plans to auction on Tuesday enough zero coupon notes due in 2004 to raise $150 million to $200 million. Although the interest rate and price of the notes are not known, analysts estimated that the Exxon Capital Corporation, a subsidiary of Exxon, would issue more than $1 billion worth.

title: General Host Sale
description: The General Host Corporation confirmed the sale of the company's Van de Kamp's Frozen Foods division to the Pillsbury Company for about $100 million. The sale, approved Wednesday by the Pillsbury board of directors, must receive regulatory clearance before its scheduled closing Nov. 5. General Host said the after- tax gain on the sale would amount to about $48 million.

title: ART: CAPTURING ESSENCE OF A REMOTE AUSTRALIA
description: AUSTRALIA is remarkable for being a land mass roughly the size of the United States with 15 million people clinging to its rim, for landscape and fauna that are often unearthly and for a vast sky that stages virtually wraparound sunsets. But none of this is any stranger than is the fact that no discussion of the country's art seems possible without a preamble about these and many other physical peculiarities.

title: BIG-PARADE SPONSORS MUST PROVIDE TOILETS UNDER NEW CITY RULE
description: Groups seeking parade permits in New York City will have to provide portable toilets if they expect a crowd of more than 150,000 people, Mayor Koch's press office announced yesterday.

The installation, which will be on view through Sunday, is based on the theme of time and consists of a 25- foot arch mounted with banners, loudspeakers, colored lights and television monitors. Today's performance runs until 6 P.M. It will be repeated tomorrow and Sunday from 11 A.M. to 6 P.M. Admission is free. Information: 269-0320.
