MAKING CAMPAIGN CROWDS FEEL GOOD
description: At the finale of a rally at dusk Monday in Gulfport, Miss., President Reagan delivered a paean to American servicemen that is now a centerpiece of his campaign speeches. ''Maybe when you see one of those young people in uniform walking along the street here in Gulfport or Biloxi or wherever, maybe, if you think of it, just nod and smile and say hello, and maybe let them know how all of us feel about them,'' Mr. Reagan softly told the silent crowd of 40,000 people. ''It'll make you feel good. And I know how good it'll make them feel.'' He grinned. ''Well, I have to go now . . . .''

title: PREPARING FOR S.A.T.'S: THE CRUNCH IS ON
description: The Scholastic Aptitude Tests - the three- hour exams taken by a majority of students applying to American colleges - will be given Nov. 3 and again Dec. 10. Some students spend hundreds of dollars on special classes; others prepare by doing nothing more than sharpening their pencils the day before the test. Some study with workbooks and others with computer disks. And although the State Consumer Protection Board is not suggesting any one way to prepare for the test, it is urging students and parents to be aware that a range of options is available.

description: Multimedia Inc. said it expects third-quarter earnings to be below the results a year earlier because of greater-than-expected losses at its Sports Time cable television unit, which is a joint venture with Anheuser-Busch Companies and Tele-communications Inc.

title: U.S.-ISRAELI TALKS TO STRESS ECONOMY
description: The Reagan Administration plans to hold detailed talks next week with Prime Minister Shimon Peres and other senior Israeli officials on ways of dealing with serious problems in Israel's economy, a senior Administration official said today.

title: G.E. COPYRIGHT ACCORD COVERS USE OF COPIERS
description: The General Electric Company this week became the first corporation to agree to pay a lump sum for a companywide license to photocopy articles from thousands of copyrighted publications.

title: BASEBALL FIGURES LAUD ALSTON
description: Walter Alston, a small-town man who managed the Brooklyn and Los Angeles Dodgers to seven pennants and four World Series championships in 23 years, was buried in nearby Darrtown Cemetery today. Friends and baseball associates paid their final respects on the campus of Miami University, from which he was graduated in 1935.

title: MCCARRAN-WALTER SADOMASOCHISM
description: It was, I believe, Charles Dickens who first and with the greatest comic genuis saw through the workings of the bureacracy of the fantastic ''Little Dorrit,'' where the Circumlocution Office, headed by Sir Titus Barnacle, prides itself on its fundamental function, which is to see to it that nothing that should get done ever gets done, or if it gets done it gets badly or incompletely done.

title: Reagan Called Unaware Of Covenants on Lots
description: President Reagan was not aware that several Los Angeles lots he bought and sold in the 1940's stipulated that only whites, except for servants, could live on the property, the White House said today.

title:

NEW STADIUM PLAN
description: Mayor Dianne Feinstein of San Francisco, who failed to push through a plan to build a multipurpose domed stadium in the city, is trying again. This time the proposal is for an open- air, baseball-only park near China Basin in downtown San Francisco to replace Candlestick Park. Mrs. Feinstein indicated that she hoped the proposal would help keep the Giants in the city in the wake of the announcement by the owner, Bob Lurie , that the team was for sale. But Corey Busch , a Giant vice president, said he doubted that the efforts would cause Lurie to change his mind about selling the team.

title: THE MIXED BLESSING OF A STRONG DOLLAR
description: The stubbornly strong dollar has created a new watchword for the industrial Middle West. In the export-producing plants, the credo has become: Automate or emigrate.

title: UNPROVOKED ATTACK ON THE BEER INDUSTRY
description: To the Editor:

title:
SPORTS OF THE TIMES;
PERMANENT WAVE IN MOTOWN
description: DETROIT Here in this old baseball town, the Tigers proved they had a better team than the Royals last night, and the Detroit fans proved their wave is better than Kansas City's during the pennant-winning, 1-0 victory by Milt Wilcox.

title: Languages of U.S. Courts
description: The third most-used language in

title: TEMPLETON SPURS ON PADRES
description: Nobody was saying that Garry Templeton had shattered the Chicago Cubs and set the stage for the San Diego Padres to win the pennant. Nobody was saying that he had reversed three seasons of disappointments and years of disputes. Nobody was even saying that he had redeemed the trade that brought him here from the St. Louis Cardinals, who ''ran me out of town.''

title: PINCHING PRETORIA'S PURSE
description: Regarding South Africa, the Reagan Administration has insisted that its quiet, firm approach would somehow moderate that country's racial tyranny. But the fruits of ''constructive engagement'' look sour even to the Republican-led Senate, which has yielded in conference to a House bill that gives symbolic expression to America's abhorrence. The measure would bar American bank loans to South Africa's Government and require the State Department to comment on the racial policies of American companies doing business in South Africa.

title: POLICY MANAGEMENT SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings have been adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split in October 1983.

title: MICHENER'S MESSAGE TO DEFAULTING STUDENTS
description: To the Editor:

title:
PEOPLE;
HOPE FOR AUBURN
description: Bo Jackson , the star Auburn back who suffered a severe shoulder separation three weeks ago and had been expected to miss the rest of the season, said there was a chance he could return for the school's final game, against Alabama on Dec. 1 - but only if the team really needed him and his shoulder was really healed. ''I can only do what my shoulder allows me,'' he said.

title: NOVEL ANTITRUST PACT FOR ARCO, ALCAN
description: The Justice Department today announced a novel antitrust agreement under which Alcan Aluminum Ltd. would acquire most, but not all, of the Atlantic Richfield Company's aluminum business.

title: LOUISVILLE PRIMPS FOR PARTIES AND PARTISAN DEBATE
description: For generations, perhaps ever since the invention of the mint julep and the garland of roses, life in this city has revolved around a two-minute horse race on the first Saturday in May. But with an intensity not usually mustered in the quiet of the fall, Louisville has been primping, polishing and preparing for a 90-minute debate on the first Sunday in October.

title: ERROR BY OFFICER CITED IN ESCAPE OF RAPE SUSPECT
description: The city's Department of Correction said yesterday that a lapse by one of its officers had permitted a convicted rapist to escape from a Manhattan courthouse on Wednesday.

title: Marijuana Worth $6 Million Seized on Yacht in England
description: Sixty British agents, including frogmen, raided a yacht and seized 10 tons of marijuana worth $6.25 million, customs officials said today.

title: FAMILY SHOWTIME THEATRES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss. The company is a franchisee of Pizza Time Theatre Inc.

title: USFL WEIGHING SUIT
description: The owners of the United States Football League have voted authorization for the league office to file an antitrust suit against the National Football League, according to one of the owners, who is prominent within the U.S.F.L.

title: No Headline
description: Comic Book SalesVintage comic books, paperbacks and movie memorabilia will be available for sale or trade at Phil Seuling's Comic Book Marketplace tomorrow from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. at Omni Park Central, Seventh Avenue and 55th Street. Admission is free. Information: 788-1126.

title: DISNEY'S NEW MANAGEMENT TEAM SIGNS TWO TOP DIRECTORS
description: Less than two weeks after arriving at the studio, the new management team of Walt Disney Productions has made deals for new movies with two of Hollywood's more successful directors.

title: SAVING PELL GRANTS FOR STUDENTS
description: Separated by 3,000 miles, two members of the class of 1984 who graduated with top honors bear a striking resemblance.

title: THE REGION ; ;  Midshipman Dies After L.I. Crash
description: A midshipman at the Merchant Marine Academy was fatally injured and six classmates were hurt when their car went out of control and crashed here early today, the police said.

title: Kaufman & Broad
description: Kaufman & Broad Inc. said it had entered into an option agreement giving it the exclusive right to sign a definitive agreement to acquire the Capitol Life Insurance Company from Providence International Ltd. Capitol Life is one of the leading underwriters of single premium annuities in the nation. Kaufman & Broad said the terms call for undisclosed remuneration, plus an infusion of new captial for Capitol Life.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST SATURDAY, OCTOBER 6, 1984
description: The Economy

title: TIMES OF LONDON LETS ITS HAIR DOWN
description: The Times of London used to call itself ''the top people's paper,'' and not-so-top people used to complain about its stuffy self- importance. But as it approaches its 200th birthday on Jan. 1, The Times has shed its tailcoat and donned a sports jacket.

title: OIL GLUT HAS DULLED THE GILT ON GOLDEN TRIANGLE IN TEXAS
description: When Paul Simien returned home to Port Arthur 10 years ago after a stint in the Air Force, he passed up college for a job paying $12.41 an hour filling cans with motor oil at the big Texaco refinery here. He fully expected to work for Texaco Inc. until he retired.

title: Italy's Foreign Minister Survives a Call to Resign
description: The political future of the Italian Foreign Minister, Giulio Andreotti, was thrown into uncertainty today after a parliamentary vote on a demand for his resignation.

title: CERBERONICS INC reports earnings for Year to June 30
Efforts to Cut Costs Set by U.S. Home
description: The U.S. Home Corporation, the nation's largest home builder, yesterday announced major cutbacks in an effort to return to profitability next year.

title: Sikh Gunmen in Punjab Kill One and Wound 15
description: Five Sikh gunmen killed one person and wounded 18 today in renewed violence in the northern state of Punjab, the Press Trust of India reported.

title: SAME OLD STORY
description: The front-runner for the National League's Cy Young Award is widely considered to be Rick Sutcliffe, who won 16 of 17 decisions for the Chicago Cubs after being traded by the Cleveland Indians in June.

title: 3 Teen-Agers Sentenced In Killing of Homosexual
description: Three teen-age boys who killed a 23-year-old homosexual by throwing him off a bridge because they said he propositioned one of them were sentenced today to indeterminate terms at the Maine Youth Center.

title: JOBLESS RATE IN NEW YORK CITY DROPPED TO 8.8% LAST MONTH
description: The unemployment rates in New York City and New York State declined last month and remained relatively unchanged in New Jersey, the regional commissioner of the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics, Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, said yesterday.

title: CORRECTION
description: A headline in Weekend yesterday misstated the anniversary celebrated by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer Wednesday. The studio turned 60.

title: 'STRIKEBOUND' RECOUNTS AUSTRAILIAN MINE UNREST
description: ''Strikebound'' is an earnest, worthy Australian film that reconstructs the true story of a coal miners' strike in the small town of Korumburra in the mid-30's. It was written and directed by Richard Lowenstein, who is only 24 years old, and is based on interviews conducted over a period of years by his mother, Wendy Lowenstein, an oral historian.

title: PANEL DEADLOCKS ON SPENDING BILL
description: House and Senate conferees bogged down today in a dispute over aid to Nicaraguan rebels and gave up efforts to compromise on a

title: Paine Webber
description: Paine Webber Group Inc. told the Securities and Exchange Commission it holds 144,859 common shares of New Yorker Magazine Inc., or 17.4 percent of the total outstanding. The brokerage firm said 102,459 of the shares, or 12.3 percent of the total outstanding, are held on behalf of investment clients who control their own accounts.

title: U.S. SAID TO IMPROVE SECURITY OF NUCLEAR WEAPONS
description: United States and allied forces in Western Europe have improved measures to protect the security of American nuclear weapons there, a senior Defense Department official said today.

title:
PEOPLE;
KICKER'S OPTIONS
description: As a punter and place-kicker, Russell Erxleben knows what playing both sides of the fence is like. Now he's playing the fence with both pro football leagues after being cut by the New Orleans Saints before the National Football League season began.

title: Gain in Service at A.T.& T.
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said today that it completed orders for new special business line connections on schedule 50 percent of the time in September, up from 34 percent the previous month.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 17.

title: AMERICAN MONITOR CORP reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-After an equity loss in British affiliate of $2,256,000. c-After an equity loss in British affiliate of $679,000 and writeoff of assets of British affiliate of $5,689,000. Year-ago results have been restated.

title: A DAY FOR RAOUL WALLENBERG
description: Amenorah was set on a card table

title: CONCERT: DAVIES PIECE FOR SOLO HORN
description: The League of Composers-International Society for Contemporary Music can usually be relied on to present some of the most unusual and varied new music concerts in town. Monday evening's program, featuring the Chamber Players of the league at the Symphony Space, offered no exception to this rule.

title: Knight-Ridder
description: -Ridder Newspapers Inc. has sold its interest in cellular telephone license applications pending before the Federal Communications Commission after the Government decided to award them through a lottery.

title: World Court Dismisses Petition by El Salvador
description: The World Court announced at The Hague today that it had rejected El Salvador's petition to intervene on the side of the United States in arguing that the Court should not decide Nicaragua's lawsuit against the United States.

title: British Air Route Pact
description: The Government has secured agreement on a route-swapping package between state-owned British Airways and British Caledonian Airways, the Transport Department said today. British Air will give Caledonian two routes in Saudi Arabia, and receive Caledonian's Latin American and unused Denver and Morocco routes. This should allow the sale of British Air to private investors to go ahead early next year, a spokesman said.

title: NEWS SUMMARY;
description: SATURDAY, OCTOBER 6, 1984 International More than 80 East German refugees have sought asylum in West Germany by entering the West German Embassy in Prague, the Bonn Government said. The embassy closed its doors Thursday to visitors in an effort to keep more refugees from entering, but eight more East Germans climbed a rear wall to get in. (Page 1, Columns 3-4.) Pope John Paul II condemned organized crime, urging listeners in a southern Italian town to break ''the tragic chain of vendettas'' and end organized crime's code of silence. In one of his strongest condemnations of organized crime, the Pope told a crowd in the Calabrian coastal village of Paola that the code ''binds so many people in a type of squalid complicity dictated by fear.'' (1:1.)

title: Neapolitan Arts
description: ''Postcard of Naples,'' a musical revue of Neapolitan music and melodrama, will be presented tomorrow at 5 P.M. at Christ Church and Holy Family, Clinton and Kane Streets in the Cobble Hill section of Brooklyn.

title: No Headline
description: Halston Plans A Repurchase Halston, the fashion-world

title: Mozambique Saboteurs Blow Up Power Lines
description: Saboteurs said to be Mozambique rebels blew up electrical lines from South Africa this week, a half hour after South African officials announced a negotiated cease-fire in Mozambique's civil war, Mozambique's press agency said today.

title: FAMILY HOME IS REBORN AS OFF BROADWAY HOUSE
description: The curtain is about to go up on a rare event - a spanking new legitimate theater Off Broadway.

title: Nippon Kokan Pact
description: Nippon Kokan K.K. of Japan said today that it had been awarded a contract by the Chevron Corporation to fabricate the underwater support structures, or jackets, for two oil and natural gas production platforms that will be positioned off the coast of California.

title: Zambian Official Dismissed
description: Zambia has dismissed its director of civil aviation because he closed Lusaka's international airport for 45 minutes last month when he could not get a seat on a flight, the Government announced today. The official, Capt. Patrick Kawanu, finally got a seat on the Zambian Airways flight to London but was ordered home four days later.

title: RATES DROP AS RALLY CONTINUES
description: The rally in the credit market continued yesterday, with Treasury note and bond prices rising as much as 3/4 point. They had risen by more than 1 1/2 points in the last two days.

title: HURDLES TO COMPETITION WHEN THE U.S. GOES SHOPPING
description: To the Editor:

title: THE CANDIDATES' STANDS ON RIGHTS
description: The purpose of the television debates is to have the candidates plainly state their views on policy questions. The area of civil rights is a good example of where issues have been blurred or not mentioned at all. As a Democrat in the civil rights tradition of Hubert H. Humphrey, and a Reagan appointee to the United States Civil Rights Commission, I find points of agreement and disagreement with President Reagan and Walter F. Mondale. Yet each has failed to address important policy concerns.

title: PRIVATE ADVENTURERS BREAKING U.S. LAW
description: To the Editor:

title: BONN SAYS 80 EAST GERMANS SEEK REFUGE IN ITS EMBASSY IN PRAGUE
description: More than 80 East Germans have entered the West German Embassy in Prague, demanding asylum in West Germany, the Bonn Government said today.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;
description: Mondale Trying Again

title: CHAMPION HOME BUILDERS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Court Backs Gasoline Pact
description: A Federal judge granted preliminary approval today to an antitrust settlement by 15 large oil companies that would allow dealers who operate company-owned stations to buy gasoline from competitors.

title:
PEOPLE ;
PUTTING WOES LINGER
description: Jan Stephenson , the golfer who won the United States Women's Open last year, hasn't been doing very well since then, and the reason is her game on the greens. ''I've been through 18 months of anguish because of my putting, and that is long enough,'' she said Thursday after finding herself six strokes off the pace, with 148, after two rounds of the Hitachi Women's British Open.

title: CHADIAN CONFERS WITH MITTERRAND
description: President Francois Mitterrand held talks with the President of Chad today amid signs that a recent French-Libyan agreement to withdraw their troops from that north African country was being delayed.

title: NEGOTIALTORS REPORT A COMPROMISE THAT MAY REVIVES IMMIGRATION BILL
description: House and Senate negotiators said today that they had reached a last-minute compromise that could revive the comprehensive immigration bill.

title: DANCE: THEATER OF HARLEM
description: Dance Theater of Harlem demonstrated its versatility Tuesday night at City Center. Four stylistically different ballets were on the program and each was given a convincing performance.

title: BRUINS TRIUMPH OVER ISLANDERS
description: The rookie defenseman Frank Simonetti scored a goal after 3 minutes 16 seconds of overtime tonight to give the Boston Bruins a 7-6 victory over the Islanders in an exhibition game.

title:
PEOPLE ;
ASSAULT ON BOXING
description: Medical literature is full of accounts of varying degrees of brain damage suffered by boxers over the years. But, until he saw Muhammad Ali on television recently, Dr. Nelson Richards , the president of the nation's largest organization of nerve specialists, regarded boxing as a decent sport.

title: GIBSON JUSTIFIES TIGER HOPES
description: Kirk Gibson stopped short of saying he was vindicated by being named the most valuable player of the American League championship series tonight.

title: ALASKA NATIONAL BANK OF THE NORTH reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including a gain of $772,000 for the quarter and 9 months on the sale of real estate.

title: U.S. JOBLESS RATE, AT 7.3%, REMIANS VIRTUALLY STEADY
description: The national unemployment rate remained virtually unchanged at 7.3 percent in September, continuing the pattern of the past several months, the Labor Department reported today.

title: AILING UNIVERSITY SEEKS NEW IMAGE TO LURE STUDENTS
description: Fairleigh Dickinson University, like many other private colleges and universities, has lost enrollment, faces serious budget deficits and needs to cut staff and reduce course offerings.

title: JERSEY RESIDENT HELD IN SLAYING OF UPSTATE MAN
description: A 25-year-old Passaic, N.J., man was arrested yesterday in connection with the murder of a Methodist minister from Saratoga Springs, N.Y.

title: Peres Visit Pondered
description: Some White House officials are

title: Former World's Fair Official Charged With Kickback Plot
description: A former director of marketing for the World's Fair was indicted by a Federal grand jury today on a charge of operating a kickback scheme in the sale of fair souvenirs.

title: Stocks End Mixed As Volume Rises
description: The stock market, which has been under pressure most of this week, finished mixed yesterday in more active trading.

title: FARMING OUT THE BIAS COMPLAINTS
description: At first glance, there is something suspect about the Reagan Administration's plan to let states investigate civil rights violations in the distribution of Federal subsidies to health and social service programs. The Administration has not been rigorous about the civil rights laws and may be seeking a way to shirk its responsibility.

title: LETTER: ON THE NONPROFIT SECTOR
description: CHARITIES ARE SURVIVING AID CUTS

title: WALKING ON THE RED
description: I have written several columns about the endemic crime-hazard in this city of drivers who ignore red lights and regularly send people scattering at crosswalks. Occasionally, readers and more immediate kibitzers have pointed out that pedestrians, too, flout the traffic lights en masse and are therefore equal participants in the general abuse here of the social contract.

title: Texas Man Is Charged In Failed Kidnapping
description: A suspect described by the sheriff as a ''complete dummy'' for seeking a $1 million ransom despite the well-publicized escape of the kidnapped victim was charged today with the kidnapping.

title: RUSSINA, AT U.N., BARS TALKS BEFORE REMOVAL OF PERSHINGS
description: A Soviet official reiterated today that until the West removed its new nuclear missiles from Europe, there would be no arms limitation negotiations with the United States.

title: BEAMAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 29
description: b-Net loss.

title: THE HOT-SELLING LIGHT TRUCKS
description: As characterized by Consumer Reports, the Chevrolet S-10 Blazer ''is simply a General Motors Corp. compact pickup truck with a boxy body that works like a station wagon and with four-wheel drive.'' Their testers found it ''rode choppily on good roads; it jerked and bounded uncomfortably on bad roads.'' They pronounced its handling ''only slightly worse than the average passenger car'' - a kind of praising with faint damns.

title: LORIMAR reports earnings for Qtr to July 28
BELL TRIES TO MAKE OWN NAME
description: Bobby Bell Jr. thought before answering, then conceded the obvious: The Jets' game against the Chiefs at Kansas City on Sunday will be special for him.

title: WARD ASSAILS OFFICER IN DEATH OF HIS PARTNER
description: Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward yesterday sharply criticized the judgment and actions of a Transit Authority police officer whose partner was killed eight days ago while chasing a robbery suspect in Brooklyn.

title: APOGEE ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 1
CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about Swiss banks misidentified the institution offering an electronic fund management system called Swisscash. It is the Swiss Bank Corporation.

title:
PEOPLE ;
FULLBACK SUSPENDED
description: Boston College's starting fullback, Jim Browne , has been suspended from the team after he was stopped in a traffic incident last weekend and the arresting officers found him with a white powder they suspect is cocaine.

title: THE MARATHON PAYS, AND SHOULD
description: One of the world's worst-kept secrets was revealed this week when organizers of the New York Marathon confessed to paying $200,000 in prizes last year to attract big-name competitors. Though the prizes probably meet the newly relaxed rules for ''amateur'' events, Mayor Koch says he's shocked by the marathon's fall from grace. He vows to bill the organizers for the city's expenses in supporting the race, reportedly $1.5 million. If they won't pay, ''they can take it to Newark.''

title: Sugar Sale By G.&W.
description: Gulf and Western Industries said yesterday that it had reached an agreement in principle to sell its sugar business in Florida and the Dominican Republic, plus related operations, to an investor group headed by Alfonso Fanjul and his brother J. Pepe Fanjul of Palm Beach, Fla., the fifth generation of Fanjul sugar producers.

title: WHO SAYS A WOMAN CAN'T PAY?
description: Restaurants are among the last bastions of male supremacy. Ask any waiter or captain. No matter how clear it is that a woman in the party is paying the check, at least 99 percent of the time it is presented to one of the men. I speak from experience.

title: GOODE'S LOSS HURT ALABAMA
description: Several plays after Kerry Goode ran back the second-half kickoff against Boston College 99 yards to give Alabama a 31-14 lead on Sept. 8, the exceptional sophomore halfback went out for the season with a knee injury that required surgery. With him, in large part, went the chance for the Crimson Tide to have a respectable season.

title: SILTRONICS LTD reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Including a tax credit of $154,000.

title: Norman Cherniss, 58; Editor at Coast Paper
description: Norman A. Cherniss, 58 years old, executive editor of The Press-Enterprise, died of a heart attack Wednesday.

title: STUDY SAYS BLACKS HAVE LOST GROUND
description: Reagan Administration tax and budget policies have devastated poor blacks and threaten the fragile black middle class that has emerged in recent years, a new study said Thursday.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Weaken the social evil that, in the eyes of many, sometimes obscures the image of this hard-working region. Defeat the scare of kidnappings, violence and other baneful evils that shake modern society.'' - Pope John Paul II, speaking to Italians about organized crime. (1:1.)

title: SATURDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Padres vs. Chicago Cubs, National League championship series, fourth game, at San Diego. Scott Sanderson tries to wrap up matters for the Cubs, opposing Tim Lollar. (Television - Channel 7, 8 P.M. Radio - WCBS, 880; 8:20 P.M.) Football

title: No Headline
description: Judge Backs Textile Ruling By The Associated Press A Federal judge yesterday

title: ARGENTINES TELL OF DOUBT ON TRIAL
description: Argentine officials expressed doubt today about the Government's ability to obtain guilty verdicts against nine former junta members charged in connection with the deaths of civilians in the 1970's.

title: THREE D DEPARTMENTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 28
UNITED TIGHTENS AGENT RULES
description: United Airlines, in a move to limit who may sell airline tickets under deregulation, said yesterday that it would continue to require the agencies it deals with to meet current standards in effect for 40 years as well as some new criteria of its own.

title: POPULAR BANCSHARES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: A Policy for Death, Taxes
description: The recent troubles of single-premium deferred annuities, with the two leaders in the

title: Agency Deadlocked On Conservative Ads
description: The Federal Election Commission deadlocked along party lines Thursday on whether offshoots of the National Conservative Political Action Committee may run radio and television commercials accusing the news media of voting Democratic in past elections.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASKETBALL

title: CLUBS WHERE DEAL MAKERS MAKE NO DEALS
description: To the Editor:

title: APEX OIL DEFENDS ITS CREDIT RECORD
description: The Apex Oil Company said yesterday that publicity indicating that its loan was being charged off by the First National Bank of Chicago was ''unwarranted and irresponsible.'' Apex added that all its principal and interest payments to banks were up- to-date.

title: NIKE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
G.E. SEEKS FEE FOR SHARING ENGINE TECHNOLOGY
description: The General Electric Company has decided it should be paid for technology that it would turn over to a rival, Pratt & Whitney, under a Navy plan to develop a second source for the F-404 jet engine, a G.E. spokesman said today.

title: VICTIMS NOT OF AGE BUT OF DEPRESSION
description: To the Editor:

title: REDISTRICTING AFFECTS KEY JERSEY RACE
description: After 22 years representing a Congressional District whose Democratic voting strength made his re-election routine, Representative Joseph G. Minish this year finds that redistricting has forced him into a tight race.

title: Rumanian to Visit Bonn
description: Rumania has confirmed that President Nicolae Ceausescu will visit West Germany this month, Government sources said today, discounting reports that Soviet pressure would force him to cancel the visit.

title: THE REGION ; ;  190 Yale Strikers Charged in Protest
description: The New Haven police arrested 190 striking clerical and technical workers at Yale University and supporters this morning for obstructing a public road in front of the house of Yale's president, A. Bartlett Giamatti.

title: FAMILIAN CORP reports earnings for Year to June 30
EXPOS MAY SEEK McCARVER
description: Tim McCarver, whose career as a broadcaster has flourished since he ended his 21-year major league catching career in 1980, may have a managerial offer from the Montreal Expos to consider when he sits down after the World Series to ponder his options for 1985.

title: STUDY FINDS FAMILY BEARS BRUNT OF SOCIAL CHANGE
description: A new report forecasts that American families will suffer increasingly negative effects from technological innovation and social change unless society devotes more attention and money to supporting them.

title: SENATE RACE IN NORTH CAROLINA PROVING A BITTER MIX OF POLITICS AND RELIGION
description: The explosive issue of religion in politics is having an especially strong impact in North Carolina, where it has added new emotion to an already embittered race for the United States Senate and has divided the state's largest religious group,

title: Southland Financial Accord
description: Ben H. Carpenter, John W. Carpenter 3d and Craig Hall said they had executed a ''standstill'' agreement prohibiting Mr. Hall from selling his 9.9 percent stake in the Southland Financial Corporation until July 31, 1985, except under certain circumstances.

title: Authorities in Sri Lanka Seize 125 Tamil Youths
description: Security forces seized about 125 Tamil youths today in Sri Lanka's northern district, the police said.

title: BEIRUT PREMIER BIDS U.N. AND U.S. HELP ARRANGE ISRAELI WITHDRAWAL
description: The Prime Minister of Lebanon appealed to the United Nations and the United States today for help in negotiating ''a total Israeli withdrawal'' from his country.

title: DeLorean Sued for Divorce
description: Cristina Ferarre filed for divorce today against John Z. DeLorean, the former automobile maker. The couple began a trial separation three weeks ago. Mr. DeLorean's attorney, Howard L. Weitzman, blamed the situation on the ''pressures'' from the unsuccessful Federal prosecution of Mr. DeLorean on cocaine conspiracy charges.

title: TOP FIGURE IN CONTRACT BRIDGE
description: Waldemar Von Zedtwitz, one of the greatest figures in the history of contract bridge, died in Hawaii yesterday at the age of 88. He had been suffering from respiratory problems following a stroke.

title: CLUBS WHERE DEAL MAKERS MAKE NO DEALS
description: To the Editor:

title: CONSUMER ACITONS BY CONGRESS
description: As the 98th Congress creaked toward a conclusion, organizations and public officials interested in consumer issues tallied up their victories and defeats, and, somewhat to their surprise, found themselves pleased.

title: Bishops Urge Members To Take Political Stands
description: The Episcopal House of Bishops has adopted a pastoral letter encouraging church members to speak out on political issues, no matter how controversial, but deleted from it a paragraph on abortion.

title: Bruno Shaw Dies at 89; Broadcaster and Writer
description: Bruno Shaw, a former radio broadcaster and a writer and authority on the Far East, died of cancer Tuesday at the New York University Medical Center. He was 89 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: PATENTS ; Treatment Reduces Toxicity of Asbestos
description: A treatment meant to decrease the toxicity of asbestos, which has caused complaints about its installation in schools and office buildings, was patented this week. Philip Graceffa and Sigmund A. Weitzman assigned the patent, No. 4,474,742, to the Boston Biomedical Research Institute and the General Hospital Corporation, also in Boston.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 46.

title: 'PRO-TRADE' LEGISLATION COMPLETED
description: Seeking to avoid a Presidential veto, House- Senate conferees today knocked out most of the protectionist provisions of a major trade bill, while authorizing a free trade zone with Israel and the renewal of trade concessions to more than 100 developing countries.

title: FOR PARTIES, FROM CHIMPS TO WHOLE CIRCUSES
description: Stuart White took one call after another from people desperately in need of 20 strolling violins - ''Fine''; a chimpanzee that roller skates - ''Sure, sure,'' and a full-scale carnival, discoth eque and circus for a three-day bar mitzvah at the Pierre Hotel - ''You got it.''

title: Artificial Insemination Apparatus Is Developed
description: Apparatus for the artificial insemination of humans and animals such as sheep has been invented by Kevin W. Gobby of Balcatta, in Western Australia. He was granted the patent, No. 4,474,576, this week.

title: OKLAHOMA BANK CLOSED
description: The farmers and Merchants Bank of Tecumseh, Okla., was closed yesterday after the Oklahoma Bank Commissioner determined that its capital was exhausted, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation said. It reopens today as Republic Bank of Tecumseh, a newly chartered unit of Republic Bankshares Inc., Oklahoma City. The bank failure was the 62d this year and the fourth in Oklahoma.

title: Ryan Homes Buyout Dropped
description: Malcolm M. Prime, chairman of Ryan Homes, said that a management group was no longer considering a leveraged buyout to take the company private.

title: NETS' NEW CENTER SLOW TO DEVELOP
description: It is a common belief in the National Basketball Association that centers are late bloomers. They usually appear to have grown too tall too quickly, still looking awkward while their quick and nimble teammates at guard and forward are displaying grace and skill.

title: Synthetic Fuels Accord
description: House and Senate conferees agreed today on a compromise breathing new life into a Government effort to squeeze oil and natural gas out of shale, coal and tar sands as a substitute for imported oil.

title: Not Palms, but Faces
description: Lady Wright, wife of Sir Oliver

title: GOVERNOR FINDS CHICAGO PRELATE AN ALLY IN DEBATE WITH O'CONNOR
description: Governor Cuomo, who this week gave his second speech in a month on religion and politics, drew upon the thoughts of a distant prelate, the Roman Catholic Cardinal of Chicago, to indirectly challenge Archbishop John J. O'Connor of New York. Speaking Wednesday evening at St. Francis College in Brooklyn, Mr. Cuomo announced the formation of a special task force to offer guidelines on ''life and the law'' issues, including such questions as abortion and the ''right to die'' of the terminally ill. In so doing, he called on Catholics to attack a wide range of social-welfare ills and, in effect, to avoid the narrower, single-issue focus on abortion some associate with Archbishop O'Connor.

title: Man Staking Out Scene Of Crime Shoots Boy
description: A trailer park manager, frustrated by a four-month string of burglaries, has been charged with shooting a boy who came near a cache of stolen items the manager set up to lure thieves, the authorities said today.

title: SALLIE MAE UNIT STIRS BANK IRE
description: The purchase of a savings and loan institution by the Student Loan Marketing Association has angered North Carolina banking groups, which are calling on the Federal courts to get the quasi- governmental organization out of the thrift business.

title: WEBSTER OF KNICKS ILL WITH HEPATITIS
description: Marvin Webster is suffering from hepatitis and an acute form of anemia, and the 7-foot-1-inch Knick substitute center will be out indefinitely, maybe as long as two months.

title: A MUSIC MAKER FOR SUNDAY NIGHTS
description: It was the early summer of 1943 and the nation was at war. As men and women in uniform scrambled for seats in the serenely beautiful East Garden Court of the National Gallery of Art, 28-year- old Richard Bales raised his baton and a Washington institution was born.

title: STOUGHTON IS LEFT AVAILABLE IN DRAFT
description: The signs were clear back in April. Blaine Stoughton came to the Rangers late in February, potentially the scoring threat they needed for right wing, and he wasn't even asked to dress when it came playoff time.

title: AN EASING BY THE FED CONFIRMED
description: The Federal Reserve Board reported today that its policy-making committee agreed in August to relax restraints on interest rates if growth of the money supply slowed significantly in the weeks after the meeting.

title: U.S. COURT REINSTATES SUIT ON HONDURAN LAND
description: A closely divided Federal appeals court reinstated a lawsuit today by an American citizen who charged that his 14,000-acre ranch in Honduras was seized unconstitutionally by the United States military.

title: SHUTTLE LIFTS OFF FOR 8-DAY MISSION WITH RECORD CREW
description: The space shuttle Challenger, carrying seven people, the largest crew in the history of space flight, rose through clouds lighted by the rising sun today to begin an eight- day scientific mission in orbit of the earth.

title: RAMTEK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: ROGER BROWN'S MINIATURE HORSE FARM reports earnings for Year to June 30

PEOPLE;
COACH TOO EAGER
description: The University of South Carolina basketball coach, Bill Foster , apparently violated National Colllegiate Athletic Association rules when he watched his players scrimmage Sept. 20, Tom Yeager , the N.C.A.A.'s director of legislative services, told The Columbia Record. By attending the scrimmage, Yeager said, Foster broke a rule prohibiting preseason basketball practice until Oct. 15.

title: MAXWELL LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
COMPUTERIZED BUYING NETORK reports earnings for Year to June 30
ARA Services Approves Buyout
description: ARA Services said its board had approved a revised proposal from a number of investors led by senior management to acquire the company in a leveraged buyout.

title: MARCOS GOES ON TV TO ATTACK CARDINAL
description: President Ferdinand E. Marcos accused the Archbishop of Manila today of seeking to destabilize the nation by encouraging people to march in an anti-Government demonstration scheduled for Sunday.

title: WOLCOX STOPS ROYALS AS TIGERS WIN PENNANT
description: The Detroit Tigers bolted to the ninth pennant in their 84-year American League history tonight when Milt Wilcox and Willie Hernandez held the anemic Kansas City Royals to three hits to complete a stunning three-game playoff sweep. The 1-0 victory put the Tigers in the World Series for the first time since 1968, gave Sparky Anderson a chance to become the first manager in baseball history to win a World Series championship in both leagues, and vindicated a team that believed it had been underrated despite a 104-58 record. Wilcox's performance was dazzling. After a 17-victory season, the finest of his major league career, the right-hander held the Royals to two singles and two walks, while striking out eight. Before yielding to Hernandez in the ninth, Wilcox threw 108 pitches, 78 of them strikes, despite the pain of a chronic arthritic condition in his right shoulder. As a rookie exactly 14 years ago, Wilcox also closed out a playoff sweep, that one for the National League Cincinnati Reds when Anderson was their first-year manager.

title: TV: 'NATURE OF THINGS,' DOCUMENTARY ON AFRICA
description: The Nature of Things,'' the public television series, tonight visits Africa, a land, we are told, where ''there's always something new.'' What is new in the one-hour documentary, ''Wild Africa,'' is not the rich variety of wild animals we see, but the efforts to preserve them. They are threatened, but in pockets they survive. The documentary can be seen on Channel 13 at 8 P.M.

title: OVERHEAD VIEW
description: The much-ballyhooed but still somewhat mysterious Skycam - that aerial camera operated by remote control to skim over a playing field like an acrobat on a tightrope - will finally make its network television debut today. Yes, it actually got a trial run some time ago, but that was all experimental.

title: PAYTON TOUTED AS TOP 'SPATTER'
description: For years, Ahmad Rashad of the Minnesota Vikings and Walter Payton of the Chicago Bears played against each other twice a season.

title: PATENTS ; Methods to Improve Use of Optical Fibers
description: Three patents on improvements in the hair-thin glass fibers used in transmitting information by light waves underground or under the ocean were granted this week to A.T.& T. Bell Laboratories, Murray Hill, N.J.

title: FANCY CROWN WINS
description: Fancy Crown burst from the pack along the rail in the homestretch today, then survived an inquiry and won the Kentucky Futurity, the final leg of the triple crown for 3-year-old trotters.

title: ADOPTING A TRUMAN TACTIC, REAGAN PLANS A TRAIN TOUR
description: Walter F. Mondale and President Reagan spent most of today quietly preparing for their Sunday debate, but Mr. Mondale took time out to assail Mr. Reagan for what he called failures of leadership and Mr. Reagan sought to upstage the Democrats by boldly scheduling a whistle-stop train tour duplicating Harry S. Truman's route through Ohio in 1948.

title: BILL ON WASTE GOES TO REAGAN
description: A bill tightening the Federal law covering hazardous waste disposal was sent to President Reagan today, making it the first major piece of antipollution legislation enacted by the 98th Congress.

title: STAODYNAMICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 1
description: b-Net loss.

title: Key Rates
description: * split rate, 12.50-12.75 ** Kenny Index, Kenny Information Systems Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: REDD FOX TO APPEAR
description: The comedian Redd Fox, who starred in the television series ''Sandford and Son,'' will appear for two weeks at Dangerfield's, 1118 Fifth Avenue, at 61st Street.

title: PATENTS ; Way Devised at NASA To Fight Kidney Stones
description: Equipment for disintegrating kidney stones was patented this week for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. The patent, No. 4,474,180, was assigned to NASA because the inventor, Earl D. Angulo, an engineer at the Goddard Space Flight Center, Greenbelt, Md., devised the equipment as part of his duties.

title: A Blaze in Subway Injures 2 And Forces 500 From aTrain
description: A fire broke out under a subway train in lower Manhattan yesterday, injuring 2 people and forcing 500 passengers to leave the train, transit officials said. It was the second subway fire in two days involving a large number of passengers.

title: ADVANCED MICRO DEVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 23
No Headline
description: Bridge:Sway Information

title: BUSH DISCUSSES FOREIGN POLICY ISSUES
description: Vice President Bush says a contingent of 80 United States marines probably would not have been able to prevent the recent terrorist bombing of the United States Embassy in Lebanon. The troops were removed from Beirut nine weeks ago.

title: STATEWIDE PLAN SOUGHT TO HOUSE THE HOMELESS
description: A top New York City welfare official said yesterday that he was considering trying to move homeless families from welfare hotels and shelters into vacant apartments throughout the state.

title: 9TH CHESS TITLE GAME IS ADJOURNED
description: Anatoly Karpov and Gary Kasparov adjourned their ninth game for the world chess championship here tonight. Kasparov, the challenger, playing the black pieces, sealed his 42d move.The game is to be resumed Saturday night.

title: London Organist
description: Jonathan Rennert, organist and director of music at the ancient Chruch of St. Michael's in London, will present a recital tomorrow at 3 P.M. at the Park Avenue Christian Church.

title: Fleet Financial
description: The Federal Reserve Board said it had approved the application of Fleet Financial Group Inc., of Providence, R.I., to set up new banks in Boston and Hartford. Before deciding to approve the proposal, the board said it had taken into consideration the views of Citicorp, which has challenged the constitutionality of the Massachusetts and Connecticut statutes under which Fleet Financial would be authorized to open the new banks.

title: CAPTIVES RELEASED IN SALVADOR WAR
description: Salvadoran guerrilla leaders announced here today that they had freed 8 army officers in exchange for 4 imprisoned rebel commanders and safe passage for 60 wounded guerrillas to travel to hospitals in six other countries.

title: RUSSIAN EMIGRES KNEW OF THE PRO-SOVIET COUPLE
description: A priest said today that he told Federal agents two years ago that a parishioner, Swetlana Ogorodnikova, was active in pro- Soviet activities. He said he had been told, ''We know all about her.''

title: CHEMICAL WARFARE: A WEAK AREA FOR NATO
description: A unit of the Fifth Mechanized Infantry Division was hit by a simulated gas attack during Certain Fury, an American exercise in mid-September. The unit's staff told reporters that, after seven hours of trying, it had failed to get Washington's required approval to retaliate in kind because of a complicated consultation procedure.

title: Shuttle Will Be 'Star' For 3 Tristate Dawns
description: The space shuttle Challenger will be visible over New York, New Jersey and Connecticut in the dawns of the next few days.

title: JUDGE IN TRIBAL CASE DECIDES AGAINST NEW MEXICAN PAPER
description: A Federal district judge has reopened an Indian tribe's $3.65 million lawsuit against The New Mexican, a daily newspaper, saying the tribe's complaint that the paper had ''demeaned and ridiculed'' it in a recent article ''was not unjustified.''

title: THE REGION ; Better SchoolingFor Teachers
description: Standards in public schools might be improved if the education of teachers was, the New Jersey Board of Education decided last week. Under a plan approved by the board, undergraduates intending to become teachers will have to take more courses in the liberal arts and other subjects and fewer courses on teaching methodology.

title: Action Was Nonstop One of the most unusual sequences of touchdowns this season highlighted the action yesterday between Hawthorne and Lodi in Lodi. Hawthorne, a 35-14 winner, was holding a 14-0 lead in the second quarter
description: when Vin Quatron, a Lodi defensive lineman, picked up a fumble by Bill

title: Debate Today On Television
description: The Presidential debate will be broadcast live tonight at 9 o'clock, New York time, on the CBS, NBC and ABC television networks; on the Cable News Network, CNN; on the Cable- Satellite Public Affairs Network, C-Span, and on the Spanish International Network, SIN, with simultaneous Spanish translation.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: CELEBRATING his 13th birthday over dinner at The Galleria last week, Matthew Williams at first thought the music was ''like radio.'' At a nearby table, Paul Carpenter decided it was ''like we were in someone's castle, you know - with the trumpets blaring, the drawbridge lowering, Charlton Heston and all that.''

title: U.S. THINKS AHEAD TO POST-MARCUS ERA
description: The assassination of Philippine opposition leader Benigno S. Aquino Jr., which a citizens panel is expected to charge was the result of a military conspiracy, has led to a fundamental shift in United States policy toward President Ferdinand E. Marcos. The American Government, once passively wedded to Mr. Marcos, is now pressuring him to loosen his grip and to permit a renewal of democratic institutions.

title: THE NATION ; Four Poor YearsFor Blacks
description: Polls consistently show that President Reagan is held in low esteem by black Americans, and a report by the Center on Budget and Public Priorities, a nonprofit research group in Washington, may help explain why. The center, which frequently criticizes the Administration, said in a study released last week that Mr. Reagan's policies had devastated poor blacks and threatened the black middle class.

title: REAGAN-MONDALE CLASHES MAY FORESHADOW THE FIRST DEBATE
description: The Presidential campaign this fall has opened a broad philosophical divide between President Reagan and Walter F. Mondale. But, as Republicans and Democrats alike observe, the two men have yet to join in a practical debate over the most pressing and telling domestic issue facing the next President: the Federal deficit.

title: CHURCHES PLAY PART IN YALE STRIKE
description: NEW HAVEN THE message board outside the First and Summerfield Methodist Church in downtown New Haven serves as a sign of the times. When an issue is on the public's mind - when, say, the economy hits a low point or income- tax day draws near - people can expect an aphorism from the church on the subject.

title: Israelis Kill 3 Arab Gunmen Near the Border With Jordan
description: An Israeli Army patrol killed three well-armed Arabs who had apparently infiltrated across the Jordanian border, the military command reported tonight.

title: THE COAL STRIKE: A STRUGGLE AGAINST 'MRS. THATCHER'S BRITAIN'
description: For almost seven months, Britons have been watching on television a spectacle that has horrified most of them. Several times each week, the nightly newscasts have pictured violence of an unusual kind - coal miners hurling stones, battling the police and blocking trucks in a desperate effort to give their strike some economic impact.

title: AFGHANS GET SLICE OF THE FAST-FOOD BUSINESS
description: The Afghans in New York may soon be to fast food what Koreans are to produce.

title: A Dad Diminished
description: In his article ''A Dad Diminished'' (About Men, Aug. 26), Brock Brower misses an important point. His wife and children are free to pursue autonomy precisely because they do not hang on to a lost autocracy.

title: FLORIDA TOWN STRUGGLES WITH DRUGS
description: Not everyone in this remote fishing village is pleased with the national reputation it has acquired in recent months.

LEISURE;
A LONG ISLAND GARDENER MIXES ECONOMY AND SPLENDOR

Philbrick of Portland, Me., and the late Burnell Poole Jr. of Englewood, N.J. The Rev. Charles S. Ketchum, a professor of religion and philosophy at Allegheny College and a cousin of the bridegroom.

THE INVISIBLE MEN OF HISTORY

Waste no tears for me. I didn't come along too early. I was right on time.'' --BUCK O'NEIL, First Baseman, Kansas City Monarchs

description: DAVID WIGG is a writer living in Bangkok.

description: The Reagan Administration says the Salvadoran military has broken a long stalemate with guerrilla forces and is capable of neutralizing the insurgents by the end of 1986 if current military and political trends continue.

description: GARSON KANIN's ''Hollywood'' has just been reissued by Limelight Editions.

description: People ask me what I like in America,'' Liang Heng said, ''and I tell them, three things - one, freedom; two, basketball; three, ice cream.''

description: Nancy Flora Koerner and Richard J. Goldberg plan to be married in October, her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Ira M. Koerner of Great Neck and Amagansett, L.I., have announced.

description: Leonard Rossiter, one of Britain's most popular comic actors, collapsed during a performance in London and died Friday night, apparently of a heart attack. Mr. Rossiter, who was 57 years old, was declared dead at Middlesex Hospital.

title: THE WORLD ; A Peace BidIn Mozambique

But the war by the Mozambique National Resistance against President Samora M. Machel's Government continued and Mozambique was starting to have second thoughts about its pledge to deprive the African National Congress of a principal base against South Africa.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A picture caption in the Guide gives an incorrect address for the theater at which the play ''Kuni Leml'' will reopen Tuesday. The Audrey Wood Theater is at 359 West 48th Street.

description: HIGH school students and teachers in the Southern Westchester Boces district who want to study the score of a Bach cantata or learn about costumes in the age of Shakespeare can now get such materials through Project ARTS, a new cooperative school library program of sharing books and resource materials in the arts.

description: JOHN NEFF is no stranger to the winner's circle.

title: BRONX OFFICES
description: At long last, Fordham Plaza, the mixed-use office and retail complex, planned more than a decade ago for a 5.5-acre urban renewal site on Fordham Road in the Bronx, appears to be a reality. On Tuesday Mayor Koch will put shovel to earth at Third Avenue and Fordham Road, symbolizing the start of construction at the $60 million private and public development project.

title: WHAT'S NEW IN EUROPE
description: Brussels: An innovative home for modern art On Oct. 25 Brussels will celebrate the opening of its new Museum of Modern Art, which gives the city a permanent home for an extensive collection of 19th- and 20th-century art. The new museum, part of the Royal Museum for Ancient Art and situated next to it on the Place Royal, is a partially submerged building with two levels, the larger one almost entirely underground.

title: ILLINOIS MAY FOLLOW CHICAGO IN SEEKING BAN ON LEAD IN GAS
description: The Illinois Environmental Protection Agency is considering seeking a ban on the sale of leaded gasoline in the state, as a health measure.

title: No Headline
description: Comic Book SalesVintage comic books, paperbacks and movie memorabilia will be available for sale or trade at Phil Seuling's Comic Book Marketplace today from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. at Omni Park Central, Seventh Avenue and 55th Street. Admission is free. Information: 788-1126.

title: DANCE: TROUPE PERFORMS TO MAHLER
description: Because of an injury to a member of the company, Dance Theater of Harlem altered its program Thursday night at City Center, replacing ''Fall River Legend'' with a repeat performance of Glen Tetley's ''Voluntaries.'' The bill also included Michael Smuin's ''Songs of Mahler'' and Geoffrey Holder's ''Dougla,'' as scheduled, and both were danced very well.

title: Martha Marshall Is Married
description: Martha G. Marshall, the daughter of Martha Rodriguez of Woodside, Queens, and the late Roger V. Marshall, was married there yesterday to Nicholas A. Governale, the son of Mrs. Josephine Morano of Rosedale, Queens, and the late Nicholas J. Governale. The Rev. Robert Robinson performed the ceremony at St. Sebastian's Roman Catholic Church. Mrs. Governale, a graduate of St. John's University, is a corporate account manager for Citibank in Long Island City. Mr. Governale, a graduate of the New York Institute of Technology, is a computer engineer with the Singer-Kearfott Company in Wayne, N.J.

title: FOLLOW-UP ON THE NEWS ; Great Pizza Trial
description: Not since the Great Cookie Monster Case of 1977, when a teen-ager was arrested for eating a chocolate-chip cookie on the sidewalk, had there been such a stir in Ocean Beach, on Fire Island. The police seized two youths for eating pizza in public.

title: Percy Objects to Moving Embassy to Jerusalem
description: Senator Charles H. Percy, Republican of Illinois, says Jews are wrong to call for moving the United States Embassy in Israel from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem. He says the issue should not be part of his campaign for re-election.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;
ONCE UPON A MEADOW: A PLACE TO GROW AND DREAM
description: WITH no warning, a trailer truck appeared one day in the lane between the rows of trees in front of our house, carrying a bulldozer. It was followed by a backhoe and mammoth earth mover - a sinister procession that began the rape of a glorious meadow that was next to our home for almost 18 years when we lived in Westbury.

title: WHO CONTROLS SCIENCE?
description: THE NEW POLITICS OF SCIENCE

title: Growing Old Ungracefully
description: Upstairs, above an elegant little Parisian gourmet shop on the Place de la Madeleine called Caviar Kaspia, is an equally elegant little restaurant where elderly White Russians and other caviar enthusiasts repair to revel in beluga, sevruga, osetra and cold vodka. Some years ago, Narsai David, the Berkeley, Calif., restaurateur and caterer, made an astonishing discovery. Along with the vodka, Caviar Kaspia had an extraordinary collection of old Champagnes.

title: THRILLER FROM THE THEATER
description: -year-old seeing his first live musical, ''The Pajama Game,'' at the Westbury Music Fair. Playing the trombone in the Huntington High School Orchestra clinched it.

title: PEI GIVES A COLLEAGUE CREDIT FOR JOHNSON & JOHNSON OFFICE
description: NEW BRUNSWICK THE Johnson & Johnson headquarters here is widely described as a creation of the architect I.M. Pei, but the person who did the actual work was one of Mr. Pei's six partners, Henry N. Cobb, chairman of the Harvard University Graduate School of Design.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;
IN PRINT: 'TO WHOM,' BUT IN MIND: 'HEY, YOU!'
description: IT has happened to us all. We sit

title: Nuclear Plant Restarted
description: Utility crews today restarted the Trojan nuclear power plant, which had not been operating for several weeks because of leaks and equipment problems. The plant, generating power for the Portland General Electric Company, was operating at 37 percent of full power by midmorning, according to a spokesman.

title: PLAYING AGAINST COMPUTERS
description: We all tend to believe that computers, unlike human beings, are always honest. If they cheat us, we assume that there has been human or electronic error. But in a bridge sense that is not true.

title: THE WORLD ; A NicaraguanElection DealFalls Through
description: For a time last week, a way out of the political and military skirmishing in Nicaragua seemed possible. But the optimism died quickly as the Sandinista leadership, the political opposition, the United States and the armed rebel groups showed no hurry to compromise.

title: Piggott Is Injured
description: Lester Piggott , the famous British jockey who had been scheduled to ride the favorite, Rainbow Quest, in today's Arc de Triomphe at Longchamp in Paris, suffered a concussion in a spill at a Newmarket race yesterday and will have to miss the race. Tony Walton will take Piggott's place in the French classic, which is regarded as the top thoroughbred race in Europe.

title: HAUNTS AND HANGOUTS
description: Carioca

title: PORNOGRAPHY BILL STIRS FUROR IN SUFFOLK
description: A SWEEPING bill to discourage movies, magazines and books that depict sexual violence against women has set off a constitutional furor in Suffolk County.

title: SMALL MISSILES INCUR OUTSIZED PROBLEMS
description: With Congress content to finance the military establishment at nearly $300 billion a year and with such blockbuster weapon projects as the B-1 bomber and Trident submarine rolling merrily along, voters might wonder in this election season whatever happened to the great defense issues. Even the MX missile program, which must run a gantlet of four votes of approval on Capitol Hill next spring, will still get almost three billion new dollars free and clear for fiscal year 1985, which began last week.

title: ; OF POETS, MADNESS AND A STATISICAL 'SHAM'
description: To the Editor:

title: IDEAS & TRENDS ; Supreme CourtMakes Its List
description: The Supreme Court can accept only a small number of the several thousand cases it is asked to review each year. So what the Justices choose to consider - or to sidestep - sometimes can tell as much about the Court's mood as the decisions it eventually hands down.

title: CUOMO SETS RULES FOR COMPANIES CLAIMING TO BE MINORITY-OWNED
description: Governor Cuomo has issued rules under which the state will determine whether companies that claim to be owned by women or members of minority groups really are.

title: KENTUCKY DEFEATS RUTGERS, 27-14, AND IS NOW 4-0
description: Mark Higgs ran 76 and 29 yards for touchdowns tonight as Kentucky (4-0) rallied from a 14-13 halftime deficit and defeated Rutgers (3-2), 27-14.

title: FANTASTIC ATTRACTIONS
description: OMNI'S SCREEN FLIGHTS/SCREEN FANTASIES

title: A DAD DIMINISHED
description: Brock Brower describes a generation of parents who are the walking wounded. The rules have been changed in the middle of the game.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;
RAISING THE SALARIES OF TEACHERS IS KEY TO BETTER EDUCATION
description: THE job advertisement called for a minimum of a bachelor's degree. The employer was looking for a bright, articulate individual who had the special talents and ability to work with children and young adults. Creativity, being able to motivate the individuals he or she would be working with everyday was clearly a prerequisite.

title: JAZZ: TOGETHER AT GREGORY'S, 2 GEORGE SHEARING ALUMNI
description: Two veterans of the George Shearing Quintet - Chuck Wayne and Warren Chiasson - have formed an unusual association at Gregory's, the tiny little bar that spills out onto a glass-enclosed sidewalk area at First Avenue and 63d Street.

title: Katherine Griffiths Weds C. W. Trout, Colgate Dean
description: Charles W. Trout, dean of the faculty and provost of Colgate University, and Katherine Taylor Griffiths, a sixth-grade teacher at the Winsor School in Boston, were married yesterday. The Rev. Elizabeth Alexander, a Methodist minister, performed the ceremony at the Friends Meeting House in North Sandwich, N.H.

title: THE POWER OF THE FANATICS
description: PEOPLE OFTEN ASK ME WHAT WAS THE MOST frightening moment I lived through in my four years in Lebanon. I saw many grotesque scenes in that country, and was shot at by anonymous madmen more times than I care to remember. But in the end it wasn't the sight or threat of death that scared me most. No, my most frightening moment came at the bar of the Commodore Hotel around lunchtime last Feb. 8. That was the day after the Shiite Moslem Amal militia had seized control of West Beirut from the Lebanese Army, and groups of Moslem militiamen belonging to the fanatical, pro-Iranian Hizbullah, or ''Party of God,'' had gone on a rampage, ransacking ''heathen'' bars and houses of prostitution. I was sitting in the hotel restaurant when I heard a ruckus coming from the lobby. I turned around and saw a tall, heavyset Shiite militiaman with a black beard, a wild look in his eye and an M-16 in his hands, heading for the bar.

title: PROBLEMS HINDER SCIENTIFIC CHORES ON SPACE SHUTTLE
description: The seven astronauts aboard the space shuttle Challenger solved one annoying problem today and worked on another as they struggled to carry out one of the most ambitious programs of Earth observation ever.

title: CHILDHOOD OF A SOCIAL CRITIC
description: WHAT'S TO BECOME OF THE BOY?

title: Lauda in No. 8 Spot
description: Niki Lauda , seeking his third world drivers' title, failed yesterday to improve his eighth-row starting position for today's European Grand Prix in Nurburgring, West Germany, following engine problems in the rain- soaked final qualifying session.

title: TEDDY-BEAR LOVERS TO HAVE THEIR DAY
description: JANICE BURNHAM of Lebanon started her teddy bear collection when she was 16 years old, but she did not really start adding to it until her daughter was born, 18 months ago.

description: Text not available

title: JUDGES DISCUSS INNOVATIVE JURY PROCEDURES
description: How can juries in the Federal courts be more efficient? Should they be allowed to question witnesses? Should the judge give them a preview of the case on trial?

title:
STAGE VIEW;
WHAT'S WRONG WITH CANADIAN THEATER?
description: Gina Mallet is a drama critic based in Toronto.

title: CHIEF'S CROWN ROMPS TO COWDIN VICTORY
description: Chief's Crown avenged a recent defeat and reasserted himself as the best 2-year-old in the East, and perhaps in the nation, with a six-length victory over Bionic Light in the $119,600 Cowdin Stakes yesterday at Belmont Park.

description: THE BEST AMERICAN SHORT STORIES 1984

title: EASY LIVING IN MARIN
description: HERBERT GOLD's latest novel is ''Mister White Eyes'' (Arbor House).
