title: No Headline
description: SUNDAY, OCTOBER 7, 1984 International Washington believes the Salvadoran military has broken a long stalemate with guerrillas and is capable of neutralizing the insurgents by the end of 1986 if current military and political trends continue, according to senior national security officials. The officials said Government forces have gained the initiative in the fighting and have increased their mobility with an infusion of United States military aid. (Page 1, Column 5.) South Africa arrested three of the six political fugitives who took refuge in the British consulate in Durban last month. The three men, all of Indian descent, left the consulate sanctuary to challenge the South African Government on several points. Before the three surrendered to the police, the six fugitives called the United States Government ''reprehensible'' for rejecting a plea for sanctuary. (10:1-3.)

title: 'ARTISAN' BLUE CHEESE: CABRALES FROM SPAIN
description: PENELOPE CASAS, the author of ''The Foods and Wines of Spain'' (Knopf), is working on a book about the Spanish appetizer called tapas.

title: No Headline
description: Old 'Worthless' Stock A Widow's Bonanza

title: A BROADWAY HIT AT CITY OPERA
description: The New York City Opera edges a little closer to the American musical theater on Thursday with its new production of Stephen Sondheim's 1979 success, ''Sweeney Todd, the Demon Barber of Fleet Street.'' Delighted and buoyed by the success of Leonard Bernstein's ''Candide'' the past few seasons, the City Opera is offering ''Sweeney'' in much the same format - by blitzing its audiences with six performances of the Sondheim hit in five days. The opera returns for seven more performances in November. Beverly Sills, the company's general director, wants to revive more musicals to go along with its operatic repertory.

title: WHAT'S NEW WITH EXECUTIVES ABROAD
description: WHILE the percentage of Americans who turn out to vote has been dropping with each Presidential election, it has been steadily increasing among Americans overseas. That figure is expected to grow even more on Nov. 6, in response to the organizing efforts by the overseas branches of the Democratic and Republican Parties.

title: QUAINTNESS
description: I went to Nantucket to see how the quainting was coming along and whether it had done in my old friend Crowley.

title: 2 Parties Reach Fund Accord
description: The Republican and Democratic senatorial campaign committees have reached an agreement on how the two parties will handle transfers of money to their respective state party committees through November.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: MUSEUM FOR INVENTOR

title: 4 HIGHSMITH SCORES ROUT NOTRE DAME
description: At the point in the college football season when teams begin to consider themselves successes or disappointments, the fortunes of Miami and Notre Dame seemed to turn in opposite directions tonight.

title: DRAMA: AN UNLIKELY BANK HOLDUP
description: NEW BRUNSWICK

title: DIASPORA IN DIXIE
description: Eli N. Evans, the author of ''The Provincials: A Personal History of Jews in the South,'' is working on a biography of Judah P. Benjamin. CRESCENT CITY

title: TRANSCENDING THE 'I-NOVEL'
description: A VIEW BY THE SEA

title: DISABLED CITE JOB ADVANTAGES
description: ''I WAS told when I first got into banking that I would never be a commercial lending officer because I would be an embarrassment to the bank,'' said 35-year-old John Carter, a paraplegic from Massapequa. ''The reasons given were that people wouldn't want to sit across a desk from someone in a wheelchair.''

title: Holdouts Waning In Helmet Game
description: The small gash on Bob Nystrom's forehead, just above the right eye, was his reminder. He's been thinking about a helmet lately. Perhaps it's time.

title: ABOUT BOOKS
description: AS THE centennial of the birth of Eleanor Roosevelt approaches - she was born Oct. 11, 1884 - her life and personality capture public attention almost as fervently as when she was the wife of President Franklin D. Roosevelt.

title: IS AN ISOLATED PAWN ANATHEMA?
description: Some years ago, the late Max Euwe of the Netherlands, who was world champion from 1935 to 1937, said,''I don't see what the fuss over the isolated pawn is all about. I never minded having one.'' But he was speaking against the prevailing mode of theory.

title: CONNECTICUT ARTISTSATAKE CENTER STAGE IN STATE CONCERTS
description: TWO chamber recitals in Hartford this week are offering high visibility - and audibility - to Connecticut artists.

title: LATEST WORRY FOR ISRAELIS: AUSTERITY
description: Eilat, Israel's southern beach resort, is traditionally jammed over the long Rosh ha-Shanah weekend. But this year, instead of the 100,000 Israelis who were expected in Eilat, fewer than 35,000 showed up.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: In today's Guide, section 2A, a television listing and a highlight for NBC's ''Saturday Night Live'' have become outdated. The Rev. Jesse Jackson's appearance as host has been postponed to Oct. 20.

title: MEREDITH MONK OPENS THE NEXT WAVE
description: ''The Games,'' an evening of music-theater by Meredith Monk and Ping Chong, opens the Brooklyn Academy of Music's prestigious avant-garde festival, the Next Wave, on Tuesday night, and a more appropriate piece could hardly have been selected.

title: House Fire Kills 6 in Family
description: A wood-burning stove caused a fire that raced through a small frame house in southwestern Indiana early Friday, killing a woman and her five children, investigators said. They said the stove had been installed only a few days earlier by the woman's husband, David Carwile. Mr. Carwile, who returned from work to find the house in flames, was hospitalized in shock.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: BALDWIN THE sidewalks of New York were as thick with slow-moving crowds as a pea soup that has gone bad, and I was a bug in a hurry to get out of it. The subway was a sauna whose attendant had locked the bathers in and lost the key. And then I found myself sneezing in the wheezy, overworking air-conditioning of the Long Island Rail Road car. But it was only a five-minute cold.

title: ON COMMON GROUND
description: AT THE RISK OF sounding corny just as the World Series gets under way, I confess that I believe baseball is one of life's treasures. Growing up in a small, isolated Pennsylvania town in the 1950's, I received from the game not only the simple summer pleasures of friendship, competition and exercise, but also an early sense of the opportunties of the outside world. Except for the fantasy of far-off places provoked by the melancholy whistles of freight trains rumbling through the night, baseball, with its exotic roster of cities and states, constituted perhaps the biggest window on the world I had for many years.

title: THE WAY IT WAS, AND IS
description: Why is it that some people refuse, or are unwilling, to go back to a place where once they have been happy? If you ask them, they will say that they do not want to spoil a beautiful memory, or that nothing can ever be the same (a wonderful thing can only happen once!).

title: HIGH-TECH DRIVER CURBS
description: To the Editor:

title: Hispanic Voters Protest Bilingual Voter Aid Rules
description: A sharp cut in the number of counties required to provide bilingual voter assistance will disenfranchise thousands of Hispanic and other minority voters, Democratic Congressmen and civil rights groups asserted Friday.

title: IDEAS & TRENDS ; ChallengerTakes a CloserLook at Earth
description: At least one flight took off on schedule last week. The space shuttle Challenger was launched exactly one month after the return of its troubled sister ship, Discovery. ''This is a harbinger of how well things can go in the future,'' Thomas Utsman, director of shuttle operations at the Kennedy Space Center, said of the dazzling predawn liftoff at Cape Canaveral. NASA considers monthly shuttle launchings critical to its plan to attract paying cargo from other nations and private businesses.

title: 2 CANDIDATES VOW TO MEET WITH PRESS
description: President Reagan says he would ''continue to be as responsive as possible to the public through the media'' in a second term, and Walter F. Mondale says he would hold ''regular and frequent'' news conferences if elected.

title: Stephen Birdsall Irish To Wed Kim W. Pauly
description: Kim Wallace Pauly and Stephen Birdsall Irish plan to be married Nov. 24, her mother, Mrs. Wilmah V. Wallace of Montclair, N.J. has announced. Miss Pauly is a daughter also of the late Melvin J. Pauly.

title: RECENT RELEASES OF VIDEO CASSETTES
description: Video Rewind - The Rolling Stones Great Video Hits.Vestron MusicVideo. 60 minutes. $29.95.

title: SPINACH COMES OF AGE
description: IT HAS ALWAYS FASCINATED ME that the most famous cartoon ever printed about food involves spinach. That cartoon, the creation of Carl Rose, appeared in The New Yorker magazine on Dec. 8, 1928, and depicted a mother saying to her child, ''It's broccoli, dear.'' To which the child replied, ''I say it's spinach and I say the hell with it.''

title: Radiation Tests Are Assailed
description: Four union leaders representing hundreds of workers in nuclear weapon plants have accused the Department of Energy of manipulating test results to minimize the health effects of radiation exposure in the plants, and have asked that responsibility for the tests be shifted to the Department of Health and Human Services.

title: AT HARVEST, VAGARIES OF FARMING ARE CRYSTALLIZED
description: The fields of western Iowa were dark late that May night when a growling bright spot of light crept over the hill. Sitting high up inside a diesel apparition, his face glowing red from the dials of the tractor's control panel, Varel Bailey was growing weary of planting back and forth, back and forth.

title: Arizona Inmate Killed In Brawl After a Game
description: One Arizona State Prison inmate was killed and seven others were injured today in a fight that erupted after white and black inmates opposed each other in a football game, officials said.

title: CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: Halloween Costumes In Yorktown Heights

title: THIS 'GISELLE' MAKES US THINK ABOUT WHAT WE SEE
description: The Dance Theater of Harlem has transferred the locale and period of its first and current production of ''Giselle'' to the bayou country of 19th- century Louisiana and away from the ballet's traditional Germanic setting. Does this kind of reinterpretation - if indeed that is what it is - tell us something new about ''Giselle'' or more about a little- known chapter of Louisiana history? Does this version, ingenious on many counts, deepen our understanding of 19th-century Romantic ballet and make it meaningful in modern terms? Or is this a case where a 19th-century Romantic ballet provides mainly a vehicle for novelty?

title: PATTERNED SWEATERS
description: ASIDE FROM their basic function warmth - sweaters inject a spark of color into the predominantly somber palette of the male wardrobe. This fall, the traditional solid colors and patterns have been supplemented by sweaters that actually seem to come from an artist's easel.

title: PARENTS ENRICH SCHOOL CURRICULUM
description: SPRING LAKE AGROUP of parents has given pupils in Grades 6 through 8 at St. Catharine's School here a richer education by teaching 10-week ''mini-courses'' in more than a dozen subjects.

title: Of Speed and Surface
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: TENFOLD RISE IN OIL LOST AT SEA REPORTED FOR 1983
description: In a reversal of the trend of the last four years, the amount of petroleum lost at sea increased sharply last year.

title: SURPRISE SPURT IN ENROLLMENTS PLEASES COLLEGE COUNSELORS
description: For the first time in recent years, the country's college admission directors and high school guidance counselors were in a conspicuously upbeat mood as they gathered for their annual round of shop talk. The issues ranged from cram courses for the Scholastic Aptitude Test to direct mail solicitation.

title: Miss Schlotzhauer Is Wed to Stanley Mullins Jr.
description: Sandra Grace Schlotzhauer, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick H. Schlotzhauer of Canajoharie, N.Y., was married yesterday to Stanley St. Clair Mullins Jr., the son of Sybil D. Thompson of New York and the late Dr. Mullins. The Rev. Kenneth L. Reichley performed the ceremony at St. Peter's Lutheran Church in New York.

title: PATIENT TESTIFIES NURSE TURNED OFF HIS RESPIRATOR
description: Minutes after midnight on Feb. 17, William Cronin's respirator was switched off as he watched television, and Mr. Cronin, a severely crippled victim of an incurable nerve disease, lost consciousness.

title: EXHIBIT EXPLORES DAIRY FARMING
description: VISITORS to the Pound Ridge Museum will discover a new theme exhibit focusing on dairy farming, which the museum director, Ethel M. Scofield, said was ''really the dominant industry in the town, from its founding through the 1920's.'' The new display was introduced last weekend.

title: Warren Odette Engaged To Marry Julie S. Kasdin
description: Mr. and Mrs. Gerald B. Kasdin of Short Hills, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Julie S. Kasdin, to Warren S. Odette, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Sol W. Odette of Livingston, N.J. The wedding is to be in November.

title: WHY I FEAR FOR AMERICA'S FUTURE
description: For the first time since I arrived in America shortly after the end of World War II, I fear for our future. I haven't lost faith in the vitality of the country, and I still see great opportunities for newcomers like myself. What concerns me is what seems to be a gathering storm of intolerance.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;
REMOVE CHILD-CARE BURDEN FROM THE SCHOOLS
description: THE brouhaha over public education, and the ways and means to improve it, continues. Every parent, teacher, and student has an opinion; every government official and investigative journalist is eager to listen. To date, there has been a lot of talk, a little significant action.

title: 85th YEAR MARKED BY ST. ELIZABETH
description: CONVENT STATION IT IS with what she calls ''appropriately immodest pride'' that

title: A NEW LOOK IN NEW BRUNSWICK
description: THE young woman, a student at Douglass College who had always lived in the New Brunswick area, stared at the fountains where water cascaded over brick semicircular steps at Monument Square here.

title: THE POLITICS OF BLAME
description: CRISSCROSSING AMERICA THIS FALL, WALter F. Mondale has taunted President Reagan with running ''a government of the rich, by the rich and for the rich.'' In the farm country of western Tennessee, Mr. Mondale accused the President of creating ''superbowl deficits'' that have had ''dust bowl consequences'' for the family farm. At the B'nai B'rith convention in Washington, in response to Mr. Reagan's charge that people who oppose school prayer are intolerant of religion, he accused the President of ''moral McCarthyism.''

title: CORRIERE DELLA SERA, MAJOR ITALIAN DAILY, FINDS A NEW OWNER
description: The newspaper Corriere della Sera has been bought by a consortium backed by Italy's financial and industrial elite, a judicial official said toady.

description: Alan S. Moore, the general manager of the Galaxy

title: BUSINESS NOTES
description: A 56-year-old Art Deco skyscraper at 26 Journal Square, the business hub of Jersey City, has been entered in the National Register of Historic Places.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: Text not available

title: ALLEYNE RUSHES FOR 112 AS JACKSON ROMPS, 33-0
description: Host Jackson sent Springfield Gardens to its fourth straight loss with a 33-0 shutout in the only Public Schools Athletic League game yesterday.

title: THE HEARTLESS SOCIETY
description: While John Kenneth Galbraith is undoubtedly correct that much legislation of recent decades has favored the affluent at the expense of the poor, this is not, I submit, because we are a ''heartless society.'' A more important reason is that we don't seem able to write laws that have the effect intended by their authors.

title: WORKOUTS AT WORK ON RISE
description: IT'S 7 A.M. and Joseph Duerr, in

title: THE MAFIA MAY BE WOUNDED BUT NOBODY'S CALLING IT DEAD
description: The Mafia is dead, long live the Mafia.

GARDENING;
PREPARING FOR THE FIRST FROST
description: IN all likelihood it will frost

title: ARUND THE COUNTY, FILM FESTIVALS BEGIN
description: YOU can laugh your head off when one man plays eight roles in a 1949 British comedy, be piqued by the poignancy of life in a plush Berlin hotel in 1932, thrill to battles in North Africa and elsewhere, take moral or defensive stands in thought-provoking celluloid wonders or cry over tragedies beyond belief - all in the county.

title: THE WORLD ; Beirut EmbassyIs Found Lax
description: President Reagan last week accepted responsibility for the bombing of the United States Embassy in Beirut Sept.20 and indicated the case was closed. The next day, it was reopened by both Democrats and Republicans of the House Select Committee on Intelligence, which accused officials of ignoring warnings of terrorist attacks.

title: Inflation Heating Up?
description: The Producer Price Index, which has served as a security blanket for many inflation worriers since January, should show signs of fraying next Friday. Some economists, such as Jason Benderly of Kidder, Peabody & Company, say the September index could rise as much as one- half of 1 percent, compared with an increase of three-tenths of 1 percent for August, and no change at all for the previous three months. ''You can blame the rise mostly on the surge in oil prices that started in August, the month that the September figures actually measure,'' he said. ''By comparison, the Consumer Price Index for September, which is due out on the 24th, will be reflecting current prices.''

title: WHAT'S NEW IN EUROPE
description: Vienna: Opera in a new place; 200 years of new wine A new experiment - outdoor opera indoors - will take place in Vienna's Stadthalle later this fall. The huge, modern building, in an unfashionable neighborhood in the western part of the city, is Vienna's Madison Square Garden; it has lately seen political activity and prizefights. From Dec. 2 to 7, however, it will be the site of a lavish production of Puccini's ''Turandot,'' presented by the troupe of the Arena of Verona. That same production led to packed crowds when it was performed in Verona's ancient amphitheater during the summer.

title: A PLAYA BEST LEFT IN THE MUSEUM
description: WHY is the Hartman Theater in Stamford opening its 10th anniversary season with ''The Torch- Bearers,'' an archaic piece of nonsense? To Edwin Sherin, the artistic director, it is, apparently, an act of methodical madness. To ''retrieve lost or rarely seen American works'' is the way Mr. Sherin puts it in a program note that, in this instance, could be construed as an apologia. In fact, or even in fancy, ''The Torch-Bearers'' does not rate retrieval.

title: Funeral in Zimbabwe Brings Foes Together
description: Calls for national unity by both Joshua Nkomo, the opposition leader, and leaders of Prime Minister Robert Mugabe's Government marked the hero's funeral today of the nationalist Josiah Chinamano, the vice president of Mr. Nkomo's party.

title: AT THE FRONT IN THE 3rd DISTRICT BATTLE
description: NEW HAVEN ON a Tuesday morning, Lawrence J. DeNardis was holding a press conference in front of the Shubert Theater here. He said his vote in Congress in 1981 allowing investment tax credits for the rehabilitation of commercial and industrial buildings helped the rejuvenation of the Shubert and other older buildings in downtown New Haven.

title: INDUSTRY CALLS OIL SUPPLY 'ADEQUATE'
description: HARTFORD OIL executives say low inventories of No. 2 home heating oil in the state are no cause for concern, despite a recent statement by Governor O'Neill to the contrary.

description: Korongy ran for 221 yards and

title: Kick Beats Cornell, 10-7
description: A 47-yard field goal by Al Yuknus put Bucknell ahead to stay in a 10-7 victory over Cornell today in nonconference action.

title: HOUSE PANEL URGES TAX BREAKS FOR DAY CARE
description: Acknowledging the rapid rise of women in the American work force, a House committee has urged a major increase in Federal tax breaks for child care and incentives for schools and employers to provide day care for the children of working mothers.

title: GARVEY HOMER TOPS CUBS TO FORCE 5TH GAME
description: In one of the most gripping games in playoff history, the San Diego Padres defeated the Chicago Cubs, 7-5, tonight on a ninth- inning home run by Steve Garvey and tied the National League playoff at two games apiece.

title: A CENTENNIAL CELEBRATION ON 102D
description: When Ralph Samuel Townsend built his two-story brick and sandstone house on West End Avenue in 1884, it was the first private home on the street. A hundred years and dozens of dwellers later, the house is dwarfed by the apartment buildings around it, but it survives.

title: WHERE MYSTERY IS COMMONPLACE
description: RACHEL BILLINGTON's most recent novel is ''Occasion of Sin'' (Summit).

title: JIM BROWN: MORE DURABLE, EVEN, THAN HIS RECORD
description: I OWNED the Browns the last five

title: REPERTORY IS THE HEART OF THE R.S.C.
description: Whenever the Royal Shakespeare Company pays a visit to Broadway, it is, by definition, a major theatrical event. Usually the R.S.C. has been represented in New York by a single production, last season with ''All's Well That Ends Well,'' ''Good'' in 1982 and the year before by the landmark two-part version of ''The Life and Adventures of Nicholas Nickleby.'' This season the R.S.C. returns with two plays, ''Much Ado About Nothing'' and ''Cyrano de Bergerac'' (now in previews, opening Oct. 14 at the Gershwin), a repertory season that is more representative of the company's founding principle. The R.S.C. is arguably the finest ensemble classical repertory theater in the world today.

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN BAYVILLE
description: At the northernmost point of Nassau

title: SCORES ARE FELLED BY CLOUD OF FUMES
description: A yellow cloud of noxious fumes leaked from a chemical insecticide plant on the Arthur Kill yesterday and spread over a 20-mile area of New Jersey and Staten Island, causing alarm and physical irritation among thousands of residents but no serious injuries.

title: Barbara Ferrara Weds R.W. Kurz
description: Barbara Ann Ferrara, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph E. Ferrara of Montvale, N.J., was married yesterday to Richard William Kurz, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William Kurz of Chatham, N.J. The Rev. James Turro performed the ceremony at Our Lady Mother of the Church in Woodcliff Lake, N.J., assisted by the Rev. Mary Heyne, a Congregational minister.

title: HOW TO CHOOSE AND USE THE SEASON'S VARIOUS KINDS OF PEARS

title: ROCKLAND IS GRANTED $277,000 TO SET UP EMERGENCY NETWORK
description: The state has given Rockland County $277,000 to establish a mobile radio system to help the county's law enforcement officials communicate in the event of an emergency.

description: London

title: Christmas At a Museum In Vermont
description: Can't wait for Christmas?

title: PAYTON: TEAM PLAYER ON THE MOVE
description: LAKE FOREST, Ill.

title: TOWN BENEFACTOR GUILTY OF DRUG CONSPIRACY
description: Joseph D. Ramirez, who spent more than $1 million for improvements around the tiny town of Princeton, was found guilty today of conspiracy to import and distribute cocaine.

title: FOUR YEARS LATER, CROATIA STILL AWAITS PAPAL VISIT
description: Hundreds of thousands of Roman Catholic pilgrims thronged to this hillside village in September to celebrate the 1,300th anniversary of Christianity in Croatia. But despite the hopes of many in the crowd, Pope John Paul II did not come, though he was invited by the Yugoslav Government four years ago.

title: Going With the Wind in Nicaragua
description: Nicaragua's Sandinistas risk blowing away a chance to demonstrate their popularity and to confound their most bitter critics. All along President Reagan has insisted that they would never permit reasonably free elections or genuine pluralism. If they go forward with plans to hold a sham vote on Nov. 4, they will confirm Mr. Reagan's thesis.

title: BIRDERS FLOCK TO CAPE MAY
description: CAPE MAY DESPITE two days of rain, wind and temperatures in the chilly 50's, birdwatchers were here in droves last weekend for the New Jersey Audubon Society's 39th annual Autumn Outing.

title: ENVIRONMENTAL REVIEW CARRIES AN IMPACT OF ITS OWN
description: When a developer wanted to build a thousand units of low-rise housing in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn a year ago, city officials decided that no environmental-impact statement would be needed because the development would create no significant environmental impact.

title: North Bergen Wins And Stays Unbeaten
description: North Bergen remained unbeaten after three games when it scored a 24- 6 victory over Snyder of Jersey City yesterday in North Bergen.

title: Q AND A ;
description: The Oldest Co-op

title: THE NATION ; CongressUnavoidablyDetained
description: Congress had hoped to wrap up its legislative season last week, but on Friday - unable to come to terms on a spending bill and a measure giving the Government authority to sink even deeper into debt - the House and Senate instead recessed until Tuesday.

title: DEBATE LOOMS ON FUTURE OF PLAYLAND
description: COUNTY EXECUTIVE Andrew P. O'Rourke and key members of the county's Board of Legislators, including some in Mr. O'Rourke's own Republican Party, may soon collide over the future of Playland, the 56-year-old county-owned Rye amusement park.

title: GEORGIA, ALABAMA HOLD REUNION
description: The occasion was more a reunion than the resumption of a rivalry. It had been seven years since the cars, trucks and Winnebagos carrying Georgia fans crossed the state line into Alabama, and the residents were treated to the sound of a bulldog's bark in the early morning hours.

description: SAN DIEGO The legacy of Walt Alston's

description: The current policy of the United

title: THE RETAILER WITH A SENSE OF LOGISTICS
description: ABOUT a year ago, when James M. Guinan, then chairman of the Gold Circle discount-store division of Federated Department Stores, heard that I.B.M. had developed a holographic scanner, he summoned his own computer expert and they promptly flew down to I.B.M.'s ''think tank'' in Raleigh, N.C.

title: RESEARCH TEAM AT I.B.M. DEVELOPS A NEW COMPUTER
description: p

title: EUGENE FODOR IS HAVING SECOND THOUGHTS ABOUT THE PAST
description: If there's one thing the violinist Eugene Fodor wants more than anything in the world, it's for the musical public to forget about his past. Not his entire past - until a decade ago, when he won the silver medal at the Tchaikovsky Competition, in Moscow, he had been living a charmed life. He was 24 then, and he had been performing publicly since he was 9, touring from age 12, and playing with major orchestras since he was 16. There were lessons with Ivan Galamian and Josef Gingold, a scholarship to Juilliard, and master classes with Jascha Heifetz. And by the time he entered the Tchaikovsky, he had already won 10 smaller-scale violin competitions and had even taken the top prize at a local piano contest. Yet, within a year of his victory in Moscow, Mr. Fodor's luck began running out, and his career became a classic example of unfulfilled promise.

title: OAKLAND FIGHTING BACK TO END DRUG VIOLENCE
description: On dozens of street corners here, heroin, cocaine and other illegal drugs can be bought day and night. At least 20 people, including a pregnant 15-year-old girl who was shot by mistake, have died so far this year in warfare involving rival drug gangs.

title: Russian Is Detained With Old $500 Note
description: The wife of a Soviet diplomat here was detained briefly by the police after trying to cash a $500 bill that went out of circulation in 1937, Foreign Ministry sources said today.

GARDENING;
PREPARING FOR THE FIRST FROST
description: IN all likelihood it will frost

title: SALVADORAN REBELS SAY FORCED RECRUITING IS OVER
description: Salvadoran rebel leaders say their forces have stopped recruiting efforts that in several instances appeared to force civilians to join guerrilla ranks.

title: Ripping Off the Governor Apparently upset that he couldn't get to talk to Governor Cuomo about getting his state job back,
description: Julian J. Quarles took matters into his own hands last week. He also took some silverware and video equipment, according to the police, in the course of burglarizing the Executive Mansion in Albany one night while members of the Cuomo family slept unawares. Mr. Quarles was fired as a state janitor in 1981 and had tried to take his case for reinstatement to Mr. Cuomo after being rebuffed by lower officials.

title: HOW I OVERHAULED MY MECHANIC'S NOVEL
description: Dan Greenburg is the author of ''How to Be a Jewish Mother.'' Y mechanic was having trouble with his novel. Knowing I was a novelist, he asked if I could help. I told him to bring it in and I'd have a look. He told me he needed it back pretty soon. I told him it was my busy season but I'd see what I could do.

title: 'THE BRAIN' BEGINS A VOYAGE OF DISCOVERY ON PUBLIC TV
description: The human brain can imagine heaven and hell, can probe the outer fringes of the universe and the innermost core of the atom, but it has never been able to understand itself. This is not surprising. The three pounds of pinkish gray tissue that make up the brain constitute the most complex and potent creation that has emerged in the whole 3.5 billion years of life on earth. It would be presumptuous to think the secrets of this marvel of biology could be easily fathomed.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Making Room for Mammals

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: A BIBLICAL injunction instructs farmers to leave a corner of the field for the poor to glean or pick. Since few Long Islanders have farms to leave ungleaned, a group from the Melville-Dix Hills area is doing what the members consider the next best thing: They are going out into the fields themselves to glean for the poor.

title: EX-AGENT IN SPY CASE SENT TO MORE SECURE PRISON
description: As his wife searched for an attorney to represent him, a former agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation accused of conspiring to sell secrets to the Soviet Union was moved to special protective custody today.

title: BIRGHTON's OCEAN OF ANTIQUES
description: DONALD GODDARD is a writer who lives in London. His latest book, ''Diamond Cut,'' a World War II adventure set in the Netherlands, is to be published by Times Books.

title: FOLLOW-UP ON THE NEWS ; Men's Rights
description: It struck Sidney Siller, a Manhattan lawyer, that all the talk about women's rights was sowing the seeds of a gross injustice. In August 1983 he founded the National Organization for Men, dedicated to ''equal rights for men.''

title: PORT AUTHORITY COMISSIONER A MAN OF TWO HATS
description: WEST CALDWELL WHEN Henry Fairfax Henderson Jr. began building control panels in the basement of his home here nearly 30 years ago, he was confident that his one-man operation would lead to grander opportunities because of two things: It helped pay the bills for himself and his family and it was a gamble with minimal risks.

title: Votes in Congress; Last Week's Tally in Key Eastern States
description: Senate

title: Cee Cee Cunning Engaged to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Michael Cunning of Troy, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Cynthia Ann Cunning to James Benjamin Wilbur 4th, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Wilbur 3d of Geneseo, N.Y., and Manchester, Vt. A January wedding is planned.

title: IN HOLLAND, A ROYAL HOUSE TOUT
description: -based writer who frequently visits the Netherlands.

title: Kathleen Murray, Kevin M. Livesey Are Wed in Jersey
description: Kathleen Galvin Murray, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Morgan J. Murray of Morristown, N.J., was married yesterday to Kevin Michael Livesey, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph R. Livesey of Plymouth Meeting, Pa., at the Roman Catholic Church of Christ the King in New Vernon, N.J. The nuptial mass was celebrated by Msgr. John F. Corr and the wedding ceremony was performed by the Rev. William J. Galvin, a cousin of the bride.

title: GROWING SUPPORT FOR REPUBLICANS FOUND IN SURVEY
description: President Reagan's popularity seems to have so strengthened the image of the Republican Party that almost as many voters now consider themselves Republicans as Democrats, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.

title: WHAT'S NEW IN EUROPE
description: Rome: Trattorias make a comback; bus link to Sicily Sun worshipers who visit Rome hoping for fine weather and find themselves disappointed have a new option, the Tigrotto (Little Tiger) bus service to Palermo, the capital of Sicily. The odds are that even deep in winter the Sicilian sky will be radiant. The coach leaves daily, including Sunday, at 8 A.M. from Piazza della Repubblica (Piazza Esedra), near the railroad terminal. It stops for an hour's lunch somewhere in Calabria and reaches Palermo at 8:45 P.M. One-way fare, including lunch, is $41. The new bus link not only provides visitors with a chance of catching some Sicilian sun, it also enables them to see a good deal of southern Italy.

title: Judy Amanda Block Wed To Jeffrey Scott Woodman
description: Judy Amanda Block, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Lionel V. Block of Toronto, was married yesterday to Jeffrey Scott Woodman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles E. Woodman of Laurel Hollow, L.I. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. T. Carleton Lee at St. John's Episcopal Church in Cold Spring Harbor, L.I.

title: Cambodia Rebels Report Attacks on Vietnamese
description: The Pol Pot guerrillas said today that they had inflicted heavy damage on Vietnamese transport and supply links in Cambodia, and had ''crushed down'' more than 10,000 Vietnamese soldiers during fighting in the rainy season, from May to September.

title: HAITIANS STRUGGLE TO SAVE A FORTRESS FROM RUIN
description: The Citadelle La Ferri ere is a huge brick and mortar fortress on a mountaintop in northern Haiti, built in the early 1800's as the keystone of the newly independent country's defenses against a possible counterattack by the defeated French colonists.

title: 200 Hours Spent, Not $200, on Census
description: I would like to correct an error in the Westchester Weekly section of Sept. 23 (''Sale of Tract Stirs Concern in Bronxville') that told of a land sale in Bronxville. I was quoted as having said that I spent $200 while making a census of the village's commercial district.

title: GEMS ARE FOUND ON THE BYWAYS OF SONG
description: Szymanowski, Auric, Stradella. Chandler, Clerambault, Hundley. Where are we? Bowles, Durey, Lili Boulanger. The experienced musical traveler will know: this is the region of Neglected Vocal Literature, on the fuzzy borders of Lieder-land.

title: UNUSUAL TEACHER FOR UNUSUAL PIANO CLASS
description: STUART HEMINGWAY of Riverside is rare among piano teachers. Most of his 35 students are blind, mentally or physically disabled, or have temporary depressions or other emotional disorders.

title: BIG SHOW IN HARTFORD SETS THE TRENDS IN ANTIQUES
description: FOR lovers of American antiques, be they collectors, curators, or merely connoisseurs, discreet dealers or indiscriminate dabblers, there is nothing more delectable than the cornucopia of a major antiques show.

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;
THERE'S NO PLACE LIKE ROME
description: YORKTOWN TAKE Latin. That is what Robert Martin, who teaches the subject at the high school here, tells students. Take Latin.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE;
description: FANFARES AND FUN

title: WHAT'S NEW IN EUROPE
description: Athens: Free ferries to less-visited islands; mountain ski resort Some outer islands of the Greek archipelagos have become more accessible to visitors - at no cost. Under a new plan devised by the Greek tourist authorities, travelers are being offered free transportation between some of the country's more popular islands and others not on the usual tourist circuit. The aim is to enable a larger number of Greeks to share the tourists' dollars, pounds or francs. For visitors, the result is easier access to those islands not favored by regular airline or ship service from Athens - those less likely to be frequented by tourists.

title: GENIUS IN SCANDINAVIAN DESIGN
description: If there is any danger to putting on

title: C. T. Buckley to Marry Lucy S. Gregg
description: Mr. and Mrs. Donald Phinney Gregg of Bethesda, Md., and Putney, Vt., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lucy Steuart Gregg, to Christopher Taylor Buckley, the son of Mr. and Mrs. William F. Buckley Jr. of New York and Stamford, Conn.

title: STAGE: EQUITY LIBRARY PRESENTS 'TRIBUTE'
description: The show chosen by the Equity Library Theater to open its 42d season is one of fairly recent vintage, Bernard Slade's ''Tribute,'' a 1978 Broadway play, a sort of philosophical comedy - wherein lies its problems - and a work that ranks high in the ''contrived'' category. For all its faults, it admirably suits E.L.T.'s purpose - to serve as an actors' showcase.

title: TIGERS' PENNANT IS SPECIAL TO ANDERSON
description: Sparky Anderson earned his fifth World Series ring Friday night, the gaudy prize that goes to members of pennant-winning teams, but the Detroit Tiger manager is no more likely to wear this one than the other four.

title: BEVERLY HILLS DEVELOPER OFFERS LAND AND DREAMS
description: On Rodeo Drive in Beverly Hills the new bronze and beveled-glass doors of one showroom hardly compete with the bolder exteriors of stores called Bijan, Giorgio's and Fred. But for sheer spending potential, there is probably nothing that exceeds it.

title: DEADLINES ARE SET FOR ENTRIES FOR PUULITZER PRIZES IN LETTERS
description: The deadline for entries for the 1985 Pulitzer Prizes in letters is Nov. 1, according to Columbia University, which administers the prizes and awards them each spring.

title: AGENCY BACKS QUINCY, MASS., ANTI-BIAS PLAN
description: After months of controversy and threatened cuts in state or Federal funds, a Massachusetts civil rights agency has approved Quincy's plan to end what the agency says is discrimination in housing, hiring and awarding of contracts to businesses owned by women or members of minority groups.

title: GEORGE BUSH - LOYALTY TO THE CAUSE
description: Francis X. Clines is a White House reporter for The Times. ONCE THERE was a time, a mere instant, when George Bush would not go gentle into the twilight of the Vice Presidency. It was in 1980, when his closest aides had to confront him with the inevitable defeat of his Presidential campaign and coax him off the treadmill of his candidacy before the rabid pursuit of Ronald Reagan proved fatal.

title: SHE HAS A MESSAGE FER OLD AND YOUNG
description: '' WE feel that well-known personalities have an influence on the public that can be very salutary,'' said Marion Glasserow Gladney of Manhasset.

title: U.S. Advances in World Cup
description: The United States made a convincing start on the road to the 1986 World Cup in Mexico today by advancing to the second round with a 4-0 triumph over the Netherlands Antilles at Busch Stadium.

title: Board Blocks Killer's Parole
description: The California parole board has ordered Theodore Streleski to spend six months more in prison for refusing to agree to terms of his parole, including that he stay away from Stanford University, where he killed a professor with a hammer.

title: 11 Food Outlets Cited by City For Violations of Health Code
description: The New York City Department of Health cited 11 food establishments last week for violating the health code.

title: FALL'S SPLENDOR COMES TO LITCHFIELD
description: ON a recent morning at about 9 A.M., Eliza Bailey unlocked the door of a tiny white building on the village green in Litchfield. After tidying the piles of brochures, maps and booklets on its shelves, she pulled her cardigan more tightly around her to ward off the morning chill, and settled into a chair to await her first visitor.

title: ; Kahn Replies
description: To the Editor:

title: PROXY ACCORD CLEARS WAY FOR CASINO LICENSE
description: The State Casino Control Commission has renewed the license for the Claridge Casino Hotel in Atlantic City after a New York securities concern agreed to give up its right to vote the stock that it holds in the casino's owner, the Del E. Webb Corporation of Phoenix.

title: No Headline
description: JeanBlodgett, Fund-Raiser, Has Nuptials

description: In the spring, when the Netherlands is ablaze with flowers, a party of travelers will set forth from the United States to rediscover the links that bind the two countries.

title: MICHIGAN IS UPSET
description: Shane Swanson returned a punt 49 yards for a touchdown in the fourth quarter to snap a 3-3 tie and Nebraska went on to a 17-3 victory over previously unbeaten Oklahoma State (4-1, 0-1) in a Big Eight Conference game today. Swanson took Cary Cooper's punt near midfield, broke up the middle and ran down the sideline after eluding the last defender.

title: Dartmouth Loses, 30-20
description: Pete Muldoon's second touchdown pass of the day broke a 20-20 tie in the fourth quarter today and led unbeaten Holy Cross to a 30-20 victory over Dartmouth, which has not won this season.

title: GREAT WHITE SHARK SIGHTINGS INCREASE OFF CALIFORNIA COAST
description: Lured by an increasing population of seals, sea lions and other marine mammals, great white sharks are preying in ever greater numbers near the northern California coast.

title: PARENTS' DIVORCE COMPLICATES AID TO STUDENTS
description: COLLEGE students whose parents have divorced often face confusion and unnecessary monetary hardships because they are unaware of how to apply for financial aid adjustments, according to financial aid directors at several Long Island schools.

title: DISPUTE ON ACCORD IN STRIP-MINE SIUT
description: A dispute within the Reagan Administration is delaying the settlement of a long-contested strip-mining lawsuit that would roll back a number of deregulatory policies.

title: RAIL TERMINAL PLAN FOR RESORT GAINS
description: ATLANTIC CITY AMULTIPURPOSE project embodying a railroad terminal, a new convention hall, at least 3,000 parking spaces and a non-casino hotel appears to be fully under way only weeks after its inception.

title: Nancy Pivirotto Is Bride in Greenwich Of William Albert Barbe, a Bank Aide
description: Nancy Patricia Pivirotto, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Roy Pivirotto of Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to William Albert Barbe, a son of Mrs. Robert W. Barbe and the late Mr. Barbe of Kansas City, Mo. The Rev. Alastair Votaw and the Rev. Jack Bishop performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church in Greenwich.

title: GPVERNOR'S PANEL IN JERSEY PROPOSES STRICT RULES ON ASBESTOS
description: New Jersey will have the toughest environmental standards for asbestos in the nation under proposals the state will adopt by the end of the year, Governor Kean said this week.

The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Thomas E. Robinson at the First Presbyterian Church of Mendham, assisted by the Rev. Peter Meaney, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: FOR SALE: TINY TOWN WITH VIEW ON COAST IN A PEACEFUL SETTING
description: For a mere $950,000, Gorda can be yours. The sale price of Gorda, situated on the Big Sur coast, includes 22 acres, seven houses, a general store, a gas station, a restaurant and a jade shop.

title: MILSTEIN TO OPEN SYMPHONY SEASON
description: NATHAN MILSTEIN will be guest soloist next weekend in the opening of the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra's 1984-85 season, playing the Tchaikovsky Violin Concerto in D under the orchestra's associate conductor, George Manahan.

description: Hector Techera kicked field goals of 39, 52 and 27 yards as Jersey City State ended a 35-game losing streak in the New Jersey State Conference by defeating Ramapo, 16-7, yesterday in Mahwah, N.J.

title: BRITAIN SHEDS ITS STATE COMPANIES
description: LONDON FIRST comes the stately music.

title: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: For an example of Hollywood moviemaking at its best, no one need look much beyond ''The Big Chill,'' which turns up for the first time on cable this week - Sunday at 8 P.M. and 4:10 A.M. on Cinemax and on WHT at 8 P.M. and on Thursday at 8 P.M. on Cinemax.

title: COMPANY TO MARKET FRESH EGGS
description: LAKEWOOD ACOMPANY that now produces eggs sold by supermarket chains under the stores' own labels is gambling that customers would pay 10 cents a carton more if those eggs were fresh.

title: LEAGUE OF MANY NATIONS, WITH A STYLE TO MATCH

Check out their hometowns and you will find N.H.L. players come from Skelleftea, Sweden, and Minneapolis as well as from Moose Jaw, Saskatchewan, and Toronto.

title: When the Expedition Is More Than a Vacation
description: Such activities are among the possibilities open to participants in the University of California Research Expeditions Program. Under the program, individuals instructed by the expedition staff contribute their labor and make a tax-deductible contribution, ranging from $500 to $1,500 depending on the project, which covers research expenses as well as food and accommodations.

title: PROTESTS INTENSIFY ON LANDFILL
description: A WAVE of protest originating within the neighborhoods near the Old Bethpage landfill is expected to crest again this week, when the Department of Environmental Conservation meets to consider a Town of Oyster Bay proposal to expand the landfill by another 13.5 acres.

title: Jordan Prince to Visit Egypt
description: Crown Prince Hassan of Jordan, brother of King Hussein, will visit Egypt Oct. 20 to 24 for a seminar on Egyptian-Jordanian cooperation, the Middle East News Agency reported today. He will be the first senior Jordanian official to come here since the two countries restored diplomatic relations Sept. 25.

BUSINESS FORUM;
RAPID ECONOMIC GROWTH IS THE SOLUTION
description: FOR the first time in 20 years, we

title: DOCTORS SHUNNING MEDICARE
description: JUST after Labor Day, Dr. Richard Ball and his two partners reviewed the accounts of their Medicare patients for the first eight months of 1984. The orthopedic group, whose office is in South Plainfield, found that for half those patients the reimbursements paid by Medicare were 70 percent or less than the doctors' usual charges.

title: MUSIC: ALEKSAI TAKENOUCHI, PIANIST
description: That battered old philosophical argument of freedom versus liberty surfaced once again at the Merkin Concert Hall Wednesday night. The subject, unwittingly perhaps, was Aleksai Takenouchi, a young pianist raised in Japan who has been studying and performing in Europe and America.

title: Data Bank; October 7, 1984
A TOUCH OF AUSTRIA OVER THE AIRWAVES
description: '' AH well, mate. She'll be right. I'll give you the drum. Stay home. Don't do any hard yakka,'' went the conversation on a recent Tuesday evening on radio station WVOF - 88.5 FM in Fairfield.

title: TONAL QUALITIES OF CARTRIDGES
description: Brazen and heretical pronouncements made in this column last week asserted that the use of different electrical design principles in a phono cartridge has little or no effect on the sound. Anticipating storms of protest, or at least murmurs of dissent, from manufacturers with sincere convictions or interests vested in either one or the other of these principles - for example, moving-coil designs as opposed to those with moving magnets - let me admit that my statements are based on no indisputable authority. I have only the evidence of my ears.

title: A LITMUS TEST ON PEACE THAT REAGAN CAN'T PASS
description: To the Editor:

title:
BUSINESS FORUM;
THE ONLY HOPE: TAX MORE, SPEND LESS
description: GROWING our way out of the chronic budget deficit is not an impossible dream, but the odds against getting enough growth to balance the budget are ruefully long. I'm sorry to have to draw that conclusion, because we badly need the economic growth - for higher living standards, greater equality of opportunity, enhanced national security and other desirable goals, as well as for the additional wages, salaries and profits that would deliver the tax revenues to close the budget gap. But the budget chasm is too wide to succumb to growth alone.

WESTCHESTER OPINION;

description: I SAID goodbye to the 1950's

title: GROMYKO SAYS U.S. IS 'DECEPTIVE' ON SPACE ARMS
description: Andrei A. Gromyko, the Soviet Foreign Minister, said today that the Reagan Administration was using ''deceptive maneuvers'' to avoid talks on limiting space weapons. He said the Soviet Union remained open to ''an honest and serious dialogue.''

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We got 40 million calls.'' - Sgt. Raymond Magyar of the Perth Amboy Police Department. (1:1.)

title: MAJOR NEWS IN SUMMARY ; Donovan IndictedIn New YorkContract Case
description: From the start of his tour in Washington, there were questions about the business dealings of Raymond J. Donovan, a New Jersey construction executive before he was sworn in as Secretary of Labor. The questions continued even after inquiries by a Senate committee, which decided to drop the matter, and by Leon A. Silverman, a special prosecutor, who investigated allegations linking Mr. Donovan to organized crime and ultimately reported that there was ''insufficient credible evidence'' to justify Federal charges.

description: JOHN VINOCUR is chief of the Times bureau in Paris.

description: Following are excerpts from a review by Bosley Crowther of ''The Eleanor Roosevelt Story'' when it had its original theatrical release in 1965. The 90-minute documentary, written and narrated by Archibald MacLeish and directed by Richard Kaplan, will be broadcast Wednesday at 10 P.M. on Channel 13.

title: KENT STOPS A RALLY AND WINS BY 21-14
description: Avon Old Farms, trailing by 21-14 in the final minutes of its game against Kent yesterday, made three first downs on fourth-down plays, which moved the visitors to Kent's 10- yard line with 6 seconds remaining. ''My old ticker was beating a mile a minute at this point,'' Cy Theobald, the Kent coach, said after the game.

title: McEnroe Withdraws
description: John McEnroe, citing shoulder and elbow injuries, withdrew abruptly yesterday from the Australian Indoor Tennis Championships next week in Sydney, and tournament officials said it was too late to find a high-ranked replacement.

description: DETROITHe had tasted champagne dripping from his forehead and the tip of his nose, but that was all the way back in 1969 with the Atlanta Braves, and Darrell Evans had not been responsible for the spraying.

title: WHERE VAN GOGH'S ART REACHED ITS ZENITH
description: ''Between two such beings as he and I, the one a perfect volcano, the other boiling inwardly too, a sort of struggle was preparing,'' wrote Paul Gauguin in his 1903 memoir, ''Avant et Apres,'' years after his disastrous two-month stay with Vincent van Gogh at Arles. ''In the first place, everywhere and in everything I found a disorder that shocked me. His color-box could hardly contain all those tubes, crowded together and never closed. In spite of all this disorder, this mess, something shone out of his canvases and out of his talk, too.''

title: 10th BIRTHDAY AT THE HARTMAN BRINGS ON 'THE TORCH-BEARERS'

title: WHITMAN LIBRARY TO BE DEDICATED
description: A THREE-STORY frame house next to the one purchased by ''The Good Gray Poet'' 100 years ago will be officially dedicated next Sunday as the Walt Whitman Library.

title: Miss Fanton Has Nuptials
description: Deborah J. Fanton, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Dwight F. Fanton of Fairfield, Conn., was married yesterday to Richard A. Manley Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Manley of Hingham, Mass. The Rev. George Coxe Bland performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. John Morton Gallop, at the Greenfield Hill Congregational Church in Fairfield.

title: ISRAELI CHIEF STARTS U.S. VISIT TODAY
description: Prime Minister Shimon Peres left tonight on a weeklong visit to the United States aimed primarily at enlisting American help in solving Israel's worsening economic crisis.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;
WHEN THE GOING GETS TOUGH-IN ELEMENTARY SCHOOL
description: WHEN my daughter, Jo, entered elementary school five long years ago, I had an uneasy feeling that I was surrendering her to the state. She was about to learn stories, songs and even values from someone other than me for the first time.

description: Greek officials blamed the United States this week for the frequent anti-American statements of Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou and his associates.

title: The Worm and the Apple ; The Right Track ; Puddle Jumpers
description: The track around the Central Park reservoir may be the most popular running facility in the world. By one informed estimate, 10,000 people run around it every day, and they come in all shapes and styles. Some circle the 1.58- mile cinder track alone, others in twos, threes, even sixes. Some are turned out in chic Gore-Tex running suits, others in reverse chic, like faded Oxford University sweatshirts. Some talk; others, who haven't built up their wind, listen. Some merely jog; a friend in his 40's says he's often passed by a woman who must be in her 60's. Others really run, at paces of seven or six minutes a mile.

title: DANCE: YASUKO NAGAMINE PERFORMS
description: There was a klieg light stationed outside Carnegie Hall on Wednesday night. Inside, the stage was bathed in stage fog and colored lights and filled with 58 chanting Buddhist monks. It all provided an elaborate setting for Yasuko Nagamine, a Japanese performer, and a production called ''Mandara'' (Reincarnation).

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: BAY HEAD THE summer crowds have left the tidal stream and the little wooden footbridge here. It is autumn, and the belted kingfisher again patrols the stream without human interruption.

title: 16TH IN ROW WON BY BRIGHAM YOUNG
description: Robbie Bosco completed 16 of 21 passes for 246 yards and two touchdowns and ran for a third to lead Brigham Young to a 52-9 rout of Colorado State in a Western Athletic Conference game today.

title: Canker Seen at 7th Nursery
description: Citrus canker was confirmed in a small Florida nursery yesterday, the first such discovery in two weeks and the seventh since the deadly bacterial disease began threatening the state's $1 billion industry. The State Department of Agriculture said canker was found near Haines City at Adams Containerized Citrus Tree Inc., a nursery with about 1,000 seedlings.

title:
DINING OUT;
A HEARTY NEIHBORHOOD SPOT

PREPARING FOR THE FIRST FROST

title: 'HARVEY MILK' RELIVES COAST SLAYING
description: Harvey stood for something more than just him,'' someone remarks in ''The Times of Harvey Milk,'' and this warm, well-made documentary makes that eminently clear. The personality of the slain San Francisco Supervisor, who along with Mayor George Moscone was shot in 1978 by the disgruntled former Supervisor Dan White, comes through strongly, but personality is not the film's foremost concern. Robert Epstein, who co-directed the equally affecting ''Word Is Out,'' indicates the ways in which Harvey Milk was emblematic of one segment of society and Dan White of another. And he traces the clash that arose between them.

title: WESTBURY IMPOSES CONSTRUCTION CURBS
description: CITING potential problems for local residents because of large construction projects in the surrounding areas, Westbury village officials have imposed a temporary moratorium on all nonresidential construction in their jurisdiction.

title: Poultry Quarantine Is Lifted
description: An 11-month-old ban on the movement of Pennsylvania poultry was lifted for most farms Thursday as all flocks infected by a deadly influenza are believed to have been destroyed.

title: S.A.T. SCORES RISE IN CITY'S SCHOOLS
description: June graduates from New York City's public high schools got slightly higher scores on the Scholastic Aptitude Tests than their counterparts did the year before, according to Schools Chancellor Nathan Quinones.

title: Cleveland Man Is Held In Death of 2 Children
description: A former mental patient was hospitalized in police custody today after being accused of torturing and killing two children and seriously injuring a third.

title: Asian Bankers To the Editor:
description: While I agree with the basic argument in William J. Holstein's article, ('Don't Underestimate the Asians Again,'' Sept. 30), it contains a number of factual and conceptual errors.

title:
ART;
INDIAN EXHIBITION LOOKS AT HISTORY
description: THE Museum of the American Indian has recently computer-indexed its paintings and drawings, a collection that covers a range of geographical subjects from Alaska to Florida. To commemorate this modernization, the upper Manhattan institution has mounted an exhibition and produced a catalogue for the Bronx Museum of the Arts. The exhibition can be seen at the museum through Oct. 14.

title: MUSICIANS' GROUP CELEBRATES
description: THE Performers of Connecticut Inc. will celebrate its 12th anniversary and its founder's birthday next Sunday in Westport's Town Hall.

title: HIS PLAYS SEEK 'THE REALITY OF THE MIND'
description: In 1971, when one of his early plays, ''Homeworker,'' had its premiere in Franz Xaver Kroetz's native Munich, riots broke out. Protesting crowds chanted their indignation outside the theater, and police had to escort the audience to their seats. Twice, stink bombs and brawls brought the performance to a halt. Such protests have continued to accompany Mr. Kroetz's development as one of Europe's most controversial and important contemporary playwrights. Last season, for example, Mr. Kroetz directed the Munich premiere of his ''Neither Fish Nor Flesh.'' By the end of the third act half the public had left, making the theater ring to the sound of angrily stamping feet, slamming doors, and ricocheting epithets.

title: WENDY LEE BURDEN TO BECOME BRIDE OF JOHN W.M. GOOD NEXT JANUARY
description: Mrs. A. Guilford Tobey of Marblehead, Mass., and Oxford, England, has announced the engagement of her daughter, Wendy Lee Burden, to John William Michael Good, a son of Mrs. George Burton of Torrance, Calif., and Ernest James Good of Palos Verdes, Calif. The wedding is to take place on Jan. 19.
