Kinnelon $158,000 *2*150 Boonton Avenue, 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, *2*17-year-old colonial; fireplace, hardwood *2*floors, piano included; taxes $2,699. Livingston $195,000 *2*43 Rumson Road, 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, *2*30-year-old ranch; den, maid's room, *2*workshop; taxes $3,874. Mahwah $132,000 *2*223 Clark Street, 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, *2*23-year-old ranch; pool, new roof, burglar *2*alarm; taxes $2,104. Plainfield $155,000 *2*816 Belvidere Avenue, 4-bedroom, 3-bath, *2*50-year-old Tudor; chestnut woodwork, library, *2*fireplace; taxes $2,834. Warren $167,500 *2*72 Round Top Road, 3-bedroom, 2-bath, *2*20-year-old ranch; new air-conditioner, built-in *2*bookcases, front porch; taxes $2,823. OTHER AREAS Tuckahoe, N.Y. $150,000 *2*25 Highview Avenue, 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, *2*59-year-old colonial; dining room, sun room, *2*eat-in kitchen, walk to station; taxes $2,233. Cheshire, Conn. $129,500 *2*1025 Amherst Place, 3-bedrooms, 2 1/2-bath, *2*12-year-old ranch; large deck, central-air *2*conditioning, 0.5 acre; taxes $1,884. Smithtown, L.I. $134,990 *2*9 Bianco Court, 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, *2*21-year-old colonial; fireplace in family *2*room, 1 car garage; taxes $3,300.

title: Flights Revisited
description: To the Editor:

title: STUDENT MOVEMENT OF '64 REMEMBERED AT BERKELEY
description: The leaders of the Free Speech Movement who returned to the campus of the University of California here this week to commemorate the events of 20 years ago met a student body accustomed to the changes their movement had brought to Berkeley and other campuses.

title: CURRY REBUILDS GEORGIA TECH HIS WAY
description: THE reawakening was evident during a midweek autumn evening when students filled the North stands in Grant Field for an old-fashioned pep rally. It could be seen in a display window in a sporting-goods store near the campus where the lettering on a T-shirt read: Georgia Tech 28, Clemson 21. And as some of the students walked to class one day last week, they might have noticed that very popular score neatly printed in the morning dew that covered the rear window of a parked car.

title: 'I CAN REMEMBER EVERY HOUR'
description: ''THE GOOD WAR''

title: ALL IN PERSPECTIVE
description: RONALD BLYTHE's most recent book is ''Characters in Their Landscapes'' (Harcourt, Brace); he is editing the Oxford Book of Diaries.

title: IDEAS & TRENDS ; CatastropheFor Caribous
description: Caribous, although large and ungainly, are excellent swimmers, and thousands of them forge across the wild rivers of northern Quebec every fall. This year, however, their migration ended in an environmental disaster that Eskimo leaders say was man-made.

title: SCIENTISTS ASKS EFFORTS TO CUT ARCTIC POLLUTION
description: Scientists meeting here have urged international action to control air pollution in the Arctic.

title: IDEAS & TRENDS ; DeLorean Divorce When John Z. DeLorean was brought up on drug charges last spring, his marriage also went on trial, it seems. Mr. DeLorean was found not guilty of conspiring to traffic in cocaine, but his 11-year union with
description: Christina Ferrare apparently did not survive the five-month ordeal. She filed for divorce last week, citing irreconcilable differences.

title: PAYING HOMAGE TO MOZART
description: ''Paying Homage to Mozart'' was a powerful communication. Thank you Peter Shaffer for capturing so perfectly the spirit and essence of Mozart's music, and of the man himself: ''a magic flute at the lips of God'' indeed! What a refreshing relief from the deadening descriptions, comparisons and explanations that so often obfuscate our great musical treasure. JODY GATWOOD, Silver Spring, Md.

title: Correction
description: An article on Rockwell International in last Sunday's Business section incorrectly reported the company's earnings for the first nine months of 1984, and a table accompanying the article gave an incorrect 52- week range for Rockwell's stock price. The nine-month earnings were $357.5 million; the stock price range was 23 to 33 5/8.

title: 63 Students Arrested During Clash in Chile
description: Riot policemen arrested 63 students during two hours of clashes Friday between hundreds of pro-Government and anti-Government demonstrators at the University of Santiago.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: Bookshelf

title:
CAMERA;
WHEN THE LEAVES TURN
description: Frederic W. Rosen is a freelance writer and photographer. The beautiful colors of fall foliage are popular with most photographers. As fall arrives, the leaves adopt different hues of green, yellow, orange and red. This can start in late September in northern New England, but it usually doesn't begin until early to mid-October in this area. To get a more specific date when photography will be particularly good, check with the local Chambers of Commerce for schedules and scenic areas.

title: KARPOV TAKES 4-0 CHESS LEAD AS HE WINS ADJOURNED GAME
description: Anatoly Karpov won the ninth game of his world championship chess title defense in Moscow yesterday and charged to an enormous 4-0 lead over the challenger, Gary Kasparov.

title: Dr. Nicholas Bruno Weds Courtney Ann Carpenter
description: Courtney Ann Carpenter, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Oliver T. Carpenter of Manhasset, L.I., was married yesterday to Dr. Nicholas P. Bruno, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Louis C. Bruno of Providence, R.I. The Rev. Charles Calcagni performed the ceremony at the First Congregational Church of Manhasset, assisted by the Rev. John Deniston, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: CEY WINS ATTENDANCE BONUS OF $500,000
description: WHEN the Los Angeles Dodgers traded Ron Cey to the Chicago Cubs two years ago, they figured he was past his prime point of productiveness. For the past two seasons, though, he has led the Cubs in home runs and runs batted in; this year hitting 25 homers and driving in 97 runs.

title: CORRECTION
description: A listing accompanying ''Bed- Breakfast's Little World Gets Bigger'' (Travel, Sept. 30) omitted information on the Norumbega. Its address is 61 High Street, Camden, Me. 04843 (telephone 207-236-4646). Rooms for two, including breakfast, cost from $90 to $120.

title: 'AMOUR PAR TERRE' BY JACQUES TIVETTE
description: The opening sequence, in which two high-spirited women compete for the affections of a debonair man, is only the first of many playful illusions Jacques Rivette constructs in ''L'Amour par Terre.''

title: Where B Means Brutal
description: I read Barney Cohen's article ''Where B Means Brutal'' (Sept. 9) with increasing disgust and incredulity. Could the actresses he interviewed be that naive, that self-absorbed? Forget about the writer, director, producer and distributor.

title: RALLY IN MIDDLESEX LIFTS MNDALE SPIRITS
description: TRENTON WALTER F. MONDALE last week paid his first visit to New Jersey since the June primary victory that helped him win the Democratic nomination, and then went into training for tonight's televised debate with President Reagan.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;
A FABLE FOR MODERN TIMES
description: IT all started about five years

title: Miss Kalish Plans To Wed Architect
description: Mr. and Mrs. Myron Kalish of New York and Remsenburg, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Nita Jane Kalish to Mikael Bjornstjerna, the son of Marta Bjornstjerna of Stockholm and the late Adja Yunkers of New York.

title: A CHANCE TO CHANGE PSYCHOLOGY OF ELECTION
description: When the Presidential candidates meet in a 90- minute debate on Sunday, Walter F. Mondale's task will be to get the nation's voters to reconsider an electoral choice that, for now, appears to be weighted strongly in President Reagan's favor.

title: Sook Young Yeu Wed To a Fellow Attorney
description: Sook Young Yeu and Gillis Lockwood Heller, both graduates of the University of California Law School, were married yesterday at the Evangelical Lutheran Church of Zion-St. Mark's in New York.

title: 4 Wounded, Including Child, In Brooklyn Store Shooting
description: Four people, including a 12-year-old girl, were wounded last night when two men entered a grocery store in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn and opened fire with handguns, the police said.

title: Ailing Mormon Leader Shows Up at Meeting
description: Spencer W. Kimball, the ailing 89-year- old world leader of the Mormon Church, surprised members today by showing up on the opening day of the church's 154th semiannual conference.

title: Margaret Stickles To Marry Nov. 24
description: Mr. and Mrs. Gordon C. Stickles of Lynbrook, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Margaret M. Stickles to Kenneth J. Monaghan, the son of Jessine M. Monaghan of Garden City, L.I., and the late Frank A. Monaghan of New York.

title: Coast Theme Park Is Given Another Year at Present Site
description: Marine World-Africa U.S.A. will remain open at its present site for another year while it prepares its new site, park officials said Friday.

title: THE NATION ; More Red InkIn Chicago
description: No one was ready to declare it an epidemic, but the banking industry was shocked last week to learn that for the second time this year a big Chicago bank had come down with a serious case of bad loans.

title: No Headline
description: Redd Foxx to AppearThe comedian Redd Foxx, who starred in the television series ''Sanford and Son,'' will appear for two weeks at Dangerfield's, 1118 Fifth Avenue, at 61st Street. There is a $15 cover and a $7 minimum. Reservations: 593-1650.

title: A NEW COOPERAION SWEEPS DETROIT
description: THE recent agreement between

title: A FIRST IN THE CITY
description: In this country, when a property is sold at auction, it often signals a distress sale. But in Europe auctions have long been a standard method of buying and selling investment-grade real estate.

title: PAYING HOMAGE TO MOZART
description: In 1943, I was in the seventh grade and a choirboy at Corpus Christi Church on West 121st Street. On Easter Sunday of that year, I sang the Kyrie solo from the Coronation Mass by Mozart. For a few moments on that glorious morning of Resurrection remembered, a boy of 12, through the spirit and genius of Mozart, was indeed ''a flute in the mouth of God.'' JOHN F. CLANCY, New York City

title: THE ISLES ARE JAPANESE, BUT WITH A DIFFERENCE
description: AMANDA MAYER STINCHECUM is the author of ''Kosode: 16th to 19th Century Textiles from the Nomura Collection''(Kodansha International).

title: LOSS FROM LOANS AT FIRST CHICAGO
description: More Trouble in Chicago. First Chicago, the nation's No. 8 bank, said it would report a loss of as much as $74 million in the third quarter because of bad loans to the domestic energy and agribusiness industries and overseas shipping and construction companies. However, the bank and Federal regulators, as well as analysts, were quick to point out that First Chicago's troubles were not as grave as those of Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust, whose near-collapse shocked the industry earlier this year. And First Chicago's chairman, Barry F. Sullivan, predicted that the bank would be profitable again in the fourth quarter.

title: 1,000 TO JOIN MAINE MOOSE HUNT TOMORROW
description: The biggest animal that Elizabeth Gramlich, 19 years old, had ever shot was a duck.

title: Paying Homage To Mozart
description: As someone who dearly loves Mozart, both his music and what I know of him as a man, I remember feeling dismayed over the news that Peter Shaffer's play ''Amadeus'' was being made into a movie (''Paying Homage to Mozart,'' by Peter Shaffer, Sept. 2). After reading his essay, I have a clearer sense of why Mr. Shaffer so mercilessly exploited Mozart's character in the play to the point where the audience almost began to side with Salieri.

title: BIG CALIFORNIA QUAKE WITHIN 50 YEARS IS FORECAST
description: A very severe earthquake capable of causing vast damage is likely to strike southern California within 50 years, according to a geologist studying excavations of the San Andreas fault.

title: The Heartless Society
description: In his article ''The Heartless Society,'' (Sept. 2) John Kenneth Galbraith again shows that he is a compassionate man, with a deep concern for the plight of the poor. However, when he turns his attention to inflation, he permits his political predilections to cause him to make some inaccurate statements.

title: A COUPLE'S FLAIR FOR FOLK ART
description: The extraordinary American folk-art collection of Bertram K. and Nina Fletcher Little combines warmth, charm and connoisseurship, a rare combination in even major art holdings. These qualities dominate in the Littles' two homes - both are period Massachusetts farmhouses. They are also strongly evident in an exhibition of selections from their collection at Boston's Museum of Fine Arts and in the book that documents the couple's pursuit of, primarily, 18th- and 19th-century American art (there are some British antiques included).

title: LOUISIANIANS WAIT FOR ALIEN CENTER
description: North of Louisiana's depressed oil patch and west of its struggling World's Fair, not far from Mamou and well south of Shreveport, in the state's flat dusty center, the small city of Oakdale is coping with euphoria.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;
FATHER AND SON
description: ONE day last February at about 6 A.M. my sister knocked on my door and told me that my father had died the night before in the emergency room of the local hospital. She told me that earlier that night, my father had been sitting downstairs, alone in the recreation room of his home, watching television, when he called my mother and sister and complained that he didn't feel good.

title: WRITING BOOKS FOR CHILDREN
description: NEW BRUNSWICK APPRENTICE writers and illustrators of children's literature got a chance recently to learn how the other half lives.

title: MAJOR NEWS IN SUMMARY ; An F.B.I. AgentAccused as Spy
description: Federal Bureau of Investigation agents on the West Coast last week arrested two Soviet emigres and Richard W. Miller - an F.B.I. counterspy - on charges of espionage. It was, said William H. Webster, director of the F.B.I., ''a very sad day'' for the agency; no agent has ever before stood accused of spying for a foreign power.

title: Rabbits and Reality in Louisville The first panel of a recent political cartoon shows a meeting of the Cabinet at which President Reagan is asleep. The second panel shows a Cabinet meeting with Walter Mondale at which the Cabinet is asleep. That might be considered a gross caricature of the Presidential campaign so far, but only until tonight. No one will be asleep when the next stage of the campaign begins in Louisville with the first televised Presidential debate.
description: Does your side have any rabbits, a Mondale adviser was asked not long ago, to pull out of the hat? The debates, he said: They offer the best hope of breaking out of the flat trajectory discernible in Mr. Mondale's own demeanor. ''I would rather lose a race about decency,'' the Democratic nominee said last week, ''than win one about self-interest.''

title: DECISION DEFERRED ON POWER CONTRACT
description: THE county's Public Utility Service Agency had approved it and County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke said last week, 'I'm going to vote for it.' Then, apparently, he changed his mind.

title: Final Giveaway Of Kuhn's Hurts
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Pilot Is Killed in Plane Crash
description: A single-engine airplane crashed and exploded into flames yesterday, killing the pilot, after it clipped a tree as it took off near Middletown, N.Y., officials said.

title: No Headline
description: to Cayea

title: Okamoto Wins by 11 Strokes
description: Ayako Okamoto of Japan shot a 77 today but won the $200,000 Hitachi British Women's Open with ease.

title: MAJOR NEWS IN SUMMARY ; East GermansIn Limbo
description: As East Germany was celebrating its 35th anniversary this weekend, more than 80 of its citizens were jammed into the West German Embassy in Prague, refusing to leave until they were granted asylum in West Germany.

title: THE BRONX AS CHILDREN SKETCH IT
description: This is better than drawing in school,'' said 13-year-old Renaldo Roman as he sprawled comfortably on an empty plastic trash bag spread on a South Bronx sidewalk. ''I won't fail this drawing. Our teacher makes you draw what you read. You can't draw

title: Accountant Wed ToMissDyckman
description: Jennifer Lee Dyckman, an editorial assistant at Crown Publishers, and David Stirling Aldrich, a senior accountant at Coopers & Lybrand, both in New York, were married yesterday at Trinity Episcopal Church in Princeton, N.J. The Rev. John Crocker Jr. performed the ceremony.

title: No Headline
description: New & Noteworthy CATHEDRAL , by Raymond Carver. (Vintage, $4.95.) Almost all of the short stories in the author's three collections are set in semi-industrial depressed American towns. Our reviewer, Irving Howe, described Raymond Carver's characters as ''plebeian loners struggling for speech.'' Mr. Howe said that the stories in the most recent collection, ''Cathedral,'' first published last year, are ''very skillful within their narrow limits, written within a dry intensity and moving, at their climaxes, from the commonplace to the unnerving. At his best he is probing, as many American writers have done before, the waste and destructiveness that prevail beneath the affluence of American life.'' LIGHT, by Eva Figes. (Ballantine, $2.95.) This novella concerns one summer's day in the life of the great Impressionist painter Claude Monet. As experimental fiction, ''Light'' does not tell its story conventionally. ''It alludes to dramatic events beyond the immediate frame of the narrative itself,'' our reviewer, Joyce Carol Oates, wrote last year. ''Technique is all or nearly all in this fastidiously wrought work. Its prose is unhurried, richly descriptive, rarely ornamental or excessive - indeed, a kind of Impressionism with words.''

title: Miss Moody Is Bride Of David Irl Huffman
description: Priscilla Louise Moody, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. W. Jarvis Moody of Washington, was married yesterday to David Irl Huffman, a son of JoAnn Huffman of Lexington, Va., and the late Palmer Irl Huffman. The Rev. Jeffrey Jeremiah performed the ceremony at the Fourth Presbyterian Church of Bethesda, Md.

title: IN DEBATE TONIGHT, WILL THE ISSUES MATTER?
description: WASHINGTON TONIGHT, a national television audience estimated at 120 million people will have an opportunity to see Ronald Reagan and his Democratic challenger, Walter F. Mondale, engage in close-order political combat for the first time in the campaign. The arena is the first of two Presidential debates. (The other is Oct. 21)

title: MUSIC: PERCUSSION GROUP IN CONTEMPORARY WORKS
description: On Tuesday night, a few minutes after 8, somebody shouted 'One! Two! Three! Four!' from the wings, and several young men leaped onto the stage of the 92d street Y to flail a barrage of percussion instruments. Dense, primeval rhythms, unleashed with deafening force, filled the hall. Some audience members tapped their feet appreciatively, others covered their ears, but when the work - William Albright's 'Take That' (1972) - was over, the performers left the stage to enthusiastic whistles and prolonged applause.

title: LOTTERY AIDS JERSEY WITH RECORD $359 MILLION
description: The New Jersey Lottery produced a record $359.7 million for aid to education and state institutions in the last fiscal year, and it set sales and prize records, lottery officials said this week.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
ELEANOR ROOSEVELT CENTENNIAL
description: Eleanor Roosevelt, one of the most widely admired women of modern times, is receiving a number of posthumous tributes upon the centennial of her birth. Among the most intriguing is a new medal now being offered in a limited edition of 150.

title: RETIREMENT PLAN WORRIES COLLEGES
description: A new law that provides a financial incentive for early retirement at New York's state-supported universities and colleges could seriously deplete the institutions of a large number of veteran faculty members, education officials say.

title: GREEK TRAGEDY AND AMERICAN GOSPEL MAKE A JUBLILANT ALBUM
description: The release of the magnificent original cast album of ''The Gospel at Colonus'' (Warner Bros. 25182-1) offers audiences who might have missed the show, which was the hit of the Brooklyn Academy of Music's Next Wave Festival last season, a chance to taste one of the richest musical-theater experiences of recent years. Given the public's expectations of what constitutes an innovative musical, it's easy to understand why many who might have liked the show shied away from it. On paper, the reconception of Sophocles' ''Oedipus at Colonus'' as a contemporary gospel service sounds dauntingly highbrow. And to a largely white audience unaccustomed to black gospel music, an all-gospel score could also seem culturally exclusionary.

title: INFANT DEATHS IN JERSEY DROP, SUT STAY ABOVE U.S. AVERAGE
description: The infant mortality rate in New Jersey dropped slightly last year, but still remained above the national average, according to preliminary statistics released by the State Department of Health.

title: DISNEY CHANNEL STICKS TO FAMILY FARE
description: With the premiere of the made-for-cable film ''Love Leads the Way'' - the true story of a blind man's crusade for the acceptance of seeing-eye dogs - on the Disney Channel tonight at 8, the Disney studio extends its exploration of new ground while staying safely within familiar territory. Although the two-hour drama, which stars Timothy Bottoms and Eva Marie Saint, is not the first film that Disney has commissioned for its own use on cable, it signals the beginning of Disney's increased involvement with producing original movies for its cable service. Four more Disney- made films are already scheduled for broadcast on the Disney Channel in the first months of 1985, and the studio hopes to present from six to eight original features every year. Tonight's offering is the third such film to be shown on the network since its inception in April of last year.

title: WHAT'S NEW IN EUROPE
description: Madrid: Performing arts festival; two popular discos The word around Europe is that a new and exciting city is emerging for culture and play, a city that happens to be one of the Continent's oldest capitals - Madrid.

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: THE political speakers on the east lawn of the State Capitol sang campaign ballads, went through some partisan antics to catch the attention of the press and railed against the ''despot of Russia.'' It was all very familiar, coming as it did in the midst of the Presidential campaign, except that the participants were acting out the politics of 1840, not 1984.

title: East German Guard Defects
description: A lieutenant of the East German border guard, armed and in full uniform, defected across the heavily guarded frontier into West Germany early today, Bavarian border police said. The 22-year-old officer chose a section of the frontier that was not mined, they added.

title: COURT, CITING UNFAIR STATEMENTS, ORDERS NEW TRIAL
description: A man convicted of killing three guards during an April 1979 robbery of a Purolator armored-car depot in Waterbury has won a new trial because a prosecutor called him a ''rat,'' a ''merciless killer'' and other names.

title: Fielders' Gloves Hampered Rose
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Susan Troy Is Bride Of Peter D. Van Oot
description: Susan Willis Troy, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Storrow Troy of Darien, Conn., was married there yesterday to Peter Dawson Van Oot, a son of Mrs. Terence Robinson Blackwood of West Hartford, Conn. and Queen Anne's County, Md., and the late Albert Powell Oot of Westminster, Vt. The ceremony was performed at St. Luke's Episcopal Church, where the Rev. Walter Taylor and the Rev. Robert Nelson Back officiated.

title: 'CLASS RELATIONS' IS BASED ON KAFKA
description: More than the films of any other directors, the minimalist works of Jean-Marie Straub and Dani ele Huillet, his wife and collaborator, demand that one be in a mood so receptive that it borders on the brainwashed.

title: MUSIC: DEBUTS IN REVIEW
description: Mischa Lefkowitz may have been born and raised in Latvia and trained as a violinist in Moscow, but he is all American now: For the last 12 years he has lived in Los Angeles, and in 1983 he won a prize in the American Music Competition at Carnegie Hall, which stresses the performance of American music. Last Sunday night, he made a pleasing New York debut at the Abraham Goodman House.

title: ROCKWELL
description: Rockwell Demurs

title: HARVEST TIME UNDER WAYAT COUNTY VINEYARD
description: '' DEER can wipe out an entire vineyard this size,'' said Dr. George W. Naumburg Jr., surveying the fruit of his labor - literally the fruit on the vines he has tended for the last 19 years at the only commercial vineyard in the county.

title: DANCE: TROUPE FROM NEW ZEALAND
description: The Limbs Dance Company, which calls itself Limbs for short, has bounded into New York from Auckland, New Zealand. And it soon made certain things clear at its performance Wednesday night at the Theater of the Riverside Church: Limbs is limber, Limbs is lithe.

title: THE SEVILLANO SPIRIT
description: V. S. PRITCHETT's most recent publication is a novel, ''Dead Man Leading,'' reissued by Oxford University Press.

title: FRENCH SAY LIBYA MOVES FROM CHAD PARIS, Oct. 6 (UPI) - Defense Minister Charles Hernu said today that Libyan troops backing rebels in Chad appeared to be leaving in compliance with a French-Libyan accord.
description: His comment came after talks with President Hissen Habre of Chad, who is on a visit here. Mr. Habre met with President Francois Mitterrand on Friday.

title: MUSIC: KARAKASHIAN QUARTET
description: The Karakashian Quartet's concert Wednesday evening at Carnegie Recital Hall can be compared to a meal made up entirely of flavored ices. Everything tasted just fine going down, and there were some attractive colors to enjoy along the way, but the evening had the ultimate nutritional value of sugar and water.

title: SHOO-IN
description: Citing the lowering of the ''misery index'' - that addition of the unemployment rate to the inflation rate - Leonard Silk, economics columnist of The New York Times, wrote: ''Mr. Reagan could have some reason to regard himself as a shoe-in.''

title: Troublemaker Winner Of Messenger Stakes
description: Billy O'Donnell, the leading driver in North America, took Troublemaker from fourth place at the three-quarter pole to a length-and-a-half victory over Long Fella to win the 29th annual Messenger Stakes, the final leg of the triple crown of harness racing, tonight at Roosevelt Raceway.

title: BRIDGING THE CULTURAL GAP
description: AS the commercial titans of the

title: THE GHOSTLY GLORY OF VIENNA
description: ANTHONY BURGESS is the author of ''Enderby's Dark Lady: Or No End to Enderby'' (McGraw-Hill).

title: THEOLOGICAL CENTER GETTING NEW HOME
description: PRINCETON SOME 400 theologians, religious leaders and scientists of many faiths from all over the world will gather here this week for the dedication of Henry Robinson Luce Hall, built this year to house the six-year-old Center of Theological Inquiry.

title: RESTORATION
description: WE ARE NOW IN THE MIDST OF A rising tide of affection for older buildings. Across the United States, buildings that a generation ago might have been - or even were - abandoned are being rejuvenated. The Philadelphia Stock Exchange becomes a shopping mall; the Dallas train station houses a restaurant complex; a school in Newport and a church in Boston are converted into condominium apartments; and in lower Manhattan, factory after factory is turned into residential lofts.

title: 2 MEN ARE FOUND SLAIN IN SICILY AFTER MAFIA ROUNDUP
description: The bodies of two men shot in the back of the head in gangland style were found early today outside Palermo in Sicily.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: transit agency, plans to have some novel new buses on the streets and highways. Their most striking feature is an accordion-like joint that links the front and back sections and lets the bus, in effect, ''swivel'' around corners and negotiate traffic on crowded streets.

title: THE QUEST FOR OFFSHORE OIL WANES
description: WASHINGTON

title: Carolyn J. Charon Is Married in Rye
description: Christ Episcopal Church in Rye, N.Y., was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Carolyn Jeanne Charon, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth A. Charon of White Plains, Paris and Leysin, Switzerland, to Scott Douglas Dutton, a son of Robert F. Dutton of Massapequa, L.I., and Gloria Knab Dutton of Los Angeles. The Rev. Edward Johnson performed the ceremony.

title: OPERA: CAST CHANGES IN 'HOFFMAN' AT MET
description: Hoffmann's three loves in one became three again Friday as Gwendolyn Bradley, Isola Jones and Myra Merritt took over the disparate roles that Catherine Malfitano had combined in the Metropolitan Opera's opening ''Tales of Hoffmann'' performances.

title: Sardinia To the Editor: Your two articles on Sardinia (Travel, Sept. 2) were informative and entertaining; they appear too seldom for the growing importance of the island in archeological discovery as well as in tourism.
description: The acceleration of archeological field work and research in the last decade or two have completely changed the concepts of that ancient island and have produced so much new and unusual material that it is no longer true - if, indeed, it ever was - that ''their finest art treasures are to be found in foreign museums.'' Along with the outburst of archeological activity there is also a proliferation in the establishment of provincial and communal museums to exhibit locally found objects or their replicas.

title: THE NATION ; A Nuclear AceIn the Hole
description: Under a plan the Air Force recently presented to the Pentagon, the United States would be able to fire back if hit first in a nuclear attack - after a few days of frantic digging, that is. Defense Department officials reported last week that, according to the plan, a reserve missile force buried as much as 3,500 feet underground would be militarily and technically feasible.

title: PRESIDENT VS. DEMAGOGUE
description: Jack Rosenthal is the Deputy Editorial Page Editor of The New York Times. WHO KILLED JOE MCCARTHY?

title: LIMITING CONTROL IN CO-OPS
description: In New York apartment buildings being

title: RECITAL: DAVID ALLEN WEHR
description: The pianist David Allen Wehr, who made his New York debut at Carnegie Recital Hall Thursday night, studied at the University of Kansas. In 1983 he won the National Federation of Music Clubs Young Artist Auditions, and was awarded second prize in the Naumburg International Piano Competition at Carnegie Hall.

title: 500,000 MORE SPY-PROOF PHONES PROPOSED BY TOP SECURITY AGENCY
description: The National Security Agency is proposing that the Government and industry be equipped with as many as 500,000 telephones that can be secured against interception.

title: 4 COASTAL WILDLIFE REFUGES FOR CONNECTICUT VOTED BY CONGRESS
description: The House of Representatives has given final approval to the Connecticut Coastal Wildlife Refuge Act, which would bar development on three islands and a barrier beach.

title: Cassandra as Fiction
description: To the Editor:

title: 3-0 PENN TROUNCES COLUMBIA BY 35-7
description: Pennsylvania, co-champion of the Ivy League the last two seasons and a favorite for a third title, routed Columbia, 35-7, today at Franklin Field. The victory was unbeaten Penn's third this season, the second in Ivy league competition, and left the Red and Blue in first place in the league with Brown.

title: BOILER INSPECTORS FACE SHAKE-UP
description: The city's Buildings Commissioner has ordered a reorganization of the boiler inspection division in response to a report that criticized some department workers for their roles in the improper dismissal of an inspector.

title: SHIPWRECKS MAKE SOME GO DIVING FOR DOLLARS
description: LEWES, Del.

title: UNBEATEN ARMY DOWNS HARVARD, 33-11
description: With an offensive backfield of galloping retreads seemingly put together by the magic wave of a wishbone, Army's undefeated football team continued to recall past glories today as it routed Harvard, 33-11, before 40,504 spectators in 39,867-seat Michie Stadium.

title: SYRACUSE, A WEEK LATER, DEFLATED BY FLORIDA, 16-0
description: Seven days ago, Syracuse fans were dancing in the streets after the Orangemen's stunning 17-9 victory over Nebraska.

title: A HANDYMAN'S SPECIAL
description: Tips on making the most of small spaces, ideas on decorating to camouflage eyesores and strategies for improving energy efficiency of heating units will be offered by some 100 exhibitors at the Third Annual Big Apple Fix-up to be held next Friday, Saturday and Sunday at Madison Square Garden's Exposition Rotunda.

title: JUSTICE DISCUSSIONS ON LAVELLE UNDER INQUIRY
description: The House Judiciary Committee is investigating whether high-level Justice Department officials discussed beginning a grand jury investigation of an Environmental Protection Agency official in early 1983 as a way to withhold embarrassing documents from Congress, a House investigator said today.

title: THE HEARTLESS SOCIETY
description: In regard to ''The Heartless Society,'' it should be added that under Ronald Reagan, greed and selfishness among the affluent have been elevated to the level of patriotism. MALVINE COLE, Jamaica, Vt.

description: New England In Honolulu By Fletcher Knebel AUTHOR OF ''POKER GAME'' (DOUBLEDAY)

title: Bush's Right to Vote In Texas Challenged
description: A Texas State Representative, Clint Hackney, filed a challenge Friday to Vice President Bush's right to vote in Texas, but a county official said the challenge would probably not be heard until after the election.

title: FORT LEE COMPSER IS GAINING A PUBLIC
description: FORT LEE AS A child, Joelle Wallach had a compulsion to write music. She studied composition in college, and now stands on the threshold of a career in the fiercely competitive world of modern music.

title: WIFE OF JERSEY MAYOR ON TRIAL IN '75 DEATH OF SON
description: Nine years after a local investigation cleared her, the wife of Mayor William G. Rohrer of Haddon Township has gone on trial on charges of murdering the couple's adopted 2-year-old son.

title: JETS' REVAMPED DEFENSE TO FACE CHIEFS
description: If the Jets' last four games ever became the subject of a documentary, an appropriate title for the film would be ''A Return to the Comfort Zone.''

title: WEEKLIES CHANGE APPROACH TO NEWS
description: WHEN Long Island Community Newspapers, a chain of eight weeklies in Nassau and Suffolk Counties, was purchased last May by a local businessman, neither the new owner nor the editors anticipated that major differences would soon erupt. But by last month, four of the editors had resigned.

title: Mari Angela Kilroy Engaged to Wed William Pike Talbert Next Summer
description: Mr. and Mrs. Edward A. Kilroy Jr. of Shaker Heights, Ohio, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mari Angela Kilroy, to William Pike Talbert, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William F. Talbert of New York. A summer wedding is planned.

title: CONQUERING HIS LONELINESS
description: RILKE, By Wolfgang Leppmann. Translated by Russell M. Stockman with the author. Verse translated by Richard Exner. Illustrated. 421 pp. New York: Fromm International. Cloth, $22.50. Paper, $12.95.

GARDENING;
PREPARING FOR THE FIRST FROST
description: IN all likelihood it will frost

title: Dr. Paula Randolph Bride of TV Aide
description: Dr. Paula Ann Randolph, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James W. Randolph of Mount Vernon, N.Y., was married yesterday to Robert Victor Edney, a son of Minnie B. Clark of Boston and the late Leon Edney of Virginia Beach, Va. The Rev. David D. Cockcroft performed the ceremony at the Riverdale Presbyterian Church in the Bronx.

title: CAFFEINE IS NATURAL INSECTICIDE, SCIENTIST SAYS
description: Caffeine and related compounds are potent, natural insecticides that help plants ward off damaging pests, a Boston researcher has found. The findings could lead to a new way to fight insects.

title: Gretchen Wulster Will Be the Bride Of G.D. Hamrick
description: Mr. and Mrs. Gregory H. Wulster of Tuxedo Park, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Gretchen Wulster, to G. David Hamrick, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Grant L. Hamrick of Charlotte, N.C. A Nov. 3 wedding is planned.

title: A 50th REUNION THAT GREW AND GREW
description: CHARLES HARPER thought it would be nifty if his Port Washington High School class of '33 had a 50th reunion. However, he found so many people getting into the act that it was decided to organize a reunion not for just one class in 1983 but for 21 classes - from 1916 to 1936 - and the big event will take place next weekend.

title: FLEDGLING ZOO KEEPERS TRAIN IN FLORIDA COLLEGE'S PROGRAM
description: Ninety students who share a love of animals have come here to learn how to become zoo keepers.

title: Spina Bifida Month Is Set
description: President Reagan on Friday proclaimed October as National Spina Bifida Month to call attention to the birth defect that affects between one and two of every 1,000 babies born in the United States. The often-debilitating disorder is characterized by incomplete development of the spinal cord.

title: THE REGION ; Cuomo SeeksWisdom onLife and Law
description: After sparring publicly in recent weeks with leaders of the Roman Catholic Church over his stand on abortion and the relationship of politics and religion, Governor Cuomo sought simultaneously to broaden the debate and to tone it down last week.

title: EGYPT GAINS IN FIGHT TO END ITS DIPLOMATIC QUARANTINE
description: Hosni Mubarak had ample cause to celebrate last week as he marked his third anniversary as President of Egypt. After Jordan's decision to restore the ties it severed in 1979 after President Anwar el-Sadat made peace with Israel, there were predictions in Cairo that other Arab states would follow.

title: F. G. Jewett 3d Is Wed To Doris Ann Downes
description: Doris Ann Downes, a daughter of Mrs. Fielder B. Downes of Scottsdale, Ariz., and the late Mr. Downes, was married yesterday to Freeborn Garrettson Jewett 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jewett Jr. of McLean, Va. Bishop John Walker, Episcopal Bishop of Washington, performed the ceremony at the Little Sanctuary at St. Alban's Church in Washington.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS
description: Oct. 7, 1984Fiction*1 THE AUERBACH WILL, by Stephen Birmingham. (Berkley, $3.95.) Three generations of a German Jewish family in New York. *2 THE WICKED DAY, by Mary Stewart. (Fawcett Crest, $4.50.) King Arthur, fulfilling a prophecy of Merlin, falls into an incestuous relationship. *3

title: PUTNAM STARTS A SUICIDE AWARENESS PROGRAM
description: State and local officials have begun an effort in suburban Putnam County to fight the growing number of teen-age suicides.

title: Founding of Nation At a Second Site
description: Referring to the article ''Manor Updates Tour - to 1790'' (Sept. 16), I would like to call your attention to the fact that, contrary to the comments of Sleepy Hollow Restoration staff members, there is, indeed, another museum representing the founding years of our nation, only a few scenic miles from Van Cortlandt Manor.

title: Bike Tours Of Polynesia
description: At first glance, the prospect seems incongruous: island-hopping by bicycle. But actually it's feasible.

title: Jill R. Baum to Be Married To B. L. Goodman Nov. 17
description: Mr. and Mrs. Gary L. Baum of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jill R. Baum, to Bruce L. Goodman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James M. Goodman of New York.

title: Student Beer Party Ends In Rampage at Purdue
description: A pregame beer party spilled out of two houses near Purdue University early today and a mob of 200 people smashed car windows and threw bottles at the police.

title: USING CHILDREN TO CUT FAMILY TAXES
description: BACK in the good old days (for that, read the days before the Tax Reform Act of 1984) interest-free loans from parents to children were among the most popular means of lowering family taxes. But this summer Congress dropped the ax on such loans, giving parents until Sept. 16 to wind them down - or pay the tax consequences.

title: THE HEARTLESS SOCIETY
description: John Kenneth Galbraith reminds us that with growing affluence comes a waning concern for the poor.

title: AUCTION PLAN PROCEEDS DESPITE MIDWAY ISSUE
description: WESTCHESTER officials said last week that they were moving ahead on the county's plan to auction time slots at the County Airport to the airlines that want to fly there and that they planned to open bids from the airlines Nov. 16.

title:
ART;
MAKING ORDINARY EXTRAORDINARY
description: MANY artists who might superficially be classified as realists are actually engaged in subtle forms of abstraction that elevate their imagery beyond the straightforward depiction of what they observe. One may well question whether there is any longer a need simply to transcribe visual fact, since the artist's role as a documentarian has long since been usurped by the photographer.

title: A SLAVE TO HIS ART
description: Theodore Weiss's most recent volumes of poetry are ''Recoveries,'' a long poem, and the forthcoming ''A Slow Fuse,'' a collection. COLLECTED POEMS 1970-1983

title:
ANTIQUES;
MEDICINE THROUGH THE MILLENIA
description: PISCATAWAY AN AMBITIOUS exhibition entitled ''300 Years of Medicine in New Jersey: the Science and Art of Healing'' opened last week at the Cornelius Low House/Middlesex County Museum, 1225 River Road.

title: HOME CLINIC ; HOW TO REMOVE OLD WALLPAPER
description: -backed wall covering is to be put up over a wall that already has wallpaper on it, or when a wall already has two or more layers of wallpaper on it, it is almost always necessary to remove the old wallpaper before hanging any kind of new material over it. Removing the old wallpaper is seldom a pleasant or fast job, but it need not be especially difficult if tackled in the right manner.

title: Headliners ; Prosecutor's Slip Loose lips also sink jobs, or so it appeared for
description: J. William Petro . President Reagan last week dismissed Mr. Petro from his job as the United States Attorney in Cleveland, a rare Presidential action, after it became known that Mr. Petro had disclosed information about a pending Federal indictment and that the information had subsequently reached the person who was about to be indicted.

title: EGYPTIANS WORRY DESPITE RIOT'S END
description: Order and tranquillity have returned to this poor northern industrial city, which erupted in rioting last Sunday.

title: BUT FOR OTHERS THE TREASURE IS ACADEMIC
description: N AUTICAL archeology, though a growing and productive field of science, has always suffered from an identity crisis. Contrary to popular perception, it is not all diving in azure waters; more time is spent topside doing the tedious work of cleaning and documenting artifacts and pondering their message. And it most certainly is not to be confused with treasure hunting.

title: CARE OF PRADER-WILLI VICTIMS ASSAILED
description: RONA LENHOFF was 19 when doctors diagnosed her insatiable appetite and obesity as Prader-Willi syndrome, a birth defect often accompanied by diabetes, mild retardation and uncontrollable overeating that can lead to an early death.

title: MIAMIANS SENSE THE ADVENT OF ANOTHER SEASON AND SEE THEIR CITY CHANGE
description: Not too long ago, when this town was younger, the seasons were measured by travel agents more than by nature.

title: CONVERSION ON EAST 13TH
description: A turn-of-the-century building just south of Union Square that served as a work space for several printing companies and, before that, as headquarters of a major textile company is being converted into loft- style residential condominiums.

title: DALAI LAMA PLANS TO SPEAK AT IONA
description: '' IF we are going to have peace, we have to understand the people we are dealing with,'' said Brother John G. Driscoll, president of Iona College in New Rochelle, who returned in April from a six-month, 28,000-mile journey to 22 countries in Western Europe, the Middle East and the Orient.

title: 3 OF 6 SOUTH AFRICAN FUGITIVES SURRENDER TO POLICE
description: Three of six South African political fugitives who took refuge in the British Consulate in Durban last month left their sanctuary today and were arrested.

title: A ZESTFUL POTPOURRI OF SOUP TOUREENS AT MORRIS MUSEUM
description: MORRISTOWN APROMISING trend that is showing up more and more is the collaboration of industry and artists. Some particularly interesting manifestations have occurred when industries have challenged artists to create works for exhibitions that are thematically related to their products.

title: RECALLING DRIVE TO PUT U.N. HERE
description: IF the Russians had had their

title: NATIONAL MUSIC TOOK ON A NEW STYLE WITH GLINKA
description: There are only a few works that can legitimately be called operatic landmarks. Obviously the list must begin with Jacopo Peri's legendary ''Dafne'' (1597), which holds an enviable position as the first true opera in history. It also happens to be unchallengeable as to artistic worth because the score has never been found. In that respect, Peri is as fortunate an immortal as the Greek sculptor Phidias, none of whose pieces has ever turned up and whose renown rests entirely on copies by Roman artists and on descriptions of his works by ancient critics. More tangibly, Monteverdi's first opera, ''La Favola d'Orfeo,'' is an early masterpiece that cannot be denied a place on the honor roll. Nor can Gluck's reform opera, ''Orfeo ed Euridice,'' or Wagner's even more revolutionary ''Tristan und Isolde,'' or Berg's salute to the decaying Romantic tradition, ''Lulu.'' Things were never quite the same in the operatic world after those works first appeared.

title: LEAGUE IRATE AS CAMPAIGNS SELECT 3 PANELISTS
description: The League of Women Voters today named three panelists for the first Presidential debate, after a torturous screening process in which more than 100 journalists were rejected by officials of the two campaigns.

title: Stephen J. Brake Wed To Pamela J. Downing
description: Pamela Joyce Downing, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Denis J. Downing of Acton, Mass., was married yesterday to Stephen John Brake, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Cecil Clifford Brake of Westport, Conn. The Rev. William Heuss performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Good Shepherd in Acton.

title: VALUE OF TAXABLE REAL ESTATE IN JERSEY UP 10%
description: The taxable real estate of New Jersey is worth $211.4 billion, 10 percent more than last year, state taxation officials said this week.

title: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: Tina Ramirez's Ballet Hispanico of New York ends its season with Sunday's performances at 2 P.M. and 7:30 P.M. at the Joyce Theater. Over the years, this company of ever-young dancers has increasingly professionalized itself.

title: WHAT'S NEW IN EUROPE
description: Switzerland: Face lift for two railroad terminals The Zurich Opera, maybe the most ambitious among Europe's many secondary temples of the lyric drama, will return to its home at the end of this year. In a process that began in 1981, the 93-year-old Opera House has been enlarged and thoroughly refurbished. It will reopen around Christmas with a gala performance of Wagner's ''Die Meistersinger.''

title: POLICE CHIEF IN BRIDGEPORT PRESERVES
description: JOSEPH A. WALSH is now laboring in reduced circumstances, but when he looks to the future he sees brighter days. Mr. Walsh is the Superintendent of Police in Bridgeport. That is something Mayor Leonard S. Paoletta has worked hard to change, with success that has never been more than temporary.

description: 18 THE FOURTH PROTOCOL, by Frederick Forsyth. (Viking, $17.95.) A London jewel robbery leads to plots and counterplots behind the Iron Curtain. *2 317 ''. . . AND LADIES OF THE CLUB,'' by Helen Hooven Santmyer. (Putnam, $19.95.) Life in an Ohio town, 1868 to 1932. *3

title: Texan, Charged With Threat To Kill Mondale, Is Acquitted
description: A Rumanian emigre shot by Secret Service agents in April has been acquitted of a charge that he threatened to kill Walter F. Mondale, then a candidate for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;
LET'S RECOGNIZE MASTER TEACHERS
description: AS A FORMER teacher and school administrator with more than 30 years' experience in education, I welcome the renewed emphasis being placed on quality after years of declining student test scores and other signs that our schools were in trouble.

title: ART OF BOOKBINDING LIVES IN HADLYME
description: ARNO WERNER pulled a book from its shelf. It slid silently and slowly from its nearly airtight cardboard cover, and its rich black leather came to rest in his hand.

description: ENDLESS WAR

title: Marjorie G. Deane Is Engaged to H. W. Swain Jr.
description: Mr. and Mrs. Disque Dee Deane of New York, Greenwich, Conn., and Tucker's Town, Bermuda, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Marjorie Gregg Deane, to Herbert Woodward Swain Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Swain of Barrington, R.I. A Nov. 3 wedding is planned.

title: T. S. Logan 3d Is Wed To Patricia Eisemann
description: Patricia Ruth Eisemann, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Aubrey Gene Eisemann of Babylon, L.I., and Delray Beach, Fla., was married yesterday to Thaddeus Sumner Logan 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Logan Jr. of Richmond and Naples, Fla. The Rev. Joseph James O'Hare 3d, the bride's cousin, performed the ceremony at St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church in Babylon.

title: WHAT'S NEW IN EUROPE
description: Germany: Restored churches; yearlong music festival Until the rumble of Allied bombers devastated half its buildings in 1944, Cologne styled itself as Germany's City of Churches. Older residents, who recall the city's former face, talk of a crown of magnificent Romanesque edifices - Sankt Georg and Gross Sankt Martin, squat and reassuring; Sankt Gereon, slender and soaring - that testified to the skill of anonymous architects who created a peculiar 12th-century Rhenish style.

title: Unfair to Fuentes?
description: To the Editor:

title: Cat Slayer
description: Someone, it appeared, had an intense grudge against cats in Indianapolis. In less than two months nearly 100 had been clubbed to death at night on the city's East Side.

title: JUILLIARD STAGES ITS FIRST REUNION
description: Class reunions aren't all the same. Consider, for example, the upcoming Juilliard Reunion Day, the first such occasion in the conservatory's 79-year history, which will take place this Friday. The day's festivities will include presentations by the dance, theater, and opera departments, chamber-music performances, Organ recitals, and open classes involving both students and the Juilliard faculty. The culmination of the day will be a concert by the Juilliard Orchestra, under the direction of Jorge Mester, in celebration of Lincoln Center's 25th anniversary. The program will include music by Albeniz and Bartok, as well as William Schuman's Violin Concerto with Robert McDuffie, a recent graduate of the school, as soloist.

title: RECITAL: BRAZIL PIANIST
description: Luiz de Moura Castro, a Brazilian born and trained pianist who is now head of the piano department of the Hartt School of Music in Harford, gave a piano recital at Goodman House on Tuesday night. His program consisted of Schumann's Arabesque (Op. 18), Medelssohn's Rondo Capriccioso and two of the piano pieces called 'Songs Without Words,' Beethoven's Sonata in D (Op. 28), Ginastera's Suite de Danzas Criollas and Liszt's Sonata in B minor.

title: ROBERT BENTON ENSHRINES FAMILY MEMORIES ON SCREEN
description: When Robert Benton was a little boy growing up in Waxahachie, Tex., family stories were as much a part of the atmosphere around him as the heat and dust of a scorching Texas summer. His family had lived in Waxahachie for five generations, and there were several times as many tales as there were aunts and uncles and cousins and grandparents and great-grandparents, since there were at least two or three versions of each story - like the one about his daddy's brother, who started having an affair with a very young lady and was shot to death by her outraged father, or the one about his daddy's other brother, who was also shot to death, this time by a man who chased him down Main Street in a Model-T Ford, firing all the way, for reasons never entirely clear but having to do with the bootlegging wars raging in the area at the time.

title: Brown Tops Princeton
description: Behind the passing of the quarterback Steve Kettelberger, Brown scored touchdowns on each of its three possessions in the third quarter today and then held off a fourth-quarter Princeton rally to gain a 32-30 Ivy League victory. It was the first time the Bruins have beaten Princeton since 1980.

title: GARVEY'S TRIUMPHANT INSTANT
description: As soon as the ball began to soar toward the right-center field stands tonight for the home run that created Sunday's decisive fifth game in the National League championship series, the moment was ''frozen'' for Steve Garvey.

title: CONSUMER RATES
YALE WINS, 41-0
description: After his team lost, 20-0, last week to the University of Connecticut, Yale's football coach, Carm Cozza, said the Elis desperately needed a victory in order to lift team morale. But Yale had to look outside Division I-A to find that elusive victory as the Elis (1- 2) pounded Morgan State (0-5), a Division II school in Baltimore, 41-0, today at the Yale Bowl in the first meeting ever between the two schools.

title: Hagler Seeks Approval
description: Marvelous Marvin Hagler has three middleweight titles, but only two of them will apparently be on the line when he takes on Mustafa Hamsho in a 15-round bout at Madison Square Garden on Oct. 19. The World Boxing Association and the International Boxing Federation are sanctioning the bout, but the World Boxing Council is witholding its approval.

title: RESCUING A MISSION
description: The Atlantic City Rescue Mission, a haven for the hapless and homeless not far from the city's golden casinos, was itself facing destitution early this year. Its income - always low after the flush of Christmas giving has subsided - was at ebb tide.

title: Vandalism Reversed
description: School buildings have always tempted vandals. During the 1970's, intruders broke through inadequate security and antiquated alarms to break glass, steal food and equipment and set fires in scores of New York City schools.

title: DAVID HOCKNEY'S JOURNEY TO A 'NEW CUBLISM'
description: David Hockney, the artist whose recent work encompasses everything from painted sets for the Metropolitan Opera to a series of fractured photographs of the Brooklyn Bridge and other American landmarks, has produced a new style of painting that he calls ''a new Cubism,'' a technique based on his study of Picasso, quantum physics and Chinese philosophy.

title: THE REGION ; Step AgainstChild Abuse
description: New York City will soon start fingerprinting child-care workers in a further effort to prevent abuse at day-care centers. Under the program, for which the City Council's Finance Committee approved $1.1 million last week, at least 60,000 people will be fingerprinted by the Department of Investigation. The prints will be checked against criminal records. The effort, which must still be approved by the full Council, is in response to charges this summer that children had been sexually abused at several day-care centers. It also covers those who work with the disabled and the elderly.

title: Mexican Denied Bail in U.S.
description: Arturo Durazo Moreno, a former Mexico City police chief who is awaiting extradition to Mexico on corruption charges, was denied bail Friday by a Federal judge who said he was a ''substantial flight risk.'' Mr. Durazo was arrested in June in Puerto Rico. No extradition hearing has been scheduled.

title: CONGO ON MY MIND
Staying in Cleveland
description: George and Gordon Gund, the businessmen brothers who own the Cleveland Cavaliers, have made an agreement with a group of minority stockholders to keep the basketball team in the city for at least five years. The agreement, subject to court approval, was designed to resolve a lawsuit filed against the club's previous owner, Ted Stepien. In agreeing to the out-of-court settlement, the Gunds also pledged they would not sell the franchise to anyone who planned to move it out of Cleveland unless local investors were given a chance to match the offer.

description: Maryland missed a 2-point conversion pass after its final touchdown with 1 minute 57 seconds to play today and Penn State escaped with its 20th consecutive victory in the series, 25-24.

title: THE BUDGETARY ROSES WILT IN ERIE AND SUFFOLK COUNTIES
description: Election-year budgets have a way of producing large deficits and tax increases the following year. That particular political rhythm is being pounded out this year in two of New York State's largest counties, Suffolk and Erie. The future of the Republican Executives of the two counties, Peter F. Cohalan of Suffolk and Edward J. Rutkowski of Erie, may well depend on their ability to contain fiscal troubles.

title: BRONX CENTER'S CLOSING LEAVES DAY-CARE GAP
description: Virginia Silva works nights as a counselor in a home for victims of cerebral palsy. Until last month, she could sleep in the daytime because she sent her 4-year-old daughter, Maria, to the Praca Day Care Center in the Bronx.

title: Empress Hotel To the Editor: In the article ''What's Doing in Victoria'' (Travel, July 29) it was mentioned that the Empress Hotel offers afternoon tea service, but it did not mention that this tea service is by reservation only.
description: Last summer, to my disappointment, I was denied admission to the tea because I had no reservation - even though I was staying at the hotel. (Neither my travel agent nor the tourist books mentioned the reservation.) Otherwise the hotel was great! ROBERT GRUBER New York

Zemann, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Zemann of New York, took place yesterday at the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest in New York. The Rev. Hugh Hildesley officiated.

title: REAGANOMICS - AN UTTER FAILURE...
description: According to the Bureau of Labor Statistics, 10 million jobs were created under Jimmy Carter; only 5.1 million under Ronald Reagan. Sadly, many laid-off auto, steel, farm-equipment and other workers are now laboring for the minimum wage.

title: Reagan Nominates 5 to Fill Judgeships in Federal Courts
description: President Reagan has nominated five people for judgeships on Federal courts in Nevada, Ohio, Louisiana, Illinois and Massachusetts.

description: Those who watch Sunday night's Presidential debate should not assume that Ronald Reagan and Walter F. Mondale are the only candidates for the White House.

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;
SOCIETY SHOULD ACCEPT BLAME FOR THE WAY SCHOOLS ARE
description: AS students and teachers begin their new year, politicians are increasing their attacks on the schools and promising reforms that evoke cheers from the crowds, who like the sound of these promises but fail to see the vacuum behind them. The failure of the public to grasp the emptiness of these political speeches may well be the greatest indictment of the schools, which have apparently neglected to teach the public to listen, read and think critically. The politicians play the old hurrah-boo game, but their audiences seriously believe that the words that lead them to cheer and boo have meaning.

title: Randi E. Reider to Marry Kenneth Flug on Nov. 24
description: Randi Elyse Reider, a marketing representative for The Daily News, and Kenneth Lloyd Flug, a financial analyst for Citicorp, plan to be married Nov. 24, her parents, Dr. and Mrs. William L. Reider of Dix Hills, L.I., have announced.

title: IS FICTION THE ART OF LIVING?
description: EVER since I wrote my first short story, people have asked if what I wrote 'was true.' Though my replies sometimes satisfy their curiosity, I am left each time, no matter how sincere my answer, with a nagging sense of having said something that's not quite on target.

title: RIGHT TO LIFE PARTY TO RUN OWN SLATE OF CANDIDATES
description: ALTHOUGH support from the Right to Life Party in the county helped elect at least six Republicans last year, candidates of both major parties have, with two exceptions, decided not to seek or accept endorsement by the group this year.

title: POGRAM AIDS CHILDREN OF ALCHOHOLICS
description: MORE than 30 million Americans are children of alcoholics. More than half of all alcoholics are also children of alcoholics, and yet only 5 percent of the children of alcoholics are receiving help in understanding and coping with their problems.

title: BOARD IN ILLINOIS AIDING CONSUMERS
description: Inside their telephone, electric and gas bills, Illinois consumers have found a cartoon showing a citizen at his mailbox getting punched in the nose by his utility bill.

title: FRENCH FOOD AND FINE SERVICE
description: LA COQUILLE in Manhasset has been under new management for several months. The change does not seem to have meant an overhaul. The small, engagingly pretty dining room that was spruced up a few years ago with the addition of some mirrored panels and a French mural is the same, as is the staff, and the menu has not been revised.

title: 49ERS, 5-0, ARE WELL PACKAGED
description: The San Francisco 49ers, whom the Giants play tomorrow night at Giants Stadium, are unbeaten after five games because all parts of the team have played well so far. That includes the overlooked defensive group, which might have disintegrated given its circumstances.

title: HOME-GROWN ACCESSORIES THAT BRING OUT THE BEST IN VCR'S
description: In the wake of all those video cassette recorders

title: ARMS-CONTROL PROGRESS MAY COST JOBS
description: Senior White House officials have passed word in recent weeks to diplomats and politicians that President Reagan, if he gets a second term, intends to put an end to almost four years of squabbling within his arms control team.

title: S. A. MacP. Horn Weds Miss Keith
description: St. John's of Lattingtown Episcopal Church in Locust Valley, L.I., was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Ann Barrett Milholland Keith, the daughter of Mrs. Norman C. Keith of Mill Neck, L.I., and the late Peter Clarke Milholland, to Stoddard Andrew MacPherson Horn, a son of Mr. and Mrs. L. Stoddard Horn of New York and Southampton, L.I. The Rev. Charles G. Newbery performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. Fred Hoesli, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: ERIK HAWKINS SPEAKS HIS MIND IN DANCE
description: David Sears is a freelance writer with a special interest in dance. With the passionate defiance of John Brown and the subtle sting of a Wild West tale of greed, Erick Hawkins' engagement at the Joyce Theater, which begins Wednesday, leaps beyond the immediacy of pure dance into dance-drama. For Mr. Hawkins, whose plotless works are often filled with free-floating images, this involves the use of spoken text with narrative action. He will be quite literally speaking his mind onstage.

title:
FASHION PREVIEW;
MILAN AGAIN SPRINGS AHEAD
description: ASKED WHAT FASHION HISTOrians will seize upon when glancing back at the 1980's, almost all the Italian designers reply: ''Freedom.'' Women are no longer slaves to a designer's fancies about skirt length, some say, while others note that women now have the luxury men have long had: to build a basic wardrobe of classic shapes and classic fabrics.

title:
DINING OUT;
ORIENTAL FARE IN HIGHLAND PARK
description: ONCE upon a time in Highland Park, there was a restaurant named Un Peu Bizarre (French for ''a little strange''). The most bizarre thing about it was that it disappeared while we were reviewing it.

title: MUSIC: MOZARTEAN PLAYERS
description: Most musical instruments have gained in size and power over the last two centuries, but the growth is rarely uniform. Violins have lengthened in the neck, added metal strings, increased string tension and, in the process, become more penetrating than their 18th-century ancestors. The piano has swollen more radically - going in Mozart's time from a gentle, equal partner with its fellow instruments to a grandness approaching tyranny.

title: HANNA SCHYGULLA ACHIEVES GREATNESS
description: The 22d New York Film Festival at Lincoln Center, now at midpoint, has gotten off to an unusally impressive start with the premieres of ''Country,'' a beautiful looking, sincere if sobersided paean to American agriculture with a good, tough performance by Jessica Lange, its star and co-producer; ''Diary for My Children,'' Marta Meszaros' memoir about growing up in Stalinist Hungary, and Jim Jarmusch's very funny ''Stranger Than Paradise,'' one of the most original American comedies currently on view.
