title: Marcos Authorizes Anti-Government Rally
description: President Ferdinand E. Marcos today authorized an anti-Government rally scheduled for Sunday after a group of businessmen appealed to him and assured him the gathering would be peaceful, Maj. Gen. Prospero Olivas, the chief of police, said.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: WISH YOU WERE HERE

title: Clare Irene Burton Exchanges Vows With Joshua J. Weeks in Greenwich
description: Clare Irene Burton, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ted Raymond Burton of Corpus Christi, Tex., and Polson, Mont., was married yesterday to Joshua Johnson Weeks, the son of Dorothy Johnson Henry of Greenwich, Conn., and Edgartown, Mass., and Joshua William Weeks of New Canaan, Conn. The Rev. Walter Wagoner performed a Protestant ceremony at the Round Hill Community Church in Greenwich.

title: A PLAN FOR DEVELOPING PEPPERIDGE FARM
description: During the sultry days of August 1937, Margaret Rudkin began baking wholewheat bread in her kitchen at Pepperidge Farm, her 320-acre home in Fairfield, Conn., to make a more wholesome diet for her asthmatic son.

title: INDIA'S GIFT: THE DISCOVERY OF EACH DAY
description: A.M. ROSENTHAL is executive editor of The Times.

title: LETTERS
description: Bilingual Classes To the Editor:

title: Reagan Defends Record On Fighting Drug Traffic
description: President Reagan took credit today for a war on drugs that he said was partly responsible for the arrest of Mafia leaders in the United States and for reducing marijuana use among high school seniors.

title: HOW AMTRAK IS WOOING THE TOURIST;
description: To those who complain that rail travel in the United States is not what it used to be, Amtrak's reply, in effect, is ''Who cares?''

title: Susan Richards Weds Charles P. McGlade Jr.
description: Susan Lori Richards, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred J. Ricchiuto of Fort Lee, N.J., and Fort Lauderdale, Fla., was married yesterday to Charles P. McGlade Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. McGlade of Philadelphia. The Rev. George Danavelil performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of the Madonna in Fort Lee.

title: Rebecca Goldberg to Be Wed to Arthur Biderman
description: Mr. and Mrs. William D. Goldberg of Hackensack, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Rebecca Lynn Goldberg, to Arthur Biderman of Hollis, Queens, a son of Louis Biderman of Yonkersand the late Ethel Littman Biderman of New York.

title: JERSEY TO TEACH BARTENDERS TO COPE WITH DRIVERS WHO DRINK
description: A program intended to help bartenders detect intoxicated patrons will be started in November in an effort to cut the number of drunken-driving cases, state officials announced this week.

title: Iran Denies It Had Part In Attack on Embassy
description: Iran today denied involvement in the suicide car bombing on Sept. 20 of the United States Embassy in Beirut.

title: No Headline
description: Prison Staffs in State Adding 100 Officers

title: SUFFOLK'S WATER:CONTROVERSIAL ARTICLE 7 'TONED DOWN'
description: WHEN environmentalists, builders, farmers, industrialists, health professionals and others meet this week to once again discuss Article 7 - a proposed addition to the Suffolk County Sanitary Code aimed at protecting ground water - they will find some changes.

title: SENATE UNIT GETS TESTIMONY ON RISE OF VIDEO CARD GAMES
description: Video poker and blackjack games are reaping big profits in America's bars, grocery stores and pizza parlors, a Senate panel has been told.

title: CONNECTICUT WILL TEST ELECTRICITY AS WAY TO HALT BRIDGE CORROSION
description: Engineers at the State Department of Transportation are trying to determine whether electricity can halt the natural deterioration of a bridge.

title: VIENNESE BAROQUE
description: Olvier Bernier's most recent book is ''Louis the Beloved, the Life of Louis XV'' (Doubleday).

title: WHAT'S NEW IN EUROPE
description: Paris: Orangerie opens as a museum; wine-bar chains A crop of new museums is gradually making its appearance in Paris. Already opened, though not yet widely known, is the new museum at the Orangerie, just across the Tuileries Gardens from the Jeu de Paume. The Orangerie, which has been used for occasional exhibitions in the past, now has its own permanent collection, thanks to a handsome gift from Domenica Walter that includes a fine collection of canvases by Renoir, Cezanne and other Impressionists.

title: Jane Solomon Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Arthur H. Solomon of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter Jane Wolins Solomon to Steven Todd Siegel, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Norman Siegel, also of New York.

title: 5 KILLED IN PAKISTAN AS SHIITES AND SUNNIS BATTLE
description: Five people were reported killed today and as many as 300 wounded when rival Moslem sects battled in a Karachi slum area.

title: BRAZILLIAN POTPOURRI
description: CRAIG CLAIBORNE is food editor of The New York Times.

title: SIMILAR CANDIDATES IN A REMATCH IN NEW HAVEN
description: A RACE for state representative in New Haven has put some community groups in an unusual position: They would like to support both candidates.

title: TESTING THE FORMULA FOR A NEW DU PONT
description: WILMINGTON, Del.

title: IN SPAIN WITH CRIMINAL INTENT
description: THE FOREIGNER

title: 'CABARET' WITHOUT THE MENACE
description: '' CABARET,'' the award-winning 1966 Broadway musical, is currently receiving a lackluster production at Theater Three in Port Jefferson. This show, with book by Joe Masteroff, music by John Kander and lyrics by Fred Ebb, is based on Christopher Isherwood's ''I Am a Camera.'' It relates the story of pre-World War II Berlin and of the people who were frantically taking what was to be their final turns around the dance floor.

title: No Headline
description: When the poet Byron, at the beginning of his first visit to Greece, stepped onto the soil of the nearly unknown province of Epirus in 1809, he fell instantly under the spell of its stark mountain scenery, inhabited by nomadic tribes and steeped in history. It was after visiting Ioannina, the province's capital, that Byron began ''Childe Harold,'' which would bring fame both to him and to the isolated province, enticing such notables as Gladstone and Disraeli to venture into its wilderness. Byron contended that no other part of Greece could match these towering peaks and steep ravines where ''roams the wolf, the eagle whets his beak, birds, beasts of prey and wilder men appear.''

title: Sharon Holden, Lawyer, Is Wed
description: Sharon L. Holden, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Holden of Urbana, Ill., was married yesterday to Clark J. Winslow, a son of Betty M. Winslow and Joseph C. Winslow, both of Edina, Minn. The Rev. Charles P. Henderson performed the Presbyterian ceremony at the River Club in New York.

title: Mark Vallely Engaged To Lisa Wolfe, Actress
description: Joan Haaren Wolfe of Wilton, Conn., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Lisa R. Wolfe, to Mark J. Vallely, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Wilfred F. Vallely Jr. of Old Greenwich, Conn.

title: WASHINTON'S WAR OVER ARMS CONTROL
description: McGeorge Bundy is a professor of history at New York University and was Special Assistant to the President for National Security Affairs, 1961- 1966. DEADLY GAMBITS

title: Miss Bremer Is Bride Of Robert Earl Nero
description: Margaret Lloyd Bremer, a daughter of Mrs. Paul Bremer of New Canaan, Conn., and the late Mr. Bremer, was married yesterday to Robert Earl Nero, a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. William Chandler Nero of Whittier, Calif. The Rev. Charles Crawford Smith performed the ceremony at the Congregational Church of New Canaan, assisted by the Rev. Ann Struthers Coburn, an Episcopal priest and cousin of the bride.

title:
ART;
TWO CENTURIES OF ENGLISH CARICATURES AT YALE
description: A CAMPAIGN season brings out the best in caricaturists and sharpens the public's response to their drawings. That heightened awareness from the Presidential campaign should carry over to viewing ''English Caricature: From the Beginning to the Present'' at the Yale Center for British Art in New Haven through Nov. 4. The exhibition covers a multitude of social and campaign seasons.

title: LORRIN P. THURSTON
description: -KONA, Hawaii, Oct. 6 (AP) - Lorrin P. Thurston, whose family has published The Honolulu Advertiser since 1888, died Wednesday after a long illness.

title: NO GLORY IN WINNING WHAT OTHERS LOST
description: FOR more than a century, baseball's hagiographers have bequeathed to us a host of special icons and heroes, some particularly deserving, others not. One ballplayer, however, has been consistently and oddly neglected by the saint-makers, many of whom have scarcely heard of him.

title: HANDSOME DECOR IN STAMFORD
description: FOR those who have considered downtown Stamford a dining wasteland, at last there is something to clap hands about - or at least one hand. That is, a new restaurant called Applause.

title: AN AMERICAN TRADITION GROWS
description: The expansion of leisure time, combined with factors such as a shortened work week and the population shift from major cities to suburbs, continues to alter American reading habits. Even with these pressures, the average American spends 11 hours each week reading books, magazines, newspapers and other materials.

title: THE WORLD ; From Hong KongTo Taiwan
description: China undoubtedly had Taiwan in mind when it successfully negotiated with Britain to recover Hong Kong when the lease runs out in 1997. The Hong Kong precedent was only four days old when China renewed a bid last week to regain what it considers another lost territory.

title: HOW THE CAMERAS MADE GARY HART FAMOUS IN 7 DAYS
description: ''Frontline,'' public television's weekly documentary series, begins its third season on Tuesday night with a winner: ''So You Want to be President,'' a two-hour examination of Gary Hart's campaign for the Democratic nomination. Senator Hart's failure to win the nomination is old news, of course, but the way he conducted his campaign is not. We can learn from it. When Mr. Hart announced his candidacy in early 1983, he was scarcely a blip in the polls. When he arrived at the Democratic National Convention this summer, he had 1,200 delegates. Sherry Jones, the ''Frontline'' producer, recorded what happened between these two points with as close to an insider's perspective as we are likely to see on television. Her camera had access even from the beginning, filming, as they say, behind closed doors. The result will be seen on Channel 13 Tuesday night at 8.

title: THE WORM AND THE APPLE ; Snow White Regular riders of New York's Broadway IRT subway take some things for granted. They know they're apt to be ankle-deep in trash. That smoke and fire are a constant worry. That the map on the wall will be obscured by graffiti. They also know better than to expect anything better. But better exists, in the form of a 10- car train called Snow White. Snow White is the chef d'oeuvre of the cleaning crews at the 242d Street subway yard. Determined to show New York what a lot of elbow grease can do, they've turned a dirty train into a monument to soap, brooms, paint and polish. Snow White's been running for six weeks now, and is still clean. The passengers, one worker says, ''have more respect for it.'' If the rest of the cars got comparable attention, they'd probably get more respect, too. Now, Robert Kiley, the M.T.A.'s chairman, promises that they will. He proposes hiring 300 new car cleaners, enough to keep about a third of the subway system's cars graffiti-free. He also promises a start on cleaner stations.
description: Subway riders have learned that M.T.A. promises are almost as prevalent as graffiti.

title: Johnson Wasn't Burned in Effigy
description: To the Editor:

title: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: This is, for operagoers with a sense of adventure and a taste for quality, the last chance this year to catch the work of a small and impressive New York opera company. Operaworks, newly born in 1984, is offering rotating performances of three separate items through Saturday.

title: TOJOURS GUADELOUPE
description: Frank J. Prial is a metropolitan reporter and wine columnist for The New York Times.

title: Maureen Miller Wed to Banker
description: Maureen Catherine Miller, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony G. Miller of Wantagh, L.I., was married yesterday to Brian Hugh Marren, a son of Madeline G. Marren of Mount Vernon, N.Y., and the late James P. Marren. The Rev. Eugene Connolly performed the ceremony in the Lady Chapel of St. Patrick's Cathedral in New York.

title:
THE LIVELY ARTS;
MILESTONE FOR NASSAU REP
description: AFTER nine years of wandering, offering theater in a kind of plain wrapper, the Nassau Repertory Theater opens its 10th anniversary season Tuesday with, its managing director, Kenneth Hahn, said, the prospect of ''being able to look to the future and the next decade.''

title: LAST SEASON'S BEST TEAMS ARE LOOKING EVEN BETTER
description: This season preview of the National Hockey League was prepared and written by Kevin Dupont. Teams are listed in their predicted order of finish within their divisions.

title: PORTRAIT OF THE 'WEALTHIEST' ON MONDALE'S LIST OF TAX TARGETS
description: To the Editor:

title: M. BRIDGET BURNS PLANS TO WED G.S. BUCKNALL
description: Mr. and Mrs. John V. Burns of Naples, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, M. Bridget Burns, to G. Stafford Bucknall, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William S. Bucknall of Greenwich, Conn., and Tannersville, N.Y. A Nov. 24 wedding is planned.

title: IDEAS & TRENDS
description: A three-year undercover investigation aimed at saving some American animals came to a climax last week. Raids by Government wildlife agents in nine states led to the arrest of more than 20 people and charges against 34 in an drive against game poaching.

title: FAILURE? IT'S A ROUSING SUCCESS...
description: Four years later, Reaganomics has altered the economic landscape. Inflation is at its lowest rate in more than a decade with no sign of an upturn. There are millions of new jobs in a growing private sector. (In 10 years, all of Europe hasn't come close to generating the six million jobs our Jack Kemp is a Republican Representative from New York. economy produced in just 18 months.) Factories are using capacity that once lay idle, and new business investment is flourishing, adding still more capacity. Real (as against inflation-induced) wages are growing for the first time in years, while productivity is rising. The income tax bite out of every worker's paycheck has been cut by one-fourth and, under the tax-indexing law that takes effect next year, should never again increase because of inflation. Interest rates, though still high, have dropped by more than a third. Building construction is vigorous. The dollar is again the world's strongest currency. And most Americans believe their future is bright. What about the Federal Government's large deficit? The reversal of this country's economic climate from 1980 to 1984 is enough to disprove the theory that large deficits in themselves cause either inflation or recession. Moreover, the deficit is even now shrinking as a result of economic recovery, and in any case growth is the absolute precondition for dealing with the problem.

title: BOND ISSUE IS PUT ON JERSEY BALLOT
description: Governor Kean signed legislation this week placing a $60 million bond issue on the Nov. 6 ballot that would pay for renovations at state institutions that care for children, veterans and mentally ill people.

title: MONDALE'S BUSINESS EDUCATION

title: Gregory B. Millard, 37, Arts Official With City
description: Gregory B. Millard, assistant commissioner for program services in the city's Department of Cultural Affairs since the start of the Koch administration, died Friday at his home in the Chelsea Hotel after a long illness. He was 37 years old.

title: QUESTIONS ARE READY - ARE ANSWERS?
description: As they campaign around the country, President Reagan and Walter F. Mondale often use the rhetorical device of posing questions to their absent opponent. Face to face in their first debate tonight, the candidates presumably will have to respond to some of those questions.

title: FRESH FACES IN DEVILS' LINEUP
description: THE Devils, entering their 11th season, their third at the Meadowlands, will get another facelift in the hope they can reduce last season's loss total of 56.

title: Hard-Pressed Texans Are Selling Off Cattle
description: Facing another winter with nothing but parched grass on grazing lands and little money to buy feed, ranchers in as many as 60 Texas counties are selling livestock in record numbers, officials say.

description: To the Editor:

title: China Price Shifts Hinted
description: China's President, Li Xiannian, said today that a full meeting of the Communist Party's Central Committee will be held in mid-October to discuss restructuring the urban economy. He hinted that the sensitive question of price reform would be among the issues.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;
description: Of Divorce and the Dower

title: POP: STEVIE RAY VAUGHAN, GUITARIST, AT CARNEGIE HALL
description: THERE'S nothing like a hot guitarist to get the men in a rock-and-roll audience on their feet and screaming. At Carnegie Hall, where the 29-year-old Texas guitar virtuoso Stevie Ray Vaughan led a ''soul revue'' on Thursday, there were moments when the staid auditorium became a whistling, stomping roadhouse.

title: Convergent's Outlook
description: Convergent Technologies Inc. said it expects its third-quarter earnings from continuing operations to be about the same as in the second quarter. Shipments are turning out to be slightly lower than planned, the company explained.

title: JETS EDGE CHIEFS, 17-16, AS NEW DEFENSE BLUNTS RALLY
description: A change of attitude and a change of personnel - and even perhaps a change in glove colors - played a role in the Jets' 17- 16 victory today over the Chiefs.

title: Burroughs Plans 3 New Products
description: The Burroughs Corporation said it would introduce a new mainframe, a minicomputer and systems software at a news conference Tuesday.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: American General Corp., Houston, a diversified financial company, has named Nicholas R. Rasmussen senior vice president-investments.

title: Albania Says Yugoslavs Sabotaged Talks
description: Albania accused Yugoslavia today of sabotaging talks on a joint cultural program that could have improved the thorny ties between the two Balkan neighbors.

title: Carol H. Ostrow Weds Executive
description: Carol Hanan Ostrow, the daughter of Miriam Ruskin of Delray Beach, Fla., and the late Solomon Hanan of New York, was married yesterday to J. Gene Hochfelder, a son of Jack Hochfelder of Lynbrook, L.I., and Hollywood Beach, Fla., and the late Mrs. Hochfelder. Rabbi Norman Kahan performed the ceremony at the Hotel Pierre.

title: Caseload in the State Courts Up 20% From 1978 to 1983
description: About 13 million civil cases and 11 million criminal cases were filed in state courts last year, marking an increase of more than 20 percent over 1978, the Bureau of Justice Statistics reported today.

title: LABOR PARTY: GRIP OF LEFT
description: In few countries does the average man on the street have as much respect and affection for the average policeman on the beat as in Britain. In few countries is there as deep-seated and long-established a public commitment to the rule of law. But at the annual conference of the Labor Party at Blackpool last week, the ritual gathering of the official opposition, there were conspicuously few voices raised in praise of the forces of order.

title: WHAT OUR TRANSIT POLICE NEED
description: To the Editor:

title: SIMMS GROWS INTO A LEADER
description: Phil Simms has never had it so good.

title: FAWCETT IN 'BURNING BED'
description: IF you are at all attuned to the

title: CHICO BORJA QUITTING COSMOS
description: Following Ricky Davis's exit, Chico Borja has informed the Cosmos that he has signed a guaranteed contract for three years with the Las Vegas Americans of the Major Indoor Soccer League and will not return to the Cosmos after his contract with them expires Nov. 15.

title: BRIGHAM YOUNG BUCKS TIDE OF UPSETS
description: In this topsy-turvy college football season of more surprise than form, the search for reliability and consistency becomes difficult. Fans were again shaking their heads in disbelief Saturday when Purdue upset Ohio State, 28-23; Michigan State stunned Michigan, 19-7; Memphis State tied Florida State, 17-17, and Vanderbilt and Georgia Tech, two of the September surprises, became October victims of upsets.

title: Washington Watch ; Tire Grading's Tug-of-War
description: The latest chapter in the Government's on-

title: CALIFORNIA BALLOT QUESTIONS DIM PRESIDENTIAL RACE
description: Millions of dollars are being poured into contentious battles over six proposals on the November ballot in California that in many ways are overshadowing Presidential politics in the nation's most populous state.

title: Brawl Marks Ranger Loss
description: Glen Hanlon, the Rangers' goaltender, was hurt and seven Rangers and Flyers were ejected from tonight's game after a bench-clearing brawl as the Flyers won a messy prelude to the season. The 8-3 loss left the Rangers with a final preseason record of 2-5-1.

title: POLL SHOWS FEW VOTES CHANGED BY ABORTION ISSUE
description: Only a tiny fraction of voters say they will base their vote in November solely on the candidates' positions on abortion, the latest New York Times/ CBS News Poll shows.

title: Texas Instruments Plans Fund for Holders
description: Texas Instruments Inc. will establish a $12 million fund to pay stockholders who asserted in a Federal lawsuit that the electronics company misled investors about earnings in 1983, according to court documents.

title: ARCHIE ROBERTS Sr.
description: Arthur H. (Archie) Roberts Sr., a football and baseball star at New York University and a member of the school's Hall of Fame, died Saturday at Holyoke, Mass., at the age of 80. He was the father of Archie Roberts Jr., a star quarterback for Columbia from 1963 to 1965.

title: Helen Altman Is Wed To David Paul Felsher
description: Helen Lynn Altman, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Stanley F. Altman of Bedford, N.Y., was married yesterday to David Paul Felsher, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Roual Felsher of Graniteville, S.I. Rabbi Maurice Davis performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents.

title: FERRARO CAMPAIGNS FOR ETHNIC VOTE
description: Geraldine A. Ferraro yesterday stressed her Italian heritage and her historic choice as the Democratic Vice-Presidential nominee as she made overtures for the ethnic vote in the New York area.

title: PADRES AGAIN OVERCOME CUBS AND GAIN THEIR FIRST PENNANT
description: The San Diego Padres completed one of the theatrical comebacks in playoff history today when they knocked out Rick Sutcliffe in the seventh inning, rallied to defeat the Chicago Cubs, 6-3, won their third consecutive game after two losses and captured their first National League pennant.

title: NEW TORCH OF LIBERTY TO BE BUILT BY FRENCH
description: The new torch to be put atop the Statue of Liberty's refurbished arm will be constructed by French craftsmen, just as the original was, the Statue of Liberty-Ellis Island Foundation announced yesterday.

title: ADVERTISING ; ; Lewis, Gilman & Kynett Elects Unit President
description: John K. Kaiser, 41-year-old Detroit native, has been elected president and chief operating officer of the advertising division of Lewis, Gilman & Kynett, Philadelphia's largest ad agency.

title: A SEGMENTING HOTEL MARKET
description: Guests at Holiday Inn Crowne Plaza hotels are pampered with doorman and bellman service, the choice of dining in one of the hotels's two restaurants, a free morning newspaper, maid service in the evening - and help with entertainment, transportation, or secretarial needs.

title: EDITED 'BINTEL BRIEF' AND WROTE 5 NOVELS
description: Isaac Metzker, a Yiddish novelist and short story writer and editor of the two-volume work ''A Bintel Brief,'' died of a heart attack Saturday in St. Vincent's Hospital in Bridgeport, Conn. He was 83 years old and lived in Brooklyn and Bridgeport.

title: MENTAL HEALTH REFORM IN NEED OF STEP TWO
description: To the Editor:

title: DISCLOSING SECRETS TO THE PRESS: U.S. CALLS IT ESPIONAGE
description: The arrest of a Navy employee accused of selling classified photographs to a British military magazine raises the question of whether the espionage laws can be used to prosecute people who make disclosures to the press. The charge filed last Monday against Samuel Loring Morison, a civilian intelligence analyst said to have sold American satellite photographs of a Soviet aircraft carrier under construction, marks only the second time that the Federal espionage laws have been used to prosecute an official or former official for disclosing classified information to a publication, legal experts said.

title: BEHIND BEIRUT TERRORISM
description: The latest bombing of the American Embassy in Beirut has been linked circumstantially to the Government of Iran - yet another example of state-sponsored terrorism. Western intelligence and journalists have begun to investigate the financial and logistical help that such Lebanese terrorists might receive from Iran. Yet much more important than any tactical help is the Iranian ideology that legitimates the use of terrorist violence and offers Moslems a simple and simplistic explanation for their woes - the corrupting influence of the United States and its ''lackey'' Arab governments.

title: FOR TRAUTMANN, VISIONS OF 4:00 MILE
description: There are times, on hard distance workouts about the rough and hilly terrain of his Central Valley, N.Y., home, when John Trautmann lets his dreams run away with him. He sees himself in a race, in the lead at the final stages, pushing his body to the limit. ''I pretend I'm breaking the record,'' says Trautmann. ''No particular record, just any record.''

title: ISRAELIS OUTLINE NEW SET OF TERMS ON SOUTH LEBANON
description: Israel is willing to consider withdrawing its troops from Lebanon in return for a ''nonwritten'' Syrian commitment to keep its forces where they are and to prevent infiltration southward by Palestinian guerrillas, Israeli officials said today.

title: PRESSURES FOR HIGHER RATES EASE
description: After a nearly three-week hiatus in the Treasury's note and bond financings, this week's auctions - $5.5 billion of seven-year notes and $4 billion of new 20-year bonds - do not seem to have put much upward pressure on interest rates.

title: JOHN PAUL, IN SOUTH ITALY, SCORNS 'MAFIOSO VIOLENCE'
description: Pope John Paul II stepped up his criticism of organized crime today, attacking the Mafia by name and urging young people in southern Italy not to ''succumb to the temptation of criminal and Mafioso violence.''

title: BUSINESSMEN JOIN ANTI-MARCOS MARCH
description: About 20,000 people, including many businessmen and other professionals who said they were taking part in a street demonstration for the first time, marched peacefully through Manila today in protest against the Government of Ferdinand E. Marcos.

title: Orange County Couple Slain; Son, 45, Held in Pennsylvania
description: A 45-year-old man has been charged with the murder of his parents at their home in this Orange County community near Middletown, the police said Sunday.

title: CROSS AND FLAG
description: It may be Ronald Reagan's most

title: NEW ETHIOPIA: FEUDAL WAYS YIELD TO MARX
description: A decade is but a moment in the life of an empire that traces its origins to Solomon and Sheba. But in only 10 years since the overthrow of Emperor Haile Selassie, a new Ethiopia has been born.

title: TRANSCRIPT OF LOUISVILLE DEBATE BETWEEN REAGAN AND MONDALE
description: Participants in the Debate The following people participated in last night's Presidential debate in Louisville:

title: ADVERTISING ; ; D'Arcy Ends Work For Alberto-Culver
description: The Alberto-Culver Company announced Friday morning that it and D'Arcy MacManus Masius, its agency since 1981, had mutually agreed to terminate their relationship.

title: TAMER SIDESHOWS AS FRANKFURT BOOK FAIR ENDS
description: Harvey Rosen, standing tall in a starched white chef's toque and flanked by an outsized copy of his book, ''How to Garnish,'' deftly carves little green whales out of zucchini.

title: A VERTEBRATE PALEONTOLOGIST
description: Dr. George Gaylord Simpson, a world authority on vertebrate paleontology, died of pneumonia Saturday at the El Dorado Hospital and Medical Center in Tucson, Ariz. He was 82 years old and lived in Tucson.

title: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.
description: Monday

title: Futures/Options ; A New Dimension In Silver
description: With the opening of the silver options market on the Commodity Exchange last Thursday, trading in the metal took on a new dimension. For the first time, traders will be able to trade exchange-traded options on Comex's silver futures at prices determined by a continuing auction and not by dealer fiat.

title: CITY RETAIL SALES SLOW FOR MONTH
description: New York City's retail business in September continued the slow trend of the prior three months, with an average gain among the seven largest retailers of only 4.5 percent over the year-earlier month, a spot check found late last week.

title: A FEEBLE U.N. SADDENS FILIPINO, A LIFELONG FRIEND
description: Carlos P. Romulo, the 85-year-old Filipino who helped draft the United Nations Charter, says he has a final ''mission'' after a succession of careers - to tell the world again that the United Nations must be strengthened.

title: KNICKS DEFEAT NETS
description: If exhibition games are supposed to provide coaches with answers about their team, Hubie Brown of the Knicks and Stan Albeck of the Nets learned several things tonight in New York's 111-107 victory here at the Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: Yugoslavia Prices Rise
description: Yugoslavia's consumer prices rose 5.4 percent in September from August and climbed 56.7 percent from September 1983, the Federal Statistics Bureau said Friday. The agency said Yugoslavia's inflation was heading to a record annual rate of about 80 percent in 1984, which would surpass the previous record of 58.4 percent set last year.

title: No Headline
description: Matsushita Names Head of U.S. Unit

title: ADVERTISING;
description: Campbell Wins Control Data

title: MUST CANDIDATES AVOID FREE TV?
description: The Reagan- Bush and Mondale-Ferraro campaigns are pouring millions of dollars into paid radio and television spots while ignoring broadcasters' invitations to expound their views for free. This is a foolishly cautious attitude, self-defeating for the candidates and bad for the quality of our national campaigns.

title: RENAULT'S TURNAROUND HOPES
description: The Paris automobile show is under way once again, attracting upward of a million people and enormous publicity. And much of the interest this year is in a smoothly snub-nosed offering by Renault known as the Supercinq, or Super Five.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We got out the old favorite tool we've come to know and love so well.'' - John T. Cox, space shuttle flight director, referring to craft's robotic arm.

title: CAPITAL PUNISHMENT: KOCH'S FLAWED CALL
description: To the Editor:

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: 60 MINUTES: The Power and the Politics of America's Most Popular TV News Show. By Axel Madsen. 255 pages. Dodd, Mead & Company. $16.95.

title: Ironman Calling It Quits
description: -KONA, Hawaii, Oct. 7 (AP) - Dave Scott says that after five grueling Ironman triathlon races, including three consecutive victories, it's time to quit.

title: Hilary Good Wed To Noubar Stone
description: Hilary Howard Good, a daughter of Mrs. Joel Michael Segal of New York and East Hampton, L.I., and Barry Campbell Good of New York and Water Mill, L.I., was married yesterday to Noubar Allen Stone, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Cabeen Stone of Corpus Christi, Tex. The Rev. Francis B. Creamer performed the ceremony at St. Luke's Episcopal Church in East Hampton.

title: Hospitalized Thai Chief Is Reported Much Better
description: Prime Minister Prem Tinsulanonda, hospitalized with a lung ailment, was ''much better'' today and was being allowed to walk around his hospital room, his doctor said.

title: FRIENDSHIP BETWEEN THE SEXES
description: -year-old Los Angeles lawyer, has a problem, she discusses it with her best friend, Alan Silverman, 36, a fellow lawyer she has known since college.

title: FRENCH TAKE LESS TABLE WINE
description: The consumption of table wine in France continues to drop sharply. For the 11 months ended Aug. 1, the figure fell 4.16 percent, according to a trade report.

title: QUESTION BOX
description: QUESTION: How many World Series games did Arndt Jorgens and Charlie Silvera get into during their years as backup catchers with the Yankees?

title: A Walk on the Waste Side
description: An evening walk along Manhattan's midtown streets was once like a visit to a museum of commercial design. The stroller could stop to examine cleverly lit, glassed-in fashions, antiques, jewelry, or even sporting art. And nowhere in his path were there any mounds of shiny plastic torsos - unmistakably full of garbage.

title: OUTDOORS: SOOTHING DAY IN A BOAT
description: NEVER one to conceal his feelings, Lou Figurelli was churning with more than the usual emotion the day Pete Silverstein and I went fishing with him out of Great Kills Harbor in Staten Island.

title: ; Joyce Guyer, Soprano, In City Opera Debut
description: Joyce Guyer, an American soprano who has previously sung with the Arizona Opera, the Central City Opera in Colorado, and the Opera Orchestra of New York, made her first appearance with the New York City Opera on Saturday afternoon, as Gilda in Verdi's ''Rigoletto.''

title: LILCO SEES ITSELF AS SOUND THROUGH '85
description: The Long Island Lighting Company has solved its financial problems through the end of 1985, according to the chairman of the board and the chief financial officer.

title: Lisa DeCrane Wed to Alvaro Saralegui
description: St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church in Bronxville, N.Y., was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Lisa Ann DeCrane, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred C. DeCrane Jr. of Bronxville, to Alvaro Javier Saralegui, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jorge Saralegui of San Juan, P.R. The Rev. Philip Marquard, great-uncle of the bride, and Msgr. Patrick J. Sheridan performed the ceremony.

title: BIRTHDAY FOR BACH
description: Johann Sebastian Bach would have been 300 years old next March, if he had lived. And in a way, he has. His music is the stuff of which celebrations, enough of them it sometimes appears to last until the 400th anniversary, are made.

title: Michele Trowbridge Is Wed to Thomas Parsons
description: Michele Trowbridge, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Clinton Whiting Trowbridge of New York and Philadelphia, was married yesterday to Thomas Ballard Parsons, the son of Mr. and Mrs. David Church Parsons of Muncie, Ind. The Rev. Robert Gustafson performed the ceremony at the First Congregational Church in Blue Hill, Me.

title: CUBANS, CITING A U.S. THREAT, STEP UP READINESS
description: In the last two months the Cuban Government has been conducting large-scale evacuation and combat drills in anticipation, it says, of an attack by the United States.

title: UMPIRES AGREE TO UEBERROTH ARBITRATION
description: The major league umpires ended their strike today when Peter Ueberroth, the new baseball commissioner, agreed to arbitrate their dispute over postseason pay. Four were quickly rounded up to officiate the deciding game of the National League playoff here.

title: DOUBT ON CHARTER-JOHNSON TIE
description: The Bank of England could not afford to be too choosy in manning its lifeboat as it scrambled to rescue the banking and bullion trading operations of Johnson Matthey P.L.C. from collapse last week. That, at any rate, is the most popular explanation in the City, London's financial community, for the prominent position and potentially lucrative role given to Charter Consolidated P.L.C.

title: EUROPE PLANS RISE IN GRAIN EXPORTS
description: European farmers are preparing to increase their sales of feed grains to the Soviet Union and other needy countries this year, according to European and American sources. Such a move would inevitably come at the expense of farmers in the United States.

title: WIFE CHARGED IN SLAYING ON L.I.
description: The police have charged a Brentwood woman with stabbing her husband to death last month and a Long Island man with conspiring with her in the slaying.

title: A.C.L.U. vs. High Court
description: The American Civil Liberties

title: Miss Greenwald Wed To Michael Cavallo
description: Leah Greenwald and Michael Cavallo were married yesterday at the Hyatt Regency Hotel in Cambridge, Mass., by Rabbi Frank Waldorf.

title: DOLPHINS (6-0) ROUT STEELERS
description: Dan Marino threw two second-quarter touchdown passes in a return to his hometown as the Miami Dolphins remained unbeaten today with a 31-7 rout of the Pittsburgh Steelers.

title: The Calendar
description: Monday

title: Wallace Said to Improve
description: Doctors will probably keep Gov. George C. Wallace in University Hospital only a few more days, John Wright, a hospital spokesman, said today. Mr. Wallace is being treated for a urinary tract infection. His fever has broken.

title: Postal Service Scores
description: Over months of disagreement over a new contract, the Postal Service is said to have stressed the contention that its clerks and carriers were overpaid. Postal workers' pride may have been wounded by such talk, but not extinguished.

title: Babbitt Sings Standards At the Rainbow Room
description: The Rainbow Room, which has been celebrating its 50th anniversary all year, featured several big bands in the spring as a reminder of the big bands that played in the room during its early years. Now, during the first two weeks in October, it has returned to this theme, presenting vocalists who sang with big bands.

title: Key Dancer Wins By Five Lengths
description: Key Dancer, ridden by Angel Cordero Jr., took command a half- mile from the finish and went on to score a five-length victory over Surely Georgie's yesterday in the $94,500 Athenia Handicap for fillies and mares at Belmont Park.

title: AROUND THE WORLD;
description: Six masked gunmen stole 220 pounds of gold, worth more than $1 million, from a metal refinery today after holding the refinery director, his family and two other people hostage for five hours, the police said.

title: Magazine Sale Could Be Biggest
description: The sale of the major portions of

title: NEWS SUMMARY;
description: MONDAY, OCTOBER 8, 1984 International Israel would consider withdrawing its troops from Lebanon in return for a ''nonwritten'' Syrian commitment to keep its forces where they are and to prevent infiltration by Palestinian guerrillas, according to Israeli officials. Speaking on the eve of Prime Minister Shimon Peres's visit to Washington, the officials said that in exchange for a pullout, Israel would insist on an expanded deployment of United Nations forces in southern Lebanon. (Page A1, Column 2.) South Africa will use its army to support the police in combatting a wave of unrest in recent weeks that has claimed 80 lives in a crackdown on dissent. A police spokesman said army units had been deployed in Soweto, the black township outside Johannesburg. Moreover, the Minister of Law and Order, Louis Le Grange, said the civilian police would be expanded by 45 percent, apparently an acknowledgement that unrest was unlikely to abate. (A1:1.)

title: CLASH ON DEFICIT, SOCIAL ISSUES; RIVALS STRIVE TO KEEP COOL ON THE ISSUES
description: The rivals faced off obliquely on a theater stage that seemed set by Beckett, for the uttering of cosmic questions amid some simple props to lean on.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;
description: As if Led by Valkyries . . .

title: CORE OF VETERANS A KEY FOR ISLANDERS
description: UNIONDALE, L.I.

title: HOW ENDINGS HAVE AFFECTED TWO RECENT MOVIES
description: Shakespeare ended one of his plays simply by having a character declare, ''Here our play has ending.'' The movies, while not as brusque about it, quickly developed several cliches to inform the audience that it was time to vacate the theater.

title: CORRECTION
description: The obituary Saturday of Bruno Shaw, a writer and radio broadcaster, omitted the name of his wife, Regina, from the list of survivors.

title: QUEEN ELIZABETH VISITING KENTUCKY HORSE FARMS
description: Queen Elizabeth II, a top breeder of thoroughbred horses in Britain, began a private six-day visit today to some of America's noted stud farms.

title: Stadiumitis
description: There are twin towers in New York's World Trade Center and twin lions at the Public Library, but it seems bizarre for serious planners to urge twin stadiums in Flushing. It would be nice to see a few professional football games again in New York City.

title: Disneyland Threatens To Replace Strikers
description: Striking workers at Disneyland have been told that they will be replaced if they do not resume work this week, but picketing continued today.

title: Academy of St. Martin, From Corelli to Bartok
description: Handsome, detailed, disciplined playing; vigor and bracing precision of rhythm: These are the virtues its hundreds of recordings have taught listeners to expect from the Academy of St. Martin in the Fields, and these are the virtues its touring string ensemble brought to a program ranging from Corelli to Bartok in Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon.

title: Kim Kashkashian To Play Hindemith
description: Kim Kashkashian, a violist, will play Hindemith's Sonata for Solo Viola, a United States premiere, on Nov. 7 at 8 P.M. at the 92d Street Y on Lexington Avenue.

title: DANCE: HARLEM TROUPE CHANGES 3 OF ITS CASTS
description: NEW casts in the three works that Dance Theater of Harlem offered Saturday afternoon at the City Center Theater allowed audiences to see both fine dancing and fine examples of acting by means of dancing.

title: Singer Play in Yiddish
description: A Play for the Devil,'' a play by Isaac Bashevis Singer, will be presented by the Folksbiene Ensemble, beginning Oct. 20 at the Folksbiene Playhouse, 123 East 55th Street.

title: JERSEY INVESTIGATING INSECTICIDE SPILL
description: As work crews began cleaning up a major spill of insecticide from a plant on the Arthur Kill in New Jersey, state officials said yesterday that they were beginning an investigation into why a 12,000-gallon, steel tank suddenly overheated and sent a steaming cloud of the chemical into the air.

title: Touch of the Pro
description: When Inez Aimee took over as executive director of the United States Ski Team three years ago, she immediately realized that the amateur organization had a serious flaw - amateurism.

title: Janet Pauline Street Weds Cesar Ordonez
description: Janet Pauline Street, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. James J. Street of Metuchen, N.J., was married yesterday to Cesar Ordonez, a son of Homero Ordonez of Brooklyn and the late Graciela Guerra Ordonez. Rabbi Philip Berkowitz performed the ceremony at Kirkpatrick Chapel at Rutgers University.

title: YOUNG MODELS COUNSELED TO BE WARY OF EXPLOITERS
description: She was not a starry-eyed youth who left a small town to look for fame as a big city model. She was a New Yorker and she thought she could look out for herself. But Pat Evans was 17 years old, and 26 years ago that was still young, even in New York. When a photographer asked her to pose in lingerie, she was nervous, but she agreed.

title: A BRIDGE CABLE'S FATAL SNAP LEADS TO YEARS OF LITIGATION
description: One afternoon in June 1981, Akira Aimi was walking across the Brooklyn Bridge when two cables overhead, each 600 feet long and more than 2 inches thick, snapped.

title: 2 NEW ENGLAND NEIGHBORS MORE THAN A BORDER APART
description: Robert Frost once wrote, ''Anything I can say about New Hampshire will serve almost as well about Vermont.''

title: K-Tel Files Under Chapter 11
description: K-Tel International Inc., which distributes recorded music products, has filed for protection under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code.

title: THE MASADA ECONOMY
description: ome to the wrong place at the

title: FIVE HELPERS FOR PAYTON
description: CHICAGO ''It was no great play, an average play,'' Mark Brotz said, referring to the blast up the left side that Walter Payton used yesterday to break Jim Brown's career record for rushing.

title: Comterm Write-off
description: Comterm Inc. said it had decided to end the operations of Bytec, its portable microcomputer division that produced Hyperion computers, and take a write-off of $48.3 million in the second quarter ended July 31. As a result, the company will shut down its Ottawa plant.

title: SALVADOR JAILING HAS U.S. BACKLASH
description: The case of a union official imprisoned in El Salvador without trial since 1980 has become an issue in relations between the United States and El Salvador, according to Administration officials.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST MONDAY, OCTOBER 8, 1984
description: The Economy

title: Rate Proposal By A.T.& T.
description: The American Telephone & Telegraph Company on Friday proposed to restructure its overseas telephone rates starting Nov. 19, with rate reductions for calls to Britain, France, West Germany, Italy, Ireland and Australia.

title: Ivy Coaches' 2d Goal
description: Princeton's football coach, Frank Navarro, has joined his Ivy League colleagues in a battle that is greater than any they face on the field. Since February 1983, the Ivy coaches have been fighting illiteracy, a problem that handicaps 26 million adults in the United States.

title: Of Pounds and Politics
description: Congress treasures all kinds of statistics, but there seems to be no way of establishing with historical precision whether any House member before Representative Barney Frank of Massachusetts ever lost 70 pounds while in office.

title: Plane Crash Injures 4
description: Three Civil Air Patrol cadets and a pilot were seriously injured when their single-engine plane crashed into woods near Richter Airfield in this Essex County hamlet early Saturday afternoon.

title:
WORLD SERIES SCOUTING REPORTS;
TIGERS BALANCED
description: Jim Russo is the major league scout for the Baltimore Orioles.

title: CAMPAIGN NOTES ; N. Carolina Senate Race Is Close, New Poll Shows
description: A new poll shows a close race in North Carolina's bitter Senate campaign.

title: CARDINALS' LOMAX THWARTS COWBOYS
description: Neil Lomax thwarted a blitzing Dallas defense with three touchdown passes and the Cardinals ended seven years of frustration in Texas Stadium today with a 31-20 rout of the punchless Cowboys.

title: CITY, THROUGH A TINY AGENCY, IS FIGHTING TO GET LOW-COST NIAGARA POWER
description: The New York City Public Utility Service is run by a borrowed staff of two in a small office down the street from City Hall. It has no power lines, no crews, no generating plants.

title: ;  Apollo to Mullen
description: Mullen Advertising in Beverly Farms, Mass., has become agency for Apollo Computer of Chelmsford, Mass. The agency said the billings would be between $3 million and $6 million. The client, a maker of 32-bit work stations for the scientific and engineering communities, formerly had its account at Clarke Goward Fitts for about nine months.

title: PARASITIC MITES IMPERIL HONEYBEES IN 5 STATES
description: A parasitic mite that preys on honeybees has invaded beehives in five states, including New York, forcing the authorities to destroy millions of bees, a spokesman for the Federal Department of Agriculture has disclosed.

title: BETTING ON NUCLEAR COMEBACK
description: As Westinghouse sees it, the market for nuclear reactors is not dead - it's merely living in exile. The company is investing heavily on the theory that the market will prosper abroad and will eventually come home.

title: AT G.E., A CHANGE OF COURSE
description: When the General Electric Company, for decades the largest producer of small appliances, announced last year that it was selling that business to the Black & Decker Manufacturing Company, the news stunned the housewares industry. Setting aside differences in scale, it was as if General Motors had suddenly abandoned car making.

title: German Prices Rise
description: West German consumer prices were up one-tenth of 1 percent in September from August and rose 1.5 percent from 12 months earlier - the lowest year-to-year increase since January 1969, the Federal Statistics Office said Friday.

title: CAMPAIGN NOTES ; Foreign Editors Expect Reagan to Be Re-elected By United Press International
description: Two dozen newspaper editors from 20 countries around the globe overwhelmingly expect President Reagan to win re-election, according to a survey by the monthly World Press Review.

title: Machinery Sector Hopes
description: The shares of machinery companies with petroleum-service operations could outperform

title: CREWMEN'S REPORTS ON NAVY CAPTAIN INVESTIGATED
description: The Navy and the Senate are investigating allegations that a former captain of a supply ship failed to report a collision at sea, fired a rifle at whales and dumped computer tapes overboard, it was reported today.

title: Teachers in 1 Jersey District Resume Talks on a Contract
description: Representatives of striking teachers here resumed contract negotiations with the district today, and talks were scheduled to get under way Monday in Sayreville, the site of New Jersey's other school strike. The two strikes affect about 11,000 students.

title: TURNING TO MEDIATION TO SETTLE A DIVORCE
description: A Long Island couple with a $2.5 million estate worked out a complex separation agreement two weeks ago. The negotiations were conducted during 18 one-hour sessions at a total cost of $1,800. No lawyers were present during the process.

title: President Appointed At Manfra, Tordella
description: Francis B. Bessenyey has been named president of Manfra, Tordella, Brooks Inc., the largest independent wholesaler of precious metals and foreign bank notes in the United States.

title: ; Jonathan Rennert Plays Modern Organ Music
description: Jonathan Rennert has an obvious affection for 20th-century British organ music, and he played some unusual selections with sensitivity and spirit at the Park Avenue Christian Church yesterday afternoon.

title: NEC Plan at U.S. Site
description: The NEC Corporation, a major Japanese computer maker, is considering a plan to produce personal computers at the plant site of its wholly owned United States subsidiary in Massachusetts, a company spokesman said Friday. He also said NEC Information Systems, based in Boxboro, Mass., would build a new production facility within its compound for personal computers. The machines' central processing units would initially be supplied from Japan, he added.

title: 'DISASTROUS' TIME FOR U.S. REFINERS
description: Profits for American oil refiners have dropped to such a low point that a growing number of refineries are closing down or severely curtailing operations.

title: Paying Their Own Way
description: Hand wringers may complain about the commercialization of amateur sports, but not apparently at Louisiana State. It turns out that at Baton Rouge college athletics is not only big business, but also state law requires it to be just that.

title: LEAGUE MAY REARRANGE PANEL SELECTION METHOD
description: A dispute over the selection of the questioners for tonight's Presidential debate has led the League of Women Voters to tentatively seek to overhaul the selection process for the journalists.

title: Elissa Udell Married To Dr. Mark Macher
description: Elissa Beth Udell, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Udell of Plainview, L.I., was married yesterday to Dr. Mark Macher, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Macher of Brooklyn. Rabbi Dr. Elliot Udell, the bride's brother, performed the ceremony at the Manhattan Beach Jewish Center in Brooklyn.

title: CAPITAL PUNISHMENT: KOCH'S FLAWED CALL
description: To the Editor:

title: CAMPAIGN NOTE ; Zaccaro Would Attend Meetings of the Cabinet
description: John A. Zaccaro plans to sit in on Cabinet meetings if his wife, Geraldine A. Ferraro, is elected Vice President, according to an interview published in the November issue of Redbook.

title: BEARS FACING FOOD SHORTAGE VENTURE INTO ALASKAN TOWNS
description: Spreading development and shortages of salmon and blueberries have led dozens of bears to stray into populated areas in search of food, and at least 23 have been shot and killed this summer and fall, according to state officials.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;
description: Goldin's Signature, Part 3: The Aides Did It

title: ADVERTISING ; ; Doyle Dane Bernbach Gets Popeyes Account
description: Popeyes Famous Fried Chicken and Biscuits, a New Orleans-based national fast-food chain, has delivered its account to Doyle Dane Bernbach, which has had a vacant restaurant-chain category since Ponderosa left in 1981.

title: CULTURAL POT LUCK IN MOSCOW INCLUDES 'AMADEUS'
description: Between chess games, in which everybody is responding to the suffering of young Gary Kasparov, who is being walloped by the chess champion Anatoly Karpov, one can take cultural pot luck in Moscow. It is a pretty big pot. The season is on, and Moscow has about 20 theaters, many with serious dramas ranging from Shakespeare through the Russian classics and up to Tennessee Williams and Peter Shaffer. In other theaters are satire, puppets, vaudeville, operetta, dance, folk dance and variety shows. Then there are the many concerts and operas, even with the Bolshoi currently on tour.

title: ;  People
description: Paul Rabstein named president of Goldsmith & Ansorge Advertising in Red Bank, N.J.

title: No Headline
description: Fran,coise Perny Is Wed

title: SHUTTLE MOVES DAMAGED ANTENNA TO FACE SATELLITE, PRESERVING DATA
description: The crew of the space shuttle Challenger today succeeded in pointing its crippled communications antenna at a tiny relay satellite sailing more than 22,000 miles overhead, saving hours of precious data that otherwise would have been lost.

title: PAYTON BREAKS BROWN'S RECORD
description: The moment finally came on the second play from scrimmage in the third quarter today. Jim McMahon, the Chicago Bears' quarterback, called ''Toss 28 Weak,'' a pitchout for Walter Payton and a play the Bears have run countless times before.

title: RANGERS STARTING A NEW SEASON ON A CONFIDENT NOTE
description: IN a moment just barely remembered from the fourth game of

title: 2 Hurt in Philadelphia Fire
description: Two firefighters were hospitalized for burns and smoke inhalation today after a four-alarm fire broke out in a 21-story office-condominium building that reportedly failed to meet city fire codes, the authorities said. The office lacked fire detectors and sprinklers.

title: HOUSE AIDES RAISE NEW CHARGE IN E.P.A. INQUIRY
description: The House Judiciary Committee is investigating whether high-level Justice Department officials discussed beginning a grand jury investigation as a way of withholding embarrassing documents from Congress, according to House investigators.

title: Two Are Killed in India In Moslem-Hindu Clash
description: Moslems and Hindus clashed in the northeastern state of Assam today and two people were killed, state officials reported.

title: PADRES MIX AGE, YOUTH
description: Dave Johnson is manager of the New York Mets.

title: Study of Transit Radios Due
description: Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward yesterday described the transit police radio system as ''archaic'' and said a committee would be set up to look into the problem.

title: Tests the Army Should Not Shirk
description: There's a troubling lack of urgency in the way the Army battle-tests its armored vehicles. The downgrading last month of a colonel who tried to improve the realism of such tests draws attention to their importance.

title: 7 UNION LOCALS REJECT GENERAL MOTORS OFFER
description: Workers at the Bowling Green, Ky., Corvette assembly plant rejected a United Automobile Workers contract with the General Motors Corporation today. It was the seventh local to reject the pact out of 13 tallied so far. One local leader attributed the votes to a $22 increase in yearly union dues.

title: Alfred A. Duckett, 67, Dead; An Author and Businessman
description: Alfred A. Duckett, an author who collaborated with the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. on a book and speeches, including Dr. King's ''I Have a Dream'' speech for the 1963 March on Washington, died of cancer Oct. 1 in the University of Illinois Hospital in Chicago. He was 67 years old and lived in Chicago and New York.

title: KENNEDY AIRPORT NEEDS REDESIGN, OFFICIAL SAYS
description: Kennedy International Airport is ''obsolescent'' and overcrowded and will require ''a major redesign'' of its passenger-traffic system to return to efficient operation, Peter C. Goldmark Jr., the executive director of the Port Authority, said yesterday.

title: Elisabeth Tabor Wed To Eric T. F. Fleisher
description: Elisabeth Ann Tabor, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald Y. Tabor of Fairfield, Conn., and Newport Beach, Calif., was married yesterday to Eric Torsten Fredrikson Fleisher, the son of Elizabeth Fredrikson Leake of New York and Eric W. Fleisher of Bethesda, Md. Rabbi Bruce Goldman performed the ceremony at the Spinning Wheel Inn in Redding Ridge, Conn.

title: 'Those Four To Martinez'
description: SAN DIEGO HE stood there in the Cubs' dressing room, taking the blame just as he had taken the loss. His face framed by his reddish hair and reddish beard, Rick Sutcliffe was wearing a blue T-shirt, gray shorts and thin white stockings up to his knees as he leaned against his locker. He had been standing there for half an hour and he would stand there for another half-hour answering all the questions about how the San Diego Padres had suddenly shelled him to win the National League pennant, 6-3.

title: Cara Jonassen Is the Bride Of Brian Andrew Bowers
description: Cara Frances Jonassen, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Ole Thor Jonassen of Locust Valley, L.I., was married yesterday to Brian Andrew Bowers, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Reginald Bowers of Chislehurst, Kent, England. The Rev. David Jacobsen performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church in Sausalito, Calif.

title: U.S. TRADE RULING DISMAYS KOREANS
description: Exports are a life-and-death matter for South Korea's economy, and this country was rattled in February when the United States Commerce Department ruled that electronics companies here were dumping color television sets on the American market.

title: Blast Damages 60 Buildings At a Resort Town in Wales
description: A huge explosion thought to be caused by a broken gas main shook this western Wales seaside resort and damged more than 60 buildings today, a police spokesman said.

title: DOCTORS ASSESS GRIM COST OF NICARAGUA WAR
description: Health and medical services in Nicaragua have been severely disrupted by the warfare that is continuing in many parts of the country, according to data presented at a Government-sponsored conference of Nicaraguan and pro-Sandinista American doctors here last week.

title: CIVIL RIGHTS STRUGGLE AS SEEN BY THE CHILDREN
description: The public park in Newhall, 30 miles north of Los Angeles, needed only slight changes to be transformed into a small Mississippi town in 1964: the California palm trees were concealed from the camera. But the most dramatic difference was the ''Whites Only'' sign in front of the park's drinking fountain. It was needed for a fight scene between a black youth and two white boys who beat him for refusing to leave.

title: PARTIES TRADE CHARGES OVER REMARKS ON BENEFITS
description: Democrats charged tonight that President Reagan misstated the history of the Social Security program when he responded to criticism from Walter F. Mondale in their debate on domestic issues.

title: SALVADOR AFFIRMS IT HAS NAPALM SAN SALVADOR, Oct. 7 (Reuters) - A high Salvadoran official acknowledged for the first time today that his country had stocks of napalm weapons but said they had not been used.
description: The official, Defense Minister Eugenio Vides Casanova, told reporters that the air force had about 25 napalm bombs, but he added, ''As far as I know, they have never been used, and the planes do not even have the equipment to fire or drop them.''

title: Commodore Corp. Fills Chief Operating Post
description: Completing a shake-up that began in July, the Commodore Corporation, a manufacturer of mobile homes, has promoted Paul M. Principe to the position of chief operating officer.

title: An Alliance Uncovered
description: Sometimes legislation succeeds

title: A RENAISSANCE MAN'S APPROACH TO 'FACTS OF LIFE'
description: Jonathan Miller, the physician, actor, author, lecturer and director of plays, operas and television, has turned his interest to the birds and the bees. For the moment, anyway.

title: TRANSCRIPT OF LOUISVILLE DEBATE BETWEEN REAGAN AND MONDALE
description: Participants in the Debate

title: Arizona Inmate Killed In Brawl After a Game
description: One Arizona State Prison inmate was killed and seven others were injured Saturday in a fight that erupted after white and black inmates opposed each other in a football game, officials said.

title: Volvo Studying U.S. Stock Plan STOCKHOLM, Oct. 7 (Reuters) - The timing of a long-
description: planned issue in the United

title: ROCK: THE BLASTERS REVIVE 50'S-STYLE ROADHOUSE ROCK
description: -style roadhouse rock out of its time capsule as it deserves to be revived in the 1980's - with spirit, respect and only a hint of self- consciousness.

title: St. Martin Posts 4th 'Arc' Triumph
description: Yves St. Martin, France's top jockey, won the Prix de l'Arc de Triomphe for the fourth time today when he rode Sagace to victory by two lengths over favored Northern Trick, a 3-year-old filly ridden by Cash Asmussen of the United States.

title: MONDAY SPORTS
description: Football Giants vs. San Francisco 49ers , at Giants Stadium, 9 P.M. The 49ers, one of only two undefeated teams in the National Football League, have not allowed a touchdown in five quarters.

title: STALEMATES WILL SURVIVE THE ELECTION
description: Reagan Administration officials and other foreign policy specialists now see a long stalemate ahead in international diplomacy, whoever wins the Presidential election.

title: TIGERS GIVE CREDIT TO PITCHING COACH
description: In one corner of the Tigers' shabby clubhouse on Friday night, removed from the general merrymaking, the pitchers and their coach, Roger Craig, shared a more private celebration.

title: READY CONSERVATORS
description: To the Editor:

title: Carol Jacobson, Nurse, Weds Dr. Steven Wiss Weds
description: Carol Ann Jacobson, a nurse practitioner at the Gouverneur Diagnostic and Treatment Center, and Dr. Steven Weiss, a senior resident at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center, were married yesterday at the Pierre Hotel.

title: BRIDGE: A Bidding Rule Holds True, Even in a Bizarre Situation
description: A well-known bidding principle, to which there are many exceptions, indicates the desirability of choosing a trump suit equally divided between declarer and dummy. In particular, four-four is often better than five- three.

title: Andean Folk Trio Adds a Flute Player
description: After ten years as a trio, the Andean folk group Tahuantinsuyo has added a fourth member, Juan Lazaro Mendolas. He made a striking entrance during the group's performance Saturday at the Alternative Museum, playing eerie, overblown high notes on a Bolivian flute made from a bent tree branch.

title: DANCE: BALLET HISPANICO IN MONTERO'S 'ESPANA'
description: THE mood was festive at the Joyce Theater on Saturday afternoon when Ballet Hispanico performed Luis Montero's new ''Espana,'' a work that shows the young company at its most charming and vibrant. Set to lilting music by Emmanuel Chabrier, ''Espana'' is a bit of Spanish Bournonville, distinguished by light- hearted flirtations and fast-flying feet.

title: CLASH ON DEFICIT, SOCIAL ISSUES
description: President Reagan and Walter F. Mondale engaged in blunt, sometimes highly personal exchanges as they clashed on economic and social issues tonight in their first debate of the 1984 Presidential campaign.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Oct. 8, 1984 GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: 2 Sergeants Are Charged With Selling Explosives
description: Two sergeants have been jailed on charges of selling a truckload of stolen Army explosives and ammunition to undercover agents posing as South American cocaine smugglers, Federal agents said today.

title: No Headline
description: 'Where's the Beef?' Wins Derby by Nose

title: BRAZIL CURBS COMPUTER COMPETITION
description: The Brazilian Congress has overwhelmingly approved a bill excluding foreign companies from participation in much of the country's fast-growing computer and data-processing industry.

title: ; Brown Forman Doing More In-House Buying
description: The Brown Forman Distillers Corporation, which has been doing its own out-of-home media buying, is going to extend its in-house buying activity to newspapers and magazines as well.

title: A TOP PRESCHOOL PROGRAM THAT MAY NOT LAST

title: POP: CARIBBEAN CARNIVAL MUSIC
description: -Tobago and Brazil,

title: NEW YORK CITY; ST. ANTHONY'S WINS
description: St. Anthony's remained unbeaten yesterday by defeating Holy Cross, 17-6, for its third victory of the season in the Catholic High Schools Football League. Sean McGlynn kicked three field goals, one of 47 yards on the last play of the first half.

title: WELFARE, FULL JAILS AND FISH
description: Gov. Dick Thornburgh has given new impetus to a controversy that is likely to keep his name fresh in the minds of voters for at least part of his last two years in the Governor's Mansion.

title: ; A Piano Recital By Abbey Simon
description: Abbey Simon played a program of very familiar piano music at the 92d Street Y Sunday afternoon. To all of it, he brought a strong technique used strictly for musical purposes, never for show.

title: NEW JERSEY; Seton Hall Prep Takes 3d Straight
description: Gil Knight ran for 120 yards on 12 carries and scored two touchdowns yesterday to lead Seton Hall Prep of South Orange to a 28-10 victory over Roxbury at the losers' field.

title: Debt Issues
description: Citicorp Overseas Finance N.V.'s 12-year floating rate note has been increased to $300 million from $250 million at a price of 99.80 through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

title: 2 Hit-and-Run Deaths
description: A 26-year-old man was charged early today with two counts of involuntary manslaughter and related offenses in the hit-and-run deaths of two teen-age boys in the city's Olney section, the police said. Kenneth Royals of Philadelphia turned himself in Saturday night after a couple in another car chased his vehicle and obtained a license number and a description of the driver, according to the authorities. They said the victims were run down in a crosswalk at about 9 P.M. Saturday.

title: 'Mayor' and the Debate Are on Peres's Intinerary
description: Shimon Peres, the new Prime

title: ;  Sports Illustrated
description: Mark Mulvoy, assistant managing editor of Sports Illustrated, has been promoted to managing editor by Henry A. Grunwald, editor in chief of Time Inc., replacing Gilbert Rogin, who Mr. Grunwald transferred to Discover as managing editor.

title: Actors Equity Contract Is Extended
description: The contract between Actors Equity and the League of Off Broadway Theaters and Producers has been extended for one week, and the negotiators have agreed that provisions in a new agreement will be retroactive to yesterday, when the contract expired.

title: Discoveries of America
description: In 1917, an American writer named Willard Price left Genoa in the steerage class of a White Star liner with 500 Italians who were emigrating to the United States. ''Italians are industrious, good- natured, very affectionate towards children, courteous and polite . . . generous and self-sacrificing,'' he wrote of his companions on the ship, adding that ''dense ignorance . . . sentences (them) to . . . the drudgery of unskilled labor.''

title: PRETORIA WILL USE ARMY TO END RIOTS
description: South African authorities say they will use the army to support the police in fighting a wave of unrest in recent weeks that has resulted in 80 deaths in a crackdown on dissent.

title: DEMOCRATIC ESTABLISHMENT'S BIG MISTAKE
description: To the Editor:

title: Treasury Plans a Heavy Schedule
description: Treasury financings will dominate the credit markets this week, assuming the Federal debt ceiling is increased. Last week, Treasury officials announced plans to hold the regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills, as well as sales of 7- and 20-year issues that were delayed from late September because of the debt ceiling.

title: PERES, MEETING WITH SHULTZ IN WASHINGTON, ASKS FOR AID INCREASE
description: Prime Minister Shimon Peres of Israel asked the United States for increased aid and other help for Israel's troubled economy today as he opened talks with Secretary of State George P. Shultz, Israeli and American officials said.

title: The Charismatic Norwegian
description: Jonathan Solomon, a stand-up comedian, was talking politics last summer and asked his Manhattan audience, ''What do you think when you hear 'Mondale'? Do you think

title: Blast Injures 2 Workers
description: Two workers were hospitalized today with serious burns from an electrical explosion and fire in a high-rise building in the Financial District here, officials said. The blast occurred at One Market Plaza at 8:37 P.M. Sunday, as the two men and a colleague were doing electrical work in the basement. The cause of the explosion at the 28- story building was under investigation.

title: REAGAN, MONDALE AND THE ECONOMY
description: During Sunday's debate on the economy and domestic affairs, President Reagan played his strongest card by asking Americans whether they were better off than they were four years ago - a question he had used devastatingly in his campaign against President Carter. Whereas, four years ago, Mr. Reagan had suggested that the answer was no, today he thinks it is obviously yes.

description: T personal computer market

title: Herr Reagan's Foot
description: President Reagan, campaigning

title: CONFEREES AGREE TO RESTRICT DISCLOSURE OF COMPUTER DATA
description: Proposed legislation would make it a crime for a Federal employee to disclose any kind of information drawn from a Government computer without official approval.

title: Crowd at TV Debate Sunday Was Partisan and Expressive
description: Unlike some previous Presidential debates, the encounter Sunday between President Reagan and Walter F. Mondale was marked by repeated bursts of partisan applause.

title: 'THE PLAY'S THE THING WHEREIN I'LL CATCH THE CONSCIENCE OF THE KING'
description: One of the most common digs used by Ronald Reagan's opponents is to say that the President is merely an actor. The polls indicate, nevertheless, that the American people persist in believing him. Why? To find the answer, we have to understand what kind of actor he was - and is.

title: THEATER: 'RED HOUSE'
description: AS author and director, John Jesurun begins ''Red House'' by issuing a warning. One character says: ''We're not here. We're not anywhere.'' Theatergoers at La Mama may share that sense of dislocation. The scene is a limbo-land stretch of Mr. Jesurun's hyperactive imagination. Mirroring the playwright's split- screen approach, the play is alternately enticing and irritating.

title: TheViewFromInformation
description: Someone who dialed telephone information yesterday also got some volunteer television criticism.

title: THE SUAVE, SOPHISTICATED AND ILLITERATE CAPITAL
description: When Michael Fox looks down 18th Street from the steps of the old town house that serves as the headquaters of Push Literacy Action Now, a privately financed group that teaches adults to read, he can easily see the Washington Monument.

title: Advertising; Whisky, Sweaters Team Up
description: WHAT'S in a name? In the case of Ballantine, plenty, no matter how you spell it.

title: EASTERN AIR LINES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: Hart Says Extremists Set Reagan's Policies
description: Senator Gary Hart, Democrat of Colorado, charged today that ''narrow- minded extremists'' set President Reagan's policies and called Walter F. Mondale, the Democratic Presidential candidate, a true leader.

title: CUBS PONDER WINTER
description: Suitcase in hand, Jody Davis, the Chicago Cubs catcher, entered the clubhouse in Wrigley Field today and shook his head. ''I just never expected this to happen,'' he said. ''It really never occurred to me that our season was going to end.''

title: G.M. Contract Gains in Voting
description: Voting by rank-and-file union members turned narrowly in favor of the tentative contract between the General Motors Corporation and the United Automobile Workers contract today.

title: TUESDAY SPORTS Baseball
description: Padres vs. Detroit Tigers, World Series, first game, at San Diego.

title: French Troops Leaving Chad
description: The first group from the 3,200 French troops stationed in Chad flew home today and Foreign Minister Claude Cheysson said he had the impression Libya was also pulling out, as provided for in a Libyan- French agreement. Mr. Cheysson said, however, that observers had not yet been able to monitor the movements of the Libyan troops, believed to number 5,000, who are in the landlocked African country. France and Libya agreed last month on a joint withdrawal from Chad, where Libyan-backed rebels have been in conflict with the Government of President Hissen Habre.

title: Dr. Joseph T. Wearn, 91, Dies; Former Medical School Dean
description: Joseph Treloar Wearn, former dean of the Case Western Reserve University School of Medicine, died at his summer home in Brooklin, Me., on Sept. 26. Dr. Wearn, who was a resident of Yemassee, S.C., was 91 years old.

title: INDIANS SEARCH FOR REMAINS OF LEAER
description: At the request of an Indian religious leader, Gov. John H. Sununu is asking the French authorities to find the remains of a 17th- century Indian chief sent to a Paris museum in the 1820's and return them to New Hampshire.

title: POLICE BRUTALITY CASE: ANOTHER TRY BY PROSECUTORS
description: One of the most complex and disturbing police-brutality cases in New York City's history is scheduled to go before a new grand jury sometime this week.

title: DRESS BARN reports earnings for Qtr to July 28
BUSINESS PEOPLE ; L. F. Rothschild Names Executive
description: Francois J. P. Mayer has been named a senior managing director and chief administrative officer at L. F. Rothschild, Unterberg, Towbin, the Wall Street firm said yesterday.

title: Article 257473 -- No Title
description: One lucky bettor, a Bronx resident who did not wish to be

title: OPERA: 'TRAVIATA' ROLES
description: ALL three major roles in the New York City Opera's ''Traviata'' changed hands Sunday night. Catherine Lamy sang Violetta. Richard Leech was Alfredo.

title: Harvester-Renault
description: The International Harvester Company announced an agreement with Regie Nationale des Usines Renault, the French manufacturer, for the joint development of agricultural tractor components in Europe.

title: EAST IS MEETING WEST IN MOVIE COLLABORATIONS
description: The Soviet-bloc nations and the West are discovering that their mostly icy relationships are thawing in at least one spot - the movies.

title: COMPROMISE IN CHICAGO MAY BE A TURNING POINT
description: In reaching an accord with City Council leaders last week, Harold Washington seemed to have come to a turning point in his 18 months as Mayor.

CAMPAIGNING SETS TONE FOR COLUMBUS DAY PARADE
description: New York City's Columbus Day Parade became a vigorous political rally yesterday as Vice President Bush and the Democratic candidates, Walter F. Mondale and Geraldine A. Ferraro, marched before a crowd of hundreds of thousands of people dominated by campaign banners, placards and posters.

title: British Telecom
description: The British Government is still considering plans by British Telecom and the International Business Machines Corporation to form a jointly owned British electronic information network, an Industry Department spokesman said, but it might take several more weeks for a decision to be reached. The project has been heavily criticized by British electronics manufacturers and software companies. The project would offer an array of network services to the banking, retailing and insurance sectors, such as computerized ordering and payments, through a company equally owned by the two companies, a British Telecom spokesman said.

description: If it's true that Earl Weaver will return to managing

title: Rizzoli Group Taken Over
description: A consortium completed the takeover of the financially troubled Rizzoli publishing group, ending two years of court-appointed management, the company's chairman said today.

title: Code-A-Phone
description: The Code-A-Phone Corporation, a manufacturer and marketer of telecommunications products, said it would stop producing such equipment Dec. 31 because of overseas competition.

title: RADIO SHACK KEEPS HOBBYIST ROOTS
description: -based Tandy Corporation, has garnered a large chunk of the personal computer trade. Initially, in fact, it was an industry leader, its original TRS-80 preceding the first Apple computer.

title: Couple Still Refusing To Testify Against Son
description: A state judge refused today to free a couple who have been in jail for almost a month because they vowed not to answer a grand jury's questions about their teen-age son, who is accused of murdering a female letter carrier.

title: BRIDGE: LEGACY OF VON ZEDTWITZ: HIS CONTRIBUTIONS TO GAME
description: In the wide world of bridge Waldemar Von Zedtwitz, who died in Hawaii last week at the age of 88, will be remembered for many contributions to the game: as the favorite partner of Harold Vanderbilt; as a participant in the Culbertson-Lenz match and the earliest international matches; as a winner of 19 national titles, and, at the advanced age of 74, a world title.

title: THE SIN THAT IS A CLASS B MISDEMEANOR
description: To the Editor:

title: ;  Jerseyan's Boxing Cure
description: The multimillion-dollar boxing industry in New Jersey has outgrown the state's ability to regulate it, and reforms are needed to protect the safety of fighters and the integrity of the sport, according to Assemblyman Buddy Fortunato , Democrat of Essex County, who has proposed corrective legislation. ''Boxers are being sent into the ring who shouldn't be there,'' he said.
