description: Day holiday, banks and most

title: CHANCE OF REVIVAL SEEN FOR MONDALE AFTER TV DEBATE
description: Political analysts and poll takers on both sides asserted today that Walter F. Mondale's performance in the debate Sunday night had created a chance for him to revive his campaign against President Reagan.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE;
description: Citizen Moyers

title: U.S. JURY CONVICTS 2D CHICAGO JUDGE
description: A former Cook County judge was found guilty today of accepting bribes and steering cases to dishonest lawyers. He became the second judge convicted in the investigation of corruption in the nation's largest court system.

title: Steel Output Up 5.1%
description: Steel production rose to 1.43 million tons in the week ended last Saturday, an increase of 5.1 percent from 1.36 million tons in the previous week, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

title: FIRST INTERSTATE BANK OF ALASKA reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Jurors Find Age Bias at Pabst
description: A Federal jury has ruled that the Pabst Brewing Company willfully committed age discrimination when it dismissed two managers in 1981.

title: 2 Who Left Paramount Will Run Y.& R. Unit
description: Two top film marketing executives who resigned from Paramount Pictures last June under disputed circumstances were named yesterday by Young & Rubicam USA to run a new entertainment unit.

title: SHOWINGS OPEN IN MILAN: FEMININITY IS A KEYNOTE
description: As the first wave of spring openings crashed on the shores of fashion over the weekend, audiences contemplated with alarm the possible return of the miniskirt. As the showings progressed, however, it seemed that there was nothing to fear. Yes, there are short skirts, baring a few inches of skin above the knee, but there are also some long ones and plenty of pants, including shorts, that look the newest.

title: Reward for a Pink Piglet
description: A three-foot-high, pink wooden piglet has

title: SCI-MED LIFE SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net income. c-Including a tax credit of $59,000.

title: NON-BANK UNIT INSURANCE PROPOSAL IS CRITICIZED
description: The Oklahoma Banking Commissioner today criticized a proposal to require up to $100,000 of insurance on deposits in nonbank financial institutions.

title: Strong, Peaceful Ads
description: An umbrella group of arms control organizations that calls itself Committee for a Strong Peaceful America plans to spend $250,000 to put its message out around the country on radio and television in the two weeks leading up to the Reagan-Mondale foreign policy debate on Oct. 21.

title: Promotion At Exchange
description: Joseph J. O'Neill, executive vice president and chief operating officer of the New York Cotton Exchange, was named president of the 114-year- old exchange. The job had been vacant since September 1982, when J. William Donaghy retired.

title: VOTES OF CONFIDENCE FOR A DIOXIN STUDY
description: To the Editor:

title: DEBATE: A BOLDER MONDALE AND AN INCUMBENT ON THE DEFENSIVE
description: In their first Presidential debate Sunday night, President Reagan and Walter F. Mondale seemed to trade roles in the way they handled the central issues of the 1984 campaign. Throughout Mr. Reagan's political career, one of his trademarks has been his ability to deliver an overarching message about American values, patriotism and his vision of the future. But in Louisville, as even Reagan strategists tacitly conceded, it was Mr. Mondale who set out broader political themes about the American future, the nation's sense of decency and fairness and the essential ingredients of Presidential leadership.

title: WD-40 CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Israelis Turn In Weapons
description: Israeli citizens have turned in hundreds of weapons, including explosives, machine guns and a heavy mortar during the first week of an amnesty program, the military command said today. The program is intended to recover $250 million in missing arms and equipment, taken for the most part by soldiers on reserve duty.

title: GIANTS NO HURDLE TO 49ERS' NEHEMIAH
description: The play that set the tone for the Giants' game tonight against San Francisco came early. It was a pass thrown by Joe Montana and caught by Renaldo (Skeets) Nehemiah, who then flew down the sideline with no Giant near him to complete a 59-yard touchdown play.

title: WESTWAY'S SLEAZE FACTOR
description: It is an American tradition to scream and inveigh at scandal, but what with having to keep up with each week's new, improved outrage, we suffer from arrested attention spans. So it can be instructive, from time to time, to return to old but unresolved scandals and retrace the many steps of the enormity.

title: No Decision on Umpires SAN DIEGO, Oct. 8 (AP) - Commissioner Peter Ueberroth will
description: need another day to complete binding arbitration of a dispute between

title: GOOD IMMIGRANT BILL
description: In a minor miracle, a conference committee has reached a tentative compromise on the Senate and House versions of the Simpson-Mazzoli immigration bill. Months of bitter debate have produced a sound bill that deserves final approval. Even so, we are likely to hear again that the measure is racist and anti-family, that its legalization provision will open the immigration floodgates, that its employer- sanction measure will be ineffective and discriminatory.

title: IC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $200,000 for the quarter and $400,000 for the 9 months. c-Including income of $400,000 for the 9 months from discontinued operations and losses from the disposition of discontinued operations of $2.0 million for the quarter and $2.1 million for the 9 months.

title: World Court Postpones Decision on Nicaragua
description: The World Court today postponed a decision on a Nicaraguan complaint that the United States is making ''armed attacks'' against the country.

title: ANTIDOTE FOR SPIDER VENOM
description: THE first antidote for the poisonous venom of the brown recluse spider, the tiny arachnid deadlier than a rattlesnake or black widow spider, has been developed at Vanderbilt University Medical Center in Nashville, the center has disclosed.

title: POISONED CANDY FOUND ON JAPANESE STORE SHELVES
description: Packs of cyanide- treated candy and cookies were found today on shelves of supermarkets in central Japan, placed there by someone identifying himself as ''the mystery man with 21 faces.''

title: CORRECTION
description: The Dining Out Guide in Weekend on Friday, Sept. 28, gave an incorrect address for the Parioli Romanissimo restaurant. It is at 24 East 81st Street.

title: QUEEM PLAYING MATCHMAKER FOR HER MARES DURING VISIT
description: As Queen Elizabeth II tours this area's famed horse breeding farms on her six- day private visit that began Sunday, she will not just be fulfilling a longstanding desire to see the world's most famous thoroughbred stallions and nurseries.

title: SALVADOR OFFICER SAID TO HAVE TOLD OF NAPALM USE
description: The commander of El Salvador's air force told visiting members of the United States Congress last year that napalm incendiary weapons had been used against guerrilla forces, a member of the delegation said today.

title: 3 Bombs Go Off in Sri Lanka
description: Guerrillas set off three bombs in Colombo today, slightly damaging oil pipelines. A National Security Ministry statement said the police disarmed another explosive device before it went off. The ministry said the bombs were intended to blow up pipelines leading from Colombo's port.

title: A YARDSTICK FOR THE UNIVERSE?
description: IN an effort to learn, at last, the

title: CHRIS-CRAFT INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $17,363,000 for the quarter and $16,933,000 for the year. c-Net income including a gain of $736,000 for the quarter and a loss of $2,080,000 for the year from discontinued operations.

title: Citrus Canker Confirmed At 7th Florida Nursery
description: State inspectors today began surveying stock at the seventh plant nursery where citrus canker has been confirmed, but the burning of its trees probably will not begin until next week, the officials said.

title: Girl Dies as Treatment Is Rejected by Mother
description: A 16-year-old girl whose medical care was the object of a custody battle resulting from the refusal of her mother, a Jehovah's Witness, to allow blood transfusions, has died despite treatment ordered by a court.

title: Europe Ship Orders Up
description: New orders booked by Western European shipbuilders in the first half of this year surged to 1.3 million tons, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development said today. The total for all of 1983 was 1.9 million tons.

title: Conscientious Objectors
description: Virtually every constituency in the country has at least a few members of Congress as its champions. For conscientious objectors opposed to military spending, there is Senator Mark O. Hatfield, an Oregon Republican.

title: TRANSIT POLICE GET DIRECTIVE FROM WARD
description: Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward announced new police communications procedures yesterday that direct the transit police to notify the city police immediately whenever a transit officer loses contact with a partner or is involved in police action outside the transit system.

title: WORLD'S STEELMAKERS WARILY BACK U.S. LIMIT
description: Officials at the world steel industry's annual convention, which opened here today, gave guarded approval to President Reagan's program to limit steel imports.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Ametek Inc. , Grand Pairie, Tex., has agreed to purchase the Acme heat exchanger product line from the Gulf and Western Manufacturing Co., a subsidiary of Gulf and Western Industries based in Southfield, Mich., for an undisclosed amount of cash. Heat exchangers, which function much like an automobile's radiator, are used in a variety of industrial applications.

title: A LOOK AT THE DEBATE BETWEEN REAGAN AND MONDALE
description: A TELEVISION debate is a performance, with the style of the presentation as important as the substance of the argument. What Ronald Reagan and Walter F. Mondale said on Sunday night was one thing; how they said it was another. The winner of the debate was the man who, joining style and substance, made the fewest mistakes.

title: COSMIC RAYS TEMPORARILY DISRUPT SPACE SHUTTLE'S COMMUNICATIONS
description: The Challenger astronauts lost much of their communications temporarily today when cosmic radiation disabled a relay satellite.

title: Falwell Says Religion Has a Place in Politics
description: The Rev. Jerry Falwell, head of Moral Majority, said today that religion had a proper place in politics but that it was too much an issue in the Presidential debate.

title: FASTBALLS TO DOUGHNUTS
description: LAKE ORION, Mich.

title: EARNINGS ; Chris-Craft Industries in Loss
description: Chris-Craft Industries, hurt by its investment in Warner Communications, reported yesterday that it had a loss of $17.9 million in the fourth fiscal quarter of 1984.

title: Registration to Vote Entering Final Phase
description: New York City polling places will be open today and Saturday from 9 A.M. to 9 P.M. for the final registration of those who want to be eligible to vote in next month's Presidential election.

title: Accounts
description: * Bide-A-Wee Pet Adoption Homes to Drossman Lehmann Marino Reveley.

title: WESTMORELAND SUIT AGAINST CBS BEGINS TODAY WITH JURY SELECTION
description: On May 18, 1981 two days after Mike Wallace interviewed Gen. William C. Westmoreland for the CBS documentary ''The Uncounted Enemy: A Vietnam Deception'' - the producer of the program wrote Mr. Wallace a note of praise.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Bank of Los Angeles announced that Tom Tarter was resigning as president and chief executive officer.

title: EAST GERMAN CLERICS: DEFENDERS OF MARXIST FAITH
description: Not long ago, when Billy Graham brought his evangelical crusade to this tranquil medieval city on the frontier with Poland, Bishop Hanns-Joachim Wollstadt reached deep into the past for a parable about the situation of German Christians living under Communism.

title: Bad Odor in New Jersey
description: Like all liquids, the insecticide called malathion expands when heated. At an American Cyanamid plant in Linden, N.J., last Saturday, overheated malathion expanded so much that it broke open its steel container and released a foul-smelling yellow cloud that sickened people in two states.

title: Philips Lab
description: Philips N.V. said it had invested $50 million in a microelectronic research laboratory in California's Silicon Valley.

title: 5 Are Said to Leave Cabinet in the Bahamas
description: Three Cabinet ministers of Prime Minister Lynden O. Pindling's Government resigned Monday and two others reportedly were dismissed.

title: ABOUT PHILADELPHIA
description: One day last month, none of the diners at the Bellevue Stratford Hotel attacked their food the way Boies Penrose would in the days when the old hotel was young, but the temptation was obvious.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: FROST. A Literary Life Reconsidered. By William H. Pritchard. 286 pages. Illustrated. Oxford University Press. $15.95.

title: INVITATION TO FARRAKHAN CAUSES RIFT AT WESLEYAN
description: A student group's invitation to Louis Farrakhan to speak at Wesleyan University has sparked an angry dispute over freedom of speech that has split the campus.

title: MORE THAN A 'MOLEHILL' IN IMMIGRATION REFORM
description: To the Editor:

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A picture caption on the Music page in Sunday's Arts and Leisure section misstated the day of Myung-Whun Chung's conducting debut with the New York Philharmonic. It will take place tomorrow.

title: West German Growth
description: West Germany has regained the economic momentum of this year's first quarter, when its real gross national product was up 3.9 percent from a year earlier, Finance Minister Gerhard Stoltenberg said today. He told a businessmen's meeting that the momentum was interrupted by labor disputes in May and June, which shut down the auto industry.

title: OBJECTS OF NORTHWEST COAST INDIANS ON DISPLAY
description: IT is certainly not a modern healer's kit: It contains a hat ringed

title: CATALOGUE WORLD'S ONE-MAN SHOW
description: ROGER HORCHOW may be the first resident Texan to consciously eschew the possibility of becoming a billionaire. The lanky, laid-back catalogue king has decided that $80 million in gross sales is plenty. ''I don't want to get too big,'' the Ohio-born maverick drawled. ''If we did, we'd explode out of our warehouse.''

title: THOMAS W. PIERCE
description: Thomas W. Pierce, who was active in Nassau County Republican politics for nearly 40 years, died of cancer Sunday at St. Francis Hospital in Roslyn, L.I. He was 61 years old and lived in Manhasset, L.I.

title: POPULAR BANCSHARES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income.

title: SPIRITED MONDALE MARCHES TO NEW BEAT
description: An exuberant Walter F. Mondale came to New York City yesterday and proclaimed, ''Today we have a brand new race, today everything is different.''

title: BRAZIL WELCOMES JIMMY CARTER ON LATIN TOUR
description: Former President Jimmy Carter, on a tour of Latin America, has been received warmly by civilian politicians who credit him with having reduced human rights violations and hastened the end of some military dictatorships.

title: 3 People Are Beaten to Death In Their Home in Los Angeles
description: Three elderly people, including a retired telephone company executive who had been an Urban League officer, were found beaten to death in their home early today.

title: Sumitomo Trust
description: The Sumitomo Trust and Banking Corporation said it had signed an agreement with the Security Pacific Corporation of Los Angeles for a venture to offer mutual fund managment advisory services in both countries.

title: White Plains Wins White Plains, a longtime power, became the early favorite for the Conference A-III championship yesterday by traveling to Mahopac and beating the previously undefeated Indians, 15-0.
description: The game was the conference opener for both teams. The Tigers are 2-0-1, Mahopac 3-1.

title: SALMON RUN BEGINS, AND THE FISHERMEN RACE TO CATCH THEM
description: Dawn's first glow had yet to break over Salina Street here, but groups of men in plaid woolen shirts and down vests were already crowding into the Salmon River Sport Shop.

title: China Plans Major
description: China has decided to link production and possibly prices of a wide range of goods to market demand in a major capitalistic reform that will partially dismantle its system of centralized planning, reports said today.

title: AUSTRALIAN LABORITE PREMIER CALLS EARLY ELECTION ON DEC. 1
description: Prime Minister Bob Hawke told Parliament today that he was calling a general election for Dec. 1, halfway through his three-year term.

title: 5 Faculty Groups Back Yale Strikers
description: Faculty members from five universities in Connecticut expressed support today for 1,800 clerical and technical employees who have been on strike for nearly two weeks against Yale University.

title: Key Rates
description: * split rate, 12.50-12.75N.A. Not available because of the Columbus Day holiday ** Kenny Index, Kenny Information Systems Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Man Dies and 5 Are Injured At Hotel Without Detectors
description: One man was killed and five people were in critical condition today after a fire swept through a hotel that did not have smoke detectors as required, officials said.

title: WHITE HOUSE AIDES MINIMIZE RESULTS
description: President Reagan resumed campaign roadwork today as his aides indulged in the prize- fight metaphor of a champion stung by jabs but hardly knocked out in the television debate with Walter F. Mondale.

title: ;  Bruin Lost for Season
description: Gord Kluzak, the talented Boston Bruin defenseman, underwent surgery on his injured left knee yesterday, and afterward the team said he would miss the entire season. The injury occurred Sunday night in the first period of a game against the Devils at Portland, Me., the Bruins' final exhibition of the autumn. Kluzak took a check that was routine, and tumbled over on the knee, tearing ligaments and requiring a major reconstruction of the joint.

title: INDIAN LEADER GETS JAIL SENTENCE
description: Dennis Banks, the Indian activist, was sentenced today to three years in prison for his role in a 1973 riot at the Custer County courthouse.

title: AIDS STUDIES HINT SALIVA MAY TRANSMIT INFECTION
description: NEW scientific evidence has raised the possibility that acquired immune deficiency syndrome, or AIDS, may be transmissible through saliva.

title: Reagan Wins Backing Of The Seattle Times
description: The Seattle Times has endorsed President Reagan's re-election, saying he has provided ''that scarcely definable, but readily identifiable, quality of leadership.''

title: Call From Reagan Caps Payton's Day
description: After Walter Payton broke Jim Brown's career rushing record Sunday, Payton was escorted into a tent large enough so that the dozens of reporters covering the historic moment at Chicago could ask questions without the pushing and shoving that might have occurred in the locker room.

title: Black History Museum Is Planned for Atlanta
description: A $17.7 million museum dedicated to black American history will be built in the Martin Luther King Jr.

title: MOSCOW'S UNLIKELY FAVORITE CANDIDATE
description: To the Editor:

title: INTERCO INCORPORATED reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
BUSH'S WIFE ASSAILS FERRARO, BUT APOLOGIZES
description: In a gibe at Geraldine A. Ferraro, Barbara Bush said today that she and her husband, the Vice President, had no intention of obscuring the fact that they are wealthy and enjoy it, ''not like that four million-dollar - I can't say it, but it rhymes with rich.''

title: ADVERTISING ; Publisher Leaves Hearst Thomas P. Losee Jr., one-
description: time publisher of Hearst's

title: First City Net Forecast
description: The First City Bancorporation of Texas said it expects to report third-quarter net income of $15.9 million, or 33 cents a share, after a substantial increase in the provision for loan losses.

title: Hearst Papers
description: The Hearst Corporation said it had agreed to buy three newspapers from the Jefferson-Pilot Corporation.

title: DUARTE PROPOSES REBELS MEET HIM FOR PEACE TALKS
description: President Jose Napoleon Duarte of El Salvador offered today to hold peace talks with guerrilla leaders starting next Monday.

title: No Headline
description: Yoko Ono to Broadcast On Lennon's Birthday

title: MONTANA, 49ERS RIDDLE GIANTS
description: The terrible 33-12 beating the Giants took from the Los Angeles Rams a week ago was only an appetizer. The main course came tonight, and it was even more distastful for Giants' loyalists, a 31-10 mauling from the San Francisco 49ers.

title: A World Gone By
description: A huge tree towers over a weathered wood house and, along a dirt path in the foreground, a woman with a basket over her right arm leads a little boy wearing a straw hat. The fields are a friendly green, the sky an unsullied blue.

title: PEOPLES BANCORP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
E-Systems Seeks Software Venture
description: E-Systems Inc. said it and 10 other companies had agreed to study the establishment of a joint venture to solve software productivity problems and to halt the rising cost of software developed for the Department of Defense.

title: A Take over of Lilco In Suffolk Is Proposed
description: Ten members of the Suffolk County Legislature plan to move for a county takeover of the operations of the Long Island Lighting Company within Suffolk, according to Wayne Prospect, one of the legislators.

title: Truck Sales Rise 12.9%
description: The Motor Vehicle Manufacturers Association said sales of trucks in the United States in September increased 12.9 percent, to 271,953, from 240,773 last year. For the year to date, the trade organization said truck sales had risen 35.2 percent, to 2,660,824, compared with 1,968,695 vehicles in the period a year earlier.

title: 10TH CHESS GAME IS DRAWN
description: Anatoly Karpov, the world chess champion, agreed today to a draw offer by Gary Kasparov, the challenger, in the 10th game of their title match.

title: Greece Bans Airliners From Northern Aegean
description: The Foreign Ministry today banned commercial air traffic over the northern Aegean Sea for 36 hours, saying that a Turkish jet fighter taking part in NATO exercises flew into the area and could have caused an accident.

title: SCOUTING;
description: Tigers' Tension

title: No Headline
description: TUESDAY, OCTOBER 9, 1984 International Jose Napoleon Duarte offered to hold peace talks with Salvadoran guerrilla leaders, starting next Monday. President Duarte, who made the proposal at the end of a 55-minute address to the United Nations, said he was ready to begin the negotiations in La Palma, a Salvadoran town near the Honduran border. (Page A1, Col. 2.) Senior Salvadoran rebel officials in Mexico City said they were ''open and attentive'' to the prospect of a meeting with President Jose Napoleon Duarte, provided he formally invited them to El Salvador. (A10:1.)

title: SCOUTING;
description: ABC Jumps Gun On Dixon Entry

title: BRITISH ASK AFRICANS TO QUOT MISSION
description: Britain today told three South African dissidents who have taken shelter in the British Consulate in Durban that it wanted them to leave but repeated that it would not force them to go.

title: ;  Billy Johnson Out
description: Billy (White Shoes) Johnson , who in his long pro career has made a habit of turning runbacks into spectacles, may be lost for the season. Johnson, who is just 54 yards short of Rick Upchurch 's National Football League record for punt-return yardage, tore a ligament in his right knee during the Atlanta Falcons' victory over the Los Angeles Rams on Sunday. . . . Tony Hill, the Dallas Cowboys' best wide receiver, has been cleared to participate in full-contact workouts, an indication that he may be reactivated in time for the meeting with the Redskins at Washington Sunday. He separated a shoulder in Dallas's opening game of the season and had been on the injured-reserve list.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Without arms and in the presence of the world press, representatives of the church and the population of La Palma, at 10 A.M. on Oct. 15, the anniversary of the insurrection of 1979, I invite the heads of the guerrilla movement who are now in the mountains to discuss the scope and details of a proposal for their incorporation in the process of democracy in the atmosphere of freedom with the hope that we may have another popular election.'' - President Jose Napoleon Duarte of El Salvador. (A10:1.)

title: Warner Says Opponent Wouldn't Help Virginia
description: Senator John W. Warner, Republican of Virginia, contends that his Democratic challenger, Edythe Harrison, lacks the experience and the seniority to help Virginia in the United States Senate.

title: TII COMPUTER SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to June 29
Republicans Are Doing Better On PAC Funds, Study Says
description: Republican candidates for Congress on average are faring twice as well as Democrats in raising campaign funds from oil and gas political action committees, according to a study released today.

title: EASTERN AIR IS BACK IN THE BLACK
description: Eastern Airlines yesterday announced its first quarterly profit in almost two years. The airline, the nation's first to report its results for the third quarter, earned $3.6 million in the period, in contrast to a loss of $34.4 million a year earlier.

title: Thai Captures Flyweight Title
description: Sot Chitalada of Thailand captured the World Boxing Council's flyweight title tonight with a 12-round split decision over the defending champion, Gabriel Bernal of Mexico.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Oct. 9, 1984 SECURITY COUNCIL

title: Grenada Politician Asks U.S. To Keep Troops on the Island
description: A leading Grenadian politician has called for United States and Caribbean troops to remain on the island for several years if necessary to guarantee its security.

title: East Islip Triumphs Mike Sonkin threw two touchdown passes and Tony Senst scored twice in helping East Islip to defeat Smithtown West yesterday, 53-0. Both East Islip and Smithtown West are now 2-1 in League III.
description: The Redmen dominated early in the game. Two minutes into the first quarter, Steve Morea intercepted a Smithtown West pass at midfield.

title: ; World Series For Fan Diego
description: SAN DIEGO Steve Garvey was walking along

title: ;  Bid for Collinsworth According to their assistant general manager,
description: Mike Brown, the Cincinnati Bengals are interested in negotiating with the Tampa Bay Bandits of the rival United States Football League in an effort to retain the star wide receiver Cris Collinsworth after this season. But John Bassett, the Bandit owner, says the Bengals have little chance of keeping Collinsworth, who has signed a five-year, $3 million contract with Tampa Bay that takes effect next spring.

title: 5 FEARED DEAD IN PLANE CRASH
description: A private jet crashed on takeoff at San Francisco International Airport tonight, leaving up to five persons feared dead, the Federal Aviation Administration said.

title: IF THIS IS GRIDLOCK, WHERE'S THE TRAFFIC COP?
description: Democracy was never intended to be the most efficient form of government, but recent events on Capitol Hill have given chaos a bad name.

title: DARING 'BOAT PEOPLE' RESCUE BRINGS HONOR TO 3 AMERICANS
description: Chua Quach was not present at an awards ceremony here today at which three American seamen were honored by Poul Hartling of Denmark, the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees.

title: HOW CANDIDATES ERRED IN THE DEBATE
description: Midway through the debate Sunday night, Walter F. Mondale charged that ''right after the election'' President Reagan ''went out and tried to cut $20 billion out of Medicare.''

title: MAXICARE HEALTH PLANS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Menudo Makes an Exit
description: While orderly crowds gathered

title: DIFFERENT ROUTES TO 81ST SERIES
description: The Detroit Tigers and the San Diego Padres got their first look at each other today as they prepared for the 81st World Series, which opens here Tuesday evening with Jack Morris pitching for the American League champions and Mark Thurmond for the National League champions.

title: TANEN TO HEAD PARAMOUNT FILM UNIT
description: Ned Tanen - the former president of Universal Pictures who had vowed never to take another job as a studio executive - was appointed today as president of the Motion Picture Group of Paramount Pictures.

title: MOHAWK DATA HEAD RESIGNS
description: The Mohawk Data Sciences Corporation, which lost $52.9 million in the last fiscal year, announced yesterday that Ralph H. O'Brien had resigned as chairman, chief executive and president.

title: African Ends Cuban Visit
description: President Thomas Sankara arrived here from Cuba on Sunday after a stop in Havana on the way home from the United National General Assembly in New York. He met with Fidel Castro and brought back with him several Cuban experts in mining and prefabricated housing construction.

title: 4 YEARS LATER: WHO IN U.S. IS BETTER OFF?
description: In his debate with Walter F. Mondale on Sunday, President Reagan asked anew the question that served him well against President Carter - whether the country was economically better off than four years earlier.

title: INSURGENTS WANT FORMAL INVITATION
description: Salvadoran insurgent leaders said here today that they had been ''completely surprised'' by President Jose Napoleon Duarte's offer to meet with them. They said they were ''open and attentive'' to the prospect of a meeting if Mr. Duarte formally invited them to El Salvador.

title: JET DEFENDERS BATTLED ERRORS
description: It was their first play in their first start as Jets, and both Ron Faurot and Kyle Clifton muffed it.

title: REFINEMET INTERNATIONAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
HONDURAS SEEKS LOOSER ALLIANCE AND RISE IN AID
description: The Foreign Minister of Honduras said yesterday that his Government was seeking to redefine its relationship with the United States to de-emphasize military ties and was not satisfied with the Reagan Administration's reaction.

title: BANCO DE PONCE reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including an extraordinary credit of $2,488,459.

title: TWO GERMANYS DISCUSS PRAGUE REFUGEES
description: West Germany and East Germany held more talks today on what to do about dozens of East German refugees who have crowded into the West German Embassy here, but a spokesman for the Bonn Government said the situation remained unchanged.

title: CUSTOM HOUSE OF FRAME
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: TUESDAY, OCTOBER 9, 1984

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: As long as you avoided the marathon runners in the streets over the weekend, walking around this city was like walking through a world of fashion ideas. The street, or rather, what people wear on it, is often an indicator of what is on the runways during this week's showings of the spring collections.

title: JAMES V. McCONNELL
description: James V. McConnell, a retired director of spot-advertising sales for NBC, died Sunday at Lenox Hill Hospital.

title: LEE D. WITKIN IS DEAD AT 49; DEVELOPED PHOTOGRAPHIC ART
description: Lee D. Witkin, who through his Witkin Gallery Inc. played a leading part in the rise of the photographic print as a collectible art object, died after a long illness at his home in Manhattan Friday. He was 49 years old.

title: ;  Comings and Goings
description: Charlotte Teske, the winner of the 1982 Boston Marathon, will compete in the New York City Marathon on Oct. 28. . . . Ed Reinhardt, the 19- year-old Colorado tight end who has been in a coma since he was injured in a game at Oregon three weeks ago, underwent a third operation in Eugene, this one to remove fluid from his lungs.

title: DOW JONES & CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
U.S. Company's Offices Bombed in Brussels
description: A Marxist group that says it is dedicated to attacking suppliers of NATO equipment carried out its third Brussels bombing in a week early today, damaging the offices of the United States- owned computer company Honeywell- Europe.

title: SOME COLLEGES QUESTION USEFULNESS OF S.A.T.'S
description: THE faculty of Bates College in Maine has voted to stop requiring high school seniors to submit Scholastic Aptitude Tests scores as part of the admissions process.

title: 'SCORNED AND SWINDLED' HAS A BASIS IN REALITY
description: THE warning reads: ''This film is drawn from a true incident. If you mistake what you are about to see for fiction, you may not believe it.'' Well, the words ''drawn from'' offer a good deal of leeway to the producers, but ''Scorned and Swindled,'' tonight's television movie on CBS at 9 o'clock, does have some roots in reality. Suggested by an article by Cable Neuhaus, the Karol Ann Hoeffner-Jerome Kass script uses the widely reported story of a man who, in the course of his travels around the country, ended up marrying 82 women.

title: AS ANCIENT WAYS SLIDE INTO OBLIVION, HUNTER TRIBES FACE PAINFUL CHOICES
description: ''It took me all my youth to learn to hunt. Where has it taken me? I don't want my son to be a hunter. I want him to go to school and be a teacher or a farmer.''

title: No Headline
description: John Gambling to Give To Broadcast Museum

title: PENOBSCOT SHOE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 24
description: Results for the latest periods include LIFO gains of about $202,000 for the quarter and $317,000 for the 9 months.

title: Treizieme in D.C.
description: Treizieme, a 3-year-old French daughter of The Minstrel, was added today to the prospective field for the Washington D.C. International, to be run Oct. 20 at Laurel Race Course. A field of 10 is expected. The nine others are: Secreto and Alphabatim, from Britain; Hero's Honor, Ends Well and Domynsky, from the United States; Princess Pati, from Ireland; Strawberry Road, from Australia; Balkan Prince, from Belgium, and Rossard, from Denmark.

title: ;  Nets Cut 4
description: The Nets, trimming their roster before an exhibition trip to the West Coast this week, cut four players at the training camp yesterday. They were left with 15, three more than the regular-season limit.

title: 3 Companies Form A Marine Venture
description: The marine service subsidiaries of the Zapata Corporation, the Houston Natural Gas Corporation and the Halliburton Company will merge into a new company with $600 million in assets and 325 vessels to serve offshore oil and gas operations around the world, the three parent companies announced yesterday.

title: NIAGARA SHARE CORP reports earnings for As of Sept 30
description: Per share figures reflect a distribution equal to $1.73 per share paid March 19.

title: Voters Wanted, Today
description: Does one person's vote make a difference? It certainly does. A mere hundred votes can decide a local race. Nationally, a few thousand can.

title: SOCIETY'S STAKE IN PRESCHOOL TEACHING OF POOR
description: CAN education for 3-year-olds make enough of a difference in the lives of poor youngsters to justify its cost? Should government - local, state and Federal - change current policies and assume responsibility for early childhood education?

title: FAST AND ACCURATE CHLAMYDIA TEST REPORTED
description: A rapid new test that can detect chlamydia, the nation's most prevalent sexually transmitted disease, within 30 minutes is just as good or even better than the old laboratory tests that took four to six days, a medical researcher told the American Society of Microbiology here today.

title: TALKING BUSINESS WITH BAYS OF AMERICAN HOSPITAL SUPPLY
description: Health care is undergoing big changes in response to sharp increases in treatment costs. Some care is being shifted from hospitals to clinics, doctors' offices and the home. Companies are having employees bear more of the expense of health insurance. Last October, a new form of reimbursing hospitals for Medicare patients began to be used. Under the system, hospitals are allotted a fixed amount for treating a given illness, instead of receiving whatever expenses were incurred.

title: Drug-House Profiles
description: Ciba- Geigy A. G. became Switzerland's largest chemical company after the 1970 merger of Chemische Industrie Basel, or Ciba, founded in 1884, and J. R. Geigy, which had been active as a trading company since 1758.

title: STATE WON'T PRESS DARTMOUTH CASE
description: The state Attorney General's office has decided not to prosecute a Dartmouth College student who secretly tape-recorded a meeting of the Gay Students Association and published excerpts in an unofficial campus newspaper.

title: Arco Seeks to Divest Units
description: The Atlantic Richfield Company, which last week won Justice Department approval to sell most of its aluminum operations to a Canadian concern, said today that it hopes to finish selling off its metals units ''in four months to a year.''

title: Debt Issues
description: * Mobile Communications Corp. of America, Jackson, Miss., a holding company and radio communications carrier, is offering $30 million of convertible subordinated debentures due in 2004 at a price of $100 through Robinson-Humphrey/American Express. The debentures may be converted into common stock at a price of $8.625 a share.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: UP OVER There's been a local flurry of art from down under - Australia and New Zealand - and now we will be getting some of the culture from up over, from New York's neighbor, the French-speaking Province of Quebec. Starting today, the province is sponsoring ''Montreal/Theater Quebec,'' a series of events designed to acquaint us with what is on stage there.

title: Talks Resume On Cocoa Pact GENEVA, Oct. 8 (AP) -
description: Seventy producer and consumer countries resumed negotiations today at the United

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: Berry Filing
description: Berry Industries said it had filed for protection from its creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code.

title: PANELS FOR NEXT TWO DEBATES ARE NOT FILLED, LEAGUE SAYS
description: Six of eight journalists to question candidates in the coming Vice-Presidential and Presidential debates remain to be selected, a spokesman for the League of Women Voters said yesterday.

title: DOW OFF 4.64 IN SLOW TRADING
description: Stock prices fell moderately yesterday in the slowest trading in more than 21 months. The biggest losers were issues responding to unfavorable news developments.

title: Carlisle Corp. Appoints Chief Operating Officer
description: Robert J. Deffeyes has been named president and chief operating officer at the Carlisle Corporation, the diversified manufacturer announced. The appointment is effective Jan. 1.

title: SURGE AT SWISS DRUG HOUSES
description: If the pharmaceuticals industry has a headquarters, it is surely this trim town where the Rhine binds together Switzerland, France and West Germany. This is the home of Ciba-Geigy, Hoffmann- La Roche and Sandoz, three of the world's giant chemical and pharmaceutical companies.

title: Deficit Troubles for Costa Rica
description: Luis Alberto Monge, the President of Costa Rica, said today that the country's fiscal deficit could not be reduced to 1 percent of gross domestic product as required by the International Monetary Fund.

title: CMC INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
JEWS BUY SYMBOLS OF SUCCOTH ON LOWER EAST SIDE
description: Tables filled with willow branches, citrons and palms lined the sidewalks on the Lower East Side yesterday as young boys wearing yarmulkes shouted, ''Aravas, 60 cents.''

title: ARCHBISHOP CENSURES THATCHER
description: The Archbishop of Canterbury has accused Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of pursuing ''confrontation'' politics and suggested that her economic policies hurt people more than they help.

title: A SQUEEZE AT STORAGE TECHNOLOGY
description: The Storage Technology Corporation, a leading manufacturer of large computer data storage devices, said yesterday that it expects to report a loss of more than $20 million for the third quarter, thus violating the company's loan agreements with its banks.

title: The Constant Complainer
description: Among the unusual services available in New York is Rent- a-Kvetch, described by its proprietor, B. L. Ochman, as a ''consumer complaint handling service.''

title: SOUTHWESTERN PUBLIC SERVICE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Pakistani Ruler Bars Return of Parties
description: Pakistan's martial law President, Gen. Mohammad Zia-ul-Haq, today ruled out the return of opposition political parties after elections for an Islamic democracy promised by next March.

title: FITTINGS GO ON THE BLOCK OFF LINER UNITED STATES
description: The auction of about one million art works, furnishings and fittings from the luxury liner United States, the fastest ever built and one of the handsomest, attracted more than 1,000 enthusiastic viewers and bidders here today for the first day of a sale that continues through Sunday.

title: THE PRIDE OF A VOTE
description: From across the Atlantic, the United States Presidential election campaign has an unreal quality that seems more about emotional euphoria than government. Europeans are perplexed in trying to pin down just what it is that Americans are debating.

title: Wellcome Venture
description: Wellcome Foundation Ltd.'s Wellcome Animal Health Inc. said it was forming a joint venture with Imperial Chemical Industries P.L.C. The joint-venture company will be known in the United States as Coopers Animal Health Inc. and will be the third-largest animal health concern in the world and the largest outside the United States.

title: Cleanup Finished At Pesticide Plant
description: Workers today completed cleaning up thousands of gallons of a pesticide that leaked from an American Cyanamid plant here.

title: NEXT UP IN SODA: PLASTIC CANS
description: After nearly two decades as the flip-top, throwaway standard of the soft-drink industry, the 12-ounce aluminum can may soon be discarded in favor of plastic.

title: COLUMBIA TUNES IN SOVIET TELEVISION
description: Residents of Siberia and students at Columbia University's Russian institute have something new in common: They watch the same television programs.

title: PSYCHOLOGY OF EAST GAINING ATENTION IN WESTERN WORLD
description: ASIAN civilizations have long been admired for their early elaborate systems of scientific thought, their medicine, their pharmacology. But to many Westerners, this Eastern body of knowledge is often seen as a trove of quaint relics rather than compelling science with contemporary application.

title: D5-1.59 (1x0.10)5 OR, DEFICIT GOING UP
description: To the Editor:

title: FAILURE OF FORD AND G.M. TO MEET FUEL EFFICIENCY STANDARDS STUDIED
description: Nearly a decade ago, when oil shortages had become a major concern, Congress ordered the automobile manufacturers to double the average fuel efficiency of their cars from about 14 miles to the gallon to 27.5 miles by this fall.

title: Five Union Officials Arrested at Disneyland
description: Six union officials were arrested today after a group of pickets at Disneyland defied a court order and marched to a forbidden area of the amusement park near the ticket booths, the police said.

title: People
description: * William J. Liss appointed senior vice president, corporate relations for Ohlmeyer Communications Companies.

title: Required Reading; A Time to Plow
description: During the 1948 Presidential campaign when he had literally been living on the ''whistle-stop'' train, making a dozen speeches a day and shaking thousands of hands, I asked him how he seemed so full of energy and never tired of doing all the things we put upon him, when his staff, much younger, was worn out.

title: PENWEST LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: The company was spun off from Univar Corp. on March 1. Comparative year-ago figures represent pre- spinoff manufacturing operations.

title: Bill Aiding Infants Is Signed
description: President Reagan today signed a bill that permits the prosecution of medical personnel who withhold treatment of severely handicapped infants. The legislation expands the definition of child abuse to include medical neglect to deter cases like that of Baby Doe, the Indiana child who died in 1982 after doctors withheld food and life-saving medical treatment.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Jay Roulier, a construction magnate who owns a one-third of the Houston Gamblers in the United States Football League, said he wanted to sell his interest in the team and take over the Los Angeles Express, which, because of J. William Oldenburg's financial problems, has been under direct league operation since July. . . . George Tardiff resigned yesterday as football coach at Washburn University in Topeka, Kans. complaining he had been harassed by the administration. He had intended to stay until the end of the season, but the school president, Dr. John Green, relieved him of his duties immediately and named Larry Elliott , the offensive coordinator, interim coach. Tardiff, who last season led the Ichabods to the Central States Intercollegiate Conference championship and was named C.S.I.C. Coach of the Year, had seen his team fall to 0-5 thus far this season. . . . Betty Jo Springs, who won the prestigious Bonne Bell 10-K in Boston Monday will run in the New York City Marathon, according to Fred Lebow, the race director.

title: MUSIC: RECITAL BY MARRUS
description: IRIS LYNN MARRUS, a singer

title: JURY SELECTION NEAR COMPLETION IN LIBEL SUIT
description: Jury selection neared completion yesterday in the $120 million libel suit brought against CBS by Gen. William C. Westmoreland, who commanded United States forces in Vietnam between 1964 and 1968.

title: Iran Now Puts Toll at 7 In Attack on Gulf Tanker
description: Iran said today that the death toll from the Iraqi air attack on the supertanker World Knight on Monday had risen to seven and that two of eight wounded crewmen were in critical condition in a Teheran hospital.

title: Sankai Juko
description: Midday strollers along Pennsylvania Avenue today may be startled to observe a group of human figures, clad principally in white body paint, hanging by their ankles on ropes suspended from the roof of the National Theater. They may be startled, that is, unless they know that Sankai Juko, a most unusual Japanese dance troupe, is in town, giving a free outdoor sample today of the performances scheduled for Friday and Saturday at the Warner Theater nearby.

title: GROSS TAKES OVER AT H.R.A.
description: In his first day on the job yesterday, the new head of the city's Human Resources Administration took a traditional step - he hired a consultant.

title: John Henry Gets 126 Top Weight
description: John Henry, the thoroughbred with the most career earnings, has been assigned the top weight of 126 pounds for the $400,000 Ballantine's Scotch Classic Saturday at the Meadowlands, the track announced today.

title: Cuomo Asserts the President Should Seek More Debates
description: Noting that some of President Reagan's supporters assert Mr. Reagan won Sunday night's debate against Walter F. Mondale, Governor Cuomo said today that the President should agree to four more debates.

title: Compaq Expects Improved Results
description: The Compaq Computer Corporation said it expects to report that third-quarter revenues exceeded $85 million, compared with $36 million in the 1983 period.

title: UNITED STATIONERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 26
description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split in May 1984.

title: New Kodak Instant Slides
description: The Eastman Kodak Company yesterday announced an instant camera and film system that can produce standard-sized slides, one at a time, within 15 minutes after taking a picture.

title: COMPRESSION LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 29
description: b-Net income.

title: SCOUTING;
description: Program Cover Stings the N.F.L.

title: ASTRONAUTS, FREED FROM TECHINCAL WOES, TURN ATTENTION TO EARTH
description: Freed from the burden of minor technical breakdowns, the seven astronauts aboard the space shuttle Challenger turned fuller concentration today to observations of the earth. But they did take time out for a jovial news conference from space.

title: CULLEN FROST BANKERS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
DR. ISIDORE S. FALK PROFESSOR OF PUBLIC HEALTH FOR YALE U.
description: Dr. Isidore S. Falk, professor emeritus of public health at the Yale University School of Medicine and a longtime champion of Federal health insurance, died of a stroke last Thursday at Yale- New Haven Hospital. He was 85 years old and lived in New Haven.

title: WHIRLPOOL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
West Virginia Congressman Is Sued Over Gambling Debts
description: Representative Nick J. Rahall 2d, Democrat of West Virginia, has been sued by the Dunes Hotel, which asserts he owes $66,000 in gambling debts.

title: Avon in Cutback
description: Avon Products Inc. said it would close its distribution and sales office in Kansas City, Mo., next June, but a spokesman in the company's New York headquarters said he expected fewer than 100 terminations among the office's 389 employees. Half of the workers will be offered jobs in other cities, and about one-third will be offered early retirement, the spokesman added. Operations of the Kansas City office would be transferred to branches in Atlanta, Pasadena, Calif., and Morton Grove, Ill.

title: AN AVOIDABLE 20-YEAR RACE
description: Twenty years ago next week, on Oct. 14, 1964, Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev was ousted from office, and the nuclear arms race started in earnest.

title: FILM: 'COMFORT AND JOY,' COMEDY FROM SCOTLAND
description: IT is late afternoon of Christmas

title: A WOMEN'S RIGHT TO CONTROL OVER HER BODY
description: To the Editor:

title: Coetzee to Meet Bey
description: Gerrie Coetzee, the South African who won the World Boxing Association's heavyweight title 13 months ago by knocking out Michael Dokes, will apparently make his first defense Dec. 7 against undefeated David Bey, who is coming off a 12-round decision over Greg Page.

title: FLORIDA NATL BANKS OF FLORIDA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including extraordinary credits of $1.7 million for the quarter and $3.9 million for the 9 months.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Amax Inc., Greenwich, Conn., has elected to its board Rodney E. Willoughby, a Chevron vice president.

title: Flooding in British Columbia
description: More than 100 people were evacuated from their homes and some were stranded on the upper floors of buildings by high water today in a flood-ravaged area around Pemberton, about 80 miles north of Vancouver. The Lillooet River and Ryan Creek have risen nearly 15 feet and inundated low- lying farmland and houses.

title: Jacobs Has Stake In G. C. Murphy
description: Irwin L. Jacobs, who recently sold for a profit a major position in Walt Disney Productions, disclosed yesterday that he had acquired 376,900 shares of the G. C. Murphy Company, a McKeesport, Pa., retail concern, for about $12.4 million. The Jacobs stake represents about 8 percent of Murphy's common shares outstanding.

title: MERGER AIMED AT AIDING THIRD WORLD AGRICULTURE
description: Three private United States aid organizations involved in promoting agricultural assistance to poorer countries are merging to form a new nonprofit organization especially geared to helping the third world.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: WEDNESDAY, OCTOBER 10, 1984

title: 2 DISNEY HEIRS HIRE AN ADVISER
description: The widow and one daughter of Walt Disney said yesterday that they had informally joined together and hired the Wall Street firm of Dillon, Read & Company to advise them about their holdings in Walt Disney Productions.

title: CITIZENS & SOUTHERN reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
OPERAWORKS: NEW 'FIGARO'
description: SUDDENLY, seemingly out of nowhere, New York has a new opera company. Operaworks, a troupe with headquarters on Manhattan's Upper West Side, is in the middle of a highly ambitious first season - two weeks of performances in the Larry Richardson Dance Studio, an unprepossessing basement on East 14th Street. With a clear sense of priorities, Operaworks has devoted the bulk of its inaugural season to stagings of contemporary works by two important composers, George Crumb and Peter Maxwell Davies. However, on Friday night, the troupe presented its first performance of one of the grandest classics in the repertory - Mozart's ''Nozze di Figaro.''

title: MIDWAY AIR'S MOVE TO LOW-FARE RUNS
description: Midway Airlines Inc., which was founded five years ago as a low-cost carrier and transformed itself into an airline dedicated to the business traveler, is coming full circle, in a sense. On Monday, Midway will introduce a low-cost, no-frills service called Midway Express, using planes, equipment and about 300 employees from Air Florida under a reorganization plan for that carrier that was approved last month by a bankruptcy judge.

title: SAINTS GET OILERS' CAMPBELL
description: Earl Campbell and Brad Van Pelt, both of whom had expressed a desire to play for other teams, got their wishes yesterday.

title: PAROCHIAL SCHOOL CASE WILL BE HEARD
description: The Supreme Court expanded its already crowded docket of church-state cases today by agreeing to decide whether the Constitution permits local school systems to use Federal funds to teach remedial classes for disadvantaged children in parochial schools.

title: HOLOCAUST MEMORIES AND A REFUGE FOR THE JEWS OF ETHIOPIA
description: To the Editor:

title: MONDALE PRESSES REAGAN ON BENEFITS
description: Walter F. Mondale challenged President Reagan late today to pledge his full commitment to Social Security and Medicare and said Mr. Reagan had failed to keep promises four years ago to continue the programs intact.

title: VOLUME RISES
description: Stock prices fell slightly yesterday in heavier trading as concern over interest rates and the economy continued to depress the market.

title: PREMIER OF ONTARIO SAYS HE'LL RESIGN
description: The Premier of Ontario, Canada's most populous and powerful province, has announced his intention to resign after 13 years in office, ending a political career that saw its highest point when he was instrumental in repatriating the nation's Constitution two years ago.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: PARACHUTES AND KISSES. By Erica Jong. 405 pages. NAL Books. $16.95.

title: 7 Chilean Protest Chiefs Are Sent to Prison
description: A judge sent seven of Chile's top opposition leaders to jail today on charges of endangering internal security by calling a two-day protest last month in which nine people died.

title: CLOSE VOTES RAISE DOUBTS OVER FATE OF G.M. PACT
description: Ratification of the tentative contract between the General Motors Corporation and the United Automobile Workers by rank-and-file members is still in doubt, union leaders acknowledged today.

title: Milton Cardona to Play Yoruba at the Public
description: The religious music of the Yoruba of Nigeria has had an important and widespread impact in the Americas. In Cuba, Brazil, and other Caribbean and Latin American countries, Yoruba slaves kept the music alive and passed it on orally, from one generation to the next.

title: Faberge Shift To K.& E.
description: fragrances company that recently came under new management, has switched about

title: STEINBERG INC reports earnings for Year to July 28
description: b-Including a special gain of $1,313,000, or 18 cents a share. The company said preferred dividend requirements were $11,598,000 for the latest period compared with $8,265,000 for a year earlier. The company is listed on the Montreal and Toronto stock exchanges.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Wine Equity Measure

title: 'There You Go Again'
description: Viewers of the Presidential campaign debate Sunday evening recognized rapidly that Walter F. Mondale had come prepared for President Reagan to invoke his ''there you go again'' line. When the President was unable to resist reaching back for the familiar quotation, his Democratic opponent replied that Mr. Reagan had proposed cuts in Medicare after he took office in 1981, precisely the step that he had dismissed with ''there you go again'' when President Carter predicted it in their 1980 debate.

title: P.& G. Foresees Profit Downturn
description: The Procter & Gamble Company told shareholders at its annual meeting that earnings for the first quarter ended Sept. 30 would clearly be below last year's $273 million.

title: Reggie Workman & Friends At Carnegie Recital Hall
description: The bassist Reggie Workman has provided imaginative melodic and textural improvisations and a strong, supple beat to bands led by John Coltrane, Max Roach and other jazz innovators. He has also appeared with his own band, Top Shelf.

title: CORE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
FAB INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 25
description: b-After an unrealized loss of $1,122,000 for a decline in market value of temporary investments.

title: DEBATE PANELISTS' SCREENING DRAWS INCREASING CRITICISM
description: The process by which journalists are screened by the Republican and Democratic campaigns before being selected to question candidates in televised debates came under added fire yesterday as officials met to select two journalists for the debate tomorrow night between Vice President Bush and Geraldine A. Ferraro.

title: A SMALL WORKERS PARTY AIMS FIRE AT CAPITALISM
description: If Larry Holmes is elected President, he cannot serve. He is 32 years old, three years less than the minimum age set by the Constitution. Nor can he step aside in favor of his running mate, Gloria La Riva. She is 30.

title: SAFEGUARDING THE CONSTITUTION FROM THE COURT
description: To the Editor:

title: FIRST UNION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Rate Rise Denied In Auto Insurance
description: New Jersey's Insurance Commissioner today rejected a request for a 9.9 percent auto-insurance rate increase by about 200 companies serving nearly three million drivers.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ; Exxon Capital Sells Zero Coupon Euronotes
description: The Exxon Capital Corporation yesterday sold about $1.8 billion face amount of zero coupon Euronotes due in 2004 to Merrill Lynch International. The notes, which are guaranteed by Exxon and will not be offered to United States citizens or residents, were bought by Merrill Lynch at a price of about 11.05, or $110.50 per $1,000 face amount, to yield 11.32 percent.

title: SCOUTING ;
description: Hard Sell

title: Kaiser Posts Deficit; International Paper Up
description: The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation, reflecting the impact of a $60.7 million charge for discontinued operations, reported yesterday that it had a deficit of $73.2 million in the third quarter of 1984.

title: Market Place; Altered Views On A.T.& T.
description: BACK when the American Telephone and Telegraph Company was known as ''Ma Bell'' to its family of three million stockholders, ''buy'' recommendations emanated from brokerage houses with almost monotonous regularity. This held particularly true in periods when the general stock market outlook became clouded. In such uncertain times, many investment professionals found A.T.& T.'s stock a safe place to ''park'' money temporarily.

title: Dysan Corp.
description: The Dysan Corporation of Santa Clara, Calif., said it intended to redirect all its efforts toward its magnetic recording disks and would sell or curtail the operations of its ''seedling affiliates'' that are not financially independent. The company's share of the research and development costs of the affiliates totaled $21.2 million in the first nine months of the fiscal year 1984.

title: TV, RECORDS HELP CBS GAIN 46.1%
description: Buoyed by a strong, broad-based performance that included top television network ratings and several best-selling record albums, CBS Inc. yesterday reported a 46.1 percent increase in its quarterly earnings.

title: Restaurant at the Meer
description: The Parks Department expects to

title: Australia to Get Sikorsky Copters
description: The Sikorsky Aircraft division of the United Technologies Corporation said its S-70B Seahawk helicopter had been selected for use by the Australian Navy.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: FOR six years James Schlefer, a freelance flutist, harbored a four-foot boa constrictor named Oliver in his apartment in Brooklyn Heights. Oliver would not hurt a fly. Water bugs he eats, and also mice, but the point is Oliver is not a dangerous pet. Nor is he an especially adventurous pet, spending most of his time sleeping in a fish tank with a screened top. Accordingly, Mr. Schlefer was shocked one night to find the fish tank empty.

title: Hayden Opponent Jailed For Drug Use in 1967
description: David Shell, a Republican lawyer trying to unseat State Assemblyman Tom Hayden in the November election, was court-martialed and jailed for drug use in the Air Force, documents released Monday by Mr. Hayden show.

title: Sikh Temple Complex Now Free of All Troops
description: The Indian Government, trying to patch up relations with the Sikhs, returned control of the entire Golden Temple complex to the sect's leaders today and withdrew the last of its security forces, the United News of India reported.

title: BRIDGE BIKE PATHS THAT OUGHT TO REOPEN
description: To the Editor:

title: Picking a President
description: Your Presidential choice on Election Day is going to be easier than it was four years ago. The Federal Election Commission says that on Nov. 6 there will be 18 candidates for President on the ballot in one state or more, as against 21 candidates in 1980.

title: HUGO SLOTKIN, CHIEF OF JOHN MORRELL CO., A PACKING CONCERN
description: Hugo Slotkin, chairman of the board of John Morrell & Company, the third largest meatpacker in the country, died Sunday at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 72 years old and had residences in Manhattan, Palm Beach, Fla., and Holly, Mich.

title: SCOUTING;
description: Forum vs. Series

title: BANKERS TRUST OF SOUTH CAROINA reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Debt Issues
description: * Citicorp said it had sold $100 million of 91-day paper at 10.67 percent, down from 10.94 percent last week, and $50 million of 182-day paper at 10.674 percent, down from 10.934 percent.

title: Oil Policy In China
description: China is considering opening up onshore areas to foreign companies interested in helping search for oil, a top official was quoted as saying today.

title: NABISCO BRANDS NAMES CHIEF FINANCIAL OFFICER
description: H. F. Powell has been named chief financial officer and an executive vice president at Nabisco Brands Inc., the company said yesterday.

title: REAGAN PROMISES NO BENEFIT CUTS FOR ANY RETIREES
description: President Reagan, responding to campaign charges by Walter F. Mondale, today went beyond his previous position and promised to oppose cuts in Social Security benefits for future as well as current retirees.

title: ONE MAN'S MEAT ISN'T CAPITOL FARE
description: Representative Romano L. Mazzoli, at the request of a Kentucky constituent, in July offered a joint resolution that found the beef. The following text needed 218 co-sponsors to be reported out of committee, but it died because only one Representative, another Democrat, Frank Annunzio of Illinois, would bite:

title: PERSONAL Health
description: One man carries a small battery- operated fan that he directs at smokers so the smoke blows back to its source.

title: Gemayel Nephew Appointed Head of the Christian Militia
description: A nephew of President Amin Gemayel took command of Lebanon's main right-wing Christian militia today.

title: In-Flight Commercials Being Planned by ABC
description: Now that the flying public has shown no resistance to commercial messages up yonder, it is apparently time to strengthen the dose, adding some real old-fashioned 60-second spots to the bland diet of almost ad- free company-style films.

title: MUBARAK BEGINS A VISIT TO JORDAN
description: President Hosni Mubarak arrived here today on the first state visit by an Egyptian leader to an Arab country since his nation was ostracized by the Arabs after making peace with Israel.

title: U.S. ASKS UNESCO FOR MORE CHANGES
description: The United States expressed dissatisfaction today with proposals for improving the way Unesco operates drawn up by a special committee and said it would seek to strengthen them by making additional proposals of its own.

title: MUSIC: SOUND FROM BRAZIL, GILBERTO GIL
description: FOR sheer ebullience, Gilberto Gil's music can stand with any pop in the world. Superbly crafted songs and virtuoso singing stood out in his set Sunday at Sounds of Brazil, where he is appearing through Thursday, but the musicianship was just a springboard for infectious high spirits.

title: SHELBY WILLIAMS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Export Bill Disagreement
description: House and Senate conferees met for about an hour this afternoon to try to resolve their longstanding differences over a bill to control strategic exports to the Soviet Union and other countries.

title: No Headline
description: Bridge:The Autumn Leaf Regional BeginsTodayin

title: Reagan to Stump in South
description: President Reagan will make his third trip in two weeks to the South next Monday with stops in three states, the White House announced today. Mr. Reagan, who was in North Carolina on Monday and in Mississippi and Texas last week, is to address campaign rallies at the University of Alabama at Tuscaloosa; at the Macon, Ga., City Hall, and at the Greenville Technical College in South Carolina.

title: FOR KARPOV, IT WAS A RELUCTANT DRAW
description: A reluctant Anatoly Karpov had trouble making up his mind Monday before agreeing to an early draw with his challenger for the world chess championship, Gary Kasparov, in the 10th game of their match in Moscow. The 33-year-old Karpov retained his 4-0 lead in the series.

title: Bond Offering For Niagara A two-part offering of tax-exempt bonds backed by the Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation was tentatively priced yesterday with $13 million of 9 1/4
description: percent bonds due in 1989 at a

title: No Headline
description: 'American Folk Roots' ToOpenWithBluegrass

title: Heredity's Importance Noted in Alzheimer's
description: Brothers and sisters and children of people with Alzheimer's disease, the leading form of senility, face a 33 percent chance of also developing the disease, new research indicates. The research buttresses earlier studies that have pointed to an important hereditary factor in the development of Alzheimer's disease, but the degree of risk has varied from one study to another.

title: COURT BACKS VOTING BY HOMELESS
description: A Federal judge issued an injunction yesterday barring New York City from ''refusing to allow homeless individuals to register to vote on the ground that they fail to inhabit traditional residences.''

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Father in Heaven, we are here under duress, but we imposed this on ourselves.'' - The Rev. Richard C. Halverson, the chaplain, opening the Senate Tuesday. (A22:4.)

title: BUSH AND FERRARO SHARPEN STRATEGIES IN PREPARATION FOR TOMORROW'S DEBATE
description: Aides to Geraldine A. Ferraro said yesterday that she hoped to follow Walter F. Mondale's lead by stressing in her debate with Vice President Bush Thursday night the philosophical and political differences between the Republican and Democratic nominees.

title: Soviet and Yemen Sign 20-Year Amity Treaty
description: The Soviet Union and the Yemen Arab Republic signed a 20-year treaty of friendship today.

title: REAGAN'S AIDES TO REASSESS TACTIS AND PREPARATIONS FOR SECOND DEBATE
description: Aides to President Reagan worked today at analyzing his performance in the Presidential debate Sunday night and devising strategies for regaining the campaign offensive from Walter F. Mondale.

title: COLUMBIA CHASE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Including a tax credit of $203,000. c-Including a gain of $200,000 from life insurance proceeds. The company is listed on the Boston and Philadelphia stock exchanges.

title: SOUTH AFRICA TO GIVE STUDENTS A SMALL VOICE IN THE SCHOOLS
description: South African authorities announced plans for a democratization of the nation's troubled schools today in what seemed an ambivalent concession to the thousands of students who have been boycotting classes since May.

title: AUTHOR'S PRISON ORDEAL AS UNEMOTIONAL DRAMA
description: IN the early 1960's, Nelson

title: The Pentagon Brew Every taxpayer should visit one of the Air Force's C-5 transport planes. He should climb the flimsy $74,000 aluminum folding ladder, sink into the $13,000 crew chief's seat, and rest his arm on the $670 foam-rubber-and-naugahyde armrest. There, sipping coffee from the $7,622 coffee brewer, he can ponder just how much extra security the Pentagon has bought with its four-year, $755 billion military spending program.
description: Congress has now seen enough overpriced military spare parts to realize that waste and extravagance are endemic to the procurement system. But the Pentagon whistle-blowers who are bringing these excesses to light through the Project on Military Procurement are not so much worried about mere prices. Their concern is that the Pentagon has lost effective control over the design and procurement of new weapons.

title: Vote of Confidence
description: He's still coaching in the shadow of Bear Bryant, and his Crimson Tide has hardly been rolling this year.

title: New Confusion in the Stewart Case It took a New York County grand jury seven months to indict three transit police officers for second-degree manslaughter and criminal negligence in the death of Michael Stewart during a subway arrest last year. Now a judge, risking further controversy in an already inflamed community, has dismissed the indictment because of improper actions by one grand juror.
description: Was dismissal warranted? Though a close call, it probably was. Manhattan prosecutors did well, however, to begin immediately to present the evidence to another grand jury.

title: SPANIARDS SIGN ACCORD ON LABOR AND SALARIES
description: An agreement governing labor relations and salaries over the next two years was signed today by Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez and representatives of employers and Socialist unions.

title: SL INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Including income of $3,000 for the quarter and a loss of $175,000 for the year from discontinued operations. c-Including income from discontinued operations of $26,000 for the quarter and $74,000 for the year.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: Tornado Kills 10 in Brazil
description: A tornado ripped through a southern Brazilian town early today, killing at least 10 people and injuring hundreds, the police reported. ''There wasn't a building left intact,'' said a police spokesman speaking by phone from Maravilha, a farming community of 20,000 situated 1,100 miles southwest of here.

title: IN CHINA, THE STEAM ENGINE IS STILL KING OF THE RAILS
description: A shiny black leviathan, welded from 133 tons of steel, nosed out of the shed. Its six driving wheels, painted bright red with white trim, slowly picked up speed.

title: McNamara Quits
description: The California Angels said yesterday that Manager John McNamara had decided not to return to the club next season. The 52-year-old McNamara, whose contract expired with the end of the regular season, has frequently been mentioned as a possible candidate for the managerial job with the Boston Red Sox.

title: Judge Bars Ouster Of 2 Union Aides
description: A Federal judge today blocked the ouster of two officials of an Atlantic City casino workers union, who state gaming officials have said have ties to organized crime.

title: STAUFFER EXECUTIVE QUITS UNEXPECTEDLY
description: The Stauffer Chemical Company said yesterday that Kenneth E. Davis, a vice chairman since last May, had resigned, effective immediately.

title: JULES CORTELLJules Cortell, founder and president of the Cortell Group, travel tour operators, and a pioneer in promoting fly-drive tours of Europe, died Saturday in his home in Manhattan. He was 77 years old and had been suffering from hepatitis.
description: Mr. Cortell, who was born in Germany, began his career as a shipping clerk with the Cunard Line in Paris.

title: SUPREME COURT CLEARS WAY FOR INQUIRY ON FEDERAL JUDGE
description: The Supreme Court today cleared the way for a judicial committee to inspect grand jury records for its own investigation of Federal District Judge Alcee L. Hastings in Miami, who was acquitted of bribery last year.

title: Human-Rights Internships
description: Columbia Law School took a step

title: BUFFALO TROLLEY LINE CLANGS TO A START
description: With the clang of a bell and the toot of a horn, the first regular trolley service since 1950 began here today as Buffalo opened 1.2 miles of its rapid-transit system through the downtown shopping district.

title: CORRECTION
description: A Washington dispatch yesterday on factual errors by President Reagan and Walter F. Mondale in their debate misstated the amounts involved in Federal housing programs. When Mr. Reagan entered the White House the budget for Federal housing was $873 million; in the fiscal year 1983 the Reagan Administration sought $445 million and Congress approved $633 million.

title: ELEGANT MEALS FROM PLASTIC POUCHES
description: FAIRFAX, Vt.

title: BULGARIA RADIO SAYS 5 HAVE BEEN KILED IN PARCE BOMBINGS
description: The official Bulgarian radio said today that five people had been killed in a series of bombings around the country earlier this year.

title: Coleco Official Plans to Leave
description: Frank T. Alfieri, senior vice president and chief financial officer of Coleco Industries, will resign Oct. 31, the company said yesterday.

title: Vanguard Starts New Bond Fund
description: The Vanguard Group of Investment Companies, based in Valley Forge, Pa., announced yesterday that it was offering the first no-load municipal bond mutual fund that invests in long- term insured bonds.

title: Mild Quake Hits Georgia
description: A moderate earthquake measuring 3.7 on the Richter scale rattled dishes and startled residents in northwest Georgia today, but no injuries or major property damage were reported.

title: Mexico Meets With Bankers
description: A presentation by Mexican officials to commercial bankers on its planned $48.5 billion debt rescheduling was well received, bankers at the meeting said today.

title: SCIENTISTS STUDY BRAIN'S 'TEAMWORK'
description: Scientists are exploring the implications of new findings on the cooperative nature of the brain's system of internal communication.

title: THE AGE ISSUE
description: In the wake of the Reagan-Mondale debate, the leading front-page story in The Wall Street Journal, no enemy of the President, dealt on Tuesday with the question of President Reagan's age.

title: MASTER COOKS TAKE TO THE ROAD
description: THEY are the culinary equivalent of rock stars, the vaudevillians of the cooking world. Clutching copies of their latest publications, armed with a set of Sabatier knives or a favorite wire whisk, they hop in and out of airports and rental cars, sleep in unfamiliar beds and cook in strange kitchens, facing sometimes critical, more often adoring audiences. They are the traveling cooking teachers who spend a good part of each year on the circuit, demonstrating techniques and recipes in thousands of professional and private kitchens across America.

title: Slot Machine Pays Record$1.5Million
description: A 41-year-old Newark man who spent about $20 playing a slot machine won a $1.5 million jackpot today, the largest slot-machine payoff since gambling began here six years ago, according to casino officials.

title: WHATEVER THE GARNISH, IT'S INDISPUTABLY SHRIMP
description: WITH the price of shrimp reaching, and often exceeding, $7.50 a pound, these crustaceans are being spoken of by household cooks with a reverence once reserved for filet mignon. And yet for ease and speed of cooking and for the variety of seasonings and presentations they can support, shrimp on the table represent money well spent.

title: SCIENTISTS REPORT NEW TOOLS FOR CURBING COLDS AND DIARRHEA
description: New medical tools that can help prevent the spread of common colds in Americans and the onset of devastating diarrhea in third world infants were described here today at a meeting of the American Society for Microbiology.

title: UNITED STATES TRUST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ROBBINS & MYERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net loss Year-ago results reflect a nonrecurring charge of $12 million reflecting a restructuring and downsizing of the company.

title: Holders Approve Hershey Proposal
description: The Hershey Foods Corporation announced that its shareholders had approved a plan to issue a new class of common stock with greater voting power. The action allows the company to raise money through a new issue without diluting the voting control of the Hershey Trust.

title: INTEREST RATES OFF FOR 3D DAY
description: Interest rates declined yesterday for the third consecutive day, with traders and investors encouraged by recent declines in overnight interest rates, which they assume are inspired by an easier Federal Reserve monetary policy.

title: Careers; When Job Security Is Provided
description: A NEW study by the Work In America Institute offers a message: ''Providing employment security to workers is good business.'' Accordingly, at a time when American companies have grown very bottom-line conscious, the study makes timely reading.

title: BEVACQUA LOST HIS FOOTING AND A TRIPLE
description: Before tonight's World Series opener, Kurt Bevacqua, the 37-year-old pinch-hitter who suddenly was in the San Diego Padres' lineup as their designated hitter, was discussing the natural nervousness of the situation.
