title: CLOSE-UPS OF A FILM FESTIVAL AND ITS SPIRITED FANS
description: Here and there in the crowd outside Alice Tully Hall, they stood with tickets raised. ''One for the 6:15, two for the 9,'' a man announced quietly, holding aloft lavender and blue tickets for two screenings at the 22d New York Film Festival. When a nearby competitor called out ''Reduced price,'' the first man advised him with a fatherly smile, ''Not yet; too early.''

title: Washington's Coach Reinstated by City
description: Three weeks after he had been suspended by the Board of Education for insubordination, Jim Walsh was temporarily reinstated as the football coach at George Washington High School yesterday, and his team received clearance to play what was called a ''nonleague'' schedule.

title: NEW CENTER DEDICATED TO THEOLOGY RESEARCH
description: A theological research center designed to be the equivalent of institutes for advanced studies in the social and physical sciences was dedicated here today.

title: Reagan Signed 1970 Law Barring Murder of Fetus
description: President Reagan, in his debate with Walter F. Mondale, mistakenly gave a Democratic Governor credit for signing a California law that makes it illegal to kill a fetus. Mr. Reagan signed the bill himself.

FARM WORKERS FACING NEW TEAMSTER CONTEST
description: Even as the United Farm Workers won a significant victory with a new boycott tactic, forcing the McDonald's restaurant chain to stop buying one brand of lettuce, the union faces a serious new challenge from an old antagonist.

title: CHEERS FOR FERRE
description: No single look dominates the Italian fashion collections for spring and summer, which some people find upsetting. Freedom of choice can be disturbing. What most designers do share is a lighthearted feeling expressed in simple shapes, cheerful colors and an arresting display of new printed fabrics. These all contribute to the gaiety of the warm-weather clothes as the schedule of fashion show openings here reaches the midpoint.

CUOMO ASSAILED ON WASTE ISSUES BY LOBBY GROUP

title: DAVID BYRNE AND TALKING HEADS MAKE A MOVIE
description: DAVID BYRNE, the singer and lyricist for Talking Heads, was a gangly, awkward performer during the band's early days. Certain critics, noting that the first Talking Heads hit was a Byrne composition called ''Psycho Killer,'' compared his stage manner to Anthony Perkins's portrayal of the neurotic murderer in Alfred Hitchcock's ''Psycho.'' Now the Talking Heads have made a film, ''Stop Making Sense,'' with the director Jonathan Demme, who broke into movies as writer-director of ''Caged Heat,'' ''Crazy Mama'' and other ''exploitation'' quickies about motorcycle gangs, women's prisons and assorted Public Enemies. The Byrne- Demme collaboration might look like an intriguing match, but not necessarily one made in heaven.

description: John McNamara, manaager, resigned. MILWAUKEE (AL) - Gave Roy Howell, utility infielder, his unconditional release. Moved Pete Vuckovich, pitcher, from disabled list to active roster. BASKETBALL HOUSTON (NBA) - Waived James Ray, forward. FOOTBALL BUFFALO (AFC) - Waived Lucious Smith, cornerback. CINCINNATI (AFC) - Traded the rights to Ricky Hunley, linebacker, to Denver for the Broncos' first-round choice in 1986. CLEVELAND (AFC) - Traded Lawrence Johnson, defensive back, to Buffalo for an undisclosed 1985 draft choice. HOUSTON (AFC) - Traded Earl Campbell, running back, to New Orleans for first-round draft choice in 1985. KANSAS CITY (AFC) - Waived David Whitehurst, quarterback, after signing Walt Arnold, free-agent tight end. LOS ANGELES RAIDERS (AFC) - Sent Jim Romano, reserve center, to Houston for undisclosed draft choices. MIAMI (AFC) - Added Sanders Shiver, linebacker, to roster. MINNESOTA (NFC) - Traded Brad Van Pelt, linebacker, to Los Angeles Raiders. NEW ORLEANS (NFC) - Placed Brad Edelman, guard, on injured reserve and signed Jim Pietrzak, lineman. PITTSBURGH (AFC) - Obtained Steve August, offensive tackle, from Seattle in exchange for a future undisclosed draft choice. SAN DIEGO (AFC) - Signed Wayne Morris, running back, and placed Carlos Bradley, linebacker, on injured reserve. TAMPA BAY (NFC) - Signed Dwayne Dixon, free-agent wide receiver. title: CONCERT: MOSCOW NIGHT
description: It was something like a program of contemporary music in Carnegie Recital Hall. Six world premieres by as many composers were given tonight in the small hall of the House of Composers. It seats about 300, and it was no more than three-quarters full. Composers were in attendance, as were representatives of the cultural offices of various foreign legations and a sprinkling of the Moscow intelligentsia.

title: Economic Scene; An Unresolved Issue: Taxation
description: WHAT will be done about taxes after the election? The 1984 political campaign appears to be driving the candidates further and further apart on how to deal with the looming budget deficits, which the Democratic challenger, Walter F. Mondale, has sought to make the key economic issue of the election.

title: CBS'S ATTACK ON FEAR
description: The crusading spirit of journalism is once again being put into the service of popular entertainment, this time in the television movie ''Attack on Fear'' on CBS tonight at 9. And once again the overall effect, not to mention the blatant exploitation, is decidedly questionable.

Other builders followed, taking sites downtown in the vicinity of Atlantic and Broad Streets, along Summer Avenue and on Tresser Boulevard. Together, they created eight million square feet of office space.

title: COMPA

Amalgamated also received guarantees of delivery covering an additional 147,089 shares, representing about 5.9 percent of the outstanding Medford shares.

Frustrated by its efforts to influence the development of Rolm products after a yearlong joint development effort, the speculation went, I.B.M. had decided it had to make the Santa Clara, Calif., company an offer it could not refuse.

title: AT IOWA, HARMON MAKES OFFENSE GO
description: Ronnie Harmon, on his way to football practice at Iowa, met the assistant sports information director, Phil Haddy. They nodded greetings and then Harmon, the ace running back from Bayside High School in Queens, whirled and said, ''Hey, Phil, I'm 6 feet, you know, not 5-11.''

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: THEATER ARTS Seven years ago the New York Art Theater Institute set about presenting theater that combined literature, the visual arts and music. A flowering of this artistic hybrid comes to full bloom today, with the first of five performances of a new play by Kenneth Koch, the poet, in a set designed by Reuben Nakian, the sculptor who, at age 87, is making his debut in this stagecraft art.

title: BATTLE FOUGHT OVER ROCKIES' ASPENS
description: The aspen, whose gold and yellow leaves flutter and shimmer in the autumn mountain breezes, stands at the center of a dispute that has pitted environmentalists and ranchers against businessmen and municipal leaders in the scattered towns of the western slope of the Colorado Rockies.

title: An Offer in El Salvador It's not just his political neck that President Jose Napoleon Duarte risks with the offer to talk to El Salvador's leftist guerrillas. The violent right has slaughtered many Salvadoran democrats for entertaining the same idea. Yet Mr. Duarte, from the forum of the United Nations, says that unconditional discussions can begin next week in La Palma, a town in guerrilla-held territory near the Honduran border. The guerrillas instantly accepted, if a neutral observer attends.
description: What is going on here? The honest answer is that Mr. Duarte's calculations are not obvious. He may well agree with the Pentagon's assessment that the tide of battle is shifting to his Government's side. Or, less securely, he may be trying to use diplomacy to ward off an expected guerrilla offensive in the autumn dry season. He might even be moving ahead of his American allies, figuring that they will restrain him less during the United States election campaign.

title: MUSIC: BACH FESTIVAL FROM NEW ENGLANDERS
description: BLANCHE Honegger Moyse has been a fructifying force in American musical life for more than 30 years, but her name still is not as widely known as it should be.

President Reagan promised Israel emergency aid if the country was faced with a balance-of-payments crisis. However, after listening for two days to detailed appeals by Prime Minister Shimon Peres for billions of dollars in additional financial support over several years, the Administration put off until next year any steps to increase military and economic aid to Israel beyond the current $2.6 billion. title: Reynolds Seeks Soft Drink Unit
description: -SALEM, N.C., Oct. 9 (AP) - R. J. Reynolds Industries has signed a letter of intent to purchase the Sunkist Soft Drinks subsidiary of General Cinema Corporation for $57 million, the companies said.

title: Electoral College TallyTo Be Delayed One Day
description: President Reagan today signed a resolution that spares Congress a Sunday session next Jan. 6 and puts off until the next day the task of counting votes from the Electoral College.

title: GUERRILLAS ACCEPT DUARTE PROPOSAL FOR PEACE PARLEY
description: Salvadoran guerrilla leaders today formally accepted an offer from President Jose Napoleon Duarte to meet rebel representatives next Monday in northern El Salvador.

title: JUDGE WITH GENTLE FIRMNESS
description: Judge Pierre N. Leval was the man in charge yesterday when the opposing sides, their lawyers and the prospective jurors assembled for the start of Gen. William C. Westmoreland's libel suit against CBS. The affable 48-year-old judge, who is known for his calm and confident manner, may need all his equanimity to cope with a case that has already attracted extraordinary attention. It involves a $120 million lawsuit by General Westmoreland, who contends that he was libeled by a CBS television program in 1982 about the Vietnam War.

title: Jet Explosion on Takeoff Laid To Plane Tail Hitting Runway
description: The authorities investigating the crash of a private jet said the plane's tail apparently hit the runway on takeoff, bringing an explosion that killed all three people aboard and hurled blazing debris for half a mile.

title: ABOUT NEW YORK
description: You can help little Gail or you can turn the page.

title: LEAD DANCER FOR BALANCHINE
description: Lew Christensen, who was the first leading male dancer in the United States for George Balanchine and a longtime director of the San Francisco Ballet, died yesterday at Peninsula Hospital in Burlingame, Calif. He was 75 years old.

title: INTERNATIONAL DAIRY QUEEN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Norwegian Oilfield
description: Production from the Oseberg oil and gas field in the Norwegian sector of the North Sea has been brought forward one year from 1990, to 1989, Norsk Hydro, the operator, said. Thorleif Enger, the project leader, said improved subsea drilling equipment meant the start-up date could be advanced. The field will be the fourth biggest on the Norwegian continental shelf.

title: BANK OF NEW YORK CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CAMPAIGN NOTES ; Farm Network Formed To Support Republicans
description: Formation of a nationwide network of state directors to turn out the farm vote for President Reagan next month was announced Tuesday by the Reagan- Bush '84 re-election campaign.

title: FUR VAULT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: THE best time to put insulation in a house is during construction, but many houses built before the need for energy conservation either did not have insulation or do not have enough by today's standards.

title: 11TH CHESS GAME IS ADJOURNED IN MOSCOW
description: The 11th game of the world chess championship was adjourned today when Gary Kasparov, the challenger, sealed his 41st move.

title: STATE'S LIMIT ON VOTING BY STUDENTS OVERTURNED
description: A Federal judge in Syracuse has ruled unconstitutional state laws that he said discriminated against college students who wanted to vote in the communities where they attend school.

title: COLT INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Sudden Move At Burlington
description: Alan R. Dragone has resigned as vice chairman and a director of Burlington Industries, the nation's largest textiles producer, after joining the company in that capacity only last December, a company spokesman said yesterday in Greensboro, N.C.

description: IF you're hankering to hear one

title: Long-Term Rates Rise a Bit
description: Short-term interest rates declined slightly yesterday, but slight declines in Treasury note and bond prices resulted in a modest increase in yields for longer-term securities.

title: 2 ABOARD SHUTTLE GET GO-AHEAD TO TRY A SATELLITE REFUELING TEST
description: Two Challenger astronauts are now set to inaugurate the era of the orbital service station.

title: Farm Bank Sale
description: The Federal Farm Credit Banks Funding Corporation, which provides financing for the Federal Farm Credit System, is offering $703 milloion of 12 percent bonds due Oct. 20, 1986, and $605 million of 12.45 percent bonds due Oct. 23, 1989. Both issues are offered at a price of 100 through various securities dealers.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: Manning-Rolle Merger
description: Manning, Selvage & Lee, a public relations subsidiary of the Benton & Bowles advertising agency, has acquired Bill Rolle Associates, a Washington public relations firm with some $1 million in billings. It is being merged into the Manning Washington office, which is about the same size. Jean Rainey, who had been in charge at Manning, and William C. Rolle Jr. will serve as co-partners.

title: CAMPAIGN NOTES ; Catholic Paper Terms Nuclear Peril Top Issue
description: A Roman Catholic newspaper said Tuesday that the ''nuclear peril,'' not abortion, should be the most important issue of the 1984 election.

title: COMPUTER DATA SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CATERPILLAR SLASHES ITS DIVIDEND
description: The Caterpillar Tractor Company announced today that it would slash its quarterly dividend to 12.5 cents, from 37.5 cents. It also said it would freeze hiring, accelerate plant closings and pare manufacturing capacity and production schedules.

title: COMIC'S WICKED WIT KEEPS RUSSIANS TICKLED PINK
description: A frail old man with hair swirling above his head in an incongruous white pompadour stands alone under a spotlight in the center of the stage and shrugs his shoulders with infinite weariness.

title: BANKS NAMED GIANTS' STARTER
description: When the Giants play the Falcons in Atlanta on Sunday, they will have a new linebacker in the starting lineup: Carl Banks, the team's first draft choice this year.

title: FANSTEEL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Edward Elkins Is Dead at 87;Dance Band Leader in 1920's
description: Edward G. (Eddie) Elkins, one of the first of the dance band leaders, died Saturday at his home in Manhattan. He was 87 years old.

title: INITIO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 4
description: b-Net income after a loss of $6,000 from discontinued operations. c-After a loss of $61,000 from discontinued operations. Results for the latest quarter and 6 months reflect litigation expenses of $130,000.

description: The results for the latest third quarter reflect a charge of $39 million from anticipated lower gas prices for future production.

title: A SMALL STEP FOR MANKIND IN THE MAKING
description: -grade son in a new school. It was a radical switch - which was what I had in mind. At his previous institution of lower learning, so much attention had been paid to the externals of getting an education (sock color, hair length, not sitting on the school steps after 3:15 P.M.) that my son - who sometimes went out of control and did a little break-dancing on the blacktop during recess - developed an ulcer. I devoutly hoped that this new school and academic year would blot last year from his mind.

title: Brain Study on Knocked-Out Fighters Under Way
description: Examinations of 50 boxers knocked out this year in New York State shows no indication of brain damage, Dr. Bennett M. Derby, who is conducting the ongoing tests for the State Athletic Commission, said yesterday, but he issued ''two major caveats'' before anyone jumped to conclusions.

title: O'SULLIVAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Acne Drug Accutane Linked To Severe Birth Deformities
description: A high rate of severe birth defects has been linked to a popular acne medication taken primarily by teen-agers, a researcher said today.

title: Syrian President to Pay Visit To Soviet Union Next Week
description: President Hafez al-Assad will pay an official visit to the Soviet Union next week, the official press agencies of Syria and the Soviet Union reported today.

title: MINISTER IS INDICTED IN THE BRONX IN SEXUAL ASSAULTS ON 6 CHILDREN
description: A 48-year-old Methodist minister was indicted by a Bronx grand jury yesterday on charges of sexually assaulting five boys and a girl in a day-care center at his church.

BUSH-FERRARO DEBATE TODAY SEEN AS ALTERING CAMPAIGN DYNAMICS
description: Vice President Bush and his Democratic rival, Geraldine A. Ferraro, will debate in Philadelphia Thursday night in an event that has taken on new importance as the two campaigns try to improve on the results of last Sunday's Presidential debate.

title: THE CITY ; ;  Bystander Killed By Stray Bullet
description: A bystander on the Lower East Side was killed by a stray bullet fired by a man in an argument 70 feet away.

title: OCEAN-FLOOR SPRINGS FOUND
description: Three mineral-rich hot springs have been discovered near the middle of the Atlantic Ocean floor, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration reported today.

title: 1,000 in Panama Protest
description: The riot police clashed here today with a thousand demonstrators charging vote fraud in the election of Nicolas Ardito Barletta, who is to be inaugurated as President on Thursday. He was elected May 6 by a margin of 1,713 votes out of 640,000 ballots cast. The protesters contended that Arnulfo Arias Madrid, a former President, had been the winner.

title: WESTMORELAND'S LAWYER OUTLINES CASE TODAY FOR THE JURORS
description: A. FARBER

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ; St. Regis Tie Spurs President to Leave
description: The St. Regis Corporation, whose merger with the Champion International Corporation is expected to become effective in December, said yesterday that Edward J. McMahon, its president and chief operating officer since 1981, will retire at the end of the month.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: NEW PLANES FOR CONTINENTAL
description: The Texas Air Corporation, owner of Continental Air Lines, said yesterday that it would buy 24 Boeing 737- 300 aircraft in a deal that the company estimated could total $600 million.

title: Postmaster Will Join Public Relations Firm
description: William F. Bolger, the United States Postmaster General, will join Gray & Company, a public relations and communications group here, effective January 1, 1985, the agency announced today.

title: Danish Jobless Rate
description: Danish unemployment rose to 9.8 percent in August, from 9.1 percent in July, but was down from 9.9 percent 12 months earlier, the Bureau of Statistics said today.

title: HOSPITAL CHAPLAIN'S COST-CONTAINMENT VALUE
description: To the Editor:

title: HONDURAN ANGER AT THE U.S.
description: The questions raised this week by by Edgar Paz Barnica, the Foreign Minister of Honduras, about his country's relations with the United States should come as no surprise to anyone who has been following our attempts to conduct our Central American policy out of his tiny, impoverished country. In Honduras, as elsewhere in the third world, Washington has underestimated the power of nationalism.

title: UNLIFE INCOME FUND reports earnings for As of Sept 30
description: Asset figures represent net assets.

title: Shard of Glass Kills Student
description: A 17-year-old football player rushing because he was late for a team meeting accidentally ran through a window and was killed when a shard of plate glass punctured his heart, officials said Tuesday. The student, Brian Spruill of Pittsburgh, was late for the meeting Sunday at Bethany College when he ran through a large window near the main door of Richardson Hall, said Todd Bullard, the college president.

title: BRIEFING;
description: Tudors in Town Tonight

title: AERONAUTICS EXPERT INVENTED FLOW METER
description: David M. Potter 3d, an inventor, explorer and founder of the Potter Aeronautical Corporation of Union, N.J., died on Sept. 29 at Warren Hospital in Phillipsburg, N.J. He was 79 years old and lived in Martinsville, N.J.

title: String Quartet Concert
description: The Mendelssohn String Quartet will give a free concert on Oct. 15 at 7 P.M. at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, Amsterdam Avenue at 112th Street.

title: French Crack Down On Illegal Aliens
description: The French Government announced a new crackdown on illegal immigrants today but stressed the need to fight racism and to help foreign workers already legally settled in France.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;
description: City Hall, Then and Now

title: Military Contracts
description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation won contracts worth $754 million from the Navy and $43.9 million from the Air Force, while the Defense Logistics Agency awarded a $327.9 million contract for jet fuel to the Shell Oil Company, the Defense Department said. The Navy contract is for 35 F/A-18 aircraft for sale to Australia.

title: THURSDAY SPORTS Hockey
description: Rangers vs. Hartford Whalers, at Madison Square Garden, 7:35 P.M. The National Hockey League's regular season gets under way with the Rangers still hunting an extraordinarily elusive championship.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ;
description: A $46.9 million issue of Dallas general obligation bonds was offered yesterday with yields ranging from 6.50 percent for bonds due in 1985 to 9.20 percent in 1994 and 10.30 percent in 2004. The underwriters are led by the Interfirst Bank Dallas.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THURSDAY, OCTOBER 11, 1984

title: Arab-American Group Claims 'Intimidation' Blocked Its Ad
description: ''Intimidation by pro-Israeli groups'' has frightened 20 New York radio stations out of running an advertisement by the National Association of Arab Americans, the group's executive director said yesterday.

title: WORLD STEELMAKERS HOPEFUL
description: For several years, the world's steelmakers have felt that they were in a bottomless pit, dug by excess capacity and deepened by falling demand. But the dozens of steel executives who assembled here this week for the annual conference of the International Iron and Steel Institute, seemed to feel they had reached bottom and were coming up again.

title: BROWN STUDENTS VOTE ON ATOM WAR 'SUICIDE PILLS'
description: Undergraduates at Brown University began voting today on a proposal to urge the university health service to stockpile ''suicide pills'' for use in case of nuclear war.

title: MONDALE ASSAILS REAGAN ON MIDEAST
description: Walter F. Mondale accused President Reagan yesterday of ''meager involvement'' in the Middle East and said that Mr. Reagan was now ''frantic'' as a result of last Sunday's Presidential debate.

title: No Headline
description: Assumed Names Used In G.O.P. Vote Canvass

title: Mets Raise Prices Of Tickets by $1
description: The Mets announced a $1 increase in ticket prices yesterday for the 1985 season.

title: SHUTZ, ON VISIT TO EL SALVADOR, HAILS PEACE BID
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz today warmly praised the offer by President Jose Napoleon Duarte of El Salvador to meet guerrilla leaders next Monday.

title: ;  Slippery Floor
description: A persistent slick spot on the floor of the Forum in Inglewood, Calif., has left Magic Johnson of the Los Angeles Lakers with a cut over his left eye and Walter Davis of the Phoenix Suns with sprained ligaments in his left knee that will keep him out of action for three to four weeks. The mishaps occurred in an exhibition game that was called off early in the fourth quarter Tuesday night at the request of the Suns' coach, John MacLeod , after several players had slipped at the same spot, near one of the baskets.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: STILL COMING UP ROSES Gypsy,'' which Brooks Atkinson of The New York Times called ''the most satisfying musical of the season'' when it opened on Broadway 25 years ago with a cast headed by Ethel Merman, has never really faded away. With a book (based on the life of Gypsy Rose Lee) by Arthur Laurents, music by Jule Styne and lyrics by Stephen Sondheim, ''Gypsy'' is an irresistible comeback item.

title: SCOUTING;
description: Recruiting Time

title: WALGREEN CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Including a gain of $3,598,000 from the sale of equity in the company's Mexican operations.

title: Interest in RMS
description: Joseph Bradway Jr., a New York investor, told the Securities and Exchange Commission that he had obtained options to buy 345,427 shares, or 21.1 percent of the total outstanding, of RMS Electronics Inc., and that if he exercised the options he intended to become chairman and chief executive. Mr. Bradway acquired the options Oct. 4 from the company's current chairman, Arthur Fink, and members of Mr. Fink's family and related trusts. An RMS spokesman said the transaction was a friendly one.

title: SOURCE CAPITAL INC reports earnings for As of Sept 30
People
description: * James F. Eckl has been appointed president of Gray & Kilgore, a subsidiary of Ross Roy, Detroit.

title: JUDGE REFUSES TO REJECT SUIT AGAINST U.S. BY BIKINI ISLAND
description: A Federal judge today rejected the Government's motion to dismiss a lawsuit by the people of the Bikini atoll in the Marshall Islands, who are seeking $450 million in damages for the contamination of their islands by nuclear bomb testing.

title: Oklahoma Back Made Ineligible
description: Mike Clopton, reserve quarterback for the Oklahoma Sooners, today was declared ineligible for further competition ''pending a review of information pertinent to his eligibility status,'' Coach Barry Switzer said.

title: SPORTS STUDY VOTED BY N.C.A.A. GROUP
description: The chairman of the new N.C.A.A. Presidents' Commission said today that the commission had voted to initiate studies of ways to assure compliance with N.C.A.A. rules and to bring under control the revenues and costs of the nation's intercollegiate athletic programs.

title: MISSION WEST PROPERTIES reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Including tax credits of $139,000 for the quarter and $700,000 for the 9 months. c-Including tax credits of $382,000 for the quarter and $595,000 for the 9 months.

title: 600 in Lehman Merger Cut About 600 employees of
description: Shearson/American Express

title: Jostens Purchase
description: Jostens Inc. said it had agreed to acquire Hazel Inc., a manufacturer of leather and vinyl business products based in Washington, Mo., for about $25 million. Jostens makes and sells school rings and yearbooks.

title: GENTILITY AND PROSPERITY ARE FADING AT CHURCHILL DOWNS
description: In the months since the last of the Derby Day revelers strolled off the infield and ''My Old Kentucky Home'' faded into memory for another year, things at Churchill Downs have been less genteel than usual.

title: THE LEVERAGE OF OUR WEALTHIEST 400
description: At a trivial level, it is almost impossible not to be interested in Forbes magazine's annual list of the 400 wealthiest individuals, minimum net worth $150 million, and 82 wealthiest families, minimum net worth $200 million. Subconsciously, we read their biographies hoping to find the elixir that will add us to the list. While the elixir - a rich father - is to be found (all of the 82 families and 241 of the 400 wealthiest individuals inherited all or a major part of their fortunes), it doesn't help most of us to point this out to our fathers.

title: UNILEVER ASSURED OF WINNING TEA MAKER
description: Unilever P.L.C. increased its bid today for the Brooke Bond Group P.L.C, the world's largest tea company, by 11 percent, to $478.5 million, and then snapped up enough of Brooke Bond's shares in trading on the stock exchange to assure victory in its long takeover campaign.

title: Peat Marwick Partners Elect a New Chairman
description: The partners of Peat Marwick yesterday elected Larry D. Horner to the posts of chairman and chief executive officer of the Big Eight accounting firm. The appointment is effective immediately.

title: EAST GERMAN INDICTED IN SPY PLOT
description: A 67-year-old East German woman was indicted by a Federal grand jury in Brooklyn yesterday on a charge of conspiracy to commit espionage for the Soviet Union.

title: WALTON CONFRONTED BY LYONS ON ROLE
description: GERALD ESKENAZI

title: Goal by Davis Helps U.S. Win
description: Rick Davis, the captain, scored a goal midway through the second half to break a 1-1 tie Tuesday night, and the United States went on to defeat El Salvador, 3-1, in the Columbus Cup, an exhibition soccer tournament. In a later cup match, Mexico defeated Colombia, 1-0.

title: LONG-DISTANCE PHONE SERVICES: A GUIDE
description: ACROSS the country, phone customers are being faced with a choice: Which of an ever-growing number of long distance phone companies will provide their primary long-distance service. It is a decision that can save them money. But it is a confusing one as well.

title: MISSED START OF HER TRIAL IN DEATH
description: The wife of a prominent New Jersey mayor and banker was arrested in Philadelphia today after failing for two days to appear at her trial here. She is charged with murdering her 2-year-old adopted son nine years ago.

title: SCIENTISTS SAY GENES IN AIDS MAY HAMPER VACCINE WORK
description: Genetic variations have been found in samples of the virus believed to cause acquired immune deficiency syndrome, or AIDS, and they could pose ''significant problems for vaccine development'' according to one of the leaders in research on the deadly disorder.

title: All Along to Run the Rothmans
description: All Along, who in 1983 became the first foreign-based thoroughbred to be voted North America's horse of the year, will be shipped from Paris to Woodbine here Sunday to run in the Rothmans International on the grass on Oct. 21, the Ontario Jockey Club announced today.

title: POPE BEGINS A HISPANIC CELEBRATION
description: Pope John Paul II arrived here today on the first leg of a trip beginning a nine-year celebration of the 500th anniversary of the discovery of the New World by Christopher Columbus.

title: RECITAL: OHLSSON PLAYS AT CARNEGIE
description: GARRICK OHLSSON'S piano recital at Carnegie Hall Tuesday night pointed out the pockets of grace and elegance that grow within the combat zone of 20th century music. When these qualities were absent from the music as he found it, Mr. Ohlsson supplied them himself.

title: TELEDYNE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including net income from unconsolidated subsidiaries of $1.9 million for the quarter and $264.2 million for the 9 months. c-Including net income from unconsolidated subsidiaries of $19.3 million for the quarter and $79.9 million for the 9 months.

title: Edward J. Jennings Jr.; Led Sunshine Biscuits
description: Edward J. Jennings Jr., chairman and chief executive officer of Sunshine Biscuits Inc., died Friday at New York Hospital after a long illness. He was 60 years old and lived in Las Vegas, Nev.

title: SOVIET ARMS BREACHES CHARGED
description: A White House advisory panel said in a report made public today that the Soviet Union had consistently followed ''a pattern of pursuing military advantage'' by selectively disregarding its arms control commitments.

title: SALVADOR CHIEF ASKS BISHOP TO ACT AS GO-BETWEEN
description: President Jose Napoleon Duarte of El Salvador said today that he had asked the Archbishop of San Salvador, Arturo Rivera y Damas, to act as an intermediary to settle the details of next week's meeting with rebel leaders in El Salvador.

THE CITY ; ;  Subway Crime Up 4.7% in August
description: Major crimes in the subway system rose 4.7 percent in August compared with August of last year, the first such increase in two months, according to figures released yesterday by the transit police.

title: PLEXUS RESOURCES reports earnings for Year to June 30
CONCERT: CONDUCTOR IN DEBUT
description: MYUNG-WHUN CHUNG, the Korean-born conductor who made his debut with the New York Philharmonic last night at Avery Fisher Hall, was clearly no neophyte on whom the orchestra's management took a nervous risk. Instead, they have entrusted three full subscription weeks right at the beginning of the season to this ''debutant,'' and last night's program will be repeated four times - tonight, tomorrow afternoon, Saturday and Tuesday.

title: MILAN SHOWS: ARMANI'S MINI LENGTHS
description: In the city where the art of fashion showings has been carefully honed, Giorgio Armani scored an astounding success Tuesday night.

title: 'WE ARE LESS SECURE THAN FOUR YEARS AGO'
description: To the Editor:

title: MODERN MUSEUM OPENS REVAMPED FILM CENTER
description: More than 150 film makers, film exhibitors and distributors, critics, scholars and friends of the Museum of Modern Art gathered last night to celebrate the dedication of the museum's redesigned and expanded Film Study Center and the opening of the new Louis B. Mayer screening room.

title: TOTAL SYSTEM SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Year-ago share earnings and shares outstanding have been adjusted to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid in September 1984.

title: Investment Bank Note Offering
description: The European Investment Bank, an international development bank owned by the 10 member countries of the European Economic Community, yesterday offered $200 million of 12 5/8 percent notes due in 1999 at a price of 99.3, to yield 12.73 percent, through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.

title: MUSIC: MUIR QUARTET PLAYS AT 92D ST. Y
description: RICHARD WILSON'S String Quartet No. 3, a work of substance and expressivity, was given its first New York performance by the Muir String Quartet at the 92d Street Y Tuesday night. Commissioned for the Muir Quartet by the Walter W. Naumburg Foundation and composed in 1982, the work was given it premiere at Yale last year and has been performed in London by the Delme Quartet.

title: CHANCES TO IMPROVE A CITY SUPERAGENCY
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWS SUMMARY;
description: THURSDAY, OCTOBER 11, 1984 International Prime Minister Shimon Peres will press next year to secure a dramatic increase in American grants to Israel, from the current level of $2.6 billion to more than $4 billion annually, according to Israeli officials. Administration officials said Israel is already the largest beneficiary of American aid, not only this year but throughout the history of the foreign aid program. (Page A1, Column 4.)

title: Cities Service
description: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation said that it would have a gain of $150 million if a Kansas commission were to approve a proposed oil project that would be operated by its Cities Service subsidiary. The venture, an infill drilling project, would be at the Hugoton Field in Kansas, formerly owned by Cities. The Kansas Corporation Commission is considering Cities' request to reduce the allowed spacing of wells in the field and to drill more wells between the existing ones.

title: DEBATE LIFTS DEMOCRATS IN SENATE RACES
description: Squeezing into the back of a car to head for his next campaign stop, Representative Paul Simon said Walter F. Mondale's showing in the Presidential debate Sunday had given a lift to his close race against Charles H. Percy, the three-term Republican Senator from Illinois.

title: Synthetic Fuels Board
description: President Reagan nominated two men today to fill vacancies on the board of the Synthetic Fuels Corporation, enough to give the embattled body the four-member quorum it needs to resume making financial commitments to synthetic fuels projects.

title: KOHLBERG WILL BUY MOTEL 6
description: The City Investing Company, which announced only two weeks ago that it would sell all of its operations, said late yesterday that it had agreed to sell its Motel 6 budget-motel company to an investor group headed by Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company, a leading Wall Street investment house, for $565 million.

title: Financial Corp. Layoffs Seen LOS ANGELES, Oct. 10 (AP)
description: The Financial Corporation of

title: PENN: MAKING UP FOR LOST TIME
description: The granting of honorary citizenship to the British Quaker who founded Pennsylvania will come a bit too late for him to appreciate. Penn died in 1718, at the age of 73, on a return trip to England from his beloved New World.

title: Send the Money With the Patients The scandal of New York's mental health system is no secret: the state spends most of its money on big upstate psychiatric hospitals, even though most of their inmates were discharged years ago to inadequate community programs.
description: Reform depends on a massive shift of resources and a rational plan for achieving it. The plan offered recently by a governor's commission deserves a fair trial.

title: Nippon Air Gets Loan
description: The Export-Import Bank said today that it was providing a 10-year, $13 million loan at 12 percent interest to help the All Nippon Airways Company buy $20.1 million of jet engines from the General Electric Company.

title: Thai Leader to Quit Hospital
description: Prime Minister Prem Tinsulanonda has recovered from a lung ailment and will leave the hospital by the end of the week, a Government spokesman said today. The 64-year-old Prime Minister entered a military hospital on Sept. 29 for treatment of pleurisy and a blocked artery leading to his right lung.

title: SENATE REPORT FINDS NO ARERICANS AIDED SALVADORAN KILLINGS
description: The Senate Intelligence Committee said today that it had found no evidence that United States officials had supported death squads in El Salvador.

description: Share earnings reflect a 4-for-3 stock split in March 1984.

title: HERS
description: The Hers column is currently being written by Perri Klass, a student at Harvard Medical School and the author of a novel,''Recombinations,'' to be published next year.

title: DISCORD DELAYING REPORT ON AQUINO
description: The long-overdue report by the panel investigating the assassination of the opposition leader, Benigno S. Aquino Jr., has been delayed by disputes among the panel members over the findings, according to board officials.

title: THOMAS INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a reduction of $2.2 million for the quarter and 9 months from the discontinuance of the company's electronic ballast operation and income of $450,000, or 6 cents a share, for the quarter and 9 months from the sale of certain properties.

title: Banking Merger
description: Southwest Bancshares Inc. and the Mercantile Texas Corporation said they had completed their merger to form a new company, Mcorp, following approval by both companies' shareholders. Based on Sept. 30 figures, the combined company would have assets of $20.4 billion and deposits of $15.9 billion.

title: DANCE: BALANCHINE'S 'TEMPERAMENTS'
description: DANCE Theater of Harlem, playing at City Center through Sunday, is a company of dancers who fill the stage with a welcoming warmth. That quality brought a special radiance to George Balanchine's ''The Four Temperaments,'' performed on Tuesday.

title: DASH INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Mondale Is Endorsed By 3 Jewish Leaders
description: Walter F. Mondale was endorsed today by the leaders of the rabbinical organizations of the nation's three major Jewish movements, Orthodox, Conservative and Reform.

title: THE CITY ; ;  $2.5 MillionAward
description: A State Supreme Court jury awarded $2.5 million in damages yesterday to a 3-year-old mentally retarded Queens girl.

title: IN EARLIER VICE-PRESIDENT DEBATE DOLE AND MONDALE TANGLED BITTERLY
description: Only once before tonight have Vice- Presidential candidates met in a nationally broadcast debate. On Oct 15, 1976, Senators Bob Dole of Kansas, Republican, and Walter F. Mondale of Minnesota, a Democrat, confronted each other for 75 minutes on a theater stage in Houston.

title: SPAIN'S ENVOY IS KIDNAPPED IN WEST BEIRUT, THEN FREED
description: The Spanish Ambassador to Lebanon was kidnapped in front of his embassy in Beirut today and was freed unharmed more than three hours later, a Spanish Embassy spokesman said.

title: SOCIAL SECURITY PAY LAG LAID TO COMPUTER DELAYS
description: About 2.5 million recipients of Social Security benefits who were still working in 1979 and 1980 were underpaid about $2 billion by the Government because of computer delays in compiling work records, Congressional auditors have reported.

description: Service Area Service

title: KRUEGER, W.A. CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid May 9.

description: The Retired President

title: 500 Disneyland Strikers Defy Bid to Return
description: About 500 angry Disneyland strikers scorned an ultimatum today and marched around the ticket booths to dump their replacement notifications into a trash bin.

title: A LOW PROFILE FOR FED IN CAMPAIGN THIS TIME
description: The Federal Reserve, like a baseball umpire, is always happiest when nobody notices it. And in the current Presidential campaign, being waged partly over the level of interest rates, remarkably little is being said about the Fed. The nation's central bank has succeeded in avoiding criticism from either side.

title: MONTGOMERY STREET INCOME SECURITIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
3 TV FILMS ON SUICIDE BY YOUTHS
description: In recent years, television movies have taken their lead from the headlines and have addressed almost every widely publicized social issue, from nuclear war to child abuse. This year's fashionable topic is teen-age suicide, the subject of three upcoming television movies.

title: Convicted of Graft, Nigerian Gets 23 Years
description: A former Finance Minister was jailed today for 23 years for corruption that, according to a tribunal, earned him more than $3.9 million.

title: FIRST FINANCIAL MANAGEMENT reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
POLL FINDS GARDENING IS TOP LEISURE ACTIVITY
description: A Gallup Poll ranks gardening, including lawn growing, as the leading leisure activity among American households for the second consecutive year.

title: LSI LOGIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including tax credits.

title: POP: KLAUSNER
description: TERRI KLAUSNER is one of the more talented of a new breed of Broadway singer who has been influenced almost as much by rock records as by longstanding theatrical traditions. Miss Klausner, who has starred in ''Evita,'' ''A Chorus Line'' and ''Sophisticated Ladies,'' has a thin, cutting soprano that carries easily over a large space.

title: DELCHAMPS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 29
SOCIETY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
PARKER PEN CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Including a gain of $690,000 on the sale of the company's 80 percent interest in First Deposit Corp.

title: DESIGN NOTEBOOK
description: Philip Langdon is a New Haven architecture and design writer who focuses on everyday American surroundings.

title: 'THE ISSUES ARE WITH US'
description: Candidates for President and Vice President vary their remarks from place to place, but in most speeches there is a common body of material.

title: Oriole Official Out of Hospital
description: Hank Peters, general manager of the Baltimore Orioles, collapsed Tuesday night at Jack Murphy Stadium during a reception after the first game of the World Series and was briefly hospitalized.

title: SYSTONETICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Including tax credits of $10,808 for the quarter and $126,436 for the 6 months. c-Net income.

title: Citicorp Names Head For Coast Thrift Unit
description: Eduardo Valencia has been named president and chief executive of Citibank Savings of California, Citicorp announced.

title: CRIME AND PORK
description: By attaching the Reagan Administration's anticrime proposals to the emergency spending legislation needed to keep Government in business, Congress is serving up a strange meal of pork and crime. It's a bipartisan stew designed for the palate of a President who had threatened to veto the spending bill alone.

title: REAGAN'S HEALTH: HOW ISSUE EMERGED
description: Why did the issue of President Reagan's fitness for office because of his age and health vault into headlines this week?

title: Perry Drug to Add 46 Car Part Stores
description: In its fifth acquisition in five months, Perry Drug Stores Inc. said it had signed a definitive agreement to acquire 46 discount auto parts stores from Corvairs Inc. of Columbus, Ohio, a subsidiary of the Consolidated Stores Corporation.

title: M.D. LEWIS, MODEL CITIES AIDE
description: Maely Dufty Lewis, who helped direct the preparation of government grants for the Model Cities program in Harlem and was a research director for the Navajo Indian nation, died Monday at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. She was in her late 60's and lived in South Orange, N.J., and Washington.

title: FAREWELL TO HUBRIS; William Safire
description: -smug Republicans are wondering what to do now that Ronald Reagan has been creamed by Walter Mondale in the opening debate.

title: THEATER: NEXT WAVE FESTIVAL OPENS
description: ''THE Games,'' conceived and directed by Meredith Monk and Ping Chong, is a time trip to a post-apocalyptical future, a thoughtful contemplation of contemporary values, a science fiction space opera and a sports- arts event. On Tuesday, the meta- media performance piece auspiciously opened the Next Wave Festival at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

title: More Stores in Japan Get Poisoned-Candy Threat
description: Extortionists have sent letters to some stores in Osaka threatening to poison more candy if the stores do not stop selling Morinaga & Company sweets, officials said today.

title: EDITOR'S NOTE
description: Under this heading, The Times amplifies articles or rectifies what the editors consider significant lapses of fairness, balance or perspective.

title: Article 261496 -- No Title
description: Seventeen cultural institutions in New York City received $7.9 million in ''challenge grants'' yesterday from the National Endowment for the Arts, slightly less than the $8.3 million awarded last year to 13 institutions in the city.

title: Milwaukee Road: New Bidding Clash
description: The Soo Line Railroad Company yesterday attacked as ''too much and too late'' a sweetened bid by the Chicago and North Western Transportation Company for the bankrupt Milwaukee Road, which the rival bidders have been pursuing for four years.

title: TPEX EXPLORATION reports earnings for Year to June 30
Lotus to Build in Dublin
description: The Lotus Development Corporation will open a software production plant in Dublin as part of its European expansion program, Chuck Digate, the company's internatonal operations director, said today. The plant will cost about $2.5 million.

title: Colt Net Rises 14.5%
description: Colt Industries, citing operating income gains by three of its four divisions - automotive, machinery and equipment, and materials and components - announced that net income in the third quarter increased 14.5 percent, to $30 million, or $1.44 a share, from $26.2 million, or $1.06 a share, in the corresponding quarter a year earlier. Sales advanced 11.2 percent, to $435.5 million, from $391.7 million. Colt said that Aerospace operating results were adversely affected by lower sales by the company's Menasco Texas and Chandler Evans Control Systems divisions.

title: BIG APPLE FIX-UP BEGINS TOMORROW
description: THE third annual Big Apple Fix-Up, a three-day symposium of exhibits, lectures and demonstrations on home improvement, begins today at Madison Square Garden. For the past several weeks, posters advertising the event have been appearing in subways and on buses throughout the city. They show a bemused Mayor Koch on a stepladder putting a bright red coat of paint on a giant apple.

title: Stocks End Mixed After Late Gains
description: The stock market made a dramatic turnabout late yesterday in accelerated trading, finishing mixed after being down sharply earlier.

title: MUBARAK AND HUSSEIN HOLD TALKS ON YACHT
description: King Hussein of Jordan and President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt met aboard a yacht off this Red Sea resort this afternoon, the second day of their discussions.

title: INNOVATIVE SOFTWARE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BIO-LOGIC SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net income.

title: Motorist Killed as Fire Truck And a Car Collide in Queens
description: A motorist was killed and six firefighters were injured last night when a fire truck and an automobile collided at Union Turnpike and Hollis Court Boulevard in the Fresh Meadows section of Queens, the police said.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption yesterday with an article about the United Farm Workers incorrectly identified a man in a lettuce field. He was a farm worker whose name is not known.

title: TRANSIT OFFICERS SAID TO HAVE BEEN GIVEN IMMUNITY IN DEATH
description: Lawyers for the family of Michael Stewart said yesterday that eight Transit Authority police officers had been granted immunity from prosecution in connection with the death of the Brooklyn man last fall.

title: FREDERICK BRISSON, PRODUCER OF FILMS AND BROADWAY PLAYS
description: Frederick Brisson, a theater and film producer, died on Monday at the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center after a stroke. He was 71 years old.

title: EXPORT BILL IS PASSED IN SENATE
description: The Senate tonight passed a last-minute compromise version of legislation to control strategic exports to the Soviet Union and other countries.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: '' 'Go and teach to all peoples.' It is these words of the Teacher that pushed me today toward the lands of America, in a voyage that has much to do with His missionary mandate.''

title: SCAN-OPTICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a charge of $19,000 from the Tax Reform Act of 1984. c-Including an extraordinary credit of $124,000.

title: WACHOVIA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Year-ago per share figures have been restated to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid Aug. 31.

title: ABC PONDERS FATE OF 'CALL TO GLORY'
description: It was the new prime time series with everything going for it: an unusually extensive promotional campaign during the Olympic Games, a large audience for its opening episode and critical acclaim.

title: Baxter Travenol
description: Baxter Travenol Laboratories Inc. said its earnings for all of 1984 will be lower than last year's $218.1 million, or $1.54 a share. It attributed much of the slippage to declining hospital admissions, cost-containment efforts by the Federal Government and a drop in foreign currency valuations. On the New York Stock Exchange today, its shares closed at $13.25, down 37 1/2 cents.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about the International Business Machines Corporation's acquisition of the Rolm Corporation incorrectly identified Paul J. Rizzo. He is I.B.M.'s vice chairman.

title: POLL FINDS DEBATE GAVE MONDALE A SMALL GAIN
description: Walter F. Mondale gained slightly on the issues of taxes and perhaps on deficits, strengthened his image as a leader and was the nation's overwhelming choice as the winner of Sunday's debate with President Reagan, a New York Times/CBS News Poll shows. Even so, Mr. Reagan continued to hold a wide lead.

title: VW PLANS TO MAKE CARS IN CHINA
description: Volkswagenwerk A.G. signed a 25-year contract today to build Santana sedans and engines in China. It will be the first time a foreign auto maker will produce passenger cars in the Communist country. The American Motors Corporation is building a factory in China to produce Jeeps under a 20-year deal signed in May 1983.

title: LOMAS & NETTLETON MORTGAGE INVESTORS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SOME JOURNAL CASE CHARGES DROPPED
description: The Justice Department said yesterday that it was dropping the most controversial portion of its insider-trading charges against R. Foster Winans, a former reporter for The Wall Street Journal indicted for leaking advance information about what the newspaper would print in its ''Heard on the Street'' column.

title: Ex-Airman Sentenced to Die
description: A 21-year-old former Air Force airman was sentenced Tuesday to die in the electric chair for killing two boys who were abducted and stabbed repeatedly. John J. Joubert, a former airman at Offutt Air Force Base from Portland, Me., pleaded guilty in July to first-degree murder in the deaths of Danny Joe Eberle, 13 years old, and Christopher Paul Walden, 12.

title: ; Appreciating Lance Parrish
description: SAN DIEGO

title: HEALTH SPENDING RISES MORE SLOWLY
description: Americans spent $355.4 billion for health care last year, representing 10.8 percent of the gross national product, a record, the Department of Health and Human Services reported today.

title: LINCOLN CENTER PLANNING MAJOR NEW BUILDING
description: Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts plans to erect a major new building, its first since the opening of the Juilliard School in 1969, according to center officials.

title: Debt Issues
description: * BankAmerica Corp. filed a shelf offering of up to $1 billion in debt securities. It said it would use the proceeds chiefly to finance investments of credit to its subsidiaries for lending and lease financing activities.

BEVACQUA RECOUPS FOR HIS STUMBLING
description: This time he didn't stumble. Kurt Bevacqua performed many other physical activities on his circuitous route around the bases tonight, but he did not stumble while running out his three-run homer in the fifth inning that electrified the home crowd, gave the Padres a 5-3 victory and tied the World Series.

title: YALE STRIKE IS WATCHED BY UNIONS ACROSS THE U.S.
description: If the striking clerical and technical workers at Yale University can win a full contract at such a prestigious university, the drive may strengthen the resolve of unionists at other universities and in the private work place. ''The university community'' across the country ''is looking at this as a test,'' said Jack Golodner, director of the A.F.L.- C.I.O.'s Department for Professional Employees and a Yale Law School graduate.

title: FOR THE PERENNIAL TULIP, NITROGEN IS IMPORTANT
description: OF all the spectacular spring bulb displays, tulips remain tops. Tulips can be chosen to bloom from early April through May. For a continuous display incorporate the earliest: Kaufmanniana, Greigii and Fosteriana, followed by the single and double earlies, then the Darwin hybrids. The last tulips to flower in May are the lily-flowered, double-late Darwins and parrots.

title: REPORTS OF INSIDER TRADING
description: The New York and American stock exchanges issued yesterday their latest reports of changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and large stockholders in companies whose shares are listed on the exchanges.

title: DISENCHANTMENT BEHIND CAMPBELL TRADE
description: Running inside, running outside, breaking tackles, Earl Campbell used his size and strength to become one of the National Football League's most powerful and prolific runners. He gained more than 1,300 yards in five of his six seasons with the Houston Oilers, and he began this season as the ninth-leading rusher in the history of the National Football League.

title: ;  Globetrotters' Case
description: They didn't exactly fit the descriptions: three armed black men wearing blue-and-red warm-up suits who had held up a jewelry store about five miles away earlier in the day. But there

title: BARNETT BANKS OF FLORIDA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
PADRES RALLY TO BEAT TIGERS AND EVEN SERIES
description: The San Diego Padres tied the World Series at one game apiece tonight when they rallied to defeat the Detroit Tigers, 5-3, on a three-run home run by Kurt Bevacqua, the man who took the big stumble the night before.

title: VOTER REGISTRATION HALTED AS GURU IS PICKETED
description: Officials today prevented some of the followers of the guru Bhagwan Shree Rajneesh from registering to vote in rural Wasco County, where other local residents said they feared a government takeover by the religious group.

title: NIEKRO WILL RETURN TO YANKS
description: Casting aside his annual thoughts of retirement, Phil Niekro confirmed today that he had accepted the Yankees' invitation to pitch again next season.

title: NEWSPAPER REPORTERS EXCLUDED
description: Defense Department officials today disclosed the makeup of a press pool the Government would form to cover the initial stages of surprise military operations. It would include news agency, radio, television and magazine reporters but not reporters from individual newspapers.

title: CONFEREES AGREE ON SPENDING BILL, ENDING DEADLOCK
description: House, Senate and White House negotiators today broke a weeklong deadlock, reaching agreement on a $470 billion spending bill that Congress must approve before it can adjourn.

title: NO PERIL SEEN FROM PCB LEAK IN FIRE
description: Oil contaminated by PCB's leaked from the undercarriage of a burning railway car in Grand Central Terminal on Tuesday, city officials said yesterday. But the officials insisted that the leak did not endanger the public or the firefighters.

title: Iranian Executions Reported
description: At least 25 supporters of the People's Mujahedeen guerrilla group were executed in Iranian cities last month, representatives of the group said here today.

title: Dr.WilliamD.ArnoldIsDead; Orthopedic Specialist in City
description: Dr. William David Arnold, director of the combined fracture service of the New York Hospital and the Hospital for Special Surgery since 1972, died last Thursday at New York Hospital. He was 59 years old and lived in Manhattan and Shady, N.Y.

title: Texaco Stake
description: The American Exploration Company said it had agreed to acquire Texaco Inc.'s 40 percent interest in the Wyco Pipe Line Company.

title: A RETROSPECTIVE OF FILMS BY NARUSE
description: Knowledge of art and artists is not always a matter of discovery of the unknown. It is, more often than not, a rediscovery of the known that in past years got lost in the shuffle of popularity, as attested by the film retrospective of the work of Mikio Naruse at the Japan Society and the Museum of Modern Art.

description: The past few weeks have not been happy ones for officials at the Farmers Home Administration, who had hoped for a tranquil fall after a painful summer of criticism.

title: Chile Opposition Chiefs Are Freed From Jail
description: Seven Chilean opposition leaders were freed today after 24 hours in prison when President Augusto Pinochet decided to drop charges arising from a protest last month against the military Government.

title: Stelco Closing
description: Stelco Inc. said that it would shut one of two remaining open- hearth furnaces at its plant here and lay off 450 workers.

title: Lawyer Wins Parole In Convict Escape
description: Mary Evans, a former lawyer who fell in love with an armed robber, helped him escape from prison and spent 139 days with him on the run, won parole today after admitting she had made ''a serious mistake.''

title: JUDGE ORDERS E.P.A. TO ACT ON ACID RAIN COMPLAINTS
description: A Federal district judge has ruled that the Environmental Protection Agency unlawfully delayed a final ruling on complaints from nine Northeastern states about acid rain.

title: WILLIAM BURDEN, EX-MUSEUM PRESIDENT, DIES
description: William A. M. Burden, a longtime president of the Museum of Modern Art who oversaw much of its expansion in the 1950's and 1960's, died of heart disease yesterday at New York Hospital. He was 78 years old and a resident of Manhattan.

title: Bridge:Grand National Team Play Under Way 2 Months Early
description: A major scheduling change involving a national championship may have taken a few players in the New York metropolitan area by surprise.

title: STANDARD SHARES reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
AGILE NOMINEE FOR JERSEY HIGH COURT
description: When Governor Kean called Gary Saul Stein early Monday to offer him a seat on the New Jersey Supreme Court, the 51- year-old lawyer marked the occasion later by going out and playing two sets of tennis. His duties since 1981 as Director of Policy and Planning have all but kept Mr. Stein, once ranked by the Eastern Tennis Association, off the tennis court. Instead he has been in the center of efforts to end prison overcrowding, create a stable financial source for transportation and develop the state's new science and technology program.

title: Navy Intelligence Expert Indicted in Photo Sale
description: A Navy intelligence analyst has been indicted by a Federal grand jury here on charges of providing a British military magazine with secret photographs of Soviet ships under construction.

title: Independent Network News Sues for Access to Debates
description: The Independent Network News filed suit yesterday to be allowed to set up its own cameras for the remaining Presidential and Vice-Presidential debates.

title: Coalition of Nuns Criticizes Bishops' Stand on Abortion
description: The National Coalition of American Nuns today criticized the Roman Catholic hierarchy's campaign to make abortion illegal, rejecting ''the claim that to be pro-choice is to be pro-abortion.''

title: BANK FEE RELIEF IN MASSACHUSETTS
description: Starting today, consumers under age 18 or over 65 in Massachusetts no longer have to pay banking fees for checking or savings accounts. Thus, with a simply worded law, Massachusetts becomes the first state to provide consumer relief from rising bank charges.

title: AVACARE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net income.

description: To the Editor:

title: HILTON HOTELS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including a gain on the sale of property of $26,798,000 for the quarter and 9 months.

title: ISREALIS SAY PERES WILL SEEK BIG RISE IN AID NEXT YEAR
description: Israeli officials said today that Prime Minister Shimon Peres intended to press next year to obtain a dramatic increase in American grants to Israel, from the current level of $2.6 billion this year to more than $4 billion.

title: COSTA RICA SEEKS PEACE PLAN SHIFT
description: The Foreign Minister of Costa Rica said today that his nation supported the regional peace plan for Central America but saw a need for changes in its timetable for arms reduction.

title: Metro-North Commuter Train Strikes Truck, Injuring Driver
description: A Metro-North commuter train struck a panel truck at a grade crossing between the Valhalla and Hawthorne stations in Westchester County at the height of the evening rush hour yesterday, injuring one man and tying up service in both directions.

title: SCOUTING;
description: Bowl Scouts To See Army

title: Market Place; Beer Industry's Uncertainties
description: EVERY industry has its problems, and beer is no exception. The nation's brewers, in fact, have been coping with a formidable set of difficulties during the last two years, a time of flourishing economic recovery. These problems range from increases in the legal drinking age and growing public concern about alcohol abuse to changes in the nation's life styles and demographics that have depressed beer sales.

title: HYMAN LITTMAN
description: Hyman Littman, founder of Littman Jewelry, the largest chain of jewelry stores in the Northeast, died of heart disease Tuesday at his home in Hollywood, Fla. He was 81 years old and had lived in Hollywood for the last 10 years.

title: ;  Wings Get Sittler
description: In a move for youth, the Philadelphia Flyers traded the veteran center Darryl Sittler to the Detroit Red Wings for the left wings Murray Craven and Joe Paterson . Sittler, 34 years old, was acquired by the Flyers from the Toronto Maple Leafs in January 1982.

title: BRITISH MINE UNION IS FINED $250,000
RUMPOLE RETURNS TO THE OLD BAILEY
description: ALTHOUGH the return of the irascible Horace Rumpole to the rather timid halls of public television is reason enough for celebration, of the proper British sort, even the barrister's most ardent fans are likely to find ''Rumpole's Return'' decidedly plodding. The two-hour special, which was produced for Thames TV in 1980, can be seen tonight on WNET/Channel 13 around 11, depending on the windup of the debate between Vice President Bush and Representative Geraldine A. Ferraro.

title: THE REGION ; ;  Fire Threatened Cyanide Drums
description: A fire today heavily damaged a metalplating factory in the Ironbound section where drums of cyanide and sulfuric acid were stored. The fire was brought under control before the barrels were damaged, authorities said.

title: SERVED 28 YEARS IN CITY COURT
description: William S. Evans, a retired justice of the old City Court of New York, died yesterday at Boca Raton (Fla.) Hospital. He was 100 years old and lived in Boca Raton.

title: TOOTHPASTE PUMP BATTLE NEAR
description: Stumble out of bed. Grope for bathroom lights. Reach for toothbrush, toothpaste. Pump.

title: Weinberger at NATO Parley
description: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger arrived here today for a nuclear planning meeting of NATO defense ministers that is expected to focus on weapons control and missile deployment. He is expected to report to fellow ministers on the Sept. 28 meeting between President Reagan and the Soviet Foreign Minister, Andrei A. Gromyko.

title: Technology; Fuzzy Logic For Computers
description: WHEN Hans Berliner first developed his backgammon-playing computer program, it had a problem. The computer played a strong game most of the time. But every so often it would make a move that was so atrocious it would blow the game.

title: Key Rates
description: * split rate, 12.50-12.75 ** Kenny Index, Kenny Information Systems Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Computer Privacy, Not Secrecy The rush to adjourn Congressional sessions breeds sloppy as well as dangerous legislation. Thus a bill designed only to make computers more secure would inadvertently create a sweeping new secrecy law. Congress cannot consider its work done until it clarifies or defeats this measure.
description: Representative William Hughes and other sponsors say they have no desire to enhance the secrecy of Government or the powers of Federal officials. They want only a law to protect Government computers from abuse by teen-age hackers and sophisticated thieves.

title: ;  Villanova's Course
description: Villanova, which plans a gradual resumption of football beginning next year, has decided to join the Yankee Conference in 1987 and to play a full conference schedule in 1988, according to the Wildcats' athletic director, Ted Aceto . He said the school's trustees had approved the plan, which calls for Villanova to resume football by playing five opponents next year, all in Division III, and eight in 1986, again all in the lowest division.

title: THE REGION Ex-Mayor Loses Suit on Legal Fees
description: A state appeals court ruled today that Atlantic City does not have to pay $81,000 in legal bills that former Mayor Michael Matthews incurred while fighting lawsuits seeking to overturn his 1982 election.

title: Victory '83 Wins 12-Meter Title
description: Victory '83, the boat that sailed for Britain in the America's Cup last year, won the world 12-Meter yachting championship off this island resort today.

title: VACUUM AT THE TOP (1)
description: BOSTON Now we have ''the age issue.'' That is the gingerly way newspapers and television have approached the reality seen by millions of Americans in the first Reagan-Mondale debate: a President who is rambling in his replies to questions, disjointed, occasionally incoherent and confused.

title: SUBURBAN FEUD'S END: ONE DEAD AND ONE JAILED
description: By its indictment, the grand jury of the County of Nassau accuses the defendant, James Peters, ''of murder in the second degree,'' alleging that on the evening of July 5, 1984, he did, ''with intent to cause death,'' shoot one Ralph Galluccio with a gun.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: HOME BEFORE DARK. By Susan Cheever. 243 pages. Illustrated. Houghton Mifflin. $15.95.

title: NOVICE CITY PROSECUTORS GET SPEEDY ON-THE-JOB TRAINING
description: The cases were moving at a hectic pace - sometimes one every three minutes - in Judge William Miller's crowded courtroom in Brooklyn Criminal Court.

title: LONG-MISSED PARIS MUSEUM REOPENS
description: A PIECE of good news from Paris is that after more than five years during which it was strengthened and redesigned the Musee de L'Orangerie is once again open for business. The Orangerie has no permanent collection, apart from Monet's panoramic 'Nympheas' on its lower level, and it looks like an overgrown mid-19th-century potting shed that has been set down in the southwest corner of the Tuileries Gardens. But regular visitors to Paris have missed it almost beyond reason.

title: Gomez Is Upset
description: John Mattke, an unseeded American ranked only 225th in the world, upset top- seeded Andres Gomez of Ecuador today, 6-4, 3-6, 7-6, in the second round of the Japan Open tennis tournament. Gomez is the world's fifth-ranked player. Mattke, a Minnesotan, has won one tournament, a satellite event, since turning professional last winter.

CITADEL HOLDING reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

Day to senior vice president of the corporation and president of the specialty materials group, and K. Grahame Walker to senior vice president and president of the specialty chemicals group.

description: President Reagan today assailed suggestions from some Democrats and news commentators that he showed signs of age Sunday in his debate with Walter F. Mondale.
