NEW TIMETABLE SOUGHT TO FINISH CONVENTION HALL
description: The head of New York City's Convention Center said yesterday that he thought the project, plagued by delays, could be completed three months ahead of its current schedule if a new construction timetable was approved.

title: ERO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid Aug. 10.

title: BECK IS OPTIMISTIC ON EVE OF OPENER
description: A tired smile creased the face of the great defenseman, who in his drenched hockey underwear looked like someone whose wife had put him out for the night instead of the cat. A three-hour practice will do that. This was only a temporary state, however. In moments, his face lost its bloodless color and returned to normal.

title: MAGIC DRAGON'S NOT-SO-INNOCUOUS PUFF
description: To the Editor:

title: ;  Marist Selects Coach
description: Matt Furjanic , who resigned as basketball coach at Robert Morris College in Coraopolis, Pa., three weeks ago, has been named coach at another E.C.A.C.-Metro Conference school, Marist College in Poughkeepsie, N.Y. He replaces Mike Perry, who resigned last month when it was announced at Marist that the National Collegiate Athletic Association would investigate charges of excessive financial support for players during Perry's tenure.

title: FOREIGN IMAGE-MAKING: IT'S A JOB FOR THE EXPERTS
description: The Sept. 19 letter, written on Gray & Company letterhead, arrived on the reporter's desk in the morning mail.

title: TWO ARTISTS LEAVE MANHATTAN TO EMBELLISH A SUBURBAN HOUSE
description: THE idea of moving to the suburbs had never occurred to Richard Haas, the noted trompe l'oeil muralist, and Katherine Sokolnikoff, his wife, a sculptor specializing in ceramics. Both are New York artists who had for years lived and worked in downtown lofts. In 1979, however, Miss Sokolnikoff was coming to the end of her lease in her Bowery loft. In looking together for a 5,000-square-foot loft in which to live and work, they encountered prices they could not afford.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: Atlas Van Lines of Evansville, Ind. , said its previously announced agreement and plan to merge with Wesray Transportation Inc. had been approved by shareholders.

title: ;  Johnson Not Giving Up
description: Billy (White Shoes) Johnson, the 32- year-old Atlanta wide receiver and return man who suffered the third major knee injury of his career during the Falcons' victory over the Los Angeles Rams on Sunday, said that he might never play football again but that he was not willing to give up yet.

title: Universal Money Pact
description: Universal Money Centers Inc. said it had signed an agreement with the Southland Corporation under which its automated teller machines will be installed in nearly 250 of Southland's 7-Eleven convenience stores in Missouri, Tennessee and Oklahoma. The machines will be operating by mid-1985, Universal said.

title: THE CITY ; ;  Free Home Repair For City's Elderly
description: The city will provide free, minor home maintenance and repair services to elderly homeowners on fixed incomes, officials said yesterday.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Oct. 11, 1984 GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Marines Switch Recruiting Theme Line
description: The other news from J. Walter Thompson yesterday was that its longtime client, the Marine Corps, is changing the theme line on its recruiting advertising back to ''We're looking for a few good men,'' after an eight-year absence.

title: ENVIRONMENTAL TESTING & CERTIFICATION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: No Headline
description: More Guards at Court In Threat to Blackmun

title: Norway's Prices Rise
description: Consumer prices in Norway rose eight-tenths of 1 percent in September from August and 6.1 percent from August 1983, the Central Bureau of Statistics said today.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Metropolitan Report on Tuesday about registering to vote at polling places in New York City misstated the hours. The polls will be open Saturday from 1 P.M. to 9 P.M.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: The DCS Capital Corporation, a joint venture of the Dow Chemical Company, the Union Carbide Corporation and Shell Canada Ltd., will offer today $100 million of 12 3/8 percent notes due in 1996 at a price of 99.6, to yield 12.47 percent, through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers.

title: NEW STUDY FIND INFLATED LABOR COSTS ON WEAPONS
description: A recent Air Force study of major military contractors showed that they were charging the Government as much as 20 times their hourly labor costs, a senior Air Force official told Congress today.

title: China's Foreign Trade
description: China posted a foreign trade deficit of $70 million in August, but the overall balance for the first eight months of 1984 showed a surplus of $803 million, the Government's statistical bureau said today. The agency said two-way trade totaled $4.09 billion in August. Countries posting a trade surplus with China included the United States, Japan, Britain, West Germany, Canada and Australia, it said.

title: ENVIRONMENT AGENCY ASKS LIMITS ON SOOT FROM TRUCKS
description: The Environmental Protection Agency today proposed limits on diesel soot pollution from heavy trucks for the first time and said it planned to tighten truck standards for a major smog- producing pollutant, oxides of nitrogen.

title: HI-SHEAR INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Including income of $269,000 from equity in earnings of an affiliate. c-Net loss including income of $188,000 from equity in earnings of an affiliate, a loss of $1,062,000 from discontinued operations and a gain of $112,000 from the discontinued operations of an affiliate.

title: ALTIUS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 27
Marriott Accord To Sell Park
description: The Marriott Corporation said it had signed a closing agreement with Santa Clara, Calif., under which the city can proceed to buy a Marriott theme park for $101 million while a recent California Superior Court decision is appealed.

title: GENERAL ELECTRIC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
3,000 Protest in Iceland
description: About 3,000 demonstrators staged a protest against Iceland's right-wing Government at the state opening of Parliament today, but the violence feared by some organizers did not develop. The protest was called in support of a strike by public-sector unions,

title: RYAN'S FAMILY STEAK HOUSES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
OWENS-ILLINOIS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: Six Sex Clubs Ignore Ban in San Francisco
description: Owners of at least six bathhouses and sex clubs frequented by homosexuals here have refused to obey Tuesday's order to close, health officials said today.

title: TELEDYNE UP 35.6%
description: The General Electric Company, the country's leading electrical products concern, reported yesterday that tight cost controls, the general improvement in the economy and improved productivity from reinvestment in its businesses, caused earnings in the third quarter of 1984 to rise 13 percent.

title: DEVON ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Nicaraguan Loans Curbed
description: The World Bank has cut off $2 million in loans to Nicaragua because it has fallen behind by 90 days in repaying some of its debt, a bank official said today.

title: HOTELS ARE HIT HARD AS TOURISTS SHUN HAITI
description: -AU-PRINCE, Haiti - In the last 18 months six tourist hotels here have closed and at least three others are in trouble with the banks, according to an official of Haiti's Hotel and Tourist Association.

title: LYNCH COMMUNICATIONS SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including a nonrecurring gain of $355,000 for the quarter and 9 months from the reduction of a provision established in 1982 for estimated costs relating to the discontinuance of a product line.

title: Coast Utility Sets $50 Million Issue
description: The Los Angeles Department of Water and Power, the nation's largest municipally owned utility, is offering $50 million of revenue bonds through underwriters led by Kidder, Peabody & Company.

title: WHITAKER DISLIKES THE BOUNCING BALL
description: The ball, Lou Whitaker explained, hit him in the heart. ''It broke my heart,'' the Detroit second baseman said. ''Bevacqua broke my heart also.''

title: DISPOSABLES FOR PAINTER
description: WHILE purists and professional painters may balk at disposable paint brushes and other disposable painting items, many do-it- yourselfers find them most useful. Not only are they far less expensive than their traditional counterparts, but there is also no need to find storage space in a small apartment or an already cluttered garage. When the job is done, just throw them away.

title: TAX ISSUE STALL DEBT CEILING BILL
description: An effort by Western senators to provide tax relief for farmers and small-business owners who finance the sale of their businesses or properties has delayed final Congressional approval of legislation to raise the ceiling on the Federal debt.

title: THE CHANGE'S THE THING IN BRITISH TROUPE VISIT
description: Backstage are tables heaped with a jumble of swords, silk roses, candles, plastic tangerines, a bloody rag, a tambourine, a sheet of unbaked rolls. The dressing room shelves are piled with plumed hats boasting grand sweeps of white feathers, black feathers, red feathers. There are 75 wigs and more than 300 costumes. And of course there are noses: drawers full of noses, boxes bursting with noses, noses scattered across the star's dressing table like a hail of delicate flesh-colored petals strewn by a storm.

title: LECTURES: U.S. GARDENS AND CITY ARCHITECTURE
description: Architecture and American gardens are some of the topics of lectures and series this month in Manhattan and on Long Island.

title: C.D. Yields Fall Again
description: Although average annual yields on most deregulated bank accounts stabilized in the week ended yesterday, yields on six-month certificates of deposit continued a four-week downward slide, The Bank Rate Monitor reported yesterday.

title: BAIRNCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
AT THE MOVIES
description: BOOKS do not often become hit movies without having been books in the first place. But that is what happened to ''Me Two,'' the novel that is the basis for ''All of Me.'' ''Me Two'' is the work of Ed Davis, who lives near Seattle and has also written historical fiction and articles about computers. All of Mr. Davis's book-length works remain unpublished, ''Me Two'' among them.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE ; ;  McNamara Favored
description: ''No question he's the leading candidate,'' Lou Gorman , the Boston Red Sox' vice president for baseball operations, said of John McNamara , who is expected to be named the club's manager next week. As ''more or less a formality,'' said Haywood Sullivan , the executive vice president, other candidates have been interviewed. But there is no doubt that McNamara, who resigned earlier this week as manager of the California Angels, will take over in Boston.

title: A COMPUTER SCORES IN SPORTS
description: Qantel is the computer system of winners - and losers.

title: No Headline
description: Paul O. Grammer Sr.; Began Steel Concerns

title: Bruins 4, Penguins 3
description: Ray Bourque ripped a 40-foot slap shot past the goalie Denis Herron at 14:28 of the third period to cap Boston's comeback from a 3-1 deficit.

title: 'REALLY GREAT,' SAYS THE FIRST WOMAN FROM U.S. TO TAKE A WALK IN SPACE
description: Dr. Kathryn D. Sullivan became the first American woman to walk in space today as she floated outside the shuttle Challenger and, with Lieut. Comdr. David C. Leestma, successfully tested a system for refueling satellites in space.

title: Trade Record Set by Japan
description: Japanese exports continued to climb at a double-digit pace in September as imports fell, propelling the country's trade surplus to a monthly record of $4.5 billion, the Finance Ministry said today.

title: U.S. Embassies Alerted To New Attack Threat
description: The State Department said today that it had received a report that a group of terrorists has threatened to crash a small plane packed with explosives into American embassies in the Middle East, including the embassy in Nicosia, Cyprus.

title: CAMPAIGN NOTES ; Bush Aide Confirms Comment About Ferraro
description: Vice President Bush's spokesman, Peter Teeley, today acknowledged using the word ''bitchy'' about Geraldine A. Ferraro but said he had only meant she should avoid being ''screechy or scratchy'' in the debate.

title: INTERNATIONAL MINERALS & CHEMICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including a gain of $6.3 million from the exchange of common stock and cash for certain debentures and a gain of $7.5 million from tax changes relating to domestic international sales corporations. c-Including a gain of $8.9 million from the sale of phosphate reserves and a loss of $800,000 related to the closing of a methanol plant.

description: Frank B. Hall Ends Its Underwriting

description: Hold That Signature

description: Corrected from Friday, Sept. 28.

description: 'Off-Hollywood' Series: 15 Independent Films

title: Shameful Row Over Social Security
description: Walter Mondale charges that Ronald Reagan has a ''secret plan'' to reduce Social Security benefits. ''Mondale ought to be ashamed,'' responds the White House. The President ''will never stand for reduction in Social Security benefits for anybody.''

title: HOME HEALTH CARE OF AMERCA INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
ART: BAROQUE PAINTINGS AT COLNAGHI
description: '' BAROQUE Paintings From the Bob Jones University Collection'' is one of the strangest exhibitions of the young season. With 36 17th- and 18th-century paintings, representing artists like Peter Paul Rubens, Anthony van Dyck, Domenichino, Guercino, Giambattista Tiepolo, Jusepe Ribera and Guido Reni, the exhibition brings to New York the cream of Baroque painting from the Bob Jones University Gallery of Sacred Art. Just how this rigorously conservative institution in Greenville, S.C., happens to have an internationally known collection tells a great deal about why the show, sponsored by the Old Master Exhibition Society of New York and on display at Colnaghi, 26 East 80th Street through Nov. 1, is such a mixed bag.

title: BRIEFING;
description: The Stogie Vote

title: FINANCIAL CORP TO PARE STAFF 20% IN COST-CUTTING
description: The ailing Financial Corporation of America will cut its staff by 20 percent and sell such items as company jets and apartments in an attempt to become a smaller but more efficient organization, William J. Popejoy, chairman, said today.

title: CENTRAL & SOUTH WEST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day Oct. 3 about the indictment of two California importers charged with violating copyrights held by Apple Computer Inc. incorrectly characterized the legal action. It appears to mark the first time Federal criminal charges for copyright infringement have been brought in a case involving computer piracy.

title: Price-Fixing Benefit Is Seen
description: Manufacturers' efforts to limit the ways and places their products are sold - known as vertical restraints - sometimes may actually benefit consumers, according to a series of studies released today by the Federal Trade Commission.

title: American Symphony To Play the Ives Fourth
description: Sunday at 3 P.M. in Carnegie Hall, the American Symphony Orchestra will celebrate the 20th anniversary of its world premiere performance of the Ives Fourth Symphony.

title: CENTRAL SOYA CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $900,000 for the quarter and year. c-Including income of $3.2 million from discontinued operations.

title: COMPROMISE EXPORT BILL DIES
description: After months of deadlock, an export control bill died in Congress today in the rush to adjourn, despite an 11th-hour effort to find a compromise acceptable to both the House and Senate.

title: SCREEN: 'FIRST TURN-ON!'
description: '' THE FIRST TURN-ON!'' is the kind of movie that looks so cheap even the rocks seem made out of cardboard. And rocks have a role to play, since the story begins when Michelle (Georgia Harrell), a nature counselor from Camp Big Tee-Pee, finds herself sealed in a cave with four of her teen- age charges.

title: Outlet Purchase
description: Outlet Communications Inc., a subsidiary of the Rockefeller Group, has reached an agreement in principle to acquire WPDS-TV in Indianapolis, an independent UHF television station, for $22 million from USA Communications Inc. This deal and the previously announced planned acquisition of a television station in Atlanta would give Outlet seven stations, which is the maximum allowed. The Indianapolis transaction is subject to reaching a definitive agreement and regulatory approval.

title: NEWS SUMMARY FRIDAY, OCTOBER 12, 1984
description: Companies

title: CONSULTANTS' TIMES SQ. ROLE BRINGS OPPOSITION AT U.D.C.
description: The legal staff of the State Urban Development Corporation has recommended that the agency not hire a consulting company because the company wrote a report that may be used in lawsuits against the Times Square redevelopment plan.

title: A Tiffany Campaign
description: Seeking to regain its old luster, Tiffany, an independent company once again, has assembled 17 Tiffany-designed pieces containing 600 carats of diamonds and lots of gold.

title: FIRST EMPIRE STATE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
COMPANY BRIEFS
description: Barry Wright Corp., a diversified industrial company based in Newton Lower Falls, Mass., said it had completed the acquisition of Cementation (Muffelite) Ltd. from its parent company, Trafalgar House P.L.C. of London.

title: VARIATIONS OF 'NO GHOST' ARE COMING ON LIKE GANGBUSTERS
description: Ever since the hit movie ''Ghostbusters'' appeared this summer with its flashy rock theme song and ''no ghosts'' logo, people around the country have been asking, ''Who ya gonna call?''

title: F.A.A. Contract
description: The System Development Corporation unit of the Burroughs Corporation said it had won a $163 million contract, in conjunction with the Westinghouse Electric Corporation, to supply 78 data link ground stations to the Federal Aviation Administration as part of the effort to upgrade the nation's air traffic control system. Under the terms of the contract, the F.A.A. will have an option for another 59 systems, which could raise the overall value of the contract to $221 million. The new systems are expected to be delivered between early 1987 and 1991.

title: Rockland Electric Co. Rates To Increase 16 Cents a Month
description: The State Board of Public Utilities today approved a $226,075 increase in annual revenues for the Rockland Electric Company.

title: Miami Votes Payments In Killing by Officer
description: The Miami City Commission has approved a $1.1 million settlement with the parents of a black man killed by a Hispanic police officer, who was acquitted.

title: SEALED DOCUMENTS SPUR LAWSUIT IN VERMONT
description: A dispute between three newspapers and several judges over the sealing of pretrial affidavits in criminal cases has gone to the Vermont Supreme Court.

title:
WHY OSTPOLITIK OCCUPIES CENTER STAGE;
BONN SEEKS UNIFICATION
description: Events of the last few months have led to a renewed interest among our allies in relations between the two Germanys. What's troubling for us in West Germany is that many Americans show so little understanding of the moral and political substance of ''the German question.''

title: REAGAN TAKES A PAGE FROM TRUMAN'S CAMPAIGN
description: From June 3 to Nov. 2, Election Day in 1948, President Truman made four whistle-stop campaign trips across the country on a special train.

title: Ursula Reilly Curtiss Is Dead;NewMexicanMysteryWriter
description: Ursula Reilly Curtiss, the author of nearly two dozen mystery and suspense novels, died Wednesday of cancer in the Lovelace Medical Center in Albuquerque, N.M. She was 61 years old and lived in Albuquerque.

title: U.S. VS. THIRD-WORLD CONSUMER PROTECTION
description: To the Editor:

title: Disneyland Unions Suing on Citizen Arrests
description: Striking Disneyland unions said today that they would file an $18 million lawsuit over citizens' arrests by park officials involving six union leaders who picketed near ticket booths.

title: CHESS GAME IS DRAWN
description: Anatoly Karpov agreed to a draw yesterday without resuming play in the 11th game of his world chess championship defense against Gary Kasparov in Moscow.

title: FRIDAY SPORTS Baseball
description: Tigers vs. San Diego Padres, World Series, third game, at Detroit. The Tigers return home as an American League championship team for the first time in 16 years, and Milt Wilcox is ready.

title: WILLAMETTE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results for the year-ago quarter and 9 months include a gain of $4,075,000 from the sale of a plant.

title: Money Fund Assets Climb
description: The assets of the nation's money market mutual funds continued to climb in the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday. In the largest weekly jump since July 1982, assets increased $4.02 billion, to $189.24 billion, the institute said.

title: Texas Bank Merger A Challenge for Mcorp
description: Texas is a big state, but distance is of no concern to Gene H. Bishop, chairman and chief executive of the newly created Mcorp. Mr. Bishop, who lives in Dallas, is not worried about getting access to his president and chief operating officer, John T. Cater, even though Mr. Cater lives in Houston.

title: Cullinet-Digital
description: Cullinet Software Inc. said it had signed a development agreement with the Digital Equipment Corporation to integrate Cullinet's information data base with Digital's VAX family of computer systems. Cullinet said the companies would also cooperate to market existing products and develop new ones to improve communications and data base interfaces between types of Digital products and those on International Business Machines Corporation-based services.

title: SUN BANKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The latest quarter and 9 months results include that of Flagship Banks Inc. from the Jan. 1, 1984 date of acquistion.

title: THE CITY ; ;  Officer Wounds Another in Arrest
description: A police officer was accidentally shot by another officer on the Lower East Side yesterday as they were arresting a suspected drug buyer who had fled two other officers in his car, the police said.

title: MERCANTILE BANCORPORATION INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The increase in net income reflects the acquisition of First Community Bancorp on Sept. 30, 1983.

title: JAROSLAV SEIFERT, CZECH POET, WINS NOBEL LITERATURE PRIZE
description: The Nobel Prize for Literature has been awarded to Jaroslav Seifert, a Czechoslovak poet, the Swedish Academy announced today.

title: ART PEOPLE
description: UP at the Minor Latham Theater on the Barnard College campus this weekend, the stage for Kenneth Koch's new play, ''The New Diana,'' is filled with sketches of beautiful women wearing no clothes. They are the most recent work of the 87-year-old artist Reuben Nakian and his first effort ever at creating a stage design.

title: Plea in Death of Girls in Car
description: A 24- year-old man pleaded guilty Wednesday to involuntary manslaughter in the deaths of his two young daughters, who had been left unattended in a disabled car on the hottest day in San Diego in five years. The father, Quindell Lewis, entered the plea before Municipal Court Judge Robert Cooney, who set sentencing for Nov. 8.

title: NEW JERSEY NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After extraordinary gains of $843,000 for the quarter and $1,444,000 for the 9 months. c-After an extraordinary gain of $1,289,000. The shares outstanding for the year-ago periods were restated to reflect 3-for-2 stock split issued May 21, 1984, and the 1984 shares outstanding reflects the sale of 923,000 common shares to institutional investors on July 16, 1984.

title: ;  Comings and Goings
description: Undefeated Donald Curry will defend his World Boxing Association welterweight title against Colin Jones in Britain in January, according to a British promoter. . . . Johnny Unitas , the former Colt star, is one of 13 people appointed by Gov. Harry Hughes to a commission that will study how to keep franchises from moving out of Maryland, and how to attract new ones. . . . Mark Malone will likely start at quarterback for the Pittsburgh Steelers Sunday against San Francisco, replacing David Woodley , who suffered his second concussion of the season last weekend. The Philadelphia Eagles, meanwhile, are waiting to see if their quarterback, Ron Jaworski , will be able to play against Indianapolis despite a cracked rib.

title: JOHN HENRY TO FACE CHALLENGES FROM 12
description: John Henry has earned more than twice as much money on the track as any other horse, is coming off victories in the two richest races run this year and was given a controversially light weight assignment for the inaugural $400,000 Ballantine's Classic, tomorrow night at the Meadowlands.

title: KOCH URGES BOARD TO BAR HOMOSEXUAL BIAS
description: In a new attempt to prohibit discrimination against homosexuals by city contractors, Mayor Koch urged his fellow Board of Estimate members yesterday to include such prohibitions in each contract they approve.

title: 'Uptown at the Apollo' Recalls a Phenomenon
description: It was 50 years ago that the Apollo, an ordinary-looking theater in Harlem on 125th Street, began a career of black entertainment that made it one of the most extraordinary cultural centers in New York. Tomorrow at 11 A.M., Channel 13 will recall that phenomenon to those who remember it or explain it to those who do not in ''Uptown at the Apollo,'' an installment of ''Tony Brown's Journal.''

title: No Headline
description: Bush Failed to Heed Ferraro Title Choice

description: The Singer Company said it had agreed to acquire the approximately 25 percent outstanding minority interest in Simuflite Training International Inc. it does not already own. It said Simuflite had been formed as a majority-owned unit of Singer and recently began commercial operations in training business aircraft pilots.

description: An epidemic that spread through vast stretches of the Atlantic Ocean and Caribbean Sea has nearly wiped out a species of sea urchin, scientists at the Smithsonian Tropical Research Institute in Panama have reported.

description: A decade ago this city's two major banks felt that they couldn't get any respect.

description: Thirteen thousand subway riders were removed from smoky trains and thousands more were delayed for long periods yesterday as six fires erupted under trains in Manhattan and Brooklyn and in tunnels under the East River, officials said.

title: Hawks 7, Wings 3
description: Bob Murray set up second-period goals by Rick Paterson and Billy Gardner in a 12-second span to break a 2-2 deadlock and help lift Chicago to victory. Murray, who set up the Black Hawks' first goal in the opening period, picked up a loose puck at the Detroit blue line late in the second period and uncorked a 55- foot slap shot.

title: MESSAGE OF IMMIGRATION BILL IS DISPUTED
description: This year's failed immigration bill, students of United States immigration policies agree, was in the American tradition of welcoming newcomers while keeping the ''golden door'' from opening too wide. The students disagree, however, on whether the principal message of the bill, which died when Congress adjourned yesterday without approving it, was ''come in'' or ''keep out.''

title: A Succoth Festival
description: A succah, klezmer music, Yemenite and Israeli folk dancing, puppet shows, crafts, storytelling and traditional foods are included in a Succoth Festival on Sunday from noon to 4 P.M. at the New York University Loeb Student Center, Washington Square South at La Guardia Place.

title: INDECISION WITH A TWIST: FORCING THE ISSUE LATER
description: It is not unusual in a Parliamentary style of government, but it is rare for the United States Congress to say, in effect, ''We cannot resolve the problem - let's wait and let a new Congress with a new election mandate decide what to do.'' Yet that is exactly what has happened recently on some important issues.

description: The Honda Motor Company said today that higher sales of cars, parts and power products offset a decline in motorcycle sales and that total profits rose 29.9 percent in its fiscal second quarter from a year earlier.

description: John L. Baxter, who perfected a process of food dehydration that was extensively used by the military in World War II, died Monday at his home here. He was 88 years old.

title: MUSEUM HIGHLIGHTS AND WEEKEND EVENTS
description: Etchings of Pennsylvania coal miners and their families from 1930 to the 40's by Nicholas Bervinchak will be displayed tomorrow through Nov. 4 at the Ukrainian Museum, 203 Second Avenue. The show is part of the museum's photographic exhibition, ''To Preserve a Heritage, the Story of the Ukrainian Immigration in the United States.'' Weekend hours are 1 to 5 P.M. Admission: adults, $1; students and the elderly, 50 cents; children under 16, free. Information: 228- 0110.

description: FRIDAY, OCTOBER 12, 1984 International Benigno S. Aquino Jr. was shot to death by one of his Philippine Government escorts in a wide-ranging military conspiracy, according to a key document being considered in the inquiry into the assassination of the opposition leader. The document is a 497-page memorandum compiled by four lawyers who assisted the citizens' panel that has been investigating the slaying. (Page A1, Column 3.) Margaret Thatcher escaped unhurt when a powerful explosion damaged the English seaside hotel where the Prime Minister and other ministers were staying for the annual Conservative Party conference, her office in London said. (A1:2-3.)

title: SOUTHTRUST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
FILM: 'GARBO TALKS,' DIRECTED BY SIDNEY LUMET
description: QUITE early in Sidney Lumet's sentimental new comedy, ''Garbo Talks,'' Anne Bancroft as Estelle Rolfe, the last word in Jewish mothers in contemporary film literature, learns that she has an inoperable brain tumor. As her initial fury turns into resignation, a wisecrack surfaces. ''I always knew everybody's got to die,'' she tells her son, Gilbert (Ron Silver), ''but I really thought I'd be the exception.''

title: MONDALE HARVESTS A BOUNTY OF POST-DEBATE CASH
description: Outside the ballroom of the Sheraton Centre hotel Wednesday night, Nancy Kuhn, a svelte figure in a long black velvet gown, attempted to keep the crowd orderly while some of New York's loyal Democrats and well-to-do political amateurs jostled one another to pick up their tickets for a black-tie dinner for Walter F. Mondale.

description: Frustrated and exhausted, the nation's lawmakers early this morning abandoned until later in the day efforts to increase the Federal debt limit. They were thus forced once again to postpone adjournment of the 98th Congress.

ISLANDERS' PERSSON DRAWS SUSPENSION
description: The Islanders' final roster alterations - all on defense - went as anticipated today, with one exception. Stefan Persson will not be in the lineup Friday night when his teammates open the season against the New Jersey Devils at the Meadowlands.

title: Delegation From Dalai Lama Will Visit Peking Next Week
description: A three-member delegation representing the Dalai Lama, the exiled Tibetan spiritual leader, will leave New Delhi for Peking on Oct. 19, a spokesman for the Dalai Lama's office said today.

title: CAMPAIGN NOTES ; Dallas May Have to Foot Unpaid Convention Bill
description: City officials, who promised to spare taxpayers the expense of holding the Republican National Convention last summer, now find they may have to recover some $1.5 million of security costs from the public treasury.

title: MODERN ARCHITECTS WIN CHARLES'S PRINCELY DISDAIN
description: The Royal Institute of British Architects was thrilled when the Prince of Wales agreed to address its 150th anniversary banquet in May. But many of the members in attendance were startled when the Prince delivered a broad, scathing attack on modern architecture.

title: I.B.M. NET UP 22.3.% IN QUARTER
description: The International Business Machines Corporation, continuing its strong earnings growth of the last few years, reported that net income for the third quarter rose 22.3 percent from the period a year earlier. But revenues, which grew only 13.3 percent, were not as robust as some analysts had expected, partly because of the strong dollar.

title: 'BLOOD SIMPLE,' A BLACK-COMIC ROMP
description: BLACK humor, abundant originality and a brilliant visual style make Joel Coen's ''Blood Simple'' a directorial debut of extraordinary promise. Mr. Coen, who co-wrote the film with his brother Ethan, works in a film noir style that in no way inhibits his wit, which turns out to be considerable. This is a film in which a dying man, mistakenly shot by a woman who cannot see him (and who meant to kill someone else), can hear her shout one more insult at the intended victim - and answer her, ''Well, ma'am, if I see him I'll sure give him the message.''

title: PADRES' MIDDLE RELIEF IS SERIES SURPRISE
description: The San Diego Padres had heard about Willie Hernandez and his 32 saves in 33 save opportunities and about Aurelio Lopez and his 14 saves and 10 victories with only one loss. The Detroit bullpen, the Padres knew, was a force to avoid.

title: ;  Benirschke Sidelined

He is expected to miss two games.. . . Joe Rose rejected the advice of the Miami Dolphins' team physician that Rose undergo surgery, and Coach Don Shula said he would probably have to put the tight end on the injured-reserve list. Rose, who had separated his left shoulder, went to two private doctors who said he would be able to play sooner if he did not have the operation.

ART: ARTHUR B. CARLES, ADVENTUROUS COLORIST
description: GOOD American artists of the past are hardly neglected these days, hovered over as they are by historians only too eager for new old material. But somehow Arthur B. Carles (1882- 1952), a modernist painter whose work seemed to prophesy Abstract Expressionism, keeps getting lost in the shuffle. Since his death there have been several Carles shows, peripheral mentions in textbooks, acquisitions here and there by major museums - but something less than the recognition he merits (he was unaccountably missing from the recent modernist extravaganza, ''Abstract Painting and Sculpture in America 1927-1944,'' organized by the Carnegie Institute Museum of Art).

title: AS EGYPT RE-EMERGES, SYRIA IS ISOLATED
description: President Hosni Mubarak's state visit to Jordan, which ended here today, was in effect an invitation to other Arab leaders to join Jordan in extending recognition to Egypt and, in the process, to form a new regional alliance. Such an alliance would end a kind of vacuum in the Arab world caused by the isolation of Egypt - the most populous Arab nation and once the most influential - for the last five years because of President Anwar el-Sadat's signing of the Camp David accords with Israel.

title: RIGGS NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
'A NOS AMOURS,' BY MAURICE PIALAT
description: SUZANNE (Sandrine Bonnaire), the teen-age heroine of Maurice Pialat's ''A Nos Amours,'' is as naturally and heedlessly amoral as the title character in Mr. Pialat's 1980 ''Loulou,'' and the film follows the course of her flirtatiousness. In the credit sequence, standing in a skimpy white outfit at the prow of a yacht, she is radiantly confident and has everything ahead of her. Mr. Pialat's film is in no way judgmental, but it knowingly and regretfully watches that initial promise slip away. As Suzanne later puts it, ''It's as if my heart had run dry.''

title: LITTLE-KNOWN IN U.S., NOBEL POET PRAISED HERE

title: THE COLLAGES OF ROBERT MOTHERWELL
description: AN exhibition by Robert Motherwell is always an important event and the reasons, though obvious, bear restating. Motherwell and Willem de Kooning, his senior by 11 years, are the only founders of Abstract Expressionism to have reached full, productive maturity. Their contribution and that of their colleagues has determined the course taken by art in the second half of the century, both by direct influence and by the rebellions against it - Pop and Minimalism, for instance. But the two artists haven't rested on their laurels: De Kooning, as disclosed by his recent Whitney Museum retrospective, has purged his imagery of grand, juicy gestures, substituting rapid linear marks that hang suspended as if in plasma. Motherwell, on the other hand, has grown more complex - at least that is the impression given by the new collages hanging at Knoedler's, 19 East 70th Street.

title: THE REGION ; ;  5 Men Accused Of Job-Sale Plot
description: A Federal grand jury has indicted five men in connection with what was said to have been the sale of 21 jobs at the Eastman Kodak Company.

title: Search for Sailor Off
description: Australian officials said Tuesday that they had abandoned efforts to find Bill Dunlop, who set out from Portland to circle the globe in a small boat and has been missing two months. ''There is no search - never has been,'' said the duty officer of the Australian Coastal Surveillance search and rescue division in Canberra. Mr. Dunlop, a former truck driver, was last heard from June 23.

WHEN OLDER MEN DIVORCE
description: When Ted Lewis, a 58-year-old insurance executive, separated from his wife after 22 years of marriage, he soon began to suffer, he recalls, from an overpowering sense of isolation and aloneness. ''I didn't have a wife to talk to anymore,'' he said, ''and I couldn't talk to other men about my problems because men aren't supposed to share feelings and weaknesses. They are supposed to keep up that macho image.''

title: Dow Up Modestly As Volume Lessens
description: Stock prices, which had been under pressure recently, rose moderately yesterday in less active trading.

title: Market Place; How Analysts View Retailing
description: As retail sales continue to moderate, securities analysts are raising questions not only about retailing's current quarter but also about the important Christmas season, which is due to start in about a month.

title: 6 Die in London In Commuter Rail Crash
description: A commuter train crashed into a standing freight train near a northwest London station in the evening rush hour today, killing at least 6 people and injuring 60, the authorities said.

title: 2 STRIVE TO WIN FERRARO'S HOUSE SEAT
description: In the meeting room of the Forest Hills Community Civic Association, filled with folding chairs and lined with red-flocked wallpaper, Councilman Thomas J. Manton stood in front of the American flag and talked about nuclear warheads.

title: THE CITY ; ;  No PCB's Found In Tests After Fire
description: Tests on samples in the area of a railway car fire Tuesday in Grand Central Terminal showed no traces of toxic dioxin or PCB's, the city's Environmental Protection Commissioner said yesterday.

description: b-Including a tax credit of $210,000. Sales figures include leased departments.

title: Nominee to F.A.A. Post
description: President Reagan today nominated Richard H. Jones, an Eastern Airlines pilot who also is a practicing lawyer and university professor, to be Deputy Administrator of the Federal Aviation Administration.

title: WEINBERGER SAYS SOVIET ADDED SS-20'S
description: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger said here today that the Soviet Union had substantially increased the number of SS-20 nuclear missiles trained on Western Europe. He declined to say how many more of the medium-range missiles had been deployed.

title:
WHY OSTPOLITIK OCCUPIES CENTER STAGE;
A RESPONSE TO PROTESTS
description: One year ago this month, close to a million demonstrators took to the streets of West Germany to protest the approaching deployment of United States cruise and Pershing 2 missiles on German soil. The Government's decision to accept these weapons - regarded as a crucial test of West Germany's commitment to the North Atlantic alliance - was widely unpopular. Today, by all appearances, the Government has weathered the storm, but not without paying a price.

description: The exuberance that marked the spring and summer fashion collections here this week extended beyond the fabrics and the shapes of the clothes to the accessories that accompanied them. The outpouring of ideas was apparent first in the shoes, no longer either flat or high-heeled as they were in recent seasons.

description: Pat Bradley of the United States launched a bid for her first victory of the year with a three-under- par 69 today and took a one-stroke lead after the first round of the $150,000 Irish Women's Open golf championship.

FROM MUSICALS TO OPERA (AND BACK)
description: Musical comedy was an outgrowth of opera to begin with, and there are indications it may be growing back in. Opera companies, traditionally suspicious of ''commercial'' art, are turning more and more readily to Broadway classics and even experimenting with recent hits. And Broadway, in turn, is producing musical scores of a sophistication that can challenge and reward operatic professionals beyond the level of their immediate initial appeal.

description: There was a moment tonight when the debate was as basic and as fascinating as a man and a woman confronting each other.

title: Wood and Calfee Lead With 64's
description: Willie Wood and Bill Calfee both shot 6-under-par 64's today to share the first-round lead in the Southern Open.

title: IN HOST TOWN FOR SALVADOR TALKS, TALK IS OF PEACE
description: While political leaders argue over the details of the meeting next week between Salvadoran Government and guerrilla officials, the people of La Palma say they are ready for peace.

title: THEATER: WILSON'S 'MA RAINEY'S' OPENS
description: LATE in Act I of ''Ma Rainey's Black Bottom,'' a somber, aging band trombonist (Joe Seneca) tilts his head heavenward to sing the blues. The setting is a dilapidated Chicago recording studio of 1927, and the song sounds as old as time. ''If I had my way,'' goes the lyric, ''I would tear this old building down.''

title: BRIDGE: ROTH AND SONTAG SPANNING THE PLAYER GENERATION GAP
description: Experts tend to select partners of their own generation, but there have been some notable exceptions.

title: Bangladesh Chief Links Martial Law to Vote
description: Lieut. Gen. H. M. Ershad, President of Bangladesh, said today he would gradually lift martial law starting next month if opposition parties agreed to participate in parliamentary elections in December.

description: Texas Utility Bonds

title: Little-Known in U.S., Nobel Poet Praised Here
description: Few Americans have ever heard of Jaroslav Seifert, whose poems are virtually unobtainable in the United States, but scholars who are acquainted with his work said yesterday that the Czech poet fully deserves the Nobel Prize awarded to him.

MARC RICH'S COMPANIES PLEAD GUILTY
description: Two companies operated by Marc Rich, one of the world's leading commodity traders, pleaded guilty to criminal tax charges yesterday and agreed to pay $150 million to the Federal Government.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We're going to lose Central America, as we lost South Vietnam, because the U.S. Congress refused to provide the aid in this protracted conflict.

title: ART: BRICE MARDEN'S BUILDING BLOCKS OF COLOR
description: WE learn from Brice Marden's handwritten notes for his new show at the Pace Gallery that what he wanted in the painting called ''Number Two'' was ''to make color all of everything.''

title: Maelstrom in Manila
description: To hear President Ferdinand Marcos, everyone in the Philippines except he is to blame for the sharp plunge in his fortunes. He now accuses Jaime Cardinal Sin, the Archbishop of Manila, of fomenting rebellion and violence. And he warns that if street turbulence continues, foreign creditors will conclude that his regime ''is unstable, weak, incompetent and unable to enforce the law.'' No sooner were these telling words uttered than business leaders joined in opposition marches, the first time in memory that has happened in Manila.

title: THE REGION ; ;  U.S.AcceptsPlans On Nuclear Safety
description: State plans for coping with a serious emergency at two nuclear power stations have been approved by the Federal Emergency Management Agency, a state official said today.

title: Lotus Development Picks First Chairman
description: The Lotus Development Corporation, the fast-growing producer and marketer of business software for personal computers, said yesterday that Michell D. Kapor, a co-founder of the company, had been named to the new posts of chairman and chief executive.

title: IRVING BANK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Series of New Jazz
description: Reggie Workman, the jazz bassist and composer, will open the New Jazz Series tomorrow at 8:30 P.M. at Carnegie Recital Hall (Seventh Avenue and 57th Street). Joining him will be the saxophonist Sam Rivers, the trumpeter Cecil Bridgewater, the pianist Stanley Cowell, the violinist John Blake and the percussionist Wilford Graves. Tickets are $10 and can be purchased at the box office or by calling Carnegie Charge, 247-7800.

title: RICH SELLS FOX STAKE
description: The ending today of the Federal Government's litigation against Marc Rich allowed the previously disclosed sale of his half interest in the 20th Century-Fox Film Corporation to Marvin Davis, who owned the other half, to take effect, the movie company said. The price for Mr. Rich's half was reported to be $116 million.

title: VIRGINIA WOOLF'S 'TO THE LIGHTHOUSE'
description: FEW works of literature would seem to lend themselves less readily to dramatization than Virginia Woolf's ''To the Lighthouse,'' but the BBC and Colin Gregg Ltd. have made the effort and the result is very special indeed. With Rosemary Harris and Michael Gough playing Mr. and Mrs. Ramsay, Hugh Stoddart's extremely sensitive and illuminating adaptation of the novel is being presented on WNET/Channel 13 at 9 tonight.

description: exhibition game between the

title: GRISLY TALE DATES FROM 1846
description: In 1973 while on a visit to London, Stephen Sondheim saw ''Sweeney Todd, the Demon Barber of Fleet Street,'' Christopher Bond's version of a 137-year-old play. Impressed, Mr. Sondheim decided to turn it into a Broadway musical and did so with the help of the director Hal Prince and the designers Eugene and Franne Lee, a team that already had collaborated with him on Leonard Bernstein's ''Candide.''

title: DISAGREE ABOUT LEADERSHIP, FOREIGN POLICY AND RELIGION
description: Vice President Bush and Geraldine A. Ferraro, his Democratic opponent for that office, engaged in a spirited debate here tonight in which they clashed repeatedly over President Reagan's policies.

title: PENTAGON PLANS TO ADD NEWSPAPER AS MEMBER OF ITS WAR PRESS POOL
description: The Defense Department, reversing an earlier decision, announced today that a newspaper reporter would be included in a national press pool it would form to cover the initial stages of any surprise military operation.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in some copies of The Home Section yesterday about a three-day symposium at Madison Square Garden on home improvement gave an incorrect opening day. The third annual Big Apple Fix-Up begins today.

title: TWO PILOTS DIE AS PLANES COLLIDE
description: Two small planes collided over a park here today, killing the two pilots and showering wreckage near a crowded restaurant and a ballfield where children and their parents ran to safety.

title: RANGERS OPEN AND GAIN TIE
description: The World Series took a night off and the hockey arena rocked last night. The Rangers were back, beginning another stab at the Stanley Cup and from the start they roused their faithful with a bristling game that stretched into overtime.

title: Blues 4, Flames 2
description: Craig Levie, a defenseman acquired by St. Louis in the waiver draft earlier this week, snapped a 1-1 tie in the first period to help the Blues to the victory. Levie, picked up from Minnesota in the draft, scored a power-play goal on a shot from the point after Bernie Federko had beaten the Flames' Steve Tambellini on a faceoff deep in the Calgary zone.

title: HIDE-A-BED (BUT INSIDE A PIANO?)
description: And so, 118 years ago, the man from Cincinnati was granted a patent for what he called ''a certain new and useful Convertible Piano, Couch and Bureau.''

title: Flyers Tie Capitals;  N.H.L.
description: Tim Kerr scored with 99 seconds left in regulation tonight to lift the Philadelphia Flyers to a 2-2 tie with the Washington Capitals in the league opener for both teams.

title: Introductions Up
description: After two months with new product introductions at lower levels then in the comparable months in 1983, September came back strongly, showing 146 introductions, 10 better than the year before. That information comes from the Dancer Fitzgerald Sample New Product News, which also reports that introductions in the first nine months of 1984 are ahead 7.2 percent, to 1,438, from 1,341.

title: BANKS' NET BETTER THAN EXPECTED
description: Six major bank holding companies surprised investors yesterday, reporting far better earnings than had been expected following the announcement last week by the First Chicago Corporation that it would report a loss.

title: 37 SONGS BY MERRILL IN SHOW AT VINEYARD
description: IT may be too early to shout

title: HOMOSEXUALS CALL FOR ASSURANCES ON CONFIDENTIALITY OF AIDS TESTS
description: A new blood test that detects the virus thought to cause AIDS has become the focus of controversy among homosexuals in New York.

title: Envoy Plans Africa Tour
description: Gen. Vernon A. Walters, President Reagan's special envoy, will travel to Africa next week and will represent the United States in Somalia on Oct. 21 at the 15th anniversary of that country's revolution, the State Department said today. He is also to visit Mali, Niger, Chad and Cameroon for discussions of topics including economic problems and what the State Department said was widespread concern about the role of Libya in sub-Saharan Africa.

title: LOCKHEED'S NET SURGES 49.5%
description: The Lockheed Corporation, aided by stronger sales from several of its new space programs, reported yesterday that earnings in the third quarter soared 49.5 percent, while sales climbed 29.6 percent.

title: CREDIT MARKETS ; Interest Rates Fall Broadly Money Supply Up 1.5 Billion
description: Interest rates fell yesterday, with the largest declines coming in the short-term market, where the rate on three-month Treasury bills dropped below 10 percent for the first time since late June.

title: STARVATION, ETHIOPIA'S SECRET WEAPON AGAINST REBELLION

UPSTATE JUDGE REMOVED BY COURT
description: The state's highest court today removed from office a Family Court judge in Rensselaer County who had been accused of falsifying records and disregarding the rights of individuals.

description: Late Correction

title: POPE, IN SANTO DOMINGO, CRITICIZES CLASS CONFLICT
description: Pope John Paul II, arriving here on the second leg of a trip commemorating Columbus's discovery of the New World, told a crowd today that the Roman Catholic Church must offer ''its generous support to the work of 'social liberation,' to the masses of the have-nots.''

title: SALVADOR REBEL LEADER RAISES DOUBTS ABOUT SAFETY AT PEACE PARLEY
description: Salvadoran guerrilla leaders said today they would attend a meeting with President Jose Napoleon Duarte next Monday unless they find that security is inadequate at the meeting site.

title: Quake Jars California Desert
description: A strong earthquake centered in the sparsely populated Anza-Borrego Desert rippled through southern California on Wednesday, but officials said no damages or injuries resulted from the quake.

title: MONDALE IS BUOYED BY HIS SUCCESS IN FIRST DEBATE
description: As Walter F. Mondale told an unusually large crowd here today that the Presidential race was now ''wide open,'' his deputy campaign director in Ohio grinned delightedly.

title: DESIGNHOUSE INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Fluor in China Accord
description: Fluor Engineering Inc. has signed an agreement to set up a joint venture with the China Foreign Nonferrous Metal Engineering and Construction Company, the New China News Agency said today. The venture will seek contracts for domestic and foreign projects, including designing and constructing mines, smelting, refining and transportation projects.

title: AMID CHARGES, IMMIGRATION BILL DIES
description: Congress today failed in its three-year struggle to shape the most important change in immigration law in three decades.

title: Gromyko to Visit Next Year, A British Official Announces
description: Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union will visit Britain next year, Sir Geoffrey Howe, the Foreign Secretary, said today.

description: Mattel, the giant California toy company, which is also Barbie's daddy, announced yesterday that it would be retaining a second agency for its toy business because its billings had grown so big.

title: CAMPAIGN NOTES ; Mondale Camp Sends Check in Visit Mixup
description: Walter F. Mondale's campaign office says a $13,500 check has been sent to a resort owner who reserved cabins for an expected visit by the Democratic Presidential candidate that failed to materialize this summer.

title: People Express Makes British Bid
description: People Express Airlines Inc. has asked the British Government to approve a minimum of three flights a day between London and New York to meet the high demand for its service and to make better use of the nine Boeing 747's the airline will have by 1986.

title: SCRIPPS-HOWARD BROADCASTNG reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
MUSIC: 'SWEENEY TODD,' A CITY OPERA PREMIERE
description: THE decision to transfer ''Sweeney Todd,'' the Broadway success of 1979 to the opera house must have been based on the hope that with trained voices in the leading roles Stephen Sondheim's gory argument in favor of vegetarianism would reveal itself as a work of real musical substance. That hope would seem difficult to justify based on the new production of ''Sweeney'' unveiled last night by the New York City Opera.

title: Knicks Fall by 12, Shoot 32 Percent
description: The Knicks shot only 32 percent from the field tonight as the Milwaukee Bucks, sparked by 23 points from Alton Lister, routed New York, 120- 108, in an exhibition game at Brown County Arena.

PPG-German Tie
description: PPG Industries has entered into an agreement to buy, for an undisclosed amount, a majority interest in Lackwerke Wuelfing G.m.b.H, a unit of Wilhelm Becker, a major European coatings manufacturer based in Stockholm.

title: CONGRESS LIMITS LOCAL CONTROL OF CABLE TV
description: Congress gave final approval today to a bill designed to establish a Federal policy for regulating the cable television industry.

title: Art Deco Walking Tour
description: Fifteen Art Deco landmarks, including the American Radiator, Chanin, Chrysler and the original McGraw-Hill Buildings, will be examined on a two-hour walking tour sponsored by the Art Deco Society of New York.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption in some editions Wednesday about a groundbreaking for an office complex in the Bronx incorrectly identified one participant. Pictured third from left was David T. Chase, president of Chase Enterprises, one of the developers. Also pictured second from right, but not identified, was Daniel Rosolio, who was representing Reynolds Construction, another one of the developers.

title: TOLEDO TRUSTCORP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
THATCHER UNHURT IN EXPLOSION
description: A powerful explosion early this morning ripped through the hotel where Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher was staying in the English Channel resort town of Brighton. Mrs. Thatcher escaped unhurt but shaken.

title: ;  Blackman Re-signed
description: The Dallas Mavericks have signed the guard Rolando Blackman to a 10- year extension of his contract, team officials said yesterday.

title: Diner's Journal
description: SUSHI bars have become nearly as commonplace as pizzerias around town in recent years. Another Japanese-style restaurant that is not so well represented is the tempura bar, at which diners sit at a counter and order various kinds of meat, fish and vegetables that are dipped in egg batter and flash fried in oil. When prepared properly, tempura is greaseless, light and with a slightly puffed and brittle crust.

title: The Editorial Notebook; Awaiting the Big Crunch
description: Astronomers may spend the night with stars but they are no strangers to frustration. For 20 years Allan Sandage, of the Mount Wilson Observatory in California, has been searching for some standard light source by which to judge distances in the far reaches of the universe.

title: THE REGION ; ;  Woman Abducted In Casino-Hotel
description: A woman was kidnapped in a casino- hotel here early this morning, held in a guest room for four hours and raped, the police said.

title: 12 Cubans Quit Embassy Of Peru After 4 Years
description: Twelve of the 15 Cuban refugees who have spent four years in the Peruvian Embassy have left to resume normal lives here, diplomats said today.

title: TIGERS GET 11 WALKS, TOP PADRES FOR 2-1 LEAD
description: The Detroit Tigers took a walk on San Diego's wild side tonight - they benefited from 11 walks, to be exact - and defeated the Padres, 5-2, in the third game of the World Series.

title: ATTACK IS SEEN AS AN EFFORT TO BLOCK IRISH-BRITISH TALKS
description: The early-morning Irish Republican Army bombing of a hotel in which Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher was staying was aimed at derailing new efforts to achieve a settlement in Northern Ireland, British and Irish politicians said today.

title: HEALTHY DINING: DO GUESTS KNOW THE DIFFERENCE?
description: The last time I served a standing rib roast with roast potatoes to company was 12 years ago, and then it was on request. Today when I really want to impress my guests I use boneless chicken breasts instead. Or, possibly, veal, occasionally fish or lamb.

description: The year-ago figures were restated to reflect the September acquisition of the M & I Wauwatosa State Bank, accounted for on a pooling of interest basis.

description: A preliminary Federal report issued today said the pesticide spill at the American Cyanamid chemical plant in Linden on Oct. 6 posed no residual danger to human life.

description: The latest quarter was for a 16- week period. The latest quarter and year earnings include a nonrecurring tax credit of about $2.3 million resulting from recent tax legislation relative to domestic international sales corporations.

title: FOR BRIGHTON, A DAY OF RECOLLECTIONS
description: The Grand Hotel stood bathed in an unusually mild October sun today, its elegant off-white Victorian facade split asunder from the roof to the rubble-strewn portico by the bomb blast that somehow missed killing any high British Government officials early today.

description: Anatoly Karpov and Gary Kasparov agreed to a draw today in the 12th game of their world chess championship match here.

title: Consort of Viols
description: The New York Consort of Viols will perform three viola da gamba sonatas by Bach at Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church tomorrow at 4 P.M. Louis Bagger, a harpsichordist, will be the consort's guest artist. The church is at the corner of Madison Avenue and 73d Street. Tickets: $5 and $7; information, 799-5877.

description: a request by the National Collegiate Athletic Association that it be allowed to submit a voluntary football television plan to its members.

PATENTS;
Means Is Contrived For Making Snow
description: A new method of making artificial snow was patented this week by James L. Hodges of Vernon, Conn., a professor of mechanical engineering at the Hartford Graduate Center.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about the Financial Corporation of America incorrectly attributed information about a severance payment. The statement that J. Foster Fluetsch, a former vice chairman, had negotiated a settlement of $1 million to be paid over five years should have been attributed to a source close to the company who asked not to be identified.

title: THE REGION ; ;  Police to Question A Mass Murderer
description: The state police said today that two detectives would go to Texas next week to question a convicted mass murderer about 12 unsolved slayings or disappearances of women in Connecticut.

title: The Perils of Protecting Police
description: Representative Mario Biaggi of New York is properly dismayed to find the gun lobby triumphing even over the police: ''Earlier this year Congress voted to expand the death benefit program for police survivors and to memorialize police deaths. It seems only logical that somewhere along the line we would also try to prevent police deaths.''

title: BRIEF ALERT REPORTED IN SOVIET AFTER QUIP BY PRESIDENT
description: American intelligence officials have told a Democratic congressman that two days after President Reagan made a joke about bombing the Soviet Union, a low-level Soviet military official ordered an alert of some of his troops in the Far East.

description: Vice President Bush, euphoric after his debate Thursday night with Geraldine A. Ferraro, said today that he felt ''very, very good'' about his performance.
