GIVE NEW YORK CITY EDUCATORS A BREAK
description: In the current era of school reform, New York City is in danger of lagging behind. Good schools depend on a good principal and high teacher morale. But in New York City, principals and teachers alike continue to struggle under burdensome regulations and demoralizing working conditions.

title: FIRST CHICAGO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income The third quarter results include those of the American National Corp., which was acquired on May 1, 1984.

title: CLOUD OVER WEBSTER
description: There was no still no word yesterday on how long the Knicks would be without Marvin Webster , their backup center, who is suffering from hepatitis and acute anemia. Webster underwent further tests at Lenox Hill Hospital and was asked to return again Oct. 22.

title: Mesta Machine Reorganization
description: A Federal judge has cleared the way for the bankrupt Mesta Machine Company to pay its creditors and resume operations under a new name by the end of the month, the company chairman said.

title: NEW YORK ; THE G.O.P. GOES FOR THE JEWS
description: This story was broken on Wednesday by a small newspaper company that publishes two weeklies on Manhattan's West Side - The Westsider and Chelsea Clinton News. And the journalists who did it - Jan Bartelli and Jeff Kisseloff - deserve credit.

title: A NOSTALGIC DAY FOR JUILLIARD ALUMNI
description: The Juilliard School has no football team and no rabid horde of pennant- waving boosters to rally around it; so no one really knew what to expect when the 79-year-old school held its first alumni reunion yesterday.

title: EMIGRE TIES RUSSIAN TO POPE CASE
description: An associate of a Soviet journalist who returned to Moscow last month asserts that the man, Oleg G. Bitov, was forcibly taken back by K.G.B. men because of fears that he would give evidence to Italian officials investigating the attempted assassination of Pope John Paul II.

title: THE DANCE: BALANCHINE IS PERFORMED
description: George Balanchine's ''Square Dance'' and Loyce Houlton's ''Wingborne'' - two ballets celebrating the joy of dancing - were performed for the first time this season by Dance Theater of Harlem on Thursday night at City Center.

title: Third-Party Candidate Sues Over Debate Right
description: Sonia Johnson, a third-party candidate for President, filed suit today against a Federal ruling, saying she wanted to establish the right of candidates like her to be included in broadcast debates.

title: Bradley Up by 3 In Irish Open
description: Pat Bradley of the United States birdied two of the last three holes to finish off a one-under-par 71 today and stretch her lead to three strokes in the $150,000 Irish Women's Open Golf Championship.

title: RIVALS' CAMPS DOUBT BIG SHIFT AFTER 2D DEBATE
description: With both sides publicly claiming victory in the debate between Vice President Bush and Representative Geraldine A. Ferraro, the private assessment in both campaigns today was that the debate would probably cause little shift of support in the Presidential race.

title: Nofziger Says Mondale Fails to Return Funds
description: Lyn Nofziger, a high aide in President Reagan's campaign, has charged that Walter F. Mondale has broken his promise to return $400,000 donated by political action committees in the primary campaign.

title: CONGRESS RAISES DEBT LIMIT ON U.S. DEBT AND ENDS SESSION
description: The 98th Congress faded into history at 3:17 o'clock this afternoon, ending a week of legislative snarls in wearying late- night sessions, as the Senate voted 37 to 30 to approve an increase in the debt limit.

title: STEIN AND GREEN ARGUE FINANCES IN 2D DEBATE
description: Representative Bill Green and Borough President Andrew J. Stein of Manhattan sharply questioned each other's finances yesterday in the second debate of their contest in the 15th Congressional District on the East Side.

title: Weekend Book Fair
description: The 11th annual Hudson Guild Book Fair is offering more than 50,000 new, used and rare hard covers and paperbacks, priced from 25 cents to $2, in the guild's gymnasium, 441 West 26th Street. The schedule: today from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. and tomorrow from 1 to 5 P.M. Included in the fair are records, leather-bound books and refreshments. Free. Information: 760- 9800.

title: Green Posts a 66, Leads by Stroke
description: Hubert Green, seeking his first victory in more than three years, shot a 66 today to take a one-shot lead after two rounds of the $300,000 Southern Open Golf Tournament.

title: CENTRAL PARK RENEWS ITS DETAILS AND VISTAS IN A BURST OF REPAIRS
description: The leaves are beginning to turn in Central Park and the first chill forebodings of winter are in the air. But it is the season of rebirth for the 126-year-old park.

title: BURGER REFUSES TO BAR ABORTION FOR RAPE VICTIM
description: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger of the United States Supreme Court refused today to prevent a Maryland woman from obtaining an abortion for her profoundly retarded 19-year-old daughter, who is pregnant as a result of a rape in a state institution.

title: FIRST FEDERAL OF MICHIGAN reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Giants' Hill Listed as Doubtful
description: Kenny Hill, who has started every game for the Giants at strong safety this season, is doubtful for the game Sunday against the Falcons in Atlanta because of an ankle injury.

title: INSTALLMENT DEBT RISE $6 BILLION
description: Americans took on $6 billion more in installment debt than they paid off in August, but the rate of debt growth slowed for the third month in a row, the Government reported today.

title: SUBWAY CAR IN FIRE HAD A HISTORY OF TROUBLE
description: A subway car that burst into flame Thursday at the Borough Hall station in Brooklyn had been in and out of the repair shop dozens of times since July, the Transit Authority said yesterday.

title: POP FUNK: OSBORNE AT RADIO CITY
description: In contrast with the rough-and-tumble soul singers of the 1960's, the present mainstream pop-soul singing idols stand or fall less on stamina than on an ability to balance the rough and smooth sides of a polished and urbane machismo. Jeffrey Osborne, a veteran of the pop-funk group LTD, epitomizes the new breed of soul man.

title: SIMCO STORES INC reports earnings for Year to July 28
POPE BIDS PUERTO RICANS TO FIGHT ILLS
description: Pope John Paul II today called upon the Roman Catholic laity to help fight the social ills that beset the poor in modern society.

title: CRAIG CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss after a loss of $336,000 from discontinued operations. Year-ago results have been restated to reflect the sale of a subsidiary and a division in July.

title: DUARTE REJECTS REBELS' BID FOR OUTSIDERS AT TALKS
description: President Jose Napoleon Duarte of El Salvador said today that his Government had rejected a request by guerrilla leaders that outside observers serve as intermediaries for their scheduled meeting on Monday. But Mr. Duarte said he believed the negotiations would nonetheless go forward.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: RESURRECTION A Pulitzer Prize usually extends the life of a play, but immortality is something else. This thought comes to mind with ''Why Marry?'' a comedy by Jesse Lynch Williams that in 1918 won the first Pulitzer Prize for drama. It has seldom, if ever, been heard of since, although the award did assure it a respectable run in its time. Perhaps it is not immortal, but the play is getting another shot at life with the Meat and Potatoes Company. It will be presented through Nov. 11 at the Alvina Krause Theater, 306 West 38th Street (564-3293).

title: Tri-Star Plans Stock Issue
description: Tri-Star Pictures Inc. filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday for an initial public offering of 4.5 million common shares. Proceeds will be used for general corporate purposes, including a reduction of the company's indebtedness.

title: COLUMBUS MILLS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Stocks Post Broad Gain As Trading Picks Up
description: Stock prices rose broadly yesterday in heavier trading, buoyed by some favorable economic news. In the overall market, advancing issues on the New York Stock Exchange outnumbered those that fell by more than 2 to 1 as volume swelled to 92.2 million shares, from 87 million the day before.

title: Peddlers and Politics
description: The Vice-Presidential debate didn't end when George Bush and Geraldine Ferraro walked off the stage Thursday night. Within minutes their partisans were smoothly lobbying reporters to see the result their way, and yesterday the principals were still arguing over who won.

title: HOOVER UNIVERSAL reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BRITISH AIDE ACCEPTS COAL PLAN
description: The state- run National Coal Board agreed today to a mediator's proposal for ending Britain's seven-month-old miners' strike, breaking a stalemate in negotiations.

title: CASTILLO WAS UNLIKELY HERO
description: One person who wasn't entirely convinced when the Detroit Tigers took the lead over the San Diego Padres in the World Series tonight was Sparky Anderson, their manager, who said: ''You haven't seen the Detroit Tigers out there yet.''

title: L & N HOUSING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Sun May Have Figured In Carolina Midair Crash
description: The setting sun may have blinded one of the pilots, leading to a midair crash of two light airplanes that rained debris over a playground crowded with young football players, officials said today.

title: TRAINS DON'T STOP, BUT PRESIDENTS DO
description: The trains don't stop here anymore, but today there was a notable exception: The Heartland Special, 16 coaches long, rumbled into the station carrying President Reagan and memories of Harry S. Truman.

title: BUSH AND FERRARO BOTH MADE MISTAKES IN DEBATE
description: Vice President Bush's office today defended his statement Thursday night that Federal spending for food stamps and welfare had risen under the Reagan Administration.

title: Equity and Producers Extend Negotiations
description: Actors Equity and the League of Off Broadway Theaters and Producers have extended their contract for a second week, until Oct. 21.

title: TSR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
U.S.-SAUDI RELATIONS: NOT BY OIL ALONE
description: To the Editor:

title: Ready for Kickoff
description: The final hurdle in the way of restoring a football program at beleaguered George Washington High School in Manhattan was cleared yesterday with the appointment of an assistant coach. He is Bruce Campbell , a 26-year-old former player at DeWitt Clinton High and at Colorado who is a special-education teacher at a private school in Manhattan.

title: HUNGRY TIGER INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
FOR SALE: REACTORS, CHEAP
description: Need a General Electric nuclear reactor? National Content Liquidators will sell one for a rock-bottom $350,000 - well below the original multimillion-dollar price tag.

title: ONEOK INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
PETROLEUM & RESOURCES CORP reports earnings for As of Sept 30
description: Asset figures represent net assets.

title: Jersey Poll Says Mondale Cuts Into Reagan's Lead
description: Walter F. Mondale has cut into President Reagan's popularity among New Jerseyans on the basis of his performance in the debate with Mr. Reagan Sunday, according to a poll made public here today.

title: American Ballet Lists 5 New Works for Season
description: American Ballet Theater will present the company premiere of Sir Kenneth MacMillan's ''Romeo and Juliet,'' four additional new works and revivals of six ballets during its 45th anniversary season, which begins Dec. 18 at the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington.

title: Howard Baker Steps Out
description: The end of this Congress also marks the end of the legislative career of Howard Baker of Tennessee. Sadly but probably correctly, one of the outstanding Republican leaders of modern times has decided that running for President is a full-time job and incompatible with the majority leadership he's performed so well for four years. He's going back to lawyering for a while, but is likely to be a major contender for his party's nomination in 1988, as he well deserves to be.

title: 30TH YEAR FOR BROOKLYN ARTS CENTER
description: Thirty years ago an audience filed into a theater in Brooklyn and settled down to hear a concert by a young singer named Leontyne Price, just two years out of the Juilliard School and beginning to make a name for herself abroad. The performing arts had come to Brooklyn College.

title: Mulvey Leaves Hockey
description: The right wing Grant Mulvey , who scored 39 goals for the Chicago Black Hawks in the 1979-80 National Hockey League season, has decided to retire at age 28. ''I could have fought my way back to play a few more games in the N.H.L., but I think there's a time when you should accept things gracefully,'' he said.

title: Courts Reject 2 Mothers Who Want Babies Back
description: Two unwed mothers who assert they were pressured into giving up their babies for adoption by officials at a charity home have lost custody battles in rulings hailed by the home as a ''vindication'' of its policies.

title: No Headline
description: Rooney, Pace Lays Off 55 The Wall Street firm of Rooney, Pace said it had laid off

title: I.R.A. SAYS IT SET BOMB THAT RIPPED THATCHER'S HOTEL
description: The Irish Republican Army took responsibility today for planting a bomb in a seafront hotel that killed at least two people, wounded at least 34 and came within minutes of killing or maiming Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher.

title: DEVILS ROMP OVER ISLANDERS IN OPENER
description: Mocked and laughed at for their first two years in New Jersey, even labeled a ''Mickey Mouse'' organization by none other than Wayne Gretzky, the Devils tonight quieted the one-liners and buried some of their sorrowful history with a 7-2 drubbing of the Islanders at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: UNION BANCORP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
U.N. Extends Mandate Of Troops in Lebanon
description: The Security Council voted today to extend the mandate of the United Nations force in southern Lebanon for six months amid suggestions that it might be expanded after Israeli troops are withdrawn.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, a Washington dispatch Thursday on criticism by the National Coalition of American Nuns of the abortion stand of the Roman Catholic hierarchy misstated the size of the nuns' organization. It has 2,000 members.

title: A BLOCK CONFRONTS LIFE WITHOUT TELEVISION
description: This is still a great nation. Yet there are thousands of people on the Upper East Side who have been going to bed hungry for Johnny Carson, Ted Koppel and Ralph Kramden.

title: ABANDON A REACTOR AND WIN - WIN BIG
description: To the Editor:

title: SOVIET DIPLOMAT NAMED IN SPY CASE
description: A Federal grand jury today named a Soviet vice consul as an unindicted co- conspirator in the espionage case involving a former agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation arrested last week.

title: WEIGH-TRONIX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
U.S. INVESTIGATING DRUG CHARGES INVOLVING VESCO AND SANDINISTAS
description: The United States Customs Service is investigating charges that the fugitive American financier Robert L. Vesco, working with the Nicaraguan Government, has financed cocaine smuggling to the United States and Europe, a Customs Service spokesman said today.

title: Mission of Mercy
description: Ed Reinhardt , the 19-year-old Colorado tight end who has been in a coma since shortly after being tackled in a game at Oregon on Sept. 15, may be transferred next week from a hospital in Eugene, Ore., to Denver, closer to his home. ''Ed's still quite critical,'' said Dr. Glenn Kindt of the Colorado University Health Sciences Center in Denver, ''but at least for the relatives and everyone involved, it would be good to have Ed here.'' Dr. Arthur Hockey , who removed a blood clot from the player's brain soon after the injury, said in Eugene that plans for the transfer would be scrapped if there were any complications. Otherwise, Reinhardt will be flown in a ''virtual flying intensive-care unit,'' said Alan Yordy , a spokesman for the Eugene hospital.

title: BANDAG INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
USING THE SENATE RULES TO ADVANTAGE
description: It was after midnight, and the Senate was wrapping up what had been one of the most agonizing crawls toward adjournment in memory.

title: CITY OPERA: SONDHEIM'S ''SWEENEY''
description: The decision to transfer ''Sweeney Todd,'' the Broadway success of 1979, to the opera house must have been based on the hope that with trained voices in the leading roles, Stephen Sondheim's gory argument in favor of vegetarianism would reveal itself as a work of real musical substance. That hope would seem difficult to justify based on the new production of ''Sweeney'' unveiled Thursday night by the New York City Opera.

title: WRITERS DISCUSS THEME OF MYTHS IN MODERN LIFE
description: Old myths, old gods, old heroes have never died. They are only sleeping at the bottom of our mind, waiting for our call. We have need for them. They represent the wisdom of our race.'' Thus the poet Stanley Kunitz sounded a major theme of a three-day conference of writers, artists and scholars on ''The Presence of Myth in Contemporary Life'' that opened Thursday at the New School.

title: In Pursuit of a Hat
description: As Howard H. Baker Jr. prepares to retire from the Senate at the end of the year to go into private law practice here, he is said to be getting ready to seek the 1988 Republican Presidential nomination. Is it too soon to toss a hat into that ring?

title: WORLD COURT SETTLES DISPUTE ON U.S.-CANADA BOUNDARY
description: The World Court settled a two-decade-old territorial dispute between the United States and Canada today, awarding the United States about two- thirds of the Gulf of Maine and giving Canada the rest.

title: INTEK DIVERSIFIED reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $163,370 for the quarter and 9 months.

title: Duo at the Bottom Line
description: The jazz guitarist Pat Martino and the bassist Stanley Clarke will team up tonight and tomorrow night at the Bottom Line, 15 West Fourth Street. Shows tonight will be at 8:30 and 11:30 and tomorrow at 8 and 11 P.M. Tickets are $10; information, 228- 6300.

title: G.I.'S WHO HELPED LIBERATE PARIS
description: To the Editor:

title: RIGHTEOUS FANATIC, NO
description: To the Editor:

title: AN AILING BRANNIFF TO CUT FARES AND SEEK MERGER
description: Patrick Foley, the vice chairman of Braniff Inc., said yesterday that the airline would add more seats to its planes and cut its fares further in an effort to stem its losses and become profitable.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an article on the Washington Talk page Thursday about the Farmers Home Administration incorrectly identified a woman in the last two paragraphs. The woman whose employment was discussed in these paragraphs was Carol Shuman, daughter of Charles W. Shuman, head of the Farmers Home Administration.

title: 3 Former Mayors Join Panel To Push Democratic Ticket
description: Three former Mayors of New York joined in announcing a new committee Thursday to support the Democratic ticket, and they ridiculed President Reagan's record.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 50.

title: LONG SHOT LEADS MARCH TO GLORY
description: The cadets in Company A-1 are puffed up with pride, almost bursting the buttons of their gray tunics because of the accomplishments of Doug Black. The junior fullback failed a pair of football tryouts, played instead on their intramural squad and now leads a team that is off to Army's best start in 26 years.

title: Comings and Goings
description: The San Diego Chargers have signed the free agent place-kicker Benny Ricardo to fill in while Rolf Benirschke recovers from surgery to remove a kidney stone. Ricardo played for the Chargers and three other teams in his N.F.L. career. . . . Michigan State's head basketball coach, Jud Heathcote , who suffered a heart attack last month, has been released from a Lansing hospital and is resting at home.

title: ;  Vote on Blue Laws Allowed by Judge
description: State Supreme Court Justice Sidney M. Schreiber today cleared the way for Jersey City voters to decide Nov. 6 whether to legalize Sunday shopping.

title: THE REGION ; ;  Retraining Backed For Educators
description: Connecticut's 37,000 teachers and school administrators would have to take additional college courses or other professional training every five years to keep their licenses valid under a plan approved yesterday by the State Board of Education's Certification Advisory Council.

title: SATURDAY SPORTS Baseball
description: Tigers vs. San Diego Padres, World Series, fourth game, at Detroit. A matchup between aces: Jack Morris and Eric Show. (Television - Channel 4, 1 P.M. Radio - WCBS, 880; 1:10 P.M.) Football

title: CONTINENTAL INFORMATION SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
SCHOLASTIC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
JAZZ: SINGER, JOE WILLIAMS, AT BLUE NOTE
description: Joe Williams's performance at the Blue Note, where he is singing through tomorrow, is a mixture of his own established past and evidence that he is continuing to reach out even within that context. Now that his hair is dusted with gray, his voice is not quite the robust instrument that it once was and he is more inclined to talk his songs than to sing them.

title: Westphal Is Waived
description: The veteran guard Paul Westphal , still awaiting word on whether he will be paid what he contends should be a guaranteed salary this season, has been waived by the Phoenix Suns. Westphal played sparingly in the Suns' recent exhibition games, and yesterday Coach John MacLeod said the club had elected to go with some of its younger players at the guard spots.

title: Cheers for Riggins
description: As John Riggins approached the 10,000-yardstick of National Football League greatness, Joe Theismann , his Washington Redskin teammate who has kept a low profile this season, broke a self-imposed silence to laud him. ''Everybody knows it takes 49 players to make a team, but without Big John this would not be a championship squad,'' said Theismann, the team's starting quarterback. Riggins needs to gain only 24 yards against Dallas tomorrow to join Walter Payton , Jim Brown , Franco Harris and O. J. Simpson as one of only five 10,000-yard rushers in the N.F.L.'s 62- year history.

title: CHEROKEE GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 1
3 TAX-RELIEF BILLS ARE PASSED
description: Congress has approved three tax-relief measures and President Reagan is expected to sign them.

title: FIRST BANCORP OF OHIO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
FERRARO, DESCRIBING STRATEGY, CLAIMS VICTORY
description: Geraldine A. Ferraro, supported by exuberant followers, today claimed victory in Thursday night's debate with Vice President Bush. Her aides said the encounter had established the fact that she was qualified to serve as Vice President.

title: Maryland Prison Guards Walk Out Over Security
description: State troopers today replaced 48 prison guards who staged a walkout, saying they were sick, at the Maryland Penitentiary. The guards said they wanted to dramatize their claims of lax security that led to the death of a guard.

title: PULTE HOME CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Relaxed Ryun Running for Fun
description: The pressures and the frustrations that once dogged his career have disappeared, and Jim Ryun is once again able to run with pleasure instead of pain.

title: Disney's Studios in Burbank Are Picketed by Park Strikers
description: Union members who are on strike against Disneyland set up picket lines today outside the Walt Disney Studios in Burbank, broadening their 18-day- old walkout as the park started hiring replacements for dismissed strikers.

title: POLICE PROGRAM AIMS TO PREVENT DOMESTIC FIGHTS
description: The Police Department has begun a one-year experiment that will pair police officers with family counselors in an effort to prevent domestic violence.

title: ADAMS EXPRESS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Asset figures represent net assets.

title: THE CITY ; ;  Voter Registration Ends at 9 Tonight
description: Polling places will be open from 1 P.M. to 9 P.M. today for the final registration to vote Nov. 6.

title: Labor Dispute Delays Printing of The Times
description: Production of today's early editions of The New York Times was delayed two and a half hours last night because of a dispute involving two pressmen who had been disciplined by a press room foreman.

title: BUSINES DIGEST
description: SATURDAY, OCTOBER 13, 1984

title: LYDALL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $4,491,000 for the quarter and $5,920,000 for the 9 months. c-Including income from discontinued operations of $477,000 for the quarter and $1,468,000 for the 9 months. Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split in June 1984.

title: U.S. Captures Title in Soccer
description: Ade Coker scored a late goal to give the United States national team a 1-0 victory Thursday night over Colombia and the championship of the Columbus Cup exhibition soccer tournament at the Coliseum.

title: TWO LIBYANS ARE SENTENCED IN A FEDERAL WEAPONS CASE
description: Two Libyan nationals who had admitted they illegally bought three handguns with silencers from a Federal undercover agent on Staten Island last May were sentenced to prison yesterday in Federal District Court in Brooklyn.

title: PENTAGON IS PROPOSING RULES FOR THE PRESS AT BATTLEFIELDS
description: The Defense Department has proposed a set of ground rules, based on those of the Vietnam era, that would permit coverage of United States military operations by reporters accredited to the Pentagon without the imposition of censorship.

title: Ranch's Royal Guest Arrives for Weekend
description: Queen Elizabeth, who arrived today for a weekend in Wyoming ranch country, was greeted at the airport by a crowd that included cheering English war brides.

title: WEST POINT RABBI
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;
description: Patty Cake Expecting

title: NEWS SUMMARY;
description: SATURDAY, OCTOBER 13, 1984 International The I.R.A. took responsibility for placing a bomb in a seafront hotel that killed at least two people, injured at least 34 and came within minutes of killing or maiming Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher. Mrs. Thatcher, who escaped without injury, had just left the bathroom of her suite when the explosion ripped through the Brighton hotel. Her husband, Denis, later reported that the bathroom was ''mangled.'' (Page 1, Column 6.) The I.R.A. bombing of the hotel in Brighton was aimed at derailing new efforts to achieve a settlement in Northern Ireland, according to British and Irish politicians. Prime Minister Thatcher is scheduled to discuss the Northern Ireland situation next month with Garret FitzGerald, the Irish Prime Minister. (4:1-2.)

title: Ireland's Possessed
description: Dostoyevsky once wrote that no cause justified the killing of a single child. To the Irish Republican Army, like the terrorists in his novels, the reverse is true. Its adherents believe that any deed is sanctified as long as it promotes the great cause of purging Northern Ireland of British ''occupiers.'' So its bombing in Brighton, which came close to killing Prime Minister Thatcher, is of the same piece as its slaughter of Christmas shoppers, its terror bombing of a dance hall and its ''execution'' of suspected Catholic traitors, youngsters included.

title: IC-Pneumo Link
description: IC Industries said its proposed merger of the Pneumo Corporation and an IC subsidiary had been oversubscribed. Pneumo shareholders who tendered their shares by Thursday will receive $38 for about 75 percent of the shares covered and 1.49 shares of IC common stock for each remaining share.

title: No Headline
description: 3 New Subway Fires Occur in Manhattan

title: AMERICAN WRITES JINLES FOR THAI TV
description: What does a 37-year-old avant-garde composer from southern California do for a living in Thailand?

title: A.F.L.-C.I.O.'S KIRKLAND BRINGS MONDALE'S MESSAGE TO UNIONISTS
description: Calling President Reagan ''the most bitter enemy of working men and women,'' Lane Kirkland, president of the A.F.L.- C.I.O., urged local union leaders here to forget public opinion polls and make a strong effort in the next three weeks to register their members to vote and secure those votes for Walter F. Mondale, the Democratic Party's nominee for President.

title: Merrill Lynch Insurance Accord
description: The life insurance subsidiary of Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith Inc. has agreed to pay the state a $45,000 fine and to stop selling annuity policies offered by the financially troubled Baldwin-United Corporation, the state's top insurance official said.

title: SEPTEMBER RETAIL SALES UP BY 1.6%
description: Retail sales rose 1.6 percent in September, following two months of declines, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: REDMAN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 28
UST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ANTHEM ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Spet 30
ITT LAYOFF OF 795 SET IN 3 STATES
description: NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;
description: Greengrocer's sign at Ninth Avenue

title: NATIONAL HOMES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income.

title: Carter Calls Debate a Draw; He Liked Ferraro Competence
description: Former President Jimmy Carter said today that he thought the Vice-Presidential debate Thursday was a draw but that he was pleased with Representative Geraldine A. Ferraro's performance against Vice President Bush.

title: INTERGRAPH CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SALVADORAN REBELS WARY ON LOGISTICS
description: A Salvadoran rebel leader insisted today that an intermediary between the rebels and the Government of President Jose Napoleon Duarte would have to come here to discuss security preparations and logistics for a meeting Monday if it is to take place as scheduled.

title: TRADE AGENCY'S HEAD ASSAILS POLICIES OF U.S.
description: The head of the United States International Trade Commission, Paula Stern, charged today that the Reagan Administration and other Federal policy makers had allowed American manufacturers to be so ravaged by foreign competition that the nation risked the loss of much of its industrial base and jobs.

title: Tennis, for Now
description: For the moment, being an actress is only a sideline for Carling Bassett. But things could change someday.

title: A LECTURER ON WORLD AFFAIRS
description: Ruth Gage-Colby, a lecturer on world affairs and a longtime advocate for peace, died Sept. 25 at the Bird Haven Christian Convalescent Hospital in Norwalk, Calif.. She was 85 years old.

title: HANDBOOK ADVISES ON CAREERS
description: ''Nine out of 10 girls will work during their lifetimes.'' So begins ''It's Your Future! Catalyst's Career Guide for High School Girls.'' This 324-page paperback book is the latest publication created by Catalyst, an organization based in New York City that has a wide range of programs to help women of all ages deal with career and family issues.

title: REAGAN FOLLOWS THE TRACKS OF TRUMAN '48 TRAIN TOUR
description: President Reagan, taking his re-election caravan on Harry S. Truman's 1948 whistle-stop train route, drew cheers from huge crowds in the farmlands and towns of western Ohio today.

title: FEDERAL SCREW WORKS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Nigeria Signs Deal To Buy 12 Soviet MIG's
description: The Nigerian Government has signed an agreement to buy 12 MIG-21B jet fighters from the Soviet Union.

title: ALBERT BLACKTON
description: Albert Blackton, a leader in the design and manufacture of women's undergarments, died Thursday, apparently of a heart attack, at his desk at Valmont Industries in Manhattan. He was 75 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: TELEVISED DEBATES: CANDIDATES HAVE YET TO MASTER THE MEDIUM
description: As the Ferraro and Bush families mingled on stage in Philadelphia Thursday night, smiling and shaking hands in the moment of post-debate relief, Peter Jennings, the ABC News anchor, leaned forward with a curious look and asked a question through his microphone of Gloria Steinem, who was being interviewed in the hall. ''Mrs. Ferraro on the stump is a very feisty woman,'' he said. ''Is this a different Ferraro?''

title: Morse Shoes
description: Morse Shoe Inc. said its agreement to operate 180 shoe departments in Wal-Mart Stores will not be renewed when it expires on Feb. 1, 1987. Wal- Mart plans to take over shoe operations in half the stores in 1986, and the rest on the expiration date, Morse said. The current arrangement accounted for about 7 percent of Morse's 1983 sales of $523 million.

title: Ampco-Portec Tie
description: The Ampco-Pittsburgh Corporation said that it had acquired 9.4 percent of Portec Inc.'s common stock and that it was considering a ''long-term relationship'' with Portec, possibly through a merger.

title: A Survivor's Narrative
description: EMPIRE OF THE SUN. By J. G. Ballard. 279 pages. Simon & Schuster. $16.95.

title: Poisoning of Candy In Japan Forces Layoffs
description: The Morinaga candy company, hit by sales losses after extortionists poisoned its products with cyanide, laid off 450 workers today and cut production in half.

title: AMSOUTH BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SOUTH CAROLINA NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Key Rates
description: * split rate, 12.50-12.75 ** Kenny Index, Kenny Information Systems Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: ORGANIZER OF DEATH-ROW ESCAPE IS EXECUTED IN A VIRGINIA PRISON
description: Linwood Briley, a convicted killer who organized an escape from death row in May, was executed tonight in Virginia's electric chair for shooting a country-western disc jockey in the back. He was pronounced dead at 11:05 P.M.

title: Elusive Citation
description: Will Rogers certainly did say, ''I tell you folks, all politics is applesauce.''

title: 4 IN APARTMENT DIE IN UPSTATE BLAZE
description: An apartment-house fire killed four people today in this western New York town, authorities said.

description: A Birthday Window

title: VELO-BIND INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results for the latest third quarter include a reversal of $183,000 of deferred taxes on the prior years undistributed earnings of Velo-Bind's Domestic International sales corporation.

description: PAMELA G. HOLLIE

title: UNITED FOODS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
IN CHESS, 'BREZHNEV' VS. 'BARYSHNIKOV'
description: As Konstantin U. Chernenko's health waxes and wanes, a succession struggle of titanic proportions is being waged inside the Soviet Union. It is a struggle between good and evil in which intensive preparation, careful planning and imaginative vision are required. It is the struggle for succession to the title of world chess champion.

title: AMERICAN ECOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BANK OF DELAWARE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
7 ASTRONAUTS PREPARE TO LAND TODAY
description: The Challenger astronauts, elated by the successes of their ambitious mission to map the earth and to practice for refueling satellites in orbit, today gathered an extra helping of scientific data, chatted with President Reagan and cleaned up their crowded cabin in preparation for their return to the earth Saturday.

title: Go-Ahead for Orlando
description: The United States Football League formally approved Orlando, Fla., as the home of the shifted Washington Federals' franchise. Commissioner Chet Simmons said Don Dizney , the Orlando businessman who bought the floundering club, ''brings strong local leadership to the league.''

title: Award to Dayco
description: The Dayco Corporation said it had been awarded a $19 million judgment against Edith Reich, a sales agent. The ruling came in Federal District Court for the Southern District of New York. The ruling came after the New York bankruptcy court removed court protection that had been granted to the sales agent during bankruptcy proceedings for her company, the Foreign Transactions Corporation.

title: FRIENDS SAY DAVID KENNEDY WAS DRINKING AND DEPRESSED
description: The Palm Beach County State Attorney's Office today released more than 500 pages of documents in the investigation of the drug-induced death of David Kennedy, the 28-year-old son of Ethel and Robert F. Kennedy.

description: An informal deadline for a settlement in the negotiations between the Ford Motor Company and the United Automobile Workers passed at noon today with both sides still at the bargaining table.

description: Some suit combinations offer considerable scope for defensive subtlety.

title: COMPUTER DOWN ON THE FARM
description: Dave and Cheryl Kalsem, who farm 540 acres of corn, and move 1,000 head of cattle annually through their feedlot operation in central Iowa, got an International Business Machines Personal Computer this spring. They thus joined a select group of Iowa farmers who are test-marketing a computer service being developed by Pioneer Hi-Bred International Inc., the nation's leading seed company.

title: Coast Man Holds Four In Bank Before Giving Up
description: A man scheduled to be sentenced Monday for bank robbery kidnapped a bank manager at her home today, then held her and three other employees hostage at a Bank of America for two and a half hours before releasing them unharmed and surrendering, officers said.

description: A new study by the State Comptroller questions whether Erie County can remain solvent through the end of the year, according to county and state officials.

title: FIRST WHITE, A BABY, DIES IN SOUTH AFRICAN UNREST
description: The unrest that has stirred in black townships in recent weeks claimed its first known white victim today when a 3-week-old boy traveling in the lap of a black maid in his mother's car was hit on the head by a rock thrown through a window.

description: Producer prices for finished goods fell two-tenths of 1 percent in September, held down by declines in the cost of food and fuel, the Labor Department reported today.

description: A Shift at the U.D.C.

description: The First Chicago Corporation, as it had previously warned, yesterday reported a large loss for the third quarter after writing off bad loans in domestic energy and agriculture, and foreign shipping and construction.

19-Year-Old Man Held in Rape Before Crowd at High School
description: A county judge set bond at $50,000 today for a teen-ager accused of dragging a 15-year-old girl into a high school restroom, where she was raped before a crowd of 7 to 10 onlookers.

title: Weinberger Comment On SS-20's Is Disputed
description: A Soviet Foreign Ministry official today denied an assertion by Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger that the Soviet Union had increased the number of nuclear missiles aimed at Western Europe.

title: NEW EFFORTS TO INFORM PUBLIC ON HEALTH 'QUACKERY'
description: Alice Hall, desperate to lose weight, spent $52.95 on a bottle of pills that she saw advertised in a magazine. The advertisement showed a slender woman in a tent-size pair of pants that, according to the headline, no longer fit. By swallowing 10 capsules a day, the advertisement promised, Mrs. Hall too could lose 10 pounds in two weeks. She took the pills as instructed for more than a month but didn't lose a pound.

title: HARPSICHORD: LINDA KOBLER
description: Linda Kobler's harpsichord concert at Carnegie Recital Hall Thursday was a pleasure to hear. She showed such mastery of rhythmic articulation, and such zest for the drama of ornament and the interplay of sound and silence, that her instrument's inherent narrowness of expressive possibilities in other areas (which sometimes inhibit its appeal for a generalist modern audience) can hardly have been felt.

title: ATOM WAR 'SUICIDE PILLS' BACKED
description: Undergraduates at Brown University have voted to ask its health service to stockpile ''suicide pills'' for use in case of nuclear war.

title: KOCH SEES MARATHON STAYING
description: Mayor Koch and Fred Lebow, president of the New York Road Runners Club, met at City Hall yesterday in an effort to settle their differences over the offering of prize money to the top finishers in the New York City Marathon.

title: Colgate Acts To Thwart Bids
description: Responding to takeover rumors, the Colgate-Palmolive Company paid a dividend of common-stock rights that could be used to thwart a tender offer.

title: GRANT'S TOMB, MONUMENT TO NEGLECT
description: As Miss Liberty is restored to her original glory, we should spare a thought at least for a forgotten monument - the Grant National Memorial. It stands at Riverside Drive and 122d Street, out of sight of most citizens' gaze and out of the minds of public officials. From its appearance, it is fair to say that nobody cares about its condition, yet when it was being built everybody in America had an opinion about how it should look.

description: Norman Tebbit, the most senior British official wounded in this morning's explosion at the Grand Hotel here, is a leading candidate to succeed Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher as Conservative Party leader when she steps down.

title: RANDOM HOUSE TO ACQUIRE TIMES BOOKS OPERATION
description: The New York Times Company has agreed in principle to sell Times Books, its book publishing operation, to Random House Inc.

description: Britain's annual rate of inflation fell to 4.7 percent in September, down from 5 percent in August, the Government said today.

description: Geraldine A. Ferraro today met privately for about 20 minutes with an anti-abortion heckler who had interrupted her speech at a high school near here.

description: Light Signatures Inc., a Los Angeles company that codes merchandise labels to prevent counterfeiting, received a patent this week for technology it regards as preventing counterfeiting of plastic credit cards.

title: Honoring Slain Officers
description: Washington is to get a new monument, honoring law enforcement officers killed in the line of duty. Legislation providing for the National Law Enforcement Officers Heroes Memorial has been approved by Congress and is expected to be signed into law by President Reagan.

title: Evenings of Greek Music
description: Mikis Theodorakis, the Greek composer and conductor, will lead an orchestral program of Greek music at Madison Square Garden's Felt Forum tonight at 8 and tomorrow at 7:30 P.M. The program will feature the vocalist Maria Farandouri. Tickets, $15 to $30; information, 564-4400.

description: A man who the police say confessed killing three women this summer was indicted today on charges of murder, attempted murder and rape in those deaths and in the sexual assault on a 14- year-old girl.

description: Margaret Papandreou, wife of the Greek Prime Minister, said yesterday that women should not get ''uptight'' if controversial political issues crop up in the Nairobi World Conference in 1985, which marks the end of the United Nations Decade for Women.

description: Thomas Eugene Gaddis, whose 1955 book ''Birdman of Alcatraz'' became one of the nation's best-known prison biographies, died Wednesday in a Portland nursing home. He was 76 years old and was suffering from cancer.

title: Iranians Bomb Tanker From India in the Gulf
description: An Iranian plane has bombed an Indian oil tanker, apparently in retaliation for an Iraqi attack on a supertanker near the Kharg Island oil terminal off Iran, shipping officials said today.

title: IMMIGRATION AGENTS VISIT OFFICES OF SPANISH-LANGUAGE NEWSPAPER
description: Agents of the Immigration and Naturalization Service visited the offices of the Spanish-language newspaper El Diario this week to check the immigration papers of three reporters and an editor.

description: Walter Byers, the executive director of the National Collegiate Athletic Association, says that illegal payments and other improprieties are so widespread in intercollegiate athletics that a convention of university presidents should be called to explore the possibility of a tougher code of violations.

title: BANKERS FIRST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Pro forma basis, the company converted to public stock in April. The company said it changed its accounting year-end to Dec. 31 from June 20.

title: Beatrice in China
description: The Beatrice Companies started a $10 million joint venture with China to make ice cream, soft drinks and other products, the official New China News Agency reported. The 15-year project will operate through the Guangmei Food Company, a company backed by Beatrice, the China International Trust and Investment Corporation and the Guangzhou Food Industrial Company.

description: An angry Walter F. Mondale demanded an apology today from Vice President Bush for making what the Democratic Presidential nominee called an ''unpardonable'' comment Thursday night about Lebanon.

title: CONGRESS STANDOFF DELAYS ROAD AND TRANSIT FUNDS
description: A standoff between the House and Senate over the terms for spending some Federal funds for highways and mass transit has delayed allocation of $7 billion in Highway Trust funds to the states until 1985.

title: U.S. Promises Signs Won't Be Confiscated
description: The Justice Department has promised that there will be no more confiscating of homemade signs at political rallies here. It acted after demonstrators filed suit because their placards were seized while President Reagan was making a speech here last summer.

title: SETTLEMENT TO REQUIRE U.S. TO ENFORCE STRIP-MINE LAWS
description: Interior Secretary William P. Clark will sign an out-of-court settlement Monday that will roll back a number of efforts by his predecessor. James G. Watt, to deregulate strip mining, aides to Mr. Clark said today.

title: 'HEAD-HUNTING' IN THE LANDSCAPES OF CEZANNE
description: There have been few artists more complex than Paul Cezanne. The high priest of Modernism was an explosive bundle of contradictions. He could be crude, aggressive, submissive and pathologically suspicious. Yet, he could also be analytical, generous and capable of an artistic courage and devotion that have rarely been surpassed. It is a mark of his genius that he was eventually able to convince the demons that were frolicking about within him that they would be better off submitting themselves to the laws of his art. Cezanne arrived at the astonishing clarity and volume of his mature work not by smothering his tempestuous, unpredictable, doubting nature, but by finding a language in which the irrationality and violence within him could breathe. If Cezanne built the most radiant cathedral of 19th-century art, it is because that cathedral is inhabited by a terrible cry.

title: Neighbor Dashes Padres
description: When he was in the eighth grade, he used to sneak into the San Diego Stadium or sometimes sell soft drinks in the upper deck. He still lives about two miles from the Padres' ball park. In the winter, he goes to the stadium every Monday, Wednesday and Friday and works out with some of the Padres. He even gets treated by their trainer.

title: Jack B. Kester Jr. A
description: Mr. and Mrs. James Edward Buck of Manhasset, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Tara Killingsworth Buck, to Jack Bevel Kester Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Kester of Salisbury, N.C. A December wedding is planned.

title: CHINA'S CITIES TO GET MORE CAPITALISM
description: Encouraged by the success of rural policies that have increased agricultural production, China is about to begin a sweeping program in the cities that will give capitalistic market forces a greater role in its centrally planned Marxist economy.

title: CAN CITY'S PLAN REBUILD THE LOWER EAST SIDE?
description: The streets of Manhattan's Lower East Side may bear the scars of unrealized dreams, but they remain home for thousands of poor and working-class families. The Koch administration is betting that thousands of others may soon want to live there, too.

title: David B. Perry Is Wed To Elizabeth F. Maury
description: Elizabeth Fontaine Maury, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John M. Maury of Rowayton, Conn., was married yesterday to David Bulkley Perry, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Hoyt O. Perry Jr. of Southport, Conn. The Rev. Douglas Ray performed the ceremony at St. Luke's Episcopal Church in Darien, Conn., assisted by the Rev. Donald Emig, a United Church of Christ minister.

title: SOUTHERN REPUBLICANS HITCH HOPES TO A STRONG PERFORMANCE BY REAGAN
description: Republican candidates in the South are seeking to translate President Reagan's enormous popularity in the region into election victories for other offices next month, but people who follow politics say such an outcome is unlikely.

title: A TRIBUTE TO MOVIE SONGS
description: AFTER two seasons of presenting popularly oriented musical entertainments, including a couple of self-explanatory ''Broadway Song Books,'' The Theater League of Westchester is moving into the realm of the movies.

title: Passaic's 16th in Row
description: Passaic (4-0) won its 16th in a row yesterday when it downed Paterson Kennedy, 8-0, in Paterson. The touchdown was scored in the third quarter on a 10-play, 53-yard drive capped by a 4-yard burst by Troy Giles, a junior tailback.

title: Sculptor Married ToMissMacIsaac
description: Heather Smith MacIsaac, a daughter of Virginia MacIsaac of Brooklyn and J. Val Smith of Dallas, was married yesterday to Peter Lewis Menderson, a son of Elizabeth Menderson of Glasgow and Ted Menderson of Cincinnati. The Rev. Harold Elliot Barrett performed the Episcopal ceremony at the Grace Church in New York.

title: YALE BEATS DARTMOUTH, 28-18
description: Yale won its first Ivy League game at home in two years today as the Elis beat Dartmouth, 28-18, before a crowd of 25,572 in the Yale Bowl.

title: SWITZERLAND'S LITTLE ITALY
description: PAUL HOFMANN is the author of ''O Vatican! A Slightly Wicked View of the Holy See'' (Congdon & Weed).

title: Patricia Halloran To Marry Dec. 29
description: Patricia Kathryn Halloran, a third- year student at George Washington University Law School, and Andrew McBrayer Garvey, a candidate for an M.B.A. at Harvard University, plan to be married Dec. 29. The announcement of their engagement has been made by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Leo A. Halloran of New Canaan, Conn.

description: Sarah Schuyler Tweedy, a daughter of Helen B. Chenery of Oyster Bay, L.I., and John Bayard Tweedy of Denver, was married yesterday to David Geror Manning Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Manning of St. Michaels, Md. The Rev. Richard Leonard performed the ceremony at the Unitarian Church of All Souls in New York.

title: THE WORLD ; U.S. and MoscowTrade ChargesOf Cheating
description: A report accusing the Soviet Union of violating its arms control commitments for military advantage has been in the White House files since January. An expurgated version was issued last week, a day after similar charges by Moscow against the United States, at the insistence of conservatives in Congress.

title: LETTERS TO THE CONNECTICUT EDITOR
description: A Turnaround In Kent A correction needs to be made in the article regarding the hot-dog stands in Kent (''Hot-Dog Stands Find Home in Kent,'' Sept. 16.) The hot-dog stand was not in front of Kent Station, nor is this building an ''old clapboard'' railroad station.

title: Roman Mosaic Floors Are Dug Up in Crete
description: Greek archaeologists excavating in Kastelli Kissamou on Crete have unearthed parts of a Roman villa decorated with multicolored mosaics and frescoes.

title: Patricia Haas Is the Bride of David A. Cleveland
description: Patricia Ann Haas, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. George A. Haas of Alexandria, Va., was married yesterday to David Adams Cleveland, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert G. Cleveland of Washington. The ceremony was performed in the great choir of the National Cathedral in Washington by the Very Rev. Francis B. Sayre Jr., an Episcopalian who is former dean of the cathedral, and the Rev. William J. English, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: TWO abused women with a total of seven children have found temporary refuge for the last three weeks at Apostles' House, an emergency shelter for displaced families.

description: HOUSE and Senate negotiators moved to agreement in Washington last week on a compromise measure to finance the first stage of the Connecticut Coastal Wildlife Refuge, a four- parcel package of coastal lands formerly known for its largest constituent - Chimon Island in Norwalk Harbor.

description: A COLLECTOR'S STORY

title: TEXAS WOES

title: Carol Ann Salvati a Bride
description: Carol Ann Salvati, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Eugene Philip Salvati of Bridgewater, N.J., was married yesterday to James Kevin Spry, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James Edward Spry of North Caldwell, N.J. The Rev. Michael Moran performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at the Chapel of the Immaculate Conception of Mount St. Mary's Academy in Watchung, N.J. Mrs. Spry is an assistant marketing manager for Citibank in New York. Mr. Spry is an assistant vice president of the United States Testing Company in Hoboken, N.J.

title: COURT SECURITY TIGHTENED
description: A RANGE of measures intended to improve security in the Nassau County court complex in Mineola, where court officers and defendants fired shots last month during an attempted escape, have been introduced in advance of preliminary reports on the incident that are expected next week.

title: Photo of Domingo Laino; PARAGUAY EXILE PRAISES LATIN DEMOCRATIC TREND
description: A prominent Paraguayan exile said in an interview here this week that moves toward democracy in Argentina and Brazil were encouraging the opposition in his country.

title: BRAZIL SIGNS SAUDI ARMS DEAL AND HOPES FOR MORE
description: Brazil has concluded a major military cooperation agreement with Saudi Arabia that should increase Brazil's arms sales to the Middle East.

title: Space Commission Created
description: President Reagan today signed an executive order creating a National Commission on Space to write an agenda for the space program and lay out a 20- year program for civilian space activities. The new commission will be composed of 15 voting members appointed by the President and up to 13 nonvoting members appointed by the President and Congress. The panel will be directed to study the nation's existing and proposed civilian space activities and to plan an agenda, long-term goals, opportunities and policy options.

title: PERES VISITS WASHINGTON FOR WARMER TIES, INCREASED AID
description: Shimon Peres's first trip to the United States as Prime Minister of Israel ended last week with at least one likely achievement. As a result of the talks here, American and Israeli officials seem convinced that relations are apt to be considerably more harmonious than during the past seven years of Likud rule. The new national unity Government is expected to be more cooperative, more supportive and less critical of the United States than the Governments of Menachem Begin and Yitzhak Shamir, which had a penchant for undermining American policy in the Middle East.

title: Five States Are to Participate In a Program on Farm Debts
description: The states of Iowa, Kansas, Minnesota, Missouri and Nebraska are to be used in the initial phases of a Federal effort to help farmers cope with large debts.

description: SINS OF OMISSION

title:
ART;
NEW L.I. TALENT ON VIEW
description: YOUNG artists living and working on the Island are perhaps more fortunate than many of their contemporaries in other parts of the country in that they have a wide range of outlets for their work. Community organizations, library exhibition programs, college and university galleries and numerous jury competitions around the region offer them opportunities to put their efforts before the public.

title: JUST AN OLD-FASHIONED CROSSING
description: WALTER LOGAN is the retired foreign editor of United Press International.

title: CHICAGO MARATHON EMERGES AS 'SECOND TO NONE' FOR '84
