description: IN the Democratically controlled

title: Hearings Set for Voting In Oregon Guru Dispute
description: The Oregon Secretary of State has scheduled residency hearings Oct. 23 for people seeking to vote in Wasco County, where longtime residents fear a government takeover by followers of the Indian guru Bhagwan Shree Rajneesh.

title: A NEGLECTED MOZART OPERA MAKES ITS DEBUT AT THE METROPOLITAN
description: Mozart's ''Clemenza di Tito'' - an opera being slowly extricated from beneath two centuries of myth and misunderstanding - makes its Metropolitan Opera debut this Thursday in a new production by Jean-Pierre Ponnelle. Mr. Ponnelle is by rights the only man for the job; for it is he, in a series of productions over the past 15 years, who has done the extricating almost singlehandedly.

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: DANCERS and musicians in New Haven have found a new stage - the downtown shopping district. They are occupying it all this month in an experimental project called ''Artspark.'' Twenty-three free lunchtime and afterwork performances have been scheduled at the Chapel Square Mall, the new Shubert Square entertainment district, the New Haven Green, the Yale Center for British Art and the Grant's Building on Orange Street.

title: PROSPECTS IN THE METROLPOLITAN AREA
description: THE job market in Westchester remains one of the sdtrongest in New York State, and new businesses and more jobs are foreseen, to brighten the county's already stable economy.

title: Deborah M. Graham, a Ballet Teacher, Is Married
description: Deborah Mae Graham, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George G. Graham of Mill Valley, Calif., was married yesterday to Peter Hendrickson Bice, a son of the Rev. and Mrs. Arthur L. Bice of Herkimer, N.Y. The bridegroom's father performed the ceremony at St. Thomas Episcopal Church in New York, assisted by the Revs. Gary P. Fertig and Leslie J. A. Lang.

title: CHLDREN'S BOOKS
description: RISKING LOVE

title: CABLE TV
description: Though life in general may be short on second chances, television is generous. For evidence, take three 1983 movies available on cable this week - ''Under Fire,'' ''Never Say Never Again'' and ''Octopussy.'' Though all have been broadcast previously, all can be recommended to anyone who missed them the first time around.

title: Susan Browndorf Weds
description: Susan Lyn Browndorf, a daughter of Mrs. Irving Milrod of River Edge, N.J., and the late Marvin Browndorf, was married yesterday to Paul Odell Hirschbiel Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Hirschbiel of Staunton, Va. Charles Agin, a justice of the peace, officiated at the ceremony at the Carlyle Hotel.

title: ADAMS CRUSHES FAR ROCKAWAY
description: Using its strong running game, last year's city champion, John Adams, routed visiting Far Rockaway by 38-0, scoring five touchdowns on the ground and emerging as the last undefeated team in Queens Public Schools Athletic League football.

title: Cathey Attridge Marries
description: Catherine Therese Attridge, the daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Patrick J. Attridge of New York, was married yesterday to Eugene F. Martin Jr., the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Martin of New York. Msgr. Edward Jolley, the bride's cousin, performed the ceremony at St. Thomas More Roman Catholic Church in New York. The bride, who is known as Cathey and will keep her name professionally, is an interior designer. Mr. Martin is president of T.E.G. Management, a Manhattan real estate company.

title: ISRAEL IN LEBANON: WRONG TACTICS FOR TERRAIN?
description: An American military analyst has criticized the effectiveness of Israel's 1982 invasion of Lebanon, arguing that its armed forces were unprepared for fighting a war on Lebanese terrain. The analyst, Maj. Richard A. Gabriel, an Army Reserve officer, asserts that the final outcome of the campaign ''ought not to obscure the fact that this was a military operation in which Israeli forces performed somewhat less brilliantly than expected and certainly less effectively than in their other wars.''

title: THE BIG BOARD'S FIGHT TO STAY ON TOP
description: LONDON ON a grey London morning, John J. Phelan Jr., who sits atop the citadel of free world capitalism, the New York Stock Exchange, eased into a boxy black taxi and went calling. He met with officials at the Bank of England on famed Threadneedle Street and at the London Stock Exchange nearby. He held talks at the Salomon Brothers, Merrill Lynch and Goldman Sachs offices here. And he broke bread with international financiers at the venerable City of London Club. Mr. Phelan was a man on the prowl - posing questions, listening and sniffing out the latest trends in world finance.

title: NEW YORK'S CONTROVERSIAL ARCHBISHOP
description: THE ROMAN CATHOLIC MASS HAD ended and the Archbishop of New York, John J. O'Connor, joined the procession of priests, deacons and altar boys filing out of St. Andrew's Church in Lower Manhattan as the organist played ''The Battle Hymn of the Republic.'' As the Archbishop approached the door, a worried aide rushed up and whispered to him that a group of reporters had gathered on the church steps. Without even breaking his stride, the Archbishop, wearing a flowing bright red chasuble and his bishop's miter, marched out the 14 church door and up to the waiting microphones.

title: DO'S AND DON'TS FOR THE DAYPACKER
description: MORNINGS are cool these days, and evenings are sweater weather. But in between, temperatures are balmy - a perfect time for daypacking.

title: LIFE WITH FATHER
description: Willard Gaylin is a psychiatrist and the president of the Hastings Center. His latest book, ''The Rage Within: Anger in Everyday Life,'' will be published this fall. BECOMING WILLIAM JAMES

title: Kohl Ends Visit to China
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany left Shanghai for Islamabad, Pakistan, today after a six-day visit to China.

title: Mistrial in a Legislator's Case
description: A Federal district judge declared a mistrial today in the trial of a Massachusetts lawmaker on charges of attempted extortion when jurors were unable to agree on a verdict after more than 20 hours of deliberation.

title: ;  International
description: SUNDAY, OCTOBER 14, 1984 The Soviet Union has begun to deploy long-range cruise missiles on strategic bombers and submarines, the Soviet Defense Ministry announced. It said the deployment was in response to the deployment of such weapons by the United States. (Page 1, Column 2.)

title: NEW CASSETTES: FROM 'TWIGS' TO A BASKERVILLE HOUND
description: The Soldier Who Didn't Wash; The Five Loaves Volume II from the Stories & Fables series Walt Disney Home Video 50 minutes. $49.95

title:
LONG ISLAND GUIDE;
 FALL FAIRS
description: At first glance, pickles and antiques would seem to have little in common - unless, of course, the pickles have passed their prime. Still, the two are featured in separate, but equal, fairs today: the antiques at the Port Washington Harbor Fall Festival, where from 11 A.M. to 6 P.M. the sidewalks along the waterfront on Lower Main Street will offer browsers their pick of various collectibles; and the pickles at the annual Greenlawn-Centerport Historical Association's Pickle Festival from 1 to 4 P.M. at the Harborfields Public Library, 31 Broadway in Greenlawn, where the emphasis will be on seasonal homemade edibles. Admission to this is 50 cents, with an additional 50 cents requested for children's rides on Northport High School's horse-car.

title: FOUR GRANDMASTER TIE FOR FIRST
description: The eighth annual Lloyds Bank International Tournament in London ended in a tie for first place among the grandmasters John Nunn, Tony Miles and Murray Chandler of Britain and Boris Spassky of France, and the international master Sergey Kudrin of Stamford, Conn. Each scored 7-2 and each won l$:610 in the 146-player, Swiss-system event that had entries from 22 countries.

title: Girl on Boys' Soccer Team
description: The Connecticut Interscholastic Athletic Conference ruled Thursday that a 15-year-old girl is eligible to play on a boys' high school soccer team, paving the way for girls in the state to play interscholastic baseball as well.

title: BISHOPS DESCRIBE VIEW OF POLITICS
description: Bishop James W. Malone, president of the National Conference of Catholic Bishops, yesterday issued a statement asserting that the bishops had no intention of creating a ''voting bloc'' and denying that the church was involved in single-issue politics.

title: A GUIDE TO TECHNOLOGICA ACRONYMIA
description: PRESIDENT REAGAN, speaking to a computer-training class last year, said that like many others, he had been looking at the help- wanted ads. ''I'll read you the entire ad,'' he said. '' 'System programmer - large-scale IBM, VTAM, TSO/SPF, ACF, CICS, OS/MVS .' The point is that we're in a new age. No longer do the ads simply offer jobs with good hours and no heavy lifting. You have to be a specialist to know what the ad is even about.''

title: Ao J.E. Diamond
description: Anne Elizabeth Diamond and Jonathan Edward Diamond, both seniors at Yale University, plan to be married in June, her parents, Dr. and Mrs. Leonard Diamond of New York and Milford, Conn., have announced.

title: LETTERS
description: TEXAS WOES

title: A Middling 98th To President Reagan, the 98th Congress was a disaster. It wouldn't do anything he wanted. In fact, with some notable exceptions, it did just what he wanted - that is, not much of anything.
description: This Congress can boast of just two major bipartisan achievements: the rescue of the Social Security System last year and the election-year vote to raise taxes somewhat in the session just ended. Even these brave efforts barely dented the central problem: the massive Federal deficits. The Government is headed still deeper into debt, passing the costs of today's economic recovery to future generations. And the leader in devising that strategy is the President, not Congress.

title:
ART;
SHOW AT THE ALDRICH EXPLORES 'BLANKNESS'
description: -born painter- philosopher, Arakawa, has weighed in at the Aldrich Museum of Contemporary Art in Ridgefield with enormous diagrammatic paintings and large drawings. They are sure bets to elicit the gamut of responses from viewers.

title: CAN A CRITIC REALLY CONTROL THE MARKETPLACE?
description: Donald Trump, the developer, clearly thinks architecture critics are the most powerful people in the building business. There can be no other explanation for the $500-million libel suit he has just filed against the architecture critic of The Chicago Tribune, Paul Gapp, and the Tribune Company, taking issue with a column Mr. Gapp wrote in mid-August questioning Mr. Trump's proposal to build the world's tallest building, a 150-story skyscraper off the southern tip of Manhattan.

title: Plunkett Out 4 Games
description: Jim Plunkett , the Los Angeles Raiders' No. 1 quarterback, has been placed on the injured reserve list with a torn abdominal muscle that will sideline him for at least the next four games.

title: RUTGERS TOPPLES ARMY, 14-7
description: Dwayne Hooper, who lost his starting job as Rutgers' tailback because of a thigh injury four weeks ago, went in for Albert Smith in the fourth quarter today and ran 12 yards for a touchdown that beat Army, 14-7, at Giants Stadium.

title: DATABANK
EDUCATION CHIEF: PAY MORE, REQUIRE MORE
description: Teacher groups in Connecticut have suggested a minimum starting salary of $24,000 a year and at least $60,000 for a teacher with six years of experience. But the State Education Commissioner, Gerald N. Tirozzi, says the public is not convinced that teachers deserve more pay. If they want to be paid more, he says, they are going to have to meet more stringent standards. In an interview with Jonathan Friendly of The New York Times, the Commissioner discussed this and other educational issues, including student testing and the role of principals. Following are excerpts from the interview:

title: LETTERS
description: CREELEY, 'LIVING TREASURE'

title:
CRAFTS;
COOKWARE FROM THE NILE TO OUTER SPACE
description: FOR anyone who has shopped for, prepared, cooked, served or simply always been on the receiving end of a meal, a viewing of the General Foods Collection, in the new corporate headquarters in Rye Brook, is certain to enlighten and delight. The well-displayed exhibit underscores that from the dawn of time - long before no- stick, space-age cookware and miracle pot scrubbers - man (and more likely, woman) had to deal with the daily, never-ending issue of nourishment.

title: A SUCCESS STORY
description: One million Mexican-Americans, registered to vote and heavily favoring the Democrats, are an excellent reason why Walter Mondale might yet make a close race of it in Texas.

title: HOME VIDEO: THAT'S A VERY BIG PICTURE!
description: ''HOME VIDEO,'' said Barry Collier softly and crisply, ''is the buzzword for the 1980's. It's like plastics was 20 years ago.'' Mr. Collier, who is president of the Prism Entertainment Corporation, a half-year-old concern based in Century City, Calif., is an independent manufacturer and distributor of home-video tapes. His modest company - it has only 11 people on staff - nevertheless has some formidable competition, including Warner Home Video, CBS/Fox Home Video, MCA Home Video, MGM/UA Home Video, Embassy Home Entertainment, Vestron Video, and RCA/Columbia Pictures Home Video. But that fact does not appear to faze the likes of Mr. Collier.

title: KENNEY MAY START FOR CHIEFS TODAY
description: In the first quarter of the Kansas City Chiefs' final exhibition game in August, someone's helmet or shoulder pad hit Bill Kenney's throwing hand so hard that the collision broke the bone at the base of the quarterback's thumb. In surgery, doctors placed two pins in his hand, and it was more than four weeks before he could grip a football securely enough to throw it.

title: VOLUNTARY SOCIAL SECURITY PLAN STUDIED
description: Top officials of the Social Security Administration have been studying proposals for changes in the retirement program, including some that would make participation voluntary while encouraging reliance on private insurance, pensions and savings to a larger degree.

title: Mary Keepnews Bride Of William O'Connor
description: Mary Patricia Keepnews, a daughter of Mrs. Lawrence W. Keepnews of Pelham Manor, N.Y., and the late Mr. Keepnews, was married yesterday to William Matthew O'Connor, a son of Dr. and Mrs. William F. O'Connor of Alexandria, Va. The Rev. Joseph G. Keegan performed the ceremony at Our Lady of Perpetual Help Roman Catholic Church in Pelham Manor.

title: Q AND A
description: No Renewal for Subtenant Question:

title: Athlete Banned for Biting
description: The Singapore Rugby Union said today that it had imposed a one-year ban on one of its top players for biting off part of an opponent's ear during a match in Malaysia. The player, David Quek, aged 29, said he had been provoked and had been trying to struggle free during a scrummage in the match in Kuala Lumpur on Sept. 29.

title: 'COMMITMENT' PUTS BUSTLE INTO FORT DIX
description: FORT DIX DRING President Jimmy Carter's Administration, talk of virtually closing Fort Dix as an economy measure buzzed through this Army post in central New Jersey. Now the talk has quieted - some say, for good.

title: LIQUEFIED GAS SHIP SET ABLAZE IN GULF
description: Unidentified warplanes hit a tanker loaded with nearly 20,000 tons of volatile liquefied gas Friday, and today the blazing and abandoned ship drifted in the Persian Gulf, threatening a huge explosion, shipping officials said.

title:
ABOUT MEN;
ALONE AND NOT MARRIED
description: Winston Groom is a novelist who lives in New York City and Point Clear, Ala. His most recent book is ''Only,'' a novel about his dog.

title: 2 WALKS SEEK AID TO FEED HUNGRY
description: HE planted the seeds in northern Westchester some time ago, nurtured them until they took root and then watched as they started to grow. Next Sunday, the Rev. Robert E. Osgood, minister of the United Methodist Church of Pleasantville, will move outdoors to tend to a project, known as CROP, designed to help feed the hungry of the world.

title: RECORD 6,800-PLUS RUN MANHATTAN MEET
description: A record field assembled at Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx yesterday for the event billed on meet T-shirts as the high school cross-country season's ''biggest and the best.''

title: CIBA-GEIGY IS FACING REVIEW OF ITS STATE PERMIT
description: LIKE no other chemical company in New Jersey's history, the Ciba-Geigy Corporation plant here has been persistently confronted by environmental demonstrators, state investigators and regulatory officials for three months now, finding itself embroiled in a hazardous-waste controversy unlikely to abate soon.

title: POPULATION LOSSES FORECAST IN NORTH
description: Low birth rates and an aging population are reinforcing the threat of a population decline in the Northeast, which is already losing people to the sunny South and West, a private population research group says .

title: Laura M. Childs, Executive, Weds Kenneth Saverin
description: The Roman Catholic Church of the Transfiguration in Norfolk, Conn., was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Laura Mabon Childs, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. Mabon Childs of Pittsburgh, and Kenneth A. Saverin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony J. Saverin of Manhasset, L.I. The Rev. Joseph A. Krasinski officiated.

title: J. B. Maxwell Jr. Weds Valerie Grace Ronson
description: Valerie Grace Ronson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Ronson of Trumbull, Conn., was married yesterday to J. B. Maxwell Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Maxwell of Clarksburg, W.Va. The Rev. Milton Ryder performed the ceremony at Presbyterian Church of the Covenant in Boston.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;
DO SCHOOLS LEAD OR FOLLOW?
description: WE have recently experienced a spiritual rebirth in our country, brought about by the summer Olympic Games and to a lesser extent the Democratic National Convention. This spiritual rebirth contrasts with many events of the past 20 years that brought tragedy and grief to many Americans.

title: Janet Markoff Marries
description: Janet Markoff, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Del Markoff of Westport, Conn., and Alan G. Momeyer, a son of Florence Momeyer of Kaneohe, Hawaii, and the late Glenn Momeyer, were married yesterday by Rabbi Burt Siegel at 24 Fifth Avenue in New York. The bride is an investment analyst for Integrated Resources Inc., a New York financial services company. The bridegroom, whose previous marriage ended in divorce, is director of manpower planning and development at the Loews Corporation in New York.

title: ORCHIDS IN BLOOM AT HARTFORD SHOW
description: WHEN people become involved with plants, there comes a time in their horticultural lives when they get hooked on a certain kind. From there, the hobby grows and grows. This is what happened to Roger Vars of Fairfield County.

title: Baseball Should Keep Its Playoff Distinction
description: In a Sept. 23 Opinion Page article, Alvin B. Lebar called for a change in how teams qualify for the major league baseball playoffs. His plan would give second- and third-place teams a chance if they had better records than the winner of another division.

title: A LEGAL JAM FOR L.I. ROAD IMPROVEMENT
description: During rush hour, the Long Island Expressway is the world's longest parking lot - so went the oldest joke in Nassau and Suffolk Counties. It has stopped being funny, particularly now that needed repair work is jammed up.

title: MARCOS SAYS I.M.F. BACKS FISCAL PLANS
description: President Ferdinand E. Marcos said today that after nearly a year of difficult negotiations, the Philippines' program of economic austerity had been accepted by the International Monetary Fund.

title: Federal Grant Denied Yonkers Office Project
description: A request for a $6.6 million Federal grant to turn an old garbage dump into an executive park has been denied, but officials in this financially strapped city say they are optimistic about getting the money next year.

title: BUSH'S DEBATE COMMENT ON LEBANON IS LIBEL, MONDALE SAYS
description: Walter F. Mondale, still steaming over what he termed a ''very, very libelous'' charge against him by Vice President Bush regarding Lebanon, demanded today that President Reagan call in Mr. Bush and force him to apologize.

title: 4-0 BOSTON COLLEGE STOPS TEMPLE, 24-10
description: Steve Strachan scored on a 2-yard run and Dave Pereira returned an interception 35 yards for a touchdown to give Boston College a 24-10 comeback victory over Temple tonight.

title: 18 IN MILLBROOK
description: At first glance, it looks as if a village of traditionally styled homes is going up near the stone entrance of the old Sandanona estate on Franklin Avenue in Millbrook, N.Y.

title: AT FLORIDA, THE ABUSES CLOUD AN ENTIRE PROGRAM
description: ABUSES in the football program at the University of Florida extended past the star and the average player to the extent that they involved even a walk-on reserve place-kicker, according to the kicker, a former Florida player.

title: HIGH TECHNOLOGY: NARROW SECTOR OF THE ECONOMY THAT AFFECTS MANY AMERICAN INDUSTRIES
description: AFTER YEARS of high hopes and dire warnings, the myths surrounding how many American jobs high technology will create or eliminate are beginning to fall away. The news is neither as good as hoped for nor as bad as first feared. Jobs that most people traditionally associate with high technology - in computers, software, defense, electronics and biotechnology - account for only a tiny fraction of the nation's total employment. And while growing fast, ''the fact is that the high-tech pie is not that big, and probably never will be,'' said John U. Burgan, who follows trends in technology for the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics. Between now and 1995, even the most optimistic projections show that only 1 new job in 25 will be ''technology- oriented'' - involving engineering, the sciences or the computer industry.

title: FOOD ; A CURRY DISH FOR FOUR SEASON
description: When the Four Seasons opened in Manhattan a quarter of a century ago, I noted in this newspaper that it was said to be the world's costliest restaurant, taking more than $4.5 million to create.

title: THE WORKING MOTHER AS ROLE MODEL
description: The cover photograph that accompanied Anita Shreve's article was wonderful. In conjunction with the title, it is humanizing, defining, illuminating, exactly right. STEVEN L. BATES

title: Kirkpatrick CriticizesReagan's Preparation
description: Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, chief United States delegate to the United Nations, said today that President Reagan was poorly prepared for his first debate with his Democratic rival, Walter F. Mondale, and as a result ''he wasn't a great deal better than Fritz Mondale.''

title: In Fighting Trim
description: It is perhaps one of the most unsettling aspects of our time that an adult perceives his relationship with others from the purely physical view of ''Can I take this guy or not?'' (''In Fighting Trim,'' by Bruce Mays, About Men, Sept. 2).

title: Oldest Academy Is West Point
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: JEWELRY THROUGHJ THE AGES
description: Jewelry was far from the most important category of art collected by Henry Walters, the turn-of-the-century Baltimore financier, railroad magnate and philanthropist. But he pursued ancient and modern necklaces, bracelets, rings and brooches as tirelessly as the Egyptian antiquities, Byzantine art, Chinese sculpture, medieval enamels, Renaissance paintings and S evres porcelain that he also collected.

title: THEATER: RUDY GARY'S 'MEDIA AND THE DOLL'
description: Blatantly patterned after ''Equus,'' Rudy Gray's ''Medea and the Doll'' is a crude psychiatrist-patient drama that substitutes a very unexotic illness - child abuse - for the metaphorically resonant ailment in ''Equus,'' the compulsion to blind horses.

title: On Bush's Itinerary, Game 5 of the Series
description: Vice President Bush, who said in his debate Thursday against Geraldine A. Ferraro that he would rather talk about the World Series, will get his wish Sunday. He plans to start a six-day campaign swing in Detroit for the fifth game of the World Series.

title:
WHAT'S NEW IN OFFICE POLITICS?;
COPING WITH AN INSECURE BOSS
description: WORKING for an insecure boss can be hell on earth. He is as quick to take the credit for a subordinate's work as he is to blame that underling for his own mistakes. Sometimes the situation can be handled by simply reassuring the boss about his strengths so that his insecurity lessens. But more often it only gets resolved in a confrontation.

title: STATE ENDS BUSY SEASON OF REGISTERING VOTERS
description: Ending what officials called the heaviest registration turnout since 1976, New Yorkers signed up at polling places throughout the city and state yesterday to register to vote on Nov. 6.

title: Pamela Henrich Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. George Cleaveland Palmer of Bayport and Fire Island, L.I., have announced the engagement of her daughter, Pamela Naylor Henrich, also the daughter of the late George Naylor Henrich, to Gregory Spencer Kurey, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Robert John Kurey of Lancaster, Pa. A June wedding is planned.

title: Lynn Byron Married To Don M. Wilson 3d
description: Lynn Suzanne Byron, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James R. Byron of Newport Beach, Calif., was married yesterday to Don M. Wilson 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Wilson Jr. of Ravenna, Ohio. The Rev. Dr. Herbert B. Anderson performed the ceremony at the Brick Presbyterian Church in New York.

title: BENEFITS FOR PEOPLE SOUGHT IN NEW BRUNSWICK REVITALIZATION
description: LEADERS in business and government here say that the city's economic revitalization would not mean much if it did not translate into a better quality of life for the people who live in the area.

title: DEFT 'IRMA LA DOUCE' IN DARIEN
description: DARIEN CRITICS are, or ought to be, unaffected by audience reaction. On opening night, response is often synthetic, with vociferous friends, relatives, well-wishers and, in the case of commercial theater, backers, out front. On the other extreme, apathy, walkouts or outright hostility don't have to mean a thing either. After all, befuddled patrons walked out in a huff and in droves during the American premiere of ''Waiting for Godot.''

title: A QUESTION FOR VOTERS
description: WASHINGTON The argument goes on in Washington about President Reagan's

title: RESURRECTING THOSE OLD MOVIE PALACES
description: THE biggest, best situated and most

title: A REGIONAL ROUNDUP ON EMPLOYMENT
description: New England

title:
CABLE TV NOTES;
NUCLEAR CONFLICT ON HBO'S 'COUNTDOWN'
description: Steve Schneider writes frequently about developments in cable.

title: PUBLIC TO COMMENT ON HOSPITAL PLAN
description: RESIDENTS of White Plains have been invited by Mayor Alfred Del Vecchio to speak out Monday night on the proposed development of 180 acres of land owned by New York Hospital into 1,900 apartments, 400 town houses, office buildings, hotel and new shopping center.

title: THE OUTCOME WAS DOUBLY DISASTROUS
description: ISRAEL'S LEBANON WAR

title: SUNDAY SPORTS Baseball
description: Tigers vs. San Diego Padres , at Detroit, fifth game of the four-of-seven World Series. Dan Petry of the Tigers, who lost the second game, gets a chance to make up for the defeat. (Television - Channel 4, 4:30 P.M. Radio - WCBS 880, 4:40 P.M.) Football

title:
CRITICS' CHOICES ;
PHOTOGRAPHY
description: Joel Sternfeld is one of a number of young American photographers whose romantic view of their native land is admirably expressed in a hymn written by a 19th-century Bishop of Calcutta: ''Where every prospect pleases and only man is vile.'' Whether Sternfeld photographs Alaska, Atlanta, California or the industrial Northeast, the beauty of nature is inevitably marred by a dump site, a trailer park, a factory or people.

title: FROM GARBO'S 'CAMILLE' TO A LIGHTHEARTED ADOLESCENT
description: Anne Tremblay is a freelance writer based in Paris.

title: HAVE CLOAK AND DAGGER, WILL TRAVEL
description: WASHINGTON THERE was a time when America's youth did not exactly believe that a job with the Central Intelligence Agency was a wonderful way to earn a living. In fact, C.I.A. recruiters used to be about as welcome as narcotics agents on many college campuses. But times and America's youth have changed to the extent that a survey of career opportunities in the spy professions, which also include the Defense Intelligence Agency and the National Security Agency, is not a wholly ludicrous task.

title: COUNTY EXECUTIVE ON INDIAN POINT
description: IN the military it's called ''after-action critique''; it sums up the action, draws lessons from the experience and often proposes changes in doctrines and tactics for the future. The subsiding furor surrounding the Indian Point nuclear power plants in the county and whether they should remain open has failed to produce any such critique. Rather, the continuing concern over Shoreham and the uncertain future of nuclear power has obscured the lessons learned and failed to generate either discussion or analysis of the Indian Point experience.

title: Mice Facing Extinction To Be Trapped by U.S.
description: Twenty-six Perdido Key beach mice, considered the last of their species, face extinction because of a condominium project and will be trapped and relocated, a United States Fish and Wildlife official said Friday.

title: 'SLOW SCIENCE' REVEALS STATE'S PREHISTORY
description: -fish site when he was 10 years old. Today, 25 years later, Mr. McDonald, a science teacher at the Westminster School in Simsbury, can tell you anything about the ancient fish of Connecticut. In fact, he has the largest collection of fish fossils collected in the state - 14,000 specimens in total. They include fishes, plants, tracks and invertebrae of the Connecticut Valley.

title: ROTATION OF CASEEWORKERS IS CRITICIZED
description: AN involuntary ''rotation policy'' at the county's Department of Social Services has rotated veteran child-protective workers into other jobs and replaced them with novices, putting abused and neglected children at risk, according to a number of judges, lawyers and social workers.

title: DANCE: ERICK HAWKINS COMPANY
description: Erick Hawkins's dancers move as if by some gentle but compelling inner impulse. And his dances suggest the harmoniousness of nature and natural processes, the latter a category that seems to include, for Mr. Hawkins, the act of dancing. On Thursday at the Joyce Theater, the Erick Hawkins Dance Company presented a program of works typical of his distinctive choreographic voice.

title: '34 Rose Bowl Stars See Columbia Lose
description: The Columbia band happily played ''Thanks for the Memories'' yesterday during the halftime ceremonies of a game the Lions happily will forget.

title: PLIGHT OF THE BAHAIS
description: To the Editor:

title: GROUP-HOME PROBLEMS CITED
description: Tougher state supervision is needed to prevent mismanagement that could endanger the health and safety of retarded people in group homes, a state commission said this week.

title: Rebecca Eaton Is Married
description: Rebecca C. Eaton, the daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Paul Conant Eaton of Pasadena, Calif., and Kennebunkport, Me., was married yesterday to Paul Robert Cooper, a son of Mrs. Henry G. Cooper of Springfield, Vt., and the late Rev. Cooper.

title: PEPSICO'S OUTDOOR MUSEUM IS GROWING BEAUTIFULLY
description: GRAND. Beautiful. Peaceful. These are only a few of the adjectives that describe a unusual arboretum-museum that has been spreading graciously around Pepsico's world headquarters in Purchase. This 144-acre space, or ''campus'' as the corporation likes to call it, is testament to the kind of unobstrusive settling-in a huge corporation is capable of when locating in a residential area. Although directly across from the college campus of the State University of New York, Pepsico's grounds are in a neighborhood that spills over into Rye's King Street and along Anderson Hill Road leading into White Plains.

title: TIGERS TOP PADRES, 4-2, AND LEAD SERIES BY 3-1
description: Jack Morris and Alan Trammell, products of Detroit's lush crop of 1976 amateur draft choices, today moved the Tigers one victory away from raising the World Series championship flag at Tiger Stadium.

title: NO, THE MARKET TAKES CARE OF ITSELF
description: AFTER the Depression, Congress concluded that the time had come to shore up public trust in the securities markets by establishing the Securities and Exchange Commission. Since then, the idea that trust is what makes the markets viable and that regulation enhances the public's willingness to invest have been central to the broad public support enjoyed by the S.E.C.

title: HEADLINERS ; Friends, Sort Of Despite her native country's history of apartheid and the current rioting there,
description: Nadine Gordimer , the South African writer, says that, miraculously, ''there are still good personal relationships between blacks and whites.''

title: WHY SEX EDUCATION IS LIKE SNAKE OIL
description: To the Editor:

title: WHAT BLACK WRITERS OWE TO MUSIC
description: Folks don't understand the blues,'' August Wilson writes in his drama ''Ma Rainey's Black Bottom,'' which opened Oct. 11 at the Cort. ''They hear it come out but they don't understand how it got there. They don't understand that's life's way of talking. You don't sing to feel better. You sing because that's a way of understanding life.''

title: KICKS BY ALABAMA STUN PENN STATE, 6-0
description: Alabama's football fortunes, which had been uncharacteristically bad this year, improved dramatically today. Van Tiffin's fourth-quarter field goals of 53 and 23 yards gave the Crimson Tide a 6-0 upset victory over Penn State.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: THE toxic cloud that developed from a leak in a storage tank at the American Cyanamid Company in Linden last weekend contained Malathion, a common pesticide that the company calls ''safe'' but that others say can be acutely toxic in some instances.

title: Recent Sales
description: Convent Station $275,000 *2*12 Sylvan Way, 5-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, *2*3-year-old contemporary; balcony off master bedroom, *2*beamed family room, 0.75 acre; taxes $4,123. Marlboro $165,000 *2*2 Duncan Drive, 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, *2*16-year-old colonial; central vacuum, attic *2*fan, lawn sprinkler; taxes $2,800. title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;
WHAT CAN BE EXPECTED FROM THE PAROLE SYSTEM?
description: WHEN properly structured, parole represents a vital component of the criminal-justice system.

title: IF YOUR'E THINKING OF LIVING IN CHELSEA
description: FOR Chelsea, the 1970's and early 1980's were something of a second childhood: a frenetic period of growth in which many of the area's brownstones were converted, rehabilitated or restored. New residents, many of them young professionals priced out of more costly areas of the city, poured into this West Side neighborhood, changing its character.

title: IDEAS & TRENDS ; HoneybeesIn Danger
description: The honeybee, whose usefulness in honey production and crop pollination has been turned into a billion- dollar business, has fallen prey to a microscopic mite.

title: MUSIC: DEBUTS IN REVIEW
description: Young-Chang Cho is a brilliant young cellist, and his New York debut recital at the Abraham Goodman House on Oct. 6 made for one of the most exciting musical evenings of the year.

title: WANG'S SEARCH FOR A NEW MARKET
description: LOWELL, Mass.

title: TWO BRITISH PLAYS STAGED BY ARENA
description: THE Arena Players Repertory Company operates two theaters, the Main Stage, where the company presents works it hope will have wide appeal, and the smaller Second Stage, where it does children's theater on weekend afternoons, and where it also stages plays it perceives as being more controversial than those performed in the Main Stage. Arena is currently offering two British plays, ''See How They Run'' by Phillip King at the Main Stage and ''The Killing of Sister George'' by Frank Marcus at the Second Stage.

title: OOH! MY SOUL
description: Stephen Holden is a music critic for The New York Times. THE LIFE AND TIMES OF LITTLE RICHARD

title: WHAT'S NEW IN OFFICE POLITICS?
description: ''We're all equal in this family,'' said the company president as he welcomed Willoughby Sharp, then a management trainee, to the employee fold. The two men, along with a beaming personnel manager, rode the elevator down from the president's penthouse. The president was going to the lobby, Mr. Sharp to the second floor.

title: Geter Case Suspect Is Jailed
description: Curtis Eugene Mason, a suspect in a Dallas robbery for which Lenell Geter was wrongly convicted, has been sentenced to 35 years in prison after pleading guilty to seven armed robberies. Mr. Geter, a black engineer, received a life sentence in the robbery of a fast-food restaurant now attributed to Mr. Mason. Mr. Geter was released after 16 months, and charges were dismissed.

title: SALVADOR REBEL AND INTERMEDIARY MEET TO PREPARE MONDAY'S PARLEY
description: A Salvadoran rebel leader met here today with an intermediary to discuss details for a meeting in El Salvador next week between the rebels and President Jose Napoleon Duarte.

title: AT LUNCH, THE BUSINESS IS BUSINESS
description: THEY came to mingle, to socialize and to eat lunch. But above all they came to do business. ''Our company packages food items for corporations to give as gifts - we have gift packages in all price ranges and will arrange shipping also,'' said Joanne Klein, who, with her partner Joan Dichter, runs Gifted Desserts.

title: Hanging of Murder Suspect Is Ruled Suicide, U.S. Says
description: The hanging of a murder suspect in his jail cell in Fort Wayne, Ind., was a suicide and did not involve foul play, the Justice Department has concluded.

title: EUROPE SEEMS LESS WORRIED ABOUT NATO'S NEW MISSILES
description: Just a year ago, the youthful leaders of a self-confident street coalition were threatening to make West Germany ''ungovernable'' through demonstrations if NATO went forward with the deployment of American Pershing 2 and cruise missiles. In many capitals, the threats were taken seriously. Editorial pages were filled with anxious commentaries about a profound crisis in the Western alliance. The mood in Bonn, the epicenter of the perceived crisis, trembled at the boundaries of hysteria.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: -DOZEN years ago, I laughed when they told me to sit down and play the computer. This was at the office, where they had just installed a system that overnight sent our trusty old manual typewriters, those wonderful heavy machines with a clunk that attested to the weightiness of what you were writing, to the limbo where they are floating along with cuneiform styluses and quill pens.

description: Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward viewed it as a violation of ''clear-cut rules.'' In the eyes of Transit Police Chief James B. Meehan, however, the failure of a slain officer's partner to report her missing immediately was ''poor judgment.''

description: I AM NOT A 'GANG'

title: LILCO'S VIEW OF POWER NEEDS IS QUESTIONED
description: WHILE Long Island householders put up the storm windows and check their heating systems, the Long Island Lighting Company has its eye on another household item, now unplugged for the season: the air-conditioner.

NEW JERSEY OPINION;
AN APPEALFOR A 'YES' ON NOV. 6
description: NEW JERSEY is on the threshold of a new era in the creation of jobs and in economic development - a high-technology era. This new era will dawn on Nov. 6, when the voters approve the $90 million Jobs, Science and Technology Bond Act of 1984.

description: College deans and other campus leaders say the nationwide drive to adopt a uniform legal drinking age of 21 years is forcing them to crack down on some beer-soaked campus traditions.

title: THE WORKING MOTHER AS ROLE MODEL
description: I read with interest Anita Shreve's important and informative article. I feel however, that the terms ''working'' and ''nonworking'' are misleading. To refer to mothers who are not employed outside the home as nonworking is not only inaccurate, but contributes to the devaluation of work outside of the home that involves child care and housework. BARBARA COHN SCHLACHET

title: ADDING A MEXICAN TOUCH TO MEALS OF OTHER BACKGROUNDS
description: MEXICAN food is hot these days, even when it is not peppery. There are Mexican restaurants, both fast food and more upscale, in many communities and new ones opening all the time.

title: MUSIC
description: ''Trio,'' a ''jazz chamber opera'' that opens Wednesday evening at Carnegie Recital Hall and is repeated there Thursday, Friday and Saturday, is a haunting a heartening gem about a grandmother, mother and pregnant daughter. The music and lyrics are by Noa Ain; although no particular song struck me as a hit when I saw the July premiere in Philadelphia, the whole is touchingly poetic.

title: PARTY REALIGNMENT (CONT'D.)
description: Like a periodic infestation of locusts or the swallows' return to Capistrano, predictions of partisan realignment have made their cyclical reappearance.

description: IN Charlotte, N.C., the University Research Park is

title: PERFECT LANDING BY SHUTTLE MARKS RETURN TO FLORIDA
description: The space shuttle Challenger, ending a productive eight-day voyage marked by technical breakdowns and shrewd problem-solving, glided to a perfect landing here today. It was the second time in 13 missions that a shuttle landed at its launching site.

title: AROUND THE WORLD ; Nkomo Accuses Mugabe Of 'Terror and Failure'
description: Joshua Nkomo, the Zimbabwean opposition leader, accused Prime Minister Robert Mugabe's Government today of a reign of terror and of leading the country to disaster.

title: FOES OF SINGAPORE PREMIER FACE TOUGH ODDS
description: J. B. Jeyaretnam is not just the leader of the opposition in the Singapore legislature, politicians here say. He is the opposition.

title: A MONUMENT OF BYZANTIUM
description: The green crag of Mistra rears up like an altar into the vast natural cathedral of the Taygetus Massif. At its crest, like a grim offering, the black walls of the Frankish citadel hang in brutal silhouette against the snow-crusted backdrop beyond. Below, amid a cascade of ruined vaults, arches, turreted walls, chapels, homes and palaces, lie perhaps the most spectacular surviving monuments to the last flourish of medieval Byzantium.

title: RETRAINING'S COME A LONG WAY, BABY
description: IN 1982 Joanne B. Booth, a 45-year-old divorcee,

title: ORGANIZED CRIME A GROWTH INDUSTRY IN INDIA
description: A high- ranking member of what Bombayites call their Mafia was gunned down the other day by members of a rival gang as he stepped from an elevator just before dawn, on the way to the airport.

title: POEMS AND STORIES POUR IN TO MAGAZINE IN STRATFORD
description: WHEN Napoleon St. Cyr of Stratford makes his daily trip to pick up the mail, he invariably finds 15 to 20 pieces of poetry awaiting him in his post-office box.

title: IN SHORT
description: Julie Cobb's mother commits suicide when Julie is 13. Soon afterward, her brother runs away from home. When she is 22, her father, nicknamed Hob, dies suddenly, leaving among his papers a letter urging her to find her brother. She does not act on her father's request, nor does she come to terms with the memories of her childhood, until she is 30; then her life is disrupted by another disaster. This last twist of fate occurs when she is living in Burlington, Vt. - it is appropriate that this somber novel be set in that cold, quiet northern town - and is the novel's central event. It compels Julie to try to understand and rise above the pain of loss that threatens to paralyze both her and her lover, Michael Gardener. Slowly, as Julie looks back on the events of her childhood, then forward to her relationship with Michael, a lifetime's tangle of emotions is unraveled. But it not until the novel's nightmarish conclusion that Julie learns how to overcome her grief and thereby save herself. T. Alan Broughton, the author of three previous novels and five books of poetry, has invested his fourth novel with a poet's sensibility. ''Hob's Daughter'' is skillfully and affectingly written; it is ''about safety, about the known fragments bobbing on the surface of a dark sea, but above all about that grace we hope pervades in all: love.''-

title: RESTORING QUALITY IN QUALITY CONTROL
description: THREE major weapons projects worth billions of dollars were halted this summer because of what was termed a massive breakdown in quality control. A new space shuttle launch pad at Vandenberg Air Force Base in California was declared unsafe because of poor welds and loose wiring, for which quality-control engineers were held responsible. The Diablo Canyon nuclear-power plant, also in California, remained shut because of quality-control questions.

title: LETTERS
description: 'SLEEPING UNDER THE MOON'

title: Lynn E. Gordon Wed To Christopher Sellon
description: Lynn Ellen Gordon, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ward Blake Gordon of Weston, Conn., was married yesterday to Christopher John Sellon, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter John Sellon of Rye, N.Y. The Rev. Theodore G. Hoskins performed the ceremony at the Saugatuck Congregational Church in Westport, Conn.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
WEST COAST SALE
description: Three of the greatest rarities of United States numismatics - the 1804 silver dollar, 1894-S dime and 1913 Liberty Head nickel - will come up for sale in January 1985 at a landmark auction in Los Angeles. The auction will be staged by Superior Stamp and Coin Company Inc. of Beverly Hills, Calif., and will feature the collection of Dr. Jerry H. Buss, a wealthy Los Angeles real estate man.

title: A SCHOLAR FROM CHINA LOOKS AT AMERICAN THEATER
description: uf912

title: HOUSING BIAS FOUND IN JERSEY
description: Housing discrimination on the basis of race has not diminished much in the past 10 years, although landlords and other property owners are now more polite when turning down prospective minority tenants and home buyers, New Jersey civil-rights officials say.

title: P.S.C. CHIEF CITES MIXED REPORTS ON A-PLANT
description: State monitoring has produced mixed reports on the progress of construction at the Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation's Nine Mile Point 2 nuclear plant, a state regulatory official said this week.

title: MY NOMEN IS KLATURA
description: Certain foreign words, taken whole into the outer circle of the English language, rotate quietly within the band assigned them by whatever elite did the importation, bothering nobody else. Then, suddenly, a satellite word slips through the frequency barrier and comes closer to Mother Tongue; it is not yet absorbed and is rarely used by most native speakers, but it is tried out by jargonauts, neologists and avant-gardians often enough to rate a close look by swinging linguists and sexy lexies.

title: SEXTET OFFERS ALL-AMERICAN SOUNDS AMID WAVE HILL FOLIAGE
description: ESPECIALLY at this time of year when the foliage is mounting its yearly exhibition, a drive to Wave Hill in Riverdale, with its own sweeping views of the Hudson and the Palisades beyond, makes a delightful excursion. If you go this afternoon at 3 o'clock, however, you will have the extra pleasure of hearing Western Wind, the splendid vocal sextet, in an all-American program ranging from Shaker tunes and spirituals to the music of Duke Ellington.

title: No Headline
description: Oct. 14, 1984 Fiction 1 THE AUERBACH WILL, by Stephen Birmingham. (Berkley, $3.95.) Three generations of a German Jewish family in New York. 2 BLOOD AND ORCHIDS, by Norman Katkov. (NAL/Signet, $3.95.) Four Hawaiian youths are accused of raping a Navy officer's wife.

title: IS 'DRUMMER GIRL' POLITICAL?
description: When director George Roy Hill and scriptwriter Loring Mandel first met with the British novelist John Le Carre, to discuss the filming of his best-selling spy novel, ''The Little Drummer Girl,'' they holed up together for three days in the novelist's chalet in Switzerland. When they finally emerged, Mr. Hill said, in mock despair, ''Great. Now we've got an eight-hour film.''

title: WOMEN ARE GETTING A MORE SYMPATHETIC READING
description: What kind of woman is television promoting these days? A clowning Lucy? A chirpily independent Mary Richards? In fact, the TV terrain is so vast that just about any kind of woman can be found somewhere on the sprawling schedule. But there is one curious development. Far more than in the movies or in the theater, women on television do get to reflect some of the more profound cultural and social changes triggered by the various feminist movements of the past decade. Women may be denigrated or very nearly invisible in the work of certain major playwrights, as my colleague Frank Rich recently noted, but they are very much on positive display in TV's situation comedies, action-adventures and in- house movies.

title: Dr. Jamie Stern to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Stern of Massapequa Park, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Dr. Jamie Rhonda Stern, to Jeffrey Marc Weiner, a son of Sondra Weiner of Massapequa, L.I., and the late William Weiner. The wedding is planned for May. Dr. Stern is an otolaryngology resident at the Long Island Jewish Medical Center. Mr. Weiner is a certified public accountant with the Syosset, L.I., accounting firm of Marcum & Kliegman.

title: NOTEBOOK: IN MILAN, FASHION IS 'SERIOUS'
description: Just as the spring collections were about to begin, ''Metropolis,'' the Fritz Lang film about the effect of industry on society, opened in Milan. That was somehow fitting because, even if roller skaters can now be seen dashing among the Fiats on the street here, they seem to be one of the few signs of lightheartedness in a city that more than ever prides itself on its work ethic.

title: Lucy R. Thackara I t B Mo K. P. Kennedy
description: Mr. and Mrs. James J. Thackara of Greenwich, Conn., and Bernard, Me., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lucy Riegel Thackara, to Kevin Patrick Kennedy, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Kennedy of Chappaqua, N.Y. An April wedding is planned.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPNION;
PUBLIC POLICY AND PORNOGRAPHY: A DOUBLE STANDARD
description: MOST people believe as their forefathers did that moral values are permanent and absolute. Conversely, some believe that moral values are situational and circumstantial, meaning that objective moral measurements cannot be defined. The public policy implication of these disparate views are significant. Each view has a different agenda for political and social change in America.

title: ROUGHING IT IN THE OUTBACK
description: CHRIS WEST is a photojournalist who has recently been dividing his time between Australia and England.

title: WHAT TO DO WHEN THE DRAPERY RODS JAM
description: WINDOW draperies that are opened and closed frequently are usually hung on traverse rods so that they can be easily adjusted by pulling down on the looped control cord that hangs down at one end of the rod. Occasionally, however, traverse rods will get out of adjustment so that the draperies no longer open evenly on both sides, or they will not meet in the center when fully closed. Or the slides may tend to jam when in the partly open or partly closed position so that opening and closing the draperies becomes difficult or awkward.

title: A NEW WAY TO TREAT DEPRESSION
description: There are nights when I awaken and am unable to return to sleep. Lying next to my husband, I realize he is someone with whom I have lost touch. It's not that we fight as much as that we don't seem to have anything in common any more. He's living his life, I'm living mine, and neither of us seems to care enough about the other to want to change.

description: LONG ISLAND'S expanding economy, led by the manufacturing sector, has brought it through the recent recession virtually untouched and placed it at the hart of the current recovery.

title: No Managerial Offers in Sight for Martin
description: IS this the end of Billy Martin as a manager? Ten major league clubs have either dismissed managers or had them resign or retire since the start of the season, and an 11th club, the Yankees, always seems on the verge of making a managerial change. Through all these changes, Martin has been roaming free, available to be pursued as the possible means of transforming a club's nightmares into pleasant dreams.

title: REVOLVING VIEW

Rich Company, developers of the new 18-story addition to the Marriott Hotel in Stamford, Conn., found a way: Its rooftop restaurant will revolve, affording diners views not only of the Sound but of the whole of downtown Stamford.

Aquino was split last week on how far up the military hierarchy it should go in charging a conspiracy. Some feared increasing the country's already considerable political tension by accusing people at the top.

description: EARLIER this month, County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke stood in a ring between the Iron Sheik and Sergeant Savage - two hulking wrestlers - and addressed a crowd about the need to support a proposition on this November's ballot authorizing $15.2 million in renovations to the County Center, where the match was being held.

description: St. Barnabas Episcopal Church in Greenwich, Conn., was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Elizabeth Scott Jeffery, a daughter of Mrs. Carleton Jeffery of Greenwich and the late Mr. Jeffery, to Peter Baldwin Hubbell, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert B. Hubbell of Woodbridge, Conn. The Rev. Richard Van Wely performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. Dr. Harold Bassage.

title: THE WORKING MOTHER AS ROLE MODEL
description: The impact of working women as role models for our sons is probably more important than the imagery we provide for our daughters.

title: COLORFUL HIGH POINT
description: FIRE-ENGINE red, indigo blue, even stark white - will be enlivening the Southern Furniture Market in High Point, N.C., this fall. The market, which opens Thursday and runs through Oct. 26, will be the largest display for furniture buyers in High Point's history. This season's 1,300 exhibitors will have about 200,000 square feet of new showroom space, adding up to a total of 115 acres.

title: ONCE-AILING NEW YORK IS AGLOW AGAIN
description: ADECADE ago, New York City began to brace itself for a full-fledged economic crash as the final act of a five-year financial tailspin. The projected municipal budget deficit had risen to $1.5 billion and the one-year job loss in the five boroughs approached 100,000. Calls rose for huge layoffs of city employees, which became reality in less than a year.

title: Andrew Rosen Is Wed To Adrian R. Mottola
description: Adrian R. Mottola, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Mottola of Longport, N.J., was married yesterday to Andrew N. Rosen, a son of Shirley Rosen of Palm Springs, Calif., and the late Carl Rosen. Rabbi Ronald Sobel performed the ceremony at the Hotel Pierre.

title: IDEAS & TRENDS ; Challenger'sMissionAccomplished
description: Although the seven astronauts of the space shuttle Challenger completed many tasks on their ambitious mission, their most visible success came at the end of the 13.5 million- mile journey: yesterday's precision landing in Florida, only three miles from the site of the shuttle's perfect lift-off eight days earlier.

title: MORE SLICES IN THE FOOD-SERVICE PIE
description: PAM BANKS spends upward of 50 hours a week preparing dishes ranging from Madras egg curry to Middle Eastern cold salads, making menu decisions, ordering food from wholesalers, waiting tables, balancing the books, hiring support workers and meeting with the seven others who collectively manage the seven-month-old Takoma Cafe in Takoma Park, Md. For Miss Banks and the other first- time restaurateurs, operating the international health- food restaurant in a restored Victorian house in a Washington suburb is an adventure and - most of the time- a labor of love.

title: Inside the Lines
description: In the 1950's when he was an undergraduate at Amherst College in Massachusets, William H. Pritchard had a prophetic exchange with Robert Frost. The future biographer asked the poet, who was on the faculty, "what he meant by a line in one of his poems.

title: Nuptials Planned By Dr. Strassberg
description: Dr. Barbara Esther Strassberg, a pediatrician, and Judge Harold Enten, supervising judge of the Bronx Criminal Court and an acting justice of the New York State Supreme Court, have announced their engagement. The wedding is to take place Nov. 18.

title: SOUTH CAROLINA (5-0) ROUTS PITT BY 45-21
description: Mike Hold and Allen Mitchell each passed for two touchdowns, and Thomas Dendy ran 43 yards for a score today as unbeaten South Carolina won its fifth game by routing Pitt, 45-21. South Carolina had a total offense of 443 yards and limited Pitt (1-5) to 285 yards.

description: John Lee made a 47-yard field goal as time ran out to give U.C.L.A. a 27-24 victory over Washington State in a Pacific-10 Conference game. It was his second field goal of the game and 16th in 16 attempts this season.

title: UNION ROUTS R.P.I.
description: The senior quarterback Dan Stewart threw a touchdown pass in his 27th consecutive game as Union College defeated Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, 38-0, today.

title: LETTERS
description: SPENDING POLICY

title: NEW & NOTEWORTHY
description: THE MOMENT OF CREATION: BIG BANG PHYSICS FROM BEFORE THE FIRST MILLISECOND TO THE PRESENT UNIVERSE ) Scientists say they know what happened in the universe's first moment: following creation, the universe briefly and rapidly expanded, an action taking one-billionth of a trillionth of a trillionth of a second. This event is the focus of James S. Trefil's ''The Moment of Creation.'' Our reviewer, Alan P. Lightman, wrote last year that ''this is the first comprehensive and readable account for the layman'' of that instant. ''Mr. Trefil surpasses almost all scientists writing about science for the public.'' THE CHOSEN PLACE, THE TIMELESS PEOPLE, by Paule Marshall. (Vintage, $6.95.) Paule Marshall's 1969 novel is set on a Caribbean island. American researchers - a Jewish anthropologist, his Main Line Philadelphia wife and a young male demographer - settle there and interact with the novel's central figure, the islander Merle Kinbona - ''part saint, part revolutionary, part obeah woman.'' Our reviewer, Robert Bone, called ''The Chosen Place, the Timeless People'' ''impressive, important - a parable of Western civilization and its relations with the undeveloped world.''

title: NEW MAN IN CLEVELAND - INTELLECTUAL AND PROUD OF IT
description: When Christoph von Dohnanyi's appointment as music director-elect of the Cleveland Orchestra was announced in March 1982, it took a lot of people by surprise - not least, Mr. Dohnanyi. There were some who grumbled that the prestigious post should have gone to an American. Even more wondered why one of the world's finest ensembles should go to a man who had not really established a far-flung international reputation.
