title:
DINING OUT;
A COZY SPOT IN LARCHMONT
description: ALICE WILKINSON, the talented and creative chef who opened The Cabbage Patch Restaurant in Larchmont four years ago, had an act hard to follow. Since her departure to return to England, the kitchen has been somewhat out of sorts. With her have gone some the vitality and sure instincts that made the cooking here special.

title: photo of Sarah Vaughan; MUSIC; KEY OFFERINGS OF A HECTIC SEASON
description: CONNECTICUT'S music schedule for the next couple of weeks is so crowded that the only way to deal with it seems to be to single out one of the many offerings for each day. Today : The Newtown Friends of Music opens its seventh annual series of chamber concerts at the Edmond Town Hall Theater at 4 P.M. with a recital by the dynamic young Mendelssohn String Quartet. Later programs in the subscription series are equally promising, by the way, including appearances by the pianist Richard Goode, the Arioso Chamber Players, the Rogeri Trio and the New York Woodwind Quintet. Call 426-8131 for more details.

title: THE REGION ; Jersey AdvancesSeat-belt Law
description: New Jersey has apparently decided that it, too, will knuckle down on drivers who don't buckle up. The State Assembly passed a measure last week requiring motorists and front-seat passengers to use seat belts.

title: REAGAN RESTRICTIONS ON FOREIGN AID FOR ABORTION PROGRAMS LEAD TO A FIGHT
description: More than two months ago, as representatives from 149 countries gathered in Mexico City for the United Nations International Conference on Population, the Reagan Administration formally announced its intention to impose tighter restrictions on United States aid to population control programs abroad. While the United States would continue its support for voluntary family planning, it would no longer contribute to private organizations that ''perform or actively promote abortion.''

title: FROM CARS TO TOYS
description: For years, the huge showroom of the two-story Ford-Mercury automobile dealership on Kennedy Boulevard near Route 3 in North Bergen, N. J., was a famiiliar sight for motorists heading toward the Lincoln Tunnel. But declining sales forced the owners out of business two years ago, and after suffering neglect and vandalism, the building was demolished late last summer.

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;
WHAT BECAME OF PARK PLACE? ANYONE FOR A HAND OF POKER?
description: WHERE would you be if you landed at Dum Dum Airport?

title: Saban to Quit Again
description: Lou Saban , whose career is noted more for his resignations than his coaching, has struck again with the announcement that this would be his final season as the coach of Central Florida in Orlando. The 63-year-old Saban said Friday he would leave the school when his contract expires on Aug. 31, and that he hand-delivered his resignation to Trevor Colbourn , the school president, that afternoon.

title: DEBATES SHIFT FOCUS AND PERHAPS THE ODDS
description: WASHINGTON FOR the first time since the week after the Democratic convention, the Reagan campaign appeared to be on the defensive and the President's strategists were uncertain and squabbling among themselves about how to respond.

title: 'PARIS, TEXAS' FROM WIM WENDERS
description: A most peculiar-looking figure wanders slowly but with purpose across the bleached expanse of a southwestern American wasteland. He wears a dusty, double-breasted suit, shoes so ragged they no longer qualify as footwear, a dirty shirt with a filthy but neatly knotted necktie, plus a maroon baseball cap. He stops, drinks the last of the water from a plastic container and continues his journey. From nowhere to nowhere.

title: COMPANIES POUR MILLIONS INTO PROGRAMS AIMED AT KEEPING WORKERS WELL
description: On a recent lunch hour in the red- carpeted fitness center at Johnson & Johnson's aluminum-and-glass headquarters in New Brunswick, N.J., 20 women in brightly patterned leotards stretched and bent to a background of soft rock music.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: THE program in occupational education for the physically disabled of Southern Westchester Boces, has been cited for excellence by the United States Department of Education and on Thursday, Madeleine Will , assistant secretary of education for special education and rehabilitative services, will present the department's Secretary's Award to members of the Boces staff at the Valhalla campus.

title: Last-Minute Muddle
description: Late last week, both houses agreed on a $470 billion spending measure covering much of Washington's overhead in the fiscal year that began Oct. 1. But seemingly irresistible partisan considerations resulted in a session-ending muddle.

title: PLAN TO BUY TIMES SQ. HOTEL PROMPTS DEBATE
description: Covenant House, an organization that cares for homeless and runaway youths, plans to buy a 750-room hotel in the Times Square area and convert part of it into administrative offices for its growing operations.

title: 5 SCORES BY BYARS LEAD OHIO STATE
description: Keith Byars's fifth touchdown of the game, a 3-yard sweep with 36 seconds to play, gave Ohio State a 45-38 victory over Illinois today after it had trailed by 24-0 in the Big Ten Conference game.

title: BROADCAST TV
description: Last Thursday, Horace Rumpole, the unorthodox British barrister, was seen in a two-hour special giving up retirement in sunny Florida (''I am not an orange,'' he grandly declared) and returning, via various outrageous ploys, to law practice at London's Old Bailey. This Thursday, on channels 13 and 49 at 9 P.M., he settles in for a run of six weeks in new hour-long episodes of ''Rumpole of the Bailey.'' Needless to say, Rumpole is still being portrayed by Leo McKern. One never meddles with inspired casting.

title: Stations' Fees Upheld For Newspaper Boxes
description: An appeals court has ruled in Manhattan that the Metropolitan Transportation Authority may charge fees for permitting newspaper vending machines to operate in railroad stations.

title: LAKE COMO'S PEERLESS VILLAGE
description: PAUL LEWIS is a correspondent in the Paris bureau of The New York Times.

title: STAGE: 'LOVE'S LABOR'S LOST'
description: The very model of a modern company devoted to new plays and playwrights, the Circle Repertory Company occasionally diversifies by trying a classic. But the troupe remains underprepared for Shakespeare, as shown in Toby Robertson's misguided production of ''Love's Labor's Lost.' A former director of the Old Vic, Mr. Robertson has a penchant for reinterpretation. In this case he has tried to update ''Love's Labor's Lost,'' but has succeeded only in unmooring it - and in nearly obliterating the poetry.

title: Elise M. Ambrose Marries in Capital
description: Elise Mary Ambrose, a daughter of Myles J. Ambrose of Washington and the late Elaine Ambrose, was married yesterday to Sgt. Robert Daniel Free of the Army military police branch, a son of Walter B. Free of Ardsley, Pa., and the late Mary Janis Free. Maj. James Kleffman of the Army Chaplain Corps performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at the Memorial Chapel of the Walter Reed Army Medical Center in Washington, where the bridegroom is a criminal investigator.

title: Philologist Wed To Miss Ramirez
description: Alejandra Amada Ramirez, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alonzo Ramirez of New York, was married yesterday to Andrew Willard Smethurst, a son of Mr. and Mrs. E. William Smethurst Jr. of Ridgewood, N.J. The Rev. Daniel Kreller performed the ceremony at St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church in Hohokus, N.J.

title: The Republicans
description: Richard Reeves's assertions characterize the G.O.P. as a party divided, rampant with bosses bent on secrecy and control. Mr. Reeves saw a far different convention than most of the people in Dallas. In his article, he paints a picture of a very different party than the Republican Party to which I belong.

title: Hardball by Hernandez
description: DETROIT UNTIL now, the screwball has been Willie Hernandez's out pitch. But suddenly, in the middle of the World Series, the Tigers' renowned relief pitcher is experimenting with a new pitch. Call it a hardball.

title: Mary Ellen Hennessy Wed to W. F. Jones Jr.
description: Mary Ellen Hennessy, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph R. Hennessy of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married yesterday to William Frank Jones Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Jones of Columbus, Miss. Msgr. Daniel S. Hamilton performed the ceremony at the Church of Our Lady of Fatima in Scarsdale.

title: Police Say Prostitution Raid Broke $1 Million-a-Year Ring
description: A raid on an Upper West Side town house has shut down a $1 million-a-year prostitution ring that catered to an affluent clientele around the world, according to the police, who said yesterday that they were waiting for the head of the ring to turn herself in.

title: MERKIN HALL SERIES
description: The third season of Concerts Plus, a program of music and commentary, begins Oct. 25 with performace of works by Liszt and Mozart at Merkin Concert Hall, 129 West 67th Street.

title: SPLIT-LOT LEXINGTON PROJECT MELDS CONFLICTING THEMES
description: TWO years ago, a large site on the northwest corner of 57th Street and Lexington

title: Pope Says He Is Ready To Visit Cuba if Asked
description: Pope John Paul II returned to Rome today after a three-day tour of Spain and the Caribbean to commemorate Columbus's voyage.

title: Freedom of Lawn
description: ''There's a point,'' Stephen Kenney said, ''where the individual has to tell the state you don't have a right to do this.''

title: Connecticut Revenue From Sales Tax Rises
description: Receipts from the state sales tax increased 21 percent in the latest reporting period, according to a state budget official.

title: ON BOXING'S BALKANIZATION AND ITS LASTING EFFECT TODAY
description: BACK in the postwar 1940's, the late Freddie Steele, who is not remembered primarily as an actor, had a major role in a film, ''The Story of G. I. Joe.'' He was pictured as a sensitive, optimistic fellow and that is the way he is remembered here.

title: HEADLINERS ; An Eye for Horses Horseracing is also the sport of at least one queen,
description: Elizabeth II of Britain. Last week, the Queen took a private jaunt down to Kentucky thoroughbred country to look over some American stallions she is considering as potential mates for as many as five of the 21 broodmares she has back home.

title: MANY STATES SEEKING TO CUT MEDICAID COSTS
description: Twenty-five states now require beneficiaries of Medicaid to pay a small share of some medical and dental bills, according to a new study.

title: Erhard Schmidt Wed To Annette S. Martell
description: Annette Syminetta Martell, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Fred C. Martell of Wanamassa, N.J. , was married yesterday to Erhard Schmidt, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Oskar Schmidt of Rochester, N.Y. The Rev. Dudley Rapp, an Episcopalian minister, performed the ceremony at the New York Junior League, 130 East 80th Street.

title: STORING PEOPLE
description: The old Morgan Manhattan warehouse on East 87th Street, where fine wine, art, and furniture once was held for safekeeping, is being transformed into a 43-unit condominium.

title: BUSINESS BOOMS AT SHOOTING RANGE
description: AT the Nassau County Rifle and Pistol Range in Uniondale, where Long Islanders shoot for sport and self-defense, the waiting list for enrollment and training courses stretches into next year. The range, which has doubled its revenues in the last five years, is enjoying a growing popularity that is rivaled by few other recreational facilities on the Island.

title: Boza-Edwards Scores Knockout in 3d Round
description: Cornelius Boza-Edwards, the former world junior lightweight champion from Uganda, stopped Charlie (Choo Choo) Brown of Philadelphia tonight after 1 minute 47 seconds of the third round of a scheduled 10-rounder. Brown sagged under a combination of punches, including a sharp left to the jaw.

title: POLICE THINK I.R.A. ACTED WEEKS AGO
description: The terrorist bomb that came close to wiping out the upper echelon of the British Government may have been planted by Irish guerrillas weeks ago, a ranking police officer said today.

title: Vietnam Says It Would Like Better Ties to U.S. and China
description: Vietnam reaffirmed today that it wanted improved relations with China and the United States.

title: D.E.P. Enforcement Called 'Tippy-Toe'
description: In 1983, Senator George Mitchell of Maine, a former prosecuting attorney and judge, said, in referring to the Federal Environmental Protection Agency under Anne Gorsuch Burford:

title: AROUND THE GARDEN;
description: JOAN LEE FAUST This Week:

title: Miss Smith Wed To David Brunell
description: Pamela Anne Smith, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Wilbert J. Smith of St. Louis, was married yesterday to David Drew Brunell, a son of Mrs. Ruth W. Ackley of Hempstead, L.I., and the late Norman Brunell. The Rev. Edward O'Connell performed the ceremony at the Holy Trinity Roman Catholic Church in Washington.

title: Patricia Sigler to Wed Keith Lindner in December
description: Mr. and Mrs. Andrew C. Sigler of New Canaan, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Patricia Eleanor Sigler, to Keith Edward Lindner, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Carl H. Lindner Jr. of Cincinnati. Miss Sigler and her fiance plan to be married in December.

title: AND NOW, THE ONE-UNIT MANAGER
description: AS an ongoing drama, the New York City housing market has had a pretty stable set of

title: ARE SCIENTISTS DIFFERENT?
description: Rosalind Williams, who teaches at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, is the author of ''Dream Worlds: Mass Consumption in Nineteenth-Century France.'' THREE DEGREES ABOVE ZERO

title: Miss Blewer Has Nuptials
description: Victoria Schaeffer Blewer, a daughter of Sondra G. Blewer of New York and Sugar Hill, N.H., and John M. Blewer of New York and Essex, Conn., was married yesterday to Christopher Aram Bohjalian, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Aram Bohjalian of Mount Vernon, N.Y. The Rev. Leslie Merlin performed the ceremony at the Brick Presbyterian Church in New York.

title: A CONSERVATIVE STYLE, BUT A FLAIR FOR GROWTH
description: CHARLES WORTHINGTON MORITZ personifies the conservative businessman. He lives in Darien, Conn., he's 48 years old, and he has three children. He plays golf and reads spy novels. His neatly trimmed hair is gray; his suit, pinstriped; and his reading glasses, half frames that sit on the edge of his nose.

title: PROSPECTS
description: A Pause for Credit Buying

title: DANCE: SANJUKTA PANIGRAHI
description: Watching the Indian dances that Sanjukta Panigrahi presented Wednesday night in the Lila Acheson Wallace Auditorium of the Asia Society was like sampling a tray laden with honeyed pastries.

title: Without Ego or Vanity
description: John Gielgud once said, "Acting is half shame, half glory. Shame at exhibiting yourself, glory when you can forget yourself." He debuted at the Old Vic in 1921 when he was 17, and ever since his career has been one of effortless glory. Acting in everything from the classics to the avant-garde, he has demonstrated creativeness and adaptability while thrilling audiences with what Alec Guinness calls a "superb tenor voice, like a silver trumpet muffled in silk." To the playwright and barrister Johnirortimer, Mr. Gielgud's influence extends beyond the footlights: his voice inspires Mr. Mortimer when making final appeals to juries.

title: NEW JERSEYANS
description: REMEMBER the Flying Nun? Well, New Jersey has a swimming pastor. She is the Rev. Gayle M. Woodman of Millburn, Protestant chaplain at St. Barnabas Medical Center in Livingston.

title:
STAMPS;
On the Protection of a Fine Collection
description: A stamp collection may represent a rather small but valuable piece of property in size and weight. Yet it presents unique problems of security.

title: NEW CASSETTES: FROM 'TWIGS' TO A BASKERVILLE HOUND
description: Windom's Way Starring Peter Finch and Mary Ure; directed by Ronald Neame, 1957 VidAmerica 107 minutes. $59.95

title: HOW I WROTE 'THE NAME OF THE ROSE'
description: IBEGAN writing ''The Name of the Rose'' in

title: UGANDA'S OPPOSITION PARTY GROWS IN A WINDOW OF TOLERANCE
description: On the second floor of a concrete building that also houses a pharmacy, an evangelical fellowship and a beauty salon, Uganda's Democratic Party occupies a warren of small dingy offices. Inside, the intense discussions and enthusiastic hustle and bustle recall the mood associated with alternative newspapers and campus political organizations in the United States. In contemporary Africa, highly vocal legal opposition is rare. It is extraordinary in Uganda, which has been singled out by American officials as having one of the world's most serious human rights problems.

title: GONE, INEXPLICABLY
description: HOSTAGES TO FORTUNE By William Humphrey. 227 pp. New York: Seymour Lawrence/ Delacorte Press. $15.95.

title:
SPEAKING PERSONALLY;
PAEAN TO THE MUSE OF SUPERMARKETS
description: IT'S MY turn to do the food shopping this week. My wife went

title: POLITICS DISCOVERS COLUMBUS DAY
description: POLITICIANS love a parade, especially when it's held four weeks before Election Day and honors a navigator born in the ancestral homeland of a politically significant ethnic group. At New York's Columbus Day Parade, the politicians were not only seen last week, they were also heard, planning and maneuvering - and complaining that others were doing the same.

title: PORTRAIT ARTIST
description: Alice Neel, the painter best known as a portraitist who was once described as ''the quintessential Bohemian,'' died of cancer yesterday at her home on Manhattan's Upper West Side. She was 84 years old.

title: NEW CASSETTES FOR THE AUDIOPHILE
description: Audiophile LP's have been going the way of the Edsel, as the laser-played compact disk seems headed for a larger and larger share of the market for highest quality sound. But the cassette, while challenging the LP in recent years, has not really made an impact on the audiophile consciousness. There are a few companies that produce pre-recorded cassettes duplicated in real time (rather than speeded up in the transfer process from master tapes, as is customary) using high quality materials, but for the most part cassettes have not been the source for the ultimate in sound quality.

title: ADVISER HELPING THE RICH DISCOVER WORTHY CAUSES
description: When David R. Hunter discovers a worthy but struggling charity seeking money, he sends out a string of memos alerting dozens of small foundations or philanthropists across the country.

title: PLAINFIELD ORCHESTRA CELEBRATES 65th YEAR
description: PLAINFIELD THE Plainfield Symphony, New Jersey's oldest community orchestra, will open its 65th anniversary season Saturday with a performance of Carl Orff's ''Carmina Burana,'' a work that the symphony's music director, George Marriner Maull, calls ''flamboyantly celebratory.''

title: Margaret Stirton Wed To John Michael Zebb
description: Margaret Ackles Stirton, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William A. Stirton of Longmeadow, Mass., was married yesterday to John Michael Zebb, the son of Mrs. Joseph J. Zebb and the late Mr. Zebb of Springfield, Mass. The Rev. Jeffrey M. Lewis performed the ceremony at the First Congregational Church of Christ in Longmeadow.

title: THE AUSTRALIAN DREAM
description: HARLAND'S HALF ACRE

title: A SELFLESS 'DON GIOVANNI' THAT AVOIDS ECCENTRICITY
description: George Jellinek is host of the syndicated radio program ''The Vocal Scene.''

title: TEXT OF STATEMENT BY BISHOPS ON CHURCH ROLE IN POLITCS
description: Following is text of the statement issued yesterday by Bishop James W. Malone of Youngstown, Ohio:

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;
WHAT THE WEEKENDER SAID, AND WHAT ENSUED
description: AS the days became longer, we followed our instincts like migrating birds and took flight to the warmer southern shores of Long Island. We packed our covered (station) wagon and set out on a journey that took us far from the northwestern tip of the Island down through to its easternmost end.

title: Shuler, Ryan Draw on Past
description: They were drafted from the Class of 1978, but until this year Mickey Shuler and Pat Ryan were more noted as backups to well-known Jet tarters than as performers in their own right.

title: LETTERS
description: LATIN DEBTORS

title: JUDGE ORDERS IMPROVEMENTS IN CONDITIONS AT JAIL IN JERSEY
description: A Federal judge has ruled that conditions at the Monmouth County Jail ''amount to punishment.''

title: SOCIAL SECURITY IS PART OF THE DEFICIT, FOR NOW
description: To the Editor:

title: STATE ACTS ON OZONE POLLUTION
description: THE New York State Department of Environmental Conservation has begun a vast enforcement program in an attempt to alleviate ozone pollution on the Island.

title: SUBSIDIES TO FARMS SET RECORD IN '83, REPORT SAYS
description: Farmers received $9.3 billion in direct Federal subsidies last year, more than double the previous high of $3.96 billion, paid out in 1972, the Agriculture Department has reported.

title: THE WORLD ; Latin AmericansThank Carter
description: Jimmy Carter toured South America last week meeting people who said they were indebted to him for their liberty and, in some cases, their lives. He was welcomed by two Presidents, Raul Alfonsin of Argentina and Fernando Belaunde Terry of Peru, who took power from military regimes that had been under pressure from Carter Administration human rights activists.

title: CARICATURES THAT STILL DRAW BLOOD
description: NEW HAVEN

title: WHAT'S DOING IN BOSTON
description: FOX BUTTERFIELD is the Times bureau chief in Boston.

title: The Working Mother As Role Model
description: Congratulations on Anita Shreve's article, ''The Working Mother as Role Model'' (Sept. 9).

title: Martha Miller Is Bride Of Lawrence C. Duvall
description: Martha Elizabeth Miller, the daughter of the Rev. and Mrs. Michael R. Miller of Matawan, N.J., was married in Washington yesterday to Lawrence C. Duvall, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Charles P. Duvall of Potomac, Md. The Rev. William Foreman, assisted by the bride's father, performed the ceremony at the National Presbyterian Church.

title: CUNNINGHAM'S 'EVENTS' ARE AUDACIOUS AND CONTROVERSIAL
description: The ''Events'' that the Merce Cunningham Dance Company recently presented at the Joyce Theater were once again both satisfying and perplexing. That is how ''Events'' have been in the past. That is surely how they will continue to be in the future. Even though it is now 20 years since Mr. Cunningham created his first ''Event,'' these 90-minute collages of movements taken from works in the Cunningham repertory remain controversial.

title:
ART;
CULTURAL CROSSROADS AT NEWARK MUSEUM
description: NEWARK TWO adjacent exhibitions at the Newark Museum reveal that institution to be aware of a kind of cultural crossroads.

title: TO WARD OFF CHAOS
description: Walter Kendrick teaches English at Fordham University. WIND AND BIRDS AND HUMAN VOICES

title: 100TH VICTORY FOR POLY COACH
description: Poly Prep won one for the Fog yesterday - and it was a big one for its coach, Phil Foglietta. The Brooklyn team presented the coach with his 100th career victory when it downed previously unbeaten Hackley, 18-0, on the winners' field.

title: Amy Jo Lyons to Wed David Kemler in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert L. Lyons of Lewisburg, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Amy Jo Lyons, to David S. Kemler, the son of Dr. and Mrs. R. Leonard Kemler of West Hartford, Conn. A June wedding is planned.

title: Luzinski Wins Contest
description: Greg Luzinski of the Chicago White Sox beat Jeff Leonard of the San Francisco Giants today in the final of a seasonlong home run hitting contest sponsored by Gatorade.

title: F.A.A. HALTS AIR FLIGHTS
description: The Federal Aviation Administration issued an ''emergency order'' yesterday halting all flights of the airline whose jet flew several hundred miles off course and came within minutes of straying over an important Soviet naval base Sept. 29.

title: BATTLES CONTINUE OVER VOTER DRIVES
description: AS Tuesday's deadline for voter registration approaches, community groups and voter registrars in some Connecticut cities are still going head-to-head.

title: IN LONDON, STAGE FARCE AND TV WAR
description: Twenty years ago, at the height of what became known as the Satire Boom, one of the four creator-performers of the revue ''Beyond the Fringe'' declared that Britain was ''sinking giggling into the sea.'' That watery fate failed to materialize then, but looks rather more likely now. Thus far, 1984 has brought the London theater farce after farce: ''See How They Run,'' ''Run for your Wife'' and, in just the last week or so, a revival of Joe Orton's ''Loot'' and something called ''Big in Brazil,'' which (please don't ask why) shows the dramatist Feydeau and others being chased round a shady Amazonian hotel by the head of the local chapter of Moral Majority, a Francophobe police chief.

title: A REGIONAL ROUNDUP ON EMMPLOYMENT
description: Mountain States

title: A ROLLICKING MOLI ERE AT THE McCARTER
description: PRINCETON AMIDDLE-AGED man imprisons a young woman to keep her pure ''in good and modest ignorance'' and then marry her. If the practice sounds unpardonable and the motivation unbelievable, consider this: Such isolation is intended as a rebellion against the impurity of society.

title: A TEACHER WHO FOCUSES ON STUDENTS
description: JOSEPH SZABO, a photographer who was awarded a major fellowship grant recently by the National Endowment for the Arts, never has to look far for inspiration. His subjects are teen-agers, the students he encounters each day while teaching art at Malverne High School.

title: HEADLINERS ; Rich Settlement
description: Marc Rich may not be able to set foot in the United States without being arrested, but that doesn't mean he can't continue to ply his trade here. While the multimillionaire commodities dealer remained holed up in Switzerland, where he fled after being indicted on tax evasion and fraud charges two years ago, two companies he controls cut a deal with the Government last week that will enable them to get back to business.

title: Dr. Prudence Anne Goodman Marries Dr. P. E. Simson, a Fellow Researcher
description: Dr. Prudence Anne Goodman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Maurice Goodman Jr. of New York and Salisbury, Conn., was married yesterday to Dr. Peter Ernst Simson, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Jerome Simson of New York and East Hampton, L.I. Justice of the Peace Stuyvesant Bearns performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents in Salisbury.

title: AIDING OLDER PEOPLE AS OLDER PEOPLE
description: '' IN organizational terms,'' said Samuel Sadin of New Hyde Park, ''the goals are to foster cooperation and exchange information between Jewish senior citizen advocacy groups and to foster the formation of new ones. The other goals are to deal with concerns - health care, Social Security income, the aged poor, the need for long-term custodial or chronic care. The focus of this organization is on the needs of older people as older people.''

title: PRACTICAL TRAVELER: WHEN VOYAGERS DON'T HAVE 80 DAYS
description: Once again this winter, it will be possible to escape almost all the ice and snow of northern climates by taking a world cruise. Seven liners will circumnavigate the globe on voyages of approximately three months. One other ship will make an extensive circle cruise of the Far East and South Pacific that, because of the length of the trip and the number and variety of ports to be visited, puts the journey in the world cruise class.

title: KIPLING COMES ALIVE, THANKS TO MCCOWEN
description: Alec McCowen, who discovered a personality for St. Mark in his one-man reading of the Gospel, has undertaken the equally challenging assignment of giving Rudyard Kipling theatrical life - Kipling, one of the most personally reticent of public writers and the embodiment of jingoistic English colonialism. Because of his politics, one might consider him to be irrelevant. That Mr. McCowen makes us see Kipling with all his leopard spots intact - and makes us care about him - is a tribute to the actor's artistry.

title:
THE JOB MARKET;
TOURISM TAKING OFF TO NEW HEIGHTS
description: STRIKING changes have taken place in the last few years in travel-industry careers. Until the late 1970's, most newcomers to travel agencies, airlines, shipping lines, tourist boards and other organizations were hired and trained on the job. Since then there has been a steady growth in the number of colleges, community colleges and privately owned trade schools offering programs to prepare students for the industry and to equip current employees for higher positions.

title: WHERE TOMORROW'S JOBS WILL BE
description: THE successful seeker after a promising career field in the year 2000 may well wind up in a position involving service to the elderly, and very likely he or she will not be computer literate but will possess a more general rather than a specialist's background or will have enough career flexibility to accommodate quick shifts in job categories.

title: BABY DOE AT AGE 1: A JOY AND BURDEN
description: Baby Jane Doe, the deformed and retarded infant who stirred national interest when her parents refused to approve surgery to prolong her life, turned 1 year old last week and, her mother says, has taken ''quite nicely to life.''

title: ABORTION ISSUE THREATENS TO BECOME A PROFOUNDLY DIVISIVE
description: The issue of abortion has become so prominent in this year's Presidential campaign that many people on both sides of the question believe that it will not go away whatever the outcome of the election, and that the resulting conflict could be bitterly disruptive. Members of the ''right-to-life'' movement have been comparing the issue to slavery in the last century and to racial discrimination in the South prior to enactment of Federal civil rights laws in the 1960's. Their opponents compare it to the drive early in this century that led to the Prohibition amendment to the Constitution, which after a period of strife had to be repealed. Whatever the comparisons, they contain forebodings of social division.

title: TASTE, WASTE AND EXCELLENCE ; Role ModelEleanor Roosevelt once wrote that her main accomplishment was to show how ''one can find a way to live widely and fully.'' But the main reason to recognize the centennial of her birth is her special gift for raising the conscience of the nation. As a wife, mother of five and First Lady, she seemed most proud of her capacity for ''self-reliance and developing into an individual.'' Her self- propulsion was fueled by her own sense of humanity. Acting as the ''eyes and ears'' of a disabled President, she traveled the country to expose the plight of the poor and disadvantaged. After her husband's death, she labored on behalf of war refugees. President Truman called her ''First Lady of the World.''
description: For a woman then to attain such prominence and individuality required a sharp break with tradition. When she died in 1962, she had become an important role model for the nascent women's movement. How she would have loved to witness the revolution it spawned.

title: IN 4th DISTRICT, NOVICE TAKES ON POPULAR INCUMBENT
description: IT is a sunny Sunday afternoon

title: NEED TO DISCUSS NUCLEAR WAR CITED
description: HOPING to overcome what they consider the ''wall of silence'' that prevents families from discussing the nuclear war threat, the county's chapter of Physicians for Social Responsibility has begun what it hopes will be a series of community meetings on the issue.

title: PROFESORS' GROUP BACKS YALE STRIKERS
description: NEW HAVEN STRIKING clerical and technical workers at Yale University received support last week from the American Association of University Professors, as the campus braced for what could be a drawn-out disruption.

title: THE NATION ; Prices of GoodsTake a Dip
description: There was good news in the nation's economic numbers last week, surprising some of those who make their own money predicting such things. The Labor Department reported that prices for finished goods fell by 0.2 percent in September, mainly because of lower food and gasoline prices, and the Commerce Department chimed in that retail sales rose by 1.6 percent last month.

title: HOUSTON SUBURB INSTITUTES ANTI-SUICIDE PLAN
description: A team of psychologists is conducting counseling sessions with students at an affluent Houston suburban high school after the suicides of six teen-agers in the last two and a half months.

title: OPERA: CHANGES IN 'SWEENEY'
description: Friday evening's performance of ''Sweeney Todd'' at the New York City Opera introduced four new principals. They didn't really constitute a complete alternate cast. A few major characters are taken by the same singer in all performances, and the singers that do switch don't divide their burdens equally. Yet while Friday's crew doesn't sing the majority of performances, it was still first rate.

title: THE PRESIDENT AND THE PRESS
description: DOWN THE CORRIDOR FROM THE OVAL OFFICE AND AROUND the corner from the Cabinet Room, in a cluttered warren of office cubicles next to the Rose Garden, the White House press corps labors. So close and yet so distant, its relationship with the President has never been easy. Presidents know they cannot function without the news media, but would if they could. Reporters understand they cannot know all the answers, but act as if entitled to them. As the campaign of 1984 enters its final weeks, it is increasingly evident that something extraordinary has happened to the relationship between President Reagan and the press. It is not simply that the level of friction is high, for that is typical of an election year. What is now clear is that Mr. Reagan has ignored some of the unstated ground rules under which reporters have traditionally covered the Presidency. As a consequence, he has dramatically altered the kind of information the public receives about him and his Administration.

title: THIS TIME, THE I.R.A. COMES CLOSE TO THATCHER
description: The political murder that is a mind-numbing accompaniment to daily life in Northern Ireland but registers only intermittently in the rest of Britain made a shocking return to center stage last week. The Irish Republican Army claimed responsibility for the bomb that wrecked the Grand Hotel in Brighton, killing at least three people, injuring a Cabinet Minister and coming close to killing Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and leading members of her Government. The explosion, which cut a gash through four floors of the white Victorian building, killed Sir Anthony Berry, a Conservative member of Parliament, Eric Taylor, a party official, as well as a woman thought to be the wife of a member of Parliament, John Wakeham. He was injured with at least 33 others. Rescuers continued to dig through the rubble yesterday.

title: 20 YEARS OF TELLING THE RANGERS AND KNICKS STORIES
description: AT that time, I thought that my sportscasting career was over before it even had begun.

title: MORE CONTROL ON ASBESTOS SOUGHT
description: TRENTON THE heightened public concern about possible asbestos contamination in the state's public schools has inspired a move in the Assembly to require the inspection of homes, workplaces and private buildings for airborne fibers.

title: Playing 'Name That Twin'
description: After two years of checking beards, neck rolls, and helmet bars, Rick Hancock has thrown in the towel on seeing double. Hancock, head coach at Ward Melville High School in Setauket, L.I., coaches two sets of identical twins. Dave and Jon Ramey, guards, and Tom and Mike Kelly, receivers, are all starting seniors. As if that weren't enough, Hancock had a third set last year, Matt and Carl Wickle, who graduated.

title: Vintage Plane Crashes, Killing 6 Off Texas Coast
description: A World War II vintage seaplane flipped over while skimming the water about two miles off the southern Texas coast today, killing six of the people aboard and injuring the other four, one critically.

title: STATE TAKES STEPS AGAINST POACHERS
description: HARTFORD MENTION poaching and the image that springs to the minds of many people is a Robin Hood- type character stealing deer to feed his family. According to state officials, that image is outdated.

title: Improving Sound Takes Commitment
description: Ho hum, another management conference on what to do with Long Island Sound (''Long Island Sound's Biggest Problem: Education,'' Sept. 23). Let's face it - we have destroyed the basic quality of the surface and below over an extended period of time.

title: PACT ON MARC RICH LEAVES LOOSE ENDS
description: A Settlement. The negotiated settlement of a huge tax case against commodity trading companies associated with Marc Rich does not end the matter. Mr. Rich's giant commodity firm, Marc Rich & Company, and its former American unit, Clarendon Ltd., which the Government claims was sold in an attempt to cloud the case, agreed to pay about $200 million in fines and back taxes on the criminal charges of fraud and tax evasion. In return for the windfall, the Government released the tens of millions in American assets of the companies. The Government would still like to get its hands on Mr. Rich and his partner, Pincus Green, who face criminal tax charges here. But both men are living in Switzerland, which does not recognize the charges for extradition purposes.

title: Future Events For Art and Academe
description: Tickets to the following may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated.

title: DUARTE'S BIG GAMBLE FOR PEACE
description: SAN SALVADOR JOSE Napoleon Duarte described it as an ''audacious act'' in a strategy session with his aides, and many diplomats agreed. Cutting through diplomatic red tape, the Salvadoran President unexpectedly announced before the United Nations General Assembly last week that he would seek a meeting with the leftist guerrilla opposition in a bid to end the five-year civil war.

title:
ANTIQUES;
POSTERS AS ART FOR THE COLLECTOR
description: PRINCETON THE combination of attractive artwork and a brief message to advertise a product, promote a political ideology or announce an important event has been used for decades in the form of posters.

title: MUSEUM VISITORS VOTE ON SCULLPTURE
description: VISITORS to the Neuberger Museum this election season are being asked to cast their ballots to help select new sculpture for the permanent collection. They will view the exhibition entitled ''Hidden Desires/Six American Sculptors,'' which includes representative work by the sculptors, and then recommend that the work of one of them be put on permanent display at the museum.

title: Peter J. Otto Married To Janet L. Nettleton
description: Janet Lockwood Nettleton, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John C. Nettleton of Greenfield, Mass., was married yesterday to Peter Jeffrey Otto, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul W. Otto of Longmeadow, Mass. The Rev. Dr. Bryant M. Kirkland performed the ceremony at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church in New York.

title: THE GUSTO IS MORE THAN JUST GARLIC
description: WOOSTER STREET, to anyone living in New Haven, means Italian restaurants. The most recent Wooster Street restaurant, Carbone's, is at the end of the street, near Interstate 95. Inside a storefront buildingthere is a cheerful two-level dining room, with the upper level having a few tables overlooking a somewhat larger area. Cream-colored walls and a high, pressed-tin ceiling give an airy effect to a room that is attractively, but not ostentatiously decorated. On Saturday nights, when there is live music, the spirit seems especially convivial. Waiters are well organized and totally professional, a welcome and unexpected pleasure.

title: TRIAL OPENS IN STABBING DEATH OF JERSEY TEEN-AGER
description: A Morristown man went on trial here this week on charges of stabbing to death an 18-year-old Parsippany Hills High School student in 1982.

title: TALKS IN BRITISH COAL STRIKE ADJOURN, EACH SIDE STAYING FIRM
description: The two sides in Britain's seven-month-old coal strike adjourned their negotiations today, each professing optimism that a settlement could be reached but defiantly insisting there could be no compromise on their part.

title: THE FACE IN THE MIRROR: ANTI-SEMITISM THEN AND NOW
description: SOME part of the genesis of this book must lie in the Brooklyn Navy Yard where I worked the night shift in the Shipfitting Department during World War II, one of some 60,000 men and a few women from every ethnic group in New York. It is no longer possible to decide whether it was my own Hitler-begotten sensitivity or the anti- Semitism itself that so often made me wonder whether, when peace came, we were to be launched into a raw politics of race and religion, and not in the South, but in New York. In any case, whatever the actual level of hostility to Jews that I was witnessing, it was vastly exacerbated in my mind by the threatening existence of Nazism and the near absence among the men I worked with 14 hours a day of any comprehension of what Nazism meant - we were fighting Germany essentially because she had allied herself with the Japanese who had attacked us at Pearl Harbor.

title: AROUND THE WORLD ; Liberia Frees 10 Accused of Coup Plot
description: Gen. Samuel K. Doe, the Liberian leader, ordered the release of 10 prominent people accused of plotting to overthrow him, the Monrovia radio said today.

title: TRANSFUSING BLACK INK INTO HOSPITALS
description: HOWARD HAMILTON helps doctors become more businesslike at the University of Chicago Hospitals and Clinics. Anne Walshe has responsibility for the budget and staff at Choices, a feminist medical center in Queens. Janet Guptill acts as a management consultant for health-care institutions at the Ernst & Whinney accounting firm in Chicago. While the duties of today's young health-care administrators are as diverse as their institutions, they reflect a common obligation: to make those institutions operate in the black.

title: FROM POLAND TO POLO
description: Sidney Zion is the author of ''Read All About It! The Collected Adventures of a Maverick Reporter.'' ''THE REST OF US''

title: DRIVE BEGUN TO CURB FLIGHT OF STUDENTS
description: TRENTON THE Department of Higher Education has begun what is believed to be the first large-scale public information campaign to promote a state's colleges and universities. Television advertisements flashing education ''hot lines'' and featuring an enthusiastic Governor Kean began to appear last week and a barrage of radio spots, which will saturate the airwaves in the coming months, will soon be heard.

title: WHERE THE FARE IS NORTH ITALIAN
description: AT Donatello, a small, pleasantly subdued and popular northern Italian restaurant in Sayville, you could say the highlights go from A to Z. Some of the appetizers and the zabaglione are outstanding. Unfortunately, dining becomes less appealing in the middle of the alphabet, around the main course.

title: THE NATION ; Our Fish,Their Fish
description: In April, the United States and Canada, bickering since 1977 about rights to the rich fishing grounds that stretch between New England and Nova Scotia, went to the World Court with competing sets of boundaries they wanted imposed on the area. The court, whose ruling was announced in The Hague last week, essentially split the difference, drawing a line roughly midway between the proposed borders.

title: COURT EFFICIENCY PRESSED IN JERSEY
description: The chief administrator of the New Jersey court system has asked the state's lawyers to support a series of changes in the judicial system, including proposals to overhaul procedures used in civil cases.

title: BATTALION'S ARRIVAL JOLTS PLAN FOR SALVADOR TALKS
description: Arrangements for a meeting next week between President Jose Napoleon Duarte and Salvadoran rebels were shaken Friday after a Government combat battalion arrived unexpectedly at the site of the talks. The development heightened rebel concerns over security arrangements.

title:
LEISURE;
A NOSTALGIA FOR APPLES IS BRINGING BACK THE OLD-FASHIONED FAVORITES
description: Patricia Barrett is a writer who lives in western Massachusetts.

title: ITALY TO QUESTION 2 MORE MAFIA MEN IN BRAZIL
description: An Italian magistrate plans to come to Brazil to interrogate two jailed associates of an Italian Mafia leader, Tommaso Buscetta, who has provided evidence against organized crime since his extradition in July.

title: FIVE DIE IN GANG-RELATED SHOOTING IN LOS ANGELES
description: Five people were fatally wounded and five others were injured Friday night after a quarrel erupted between teen-agers leaving a party and occupants of a car that drove up to the scene, the authorities said.

title: MANY STRIP MINERS PLAY WITHOUT RULES
description: Seven years ago, when President Carter was signing the Surface Mining Control and Reclamation Act into law, he observed that ''in many ways this has been a disappointing effort.'' The remark may have been one of the great understatements of the environmental age of the 1970's.

title: CONSUMER RATES
THE REGION ; State OverruledOn Student Vote
description: The walls may sometimes be bare and the furnishings austere, but a college dormitory is still a home, a Federal judge ruled last week. So, said Judge Neal P. McCurn of Federal District Court in Syracuse, a student who has lived in a college community for at least 30 days has the right to register to vote there.

title: THE BLUES AT MANUFACTURER'S HANOVER
description: WHEN the First Chicago Corporation announced early this month that it would report a loss for the third quarter, many on Wall Street were surprised. ''I thought it would be Manufacturers Hanover,'' a bank analyst said.

title:
GARDENING;
WHEN IT IS WORTHWHILE TO SAVE SEEDS
description: MANY plants in the garden end their season loaded with fruits containing seeds. It is a temptation to save the seeds to start new plants, but is it worthwhile?

title: COSMETIC DENTISTRY
description: A radiant smile has usually been a requisite of good looks. But few people are born with perfect teeth, and until recently, remodeling remained mostly the reserve of celebrities and the wealthy. During the last several years, however, advances in cosmetic dentistry have changed all that. In some ways, the dentist has become the newest beauty professional.

title: Marjorie McAboy Marries Richard H. Lowe, Lawyer
description: Marjorie Ellen McAboy, a daughter of Margaret McGlynn McAboy of LaCanada, Calif., and the late William Kincaid McAboy, was married yesterday Richard H. Lowe, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Arnold Lowe of Abington, Pa. Rabbi Bruce Goldman and the Rev. Louis Gioia, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated at the ceremony at the Snuff Mill at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx.

title: REGISTRATION DRIVES RESULT IN POLITICAL SHIFTS
description: THE 1984 election year already marked by historic firsts nationally - is producing a number of footnotes to the county's political history.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;
SHOPPING FOR NEW HOUSE IS NO EASY TASK
description: MY family and I have been house hunting. The modest suburban house we have lived in for 12 years has gradually become too modest, too suburban. We long for larger rooms, better work spaces, more junk storage, and enough acres so that we can trade in our tiny front-yard vegetable garden for berry bushes and apple trees and long rows of corn.

title: SAYVILLE GAINS A TIE
description: When Comsewogue's Eric Mas intercepted a pass by Sayville's Michael Buck and returned it for a touchdown to give his team a 14-6 lead with just 2 minutes remaining in yesterday's League V battle, Buck, the Sayville quarterback, had every reason to hang his head and give up.

title: A RETURN TO THE THOUGHTS OF CONFUCIUS
description: A 2,535th birthday was celebrated late last month as hundreds of scholars and other visitors converged on the town of Qufu in Shandong province to pay homage to its most famous son, Confucius. It was a fitting climax to China's rehabilitation of the sage whose teachings in the 6th and 5th centuries B.C. came to permeate the fabric of Chinese civilization. During the 1966-1976 Cultural Revolution, he was made the historical scapegoat of the Maoists, vilified as the ''stinking reactionary'' who stood for all the vestiges of the past that the Communists vowed to eradicate. After the leftist Defense Minister Lin Biao botched a plot in 1971 to overthrow Mao Zedong and was killed trying to flee the country, the Maoists posthumously insulted the traitor by coining a slogan to ''criticize Lin Biao and Confucius,'' as if one deserved no better than the other. Since Chairman Mao's death in 1976, however, the new leadership has decided that China could use more of the virtues that Confucius espoused, such as benevolence, righteousness, propriety, wisdom and fidelity. His emphasis on courtesy and ethics has been echoed in Peking's campaign to promote the ''four beauties'' - language, heart, behavior and environment - among Chinese whose manners have grown slovenly under communism. The Confucian respect for education has become important as China tries to restore the dignity of its intellectuals, who were persecuted for knowing too much and who are needed now to supply the brainpower for the modernization drive.

title: NUN FINDS THAT RELIGION AND BANKING MIX WELL
description: LIKE most nuns, Sister Mary Richards begins her day with prayer. But, unlike any other nun she knows of, she spends the rest of her day as a bank manager.

title: U.S. HELPS TEXANS SURVIVE DEATH OF BANK
description: A year ago this month the First National Bank of Midland, for nearly a century the financial and social pillar of this proud West Texas oil city, collapsed under the burden of bad energy loans and had to turn over most of its dubious assets to the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation.

title: PLAN FOR A DAM STIRS FEARS FOR MAINE'S PENOBSCOT
description: With the first snow falling, Nick Albans, a fishing guide, packed up his trailer and hauled in his canoe from the riverbank where it had been since the ice broke last May.

description: BARRY S. wanted to participate in the upswing of the Magellan Fund, an equity mutual fund. In August, he ordered his broker at Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith Inc. to switch his Individual Retirement Account to the Fidelity Group, manager of the fund.

title: DAY-TO-DAYNESS
description: John Domini is the author of ''Bedlam,'' a collection of short stories. TIME TO GO

title:
PROSPECTS IN THE METROPOLITAN AREA;
NEW JERSEY
description: 'THE job picture in New Jersey over the past two years has been very, very good,' said Arthur J. O'Neal Jr., director of the planning and research division of the New Jersey department of Labor. Since the recession leveled off in December 1982, he said, there has been an increase of 171,000 jobs in the private sector, primarily in the service area. And the total nonfarm seasonally adjusted employment in the state as of last July was 3,260,800, a gain of 106,700 over July 1983.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I learned in business that you had to be very careful when you told somebody that's working for you to do something, because the chances were very high he'd do it. In government you don't have to worry about that.'' - Secretary of State George P. Shultz, discussing efforts to improve security at overseas embassies. (21:3.)

title: 3 VILLAGES AWAIT CLERK'S THEFT TRIAL

King Jr., on charges that he stole money from Hewlett Bay Park. Mr. King's case may provide clues to the state of the villages' finances, which have been under a Nassau County grand jury investigation for eight months.

title: THE WORLD ; Egypt, JordanStir Things Up
description: ''We Egyptians always make historic visits,'' President Hosni Mubarak said last week as he embarked on three days of meetings with King Hussein of Jordan. Although Mr. Mubarak's visit to Jordan, the first by an Egyptian President, may not be in the same historical category as Anwar el-Sadat's 1979 trip to Israel, it did shed light on the latest power alignments of the volatile region. By receiving Mr. Mubarak, Jordan underlined its refusal to continue the Arab ostracism of Egypt begun when Mr. Sadat made peace with Israel.

description: John Gross is an editor of The Book Review.

description: ELIE WIESEL, Andrew Mellon Professor of Humanities at Boston University, is the author of more than 20 books, including ''A Beggar in Jerusalem.'' This article was translated from the French by Iver Peterson, a national correspondent of The New York Times.

title: AROUND THE NATION ; Actor Wounds Himself On Set of TV Series
description: Jon- Erik Hexum, a television actor, was in critical condition today after he accidentally shot himself in the head Friday with a blank-loaded pistol on the set of the CBS-TV series ''Cover Up,'' a studio spokesman said.

title: AM OPERATIC CHARACTER CAN COME TO LIFE IN A SINGLE ARIA
description: The other evening, at a thoroughly respectable and therefore less than satisfactory performance of ''Eugene Onegin'' at the Metropolitan Opera, I found myself sitting up a little straighter as the dancers began swirling and swooping through the polonaise of the third-act ball scene. And for good reason. The moment was at hand when Onegin would meet Prince Gremin, who then would sing the great aria in which he tries to explain to the younger man what falling in love with Tatyana at his advanced age has meant to him. It is Gremin's only appearance in the opera but with a few musical strokes Tchaikovsky puts before us, not an operatic bass, but a palpable, three-dimensional human being. Gremin, who describes himself wryly as ''a gray-haired warrior,'' blissfully describes his happiness and is gone, leaving Onegin and Tatyana to play out their tragedy of missed romantic opportunities.
