title:
Market Place;
Trying to Spot The Takeovers
description: IF corporate takeovers - both real and rumored

title: Amy Holof Wed To A. A. Rhodes
description: Amy Bogardus Holof, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Morton Holof of New York and Elberon, N.J., was married yesterday to Archibald Alexander Rhodes, a son of Dr. William H. Rhodes of Villanova, Pa., and Augustine Janeway Rhodes of Tucson, Ariz. Justice Martin B. Stecher of the New York State Supreme Court performed the ceremony at the home of Dorothy Morrison Allen in New Rochelle, N.Y.

title: RIO GRANDE BORDER GUARDS ADOPTING NEW TACTIC
description: As the most sweeping immigration legislation in three decades died in Congress this week, the tide of aliens crossing the Mexican border illegally continued to swell, and the Border Patrol began shifting its emphasis north, hoping to prevent the illegal entrants from melting into society.

title: OPERA: 'IVAN SUSANIN,' TALE OF RUSSIAN PEASANT
description: Eve Queler, our most dedicated collector and exhibitor of operatic curios, held an especially fascinating specimen up to the light last night at Carnegie Hall. This time we were invited to inspect the facets of Mikhail Glinka's ''Ivan Susanin,'' and that in itself was something of a surprise since the work that had been announced was the same Mikhail Glinka's ''Life for the Czar.'' Actually, the two works are one and the same - and then again, they are not.

title: STRATEGISTS ON BOTH SIDES NOW SEE FEWER GAINS FOR G.O.P. IN HOUSE
description: The revival of the Democratic Presidential campaign after last Sunday's debate has apparently dimmed the prospects for major Republican gains in the House of Representatives, according to strategists in both parties.

title: G.M. ACCORD IS SET
description: Negotiators for the Ford Motor Company and the United Automobile Workers reached agreement on a new labor contract this morning.

title: THE RACE ISN'T OVER TILL SENATE RACE IS OVER
description: As lawmakers streamed out of the capital this weekend, their eyes fastened on the election Nov. 6, some were focusing on another vote that will be held three weeks later. On that day Republican Senators will choose someone to replace Howard H. Baker Jr. as their leader, and the decision will influence both the next Congress and the battle for the Republican Presidential nomination in 1988.

title: SURPRISING L.S.U. HOLDS OFF VANDERBILT
description: In its first season under Coach Bill Arnsparger, Louisiana State has achieved one of the biggest turnarounds in college football. With an opening-game tie against Florida followed by four straight victories, the Tigers are well ahead of 1983 when, for the first time, they did not win a single Southeastern Conference game. They finished the season at 4-7.

title: Inmate, 35, Hangs Himself
description: An inmate serving a five-year term for transporting stolen property and tax evasion hanged himself today, Federal prison officials here said. They said the body of the inmate - Marc Wayne Wilburne, 35 years old, of Far Rockaway, Queens - was found hanging from a tree at about 7:15 A.M. He had been in the prison's minimum-security camp.

title: DR. EDWARD TELZAK WEDS MISS LIEBERMAN, ARCHITECT
description: Laurie Ellen Lieberman, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Marvin Lieberman of Brooklyn, was married yesterday to Dr. Edward Telzak, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Telzak of Forest Hills, Queens. Rabbi Neal I. Borovitz performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents.

title: PENN STATE VICTIM OF OPTIONS
description: The experiences of one major football power, Penn State, in its first six games this season demonstrate how many snags have arisen in this initial season of television decontrol.

title: U.S. to Investigate Food Tampering
description: The Federal Food and Drug Administration has decided to investigate possible food tampering following a fifth case involving purchases in stores here, according to the Health Director for Bristol and Burlington.

title: South Korean Debt Up
description: South Korea's outstanding foreign debt stood at $42 billion at the end of August, up from $40 billion at the end of 1983, the official press agency, Yonhap, reported.

title: FILM STUDIO NEAR HOUSTON PLANNED
description: The state of Texas is moving boldly to compete with New York and California as a world center of film making.

title: Libya Protests Arrests In Britain and U.S.
description: Libya has sent strong protests to the United States and Britain over legal actions taken against Libyan students, the official Libyan press agency said today.

title: Required Reading; Moynihan's Farewell
description: When the Senate took up a measure Thursday setting spending levels estimated at $9 billion for intelligence agencies, Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan used the occasion for a valedictory address.

title: THOUSANDS IN CITY HAIL GHANA KING
description: Around his thick wrists were several bands of gold. His fingers were covered with rings carved from delicate woods, and his heavy robes were of flowing orange-red asasia, the silk and cotton cloth of African royalty.

title: State Study Faults Bus Dispatchers
description: Some bus dispatchers in Manhattan and the Bronx shirk their assigned tasks and, when they do work, they often do a poor job, according to a report released yesterday by the State Comptroller.

title: Cigarette Warning Bill Is Signed by President
description: President Reagan signed legislation Saturday requiring cigarette packages and cigarette advertising to carry stronger warnings about the dangers of smoking to health.

title: BANCROFT PORTRAYS A FEISTY FRUMP
description: uf812

title: CURRENT INTEREST RATES
description: Tax-Exempt Bonds*10.36

title: FRENCH PRICE CUTTER BACK IN ACTION
description: Seated in a small Paris office, Edouard Leclerc and his son Michel chuckled the other day at the discomfort they are causing the French Government and many small shopkeepers.

title: People
description: * Alan Schwartz named senior vice president/chief operating officer and financial officer at Bernard Hodes Advertising, a division of Doyle Dane Bernabch.

title: Futures; A Bullion Seller's Guarantee
description: TO say that most investors in gold

title: GIBSON BATS IN 5 RUNS
description: They led their division after their first game of the season, and now they lead the major leagues after their last.

title: WORLD TRADE MAY FACE MORE 'VOLUNTARY' CURBS
description: Voluntarism, Japan has learned, is contagious in international trade. Within two months of Japan's reluctant decision on May 1, 1981, to limit automobile exports to the United States, arm-twisters from Canada, West Germany, Belgium, Luxembourg and the Netherlands all had extracted similar ''voluntary'' agreements from Japan.

title: DUTTON IDENTIFIES WITH HIS ROLE IN 'MA RAINEY'S'
description: Charles S. Dutton is on stage, sprawled on a bench in the seedy musicians' warmup room that is one- half the set of ''Ma Rainey's Black Bottom,'' August Wilson's highly praised drama. He is playing the role of Levee, a black trumpet player who swaggers around, admiring his new shoes, scorning the blues as ''jugband'' music, talking about forming his own hot jazz band. With the certainty of the na"if, he forges ahead with his plans, ignoring the advice of the three older band members.

title: Eskimos Deplore Lack Of Inquiry on Caribous
description: Leaders of Eskimos who live in northern Quebec are protesting the refusal by the province's Premier, Rene Levesque, to hold an independent public inquiry into the drowning of 9,600 caribous during the annual migration earlier this month.

title: Musica Sacra Performs At Central Presbyterian
description: Musica Sacra under Richard Westenburg returned to its old home at Central Presbyterian Church on Park Avenue Wednesday night. The program was all Bach and served as a small but pointed preface to next year's 300th anniversary celebration.

title: REAGAN ORDERS ACTION ON EAVESDROPPING
description: President Reagan, acting on on intelligence reports that Soviet eavesdropping is a serious security threat, has ordered the creation of a cabinet-level group to combat it.

title: BATTLE TO RID MONUMENTS OF GRAFFITI IS HARD TO WIN
description: Vytenis Gureckas, a 26-year-old student at Columbia University's Graduate School of Architecture, strolled by Grant's Tomb the other day and admired its classical lines.

title: WESTMORELAND TRIAL
description: In some ways, room 318 at the Federal Courthouse in Foley Square looks like the most dignified television showroom in New York: throughout its wood-paneled expanse - in front of the bench, to the left and right of the jury, on tables before the defendant and the plaintiff - are video monitors. The $120 million libel suit that Gen. William C. Westmoreland is bringing against CBS is all about television, and televisions are all about.

title: Idleness Angers Padres' Summers
description: Champ Summers, the Padre reserve outfielder and pinch-hitter who enjoyed his most productive years in a Detroit uniform, is angry with Manager Dick Williams for not playing him in Tiger Stadium during the World Series.

title: A Convention for Lovers Of the Romance Novel
description: Hundreds of readers of romance

title: QUESTION BOX
description: QUESTION: A pop foul by a Team B batter is chased toward the Team A dugout by the Team A catcher. As the ball descends, it is apparent that it will strike near the front of the dugout roof, and so several players on the Team A bench scramble from their seats to hold the catcher up and prevent him from falling into the dugout as he attempts the catch. If the catch is made while the catcher is supported by his teammates, will the batter be called out or is interference involved?

title: GHOSTS OF FASCISM INTRUDE ON COLOSSEUM'S SLEEP
description: ''The Colosseum Reopens After Two Millenniums,'' the Milan daily, Corriere Della Sera, said in a headline the other day. Now that's news.

title: Top Grumman Lobbyist Retiring in February
description: Gordon H. Ochenrider, who for the past 10 years has defended the Grumman Corporation's interests in Washington, plans to retire in February as vice president of Grumman and will establish a private consulting business in Washington.

title: In Like Quinn
description: Happily, it turned out to be nothing more serious than perhaps biting off more than he could chew. Pat Quinn still is not sure that it indeed was the chewing tobacco he swallowed that caused the pains in his chest and the dizziness in his head. He knows it was probably the fact that he was simply a 41-year-old, out-of-shape coach trying to keep up with his players.

title: Time to Burn the Trash As New York City runs out of land space for its daily 22,000 tons of waste, the Sanitation Department moves ahead with plans to bury it in the sky. It would spend $3 billion to construct eight massive incinerators, and argues persuasively that they will be safe and efficient. But some environmental groups favor a strong effort to recycle garbage as well, contending that this would reduce both disposal costs and health risks.
description: While the environmentalists' advice is well worth heeding, it should not delay construction of the first plant.

title: Amoco Rumors
description: Word spread Friday in both New York and Chicago like an oilfield fire that Chicago-based Amoco Oil Company, a longtime client of the D'Arcy MacManus Masius office there, was looking for a new agency. The truth of the matter, according to C. F. Meyerdirk of the public relations department of Standard Oil (Indiana), Amoco's parent, is that the D'Arcy's position as agency of record for both Amoco and Standard of Indiana is unthreatened. The company, he said, is merely having a ''routine credentials review'' of other agencies, which he believed to be a fairly common industry practice as a way of keeping in touch with the agency scene.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES ;
description: YOUNG HEARTS CRYING. By Richard

title: SOCIAL PROGRAMS-CAMPAIGN ORPHANS
description: What is the reason for the low visibility of social programs in the election campaign? They were hardly mentioned in the Presidential and Vice Presidential debates - a sharp contrast to past campaigns in which urban blight, the Great Society and welfare reform were central issues.

title: FOCUS OF U.N. FOOD DAY TOMORROW: WOMEN
description: The United Nations will mark World Food Day on Tuesday, an annual event intended to build public support for more effective international policies to fight hunger.

title: WORK FIRST PRESENTED IN 1836 AND DEDICATED TO NICHOLAS I
description: ''A Life for the Czar,'' the first of Mikhail Glinka's two operas, made a strong impression at its premiere in St. Petersburg in 1836. It remained popular throughout Russia until the revolution of 1917.

title: MALTA AND VATICAN LOCKED IN TUSSLE OVER SCHOOLS
description: Sometimes, even in a language like Maltese, which fuses the brilliantly evasive formulas of Arabic and Italian, someone here says what he means.

title: CORRECTION
description: A subordinate headline with an article on the Style page Sept. 29 about indoor pollution was incorrect. Sealed office buildings add to the problem of pollution, but better insulation does not.

title: MUSIC: JULLIARD ORCHESTRA
description: The orchestra on the Avery Fisher stage Friday night was full of future famous soloists, principal players of the great national ensembles, beloved teachers and crackerjack freelancers. That was a given, Juilliard being Juilliard.

title: OFFICIATING IN 15-15 TIE ANGERS SOONERS
description: At the offices of the Big Eight Conference in Kansas City, Mo., callers identifying themselves as reporters today asked for the names of the officials who had been part of the crew at the Oklahoma-Texas game on Saturday. Some of the calls were even from real reporters.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: THEATER TALK There's a real life that goes on backstage, behind the dramas that hold the spotlight and that's what Theaterscope is devoted to talking about. Theaterscope, which starts a new season at 8 P.M. today at the West Side Y.M.C.A., 5 West 63d Street (787-6557), puts all manner of behind- the-scenes theater people up front in the Y's Little Theater to speak about their lives and careers.

title: THEATER: THE ROYAL SHAKESPEARE'S 'MUCH ADO'
description: When Derek Jacobi's Benedick and Sinead Cusack's Beatrice launch their witty fusillade in the Royal Shakespeare Company's ''Much Ado About Nothing,'' the war of words is as merry as it's claimed to be - more a chummy vaudeville turn than a battle royal. The actors don't square off to exchange their opening volley of insults; they sidle up to one another as if they were wary rival comedians trying out their best new zingers in a game of ''Can you top this?''

title: STEEL RULE'S EFFECT MAY BE LIMITED
description: On its face, the trade bill approved by Congress makes protection of domestic steelmakers contingent on their spending to modernize plants and retrain workers.

title: 'WORLD'S GREATEST MYSTERIES' ON ABC
description: Despite a bombardment of promotional ads during the Olympics this summer on ABC, despite a strong August launching that left an assortment of cheerleaders babbling about the ''season's first hit,'' the series ''Call to Glory'' has gone downhill steadily in the ratings and is already being pre-empted on the ABC schedule. Tonight the 8 P.M. to 9 slot will be filled instead with a documentary entitled ''World's Greatest Mysteries,'' starring, if you will, George C. Scott as host/narrator and Arthur C. Clarke, the science-fiction author, as an occasional walk-on.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''In the rain, New Yorkers will get into anything.'' - Andrew Fellman, taxi driver. (B1:6.)

title: ISLANDERS TO FOCUS ON DEFENSE
description: After only two games, two tiny steps into the six-month regular season, the Islanders must shield their eyes when they review their start.

title: MUSIC ; Rosalyn Tureck Recital At Carnegie Hall
description: Rosalyn Tureck's Bach recital at Carnegie Hall Thursday night placed its trust in the composer's ability to speak eloquently for himself without dramatic amplification or interpretive rhetoric.

title: Alexandra Du Val Becomes a Bride
description: Alexandra Lynde Du Val, a daughter of Philip L. R. Du Val of New Canaan, Conn., and Mrs. Edward Spaulding of Santa Barbara, Calif., was married yesterday to Joost Bongaerts, a son of Annette Bongaerts- Hafkemeijer of The Hague and the late Josephus Bongaerts. The Rev. T. Guthrie Speers Jr. performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church in New Canaan, assisted by the Rev. Edward J. Howley, pastor of St. Thomas More Roman Catholic Church in Darien, Conn.

title: MONDAY SPORTS Football
description: Broncos vs. Green Bay Packers , at Denver. The Broncos have won four straight games and entered the weekend tied with the Los Angeles Raiders for first place in the A.F.C. West.

title: MONDALE PORTRAYS AS 'HOAX' REAGAN'S SPACE-ARMS PLAN
description: Walter F. Mondale yesterday termed President Reagan's plan to test and develop antimissile systems in space a ''hoax,'' as he sought to cast doubts about Mr. Reagan's grasp of arms control issues.

title: Advertising; Top-Level Moves at Leber Katz
description: LEBER KATZ PARTNERS not only

title: HOW COVERT ANTI-TERRORISM FIGHTERS LOST OUT
description: To the Editor:

title: OF TAXES, WEATHER AND FLIGHT
description: In the political history of California, some names tower above others: Gov. Hiram Johnson, the turn-of-the-century Progressive; Earl Warren, the former Governor and later Chief Justice of the United States; Richard M. Nixon; Ronald Reagan.

title: C.I.A. SAID TO PRODUCE MANUAL FOR ANTI-SANDINISTAS
description: Intelligence officials say the Central Intelligence Agency has produced a manual for Nicaraguan rebels that instructs them to hire professional criminals for ''selective jobs.''

title: BLAST CALLED 2D I.R.A. PLOT ON THATCHER
description: The bomb attack on the British Cabinet before dawn on Friday was the Irish Republican Army's second planned effort to kill Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, it was reported today.

title: Jane Schaffer Is Married
description: Jane Esther Schaffer, the daughter of Mrs. Aaron Dechter of Los Angeles and the late Martin J. Schaffer, was married yesterday to Benjamin Robert Gruberg, a son of Pearl Richter of Ridgewood, N.J., and the late Leon Davis Gruberg. Rabbi Erwin Zimet officiated at the Valeur Manor in Rhinebeck, N.Y. The bride, who will keep her name, is a freelance writer and producer of business communications materials. Her previous marriage ended in divorce. Mr. Gruberg is the assistant director of Mayor Koch's Office of Film, Theater and Broadcasting.

title: Justice Dept. Cancels A $700,000 Contract
description: A Justice Department agency canceled a consulting group's contract worth more than $700,000 because of complaints of ''irregular employment practices'' at the company.

title: 20 YEARS LATER, KHRUSHCHEV IS DIM MEMORY FOR RUSSIANS
description: Twenty years ago tonight, some time between 9 and 11, workmen removed a huge portrait of Nikita S. Khrushchev from the facade of the Moskva Hotel near Red Square, and the man who had led the Soviet Union for more than a decade slipped quietly into official oblivion.

title: SLEW O' GOLD KEEPS UP WITH HIS MAGNIFICENT SIRE
description: It is still 10 minutes before post

title: FIRE PUT OUT ON GULF TANKER, BUT SHIP REMAINS IN DANGER
description: A fire aboard a gas tanker damaged by missiles in the Persian Gulf was put out today, but the Greek-owned vessel remained in danger, shipping officials here said.

title: REBEL LEADERS FLY HOME TO SALVADOR FOR PARLEY TODAY
description: Two leading Salvadoran rebel officials flew to El Salvador today, ending, at least temporarily, more than four years of political exile and setting the stage for a meeting Monday with President Jose Napoleon Duarte.

title: The Editorial Notebook; Allocating Dick Tracy Channels
description: Cellular radio telephones may revolutionize communication, leading from low-cost connections with autos and boats to perhaps even Dick Tracy-style wristphones. Licenses to sell this service over federally controlled airwaves may become immensely valuable. But actions of the Federal Communications Commission suggest that Government lacks the political will to claim the public's share of this valuable commodity.

title: Rev. Martin Luther King Sr. Is Discharged From Hospital
description: The Rev. Martin Luther King Sr. has been discharged from the hospital and is doing well after being treated for a chronic heart ailment, officials said today.

title: PADRES' DOWNFALL CAUSED BY POP FLY
description: It was a little pop fly into short right field, and the second baseman ran back and caught it, but it was the turning point. And it was so ironic that Tommy Lasorda, the manager of the Los Angeles Dodgers, watched it come down and said:

title: G.M. Recalls 760,000 Autos To Replace Pollution Device
description: The General Motors Corporation is recalling 760,000 automobiles made in 1981 and 1982 because of faulty catalytic converters.

title: ABC AND NBC CUTTING 150 NEWS JOBS
description: In a move designed to promote efficiency and help increase profits, two of the three major television networks, ABC and NBC, are eliminating more than 150 jobs in their news operations, according to network officials. Executives at CBS News, which experienced three waves of staff cutbacks over the last two years, said they too will be cutting some positions, although the number will probably be no more than 10.

title: BRANDT VISITS MANAGUA BUT FAILS TO SETTLE NICARAGUA VOTE DISPUTE
description: Former Chancellor Willy Brandt of West Germany, who arrived here less than 48 hours ago to mediate disputes over Nicaragua's planned presidential election, left today, his mission apparently a failure.

title: RESHAPING FIRST INTERSTATE
description: By using all of banking's electronic and marketing innovations, and inventing a few of its own, the First Interstate Bancorporation has hung its sign above more retail branches than any other bank in the country. That was the easy part: Now it faces the formidable task of welding the disparate parts.

title: Poll Says Republican Trails Bradley in Jersey
description: Mary Mochary, Senator Bill Bradley's Republican challenger, has failed to make any inroads into his commanding lead, a poll released over the weekend shows.

title: MONDALE'S DRUG WAR PROPOSALS ARE ALREADY A REAGAN PROGRAM
description: To the Editor:

title: Battle Over Generic Drugs
description: In the closing days of Congress last week, the manufacturers of generic drugs were glad to see the defeat of an amendment threatening, in their view, a new law intended to speed the way of low- cost drugs onto the market.

title: Lee Webb and Judith G. Daniels Wed
description: Judith Glassman Daniels, a senior editor at Time Inc., and Lee Dunham Webb, president of the National Center for Policy Alternatives, a public- policy research institute in Washington, were married yesterday at the Norumbega Inn in Camden, Me. James Tierney, the Attorney General of Maine, officiated.

title: Better Late Than Lobster
description: The closing days of a session of

title: Light Trucks in Auto Sales Data
description: Beginning with Tuesday's report covering automobile sales for the first 10 days of the 1985 model year, such reports will be broadened to include light trucks. The change is being made to reflect the increasing personal use of vehicles such as small pickups and mini-vans, making them more of a consumer than a commercial product.

title: THE CHEEVER CHRONICLE: A DAUGHTER'S BOOK
description: When Susan Cheever learned in the fall of 1981 that her father was dying of cancer, she found herself writing about it in her journal. It began, she recalls, as ''just therapy'' - an account of the progress of her father's illness and how she felt about it during a time that was painful to her, to her mother, Mary, and to her brothers, Ben and Fred.

title: Shultz Leaving Today On Brief Canadian Trip
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz is due to travel to Canada Monday for a 23-hour visit that officials say is intended to maintain a rapid improvement in relations with Canada's new Progressive Conservative Government.

title: USE OF SULFITE PRESERVATIVES IS SEEN AS A THREAT TO SOME
description: A federally financed study into the use of sulfites in food has found that they may cause ''acute allergic-type reactions'' in asthmatics. The panel said it was suspected that four deaths were linked to the preservatives, but it did not recommend a ban.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.

title: NewspaperGuildGives 23 Journalism Awards
description: The Newspaper Guild of New York yesterday announced 23 Page One Awards for journalism in 1983.

title: NOW, PAY PHONES ON JETLINERS
description: An era in communications begins today with the inauguration of pay telephones on airborne commercial jets.

title: Thrift Unit Severance
description: The Financial Corporation of America is under increasing Government pressure to force Charles W. Knapp, its former chairman, to return a $2 million severance payment he was granted when he resigned in August, according to a Federal Home Loan Bank Board spokesman.

title: St. John's Expects A Banner Season
description: When St. John's University begins practice this afternoon in preparation for the 1984-85 basketball season, Lou Carnesecca, the Redmen's head coach, will be looking at a team that potentially ranks among the best teams in the country.

title: ABORTION LAWS TO MIRROR OUR MORAL UNEASE
description: To the Editor:

title: TV SEASON IS ONE OF DISCONTENT
description: By ruling last June 27 that the National Collegiate Athletic Association's exclusive control over college football television rights was illegal, the Supreme Court tossed those rights into a grab-bag that was open to all comers. The resulting free-for-all has spread chaos across the television landscape.

title: NEW CRIME ACT A VAST CHANGE, OFFICIALS ASSERT
description: The anticrime legislation signed into law Friday by President Reagan is the most far-reaching overhaul of the Federal criminal laws in history, according to Congressmen from both parties and Administration officials.

title: Lendl Is Upset by Jarryd
description: Anders Jarryd of Sweden scored the biggest victory of his career today with a straight-set victory over the world's No. 2 player, Ivan Lendl, in the final of the $310,000 Australian Indoor tennis championships.

title: STUDY PREDICTS BIG RATE RISES FROM NUCLEAR PLANTS
description: About one in three households in the United States will face electricity rate increases in the next few months because of over-budget nuclear power plants, according to a study by an environmental group.

title: WOMEN AND THEIR SECRETARIES
description: SECRETARIES can be an executive's best friend, or worst

title: VACUUM AT THE TOP (2)
description: BOSTON This was going to be a column, the

title: Mondale Gains Ground, According to Straw Poll
description: Walter F. Mondale has narrowed President Reagan's lead to 4 points in a straw poll published yesterday in The Daily News.

title: ADS DEBATED IN NORTH CAROLINA RACE
description: Senator Jesse Helms called his opponent a ''Mondale liberal'' and Gov. James B. Hunt Jr. responded by calling Mr. Helms a tool of the ''radical right'' Saturday night in the final television debate of their hotly contested campaign for the Senate.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Oct. 15, 1984: MONDAY Dana CorpJohnson & JohnsonEastern Utils AssocLilly (Eli) & CoFlorida Pwr & LtSouthern Co TUESDAY Bearings IncInter First CorpBemis CoK Mart CorpCBI IndusScott PaperChase Manhattan Southern Ind G & EDonaldson Lufkin Stauffer ChemicalFleming CosTexas Commerce BancGt Western FinlTexas IndusHoneywell IncVF Corp WEDNESDAY Alberto-CulverIntl Min & ChemBanc Texas GroupMagic ChefBarnett Banks FlaMelville CorpCessna AircraftNewhall Land & FarmConrac CorpPNB Mtge & RltyContinental GroupSunstrand CorpDow Jones & CoUnidynamics CorpEquitable GasWisc Pwr & LtHillenbrand Indus

title: The Candidates Today
description: Walter F. Mondale has appearances scheduled in the

title: Treasury Resets Delayed Auctions
description: Now that Congress has approved an increase in the Federal debt ceiling, the Treasury will proceed with note and bond auctions that have been delayed since late September.

title: MUBARAK CONFERS WITH WEINBERGER
description: Senior Egyptian and United States officials disagreed today about whether a breakthrough was imminent in efforts to bring about the wihdrawal of Israeli forces from southern Lebanon.

title: S.S. UNITED STATES FANS BUY PIECES OF HISTORY AT SHIP AUCTION
description: Thousands of bidders went away weighed down with wares yesterday from the superliner United States, the fastest passenger ship ever built and one of the most handsome.

title: NAKASONE APPEARS LIKELY TO WIN A SECOND TERM
description: Polls and other signs here suggest that Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone is likely to be re- elected as head of Japan's governing conservative party next month with only token opposition, if that.

title: MULTISTATE BANK STEP CALLED NEAR
description: The failure by the 98th Congress to enact banking legislation allows C. Todd Conover, the Comptroller of the Currency, to resume his campaign of deregulation by adminstrative action.

title: Possible Clue on AIDS Noted by Researchers
description: A tongue infection found in male homosexuals appears to be a possible ''early warning sign'' of AIDS, or acquired immune deficiency syndrome, researchers at the University of California at San Francisco report.

title: 'I'm Gonna Hit It Out'
description: DETROITNear home plate, Kirk Gibson looked over at Sparky Anderson in the Tigers' dugout. The Tigers were leading, 5-4, with runners on second and third in the eighth inning. Their manager held up four fingers. He thought that the San Diego Padres' manager, Dick Williams, would order Goose Gossage to walk his right fielder intentionally to pitch to Lance Parrish.

title: REDSKINS CRUSH COWBOYS, 34-14
description: With one of their finest performances of the season, the Washington Redskins staked the Dallas Cowboys to a touchdown lead today and came roaring back with 34 consecutive points to win the first meeting of the year between these divisional opponents, 34-14.

title: The Cost of Ignoring Vaccine Victims Vaccines make it possible, for a few cents a shot, to immunize children against diseases that would otherwise kill or maim thousands. But this triumph of preventive medicine is marred by a cruel injustice. Even well-made vaccines may cause fatal or crippling side effects in a very few patients. Though such individual tragedies are an inevitable price of the vaccine's public benefit, the victims are not assured of compensation.
description: For every four million people who take live polio vaccine, one may contract the disease itself. One of every 300,000 doses of whooping cough vaccine produces brain damage. The victims suffer for the common good: When many are vaccinated, the population acquires ''herd immunity'' that protects even the inevitable few not reached by vaccination programs.

title: BARBARA BUSH AS HER HUSBANDS ARDENT DEFENDER
description: One cold winter's day in 1980, the Statehouse bureau chief of The Boston Globe was busy at his desk when a white-haired woman burst into his office and demanded to know why he was not out covering a news conference held by her husband, George Bush.

title: 5 DERRING-DOERS TELL WHY THEY DID IT
description: On June 9, 1901, Adie Walford walked across the Williamsburg Bridge when it was nothing more than a series of cables.

title: PAVELICH OUT 5 WEEKS
description: The Minnesota North Stars and injuries to a number of key New York players are making life miserable for the Rangers early in the the National Hockey League season.

title: NEW NOBEL LAUREATE PLEASES CZECH GROUP
description: When word came last week that Jaroslav Seifert, an 83-year-old poet living in Prague, had been named the first Czechoslovak to win the Nobel Prize in Literature, it hardly caused a stir in what once was known as Little Bohemia on the Upper East Side of Manhattan. Few people in the gentrified neighborhood raised a glass of Pilsener Urquel, the national beer, to celebrate because they hadn't heard of Mr. Seifert and, if they had, couldn't find a book of his poetry.

title: JOBS INCREASE IN NUMBER, BUT TRENDS ARE SAID TO BE LEAVING MANY BEHIND
description: The growth in the number of jobs in the United States has become an important issue in the 1984 Presidential campaign, with members of the Reagan Administration taking pride in recent gains while Walter F. Mondale, the Democratic nominee, and others are less enthusiastic about the trends behind the numbers.

title: THE CALENDAR
description: Monday

title: BOLT FROM THE BLUE
description: WASHINGTON Eighteen months ago, in the informal talks after a nuclear arms

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ; Booz, Allen Elects Its Fifth Chairman
description: -year- old president of Booz, Allen & Hamilton Inc.'s technology group, has been elected chairman and chief executive of the management consulting firm.

title: Taiwan's Purchases in U.S.
description: Taiwan, eager to protect what is left of its political relationship with the United States and its access to American arms, is making efforts to publicize its ''buy American'' campaign.

title: Tentative Pact Reached In Strike at Disneyland
description: A tentative settlement was reached late tonight in the 20-day strike of Disneyland ride operators and other workers, and five striking unions were scheduled to vote on the agreement Tuesday, a Federal mediator said.

title: CABLE GUIDE SHOWS SAVVY AND SUCCESS
description: Just over a year ago, Time Inc. folded TV-Cable Week, its ambitious television-listings guide that lost $47 million before taxes and won fewer than 400,000 subscribers.

title: ISSUES FOR '85 WOMEN'S PARLEY
description: Nancy Clark Reynolds, the United States representative to the United Nations Commission on the Status of Women, drew scattered boos and hisses at a weekend women's conference in New York when she said the United States planned to emphasize development at the Nairobi World Conference in 1985.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: FERRARO OFFERING ANGER, PRICE AND SOME PLAIN SPEAKING
description: The candidate has a temper.

title: Gaelic Touch
description: For some people, the main event this Friday night at Madison Square Garden will not be Marvelous Marvin Hagler's defense of the world middleweight title against Mustafa Hamsho. Some people have brogues.

title: CYCLE RACING PROPOSAL SPLITS WILDERNESS AREA
description: The complaints began last October, when Donald L. Keller invited the owners of all-terrain vehicles over for a race.

title: Washington Watch; Airports Make Noise On Noise
description: WASHINGTON IT may have been more noise than substance, but

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Criterion Group, Houston, announced that Thomas J. Press has joined the investment management concern as vice president and general counsel.

title: 2 Suspects Seized In Jersey Slaying
description: Authorities said today that they were holding the second and third suspects in the slaying last month of a woman at a rest stop on the Garden State Parkway in New Jersey.

title: 2 Turkish Separatists Slain
description: Turkish security forces said today that they had killed two separatist guerrillas, a phrase normally used to refer to Kurdish rebels. A statement by martial-law authorities, reported by the semiofficial Anatolian News Agency, said the operation took place Saturday night in northeast Turkey.

title: THE DAY A PARTY STOLE A MARCH
description: To the Editor:

title: DETROIT REJOICES AT TIGERS' VICTORY
description: Downtown Detroit erupted in a triumphant celebration tonight following the Tigers' first World Series victory in 16 years.

title: Statler Brothers Named Country Group of Year
description: The Statler Brothers have been named vocal group of the year for the ninth time at the Country Music Association awards Monday night, while Anne Murray won album of the year for ''A Little Good News.''

title: LATIN DIPLOMACY: U.S. INFLUENCE MAY BE LIMITED
description: A week of unusually intense diplomatic activity is beginning in Central America, and the Reagan Administration finds itself less capable of influencing the outcome than it would like, according to Administration officials and Latin American diplomats. The State Department has made a major effort to insure that a proposed regional peace treaty is revised to protect perceived United States interests. But, with modification of the document beginning this week, some of the nations that drafted it, including Mexico and Colombia, are not likely to endorse all the Administration objectives, the officials and diplomats say.

title: TRAMMELLL SERIES M.V.P.
description: Alan Trammell, the Detroit shortstop, who was the leading hitter in the World Series with a .450 average, was named the Series' most valuable player today. His was not a totally popular choice, though, because many observers thought that Jack Morris, the winning pitchers in Games 1 and 4, contributed more.

title: Marcos Sees New Credits
description: President Ferdinand E. Marcos, in dire need of loans to rescue the economy of the Philippines, said today that he is confident foreign banks will approve his Government's request for $1.65 billion in new credits.

title: Advertising Watchdog Settles 10 Complaints
description: The National Advertising Division of the Council of Better Business Bureaus settled a mixed bag of complaints in September - and the bag included a bunch of bananas.

title: MONDAY, OCTOBER 15, 1984
description: International Two Salvadoran rebel leaders flew to El Salvador, setting the stage for their meeting with President Jose Napoleon Duarte. The leaders, Guillermo Manuel Ungo and Ruben Zamora, are the top officials of the rebel opposition. Mr. Ungo said that they came ''to start a dialogue'' that will ''win peace for our homeland.'' (Page A1, Column 6.) Men of similar backgrounds will meet during the talks scheduled between President Duarte and leaders of the Salvadoran left. In the past, Mr. Duarte and the leftist rebel leaders, Guillermo Ungo and Ruben Zamora, all supported peaceful change in El Salvador's dictatorship, but they veered to sharply different paths in their efforts to remedy their country's social injustices. (A1:4-6.)

title: Handel and Banners Salute Town Hall's Restoration
description: A wind quintet played Handel's

title: 6 People Injured On Coney I. Ride
description: Six members of a family received minor injuries yesterday when the car they were riding on a water ride flipped over at the Astroland amusement park in Coney Island, plunging them into the water, the police said.

title: In From the Cold
description: You might think that a city that has virtually ceded its parks and roadways to joggers, that casually closes a thoroughfare to make room for a triathlon and that practically shuts itself down to accommodate a marathon has been doing its all for the running community.

title: SLAYINGS ANGER RUSSIAN COMMUNITY
description: Alex Blinder's wife was so upset that she lost her voice on Saturday. And yesterday afternoon, grim knots of men in gray fedoras and women in shawls gathered outside Mr. Blinder's Russian food market, discussing a story in a Russian-language paper. ''Savage Murder of Emigre Woman and Her Son,'' the headline on the story said.

title: ROWNTREE EXPANSION IS SOUGHT
description: Rowntree Mackintosh P.L.C. has torn down old warehouses here to build a manufacturing plant for KitKat, the chocolate wafer bar that is its biggest seller.

title: Political Boos!
description: The first political Halloween

title: Illinoisan Kills Himself After Highway Slaying
description: An Illinois man stole a police car, used it to pull over another car, killed the motorist and drove to Iowa, where he killed himself, the police said today.

title: CITY TO MONITOR FLOW OF VEHICLES TO SPEED TRAFFIC
description: Television cameras will be placed atop the city's East River bridges to watch the traffic on the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive and other East Side thoroughfares.

title: STEELERS TRIUMPH BY 20-17
description: The linebacker Bryan Hinkle's one- handed interception and return of 43 yards set up the winning 21-yard field goal by Gary Anderson with 1:42 to play as the Pittsburgh Steelers defeated the San Francisco 49ers, 20-17.

title: Parole System Improvement Sought by Legislative Panel
description: The state could have saved the equivalent of the use of 240 prison cells during the 1982-83 fiscal year if New York's parole system was working better, according to a study by a state legislative panel.

title: CATHERINE J. PERRI IS WED TO ARON L. PASTERNAK
description: Catherine J. Perri, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony Perri of New Haven and Singer Island, Fla., was married yesterday to Aron L. Pasternack, a son of Dr. Alan Pasternack of Avon, Conn., and the late Bette Kolman Pasternack. The Rev. Russell Hicks, a Congregational minister, performed the civil ceremony at the New Haven Lawn Club.

title: Swiss Unemployment
description: Swiss unemployment dropped to 1 percent of the work force in September from 1.1 percent in August, but was up from eight- tenths of 1 percent from 12 months before, the Federal Office of Industry, Trade and Labor said. The report said 32,234 people were jobless in September. In another area, the Federal Customs Office reported Friday that Switzerland's merchandise trade deficit in September rose to 578 million francs, or about $226 million, from a deficit of 404 million francs in September 1983.

title: MUSIC ; American Symphony And the Ives Fourth
description: Charles Ives's Fourth Symphony had to wait half a century for its premiere, which Leopold Stokowski gave with the American Symphony Orchestra in Carnegie Hall 20 seasons ago. It is still far from a repertory piece. The complex, independent and largely uncoordinated music for different orchestral groups, especially in the second movement, pose difficulties that are insuperable unless the normal procedures for preparing symphony concerts can be modified.

title: Poisoning Feared In Deaths of Geese
description: At least 87 Canada geese have been found dead in recent days near Great Pond, a prime resting area for the migrating birds.

title: Addenda
description: * Vanity Fair magazine increasing its circulation rate base 10 percent, to 275,000, from 250,000, and its advertising rates 8 percent with the January issue.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Oct. 15, 1984 GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Economist's Outlook
description: A recession in the second half of 1985 is a ''distinct possibility'' if the rate of foreign investment falls more than expected, a top economist for the savings industry said today. James W. Christian, chief economist for the United States League of Savings Institutions, predicted that the United States economy would grow at a rate of 3 percent to 4 percent next year as long as foreigners supply about 20 percent of the total savings available.

title: NOT VOTING THE TICKET
description: To the Editor:

title: V.A.T. HELD UNLIKELY BY REAGAN
description: The Reagan Administration has all but abandoned any idea of proposing a value- added tax to narrow continued huge budget deficits, Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan said during a meeting of the Business Council in Hot Springs, Va. The council is a group made up of chief executives of the nation's largest companies.

title: Charleston Rag Takes Frizette
description: Charleston Rag, an unbeaten 2-year-old filly, scored a runaway 5 3/4- length victory in the Grade I Frizette Stakes at Belmont Park yesterday.

title: Oh, Christmas Tree
description: Last July, when many working

title: Pick a Commercial
description: The best way to persuade people

title: AN 'INDEPENDENT' FRANCHISE
description: To many small banks, the prospect of interstate banking is as comforting as an approaching cattle stampede. Many fear that Congress will soon deregulate the financial markets, pitting them directly against giants such as Sears, Roebuck & Company and Shearson Lehman/American Express, as well as the money-center banks.

title: Net Up 21.2% At First Boston First Boston Inc., the Wall
description: Street investment bank, reported that net income in the

title: Percy Says Mayor Made 'Racist' Commercials
description: Senator Charles H. Percy has accused Mayor Harold Washington of using a ''racist'' appeal in radio commercials for his Democratic challenger, Representative Paul Simon.

title: Foreign Banks Lose Mexican Debt Case
description: A Mexican court has ruled that foreign banks must allow Cerveceria Moctezuma, one of Mexico's largest beer companies, to repay its debt over the next three years.

title: A $500,000 Gift Idea
description: We haven't even had Thanksgiving

title: Caviar for Beverly Sills
description: No one sang ''Happy Birthday,'' but

title: Kansas State Students In Melee With Police
description: Several thousand students, many drunk, clashed with the police early today after a college football game. The melee was started by a smoke bomb thrown into a bar and the stabbing of an officer, the authorities said.

title: OUTDOORS: IT'S SHAPE-UP TIME FOR SKIERS
description: It's late - but not too late - to get

title: ; IT'S FOLLY TO THINK MORE PRISONS CONFINE CRIME
description: To the Editor:

title: DUARTE AND LEFTIST FOES LINKED BY OLD TIES
description: The meeting between President Jose Napoleon Duarte and leaders of the Salvadoran left will not be one between an established government and peasants in arms, but rather among men with similar backgrounds who have in some cases been friends and colleagues.

title: DILLON AND ARTS FEDERATION HONORED
description: With speeches, music and dancing, the New York art world yesterday celebrated the 75th anniversaries of two of its most formidable institutions: the American Federation of Arts and Douglas Dillon.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: TUESDAY, OCTOBER 16, 1984

title: MCI NET TUMBLES BY 86.2% IN QUARTER
description: The MCI Communications Corporation reported yesterday that earnings in the three months ended Sept. 30 fell 86.2 percent, to $7.1 million, or 3 cents a share, from $51.5 million, or 22 cents a share, in the comparable period of 1983. It was one of MCI's worst quarters in years and reflected the hard times that many long-distance carriers are suffering in the aftermath of the breakup of the Bell System.

title: American Air Trust Suit
description: The Federal Government can prosecute American Airlines and its president on charges of attempting to fix fares with Braniff Airlines in 1982, a Federal appeals court ruled today.

title: Executives Join In Caressa Bid MIAMI, Oct. 15 (Reuters) -
description: Caressa Group Inc., which designs and makes women's footwear, said it had reached a

title: SHAW INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 29
Reliance Steel
description: The Reliance Steel and Aluminum Company said it had closed its Houston metals-service facility because of the continuing slump in the oil industry. A metals-service company acts like a wholesaler, buying large orders of metal from mills, then processing and reselling them to customers who do not have large enough orders to purchase directly from the mills. Reliance bought the Houston facility in 1975.

title: ROCHESTER TELEPHONE reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Transactions
description: Released Russell Cross, forward, and Pace Mannion, guard. INDIANAPOLIS (NBA) - Cut Brook Steppe, guard, and Leroy Combs, forward.

MARYLAND NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ESPIRIT SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net income.

title: BOND PRICES OFF IN ERRATIC DAY
description: Prices of notes and bonds declined and short-term interest rates rose modestly in erratic, nervous trading yesterday as securities dealers prepared for a heavy supply of new Treasury issues in the next two days.

title: REICHHOLD CHEMICALS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Trend to Tigers
description: Mike Cosby, the manager of Gerry Cosby & Company, the sporting- goods store in the lobby of Madison Square Garden, didn't have to refer to his newspaper yesterday morning to find out who won the World Series.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Oct. 16, 1984 GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: ERROR SEEN ON END-ZONE CALL
description: The supervisor of officials for the Big Eight Conference acknowledged today that one of his men erred on a call that allowed Texas to tie Oklahoma as time expired in a major football matchup Saturday.

title: TELEFLEX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
'GREENHOUSE EFFECT' AND METHANE RISE
description: METHANE gas, a contributor to the greenhouse effect that scientists believe may be slowly warming the earth's surface, has been increasing in atmospheric concentrations since 1977, a team of researchers at the University of California at Irvine report.

title: HOWARD BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Inaudible at Times Sq.
description: Standing in a passageway in the

title: FIRST INDIANA FEDERAL SAVING BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Deal for Bakeries
description: The Interstate Bakeries Corporation said it had agreed to sell its Western region operations to G.S.F.C. Inc. The agreement, terms of which were not disclosed, is scheduled to be closed on Dec. 1. The Western region includes four bread bakeries, a cake bakery and a dry products plant. Interstate said the region had sales of $163.4 million in its latest fiscal year.

title: Chairman Who?
description: Fame does not always come fast

title: FIRST PENNSYLVANIA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $10,024,000 from the retirement of convertible subordinated debentures. c-Net loss d-After a tax credit of $3,441,000.

title: COLONIAL BANCORP (WATERBURY, CONN)(O) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
UNITED MISSOURI BANCSHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
PLYMOUTH RUBBER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 1
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,482,000 for the quarter and $2,159,000 for the 9 months. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,534,000 for the quarter and $2,172,000 for the 9 months.

title: Florida County Airport Bonds
description: Lee County of Florida is selling $86 million of airport revenue bonds with a maximum yield of 10.56 percent for 10 1/2 percent bonds, which are tentatively priced at 99 1/2.

title: The Candidates TodayBefore immersing himself in preparations for the debate
description: Sunday night, President Reagan returns to the road today, visiting a career education center in Will County and

title: PHOTO OF DISK AROUND A STAR MAY SHOW NEW SOLAR SYSTEM
description: A STRONOMERS have photographed a disk of material surrounding a young nearby star, providing what may be the first view of a solar system being born. The photograph lends strength to the theory that planets and solar systems like ours developed from such orbiting clouds.

title: DAUPHIN DEPOSIT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BANKS RATES A 'PRETTY GOOD'
description: Carl Banks did not have a restful sleep Sunday night.

title: OPERA: 'SUSANIN' BY GLINKA
description: EVE QUELER, our most dedicated collector and exhibitor of operatic curios, held an especially fascinating specimen up to the light Sunday night at Carnegie Hall. This time we were invited to inspect the facets of Mikhail Glinka's ''Ivan Susanin,'' and that in itself was something of a surprise since the work that had been announced was the same Mikhail Glinka's ''Life for the Czar.'' Actually, the two works are one and the same - and then again, they are not.

title: PLOWING THE FERTILITY BACK INTO THE TOPSOIL, WITHOUT A PLOW
description: To the Editor:

title: UNIBANCORP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $2,081,000 for the quarter and 9 months. The latest quarter also includes an extraordinary gain of $650,000 from the sale of Unibanctrust Co.'s travel agency Oct. 1. This gain was offset by a special $1.67 million provision for loan losses and by an $821,000 writedown of certain other nonperforming assets acquired through foreclosure in prior years' carrying values.

title: GREEN CHARGES STEIN RECEIVED CONTRIBUTIONS OF DEVELOPERS
description: Representative Bill Green said yesterday that his opponent for Congress, Borough President Andrew J. Stein of Manhattan, had accepted more than $400,000 in contributions from realestate developers who had benefited from Mr. Stein's votes on the Board of Estimate.

title: A NEW VITALITY MARKS OPENINGS IN LONDON
description: British fashion is on a roll. Modest increases in exports over last year - about 10 percent - and in the number of retailers attending the 30 major shows and hundreds of smaller presentations during the spring and summer fashion week here are tangible signs of the rehabilitation of London as a source of international style.

title: CRINKLEY OUT AS BEAUMONT DIRECTOR
description: Richmond Crinkley, whose leadership of the Vivian Beaumont Theater has encompassed a long period of bitter controversy over the direction of the company and the fact that the theater has remained largely dark in recent years, has resigned as executive director, effective immediately.

title: TOXIC STUDY BLOCKED, FLORIO SAYS
description: Representative James Florio, citing a General Accounting Office report, charged today that the Reagan Administration has blocked Federal efforts to collect data on health hazards to humans posed by toxic waste.

title: U.S. DENIES ACCORD
description: Israeli officials said today that the Reagan Administration had offered to defer $500 million in debt payments until March, and that Prime Minister Shimon Peres had accepted the offer. American officials immediately responded that no such agreement had been reached.

title: HALLWOOD GROU reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Including tax credits of $397,000 for the quarter and $709,000 for the 8 months. c-Including tax credits of $1,191,000 for the quarter and $1,412,000 for the 8 months. Hallwood Group was formed on April 30, 1984 by the merger of Atlantic Metropolitan Corp. and Umet Properties Corp. The merger was treated as a purchase of Atlantic by Umet. Results for the latest periods reflect the combined results of Umet and Atlantic. Year-ago results are for Umet Corp. only. The company said it would report results on the basis of a fiscal year ending July 31. Share earnings were not reported.

title: RESEARCH CENTERS A VOTE AWAY IN JERSEY
description: To the Editor:

title: Candidates Ruled Off Ballot
description: Socialist Workers Party Presidential candidate Mel Mason and running mate Matilde Zimmerman were ruled off the ballot today by the state Court of Appeals. The court unanimously upheld a state Board of Elections' decision citing the candidates' failure to include on their nominating petitions a listing of persons who would cast electoral votes on their behalf.

title: JERSEY FAMILIES FEAR EFFECT OF RADIATION IN HOMES
description: For about 80 residents of three Essex County communities, the discovery of radium-contaminated soil in and around their homes more than a year ago has been a nightmare.

title: GUARDSMAN CHEMICALS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Space Shuttle Condition Is Reported Excellent
description: Except for one slightly damaged part, Challenger returned to earth in better shape than any previous shuttle, space agency officials said today.

title: BANCTEXAS GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss c-Preferred dividend requirements exceeded net income.

title: NCR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a nonrecurring gain of $30,600,000, or 25 cents a share, from 1984 tax legislation.

title: PENRIL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
FEDERAL NATIONAL MORTGAGE ASSN (FNMA)(N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income.

title: POPE AUTHORIZES LIMITED USE OF LATIN MASS BANNED IN '63
description: The Vatican announced today that Pope John Paul II would allow limited use of the Latin- only Tridentine Mass, which was banned worldwide two decades ago.

title: REAGAN SAYS NO MORE HARD LINE ON RUSSIA
description: President Reagan was quoted today as saying that it was ''realism'' for him to denounce Soviet behavior in sharp terms at the outset of his Presidency, but that he would not return to a hard line with Moscow if re-elected.

title: Dow Chemical
description: The Dow Chemical Company said it would build two specialty- chemical manufacturing plants at an estimated cost of more than $25 million. It also said it would phase out operations at its brine manufacturing plant in Midland by the end of 1986.

title: CONOVER TO ACT ON BANK UNITS
description: C. Todd Conover, the Comptroller of the Currency, said today that, because the 98th Congress had failed to act on the controversy over ''non-bank banks,'' he would begin acting on applications for limited-service, interstate banking offices within the next few weeks.

title: GTI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net losses.

title: Clashes in India Leave 4 People Dead
description: At least 4 people were killed and 18 others injured today in religious clashes in India's northern Uttar Pradesh state and in separatist violence in northeastern Tripura state, the Press Trust of India reported.

title: GTE Preferred Offering Grows
description: The GTE Corporation's offering of convertible adjustable preferred stock at a price of $50 a share was increased to 1.3 million shares, from a million shares. Underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company offered the stock at $50 a share with an initial dividend rate of 8.85 percent.

title: Bomb Threat Evacuates New York Reagan Office By United Press International
description: The police evacuated about 100 workers at President Reagan's Manhattan campaign headquarters yesterday after they found signs attached to the building's front door reading, ''We Will Be Bombing in Five Minutes.''

title: Judge Closes Bathhouses
description: Judge William E. Mullins of the Superior Court today ordered nine bathhouses catering to homosexuals closed temporarily, calling them a ''health menace'' that could promote the spread of acquired immune difficiency syndrome, or AIDS.

title: THEATER: 'CHIP SHOT,' A COMEDY
description: ''CHIP SHOT,'' which opens the season at the Pan Asian Repertory Theater, promises to be a state-of- the-art computer comedy. Instead, it is a contrived compilation of news reports and gossip about corporate piracy and the computer world, with the author somehow managing to take a cheap shot at, of all people, Shakespeare.

title: BANKEAST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SMITH'S LESSON IN PATIENCE
description: HICKSVILLE, L.I.

title: New Blitz Report
description: The Chicago Blitz, one of several stumbling franchises in the United States Football League, were reported several weeks ago to be looking at Honolulu for at least a temporary home. Then, last week, interests in Charlotte, N.C., were reported on the verge of making an offer to the owner, Eddie Einhorn , in hopes of buying the team and moving it there.

title: BANKERS TRUST CUTS PRIMES RATE
description: The Bankers Trust Company reduced its prime lending rate yesterday to 12 1/4 percent from 12 3/4 percent. No other major banks followed the move but some economists predicted that they would soon.

title: SOVIET MORE ACTIVE IN MIDEAST
description: President Hafez el-Assad of Syria, a close Soviet ally, arrived here today for talks. The visit appeared to be the latest of a series of Soviet diplomatic overtures in the Middle East.

title: FRANCE ACCUSES SOVIET ON AFGHAN REPORTING
description: A French official said today that the Soviet Union appeared to be trying to intimidate journalists who report from inside Afghanistan through the arrest and probable trial of a reporter for the French state television network.

title: 5 BIG MILITARY BUILDERS PAID NO TAXES FOR 3 YEARS
description: Five of the nation's top dozen military contractors earned profits in the years 1981, 1982 and 1983 but paid no Federal income taxes, a private tax research group has asserted on the basis of the companies' public reports.

title: TEMPLE-INLAND INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-The company said its shares were distributed on Jan. 26, 1984. Hence, year-ago share earnings are not meaningful and were not reported.

title: SOUTHWESTERN BELL TELEPHONE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Comparable year-ago results are not available because Southwestern Bell was part of American Telephone & Telegraph Co until Jan. 1, 1984.

title: NORTHEASTERN BANCORP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
RANGAIRE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $960,000 from the termination of a pension plan.

title: PHYLLIS GEORGE IS GIVEN A TRYOUT BY CBS NEWS
description: CBS News will give Phyllis George, the CBS sportscaster and former Miss America, a two-week tryout as co-anchor of ''The CBS Morning News,'' beginning on Monday, CBS news officials said yesterday.

title: DESIGNCRAFT INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $205,000 for the quarter and $361,000 for the 6 months. Share earnings have been adjusted for a 10 percent stock dividend in September 1984.

title: Addendum
description: * Taylor & Silverman Communications, public relations, has split into Silverman, Warren/Kremer at 2 Park Avenue and Alan Taylor Communications at 322 Eighth Avenue.

title: PRISONER OF HAITI
description: To the Editor:

title: MAN WITHOUT A CANDIDATE
description: DAVID H. KOCH has the faded blue eyes and dark blond hair of his native Kansas. Even in a suit and a sleek Manhattan office, he looks the big, sturdy farm kid he never was. Instead, he is heir to an oil fortune. He remembers the 1980 Presidential campaign with a certain horror.

title: OCG TECHNOLOGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SEAGATE TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
KAYDON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Year-ago share earnings are unavailable because the company was spun off from Bairnco Inc. in April 1984.

title: GOLD WORK BY ASANTE GLEAMS IN TRIBAL SHOW The tobacco pipes are a textbook of extravagant design: one is shaped like a tortoise, another like a leopard. There are pipes shaped like frogs, baboons, a door lock, a scorpion, a human head. Beginning today, the pipes - along with hundreds of other objects from Asante, an African tribal kingdom now part of Ghana - can be seen at the Museum of Natural History through March 17.
description: The exhibition includes examples of nearly every material object used by the Asante people, ranging from a pea-size gold weight to a mud-and- thatch house erected in the museum's Gallery 3 on the third floor. The exhibition is called ''Asante: Kingdom of Gold'' because about one quarter of its 800 objects are made of the precious metal, found in abundance in central Ghana.

title: PPG INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SIERRACIN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $634,073.

title: DANCE: ERICK HAWKINS AND 'GOD'S ANGRY MAN'
description: ERICK HAWKINS has drawn upon American themes throughout his choreographic career. But whereas in recent years he has let his concern for the turbulence of American history and the grandeur of American geography give a poetic coloration to his essentially abstract choreography, some of his earlier works dealt with specific figures from the American past.

title: TIME POSTS 51.8% GAIN IN PERIOD
description: Time Inc. reported yesterday that net income for the third quarter climbed 51.8 percent, to $46 million, or 72 cents a share, from $30.3 million, or 47 cents a share, a year earlier.

title: RYLAND GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
KOCH MOVES TO LIMIT BREAKS FOR NEW MIDTOWN HOUSING
description: In the latest move to amend a tax incentive program for developers that critics say has cost the city $100 million, Mayor Koch proposed yesterday that tax exemptions for residential construction in much of Manhattan be eliminated.

title: CIPHER DATA PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Jacobs in Filing On Murphy Stake
description: The C.O.M.B. Company, a Minneapolis marketing company tied to Irwin L. Jacobs, the investor, told the Securities and Exchange Commission that it may seek control of the G. C. Murphy Company. C.O.M.B., which holds 376,200 shares, or 9.1 percent, of Murphy's shares outstanding, said it also might buy additional shares or consider making a proposal for a merger or business combination.

title: ARGENTINE EXILES FLOCKING HOME, BUT MANY FIND TIMES ARE HARD
description: The university rector eluded the police by crossing the border into Brazil in the back of a tourist bus. A woman barely had time to change from her nightgown before she had to rush to the airport to board an international flight.

title: Bat Manufacturer Likes Statistics
description: For the last four years, Worth Sports Company of Tullahoma, Tenn., has been striving to cut into the business of two older rivals - Hillerich & Bradsby and Rawlings Sporting Goods - in selling bats to major league baseball players.

title: HORIZON BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
U.S. BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
INTERTHERM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Child's Testimony Blocked by Judge
description: A Superior Court judge ruled today that a 3-year-old girl is not mature enough to testify against her 56-year- old grandfather, who is accused of sexually molesting her.

title: People

SOME FLAWS IN THE PRESIDENTIAL RIVALS' DRUG PLANS
description: Both President Reagan and Walter F. Mondale have disclosed their official strategies on the issue of drug law enforcement, and both are relying on programs with demonstrated problems. Mr. Mondale, who made his plan public two weeks ago, said he would turn over substantial responsibility for drug enforcement to the military. But Democrats in Congress have repeatedly attacked that proposal in recent months, and the General Accounting Office, a Congressional research and investigative arm, concluded that the military could provide only limited assistance.

description: Talks intended to settle Britain's seven-month- old coal strike collapsed tonight. The miners' union leader, Arthur Scargill, said there was no hope for an end to the dispute soon.

title: The Right Tone for Bishops All Americans should be grateful for the wholesome statement last weekend by the National Conference of Catholic Bishops, reaffirming its desire to address moral and political issues in a nonpartisan and reasoned manner.
description: ''We are not a one-issue Church,'' said Bishop James W. Malone, the conference president, explaining that Catholic leaders care no less about nuclear war and peace than they do about abortion. He also cited the bishops' concern for human rights and human needs, especially the needs of the poor.

description: The trial of the Securities and Exchange Commission's civil case against Paul Thayer, former Deputy Secretary of Defense, and eight others has been indefinitely postponed. The trial had been scheduled to begin in January.

description: The State Department today said that ''insensitive and inhuman treatment'' was responsible for the death of Valery Marchenko, a Ukrainian dissident, who died in a Leningrad prison hospital on Oct. 7 at the age of 37.

description: Walter F. Mondale has decided not to attend the Alfred E. Smith dinner Thursday night at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel in New York City in order to prepare for Sunday's Presidential debate.

description: As retailers tell it, this Christmas season will be the first one in years that has gotten off the roller coaster. The economy, after enduring a deep slump and then booming in recovery, is settling into something approaching normality.

Frere, former chairman of William Heinemann Ltd. and a major figure in British publishing from 1945 to his retirement in 1961, died Oct. 3 in a hospital near his home in Kent, England, of complications following surgery for a broken hip he suffered in a fall. He was 91 years old.

description: As eligible major league players began filing for free agency yesterday, the Yankees made Oscar Gamble a free agent by choosing not to exercise the option year in his contract.

No Headline
description: TUESDAY, OCTOBER 16, 1984 International The Salvadoran combatants agreed to form a joint commission to seek an end to the five-year civil war. The agreement was reached at a historic four-and-a-half-hour meeting led by President Jose Napoleon Duarte and insurgent leaders in La Palma, Salvador. The commission is to meet at an undisclosed site in late November to study ways to ''humanize'' the conflict. A joint communique stopped short of calling for a formal cease- fire, but that the meeting occurred at all was a major acheivement for both sides. (Page A1, Column 6.) Opposing U.S. and Israeli statements were made on a deferral of debt payments. Israeli officials said the Reagan Administration had offered to defer $500 million in debt payments until March and that Prime Minister Shimon Peres had accepted the offer. American officials including Secretary of State George P. Shultz responded that no such agreement had been reached. (A1:2.)

title: Chad Factions to Meet In Congo on Saturday
description: Chad's warring factions will hold preparatory talks aimed at ending their 20-year-old civil war next Saturday in Brazzaville, Congo's Foreign Minister, Antoine Ndinga-Oba, said today. His announcement, on the state radio, gave no details of who would attend the meeting.

I.R.S. INTEREST CHARGE
description: -The annual interest rate taxpayers must pay on underpayments will increase to 13 percent on Jan. 1, the Internal Revenue Service said today. The rate had been 11 percent, but it was raised after a review of interest rates the IRS must conduct twice a year. Based on the review, the IRS said it was also raising to 13 percent the amount it would pay to individuals and corportions who overpay their taxes and do not receive prompt refunds from the Government.

title: LTV in Accord To Sell Ohio Plant
description: The LTV Corporation said it had agreed to sell its flat-rolled stainless steel finishing plant in Massillon, Ohio, to CDH Metals Inc. The sale includes the assets of the stainless cold-rolling and finishing operation at Massillon, as well as the Enduro product name, officials said. Terms were not disclosed.

title: A SCIENCE QUIZ THAT'S FUN, ON 'NOVA'
description: ''NOVA'' begins its 12th season tonight with something different: a science quiz. It is not intimidating; it is fun, and you need not know very much about science to take it. It is called ''The National Science Test,'' and it will be seen on Channel 13 at 8 o'clock.

title: ADOPTION TALE REVIVED: YOUTH SUICIDE EXPLORED
description: SAY this much for the Nelia Gardner White story: it's got legs. It was first dramatized for the 1946 film ''Sentimental Journey,'' in which Maureen O'Hara played the dying actress who adopts a child to give her husband, John Payne, a companion after she is gone. Then, in a 1958 remake called ''The Gift of Love,'' Lauren Bacall did the same for Robert Stack, except that Miss Bacall, who even then would never say die, returned to earth as some sort of guiding spirit for the family.

title: G.O.P. Leader Considers Future Debates' Format
description: Frank Fahrenkopf, chairman of the Republican National Committee, said today that he might propose different ground rules for future Presidential debates to prevent an incumbent from being put at a disadvantage.

title: Lawsuit Settlement Attracts Attention
description: The payment of at least $45 million in settlement of a suit brought by the Chase Manhattan Bank against Arthur Andersen & Company is believed to be one of the largest such payments ever by an accounting firm.

title: Slater Sidelined
description: Jackie Slater , the Los Angeles Rams' all-pro right tackle, was lost for the season yesterday when he underwent surgery to repair ligament and cartilage damage in his right knee, the team announced. Slater, in his ninth National Football League season, sustained the injury in the third quarter of Sunday's game in New Orleans.

title: SALES FALL

title: Broncos Down Packers In a Snowstorm, 17-14 DENVER, Oct. 15 (AP) - Steve Foley and Louis Wright, Broncos defensive backs, each returned a fumble for a touchdown in the opening minute tonight and Denver held on for a 17-14 victory over the Green Bay Packers. The game was played in a driving storm that left the field ankle- deep in snow.
description: The Broncos, extending their winning streak to five games, raised their record to 6-1 and kept pace with the Los Angeles Raiders in the American Conference West. Green Bay (1- 6) dropped its sixth straight, its longest slump since 1958.

title: 3 Missing in Ship Collision
description: Three Japanese, including an infant girl, were missing after their small coastal ship collided with a Panamanian-registered freighter and sank near here today, the Maritime Safety Agency said. It said six patrol boats and a plane were looking for the the captain of the 147-ton freighter Saiei Maru, his son's wife and her 16-month- old daughter. There was no report of serious damage to the freighter, the 3,422-ton Aqua Trader.

The climber lost his footing while descending the 5,200-foot Brunnenkopf overlooking Oberammergau on Sunday, a police statement said.

title: IN BROOKLYN, IRISH QUIT THE DEMOCRATS
description: You see them drinking tap beer in Farrell's, at 16th Street and Prospect Park West in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn. Some of them I grew up with over in the tenements of 17th Street. Most of them are cops, firemen, dock workers, sanitation workers and bartenders now. They are the people who still ride the subway. They have been registered Democrats as long as anyone in the neighborhood can remember, but lately there is a lot of grumbling among them that the Democratic Party no longer speaks for them on the issues that affect their jobs and families.

Before an arbitrator could even rule on whether an offer sheet drawn up by the Knicks fell within the salary-cap guidelines, the Blazers held a news conference to announce that Paxson had re-signed with them.

title: Auto 'Safety' Can Be Harmful Following New York's lead, the New Jersey Assembly has approved a bill requiring the use of seat belts. Despite all the talk about the profusion of educational computer games for children, the fact is that parents often find the search for such games to be frustrating and disappointing. Last year's Sesame Street software proved popular with parents and was well received by software reviewers.

description: The Rolm Corporation of Santa Clara, Calif., a telephone equipment maker that is the object of a takeover bid by the International Business Machines Corporation, reported yesterday that earnings in the three months ended Sept. 28 fell 13.3 percent, to $2.6 million, or 11 cents a share, from $3 million, or 12 cents a share, in the same period last year.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: WHEN it comes to blending savory foods with fruits and berries - duck a l'orange, duck with cherries and the like - there is not much neutral ground. There are those who deplore such combinations and those who find them delightful. I am a member in good standing of the latter group.

title: Four Games Forfeited
description: San Francisco State, which reached the quarterfinals of the National Collegiate Athletic Association's Division II basketball tournament last season, yesterday forfeited all four games it won in posteason play because one of its best players was found to have been academically ineligible.

title: CHURCH COUNCIL FACING PROBLEMS
description: The South African Council of Churches, whose General Secretary, Bishop Desmond Tutu, received the Nobel Peace Prize today, was formed in 1968 and has 18 member churches that claim a following of 12 million Christians.

title: FERRARO ASSAILS REAGAN AS CAPTIVE OF 'THE POWERFUL AND THE GREEDY'
description: Geraldine A. Ferraro today denounced President Reagan, before a cheering crowd of Democrats here, as a captive of special interests, ''the rich, the powerful and the greedy.''

title: FIVE SCHOOLS WHERE INNOVATION IS ON THE MENU
description: CATERING to the vehement food likes and dislikes of children and teen-agers is hard enough in a family. Multiplied several hundredfold, the task seems insurmountable. Making institutional food taste good is admittedly difficult. The task is almost impossible when the institution is a school where money is limited; the time for eating is short - sometimes 20 minutes; the lunchrooms are often dreary, and educators treat the lunch hour as the least important part of the day.

title: AMERITECH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Comparative year-ago results are not available because the company was a unit of American Telephone & Telegraph.

title: FOR HAULING LITTER, SMALL IS BEAUTIFUL
description: The morning rush hour had barely begun yesterday when Joe Matras pulled up to the curb at Seventh Avenue and 34th Street in a small white pickup truck equipped with flashing lights and a rear loading hopper.

title: SOUTH AFRICAN FOE OF APARTHEID WINS THE 1984 NOBEL PEACE PRIZE
description: The bells of the Chapel of the Good Shepherd at General Theological Seminary began ringing at 9:05 yesterday morning. In his room on the third floor, Bishop Desmond Tutu sat with his wife, Leah, and listened to them sound with joy over his Nobel Peace Prize.

title: COSTS OF IMMIGRATION REFORM, MEASURED AND UNKNOWN, DROWNED 1984 BILL
description: The efforts of three successive Administrations to reform the nation's immigration policy collapsed last week on the critical question of cost.
