title: THE POP LIFE
description: LOU REED, who has been New York City's unofficial poet laureate of rock-and-roll since the mid-60's, includes in most of his concert performances a song he wrote and recorded two years ago, ''Average Guy.'' In it, he sings, ''You wouldn't recognize me if you met me face to face . . . I worry about money and taxes and such, I'm really just your average guy, trying to make ends meet.''

title: CANADA'S LUCKY CAR INDUSTRY
description: Canada's car industry is one of the brightest spots in the country's economy - a triumph, as it happens, that is in large part a matter of luck.

title: WORLD BANK IS URGED TO HALT AID TO BRAZIL FOR AMAZON SETTLEMENT
description: Critics asserted yesterday that Brazil's program to settle the Amazon frontier was harming the forests and jeopardizing Indian tribes, and they called on the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development to reassess its financial support of the project.

description: President Reagan, campaigning against Walter F. Mondale, told a group of high school students today that he had inherited a nation that ''over the years had unilaterally disarmed.''

description: A B-52 bomber with seven people aboard crashed tonight in Monument Valley and Navajo Tribal Police said there were at least some survivors, according to the Arizona Department of Public Safety.

LOSER WITH PERFECT RECORD
description: His last conversation with the woman he loved, Mike McCallum recalled yesterday, was about how he would beat Roberto Duran and win the World Boxing Association junior middleweight championship. Not long afterward, Yvonne Ladely died from complications following open-heart surgery, leaving the fighter with their 3-year-old daughter, Michelle, and another bitter memory.

title: OHIO EDISON CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ISLANDERS WIN ON 4 GOALS IN 3D
description: Even in victory tonight, the Islanders could not dispense with the drama of a blossoming rivalry with the Devils. The Islanders won, 6-4, but they needed two fast goals at the start of the third period and an open-net goal in the closing seconds to secure the result, because the Devils scored twice in the final two minutes.

title: WINE TALK
description: -DE-MARSAN, France

title: Sutcliffe Shops Around
description: Rick Sutcliffe is going to do a little shopping - if not for a good contract from the Chicago Cubs, then for a new club in the free-agent draft. ''Chances are reasonable and good that Rick will go through the free-agent process,'' said his agent, Barry Axelrod , noting that Sutcliffe had not yet received an offer from the Cubs, whom he led to a division championship this season.

title: F.B.I. RECOVERS RARE STAMPS STOLEN FROM LIBRARY IN 1977
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation today announced the recovery of 82 postage stamps valued at $500,000 that were stolen in 1977 from the New York Public Library.

AROUND THE WORLD ; Britain to Make Public Conclusions on Bombing
description: Viscount Whitelaw, the Deputy Prime Minister, said today that ''some of the general conclusions'' of an investigation of the bomb attack last Friday on the British Cabinet would be made public. Most such security investigations in Britain remain secret.

title: 2 SALVADOR SIDES APPEAR HOPEFUL, BUT STILL DIVIDED
description: Participants in talks Monday between Salvadoran Government and rebel officials said today that despite the lack of agreement on a cease-fire, they were cautiously optimistic about results of the meeting. They said, however, they were divided on major issues.

title: ADVOCATE OF CHANGE
description: For many among South Africa's black majority, Bishop Desmond Tutu, who was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize today, is a voice full of passion for change in this divided land, a man whose humor turns quickly to a sonorous invocation of ''liberation.'' Diminutive in stature, but not in other ways, sharp-eyed and outspoken, the 53-year-old cleric, that is to say, is a man with a message that is yearned for.

title: On the Record ; Reagan on Missiles
description: On Monday, Walter F. Mondale questioned President Reagan's understanding of nuclear weapons, stating that Mr. Reagan had incorrectly asserted that ''submarine ballistic missiles are recallable'' and that the President seemed unaware that the missiles carry nuclear warheads rather than conventional arms. The Mondale staff said later that Mr. Mondale was referring to a statement made by Mr. Reagan at news conference on May 13, 1982. Following was the exchange at that news conference:

title: INTEREST RATES LITTLE CHANGED
description: Interest rates were little changed yesterday as securities dealers bid at the first of seven auctions of Treasury notes and bonds totaling an estimated $43 billion that are scheduled in a period of only 18 business days.

Northeast-Midwest Tremor
description: Up at the Northeast-Midwest Congressional Coalition office on Capitol Hill, an unusual tremor of political excitement is in the air. The eight-year-old lawmakers' alliance, not known in the past as a riveting attention-getter, has become an issue in a House campaign.

title: INDUSTRIAL OUTPUT FALLS 0.6% ENDING A 22-MONTH CLIMB
description: Industrial production in the United States fell last month for the first time since the recession ended in November 1982, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

title: A SURPRISING DROP IN PETROLEUM PRICES
description: Oil prices, after rising steadily in September, have fallen sharply this month. The decline has surprised many industry analysts, since prices normally rise as autumn progresses. But the analysts believe prices will soon recover when the cold weather comes.

title: GRENADA'S TRIAL OF EX-OFFICIALS OPENS IN UPROAR
description: The trial of 19 people accused of murdering former Prime Minister Maurice Bishop started dramatically today with the defendants refusing to enter pleas and one of them appearing to collapse.

description: The shares outstanding and the per share figures reflect 10 percent stock dividend paid in March 1984.

title: Counsel Is Named for N.L.R.B.
description: The White House today appointed Rosemary M. Collyer to an interim term as general counsel to the National Labor Relations Board, filling a vacancy that had temporarily disrupted the agency's power to enforce Federal labor laws.

title: Greek Socialist Party Ousts A Journalist From Its Ranks
description: The governing Socialist Party expelled a journalist from its ranks this week on charges of breaching party discipline.

title: VALLEY RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
BIG BANKS CUT PRIME TO 12 1/2%
description: The nation's leading banks yesterday lowered their prime lending rate a quarter of a percentage point, to 12 1/2 percent, providing a further indication of the slowing of the economy.

title: A COOL TABLE COOKTOP
description: EVERY so often a piece of kitchen equipment that comes onto the market is remarkable and innovative. The Sanyo solid-state induction cooktop fits into that category. A lightweight and handsomely designed tableside burner, it operates on a principle involving magnetic force that, despite several explanations by experts, remains inscrutable to lay listeners. It is enough to say that the burner, which has a ceramic-glass top, heats with all the power and efficiency of a gas range. Yet, while it is cooking on the highest setting, its surface feels cool to the touch.

title: EXCERPTS FROM PRIMER FOR INSURGENTS
description: Following are excerpts from ''Psychological Operations in Guerrilla Warfare,'' a primer for Nicaraguan rebels prepared by the Central Intelligence Agency. The document was translated from the Spanish by the Congressional Research Service at the request of the House Select Committee on Intelligence.

title: MUSIC: YOUNG UCK KIM AND SERKIN
description: It was almost a shock to see so many empty seats at the Metropolitan Museum Monday night, when Young Uck Kim and Peter Serkin presented the second of five concerts of the complete Mozart sonatas for violin and piano this season.

title: Nets Lose, 113-94
description: Ricky Green scored 21 points tonight in helping the Utah Jazz to a 113-94 exhibition victory over the Nets. New Jersey was paced by Mike O'Koren, with 18 points, and Darryl Dawkins, who had 17 before he was ejected with eight minutes to play.

title: Mine Safety Workers Joining British Strike
description: Supervisors in charge of safety at British coal mines said today that they would join the seven-month-old miners' strike next week.

description: The GTE Corporation reported yesterday that earnings in the three months ended Sept. 30 increased 17.4 percent, despite continuing problems in its Sprint long-distance operations and in its telephone manufacturing and sales operations. Also yesterday, four of the regional telephone companies divested Jan. 1 by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company reported profits that exceeded analysts' expectations because of drastic cost-cutting.

description: 1.*Well-Filled but Compact

title: Kentucky Bonds In Heavy Demand
description: A $217.8 million issue of Kentucky Turnpike Authority revenue bonds met with strong investor demand yesterday, and it quickly attracted orders for far more bonds than were available.

title: FASHION IN LONDON: REBELS WITH CAUSES
description: By the end of the Body Map fashion show on Saturday things were becoming a little unglued. Models wearing tight, stretchy tube skirts and metallic stickers that barely covered their breasts danced down the runway. Male models strode out in skirts.

title: No Headline
description: WEDNESDAY, OCTOBER 17, 1984 International Salvadoran negotiators said that despite the lack of agreement on a cease-fire, they were cautiously optimistic about the results of the meeting Monday between Government and rebel officials. However, they said they were divided on major issues. (Page A1, Column 6.) Nicaraguan leaders rejected strongly opposition suggestions that they follow the example set in El Salvador and agree to talk with anti-Government rebels. (A9:1-3.)

title: ALEXANDER & BALDWIN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BLIZZARD COVERS COLORADO CITIES, BLOCKING ROADS
description: An unusually early autumn storm dumped nearly a foot of snow on central Colorado Monday night and up to three feet of snow near Colorado Springs, paralyzing the state's largest cities and stranding many motorists for several hours.

title: WESTMORELAND DEPUTY REBUTS CBS ASSERTIONS
description: Robert W. Komer, the chief civilian deputy to Gen. William C. Westmoreland in South Vietnam in 1967, yesterday contradicted an assertion by CBS that the general had suppressed a report by his intelligence chief on the size of Vietcong irregular forces.

title: 'PEOPLE VS. DAN WHITE' ON CHANNEL 13
description: ''THE PEOPLE vs. Dan White'' is a docudrama, a re-creation of one of San Francisco's most sensational murder cases. Along with the re-creation are interviews with real people who comment on the case.

title: BINKS MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: HANDIWORK A flowing hand has always been classified by the Chinese as among their fine arts. But appreciation of their calligraphy caught on rather slowly in the West, which, perhaps because it did not understand what the writing said, tended in its pragmatic way to shrug it off. In the mid- 1950's, John M. Crawford Jr., already a collector of books, printing and Chinese jade, porcelains and bronzes, was seized with the exquisite beauty of Chinese calligraphy and art and began to collect that, too.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: MUCH, of course, has been made of the city's terrace and rooftop gardens. There is, too, the somewhat less classy but more hardy greenery that somehow manages to thrust out of sidewalk cracks or that struggles up urgently from subway gratings, searching for sunlight. Recently, David Hellerstein, a Manhattan psychiatrist and writer, has noticed the newest spots in town being conquered, mysteriously, by flora. These are the tops of bus shelters. From his window seat on the First and Second Avenue buses, which he rides to and from work, Dr. Hellerstein has been delighted to spot the bright green shoots of living plants on the roofs of least a half-dozen shelters.

title: NATIONAL STATE BANK (ELIZAETH, NJ)(O) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

Spock Arrested in Protest
description: Dr. Benjamin Spock, the 81-year-old pediatrician and author, was one of five people arrested Monday for placing signs in a prohibited area in front of the White House at a demonstration against President Reagan.

title: Aide Is Ineligible
description: Bruce Campbell , who last week was named an assistant to Jim Walsh , the head football coach at George Washington High School in Manhattan, has not had time to fulfull the city's public school certification requirements, and thus is not eligible to coach. On Friday, Washington is scheduled to play its first game since its football schedule was suspended last month.

title: REAGANOMICS IS TOO PAROCHIAL
description: Why did Ronald Reagan fail to convey a vision of the future in his domestic-policy debate with Walter F. Mondale? One reason may be that the President's main constituencies - the Republican Party, conservatives, the business and financial communities - are themselves divided, particularly about economic policy. Bluntly put, if the President wins a second term, he is going to have to choose between the simplistic and the complex, the parochial and the global.

title: ONE MAN'S FAST TRACK: FROM RACER TO TOP COOK
description: DIFFERENT ingredients seem to go into the making of a European and an American chef these days. Exceptions can be found, but the typical young European chef entered the kitchen as a teen-ager, where his first task was peeling vegetables and scrubbing pots and pans. His family was rarely well endowed with money, but from diaper days onward his meals were sophisticated. They were cooked with uncommon care by a mother or an aunt or a grandmother, and the notion that good food should always be prepared carefully is now a mainstay of his cooking philosophy.

title: SCOTTY'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 29
ECHOES OFF THE MARBLE WALLS
description: The United States Senate, to those who have served in it, is a place of marbled scents and silent sentinels. Or so it was pictured, with an eloquence that is so often lacking in routine debate, in the waning days of the Congress that adjourned last week.

title: Bookish Series
description: Until the San Diego Padres swept the last three games of the National League playoff, book dealers around Chicago were among the happiest of fans as they sold copies of ''Cubs Win! A Celebration of the 1984 Chicago Cubs,'' written by Bob Logan and published by Contemporary Books.

title: C.I.A. PRIMER TELLS NICARAGUAN REBELS HOW TO KILL
description: A Central Intelligence Agency documend that became public this week tells Nicaraguan rebels how to win popular support and gives advice on political assassination, blackmail and mob violence.

title: Topics ; DUCKING DINNER, DODGING FACTS Disabled Credibility To the list of this campaign's misrepresentations, add Vice President Bush's alibi for the Social Security Disability mess. It came in response to an elderly Californian who doubted the Administration's credibility on Social Security because it had tried to cut benefits to hundreds of thousands of the disabled. ''The thing you're talking about,'' Mr. Bush replied to the man's question, ''was imposed by Congress and corrected by this Administration.''
description: Congress did, in 1980, call for periodic reviews of individual cases to eliminate fraud in the $18 billion program of aid to those too disabled to work. But it was the budget cutters in the Reagan Administration who in 1981 sharply expanded and accelerated the review.

title: STAGE: ROYAL SHAKESPEARE'S 'CYRANO'
description: YOU'RE not going to spend the evening staring at Derek Jacobi's nose at the Royal Shakespeare Company's ''Cyrano de Bergerac.'' There's just too much else going on. In his beguiling presentation of Edmond Rostand's classic piece of hokum, the director Terry Hands fills the Gershwin's stage with teeming choruses of Parisian swells, smoky battlefield explosions and all the picture-book moonlight required to send us flying back to a lost romantic age. This is a ''Cyrano'' as outsized as grand opera - and, in Mr. Jacobi, it has its virtuoso soloist, the very exemplar of panache.

title: Armstrong's Trial Set
description: A Colorado state judge has ordered Otis Armstrong, the former Denver Bronco running back, to stand trial Nov. 19 on charges of having illegally obtained the drug Percodan. Armstrong, who pleaded not guilty to all counts in the indictment, maintained that he needed the painkiller because of injuries suffered while he was with the team. But the state charges that he received 1,486 tablets from nine doctors over a six-month period by making each believe that he was Armstrong's only source for the drug.

description: It was ''Westward Ho!'' the strollers on a warm, sunny October morning. The babies were out in force on the Upper West Side, rolling along the sidewalks on nearly every block and converging at 83d Street and Riverside Drive.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an article about the Texas-Oklahoma football game in some copies of SportsMonday this week misidentified the supervisor of officials for the Big Eight Conference. He is Bruce Finlayson.

title: Upjohn Net Down 27.6% in Quarter
description: The Upjohn Company, hurt by weaker sales of one of its key pharmaceuticals, yesterday reported a 27.6 decline in third-quarter earnings. At the same time, the American Home Products Corporation reported an 8 percent increase in earnings, Eli Lilly & Company a 7.5 percent gain, and Merck & Company a 10.9 percent advance.

title: GRAINGER, W.W. INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Peace in South Africa
description: By awarding this year's Nobel Peace Prize to Bishop Desmond Tutu, general secretary of the South African Council of Churches, the Norwegian Nobel Committee recognizes ''the courage and heroism shown by black South Africans in their use of peaceful methods in the struggle against apartheid.''

title: AQUINAS HELD ALL ABORTIONS A GRAVE SIN
description: To the Editor:

title: CHINESE OFFICAL DENIES GIFT FOR PANDAS WAS SIDETRACKED
description: China's Minister of Forestry, Yang Zhong, has disagreed with a ministry spokesman over whether foreign donations to save pandas from a bamboo famine had been deposited in a bank instead of being used promptly.

Results for the latest 9 months include an after-tax charge of $3,200,000 for the closing of certain mining operations in Jamaica.

title: MARIETTA IN ALUMINUM DIVESTITURE
description: The Martin Marietta Corporation announced yesterday that it was withdrawing from the aluminum business to concentrate on high-technology areas such as aerospace and defense, where it sees its future growth.

title: Military Orders
description: The Charles Stark Draper Laboratory received a $220.8 million Navy contract to design and develop a guidance system for the Trident missile program, the Defense Department said. In addition, the department said it had given jet fuel contracts of $202.3 million to Chevron USA, $174.9 million to Coastal States Marketing Inc. and $108.9 million to the Koch Refining Company. Other companies receiving jet fuel contracts were Hawaiian Independent Refinery Inc., which got one of $94.5 million; CPI Oil and Refining Inc., $94.2 million, and the Navajo Refining Company, $90.9 million.

title: STUDY OF BELLEVUE PRISONERS IS HELD UNAUTHORIZED
description: An inquiry by the City Department of Investigation has uncovered what it terms unauthorized research and mismanagement in a Bellevue Hospital Center ward for accused criminals.

title: President Is Leaving Staten Island Teleport
description: Teleport Communications, the joint venture company that is building a $200 million satellite communications center on Staten Island, said that Rosario P. Romanelli, its president and chief executive officer for the last two years, had resigned to pursue other business interests. He will remain a senior consultant to the project, Teleport said.

title: ANOTHER VALVANO TAKES HISTURN
description: The perquisites and privileges were surely not the lure for Bobby Valvano when he yearned for the basketball coaching job at St. Francis College of . While other Division I coaches, including his older brother Jim at North Carolina State, are richly remunerated with long-term contracts, hefty recruiting budgets and full staffs, Valvano's resources and rewards are meager: A $26,000, one-year contract, a recruiting budget of $3,000 and no full-time assistants.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ; Key Warner Aide Is Stepping Down
description: Emanuel Gerard, a member of the office of the president and co-chief operating officer at Warner Communications Inc. since October 1976 and the principal advocate of the company's purchase of Atari, said yesterday that he had resigned those posts, effective immediately. Warner said that Mr. Gerard would remain a consultant to the company and had agreed to complete certain ''key assignments.''

title: MUSIC: SONGS OF KERN
description: A ''CENTENARY GALA'' that filled Town Hall on Sunday afternoon celebrated both the 100th anniversary of the birth of the composer Jerome Kern and the reopening of the West 43d Street auditorium, which had been closed for a $1.5 million refurbishing and restoration.

title: NUTRITION PARLEY: NO LACK OF FOOD
description: Twelve thousand dietitians and nutritionists from institutions across the country are here this week to attend the American Dietetic Association convention. But the look is as much market bazaar as nutrition science assembly, with participants wandering among 113 seminars and demonstrations and 691 booths at which they can sample the latest in low-calorie lasagna, high-fiber cereals and artificially sweetened soft drinks.

title: Sounds
description: When the Royal Shakespeare Company opened its 10-week run this month, it became the first group to present straight plays, rather than musicals, in the Gershwin Theater since it opened in 1972.

title: FIVE DISNEYLAND UNIONS VOTE TO ACCEPT WAGE FREEZE PACT
description: Five unions representing workers at Disneyland voted today to accept a contract that will freeze wages for two years, ending the amusement park's longest strike.

title: MONDALE AND AIDES PLAN WIDE ATTACKS ON POLICY
description: Walter F. Mondale and his strategists, convinced that the next Presidential debate Sunday is the most important event of the fall campaign, are planning a broad assault on President Reagan's foreign policy and his personal competence.

title: SUCCESS AT CARDOZO HIGH SCHOOL: FOCUS ON STUDENTS WHO ARCHIEVE
description: Benjamin N. Cardozo High School won a national award yesterday that went to only 7 other schools in the state and 114 in the country.

title: Boesky Dealings In 2 Companies
description: Ivan F. Boesky, a New York investor, and a group of companies he controls reduced their stake in the Scott & Fetzer Company by selling 130,000 shares on the open market. Mr. Boesky remains in control of 227,100 common shares, or 3.4 percent of those outstanding of the manufacturer of home cleaning products and World Book encyclopedias, which is based in Lakewood, Ohio. In May, Scott & Fetzer rejected an offer of $60 a share, or $420 million, from a group led by Mr. Boesky.

description: Georges Thill, one of the most admired French tenors of this century, died yesterday at his home in Draguignan, in southeastern France. He was 86 years old.

description: The chairman of the House Ways and Means Subcommittee on Social Security said Tuesday that Vice President Bush and the Reagan Administration could not claim credit for passage this year of legislation to expand disability rolls.

title: Byelorussian Denies He Said Sakharov Can Leave Soviet
description: The visiting President of Soviet Byelorussia, Ivan Y. Polyakov, denied today that he had told Danish legislators that Andrei D. Sakharov, the banished physicist, was free to emigrate.

description: Walter F. Mondale temporarily stopped taking one of the three drugs he uses to control high blood pressure to learn whether it affected his mood or work performance, his personal physician said yesterday.

description: For the second consecutive week, members of the opposition party disrupted a session of the Bahamian Parliament today, demanding the resignation of Prime Minister Lynden O. Pindling.

description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company reported yesterday that it earned $317 million, or 28 cents a share, in the third quarter, well below analysts' expectations and the forecasts that A.T.& T. itself had made before its breakup in January.

NASA REFUSES TO COMMENT ON ITS FORMER OFFICIAL
description: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration said yesterday that it would have no comment on the announcement that a former highly decorated space official had been linked to Nazi war crimes at a German V-2 rocket factory during World War II.

MONDALE SHIFTING FOCUS FROM DEFICIT
description: Walter F. Mondale has quietly decided on a strategic shift that blunts the issue of the Federal budget deficit and focuses on broader social and foreign policy themes.

title: MAYFLOWER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ETHNIC DEMOCRATS SEEN AS A TOP G.O.P. PRIORITY
description: ''I was a Democrat all the time,'' said John Chaya, a 34- year-old steelworker, as he ate dinner with his wife in a suburban shopping mall. ''I thought the Democrats supported the working man and so forth. But somewhere along the line, maybe with Reagan, I switched. I got tired of the Democrats being bleeding hearts. They were paying the way for everyone, to the point where it was bleeding me.''

description: Officials of the Interior Department and the Justice Department have signed an out-of- court settlement with an attorney for two Appalachian citizens' groups that sued the Interior Department's Office of Surface Mining in 1979 to compel the collection of $150 million in unpaid fines.

title: Soviet Wide-Body Jet In a Forced Landing
description: The newspaper Komsomolskaya Pravda said today that an IL-86 airbus with 279 passengers on board was forced to make an emergency landing because of an structural failure in the wing.

I mean, you wouldn't think people would actually imply that you were doing your baby a great disservice by leaving him with his father, would you? And yet some do just that. title: Jacobs Increases Stake in Murphy
description: Irwin L. Jacobs, the Minneapolis investor, and two associates said they had acquired 427,000 more common shares of the G. C. Murphy Company, a retailer based in McKeesport, Pa. These shares, in addition to 376,200 shares they already owned, raised the group's stake in Murphy to more than 20 percent.

title: Topics; Second Opinions; Reprimands Are Cheap
description: Last April George Hansen, a seven- term Representative from Idaho, was convicted of failing to report $334,000 in loans and other transactions - and was subsequently reprimanded by the House. This fall, many of the same House Republicans who voted for the reprimand see nothing wrong with letting the National Republican Congressional Committee allot $42,000 for Mr. Hansen's re-election campaign.

title: SIX PARIS SHOPS: STYLISH THINGS FOR THE HOME
description: SUNBEAM, Rival, General Electric, Mitsubishi, Electrolux and Juice-O-Mat are hardly the brand names that one would expect to find sitting on a shelf in a Paris shop. But there they are, emblazoned on an impressive array of vintage waffle irons and fans, vacuum cleaners, ice crushers, blenders and toasters from the 40's and 50's at Trophee, a St.-Germain gallery and shop. title: Another Top Executive To Retire at St. Regis
description: The St. Regis Corporation, which is merging with the Champion International Corporation to form the nation's largest paper producer, said that Malcolm T. Hopkins, its vice chairman and chief financial officer, would retire at the end of this month.

title: Soviet Buys More Wheat
description: The Soviet Union bought an additional 121,440 metric tons of United States wheat - about 4.45 million bushels - for delivery in the coming year, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: ADVERTISERS DISCOVER A TRULY CAPTIVE AUDIENCE

title: STARTS OF HOUSING JUMPS 8.9%
description: Construction of new homes, rebounding from two consecutive monthly declines, rose 8.9 percent in September, the Government reported today.

title: Leveille Wins a Battle
description: Lloyd's of London has agreed that the cerebral hemorrhage that ended Normand Leveille 's career with the Boston Bruins two years ago was work-related, and as a result the 21- year-old Leveille will receive $125,000 in insurance benefits, according to his lawyer, Neil Abbott . Leveille was stricken between periods of a game in October 1982, and the Bruins and various insurance companies maintained afterward that the stroke was not related to his work and not covered by his contract or by worker's compensation, disability and other policies maintained by the Bruins, the National Hockey League and the N.H.L. Players Association.

title: 'GUARDIAN,' A THRILLER ON CRIME
description: Most successful Hollywood screenwriters have at least one script buried in their trunk that they regard as their neg lected masterpiece. For Richard Levinson and William Link - creators of ''Columbo'' and writers of more than a dozen acclaimed television movies - that script was ''The Guardian,'' a suspense thriller about urban crime and the lengths people will go to control it.

Chernenko's remarks in an interview Tuesday on the possibiity of improved Soviet-American relations. But it rejected the Soviet leader's contention that the Administration was to blame for the lack of progress in arms control.

title: CUBS' FREY VOTED TOP N.L. MANAGER
description: Jim Frey of the Chicago Cubs, who took over a team that finished 20 games under .500 in 1983 and guided it to the National League's Eastern Division title this year, was named the league's manager of the year yesterday by the Baseball Writers Association of America.

description: It started with a simple clerical mistake at Mosher, Pooley, Sullivan & Henderson, one of the most successful firms in Silicon Valley's fast-growing legal community.

title: Jets Are Believers In Clutch Victories
description: The Jets are being outpassed, outpunted and generally outproduced. They start slowly, with indifferent opening quarters. Their defense ranks 24th among the National Football League's 28 teams. Their last three victories have been gained by a total of 7 points. The clubs they have beaten this season have a combined record of 8-27.

title: AGENCY HEAD, NOT REAGAN, TO ATTEND GRENADA CEREMONIES
description: The head of the Agency for International Development, and not President Reagan, will represent the United States at celebrations in Grenada marking the first anniversary of the American invasion last October, State Department officials said today.

title: LOUISIANA PACIFIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including a gain of $19 million on the sale of nearly 2 million shares of National Gypsum in January.

title: 3 SCIENTISTS NAMES AS THE 1984 NOBEL LAUREATES IN CHEMISTRY AND PHYSICS
description: As Bruce Merrifield stepped out of the elevator and walked toward his office at Rockefeller University yesterday morning, slightly late for work, a laboratory helper broke the news to him that he had won the Nobel Prize in Chemistry. At first, Dr. Merrifield said, he suspected it was a joke, but as others joined the chorus he soon realized it was not.

title: CHURCH-STATE ISSUE MAY HURT REAGAN'S EFFORT TO ATTRACT JEWS
description: President Reagan is making a major attempt to lure Jews from their traditional Democratic base in the Nov. 6 election. But his efforts are being at least partly offset by Jewish concern over the role of the Protestant right wing in his campaign.

title: Philadelphia Wins Time To Cut Back on Inmates
description: Robert Nix Jr., Chief Justice of the Pennsylvania Supreme Court, today granted Philadelphia's request for more time to reduce the inmate population at its three prisons.

title: WAR IN GULF: IRAQI BUILDUP VS. IRANIAN MENACE
description: Western intelligence and military analysts reviewing the positions of Iran and Iraq say new figures issued this week show that Iraq's heavy weapons have increased substantially over the last year. Iraqi fortifications have also improved, they said, making a successful Iranian offensive unlikely.

title: Blacks Boycott Helms's Talk On His Visit to Their Campus
description: About 200 students at Livingstone College locked arms in protest and boycotted a speech by Senator Jesse Helms today when the conservative Republican made his first visit to a predominantly black college.

title: IN THAI WAR ON OPIUM, POPPIES YIELD TO POTATOES
description: In this tribal hamlet high in Thailand's northern hills, the farmers have just finished planting a new poppy crop. Acre after acre of freshly turned earth nurtures December's opium harvest.

title: DECORATORS FOR THE SMALLER PROJECT
description: WHEN many people think of hiring a decorator, they envision a major project in which their entire home will be redesigned, often at substantial cost. But there are those with more modest decorating projects - perhaps just the refreshment of a single room, advice on new slipcover fabrics or a change of an apartment's color scheme - who want to spend less money and time.

title: Party at the C.I.A.
description: It is not easy to get invited to visit

title: RCA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $18,900,000, a gain of $75,700,000 from the cumulative effect of a change in an accounting principle, an after-tax provision of $94,500,000, or $1.15 a share, related to the restructuring and phase-down of videodisc operations, and a nonrecurring gain of $8,700,000 from the redemption of stock received in connection with the sale of Banquet Foods Corp. in 1980. c-Includes income from discontinued operations of $22,100,000, ir 27 cents a share, for the quarter and $59,500,000 for the 9 months.

title: ENDOWMENT CHIEF LISTS PRIORITIES
description: Frank Hodsoll, the chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts, said yesterday that ''in the foreseeable future'' his agency would consider among its highest priorities the support of arts education programs, of local support groups for the arts and of assessing whether economic pressures are forcing arts groups to lessen the quality of their productions.

title: REPORT WARNS OF DECLINE IN HIGHER EDUCATION
description: A panel of scholars has sharply criticized the quality of undergraduate education in the United States, saying that half the students who set out to earn a college degree never do and that for 12 years test scores have been declining on examinations taken by college seniors seeking to enter graduate schools.

title: MUSIC: BOWERY ENSEMBLE
description: MAURICIO KAGEL, an Argentine composer who moved to Cologne, West Germany, in 1957 and has long been identified with the avant-garde musical scene there, was the chief composer represented in the Bowery Ensemble concert at Cooper Union on Tuesday night. His multimovement work entitled ''1898'' filled the second portion of the program. The earlier part was given over to Chris Newman's ''Symphony'' and ''Sad Secrets'' (a song cycle) and Elliott Sharp's ''XV,'' a duet for flute and snare drum played (electronically) by one person.

title: A REPRESENTATIVE'S DUTY TO CONSTITUENTS
description: A major question being debated in the Presidential campaign is whether an elected representative's first obligation is to his conscience or to his constituents - for example, on the issue of abortion. A classic statement on a representative's obligations, excerpted below, was made by Edmund Burke on Nov. 3, 1774, to the electors of Bristol, England, on his election to the House of Commons from that city.

title: U.S. Military Delegation Starts Visit to China
description: A United States military training delegation has arrived in China, the first such group to be invited since the two nations began normal relations in 1979, diplomats said today.

title: League Chooses Panel For Sunday's Debate
description: The League of Women Voters chose four journalists and one backup yesterday to question the Presidential candidates in the final campaign debate Sunday night in Kansas City, Mo.

description: Former Presidents Jimmy Carter and Gerald R. Ford will be co-chairmen of a forum on nuclear arms control next April that will include representatives of the Soviet Union. Mr. Carter announced Monday that the four-day symposium at Emory University's Carter Center April 9-13 would also include representatives of European nations and other United States leaders.

title: NBC Wins Decisively In Nielsen TV Ratings
description: NBC-TV, the third-place network for nearly a decade, won a decisive victory in the Nielsen ratings last week on the combined strength of ''The Burning Bed'' and the World Series.

description: A bomb wrecked part of the local headquarters of the Christian Democratic Party today. No one was hurt in the blast.

description: A $20 million research campaign against parasitic illnesses that plague about three billion people worldwide is being started by the John D. and Catherine L. MacArthur Foundation.

description: A landlord with one of the longest records for housing violations in the city was captured yesterday after a high-speed car chase, the authorities said.

U.S.F.L. FILES ANTITRUST SUIT AGAINST N.F.L.
description: The United States Football League brought an antitrust suit yesterday against the National Football League, charging it with monopolizing and conspiring to control ''the business of major league professional football.''

title: BUSH CHALLENGES MONDALE ON DEMAND FOR APOLOGY

title: Firing Up Subway Management Car No. 9000 had become a headache for New York's subway maintenance crews: they'd no sooner fix one of its electrical problems than it was back with a new one. Nobody seemed able to diagnose the basic trouble. One day last week, after again being judged fit for service and released, car No. 9000 raised its ante. At evening rush hour, its switch box ignited. The smoke and flames drove 2,000 passengers from the train and tied up subway service for hours.
description: Transit officials rush to assert that though subway car fires seem to be occurring daily, they've been less frequent this year than last. The 1,500 so far in 1984, however, are still too many. And the most dangerous, the switch-box fires, have increased.

3 SCIENTISTS NAMED AS THE 1984 NOBEL LAUREATES IN CHEMISTRY AND PHYSICS
description: Dr. Carlo Rubbia has been called ''the Alitalia scientist'' because of his constant airplane flights between Cambridge, Mass., where he teaches physics at Harvard, and CERN, the international atomic research center on the outskirts of Geneva, where he conducts the experiments that led to his Nobel Prize. It is a glamorous association with physics that began, somewhat less glamorously, in 1944 when Carlo Rubbia, then 10 years old, was living in Gorizia, Italy. Young Carlo, the oldest son of an electrical engineer, began picking up electrical equipment abandoned by the armies that marched through Italy in World War II. As a result of childhood experiments with that equipment, he developed a knack for electronics that would be essential in his work as a physicist.

title: TRAIN CRASH AT STAMFORD TIES UP LINES

title: HOLIDAY INNS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
COETZEE'S FIRST TITLE DEFENSE SHOT DOWN
description: Another fight has gone down. Gerrie Coetzee's first defense of the World Boxing Association heavyweight title, against unbeaten David Bey, appeared headed for HBO, the pay cable television network, on Dec. 7. HBO was more interested in showing Thomas Hearns defending the World Boxing Council junior middleweight title against undefeated John (the Beast) Mugabi of Uganda. But because Emanuel Steward, Hearns's manager, could or would not name the mysterious backers for that overpriced fight, HBO opted instead for the ''safer'' Coetzee-Bey package from Don King.

Larouche in Accord

The deal is believed to be for two years for more than $300,000 a season plus an option year that would bring the total package, including incentive clauses, to a million dollars. Larouche, 28 years old, has scored 320 goals in his 10-year career.

title: REVIVING THE FOREMOST AUTHORS

title: FERNS BRING THE WOODLAND TO THE CITY
description: FERNS, leafy remnants of the Permian period that date back some 250 million years, once covered much of the earth. Fossil remains, outlined in rock or transformed into coal, indicate that fernlike plants predated the dinosaurs. Yet despite their great antiquity, ferns are very much at home in the modern city garden. They impart woodland magic to shady yards and, nestled in rooftop containers, create a shimmering understory for shrubs, which in turn shelter them from wind and sun.

title: Student Is Held in Shooting
description: An anti-Communist Vietnamese refugee has pleaded not guilty in the killing of his college physics professor, who had received death threats after visiting Hanoi. Minh Van Lam, 20 years old, made his plea Wednesday in the slaying of Prof. Edward Lee Cooperman, 49, shot to death Saturday in his office at California State University here. Mr. Lam, who is being held in lieu of $250,000 bail, reported finding the body. A .25-caliber pistol was at the professor's side, the police said.

title: Team Player
description: As part of the United States gymnastics team that captured the admiration of the American public with its performance in the Olympic Games, Jim Mikus is appearing with teammates on a 10-city tour that includes stops tomorrow night at Byrne Meadowlands Arena and Sunday afternoon at Madison Square Garden.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: WHEN Brian De Palma's ''Body Double'' opens next Friday, Alfred Hitchcock's name will inevitably be mentioned alongside Mr. De Palma's. The new film, which, of course, contains plenty of Mr. De Palma's own material, deliberately invokes elements of Hitchcock's ''Vertigo'' (the hero has a paralyzing ailment, in this case claustrophobia) and ''Rear Window'' (he has a very interesting neighbor and a telescope).

title: La Monte Young Music
description: To celebrate the 49th birthday of the pioneering Minimalist composer La Monte Young, the FM radio station WKCR (89.9) will feature 24 hours of his music beginning tomorrow at midnight. The program will include rarely heard early works for solo saxophone, concept works and, from 7:30 P.M. to midnight Sunday, an uninterrupted performance of Mr. Young's ''Well-Tempered Piano.'' Information: 280-5223.

title: Hinckley, in Published Letter, Likens Himself to Sakharov
description: John W. Hinckley Jr., confined to St. Elizabeths Hospital here after his attempt to assassinate President Reagan in 1981, says he is a political prisoner and compares his confinement to the exile of Soviet dissident Andrei Sakharov.

title: OPERA: 'NEW MOON' OFFERED
description: ANYONE who can resist Sigmund Romberg's ''New Moon'' in the production unveiled by the Light Opera of Manhattan on Wednesday night must be hard-hearted indeed. A Broadway hit of 1928, it gets off to a winning start with five songs that have retained their luster through the years - ''Lover, Come Back to Me,'' ''Wanting You,'' ''One Kiss,'' ''Softly, as in a Morning Sunrise'' and ''Stouthearted Men.'' And the story about an 18th-century aristocrat who fled his native France and became a bonded servant in New Orleans frames the songs decently.

title: Economic Scene ; Reagan's Tax Strategy
description: With the Presidential election just two and a half weeks away, signs are increasing that the United States economy is slowing down faster than most economists expected.

title: OFF BROADWAY PLAYS BY ISSAC BASHEVIS SINGER TO OPEN
description: FOR a man who describes himself as ''less than a beginner in the playwriting business,'' Isaac Bashevis Singer figures that he hasn't done too badly. This weekend, for instance, he has two plays opening Off Broadway. ''A Play for the Devil,'' in Yiddish, will have its premiere tomorrow at the Folksbiene Theater. ''Shlemiel the First,'' which has been translated into English, opens Sunday night at the Jewish Repertory Theater.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST FRIDAY, OCTOBER 19, 1984
description: The Economy

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday POLITICAL SKITS ON 42D ST.

FIRST WISCONSIN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
EXECUTIVES
description: Abercrombie & Fitch , an Oshman's Sporting Goods company, has named Alexander Lange managing director of the newly reopened New York City store in the South Street Seaport district.

title: KIMBERLY-CLARK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including an extraordinary gain of $7.4 million.

title: PRESIDENT ORDERS 2 INVESTIGATIONS ON C.I.A. MANUAL
description: President Reagan ordered two investigations today into whether the Central Intelligence Agency acted improperly in preparing a manual for Nicaraguan rebels that includes advice on kidnapping and killing public officials.

title: HOW TO COMBAT CRIME BEFORE THE FACT
description: To the Editor:

title: JORDAN DAZZLES CROWD AT GARDEN
description: The Knicks, depleted by injuries, played an exhibition game last night but that's not what caught the attention of crowd of 15,239 at Madison Square Garden last night. The fans came to see the Chicago Bulls' rookie Michael Jordan, the star of the 1984 United States Olympic basketball team, and he did not disappoint them.

title: British Reject Fare-Cut Bids
description: The British Government today rejected all applications from British and American airlines for cheap trans-Atlantic winter fares. Pan American World Airways and Trans World Airlines, two big American carriers planning to offer the new fares beginning Nov. 1, expressed shock at the decision.

title: MINNESOTA MINING & MANUFACURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
THE UGLIEST CAMAPIGN
description: In a senatorial campaign debate televised throughout North Carolina on

title: TRANSIT OFFICERS RECEIVING CITY POLICE RADIOS
description: Transit police officers in Queens were issued 40 New York City Police Department radios yesterday as the first step in a long-range plan to improve police radio communication in the subways.

title: ADAMS-MILLIS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including a gain of $1,377,000 from discontinued operations.

title: ARGENTINE-CHILEAN PACT ADVANCES
description: Argentina and Chile signed a Vatican-mediated protocol today declaring their agreement to a treaty resolving their century-old dispute over the Beagle Channel.

title: Debating the Debate
description: As befits the likely major event of the cresting Presidential campaign, the foreign policy debate scheduled Sunday between Walter F. Mondale and President Reagan has spun off a number of satellite events, some of which may try the endurance of even the committed.

title: G.O.P. JOINS DEMOCRATS COURTING HISPANIC VOTERS
description: Mayor Eudocio Garcia of the small city of Bishop, 30 miles south of here, is a rarity in the Rio Grande Valley. He is a Mexican-American who is a Republican.

title: FAULTED FOR HAVING A WOMAN AS GUEST IN OFFICE AT NIGHT
description: New York City's Department of Investigation released a 1983 report yesterday that criticized Benjamin Ward, now the Police Commissioner but then the city's Correction Commissioner, for using his office for ''late night and weekend meetings with a female guest.''

title: SALVADOR ARMY OPENS A SWEEP AGAINST REBELS
description: Salvadoran Army units today opened the first major offensive against leftist guerrilla forces since rebel and Government officials met three days ago to discuss ways of ending the war here.

title: AUCTIONS
description: MICHAEL L. AINSLIE, the new president and chief executive officer of Sotheby's Holdings Inc., has been busy investigating ways to increase services to clients of the American-owned, international art auction house since he assumed command in July of the parent company.

title: SHULTZ SAYS U.S. SOVIET RELATIONS ARE LIKELY TO IMPROVE, BUT SLOWLY
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that ''the way is wide open'' to sustained progress in Soviet-American relations, but he warned against expecting ''immediate and exciting breakthroughs.''

title: THE SOURCES OF INCOME FOR AMERICA'S ELDERLY
description: To the Editor:

title: CONNER HOMES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 2
description: Results are for 53 weeks for the latest year and 52 weeks for the previous year.

title: SEARS, ROEBUCK & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a credit of $60,000,000 in the Allstate Insurance Group income tax provision, reflecting the reduction of deferred income taxes under the Tax Reform Act of 1984.

title: LOCAL UNITS ASK RISE IN PHONE FEE
description: A six- month, $426 million increase in the rates local telephone companies can charge long-distance companies for services was proposed yesterday to the Federal Communications Commission. If approved, the increase would take effect Dec. 1.

title: FIRST MARYLAND BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Argentina Seeks Loans
description: Argentina has asked foreign banks for an additional $5.45 billion and a new schedule for repaying its $45 billion foreign debt, the country's Economics Minister, Bernardo Grinspun, said today.

title: Ralston, Cargill
description: The Ralston Purina Company said it had reached a tentative agreement to sell substantially all of its soybean processing operations to Cargill Inc. Terms were not disclosed.

title: MOVIES: TALKING HEADS IN 'STOP MAKING SENSE'
description: FROM the opening frames of Jonathan Demme's ''Stop Making Sense,'' which opens today at the 57th Street Playhouse, it's apparent that this is a rock concert film that looks and sounds like no other. The sound is extraordinarily clear, thanks to the pioneering use of 24-track digital recording. And the film's visual style is as coolly iconoclastic as Talking Heads itself. Mr. Demme has captured both the look and the spirit of this live performance with a daring and precision that match the group's own.

title: British Spending Up
description: British consumer spending rose five- tenths of 1 percent in the third quarter, seasonally adjusted, the Central Statistical Office said today.

title: STERLING DRUG INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a pre-tax gain net of associated costs of $4,500,000 resulting from the recent sale by Sterling Drug of several proprietary products to Mentholatum Co.

title: MUSIC:CLEVELAND ORCHESTRA PERFORMS SCHOENBERG
description: PUTTING together intelligent and effective orchestral programs is an art that too few conductors today seem to care about. But now and then a concert turns up that reminds us how ne glected that art is.

title: PATRIOT BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The per share figures are fully diluted.

title: U.S. HELP FOR STUDENTS IN GREATEST NEED OF HELP
description: To the Editor:

title: Sikorsky to Geer
description: Geer, DuBois has become the agency for the Sikorsky S-76 helicopter, the corporate chopper built by the Sikorsky Aircraft division of United Technologies. Keiler Advertising of Farmington, Conn., will continue doing the advertising for helicopters for the military and the offshore oil industry.

title: MAYTAG CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
PUBLISHING: A MAUGHAM COLLECTION
description: MANY books and collections by W. Somerset Maugham were published in his lifetime, but Maugham also wrote many newspaper and magazine articles that were never reprinted in books. Next January, Clarkson N. Potter will publish 66 of them in a Maugham collection titled, ''A Traveller in Romance: Uncollected Writings, 1901-1964.''

title: Hong Kong Lawmakers Back Accord on Colony's Future
description: Hong Kong's Legislative Council formally endorsed the Chinese-British draft agreement on the colony's future today.

title: ILLINOIS TOOL WORKS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including a gain of $720,000 related to the disposition of properties, a special credit of $4,405,000 from the reversal of deferred taxes due to changes in tax laws and an increased provision of $3.8 million for undistributed earnongs of internationsl subsidiaries. c-Including a gain of $6,772,000 for the quarter and 9 months related to the partial sale of an operating affiliate, a $4 million provision for the quarter and 9 months related to the disposition and relocation of properties, a gain of $1,675,000 for the 9 months from the sale of a manufacturing plant and $2,290,000 for the 9 months related to the partial sale of an investment affiliate.

title: HIGH VOLTAGE ENGINEERING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $212,000.

ALLTEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
FERRARO ACCUSES REAGAN OF 'BLINDNESS' ON POLICY
description: Representative Geraldine A. Ferraro accused the Reagan Administration today of ''blindness'' in foreign policy and labled President Reagan as ''consistently uniformed and disturbingly detached'' on the need to control nuclear weapons.

title: UNITED STATES HOME CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including provisions totaling $888,000 for certain legal and warranty claims. c-Net income.

title: 2 Papers Drop 'Doonesbury'
description: Two conservative West Virginia newspapers have stopped carrying the comic strip ''Doonesbury.''

title: Thomas Creighton, Architect And Editor, Dies in Honolulu
description: Thomas Hawk Creighton, an architect and a former editor of Progressive Architecture, died Oct. 6 of a heart attack in at the Kaiser Hopital in Honolulu. He was 80 years old and lived in Honolulu.

title: U.S. JUDGE MOVES TO CONTROL PUNITIVE PRISON SEGREGATION
description: A veteran Federal district judge today ordered that Folsom and San Quentin prisons improve conditions in their segregation cells. He appointed a lawyer to monitor compliance with the orders.

title: Santa Fe's Net Up a Bit
description: The Santa Fe Southern Pacific Corporation said today that its third-quarter results were virtually steady. The railroad holding company earned $137.4 million, or 73 cents a share, up slightly from $137.3 million, or 73 cents a share, a year earlier. Sales rose to $1.7 billion from $1.6 billion.

title: Garden Tool Campaign From Burton-Campbell
description: To the confirmed gardener - backyard or rooftop - the spring of 1985 will be remembered as the Time of the Swoe.

title: McNamara Signs
description: To no one's surprise, John McNamara , who had decided not to return as manager of the California Angels next season, was introduced yesterday as the new manager of the Boston Red Sox, succeeding Ralph Houk . McNamara is a good friend of Haywood Sullivan , one of Boston's owners, and the appointment had been expected for more than a week.

title: Louisiana Land
description: The Pioneer Corporation said it had sold to the Louisiana Land and Exploration Company 2,760,000 shares of Louisiana Land for $35 a share, or $96.6 million.

title: PAN AMERICAN BANKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
DEKALB AGRESEARCH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Including a gain of $2.5 million, or 19 cents a share, for the quarter and year from tax law changes. c-Including an extraordinary gain of $2.4 million on the extinguishment of debt.

title: MASSACHUSETTS DEATH PENALTY LAW OVERRULED
description: A divided Massachusetts Supreme Court ruled today that the state's death penalty law is unconstitutional because it unfairly encourages murder defendants to plead guilty to avoid the threat of capital punishment.

title: COMBUSTION ENGINEERING INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Excluding a disc credit of $31.7 million for the quarter and 9 months. Results for the latest 9 months include operations of Jamesbury Corp. and Impell Corp., acquired in April 1984.

title: GIANTS MAY START SHAW IN SECONDARY
description: The sprained right ankle that kept Kenny Hill out of the Giants' game against the Atlanta Falcons last Sunday still bothers him, and he has not practiced this week. Bill Currier practiced again today, but he remains on injured reserve.

title: Holly Sugar Stake
description: Brookehill Equities Inc. and Moran, Moore, Grossman & Derose told the Securities and Exchange Commission that they had a combined total of 142,434, or 12.8 percent, of the shares outstanding of the Holly Sugar Corporation.

title: M Marks Successful First Year
description: M magazine, brother of W, reached its first birthday this month and it looks as if Fairchild Publications has another winner in its second consumer publication.

title: 'DINING ROOM' OF U.S. UPPER CLASS
description: ''THE DINING ROOM'' by A. R. Gurney Jr. is a short play - running about 90 minutes - that employs six actors to fill more than 50 roles in a rambling scenario covering 50 years. It is not ideally suited to the overwhelmingly naturalistic terrain of television. Nevertheless, the version that can be seen tonight at 9 on WNET's ''Great Performances'' series nicely demonstrates why the play, originally produced in 1982 at Playwrights Horizons, enjoyed 18 months of Off Broadway success.

title: Wage Offer Rejected ByUniformedUnions
description: Negotiators for the Uniformed Forces Coalition, which represents 40,000 police, fire and corrections workers, yesterday rejected the latest wage proposal from New York City, 3 percent rises in each of three years.

title: A Job Assumed
description: The statewide political campaign, it seems, has become too

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''This Administration has not advocated or condoned political assassination nor any other attacks on civilians, nor will we.'' - Larry Speakes, the White House spokesman. (A1:4.)

title: U.S.F.L. OWNERS TO STUDY PROBLEMS
description: The owners of the United States Football League open a three-day meeting here Friday, and there is plenty to discuss in addition to the antitrust suit that they filed this week against the National Football League.

title: LAMB, AND BIT OF POLITICS, SERVED AT SMITH DINNER
description: Some 2,000 of the city's most prominent and connected people, minus a few angry Democrats, gathered last night at the Alfred E. Smith Memorial Dinner to dine on rack of lamb and chew over both the words of President Reagan and the absence of any official Democratic reply.

title: U.S. Calls on Papandreou To Help Improve Ties
description: The State Department called on Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou of Greece today to match United States efforts to seek good American-Greek relations.

title: BRITON IS AWARDED NOBEL IN ECONOMICS
description: Sir Richard Stone, a retired 71-year-old Cambridge University professor, today won the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science for his work to develop the systems widely used to measure the performance of national economies.

title: No Headline
description: A key witness who is said to have implicated the military in the assassination of Benigno S. Aquino Jr. was reported today to have retracted his testimony, prompting charges by a civilian board of inquiry that an effort was under way to discredit its findings.

title: MAFIA ROLE SEEN
description: Eight people were shot dead in Palermo today in what the police believe was a settling of scores in a Mafia gang fight.

title: Gerber Recalls Juices After Glass Is Found
description: The Gerber Products Company announced today that it had recalled about 550,000 jars of fruit juices for infants after glass fragments were found in jars in Rhode Island and Vermont.

title: SEACOAST BANKING CORP OF FLA reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
INNOVATIVE MORTGAGES AT JERSEY PROJECT
description: Creative financing has become so pervasive since the era of high interest rates began in the 1970's that innovative packages are now being used to originate even conventional fixed- rated mortgages.

title: Arabian Nights
description: Although the national ratings for ABC's ''Monday Night Football'' are down from last season, interest in National Football League games is apparently holding steady in the Middle East.

title: Party Celebrates Book OnBlackClassicActors
description: A book party and performance tomorrow at the American Shakespeare Theater in Stratford, Conn., will celebrate publication of ''Shakespeare in Sable: A History of Black Shakespearean Actors'' by Errol Hill.

title: MARY CASSATT, IMAGES BY AN AMERICAN IMPRESSIONIST
description: -1926) is an extraordinary saga. Not only did she manage to surmount the handicaps posed in America by her gender and gentle breeding to make a full-time profession of art; she also became the only American to play an active role in the French Impressionist movement (and, by advising prominent friends on their collections, she helped bring it to this country).

title: Preacher Charged In Death of Disciple
description: A preacher whose followers refuse medical care has been indicted on charges that his teachings killed a teen-age disciple with chronic kidney disease.

title: Jerry Lee Lewis Found Not Guilty of Tax Charge
description: A Federal District Court jury today acquitted the rock star Jerry Lee Lewis of charges of evading taxes and the jubilant singer said the verdict made him feel ''the power of God.''

title: Apparent Cholera Outbreak Worries Officials in Houston
description: Houston officials battled an apparent cholera outbreak today, warning people not to eat raw oysters.

title: E.P.A. Seeks a Role In Protection of Parks
description: The Environmental Protection Agency, agreeing with enviromentalists that most states are doing a poor job at protecting national parks and wilderness areas from air pollution, said today that it wants to take the job away from them.

title: 5 More Charged In Prison Incident
description: Five more inmates have been charged with disciplinary infractions at the state prison here in connection with a cafeteria disturbance Monday, a correction spokesman said today.

title: NO OVERT POLITICS FOR REAGAN AT SMITH DINNER
description: President Reagan offered a low-key address to the Alfred E. Smith Memorial Dinner here last night, avoiding overt politicking in favor of a tribute to ''that gentle soul,'' the late Terence Cardinal Cooke.

title: COLUMBIA FEDERAL SAVINGS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: No year-ago share earnings were reported because the company converted to a stock institution on Feb. 9, 1984.

title: AT PARIS READY-TO-WEAR SHOWS, NEW JAPANESE MOOD IS BRIGHTER
description: The spring and summer ready-to-wear shows opened on an offbeat note when, for the first time in anyone's memory, buyers and the press attending the openings here were invited to a reception at Elysee Palace Wednesday night to meet the designers. In today's showings, the Japanese dominated the runways. The reaction to both events was mixed.

title: CARTERET SAVINGS & LOAN ASSOC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss. c-Year-ago share earnings are not available because the company had its initial public offering in September 1983. Results for the latest periods include a gain of $5.9 million for the quarter and year from the sale of four branch offices. Results include gains on the sales of mortgages and securities of $4.6 million for the latest periods and $46.8 million for the year-ago periods.

title: SURVIVORS OF PATERSON FIRE DESCRIBE A NIGHT OF HORROR AND HEROIC RESCUES
description: Three women walked quickly into the makeshift Red Cross shelter in the gymnasium of John F. Kennedy High School here this morning and looked around anxiously at the faces of about 100 people, survivors of a blaze that left 13 dead and more than 50 injured.

title: BUSINESS COMPUTING INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
AMERICAN BROADCASTING COMPANIES INC (ABC) (N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 29
ART:UTAMARO PRINTS SHOW COURTESAN LIFE
description: UTAMARO was one of the bright lights of the ''Golden Age'' of Edo culture. His elegant and gracefully stylized wood block prints of Japanese courtesan life are a record of late 18thcentury Japan that plays on because of their quietly decisive rhythms and clear and accepting tone. As with the prints of his great contemporary Hokusai, Utamaro's economy of means and unexpected points of view have been an inexhaustible notebook for Western artists since the middle of the last century.

title: THE DEFICIT PROBLEM IS EXAGGERATED
description: The Federal budget deficit is a genuine problem, but the problem has been exaggerated by two myths: first, that it will abort the expansion by crowding out private borrowers, and, second, that the Federal debt will impose an intolerable burden on our children.

title: Pistons Drop Turner
description: Eric Turner , a 6-foot-3-inch guard, who helped lead Michiagan to the National Invitation Tournament championship last spring and then decided to skip his senior season, was cut by the Detroit Pistons. He was their second-round draft choice this year.

title: GEORGIA FEDERAL BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Northeastern Air
description: Northeastern International Airways said that it had laid off more than 100 of its 1,500 employees and had stretched out airport fee payments because of a seasonal slowdown in air traffic.

title: MONDALE COMMERCIALS SEIZE SPACE WEAPONS ISSUE
description: In a 30- second commercial shown tonight on ''Cheers,'' ''Hill Street Blues'' and other parts of the prime-time television schedule, the Mondale-Ferraro campaign unveiled one issue by which it hopes to dominate the Presidential debate Sunday night and the rest of this campaign.

title: IRANIAN GROUND ASSAULT BREAKS LULL
description: An eight-month lull in major ground combat between Iran and Iraq ended today as Iranian troops opened a drive against Iraqi positions in the mountainous central border region.

title: POPULAR WORK FOR 40 YEARS
description: The last of Mozart's 21 extant operas, ''La Clemenza di Tito,'' was commissioned for the coronation of Leopold II of Bohemia. It was completed on Sept. 5, 1791, and first performed the following day in Prague.

title: APPLE COMPUTER INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 28
description: b-Including a $4.9 million credit from reversal of deferred taxes.

title: RESTAURANTS
description: -setting new restaurants where the room is decorated in early attic and the service is an afterthought? Happy to mingle with elegantly dressed people so self-confident they sing happy birthday at lunch and take family snapshots at dinner? Willing to take your chances on a $47.50 four-course prix-fixe dinner that offers some expertly honed versions of nouvelle cuisine and classic French food, as well as some that fall far short of the mark?

title: West Germany Puts Off Action on Ex-Nazi
description: A West German prosecutor said today that he was awaiting documentation from the United States before determining whether to take legal action against Arthur Rudolph, a German-born scientist who left the United States earlier this year to avoid prosecution for brutalizing slave labor at a Nazi rocket center in World War II.

title: COX COMMUNICATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
THE CITY;
description: A State Supreme Court jury in the Bronx has awarded more than $2 million to the family of a Long Island man killed in a pothole-related accident, authorities said yesterday.

title: POLICE BELIEVE JERSEY SOCIALITE RAN WEST SIDE CALL-GIRL RING
description: A woman charged with running a $1 million-a-year call-girl operation from an Upper West Side apartment is apparently Sydney Biddle Barrows, a member of a socially prominent New Jersey family, according to the police.

title: 2 Greens Are Ejected From Bonn Parliament
description: Two legislators from the Greens Party were ejected from Parliament today for using insulting and foul language, setting off a shouting match in the normally staid chamber.

title: Governor Blocks Strike on L.I.R.R.
description: Governor Cuomo took legal action last night to prevent a threatened strike by Long Island Rail Road supervisory personel that could have shut down the railroad, which serves 175,000 riders.

title: Republic Air
description: Republic Airlines said it had signed a letter of intent with Simmons Airlines to acquire 9.29 percent of Simmons.

Addendum
description: Ladies' Home Journal increasing its advertising rates 7 percent with the February issue.

title: REAGAN PLEDGES NOT TO OVERRIDE SHOREHAM FOES
description: President Reagan, in a letter to a Long Island Representative, said yesterday that the Administration would not override Suffolk County's objections to the opening of the Shoreham nuclear power plant.

title: FERRARO ATTACKS NEW YORK POST
description: Representative Geraldine A. Ferraro today lashed out at The New York Post publisher, Rupert Murdoch, for an article saying that her parents had been arrested on gambling charges in 1944.

title: WILMINGTON TRUST CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SKATES AND GAMELAN IN MASS AT ST. JOHN'S
description: AT this Sunday afternoon's mass at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, 10 children on roller skates will charge down the aisles during the ''Gloria.'' A Miskito Indian fertility dance will take place on the altar. The tuned gongs of a Balinese-American gamelan, a group of Andean pipers and drummers and a Latin-pop band will face one another across the congregation, sometimes all playing at once. And the congregation is likely to be singing along.

title: Peggy Ann Garner, 53, Dies;Won an Oscar as a Teen-Ager
description: Peggy Ann Garner, a former child actress who won a special Academy Award as a teen-ager for her role as Francie Nolan in ''A Tree Grows in Brooklyn,'' has died at age 53.

title: MICHIGAN NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Communications Help B.& B. Revenues
description: Benton & Bowles, which only in recent years began building up a roster of subsidiaries in communications, will realize 27 percent of its total worldwide revenues from them this year, according to George J. Simko, a senior vice president and group executive.
