title: EASTMAN PHOTO ARCHIVE MAY STAY IN ROCHESTER
description: The trustees of the George Eastman House in Rochester, N.Y., bowing to intense community pressure, yesterday set aside their earlier decision to transfer the museum's large and valuable collection of photographs, films and other material to the Smithsonian Institution in Washington.

title: PRO-LIFE ADVOCATES IN STEP WITH THE DEMOCRATIC PROCESS
description: To the Editor: It was not only the candidates who sadly ''erred'' in the Oct. 7 debate (news story Oct. 9). The questioner on the abortion issue twice fell into a trap in tacitly accepting the exploitation by Mr. Reagan of the spurious claim that the ''unborn child'' is ''protected by the Constitution which guarantees life, liberty, etc.'' and the assumption that the crucial issue regarding abortion is the point at which human life begins.

title: JIM WALTER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Newsprint Rise Seen Delayed By The Associated Press Abitibi-Price Inc., the
description: world's largest newsprint producer, has delayed a planned

title: 2 Ex-Defense Secretaries Assail Mondale's Record
description: Two Republicans who served as Secretary of Defense, Melvin R. Laird and Donald H. Rumsfeld, today attacked the military policies of Walter F. Mondale, the Democratic Presidential nominee.

title: A DEVISER OF COMPLEX ECONOMIC MODELS: JOHN RICHARD NICHOLAS STONE
description: Building models was always a passion for Sir Richard Stone. As a child in London, he would carve detailed, balsa wood miniatures of trains and airplanes. Even today, at the age of 71, Sir Richard recalls that whittling the toys was the greatest joy of his youth, offering deep insight into the world around him. So, it is fitting that, when the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences announced yesterday that it had chosen Sir Richard, a retired Cambridge University professor, as the 1984 winner of the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science, it was for making splendid models.

title: Silver Anniversary For 'The Twilight Zone'
description: Twenty-five years after its premiere, ''The Twilight Zone'' still holds our imagination with its portraits of misfits and dreamers who slip out of everyday existence into ''another dimension.'' While the term karma wasn't yet in vogue when Rod Serling offered his oracular drollery on the show's parapsychological endings, journeying into the twilight zone usually meant getting one's just desserts.

title: HUGHES PLANT EXPECTED TO RESUME PRODUCTION OF 3 MISSILE PROGRAMS
description: Military officers said today that they expected the Pentagon to let Hughes Aircraft resume production of three missile programs shut down this summer because of the company's poor workmanship and quality control.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ; G.M. Acceptance Corp. Sells Notes to Yield 12%
description: Encouraged by the recent decline in interest rates, several corporations tapped the debt markets yesterday.

title: RELEASE OF 1983 REPORT RAISES QUESTIONS ON HIS ACTIONS
description: Behind Benjamin Ward's acknowledgement that, as the city's Correction Commissioner, he permitted after-hours visits by a woman to his office and that he appeared to be drunk at a police union convention last summer, a larger question looms:

title: TRANSWORLD BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CELANESE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
WYOMING GETS 'SONIC BOOM'
description: An earthquake that sounded like ''a sonic boom'' near its center jolted parts of six states today and damaged buildings 200 miles apart in Wyoming and Colorado, forcing their evacuation. No injuries were reported.

title: Fitchburg Gas
description: The Fitchburg Gas and Electric Company said that its board had reduced its quarterly dividend on common stock to 35 cents a share, from 65, as a result of a lack of state regulatory approval for external financing plans and uncertainty of requests for rate increases.

title: ROGERS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

Whom Do These Lawyers Represent? In a recent letter to solicit new members, the New York State Trial Lawyers Association makes something regrettably clear: that it considers its members' pocketbooks more important than the fair and efficient administration of justice.
description: ''The fate of our law practice is being decided by the legislature in Albany,'' the letter reads. It complains of ''the effect of such bills as 'No-Fault' and the limitations on malpractice suits.''

title: TEXTRON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
COMPUTERS AT LINCOLN CENTER
description: Lincoln Center has announced that it will introduce computerized video display information centers at three sites in the center by next March.

title: GTE Sprint Pact
description: The GTE Corporation's GTE Sprint Communications subsidiary said it had concluded an agreement with British Telecom International to provide long-distance, discount telephone service to Britain. GTE Sprint said that the new enterprise would be its first trans-Atlantic service and that it expects to announce agreements soon with other major countries.

title: 5 Pakistanis Killed In Battle With Police
description: The police near Hyderabad tried to stop two busloads of people traveling to the hometown of former Prime Minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto, and 5 people were killed in ensuing gunfire between the police and some of the nearly 100 passengers, the police said today.

title: BURR-BROWN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including a gain of $1 million from the reversal of previously deferred income tax related to its Domestic International Sales Corp.

title: BRIDGE: THE JOY OF TOURNAMENT LIFE FADES FOR SOME TOP PLAYERS
description: Many experts fight for titles for half a century or so, but others disappear from view.

title: THE LAWYER WHO OVERSEES THE MILITARY BUDGET
description: If William Howard Taft 4th had become a race car driver or rock guitarist instead of Deputy Secretary of Defense, people could have said he was just rebelling against the past. But a prominent portrait behind his desk at the Pentagon of the first William Howard Taft, who was also the 27th President of the United States, suggests that rebelliousness has never been a factor in No. 4's personality.

title: Spending, Income Up
description: Americans enjoyed a nine-tenths of 1 percent increase in personal income last month and raised consumer spending by an even stronger 1.4 percent, the Government reported today.

title: KASPAROV IN 14TH GAME: LACKLUSTER PERFORMANCE
description: What was Gary Kasparov up to in the 14th game of the world championship chess match in Moscow on Wednesday?

title: BRADLEY IS CAMPAIGNING ON RIGOROUS SCHEDULE
description: Senator Bill Bradley is the odds-on favorite to win re-election next month, but he is running an expensive and intensive campaign, almost as if he were behind in the polls.

title: U.S. Home Ex-Chief Quits Other Posts
description: Guy R. Odom, chairman of the executive committee of the U.S. Home Corporation, the nation's largest home builder, resigned yesterday in a move that surprised analysts.

title: WASHINGTON POST CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CHINA AND SOVIET RESUME TALKS ON MENDING BREAK
description: China and the Soviet Union returned to the conference table today for a fresh round of discussions aimed at normalizing their strained relations.

title: COLLEGES GO WITH A WINNER
description: That old bomb-thrower, Walter

title: A STATEMENT USED BY CBS IS QUESTIONED AT LIBEL TRIAL
description: Conflict arose yesterday over whether a statement attributed to Gen. William C. Westmoreland in a 1982 ''CBS Reports'' documentary was actually made by Gen. Earle G. Wheeler when he was chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff.

title: 13 KILLED AND 57 INJURED IN HOTEL FIRE IN PATERSON
description: A fire believed to have been set by an arsonist swept through the first floor of a downtown residential hotel here early today, killing 13 people and injuring 57, four of them critically.

title: U.S. Questions Crews of 2 Trains
description: Federal officials today began questioning crews of an Amtrak work train and a Conrail freight train that crashed two miles east of the train station here Wednesday.

title: GILLETTE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Father Kills 6 Children And Himself, Police Say
description: A man with a history of violence shot and killed his six children in their beds and then killed himself, the police said today.

title: DOLLAR ALSO SLUMPS
description: Both the dollar and the British pound were battered in the foreign exchange markets yesterday. The dollar's slump led some to believe that the extraordinary rise in its value against the major foreign currencies has finally ended.

title: 'LITTLE DRUMMER GIRL,' BASED ON LA CARRE NOVEL
description: MOVIE makers refuse to learn that big, intricately plotted suspense novels, stuffed with characters, incidents, exotic locations and twists of plot, don't always adapt to the screen with ease. A perfect case in point is ''The Little Drummer Girl,'' the film adaptation of John le Carre's best-selling novel, adapted by Loring Mandel, directed by George Roy Hill, and starring Diane Keaton.

title: OPERA: MOZART'S 'CLEMENZA DI TITO'
description: IT took the Metropolitan Opera

title: 2 GERMAN STEELMAKERS APPEAR READY TO MERGE
description: Two of West Germany's largest steel companies are set to merge their steelmaking activities in a venture that would form Europe's second-largest privately owned steel company.

title: F.C. Lane, Historian; Authority on Venice
description: Dr. Frederick C. Lane, retired professor of history at the Johns Hopkins University and an authority on Venice and the Venetians, died Sunday at the University of Massachusetts Medical Center in Worcester, Mass., after a short illness. He was 83 years old and lived in Westminster, Mass.

title: Davis Cup Dispute
description: The United States and Sweden are not supposed to begin their Davis Cup final until December, but a dispute over the exact dates has already taken on the back-and-forth character of a tennis match - one that neither side seems able to finish. Yesterday, just two days after the International Tennis Federation had announced a supposedly satisfactory compromise fixing the dates at Dec. 16-18, Thomas Hallberg , the federation's director of men's tennis, said the I.T.F. had agreed to a request by the host Swedish team for a ''flexible'' schedule that would allow the match to be played anytime from Dec. 16 to Dec. 22, with Sweden given until next Wednesday to fix the exact dates. The United States Tennis Fedreration said, in turn, that it would not go along with the change and emphasized that it had already accepted the Dec. 16-18 schedule.

title: GIBRALTAR FINANCIAL CORP OF CALIF reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
HAGLER-BOUT JUDGES SWITCHED
description: Marvelous Marvin Hagler held up his right hand. ''This is 'K','' he said. He held up his left hand, ''O.''

title: Ally & Gargano Wins Datril Assignment
description: Ally & Gargano has just won its first Bristol-Myers assignment and first over-the-counter drug in a decade.

title: U.S.-HANOI TALKS ON AMERASIANS
description: A White House aide met this week with Vietnam's Foreign Minister to discuss details on how to carry out the Administration's offer to accept tens of thousands of Vietnamese immigrants, State Department officials said today.

title: EASTERN GAS & FUEL ASSOCIATION reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Year-ago 9 months results have been restated.

title: Manila Debt Rescheduling MANILA, Oct. 18 (AP) -
description: The Philippines said today that

title: Reagan Keeps Big Lead In Nationwide Poll By The Associated Press
description: A majority of likely voters questioned in an NBC News poll released said Walter F. Mondale won his first debate with President Reagan, but that seemed to have little effect on the Republican's commanding lead.

title: ESTATE CHECKS SAID TO HAVE GONE INTO ZACCARO COMPANY'S ACCOUNT
description: Six checks totaling more than $50,000 that were supposed to go to an estate that John A. Zaccaro was overseeing were deposited instead in the bank account of Mr. Zaccaro's real-estate company, a court-appointed guardian said yesterday.

title: COMPUTER TERMINAL SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income.

title: NEWS SUMMARY;
description: FRIDAY, OCTOBER 19, 1984 International Nigeria cut the price of oil by $2 a barrel to $28, becoming the first member of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to break the official price structure that OPEC set 18 months ago. Reaction was swift in foreign-exchange, stock and credit markets because of a widespread belief that a general oil price break is inevitable. (Page A1, Column 6.) Two inquiries into whether the C.I.A. acted improperly in preparing a manual for Nicaraguan rebels that includes advice on kidnapping and killing public officials were ordered by President Reagan. One of the investigations is to be by the agency's Inspector General and the other by its oversight board. (A1:4.)

title: LIMIT ON DIVIDENDS SET BY MAINE UTILITY
description: The stock of the Maine Public Service Company fell sharply today, after a delayed opening, following the announcement by the company of an austerity program that will mean lower dividends for stockholders.

title: FIRE SAFETY CHIEF SEEKS SPRINKLERS
description: The chairman of the State Fire Safety Commission said today that the New Jersey fire code should be changed to require sprinkler systems in all hotels.

title: Houston Utility's Offering of Notes
description: The Houston Natural Gas Corporation issued $100 million of seven-year notes due Oct. 15, 1991.

title: APOLLO COMPUTER INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including a tax credit of $1,950,000.

title: PANEL CITES U.S. COMPLIANCE WITH LAW LIMITING WIRETAPS
description: The Senate Intelligence Committee said in a report today that a 1978 law regulating the electronic collection of intelligence in the United States has protected constitutional rights while enhancing the ability of the Government to collect such information.

title: CHICAGO & NORTH WESTERN TRANSPORTATION COMPANY reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results for the latest third quarter reflect the company's capitalization of acquisition costs which were expensed in prior periods, the effect of which was to increase net income of $2,091,000, or 13 cents a share. Year-ago results have been restated to reflect accounting changes during the fourth quarter of 1983.

title: Padres Drop Sherry
description: His staff did well enough to get the San Diego Padres into the World Series, but what happened next has cost Norm Sherry his job as pitching coach, or so it seems. General Manager Jack McKeon denies that Sherry's dismissal was a result of the pitchers' World Series collapse to the Detroit Tigers and attributes it instead to ''conflicts.''

title: AMOSKEAG BANK SHARES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company converted to stock ownership in December 1983.

title: CITY FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including tax credis of $960,000 for the quarter and $3,076,000 for the 9 months. c-After a charge of $854,000 from penalties on prepayment of Federal Home Loan Bank advances.

title: Flyers Get 13, Tie Club Mark PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 18
description: Illka Sinisalo and

title: ECONOMICS LABORATORY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ALBERTA HUNTER, 89, CABARET STAR, DIES
description: Alberta Hunter, an internationally famous blues singer and cabaret star in the 1920's and 30's who, after two decades of retirement, began a second successful singing career in her 80's, died Wednesday at her home on Roosevelt Island. She was 89 years old and performed until last summer.

title: PACIFIC GAS & ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
MONDALE, ON OFFENSIVE, ASKS 'WHO'S IN CHARGE' OF POLICY
description: Walter F. Mondale, voicing confidence about a strong showing in his debate on Sunday with President Reagan, said today that ''a central issue'' now in the Presidential campaign was ''who's in charge, who's the Commander in Chief, who's running the shop.''

title: JOAKIM LEHMKUHL, 89, MADE TIMEX A TOP-SELLING WATCH
description: Joakim Lehmkuhl, retired president and chairman of the Timex Corporation, died Monday at his home in Nassau, the Bahamas. He was 89 years old.

title: SMITHSONIAN OFFERS THE OFFBEAT WITH A PURPOSE
description: Each day thousands of people take in what has become the hit of the year at the Smithsonian Institution's National Museum of American History: the set where the ''M*A*S*H'' television series was filmed for 11 years.

title: First Interstate's $150 Million Issue
description: First Interstate Bancorp offered $150 million of seven-year senior notes at competitive bidding.

title: THIRD NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Apple's Profit Bounds Back SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 18
description: Apple Computer Inc.

title: CONSOLIDATED FREIGHTWAYS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BRITISH LIFT A GLASS AS AN EX-FIREBRAND TURNS 100
description: Sixty years ago, in the heyday of left-wing agitation on the River Clyde, Manny Shinwell was one of the fiercest of the ''Red Clydesiders,'' the radicals who wanted to change the world, or at least the part they knew. At bedtime, Glasgow mothers used to tell their children to go to sleep or Manny would get them.

title: BOND PRICES CLIMB
description: Bond prices climbed sharply in the credit markets yesterday, as falling oil prices and the Federal Reserve's reluctance to prop up a key interest rate sent traders on a buying binge.

title: FRUEHAUF CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: CENTOCOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: 'For Sale'? No; 'No Vacancy'
description: The Department of Housing and Urban Development wants to help some public housing tenants become homeowners. Is that a healthy experiment or a disguised assault on public housing? The Reagan Administration's efforts to chop public housing subsidies encourage skepticism at the outset. The details of H.U.D.'s proposed three-year demonstration Public Housing Homeownership Program encourage still more.

title: Oregon Commune Stops Recruiting the Homeless
description: An Indian guru's disciples have stopped recruiting homeless people to live in their commune, but they denied today that the halt was timed to coincide with a deadline for voter registration.

title: FIRES WITH MAJOR LOSS OF LIFE
description: Fires in recent years involving major loss of life in the New York metropolitan area include the following: May 11, 1984 - Six Flags Great Adventure amusement park, Jackson

title: VINCENT VAN GOGH, CANVASES AND DRAWINGS OF SUN-SWEPT ARLES
description: THE exhibition of ''Van Gogh in Arles'' at the Metropolitan Museum of Art is a runaway popular success. How could it be otherwise? Ever since the centenary exhibition of 1953 in Amsterdam, the very idea of an unsuccessful exhibition of van Gogh has been a contradiction in terms.

title: FILM:'THIEF OF HEARTS' FINDS SECRETS
description: ALMOST everybody, including her husband, is aware that Mickey Davis (Barbara Williams), an interior designer, keeps a series of private journals. What they don't know is that the journals record her wildest sexual fantasies. Perhaps because he is a professional author, Ray Davis (John Getz), her husband, a successful writer of children's fiction, never pries and never seems to wonder why Mickey insists on keeping the journals locked up in the house safe.

title: FILM: TONY PERKINS IN 'CRIMES OF PASSION'
description: FOR all their extravagance, Ken Russell's films have never lacked exuberance or humor, which makes the flat, joyless tone of ''Crimes of Passion'' a surprise. Much of this is attributable to a screenplay by Barry Sandler filled with smutty double-entendres and weighty ironies. Only intermittently does Mr. Russell break through with the kind of manic flamboyance that is so singularly and rudely his own.

title: COCA-COLA UP 15.6% IN QUARTER
description: The Coca-Cola Company reported yesterday that its third-quarter net income rose 15.6 percent, to $175.3 million, or $1.34 a share, from $151.6 million, or $1.11 a share, a year earlier.

title: ELLIS ROBISON, HEAD OF A DRUG COMPANY AND PHILANTHROPIST
description: Ellis H. Robison, a philanthropist who headed John L. Thompson Sons & Company of Troy, N.Y., one of the country's oldest wholesale pharmaceutical concerns, died Wednesday at Samaritan Hospital in Troy. He was 88 years old and lived in Troy.

title: SALES SLOW
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company, the nation's largest retailer and a leading financial services marketer, said its third-quarter net income rose 11.5 percent, to $321.9 million, or 88 cents a share, from $288.8 million, or 81 cents a share, a year earlier.

title: BRIEFS
description: Avalon Energy Corp. of Atlanta said it had an agreement in principle to acquire Tri-South Investments Inc., also of Atlanta, by swapping 1.18 common shares of Avalon for each common share of Tri-South.

title: Frederick Lechner, 80, Dead; Cantor and Met Opera Singer
description: Frederick Lechner, a cantor who also sang with the Metropolitan Opera, died of leukemia Wednesday at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 80 years old.

title: LETTER: ON ANIMAL RIGHTS
description: -SPLICING WILL ENHANCE RESPECT

title: MOVIES: BILL MURRAY IN 'RAZOR'
description: ''LET'S talk,'' says Bill Murray as the idealistic young hero of W. Somerset Maugham's ''Razor's Edge'' as he prepares to tell his fiancee that he wants to postpone the wedding and is not yet ready to settle down. ''

title: Plea Filed on Gastineau A lawyer for Mark Gastineau, the all-pro Jet defensive end who
description: was convicted last month of misdemeanor assault, filed a motion yesterday to have the conviction overturned because of evidence that the

title: Bethlehem Steel
description: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation said it would sell coal and coke through a new Bethenergy marketing and brokerage unit, opening up new markets for the fuel that the company has been producing exclusively for its steel mills. Robert M. McCann, a Bethlehem vice president, said at a news conference that employment in the company's coal operations should fluctuate less through Bethenergy's efforts to market low-sulfur coals.

title: DATAPRODUCTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 29
CORRECTION
description: A picture caption in The Home Section yesterday with an article on interior decorators who specialize in smaller projects misidentified the man shown at left. He was David Wood.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: DINNER at Tiffany's is better than breakfast, mostly because they bring out the diamonds. The Duke of Norfolk walked in, cased the joint and said, ''I've never seen so much kit lying about.'' The Duke said he hoped the Duchess was not in a shopping mood, but ''I've taken away her credit cards in case.''

title: Call It Economics 11
description: In the wake of Mike Rozier 's disclosure that he had violated collegiate rules by engaging an agent and accepting payments while still playing for Nebraska last year, Tom Osborne , the Cornhuskers' coach, said he was organizing a class aimed at showing his players how to plan their future professional careers legitimately. ''It will meet eight or nine times,'' he said.

title: WOODY SHAW TO PLAY
description: The trumpeter Woody Shaw and his sextet are performing though Sunday at the Village Vanguard (255-4037), 178 Seventh Avenue South below 11th Street. Sets begin at 9:30 and 11:30 P.M. and 1 A.M. There is an $8 cover ($7.50 on Sunday) and a one-drink minimum.

title: Cells Over Brooms
description: Q. What would a petty criminal

title: Son Seals to Play
description: The blues guitarist-singer Son Seals will play Saturday at Danceteria (620- 0790), 30 West 21st Street. Sets begin at approximately midnight and 2 A.M.; admission is $8 until 11 P.M., and $12 afterward.

title: CONNOR IN L.I. REGATTA
description: The annual Manhasset Bay Fall Series sailing regatta, which began on Long Island Sound last weekend, has attracted the largest turnout in its seven-year history and this year it includes a roster of internationally known yachtsmen.

title: SUTCLIFFE AND SUTTER RATED AMONG ELITE FREE AGENTS
description: Rick Sutcliffe and Bruce Sutter, who could be on the brink of becoming the highest-paid pitchers in baseball history, rate high in the statistical rankings, too. According to ranking statistics completed yesterday, Sutcliffe and Sutter are among seven eligible players who qualify as Type A free agents.

title: WHERE THE MEEK AND THE MIGHTY FIGHT THE I.R.S.
description: Nelson Bunker Hunt and his wife, Caroline, one of America's wealthiest couples, are engaged in fights with the Internal Revenue Service over more than $10 million.

title: POP:LOU REED MAINTAINS HIS DARK UNDERTONES
description: -mannered, ingratiating rock bandleader Wednesday, opening a three-night stint at the Beacon Theater. He prefaced most songs with a bit of explanation and thanked the audience for attending - a far cry from his belligerent or taciturn performances of years past.

title: Amy Carter Is 17
description: Amy Carter, daughter of former President Jimmy Carter, will be 17 years old Friday. A family spokesman said Miss Carter, a senior at the Woodward Academy in Atlanta, would see her parents ''sometime around her birthday,'' but refused to be more specific about a celebration. The spokesman, Cindy Herzog, said Miss Carter only occasionally visited her parents' home in Plains, Ga.

title: No Third Man at the Debate
description: There really is no room for Konstantin Chernenko in Sunday's Reagan-Mondale debate. Hard though it is on journalists, the truth is that the Soviet leader had nothing new or important to say in his interview with The Washington Post. How could he have, just 12 days after his Foreign Minister lunched at the White House? If there was any need to amend Mr. Gromyko's remarks, or to respond to a private Reagan inquiry, it would have been done in private.

title: Miami's Resolve
description: A National Basketball Association exhibition on Monday night between the Nets and the Washington Bullets in Miami is regarded as ''the first step in our quest for an N.B.A. franchise,'' according to Rick Horrow, the executive director of the Miami Sports and Exhibition Authority.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Oct. 19, 1984 GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Transactions
description: Named Jim Beauchamp manager of Durham, N.C., farm in Class A Carolina League. BOSTON (AL) - Named John McNamara manager, replacing Ralph Houk, who retired.

title: REAGAN AIDE ASSAILS COMPARABLE WORTH IDEA
description: William A. Niskanen, President Reagan's senior economic adviser, told an audience of women here today that the issue of comparable pay for jobs of ''comparable worth'' was a ''medieval concept'' whose time had passed.

title: Diner's Journal
description: FANCIERS of veal chops know that on the infrequent occasions when forces conspire to produce a top grade chop expertly cooked, it is one of the most sublime meats around. Too often in restaurants, this expensive delicacy lacks the subtle beefy flavor and buttery texture it should have.

title: Dining Out Guide: Where to Find Pies
description: Following is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. AMERICAN HARVEST, Vista International

title: FIRST NATIONAL STATE BANCORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a $4,176,000 gain from the sale of nine branch offices. c-After a tax credit of $1,277,000. d-After extraordinary items of $3,504,000. The latest quarter and 9 month results reflect First National State's acquisition of Fidelity Union Bank on April 5, 1984. The transaction was accounted for as a pooling of interests and all 1983 data have been restated to reflect the acquisition. The sale of the nine branch offices resulted from the acquisition.

title: Mime at Museum
description: The mime Mark Stolzenberg, a former member of the Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey Circus, will perform on Sunday at 2 P.M. at the Fraunces Tavern Museum, 54 Pearl Street.

title: SCHLUMBERGER LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
KEY BANKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
UNION CARBIDE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Market Place ; Bright Spots In Banking
description: Goldman, Sachs & Company, the Wall Street investment house, revised its earnings forecasts the other day for the 40 leading banks that it follows, reporting that its bank stocks would show an average rise in profits of only 8.1 percent this year, rather than the 9.1 percent that it had previously forecast.

title: CALIBRE CORP reports earnings for Year to July 29
description: b-After a loss of $1,816,467 from discontinued operations of 7 G. D. Ritzy's Restaurants. c-Net income.

title: Dow and Celanese Post Gains; Monsanto and Carbide Off
description: Four of the nation's leading chemical producers yesterday announced mixed earnings results in the third quarter of 1984.

title: 'Trio,' Chamber Opera
description: ''Trio,'' a chamber opera about family relationships, is having its first New York performances this week in Carnegie Recital Hall.

title: UNITED CENTRAL BANCSHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
German Auto Output
description: Auto industry output in West Germany fell to 2.85 million vehicles in the first nine months, down 7 percent from the period a year earlier, V.D.A., the industry association, said today. It attributed the decline to the seven- week metalworkers' strike.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY ; Remembering the Bums
description: In the shadows of the seats in back of

title: A 'STRAPPING' YOUTH OF EONS AGO
description: The skull and bones of a ''strapping'' young male who lived 1.6 million years ago, described as the most complete skeleton of an early human ancestor ever found, have been discovered by fossil hunters in Kenya.

title: DAVID HOCKNEY, PORTRAITS AND FRAGMENTED PHOTOS
description: DAVID HOCKNEY draws beautifully and handles paint with an aplomb that is Dufy-like when it doesn't recall Picasso. The artist is a diarist who sets out to charm and only the terminally serious or the envious could resist him. All of which softens the ruthlessness of his observations, for deep down, Hockney is one of those appalling children who not only spot a physical blemish in an elder, but also comment on it.

title: ST. REGIS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a gain of $117,000,000 on the sale of assets and nonrecurring charges of $85,000,000 which include $55,000,000 in costs relating to the proposed merger with Champion International and $15,000,000 for divestiture of assets.

title: GCA CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss. Results for the latest third quarter include nonrecurring tax credits of $4,081,000, or 30 cents a share, reflect provisions of the Tax Reform Act exempting taxes related to disc export sales.

title: A Mortgage Banker Is Fannie Mae President
description: Mark J. Riedy, the executive vice president and chief operating officer of the Mortgage Bankers Association of America, was named president and chief operating officer of the Federal National Mortgage Association yesterday.

title: FIRST FINANCIAL CORP WISC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The 1983 figures are restated to reflect holding company formation with First State Savings of Wisconsin, which was accounted for as a pooling of interests. The per share earnings for both 1983 periods is based on historical net income and outstanding shares of First Financial Savings & Loan Assn. and its subsidiaries only. No effect has been given to the conversion of First State Savings of Wisconsin.

title: ASSAD ENDS VISIT TO MOSCOW AMID SIGNS OF DISAGREEMENT
description: President Hafez al-Assad of Syria ended a three-day visit to Moscow today, and the two sides called for Palestinian unity.

title: Scranton Bishop Denies Direct Attack on Ferraro
description: The Roman Catholic Bishop of Scranton told Geraldine A. Ferraro in a letter that he was not attacking her personally when he called her position on abortion ''absurd.''

title: REYNOLDS, R.J. INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $24,000,000 for the quarter and $101,000,000 for the 9 months. c-Includes income from discontinued operations of $34,000,000 for the quarter and $152,000,000 for the 9 months.

title: MAGIC CHEF INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 24
description: The company said net income for the latest quarter includes a gain of 9 cents a share related to a real estate transaction. Results for the latest quarter include the operations of Toastmaster, which was acquired in October 1983.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about Jewish voters in the Presidential election omitted part of the identification of the writer of a letter to the magazine Commentary. The ''Mr. Gordis'' quoted was David Gordis, executive vice president of the American Jewish Committee, which publishes Commentary.

title: 5 ACTORS QUIT CATHOLIC GUILD BENEFIT
description: Five Broadway actors have withdrawn from performing in a benefit for the Catholic Actors Guild, a philanthropic group, apparently because the event is to salute Archbishop John J. O'Connor.

title: PACWEST BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BRUSH WELLMAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including a gain of $2,411,000 from the reversal of previously deferred income tax. Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid in June.

title: TAKING TIME TO PROMOTE THEIR SPORT
description: Julianne McNamara achieved brilliant heights in Olympic gymnastics last summer, winning a gold medal on the uneven parallel bars and a silver in floor exercise. She finished fourth in the individual all-around competition, only 275-thousandths of a point from a bronze medal, and 775-thousandths of a point from the gold, won by Mary Lou Retton.

title: DOW CHEMICAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including a tax credit of $7 million. c-Including a gain of $14 million from the redemption of bonds.

title: ARABS ASK A CAMPAIGN HEARING, TOO
description: The Middle East is certain to figure prominently in Sunday's foreign policy debate between President Reagan and Walter F. Mondale. Given the increasingly pro-Israeli temper of this year's election politics, it is doubtful, however, that the hundred million or so Americans expected to hear the debate will get the facts as they really are. That, at least, is what we Arabs fear.

title: MONSANTO CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid June 6.

title: Breland Follows Tate to Houston

title: BELMONT INNOVATION: AN ALL-STAKES CARD
description: Belmont Park officials are still bristling over the selection of Hollywood Park in California as the site for this year's inaugural Breeders' Cup Event Day on Nov. 10. Seven races worth a total of $10 million will be run, replacing the Jockey Club Gold Cup day at Belmont as the climax of the fall racing season.

title: C.I.A. LINKED TO COMIC BOOK FOR NICARAGUANS
description: Congressional investigators conducting an inquiry of the Central Intelligence Agency's manual for Nicaraguan rebels say they are also investigating the agency's role in preparing a comic book for Nicaraguan citizens. The comic book shows how to puncture tires and stop up toilets as a means of overthrowing the Government.

title: LOMAX-TO-GREEN COMBINATION GIVES CARDS A POTENT ATTACK
description: Two weeks ago, the St. Louis Cardinals beat Dallas for the first time since 1977. And last weekend, at a time when Chicago had the top-rated defense in the National Football League, they defeated the Bears.

REDGRAVE'S LAWYER ASSAILS SYMPHONY AS BOSTON TRIAL OPENS
description: A lawyer for the actress Vanessa Redgrave charged in Federal District Court today that the Boston Symphony Orchestra had canceled her scheduled appearance with the orchestra in 1982 for political reasons, seriously damaging her career.

title: NIGERIA CUTS PRICE OF OIL IN FIRST RIFT IN OPEC STRUCTURE
description: Nigeria cut the price of its principal grades of oil by $2 a barrel yesterday, to $28, becoming the first member of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to break openly with the official price structure set 18 months ago.

title: Congress Unit Concurs In 6-Year Bias Ruling
description: A Congressional investigative agency has agreed to a ruling by the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission that said the agency ''discriminated intentionally and unlawfully'' against blacks in promoting employees from 1976 to 1982.

title: U.S. SAID TO HAVE HEARD WARNING OF BEIRUT RAID
description: An American with contacts in Lebanon said today that she warned the State Department in mid-August that a radical Shiite group would attack the American Embassy in East Beirut between Sept. 20 and 22.

title: CONCERT: BEAUX ARTS TRIO AT MUSEUM
description: The pleasure of hearing the Beaux Arts Trio once again in the standard works it has played for decades is not that of fresh insight and continuing rediscovery. It is more like walking down a familiar mountain trail, stopping at exactly the same places you have always stopped, admiring the same views - not out of bored inertia, but because it can be deeply satisfying to affirm that a thing loved has some permanence.

description: This is a rant. It's about R. J. Reynolds, Robert Browning and seltzer. It is also about the not inconsequential fact that our society is having its substance vacuumed out of it.

title: Philippine Editor Killed
description: The editor of an opposition weekly newspaper was killed by three gunmen today while driving home with his wife on his 38th birthday. The police said Alexander Orcullo, managing editor of The Mindanao Current, was stopped by assailants armed with automatic rifles in Davao, 600 miles south of Manila.

title: LAW DEAN TO RUN PHELAN ESTATE
description: A judge yesterday appointed Patrick J. Rohan, the dean of the St. John's University Law School, to succeed John A. Zaccaro as the overseer of the estate of Alice Phelan of Queens. Mr. Zaccaro had borrowed $175,000 from the estate for his own business.

title: V.A. Medical Chief Named
description: The Veterans Administration today announced the appointment of Dr. John W. Ditzler, a 65-year-old anesthesiologist, as its new chief medical director, in charge of the nation's largest health care system. Dr. Ditzler, who has been director of the V.A. Medical Center in San Diego since 1980 and previously managed the agency's medical budget, succeeds Dr. Donald L. Custis, who retired in May.

title: RUSSELL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ACTORS AND PRODUCERS IN OFF BROADWAY PACT
description: A new contract has been reached for Off Broadway actors and stage managers, it was announced yesterday by representatives of Actors Equity and the League of Off Broadway Theaters and Producers. The major element in the pact is a salary increase in the two categories.

title: Prosecution Drive Denied
description: According to the Attorney General of Maine, John E. Tierney, a Democrat, the Reagan Administration is looking for environmental cases to prosecute before Election Day. According to the Justice Department, this is not true.

title: SAKHAROV AND WIFE THOUGHT TO BE TOGETHER
description: Friends of Andrei D. Sakharov say several telegrams and postcards have been received from the Sakharovs in Gorky, and the messages suggest the exiled dissident is now living in his apartment with his wife.

title: TRANSIT INSPECTORS FACE NEW TRAINING
description: Transit Authority officials, trying to ease concerns about fires on the city's subways, yesterday announced plans to increase training for some 3,000 car inspectors.

title: McCALLUM DEFEATS MANNION
description: Mike McCallum, who was nicknamed The Body Snatcher by his former sparring partner, Thomas Hearns, joined Hearns as a world 154- pound boxing champion last night at Madison Square Garden. Earlier, Steve McCrory, still a Hearns teammate, became the first of the nine United States 1984 Olympic champions to fight professionally.

title: SEYMOUR BRAUN
description: Seymour Braun, founder and past president of J. S. Braun and Sons, importers of nuts, dried fruits and cocoa, died of cancer Thursday at his home in Manhasset, L.I.. He was 74 years old and also lived in Palm Beach, Fla.

title: CLAEAN AND GREEN ; Garden by the YardA carpet of green surprises the pedestrian who strays west of Ninth Avenue on Manhattan's West 48th Street. The Clinton Community Garden, a rare oasis, occupies a city- owned lot that lay vacant for a quarter-century until neighbors leased it for a dollar a year and started growing flowers and vegetables.
description: But now the garden is in danger. Gentrification and the prospect of Times Square redevelopment threaten to engulf this bright spot on a still-dreary landscape.

title: BATTLESHIP IOWA STEAMS INTO THE CITY TO GET A TASTE OF FUTURE HOME BASE
description: The battleship Iowa, a nearly half- century-old dreadnought reclaimed last spring from mothballing, anchored off Staten Island yesterday morning amid rusty freighters and orange ferryboats.

title: B.P. Gets 4% Stake In Johnson Matthey
description: The British Petroleum Company said today that it had purchased 4.75 million shares of Johnson Matthey P.L.C., or about 4 percent of the company's shares outstanding, and indicated that it might be interested in acquiring more.

title: OPERA: MOZART'S 'TITO,' A PREMIERE AT THE MET
description: It took the Metropolitan Opera more than a century to get around to Mozart's final opera, ''La Clemenza di Tito,'' but now we have it. This grand example of his opera seria manner, a work fit to set beside ''Idomeneo,'' his other essay in high- flown Baroque artifice, made a spectacular first appearance Thursday night in Jean-Pierre Ponnelle's grander-than-grand production. Vocally the performance had a few lows but there were more than enough highs to compensate. Any Mozart lover would be a fool to miss this one.

title: FROM MOVIE 'CUTS' TO RING CUTS

description: Orest Sergievsky, a well-known ballet teacher, died on Tuesday in New York City after a heart attack. He was 73 years old.

THEATER: TWO ASPECTS OF POLISH HEROISM AT LA MAMA
description: Modern Polish drama, like the history it reflects, is drenched in a tragic sense of individual heroism overrun by treacherous political storms. Slawomir Mrozek's full-length play ''Alpha'' and Tamara Karren's one- act drama ''Who Was That Man?'' portray gallant individuals victimized by political and historical forces beyond their control. The plays are being presented at La Mama by the Polish Theater Institute, a New York- based performing arts organization.

description: Morris Malech, a retired New Jersey Superior Court judge, died of a heart ailment Wednesday at Hackensack (N.J.) Hospital. He was 71 years old and lived in Woodcliff Lake, N.J.

PATENTS;
ELECTRIC CAR SYSTEM FOR TWO KINDS OF ROADS
description: An electrified transportation system that would allow a motor vehicle to run on both conventional and electrified roadways was patented this week for the Chevron Research Company of San Francisco. The inventor, who obtained patent 4,476,947, is Jay D. Rynbrandt, the research scientist on the staff.

title: 2 Climbers on El Capitan Froze in Sudden Storm
description: Two Japanese mountain climbers were not equipped for a sudden snowstorm and freezing temperatures that claimed their lives 140 feet from the rim of El Capitan, park officials say.

title: FIRE DOOR IN PATERSON HOTEL WAS KEPT OPEN WITH DRUM
description: A fire door that had been propped open with a 55-gallon drum allowed smoke and heat to fill the Alexander Hamilton Hotel here early Thursday, trapping residents and preventing firefighters from reaching many victims, officials said today.

title: WEST VIRGINIA AIMING TO SETTLE A SCORE
description: A. James Manchin, Secretary of State of West Virginia, was just as upset as most other West Virginia football fans last January when the Lambert-Meadowlands Trophy committee voted to award that prize to Boston College as the top team in the East. The vote was 3-2 for Boston College over West Virginia, with the sixth member of the committee somehow deciding to name Penn State the winner.

title: Canadian Prices Rise
description: Canadian consumer prices rose one-tenth of 1 percent in September from August and were up 3.8 percent from 12 months before, Statistics Canada said today. The Government agency said food prices fell seven-tenths of 1 percent in September from August but rose 5.6 percent from a year earlier. Prices of non-food items were up three-tenths of 1 percent from August and up 3.3 percent from a year earlier.

title: HOW THE POLL WAS CONDUCTED
description: The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted Oct. 14 to 17 with 1,809 adults around the United States, excluding Alaska and Hawaii, of whom 1,253 indicated they were registered to vote.

description: Per share figures do not reflect a 2-for-1 stock split that became effective Oct. 15.

title: SOME EARLY REURNS THAT FAVOR MONDALE
description: Despite a computer failure that delayed voting a day, the turnout was heavy Thursday at a West Side polling place. If the students and teachers of the Center School had their way, Walter F. Mondale would clearly be the next addressee at the White House.

description: Representative William R. Ratchford, a Democrat, was campaigning at a street festival here the other day when a woman came up to him and proclaimed for all to hear, ''I'm going to vote for you, Mr. Ratchford.''

description: The First Jersey National Corporation asid it plans to acquire People's National Bank of North Jersey in a stock swap valued at about $18 million.

description: Almost five weeks after George Washington High School refused to kick off in a game against Lehman High School, the Trojans lined up to receive a kickoff from Stevenson High yesterday in the Bronx.

description: The Justice Department announced yesterday that a second naturalized American citizen had surrendered his citizenship and left the United States for West Germany rather than contest charges involving Nazi war crimes during World War II.

description: An espionage indictment here is creating questions about whether the Soviet Union has taken advantage of the American immigration system to filter spies into this country.

STAGE: 'TOBACCO ROAD' REVIVED AT LONG WHARF
description: In the bleakness of the landscape, the scene simulates a Walker Evans photograph of a Depression family. A dusty road leads to a dilapidated house. On the porch sits the haggard father. Her shoulders stooped with an early old age, his wife stares emotionless at the remains of a farm that has not been tilled in seven years. There is not a touch of brightness in the monochromatic design.

title: COMMISSIONER WARD'S STERN STANDARDS
description: Benjamin Ward has been a good Police Commissioner of New York City for the last nine months, and new questions about his personal conduct do not tarnish that record. But they do affect his ability to command the respect of the public and the department. Both deserve better answers than he and Mayor Koch gave this week.

title: Panamanian Ship Hit By Air Attack in Gulf
description: An Iranian F-4 Phantom fighter-bomber set ablaze a Panamanian-registered ship in the southern Persian Gulf today, killing two people and prompting a rescue by nearby United States Navy helicopters.

description: In a defense of the city's wage offer to its labor unions, Mayor Koch yesterday outlined improvements in services that he said the city might be able to afford if raises were kept to a ''fair'' level.

description: There was no need for judges of either sex, after all. Marvin Hagler, putting the Marvelous back in his name and finally fighting in Madison Square Garden, stopped Mustafa Hamsho on a technical knockout at 2:31 of the third round last night to successfully defend his undisputed world middleweight boxing championship for the 10th time over all and the second against the outclassed challenger.

title: JAZZ: BUSHKIN LEADS SEPTET

title: MIDAIR COLLISIONS: SOME PROPOSALS TO IMPROVE SAFETY
description: When Vice President Bush's Boeing 707 abruptly dropped 200 feet Thursday to avoid colliding with a small private plane, it provided a classic example of a perennial air-traffic hazard: Approaching airports, large planes that are under a tower's control might mingle with small planes that sometimes are not. At the same time, it illustrated the protection afforded by the on-the-ground system when controllers are alert and available technical equipment is used.

title: OIL PRICES ARE LITTLE CHANGED
description: Oil trading came to a virtual standstill yesterday and prices stabilized as nervous dealers awaited a response by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to the price cuts by Norway, Britain and Nigeria that threaten a general slide in world petroleum prices.

title: ON DEBATE EVE, FOREIGN POLICY DIVIDES VOTERS
description: As Sunday's foreign policy debate between the Presidential candidates nears, voters who have made up their minds back President Reagan's approach, while undecided voters are less impressed by his policies, the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll indicates.

title: ANOTHER TRUMANESQUE RURAL VOTE?
description: It is probably true that Walter F. Mondale cannot win the election without extraordinary help from rural voters, who represent one-third of the total electorate. It may also be true that a rural turnaround this year could do for Mr. Mondale what it did for Harry S. Truman in 1948.

Metropolitan A self-closing fire door that had been propped open with a 55-gallon drum allowed smoke and heat to fill an eight-story downtown residential hotel in Paterson, N.J., trapping people on the upper floors and preventing firefighters from reaching many victims, fire officials said. Thirteen people were killed and 57 were injured in the blaze on Thursday that, the authorities charge, was set by a hotel handyman. (26:1-2.)

title: ENVIRONMENT-BUSTER REAGAN

title: DOW TO DROP ANTIFREEZE LAW
description: The Dow Chemical Company said it was withdrawing from all sales of packaged antifreeze-coolants in the United States. Dow, based in Midland, Mich., said it would supply packaged antifreeze-coolant to its customers through the antifreeze season. The products affected include Dowgard brand antifreeze-coolant and 40 private-label brands. Dow said it was making the move as part of a program to strengthen its product mix.

title: Sharing Pain in Socialist Spain A specter of austerity now haunts Western Europe, greatly shrinking the distance between Tories and Socialists. description: The nation's economy grew at a surprisingly slow annual rate of 2.7 percent from July through September, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: OPEC'S MOUNTING PROBLEMS
description: With oil prices slipping and the ministers of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries preparing for an emergency meeting 10 days from now in Geneva, the world oil markets appear to be well on the way down the same path that forced a 15 percent cut in OPEC prices early last year.

description: Three United States military advisers flew into this rebel-dominated area Friday and marched to this town while fighting was taking place on a nearby hill between Salvadoran Army and rebel combat units.

title: REAGAN AND TELEVISION: HOW HIS IMAGE LEAVES HIM VULNERABLE IN DEBATES
description: Every evening in President Reagan's campaign headquarters in Washington, a young aide on the staff of James H. Lake, the press secretary, videotapes the evening newscasts of the three major networks and provides an analysis of what was shown and said about the President for Mr. Lake to study the next morning. As he reads those reports day by day, Mr. Lake has come to understand fully a basic fact of political life in this country today, the fact that so troubles the networks and delights the Reagan White House: that no matter what is said by the reporters on the evening news, it is the pictures that convey the impression that most Americans get of this Presidency.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about the earnings of the American Broadcasting Companies incorrectly described an influence on them. The company said that if it had renegotiated a payment for broadcasting the Olympic Games last summer, any saving would have been passed on to advertisers.

PATENTS;

description: A self-closing container for radioactive materials, patented this week for the Department of Energy, is designed to reduce the dangerous exposure of individuals handling such materials.

title: CONTROLLED INTOXICANTS

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: I HAD a party one recent weekend, the first I've given in almost a decade. It was a reunion of sorts; many of the guests had been mainstays of the parties I had years ago. A lot of things had changed.

title: Zoo Gets Rare Crocodiles
description: Two rare Cuban crocodiles from the Havana Zoo have been received by the National Zoo, it was announced Friday. The crocodiles, both adult females, arrived Wednesday as part of an exchange program between the Cuban Academy of Sciences and the Smithsonian Institution, according to Leslie Hornig, a National Zoo spokesman. The zoo is part of the Smithsonian.

title: Equity Program
description: To the Editor:

title: A GROWING NEED: DAY CARE FOR THE ELDERLY
description: A GENERATION ago, the care of ailing elderly relatives was usually the responsibility of those in their 40's and 50's. But as medical care has improved and life expectancy averages have risen, more people are faced with the responsibility of caring for their relatives at the same time that they are planning their own retirements and confronting their own aging.

title: TOURING TOULOUSE
description: In Toulouse, deep in the French Midi, fanciful Renaissance towers, late nights at outdoor cafes and hearty eating flourish alongside the serious scientific and technological activity that has made this ancient city astride the Garonne River the home of Caravelle, Concorde and airbus aircraft and a leader in the international aerospace industry and in scientific research.

title: NAVY ROUTS PRINCETON BY 41-3
description: Bill Byrne threw for two touchdowns and ran for one, and Todd Solomon kicked a school-record 52-yard field goal today to lead Navy to a 41-3 rout of Princeton.

title: CONCERT: SMEDVIG, TRUMPETER
description: The Scandinavian Ameican Chamber Orchestra's concert at Alice Tully Hall Thursday night suffered a natural disaster before the fact and then managed to manufacture problems of its own. The event was titled 'A Danish Evening,' and central to it was that country's Leif Roar, a baritone known at the Metropolitan Opera and most of the opera houses in Europe.

title: Stacy Pomeroy, Curator, Wed to G. Steven Draper
description: Stacy Fox Pomeroy, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Burdette Pomeroy of Bronxville, N.Y., was married yesterday to G. Steven Draper, a son of Glenn P. Draper of Fresno, Calif., and Mrs. Emil Apfel of Albany.

title: Robert MacNeil Weds Miss Richards
description: Robert MacNeil, executive editor of public television's nightly newscast ''The MacNeil/Lehrer Newshour,'' and Donna Richards, executive director and vice president of Superlearning Inc., which sells educational aids, were married yesterday at the New York Yacht Club. The Rev. Ervin Seal, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony.

title: FINDING MODERN COMEDY IN TROLLOPE'S VICTORIAN SAGA
description: Late in 1981, when the project hectically got going, no one would have prophesied that ''The Barchester Chronicles'' would become one of the BBC's more successful drama series. Nor would anyone have dared expect it to be bought by PBS for the American airing that begins next weekend. After all, it all came about in a nervous, harried sort of way. The powers-that-be decided at the last moment that Stendhal's ''Red and the Black'' was too expensive to adapt to the small screen, leaving an awkward hole in the schedule only a few months ahead. They substituted Anthony Trollope's cathedral-city saga partly because it was cheaper, partly because they had a vague, guilty feeling they'd too long been neglecting a minor 19th-century classic.

title: DEVILS ARE ROUTED, 8-3
description: Dave Barr and Kevin LaVallee each scored three goals tonight to power the St. Louis Blues to an 8-3 victory over the New Jersey Devils.

title: ABOUT BOOKS
description: ''I BECAME a writer when everbody I worked for in Jersey City politics went to jail,'' said Warren Murphy. ''I thought God was sending me a message to find a new line of work.''

title: Lori Walter to Marry Harry Cohen Nov. 18
description: Mr. and Mrs. Marvin Walter of Woodbury, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Lori Ellen Walter to Harry Philip Cohen, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin A. Cohen of Great Neck, L.I. A Nov. 18 wedding is planned.

title: DOWNTOWN DOVER ON THE REBOUND
description: Once a city or a town manages to change its image from that of a dying settlement to a community on the go, its recovery can be as swift as its original decline was precipitous.

title: Los Angeles Drug Gangs Blamed for 25 Murders
description: The authorities blame a struggle between two drug gangs in south-central Los Angeles for 25 murders since March, including the ''drive-by'' slayings of five youths Oct. 12, according to a published report.

title: FAMILY PLANNERS SEE GAINS IN 1984
description: It has been a year when abortion has moved back onto the public agenda, with a vengeance.

title: TACONIC ROADRUNNERS CLUB LOOKS TO THE NEW YORK MARATHON
description: NEXT Sunday, runners from around the world will be in New York City to compete over a 26.2-mile course - the distance one must go to make it from start to finish in the New York Marathon. Some of the competitors will have a bona fide chance to win, some will simply be trying to better their last year's time and others will only hope to finish.

title:

MARRYING EQUALITY TO EFFICIENCY
description: Barry P. Bosworth is a senior fellow in economics at the Brookings Institution and the author of ''Tax Incentives and Economic Growth.'' THE ECONOMIC ILLUSION

title: CHRISTMAS IN THE TROPICS
description: For me, life is spent plotting and planning new recipes, both cooking and writing about them. But there are about 10 days a year when I do cook special foods with no thought of work in mind - days when I cook for the sheer pleasure and relaxation of it. And that is when I am on holiday at the end of each year on an island in the Caribbean.

title: Dr.Susan Tarnofsky to Wed a Securities Analyst
description: Mr. and Mrs. Isaac Tarnofsky of West Orange, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Dr. Susan Barbara Tarnofsky, to Robert J. Grossman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Grossman of Newton Centre, Mass. The wedding is to take place Nov. 25.

title: SUMMER'S LAG TAKEN IN STRIDE
description: ''One month of data,'' Robert A. Gough cautioned last week, ''doesn't make a trend.'' Nor, other analysts were adding, may a quarter's worth.

title: PROPOSED CIBA PLANT STIRS CONTROVERSY
description: ALTHOUGH environmentalists have criticized the Ciba- Geigy Corporation's plan to build a large pharmaceuticals plant next to its chemical plant here, company officials say it would be ''totally different'' from the one in Rhode Island that has polluted the Pawtuxet River and stirred so much opposition there.

title: PRACTICAL TRAVELER: FOR THE TOURIST WHO HAS EVERYTHING
description: At TravelMarket in San Francisco you can buy a packet of 14 earplugs for $3.50. ''Silence, please'' the store's description says. ''These imported beeswax earplugs are the B's knees when foreign noises come between you and your sweet dreams.''

title: 3 IN PROTEST ON JOBS ARRESTED IN ASSAULT ON PAVING CREW
description: Three Brooklyn men were arrested Friday night after they and about 60 other protesters marched onto the Throgs Neck Bridge and assaulted construction workers who were repaving a traffic lane, the police said yesterday.

title: RUM FOR ALL SEASONS
description: They have not always been happy about it, but Americans have long been a rum- drinking nation. They drank it in colonial times because it was cheap and plentiful. They drank it during Prohibition because so little else was available, and they drank it during wartime for pretty much the same reason. Lately, they have been drinking it because they have found it to be a drink for all seasons, a drink made in many styles and a drink of infinite variety.

title: REAGAN VS. REAGAN
description: WASHINGTON Nobody can accuse the Reagan Administration of being a prisoner of its own rhetoric. It often overstates and misstates its own case, but it has been singularly successful at recovering its own fumbles and even stealing the ball from the opposition.

description: MUSIC, MUSIC FOR EVERYONE

title: AN ELEGANT COLLABORATION
description: Few people today have enough leisure hours to devote to elaborate party preparations. The alternatives for some are a caterer or carryout, but many people just stop entertaining. Enter the cooperative dinner. Even though potluck dinners never went out of style entirely, this elegant, carefully orchestrated form is fairly new, a modern solution to contemporary time squeeze.

title: TURBOS ADD ZIP
description: BACK in the 1950's, we called them Hollywood mufflers. Their shells were packed with glass fiber and they were made without the usual noise- deadening baffles. They let the exhaust gases run straight through, building horsepower and sounding terrific. I remember putting them on my first car and loving the burble of that V-8. I was a confirmed eight-cylinder guy.

title: WHILE ATLANTIC CITY ROLLS ON, LAS VEGAS COMES UP LOSING
description: Check in for a flight to Las Vegas and chances are that with your boarding pass you'll get a little pack of coupons called a Las Vegas FunBook. Register at a hotel here - other coupons come with the room key, these called FunPak or Fun Spree and the like. A dinner at a different hotel will bring yet another little batch of coupons courtesy of the establishment. All are designed to lure the visitor toward the casinos, lounges and supper clubs up and down the Vegas Strip with offers: for instance, a shrimp cocktail for only 99 cents at the Imperial Palace.

title: THE CLAMOR FOR DAY CARE
description: ''There are an estimated 110,000 kids who need day care, for whom we have roughly 30,000 slots,'' said Frances T. Roberts, the director of the state's Office of Child Day Care. ''Families can't manage on one salary any more. And women in management having babies in their 30's are not about to give up good places on the rung to stay home and raise kids.''

title: SMALL STEP FOR JUSTICE
description: Postwar investigations suggested that Arthur L. H.Rudolph , a close friend of Dr. Wernher von Braun, was not exactly immersed in pure science when he was operational director of Hitler's V-2 flying bomb production. Nevertheless, he was included among the rocketry experts secretly brought to the United States after Germany surrendered.

title:
CRAFTS;
ACIENT METHOD OF NERIKOMI IN SCARSDALE SHOW
description: THE ancient Japanese clay art of Nerikomi is a painstaking and tedious technique. It requires the potter to press colored clay fragments into a handmade mold to form the receptacle. Before the actual fabrication, however, the clay must be prepared by slicing, stacking, folding, twisting or wedging diversely colored layers of the material together to form patterns that will ultimately emblazon the surface of the container.

description: Has the National Football League conducted its business for the sole purpose of earning profits for its owners or to drive out of existence any potential competition, such as the young United States Football League?

THERE'S NOTHING TO FEAR FROM MONDALE
description: Wall Street has always had a love affair with the Republican Party. While I think this is somewhat illogical (since 1900 the stock market has done about one- third better under Democratic Presidents than Republican), most of my colleagues in the securities industry routinely support the Republican candidate for President.

title: 'DISPLACED' WOMEN SEEK NEW SKILLS
description: SHE is typically between 35 and 60 years old and has spent most of her adult life doing what she believes has been expected of her - raising children and being a wife. Then her husband dies, leaves the marriage or becomes disabled and she finds herself in an emotional and financial crisis. For the first time in years, she has to find a way to make a living. But she has few, if any, marketable skills and because her life has been so wrapped up in pleasing others, she does not even know herself.

Mr. Strader is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Strader of Fort Lauderdale, Fla.

description: Jane Brown Abrams and Lloyd Charles Nintzel, both of New York, were married yesterday in New Canaan, Conn., at the home of Lester and Patricia Brooks. Mrs. Brooks, who is a justice of the peace, performed the ceremony.

title: ILL HANDLERS SUSPECTED IN OREGON FOOD POISONINGS
description: Investigators searching for the cause of an outbreak of food poisoning that affected nearly 700 restaurant patrons here last month are focusing attention on salad bars and food handlers.

description: John Harvey's life swings between bitter and sweet these days - the bitterness coming from the pressures of the classroom and the sweetness from the pleasures of the football field.

description: The Reagan Administration decided today to reduce significantly the size of the United States Embassy staff in Beirut as a result of continuing security threats, State Department officials said.

title: HAGLER IS STRIPPED OF TITLE BY W.B.C.
description: Just as boxing began to prepare for its first ''fight of the century'' in three years, the sport was reminded yesterday of why it was in the doldrums.

title: Broadcast TV
description: By the time of his historic international telecast from London in May, 1982, Vladimir Horowitz was 77 years old, and had been before the public for over half a century. But this was his first European concert in 31 years, and some symbolic token of the event seemed to be in order.

title: THE HOUSE OF DELICIOUS SCENTS
description: Each day it starts about noon. Deep, romantic aromas begin wafting up toward our third- floor apartment - the stiff and heady scent of grilled sardines; the smoky, eye-stinging trail of lardons being sauteed for a salad of cubed bacon, washed with red-wine vinegar and tossed atop crisp greens; the gentle hint of a blanquette de veau that seeps beneath the double oak doors that divide us from our Parisian neighbors. Even the humble scent of onions turning golden in a pan of butter captures my attention, forcing me to drop what I'm doing and take notice.

title: COUPLE'S SUCCESS IS UNSUNG BUT STEADY
description: WHAT is most certain about a life in the theater is its uncertainty. Less certain, but as characteristic, is its volatility; and its valleys and the peaks, if any. A noted playwright once observed that ''in the theater, you can make a killing; but a living, no.''

Griffin of Bronxville, N.Y., and Ocean Ridge, Fla., was married yesterday to James Matthew Marrone Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Marrone of Mount Vernon, N.Y. Msgr. Patrick J. Sheridan performed the ceremony at St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church in Bronxville.
