title: JOSTLING IN THE OVERCROWDED MARKET
description: When the historic breakup of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company was announced in January 1982, executives at scores of telecommunications companies were certain that a huge, lucrative market had been laid at their feet. ''It's what we've been pushing for for a long time,'' William G. McGowan, chairman of the MCI Communications Corporation, said the day he heard the news.

title: U.S. SHIFT IN SALVADOR DENIED
description: Government officials said today that senior American military officers had begun to move more freely around El Salvador. But they denied there had been any changes in rules barring advisers from combat.

title: MUSIC: THE CLEVELAND
description: The Cleveland Orchestra continued its triumphant tour of New York Friday night with an exhilarating concert at Carnegie Hall. Under the baton of its new music director, Christoph von Dohn anyi, the orchestra sounded splendid - luxuriant, well rehearsed and full of energy.

title: How Suffolk Democrats View Their Ticket
description: While the words were different, the sentiments were the same; the three Democratic candidates for Congress in Suffolk County are attempting to walk away from the Democratic candidates for President and Vice President. This was the thrust of the article ''Democrats Run L.I. Races Apart From Mondale'' on Sept. 23.

title: Donations Hit Record In Races for Congress
description: Propelled by donations from political action committees, House and Senate candidates raised a record of $213 million by midyear, up 21 percent from 1982, the Federal Election Commission said today.

title: NO FLOGGINGS ON SUNDAY
description: Martin J. Wiener is professor of history at Rice University. His most recent book is ''English Culture and the Decline of the Industrial Spirit 1850- 1980.'' BOYS TOGETHER

title:
WORLDLY CONCERNS;
IN ROUND 2,EVENTS MAY HAVE A WAY OF UNDOING STRATEGIES
description: LAST summer, Democratic strategists targeted foreign affairs as President Reagan's most vulnerable area and laid plans for a campaign building to a foreign- policy crescendo in late October. Even in September, when Walter F. Mondale was floundering, his aides resisted turning from deficits and taxes to foreign policy. ''The time for that is October,'' one of them firmly insisted. Deliberately, the Mondale camp fought for and won agreement for what has become a make-or-break event, the second Presidential debate, on foreign policy, in Kansas City tonight.

title: A UNION AND QUEENS COLLEGE RUN STUDY PROGRAM AT NIGHT
description: For 11 years, Maria Pratts, a clerical worker at a health center, has wanted to go to college.

title: THE SPIRIT TO KEEP PLAYING IN FACE OF DROUGHT
description: UNTIL a few years ago, when more locks and dams were added to the Ohio River, this small college town (pop. 16,000) situated on the bank of the river in a corner of southeast Ohio would experience a terrific, annual flooding.

title: Denise Svatos Is Wed To Henry Thomas Jr.
description: St. Paul's Chapel at Columbia University was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Denise Mary Svatos, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald Charles Svatos of Atlanta, and Henry Hoen Thomas Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas of Fair Haven, N.J. The Rev. Paul Dinter, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Hector Is Rolling as Backup for McNeil
description: He moans, he groans, he gets up slowly after being tackled. Freeman McNeil, the top rusher in the American Football Conference, is in pain and that is why Johnny Hector has become a pivotal player on the Jets.

title: LET THEM EAT TURKEY
description: Is there anyone else out there who sincerely doesn't like apple pie? Is there anyone else out there who sincerely thinks that baseball is a boring game? Is there anyone else out there who sincerely loathes parades?

title: BRITAIN'S TOP YANKEE EXECUTIVES
description: LONDON

title: WHY CAN'T VERDI VOICES HANDLE SONDHEIM?
description: W hy has the American musical, a form that certainly has produced a rich and various repertory of famous works, been so slow in finding a place in the world's opera houses? Is it because of some intrinsic inferiority to other light-classical genres such as the Viennese operetta and Gilbert and Sullivan? Or is the American musical simply founded on vocal traditions that do not allow it to adjust easily to opera surroundings? I found myself mulling over that and related questions the other evening during the New York City Opera's ambitious new production of ''Sweeney Todd,'' Stephen Sondheim's Broadway hit of five seasons ago. I came down, somewhat tentatively, on the side of incompatible vocal traditions, but I grant that the issue is a complicated one.

title: TALKS STALLED ON GERMANS IN PRAGUE EMBASSY
description: Talks between Bonn and East Berlin over the status of 154 East Germans who have taken refuge in the West German Embassy in Prague have reached an impasse, according to officials here who are familiar with the situation.

title: SCIENCE-LAW CHAIR IS SET BY COLUMBIA
description: A professorship in law and its relation to science and technology will be established at Columbia University's School of Law with the donation of $1.1 million from an alumnus, the university has announced.

title: LUNG CANCER RISING AS KILLER OF WOMEN, U.S. AGENCY SAYS
description: Lung cancer will soon become the nation's leading cause of all cancer deaths among women, who have failed to stop smoking at a rate as high as that of men, Federal health officials have predicted.

title: Dr. Alice Magner, Pediatrician, Wed
description: Dr. Alice Marie Magner, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles A. Magner of Harwich, Mass., was married yesterday to Dr. Peter Condro Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Condro of the Bronx. The Rev. Jeremiah Casey, a cousin of the bride, performed the ceremony at St. Matthias Roman Catholic Church in Bala Cynwyd, Pa.

title: Peppers and Eggs - And Arias, Too
description: I'm writing in praise of Christine Vanderberg's article, ''Peppers and Arias, Old Times and New'' (Sept. 30).

title: REAGAN VETOES BILL TO ALTER INDIAN HEALTH SERVICE
description: President Reagan, overriding the pleas of several Republican Senators who supported the bill, has vetoed an $85 million measure designed to improve Federal health care programs for American Indians.

title: REFUSE PLANT TO MEASURE DIOXIN LEVEL
description: WHILE the New York City Board of Estimate prepares to open debate on the health risks of building a garbage-to-energy incinerator, just such a plant is going into commercial operation in Peekskill.

title: WHOEVER IS ELECTED, POTENTIAL IS GREAT FOR CHANGE IN HIGH COURT'S COURSE
description: The 1984 Presidential election could be the most important in a half-century in its effect on the future of the Supreme Court and constitutional law.

title: WOMEN IN SCHOOLS CITE MENTORS' VALUE
description: THE importance of male mentors, the support of female colleagues, good preparation, strong motivation and a sense of knowing what it is one wants in a career were cited as important factors in ''Getting to Be No. 1'' in school administration at a meeting Tuesday night of the Association of Women Administrators in Westchester. Three women who are school superintendents spoke about the pleasures and pitfalls of the job and what it takes to get and remain No. 1.

title: A TIME FOR TEA
description: This is the time of year when the self-indulgence of sweets can be best defended. The ability to rationalize surrender to cravings seems to increase as the weather grows harsher. And while there are scores of festive occasions through the end of the year that encourage the sweet tooth, any excuse will do for another piece of cake. Tea time is just one an an excellent diversion from the usual holiday entertaining. The cakes picutred here were created specially for this issue by Flo Braker, an inventive baker from California whose book 'The Simple Art of Perfect Baking' (William Morrow) will be published next month. While festive and elegant, these recipes are straightforward and unfussy. They include mocha torte, a genoise that is flavored with freshly ground coffee beans; charlotte portugaise, a dome-shaped cake moistened with orange-flavored cream and crowned with meringue; Richelieu torte, a surprisingly light flourless cake made with chocolate and almonds, and chestnut cake, an autumnal dessert made withpureer chestnuts. Teas appropriate to serve with sweets include Darjeeling, Earl Grey, oolong and Irish breakfast, as well as flavored varieties such as black currant almong and raspberry.

title: LAXALT'S POWER: SUITS FOCUS ATTENTION ON SENATOR
description: Paul Laxalt, as the senior Senator from Nevada, general chairman of the Republican Party and one of President Reagan's closest advisers, rides on the crest of a wave of power.

title: MEDIUM FORMAT CAMERAS GROWING IN POPULARITY
description: Before 35mm cameras became so popular, medium format cameras that used 120 roll film were the choice of most amateurs and professionals. These slower-working, heavier cameras faded from the scene for awhile - or at least seemed to have lost much of their popularity - but the wheel seems to be turning once again in their direction. Newer models have so many convenience features that they rival the 35mm in flexibility and performance.

title: STAGES OF LIFE FOUND IN A CLOSET
description: MY husband and I recently decided to do some fall housecleaning and realized it was time to have a yard sale. After 20 years of marriage and two boys, our house was overflowing with the discarded bounty of family life. We started to sort through what I had been referring to as ''the burdensome junk'' when I made a startling discovery. The junk was a record of the stages in my life.

title: Suspect Held in Syrup Spill
description: James Francis Polarine has been charged with emptying 400,000 gallons of corn syrup from 27 railroad cars Sept. 3. On Thursday, Mr. Polarine, who is 21 years old, said he and two juveniles had emptied the cars to ''remember this Labor Day,'' the police said. He faces charges conspiracy and mischief charges calling for a maximum of 476 years in prison and a $1 million fine on conviction. Mr. Polarine is being held in $25,000 bail.

title: THE CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: A Cupboard in Rye Far From Bare Widow Haviland's Cupboard is the name given to the year-old gift shop at Rye Square House, an 18th-century building once a tavern and noted in the diary of George Washington and still hard by the village green in the city of Rye. The shop keeps the same hours as the museum, except for Sunday, the year-round, with the door opened by fifth- or sixth-graders in long calico dresses, helpers to the volunteer docents who conduct the individual or group tours and special events.

title: Susan Dayton, a Caterer, Is Wed to Martin O. Olive
description: Susan Comey Dayton, the daughter of Mrs. Frederick H. Owen Jr. of East Hampton, L.I., and Vero Beach, Fla., and the late Daniel L. Dayton Jr. of Upper Brookville, L.I., was married yesterday to Martin Orlo Olive, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Orlo Francis Olive of Corning, Iowa. The Rev. Francis Creamer performed the ceremony at St. Luke's Episcopal Church in East Hampton.

title: ANOTHER U.S. PLAYER IN THE INTERNATIONAL
description: Maxim Dlugy, an 18-year- old international master from Queens, has become the fourth United States player to advance to next year's interzonal round of qualifications for the world championship. Dlugy defeated John Fedorowicz, a Clearwater, Fla. international master, 3 1/2-2 1/2, in a tie-breaking match at the Manhattan Chess Club.

title: Anne Edwards Paddock Is the Bride Of Andrew Schieffelin in Mount Kisco
description: In the Presbyterian Church of Mount Kisco, N.Y., yesterday Anne Edwards Paddock was married to Andrew Lawrence Schieffelin by the Rev. Jack Silvey Miller.

title: MADE IN U.S.S.R.
description: To the Editor:

title: THE DEFENSE DEPARTMENT GOES ON OFFENSE
description: On the wall in the Pentagon office of the Assistant Secretary of Defense for Public Affairs, Michael I. Burch, there hangs a straw boater bearing a ribbon inscribed ''Reagan-Bush '84.'' The white hat is a souvenir that Mr. Burch, who is the chief spokesman for Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger, picked up at the Republican National Convention in Dallas. And it is a not-so-gentle reminder of the part that the Pentagon, especially Mr. Burch's press office, has been playing in the campaign to re-elect President Reagan.

title: PENN ST. STUNS SYRACUSE, 21-3
description: D. J. Dozier rushed for a season-high 159 yards on 22 carries and scored on a 58-yard run to lead Penn State to a 21-3 rout of Syracuse today.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: A Corner of the World

title: DR. CARL F. CORI, WHO WON NOBEL WITH HIS WIFE IN '47, DIES AT 87
description: Dr. Carl F. Cori, the biochemist who shared the Nobel Prize in Medicine in 1947 with his first wife, died yesterday at his home in Cambridge, Mass. He was 87 years old and was active in medical research until his death.

title: LAND SALE TO SAVE VIEW OF HOUSATONIC
description: ON the drive north from Kent to Cornwall on Route 7, there is a point where a traveler is treated to a panoramic view of the Housatonic River Valley, a mile-long stretch of uninterrupted wilderness through which winds the Appalachian Trail.

title: SHOREHAM IS KEY ISSUE IN CARNEY-HOCHBRUECKNER RACE
description: THE Shoreham nuclear power plant, which has been largely a local issue, has become a major issue in the Congressional campaign in the First District in Suffolk County.

title: A CONCESSION ON LATIN MASS
description: In a decision that was praised by traditionalists, the Vatican announced last week that under limited conditions the Roman Catholic Church would permit the celebration of the old-style Latin mass.

title: Stars in Chicago Race
description: A pack of superstars and about 9,000 other runners are expected to take part as America's Marathon/ Chicago makes its debut on national television today. Thousands of spectators are expected to line the streets, and millions more to watch at home.

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN WINDSOR TERRACE
description: The topography of mid-Brooklyn

title: ; LETTERS
description: VICTIMS OF SUPRPRISE MILITARY OPERATIONS

title: RECYCLED IMAGES WITH EERIE ECHOES
description: Richard Prince's photography - or, in his terminology, his ''rephotography'' - seems intentionally designed to straight-arm the viewer. Like a great deal of Minimal and Conceptual art of the 70's, it is reticent about providing pleasure, preferring to err on the side of the cerebral for fear of the sentimental. Indeed, his images can hardly even be called his own: they are photographs of others' photographs, slightly altered recapitulations of pictures he clips from magazines and other mass-media sources. One is hard pressed to imagine a less accessible, more obdurate form of art, and there is little need to wonder why the 35-year-old artist has yet not achieved the public celebrity and national recognition of some of his peers.

title: JERSEY CRIME STATISTICS SHOW 8% DECLINE IN FIRST HALF OF 1984
description: The rate of reported crime fell 8 percent in New Jersey during the first six months of this year, compared with the same period in 1983, according to the state police.

title: SEATTLE SONG TRIUMPS
description: Seattle Song, a 3-year-old son of Seattle Slew who had not won in five previous starts this year, overtook Alphabatim in the stretch and won the $250,000 Washington D.C. International today by three lengths at Laurel Race Course.It was the third consecutive victory for a French entry in the the mile- and-a-half turf race.

title: BLACK AND WHITE
description: It begins with someone saying, ''What if. . . .'' And then it's off to the market. With theme parties, which offer the opportunity to entertain whimsically and elegantly on a large scale, the imagination is the limit. Suppose, for the sake of argument, you decide to celebrate a friend's birthday at the stroke of one minute after midnight. And suppose you decide to do everything in black and white, the same colors as the floor on which the celebrants will gather. It's as easy as soup and fish, which is where one begins.

title: 'MEFISTOFELE' AT CITY OPERA
description: The New York City Opera has

title: Miss Rossman Is Wed To Douglas Kaufman
description: The marriage of Karen Jill Rossman, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome I. Rossman Jr. of Scarsdale, N.Y., to Douglas Goldsmith Kaufman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William E. Kaufman of Armonk, N.Y., took place yesterday at the Sunningdale Country Club in Scarsdale. Rabbi Maurice Davis officiated.

title: RESOURCE RECOVERY:A DILEMMA
description: THEY don't like me in Kearny, and I can't say I blame them. For years, Essex County's 22 municipalities have hauled their garbage to landfills in the neighboring Hudson County town of Kearny, where we deposit some 2,300 tons of it a day.

title: TOXIC LEGACY THAT WON'T GO AWAY
description: AND ROBERT M. SCHWARTZ

title: APOLLO AND THE DWARFS
description: The Apollo Project to land men on the moon presented technology in its best light - an imaginative use of high skills to accomplish a stirring and peaceful purpose. But that high venture began in the subterranean factories of Nazi Germany. And the links between the light and the dark were direct: The project manager for Apollo's Saturn 5 rocket, Arthur Rudolph, turns out to have been the production manager in charge of slave laborers who built the German V-2 missile.

title: A Part-Time Marriage
description: I found Noel Perrin's article, ''A Part-Time Marriage'' (About Men, Sept. 9), a refreshing change from the usual machinations on the subject of companionship. However, the conclusion of his article is amiss. Mr. Perrin equates intimacy with physical proximity, the quality of which is measured in calendar days. The truth may be that the end product of a seven-day-a-week relationship is not intimacy, but rather, stability and continuity, with intimacy sacrificed as the bargaining chip. KIM SUSAN BLAKELY

title: VILLELLA TO OPEN COLLEGE SERIES
description: MONTCLAIR DESPITE his ''official retirement'' in 1974 because of chronic injuries, Edward Villella, considered by many as American ballet's most gifted performer, retained such a strong desire to dance that he is returning to the stage.

title: The P.L.O. At the U.N.
description: Jane Rosen's article, ''The P.L.O.'s Influential Voice at the U.N.'' (Sept. 16), accurately outlines the power arrangements within the United Nations, with the United States and Israel as the main forces of resistance to the Palestine Liberation Organization-Soviet anti-Israel public-opinion campaign. However, the current weakness of the P.L.O., as well as the U.S.S.R.'s problems in Afghanistan, should not invite complacency among supporters of democracy.

title: Abigail Schade Bride Of Paul Arthur Gary
description: Catharine Abigail Schade, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Knorr Schade of Canonsburg, Pa., was married yesterday to Paul Arthur Gary, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard J. Gary of Huntington, L.I. The Rev. Nadine Hunder, a Presbyterian minister, and Rabbi Roy Rosenberg officiated at the ceremony in the Chapel of the Church Center for the United Nations in New York.

title: TRAVEL BOOKSHELF
description: Tuscany: An Anthology

title: Cecelia Fitzpatrick and Peter W. Frame Are Wed
description: At All Souls Unitarian Church in New York yesterday Cecelia Fitzpatrick, an associate director of corporate human resources for Time Inc., and Peter W. Frame, an executive vice president of Home Box Office Inc., were married by the Rev. Richard Leonard.

title: AS ONE TITAN TO ANOTHER
description: Edited by Warren F. Kimball. Illustrated. 3 Volumes. 2,189 pp. New Jersey: Princeton University Press. $125; $150 after Dec. 31.

title: Heiden Bike Winner
description: Some accomplished Olympic bikers were in the field of 70, but when they held the 35-mile Marine Midland Oyster Festival bicycle race over a seven-tenths-of-a- mile course through the streets of Oyster Bay, L.I., yesterday, a former Olympic speed skater was first over the line. Eric Heiden, who won five gold medals in skating at the 1980 Winter Games, completed the race in 1 hour 16 minutes 44.46 seconds, just ahead of John Lovell of Forest Hills, Queens, who finished in 1:16:48.35.

title: A DEATH OFFSTAGE
description: M. S. Kaplan is a freelance writer and critic. MURDER AT THE MET

title: MUSIC: DAVID GARLAND'S 'OPERA IN PROGRESS'
description: David Garland has been presenting experimental-music concerts in lower Manhattan since 1978, two years after he graduated from the Rhode Island School of Design. Since 1980 he has been calling his music ''Control Songs,'' for no entirely clear reason: He says it's because ''the songs are about the things we do to sustain our fragile hope that we are in control of our lives.''

title: LETTERS ON TRAVEL
description: TUNISIA

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: TALKS AROUND COUNTY

title: S.M.U. Upset by Houston
description: A 68-yard pass from Gerald Landry to the tight end Carl Hilton opened a 19- point lead late in the third quarter today and Houston hung on to upset Southern Methodist, 29-20. The victory left Houston (4-2, 3-0) alone atop the Southwest Conference. S.M.U. (4-1, 2-1) suffered only its second regular-season loss in the last three seasons.

title: HOW TV DILUTES POLITICAL DEBATES
description: Television is not just showing us the Presidential and Vice Presidential debates; television is determining how we score them, too. What plays well is what wins. The Founding Fathers may have reckoned that truth would drive out error after careful deliberation, but that was before the cathode ray tube and coaxial cable. Old-style political discourse, imperfect as it was, rested on the assumption that candidates were divided by issues, and by issues they would be judged. New-style television discourse operates under different rules. Do the candidates have presence? Are they showing lots of zip? When we hunker down in our living rooms tonight to watch Ronald Reagan and Walter F. Mondale discuss war and peace, the new rules invite us to be theater critics. It is not the issues we are asked to judge; it is the nuances of the presentation.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN SALZBURG
description: PAUL HOFMANN, the author of ''O Vatican! A Slightly Wicked View of the Holy See'' (Congdon & Weed), is a native of Austria.

title: MARINERS BEAT WAGNER, 34-13
description: Chris Fiore rushed for two touchdowns on runs of 1 and 13 yards and gained 147 yards over all as the unbeaten United States Merchant Marine Academy trounced Wagner, 34-13, yesterday at Fischer Field on Staten Island.

title: SHOOTING PRESERVE AROUSES EAST END DISPUTE
description: ON March 13, 1983, Charles Gilbert conducted his first circle shoot at Teal Pond Farm, the 300-acre property in the East End hamlet of Water Mill that he is licensed by New York State to operate as a shooting preserve.

title: FORGIVE ME, BUT...
description: ''Forgive me,'' President Reagan began recently, ''but judging from the record of those who are philosophically or constitutionally opposed to what we are doing, we might be better off consulting astrologers about what the deficit will be in 1989.''

title: Trust and S.E.C.
description: To the Editor:

title: HIS OWN BEST EXAMPLE
description: Sandra Salmans is a reporter for the Business Day section of The New York Times. WHAT THEY DON'T TEACH YOU AT HARVARD BUSINESS SCHOOL

title: EVADING THE INEVITABLE
description: George F. Kennan did not intend to write ''The Fateful Alliance'' to show the parallels between the diplomatic runup to the First World War and now. ''But as I went on in my research,'' he explained in an interview, ''I became struck with the relevance to the present day.'' His goal was to permit people to see ''what the process of diplomacy was really like, how much personal pride and ambition got in the way, how internal politics affected external policy and the importance of military planning on events.'' To this veteran diplomat and historian, only a handful of the Russian and French leaders were ''able to discern the long-term effects of their decisions, particularly in the military field.'' He called attention to the Russian General Staff's planning paper in the book's appendix as an example of how leaders ''locked themselves into an imaginary war to such an extent that it became quite real.'' He worries about today's leaders making an even more catastrophic error in building nuclear forces for deterrence, but at the same time, thinking and planning to fight and win nuclear wars. But he acknowledges an important difference between then and now in this respect. Then, the generals made ''the crazy plans.'' Today, civilian strategists provide the dangerously imaginary scenarios akin to the mobilization plans for World War I. ''Maybe,'' he reflected, ''the military learned more than the civilians. Perhaps the military now understands there are unlikely to be any victors in any international conflict, whereas many political leaders don't think that at all as they make their appeals to the hard-line constituency.''

title: Sheilah L. Thorn Is the Bride of Prentice Smith Jr.
description: The Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Sheilah Langford Thorn, the daughter of Mrs. Martin R. Flink of Chicago and Norman L. Thorn, to Prentice Kellogg Smith Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Smith of Far Hills, N.J., and Edgartown, Mass. The Rev. Charles Amstein performed the ceremony.

title: COLLECTOR NEARLY TRADES AWAY RARITY
description: New Jersey stamp collector, John Rozycki, was putting together some duplicate stamps to take to his local stamp club meeting not too long ago, to do some trading. He came across two copies of the 1954 30- cent Owens Falls Dam definitive stamp of Kenya-Uganda-Tanganyika and noticed that they differed. Under a magnifying glass. he discovered that one copy showed the dam appearing upside down.

title: RELIGIOUS LEADERS TELL OF WORRY ON ARMAGEDDON VIEW ASCRIBED TO REAGAN
description: ''Ronald Reagan said it as Governor and as President, in his home in the White House, over lunch, over dinner, in the car and over the phone, to religious leaders and lobbyists, to his staff, a Senator and even to People magazine. On at least 11 occasions Ronald Reagan has suggested that the end of the world is coming, and it may be coming soon.''

title: TIME MAGAZINE ASKS JUDGE TO DISMISS SHARON SUIT
description: Time magazine has asked a Federal judge to dismiss a libel suit by Israel's former Defense Minister, Ariel Sharon, who contends the magazine defamed him in an article about the 1982 massacre at two Palestinian refugee camps in Lebanon.

title: IOWA DEALS SCHEMBECHLER WORST DEFEAT
description: It was improbable enough to lead Coach Hayden Fry of Iowa to say, ''Who'd ever dream we'd goose-egg Michigan?''

title: Linerboard Prices
description: To the Editor:

title: Miss Coutrakon Marries Lawyer
description: Elizabeth Coutrakon, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Basil H. Coutrakon of Springfield, Ill., and Robinson B. Lacy, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin H. Lacy of Brookline, Mass., were married yesterday. The Rev. Dr. John Andrew performed the ceremony at St. Thomas Episcopal Church in Manhattan.

title: IDEAS & TRENDS
description: PEACE

title: A NEW SHOW 'ACTIVATES' THE PHILADELPHIA MUSEUM
description: PHILADELPHIA

title: JERSEY VOTERS TO DECIDE 3 PROPOSITIONS ON NOV. 6
description: New Jersey residents will vote Nov. 6 on a $90 million high-technology bond issue, a $60 million bond issue to improve human-services institutions and centers, and an amendment allocating 31 percent of the state's gasoline tax for highway projects.

title: ADAMS SEALS FIRST PLACE
description: Although the score was tied at 14-14 at halftime, John Adams, the defending city champion, turned on its power in the second half and shut down Bayside to win, 35-14, and secure its third consecutive first-place finish in the Queens A division.

title:
DINING OUT;
CHINESE CUISINE IN ARMONK
description: AMONG the many Chinese restaurants celebrating their recent openings up-county, the newly-renovated Flower Dragon in Armonk is probably one of the handsomest. Clever plant-dividers holding a silk lushness of green foliage and white and magenta blossoms, thickly cushioned black-lacquered dining chairs and white linen over plum table skirts with matching napkins strike a harmonious chord against serene dove-gray walls.

title: BUSINESS NOTES
description: A COMMITTEE headed by David J. Sherwood, president of the Prudential Insurance Company of America, and John D. Feehan, chairman of the board of the Pleasantville-based Atlantic Electric Company, is campaigning for passage of a $90 million bond issue on Nov. 6 that would expand the state's capability as a center of high technology.

title: Amy McIlvane Is Wed To Robert Rea Ballard
description: The First Congregational Church in Old Greenwich, Conn., was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Amy Eileen McIlvane, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. McIlvane of Stamford, Conn., and Robert Rea Ballard, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John W. Ballard of Riverside, Conn. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Thomas Stiers, assisted by the Rev. Donald McIlvane, a Roman Catholic priest who is an uncle of the bride.

title: Jersey Man to Head Scouts
description: Ben H. Love, an administrator in the Boy Scouts of America, has been named the new chief Scout executive, the top career position in the 4.7 million-member organization. Mr. Love, who is 54 years old and lives in Princeton Junction, N.J., has headed the organization's Northeast region, based in Dayton, N.J. He will now direct a national staff of 1,000 people in the national headquarters in Irving, Tex.

title: HEADLINERS ; BLAMED IN BOSTON The actress
description: Vanessa Redgrave hasn't worked much lately, and she says the Boston Symphony Orchestra is to blame.

title: MANCHILD IN HARLEM
description: Claude Brown's being left ''momentarily apoplectic'' after arguing with a ''deadly and cynically rational'' manchild, rang a bell with me. As a psychiatric social worker in a welfare hotel, I remember the man who talked to me nostalgically of the House of Detention where he paid no rent and got three meals a day.

title: Disney World Workers Back 3-Year Pact With One Raise
description: Maintenance workers at Walt Disney World have approved a three-year labor contract that includes a pay increase in only the third year but grants cash bonuses in the first two years.

title: THE AGE OF GIANTS A new and strikingly complete skeleton of
description: Homo erectus, a species ancestral to humans, has been found in Kenya by fossil hunter Richard Leakey. Its position between datable layers of volcanic ash puts the owner's death at 1.6 million years ago.

title: A FRAGRANCE EXPLOSION
description: Until recently, no self-respecting perfumer would have thought of introducing a new fragrance that cost as much as $150 an ounce by putting a whiff of it in a magazine ad. The upper end of the $2 billion women's fragrance market has always depended on sales at department stores where women could test the fragrance personally.

title: Manchild In Harlem
description: Claude Brown's article, ''Manchild in Harlem'' (Sept. 16), was devastatingly sad and much more an indictment of our values than about growing up in Harlem. Acquisitiveness is one of the potent forces in American society.

title: NIGERIA HOLDS JERSEY CITY WOMAN
description: IN THE summer of 1983, Marie

title: THE P.L.O. AT THE U.N.
description: How ironic it is that Zehdi Terzi can manipulate the General Assembly in behalf of Yasir Arafat and the P.L.O. when Arafat's view of the United Nations, as stated in The Beirut Daily Star, is as follows: ''Frankly, we have come to consider the United Nations as a kind of circus where so-called representatives of countries perform acts and make speeches for the entertainment of the world audience.'' Jane Rosen's article points out what an adroit circusmaster Zehdi Terzi is. NORMAN WASSERMAN

title: MUSIC: DEBUTS IN REVIEW
description: Recent debut concerts in New York ranged in quality from the exceptional to the tolerable. The most encouraging of them was by the Meliora String Quartet at Alice Tully Hall Sunday night.

title: A NEW FACE AND VOICE, BUT A FAMILIAR THEME
description: Nearly 30 years ago, three young men worked together in the Mobil Corporation's Middle East Department. One was Rawleigh Warner Jr., an urbane, Princeton- educated son of an oil executive. The other two were William P. Tavoulareas and Allen E. Murray, two New Yorkers, complete with the accent, who were pushing their way up from relatively humble beginnings.

title: 'STRANGER THAN PARADISE':ITS STORY COULD BE A MOVIE
description: Picture Cinderella without a ticket on the night of the ball. That was pretty much the situation Jim Jarmusch found himself in last spring at Cannes. Here was a 31-year-old filmmaker who had started out in 1982 with enough left-over film to make a five-minute movie, and had managed to transform it first into a 30-minute short and then into a 90-minute feature, ''Stranger Than Paradise,'' that had been chosen for exhibition at the world's most prestigious film festival.

title: ONWARD AND UPWARD FOR THE TELEPHONE
description: Richard Levine and Katherine Roberts

title: GOING FOR IT AT THE PENTAGON
description: Defense Department officials confirmed last week that when the skirmishing over the budget for fiscal year 1986 begins in earnest in a few weeks, their opening bid may be as high as $333.7 billion. That is almost 14 percent more than the $292.9 military budget for fiscal '85 that Congress approved last week.

title: L.S.U. STOPS KENTUCKY, 36-10
description: Dalton Hilliard rushed for 164 yards and a school record-tying four touchdowns as Louisiana State overcame five first-half turnovers and handed Kentucky its first defeat, 36-10, today. Kentucky (5-1, 1-1) had achieved its best start in 34 years.

title: FOR DEVELOPERS, AN EARLY LINE ON ZONING
description: IT is axiomatic among land-use planners

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: TRICENTENNIAL CONCERTS

title: MASTERS IN MAKING CHAIRS
description: Some furniture collectors covet chairs more than other designs because they are the most personal, the most provocative and the most difficult of all to produce.

title: FIRE HEIGHTENS CONCERN OVER PCB
description: A SERIOUS fire in Oceanside last July has heightened concern about the potential for similar accidents involving the toxic chemicals known as PCB's. In that incident, firefighters were exposed to PCB's (polychlorinated biphenyls) in the smoke from burning transformers at the Long Island Lighting Company's Barrett generating plant in Oceanside.

title: IN CITY, AIDS AFFECTING DRUG USERS MORE OFTEN
description: Recent cases of AIDS reported in New York City show that, proportionally, fewer homosexuals and more intravenous drug users are contracting the deadly immune disorder, according to Dr. David J. Sencer, the city's Health Commissioner.

title: FLOATING A PLAZA
description: Conventional shopping-center-development wisdom says that malls need ''anchors'' - the large department, food or home-improvement stores that pull in shoppers.

title: CEAUSESCU OF RUMANIA CROSSES EAST-WEST GAP
description: Rumania's Nicolae Ceausescu rarely misses an opportunity to strengthen his claim to the title of outstanding maverick among Eastern Europe's leaders. Last week, he did so again, making a three-day visit to West Germany that was notable because two other leaders in the region, Erich Honecker of East Germany and Todor Zhikov of Bulgaria, had recently canceled long-planned trips to Bonn.

title: PROGRAM SEEKS TO AVERT TEEN-AGE PREGNANCY
description: SONIA is 16 years old and she has learned that she is going to have a baby. She is not married, and she is frightened. Marianne was 18 when she learned she was going to have a baby. She was not married. She was frightened.

title: Army and E.P.A. Agree On Arsenal Cleanup Plan
description: The Army and the Environmental Protection Agency have agreed on a $500 million plan to detoxify the Rocky Mountain Arsenal, Representative Ken Kramer said today.

title: Reagan Signs Arms Measure
description: President Reagan has signed the $292.9 billion defense spending bill for fiscal 1985, a compromise measure he said would mean preserving the peace ''at a reduced pace'' because he got substantially less than he wanted.

title: Accuser Sentenced
description: Charles McGinley, who filed one of the assault charges that led to Mark Gastineau's conviction on a misdemeanor count, was sentenced to four years to life on a cocaine conviction unrelated to the Gastineau case. Gastineau said he was sorry to hear about it. ''I never like anybody going to jail,'' he said.

title: IRISH SAID TO SINK SPANISH TRAWLER
description: Irish fishery patrol boats opened fire on a Spanish trawler in a confrontation that developed after the vessel was found fishing illegally in Irish waters, Irish officials said here today.

title: PAGNOZZI LEADS UNBEATEN CRESSKILL
description: Gene Pagnozzi passed for two touchdowns and Vincent Spina ran for two more when Cresskill (5-0) blanked Weehawken, 31-0, yesterday in Weehawken.

title: OPULENT 'VOLPONE' STAGED
description: THE Nassau Repertory Theater is making an auspicious beginning for its 10th anniversary season with an opulent production of Ben Jonson's classic comedy, ''Volpone.'' This Elizabethan play about avarice and the lust for gold chronicles the shameless doings of a sly old fox named Volpone, who manages to put into effect the lazy daydream of staying home, relaxing in bed, while money comes to him.

title: EL SALVADOR GETS BRIEF GLIMPSE OF PEACE
description: The men of El Salvador interrupted four years of killing last week, but only for a moment. Unarmed leaders from both sides got together and took a hesitant first step toward peace. Then they went back to warmaking.

title: Keats Van A. Johnson Married to G.P. Landis
description: Keats Van Alstyne Johnson, a daughter of Edward Fuller Johnson of Bay Head, N.J., and New York and Joan Van Alstyne Johnson of Englewood, N.J., and Point O'Woods, Fire Island, L.I., was married yesterday to Gregory Paul Landis, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Edward Landis of Bethesda, Md. The Rev. James Steele performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church in Englewood.

title: THE FESTIVAL MAKES A POTENT CASE FOR PRESERVATION
description: Perhaps more important than any other aspect of the 22d New York Film Festival, which ended a week ago today at Lincoln Center, was the emphasis it placed on film preservation - in all its forms. Film preservation is not ordinarily the sort of topic that rivets attention. It's not what people talk about at dinner parties. More than any of the other arts, movies are for the here and now. People want to see and talk about this week's hit to the exclusion of just about everything else. We have our repertory theaters, of course, but even they tend to cater to fads, showing over and over the old films that, at the moment, happen to be in.

title: NEW JERSEYANS
description: or his likeness, at any rate - is back in Washington, this time across the street from the White House in a Presidential arts and crafts exhibition.

title: CENTER AIDS VICTIMS OF 'GUTHRIE' DISEASE
description: NEW BRUNSWICK ONE OF Clara Martin's shoes kept falling off as she sat in the clinic conference room, crossing and uncrossing her legs. Her arms jerked suddenly up or out, as if yanked by invisible strings.

title: HARMS PLAZA; NEW LOOK DUE
description: -high scaffolding and a heavy odor of fresh paint, the John Harms Plaza Theatre here has begun its 1984-85 season.

title: VERBATIM: MRS THATCHER ON TERRORISMVerbatim: Mrs. Thatcher on Terrorism
description: Political leaders 'must never, never be stopped from going among the people by a few men of violence, because that is just what they want.'

title: EX-NAZI DENIES ROLL IN DEATHS OF SLAVE LABORERS
description: Arthur Rudolph, a German-born engineer who helped pioneer some of America's boldest ventures in space, denied today that he had persecuted slave laborers in a Nazi rocket installation where he worked during World War II.

title: REACHING ACROSS TO CHINA
description: ''I ALWAYS feel that everybody has a responsibility toward the community he lives in,'' said Tun-Hsu McCoy of Setauket. And one of the communities inhabited by Dr. McCoy - familiarly known as Martha - is the world at large.

title: KEY AIDES DISPUTE U.S. ROLE IN NICARAGUAN VOTE
description: The Reagan Administration, while publicly criticizing the Nov. 4 elections in Nicaragua as ''a sham,'' has privately argued against the participation of the leading opposition candidate for fear his involvement would legitimize the electoral process, according to some senior Administration officials.

title:
BUSINESS FORUM;
MARKETS WOULD FLOURISH WITH REAGAN
description: Wall Street markets would react favorably to the widely-anticipated Reagan- Bush victory next month. Although the immediate market effects of the election have been largely discounted, lower interest rates and higher stock prices could be anticipated over the next several years.

title: MART EXPANSION SPLITS TOWN
description: -lined Lake Avenue in St. James has become a battleground, pitting those who want to maintain the status quo against those who say they want to revitalize the downtown business area.

title: THE CHILDREN LEAD THE WAY IN A SEASON OF DISCOVERIES
description: THE first night of vacation I was awakened by plaintive moans from above. It must be one of the children, I thought, alarmed by the strange cast and slant of the room, windows where there were none the night before, unexpected lights, foreboding shadows.

title: STATE'S NEW MISSING PERSONS AGENCY GOES INTO OPERATION
description: ON A recent afternoon, Sgt. Bernard M. Poggioli, head of the Youth Services Unit of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, stood on the roof of the bus terminal on Manhattan's Eighth Avenue, scanning the crowds below for faces from missing-persons posters.

title: ANOTHER ROUND OF NOBELS
description: Perhaps nothing in modern science inspires quite as much guesswork as who will win the Nobel Prizes. Nominators are a tight- lipped bunch, and the process by which the Swedish Academy of Science and Stockholm's Karolinska Institute cull through candidates' credentials is a carefully guarded secret. Still, many expected this year's award for medicine to go to three immunologists - Dr. Cesar Milstein of England, Dr. Georges J.F. K"ohler of Switzerland and Dr. Niels K. Jerne, who was born in Britain and raised in Denmark - for their work developing monoclonal antibodies, biological bullets that may one day be used to ''seek and destroy'' cancer cells. Last week, it did.

title: KINGSTON SHUT DOWN BY N. ROCKLAND
description: Joe Casarella's North Rockland team moved to the front of what he called ''the dinosaur league'' with a 24-0 victory over previously undefeated Kingston.

title: NINE SEATS IN ASSEMBLY CONTESTED
description: -business men, a college professor, an electrician and the Mayor of Peekskill are among the challengers to the county's incumbent State Assemblymen in the Nov. 6 election.

title: THE ROLLING STONES EMERGE IN AN EVOCATIVE EDITION
description: ''The Rolling Stones,'' a limited edition boxed set of 11 Stones albums from the 1960's in special audiophile pressings, is the latest rock collection from Mobile Fidelity Sound Lab, the company whose earlier compilations of albums by the Beatles and Frank Sinatra have become collectors' items. The continuing popularity of vintage Stones albums made the group seem a logical choice for canonization in Mobile Fidelity's series of Original Master Recordings, which are transferred directly from each session's original master tapes using the most up-to-date American and Japanese technology and the purest, most durable vinyl compound money can buy.

title: RUTGERS CAPTURES FIFTH VICTORY
description: What otherwise would be described as ear-shattering noise was the sound of music to Rutgers today. The cannon that sits on the bluff overlooking the stadium is fired every time the Scarlet Knights score, and it boomed often in appreciation of an offense that in previous games had trouble in finding the end zone but produced a 38-21 victory over Louisville.

title: FRENCH REPORTER IS GIVEN 18-YEAR TERM BY AN AFGHAN COURT
description: A French television reporter captured by Soviet troops in Afghanistan last month has been sentenced to 18 years in prison by a ''special revolutionary court'' in Afghanistan, the official Kabul radio said today.

title: EUBIE!
description: Music by Eubie Blake. Conceived and directed by Juliette Boyd. With Gregory and Maurice Hines, Lynnie Godfrey, Terri Burrell, Alaina Reed. 1984.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: A VICTORIAN gazebo has been erected in Tibbits Park in White Plains. The structure, named for the late Edwin G. Michaelian, who served as Mayor of White Plains from 1950 through 1957 and as County Executive from 1958 through 1973, was put up by the White Plains Beautification Foundation, a nonprofit group active in the city for more than 30 years.

title: BIDDING ON L.I. TRANSPORTATION WORK PLANNED
description: State officials say they will seek bids for up to $100 million for transportation improvement projects on Long Island over the next six months.

title: SECOND ONLY TO PUSHKIN
description: David Bethea, the author of ''Khodasevich,'' teaches at the University of Wisconsin, Madison, and directs the Middlebury College Russian School. MIKHAIL LERMONTOV: MAJOR POETICAL WORKS

title: BID FOR NOISE CONTROL REJECTED
description: ALTHOUGH tests at 25 Westchester locations along the New England Thruway have shown that Federal noise standards were exceeded at 23 of them, officials in charge of the road have rejected requests by local municipal officials for the erection of noise barriers, contending that the money is not available.

title:
BOOKS AND BUSINESS;
A CALL FOR CHANGE
description: Myron Kandel is the financial editor of the Cable News Network. THE ADAPTIVE CORPORATION

title: Hilary Mills Wed To B. J. Lambert
description: At St. James' Episcopal Church in Upper Montclair, N.J., yesterday Hilary Frances Mills, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James T. Mills of Upper Montclair, was married to Brian John Lambert, a son of Maura Curran Lambert and Robert Lambert, both of Cleveland.

title: DEEP IN THE HEART OF TEXAS, PACKAGES MOVE SLOWLY AND GO AWRY
description: Every weekday at noon a big pink 18-wheeler pulls out of the Mary Kay Cosmetics plant in Dallas. The truck is loaded with 300 packages full of Day Radiance, Magic Masque and other products going to its ''beauty consultants,'' as the company calls its sales people, throughout the state of Texas.

title: WHITNEY, MUSKETS AND MYTHS
description: To the Editor:

title: Douglas Paul Is Wed To Pamela D'Orsaneo
description: Pamela DeGroot D'Orsaneo, the daughter of Mrs. John F. DeGroot of Dallas, Tex., and the late Mr. DeGroot, was married yesterday to Douglas Allan Paul, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene F. Paul of Chicago. The Rev. Robert Helm performed the Presbyterian ceremony at the Carlyle Hotel in New York.

title: Jacqueline Bongiorno Weds
description: Jacqueline Elizabeth Henes Bongiorno, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Martin E. Henes of Denville, N.J., was married yesterday to James Stephen Burns, a son of Mrs. David A. Burns of Chicago and the late Mr. Burns. The Rev. Carl Nelson officiated at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church. Mr. Burns is group president of Becton Dickinson & Company, manufacturer of medical supplies in Paramus, N.J. His previous marriage ended in divorce, as did his wife's.

title: A REAL STRAW POLL ON THE PRESIDENCY

title: More on the Marathon
description: Mayor Koch and Fred Lebow have had another dispute. The Mayor is ''distressed'' over references to his involvement in the New York City Marathon by Mr. Lebow, the president of the New York Road Runners Club, which organizes the Marathon.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article Oct. 7 about a Congressional measure that establishes protected wetlands along the Connecticut coastline listed the bill's sponsors incompletely. It should have included three Connecticut Republicans - Representative Stewart B. McKinney (the bill's author), Representative William R. Ratchford and Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr.

title: AS UNREST RISES AND POUND FALLS, THATCHER FACES BIGGEST GHALLENGE
description: Britain is embattled, with problems pressing in on every side, to a degree unparalleled since Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher took power in a political upheaval five years ago.

title:
DINING OUT;
A STAR IS BORN IN MORRISTOWN
description: THREE years ago, the Grand Cafe in Morristown was given two stars by this reviewer. It was described at that time as, and still is, an upscale bistro with a brass-rail bar in front and a dining room to the rear of the building, much in the same manner as some of the better small French restaurants in Manhattan.

title: Donna Burns Is the Bride Of William J. Charlton 3d
description: Donna Marie Burns and William James Charlton 3d were married yesterday at St. John's Roman Catholic Church of Noroton in Darien, Conn.

title: GIANTS' MANUEL A QUIET THREAT
description: At Bassett High School in Rancho Cucamonga, Calif., and in his two years at Citrus Junior College in Azusa, Calif., Lionel Manuel was a sprintout and option quarterback.

title: PERFECTIBILITARIAN
description: WILLIAM GODWIN

title: ODES TO THAT ENDLESS SUBJECT
description: ''DON'T knock the weather,'' warned Frank McKinney Hubbard. ''Nine-tenths of the people couldn't start a conversation if it didn't change once in a while.''

description: WHITE PLAINS

title: WEAK TEAMS ARE GETTING STRONGER
description: IN a move to provide additional revenue, the National

title: Art
description: Mary Cassatt has a double reputation. She is universally agreed to have been a very good judge of French late 19th-century painting.

description: ARMS CONTROL FOR BEGINNERS

description: To the Editor:

title: Arizona School Goes 1 for 46 PHOENIX, Ariz., Oct. 20
description: To the cries of ''One in

title: YALE OUTLASTS COLUMBIA, 28-21
description: The latest game in one of the oldest rivalries in college football ended in exciting, but familiar fashion today. Yale beat Columbia, 28-21, in the 62d meeting of the schools, who first met in 1872.

title: IN SHORT
description: FICTION

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE;
description: LIDDY IN MONTCLAIR

title: News of the Island On Television
description: I read with great interest the article on Long Island television news (''Cablevision Plans Major News Show,'' Sept. 16). The main question raised was: ''Should Long Island have its own nightly television news program?'' I join with others who say, ''Absolutely yes!''

title: Dr. Elliott Rose, Miss Rabinowitz Exchange Vows
description: The marriage of Susan Gail Rabinowitz, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Herbert Rabinowitz of Ardsley, N.Y., to Dr. Elliott Rose, a plastic and reconstructive surgeon in private practice in Burlingame, Calif., took place yesterday at Temple Rodeph Sholom in New York. Rabbi Gunter Hirschberg performed the ceremony.

title: Animated Films
description: ''The Best of Zagreb/Toronto '84,'' a selection of award-winning films from the International Animation Festival, will be screened Nov. 1-8 at the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West 53d Street.

title: THE HIGHLANDS
description: To the Editor:

title: Linda S. Rogers Becomes a Bride
description: Linda Susan Rogers, a daughter of Susan S. Rogers and the late Thomas W. Rogers of Ballston Spa, N.Y., was married yesterday to Andrew Safran, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Melvin H. Safran of New York and Ocean, N.J. Associate Justice Theodore R. Kupferman of the Appellate Division, New York Supreme Court, performed the ceremony at Harkness House, 4 East 75th Street.

title: THE CONTROVERSY OVER APARTMENT TAX BREAKS
description: The program known in government circles as ''421-a'' may sound obscure and bureaucratic. But according to its proponents, 421-a has changed the face of Manhattan since it was enacted 13 years ago. To stimulate the construction of apartment buildings in New York City - both rental and cooperative or condominium - developers have been granted property tax abatements on a declining scale over 10 years.

title: THE GOOD LIFE, PORTUGUESE STYLE
description: MARVINE HOWE, who was a correspondent for The Times in Portugal, is now a reporter on the metropolitan staff.

title: NEARLY THIRD OF REAL PROPERTY IN STATE ON TAX-EXEMPT ROLLS
description: Nearly a third of the value of real property in New York State is at least partly tax exempt, according to the State Board of Equalization and Assessment.

title: COALITION SAYS YELLOWSTONE NEEDS ELBOW ROOM
description: With 2.2 million acres of pine-covered mountains, tall prairie and snow-fed rivers surrounding its famous geysers, Yellowstone National Park is one of the nation's most brilliant natural jewels, larger than Delaware and Rhode Island combined.

title: Penn and His Spouse Become U.S. Citizens
description: More than 300 years after they founded Pennsylvania, the English Quaker William Penn and his wife, Hannah, are honorary American citizens.

title: MONDALE AND REAGAN MAKE SHARP POLICY ATTACKS
description: President Reagan and Walter F. Mondale exchanged final predebate broadsides today, criticizing each other's competence in foreign affairs and warning that the nation's security was at stake in the coming election.

title: Thomson Shoots a 69, Leads Seniors by Shot
description: Peter Thomson of Australia started the second round of the $200,000 Seniors International golf tournament with three straight birdies and posted a three-under-par 69 for 135 and a one-shot lead today.

title: ISRAEL HAS GRIM CHOICE IN LEBANON
description: Almost 30 months after launching an invasion into Lebanon, Israeli policymakers find their options in that country reduced to three choices - bad, worse and worst.

title: S. CAROLINA BEATS NOTRE DAME
description: South Carolina stunned Notre Dame, 36-32, and achieved its best start in the school's history with a 6-0 record. The loss dropped the Irish to 3-4 and marked the first time since 1956 that the Irish had lost three consecutive home games.

title: A PART-TIME MARRIAGE
description: Hurrah for a brilliant idea - the four-day-a-week marriage. I am a full-time businesswoman, part-time educator and a triple-time mother. I would like nothing more than to be remarried if it could only be for four days a week! BARBARA G. SAMET

title: Sandra Spizziri Betrothed
description: Announcement has been made by Sandra S. Spizziri of Wyckoff, N.J., and John A. Spizziri of Franklin Lakes, N.J., of the engagement of their daughter, Victoria-Jean Spizziri, to Robert John Ott, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Reginald Ott of Wyckoff, N.J.

title: ALBERTA
description: Alberta

title: Two Die in Helicopter Crash
description: Two Customs Service officers, Morley Miller, 57 years old, of El Paso, and John Hollingsworth, 37, of Big Bend National Park, died in a helicopter crash today while searching for drug smugglers, the authorities said. A witness said the helicopter appeared to be having engine trouble just before it went down.

title: COURT ORDERS CO-OP TO SAY WHY IT REJECTS APPLICANTS
description: AFEDERAL district judge in Brooklyn

title: FRESH VIEWS OF CLASSIC COMPOSERS GET A HEARING
description: Paul Turok writes frequently about recorded music.

title: Sports of The Times ; For Vidmar, Life Goes On
description: PETER VIDMAR realized his life had changed a few days after the Summer Games ended in August. He and his wife, Donna, a former gymnast, were driving up the California coast to drop off a pet for boarding while they took a post-Olympic tour.

title: Peter B. Van Syckle Wed To Janet Gayle Richards
description: Janet Gayle Richards, a daughter of Col. Howard W. Richards, U.S.A. retired, and Mrs. Richards of Falls Church, Va., was married yesterday to Peter B. Van Syckle , a son of Dr. and Mrs. Guy W. Van Syckle of Newtown, Conn. The Rev. Leslie Smith performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church in Glen Ridge, N.J.

title: THE CASE AGAINST LIBERATION THEOLOGY
description: Michael Novak, resident scholar in religion, philosophy and public policy at the American Enterprise Institute in Washington, is the author of ''Freedom With Justice: Catholic Social Thought and Liberal Institutions,'' to be published next month.

title: DISABILITY: THE FORGOTTEN INSURANCE
description: These days only the poor or the foolhardy

title: GULF WAR: IRAN'S PUSH IS LIMITED
description: Western intelligence officers say they doubt that an Iranian ground drive against Iraqi positions on the northern front this week was a prelude to a major offensive in the four-year-old war with Iraq. The drive, which began before midnight Wednesday night, was followed yesterday by what Teheran's official press agency described as ''limited attacks'' intended to clear the high ground around Meimak in the mountains 70 miles northeast of Baghdad.

title: Miss Harrity Has Nuptials
description: Gail Mitchell Harrity, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Johnstone Harrity of Rosemont, Pa., was married yesterday to Sheldon Tilney, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Norcross Sheldon Tilney of Cedarhurst, L.I., and Palm Beach, Fla. The Rev. Timothy Pickering performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Redeemer in Bryn Mawr, Pa.

title: THE HIGHEST LEGAL AUTHORITY ENTERS CHURCH-STATE DEBATE
description: Even before the Supreme Court term opened this month, it was evident that the Justices, no less than the rest of the country, were acutely interested in questions of church and state. Already on the Court's agenda were three religion cases, each with the potential to produce a major decision.

title: AGENCY REJECTS CONSULTANTS WHO ASSAILED TIMES SQ. PLAN
description: The State Urban Development Corporation has reversed a decision to hire a Brooklyn consulting company, citing the company's work on a report that may be used in lawsuits challenging the Times Square redevelopment plan.

title: MANCHILD IN HARLEM
description: Claude Brown's article on Harlem is a superb piece of fiction - all the details have been carefully selected to fit Mr. Brown's personal apocalyptic vision of Harlem.

title: A DOSE OF STRONG MEDICINE
description: THE DOCTOR STORIES

title:
MUSIC;
NEW WORK TO BE HEARD AT FREE CONCERT
description: THE second annual ''Hardly Any Sampson Music Festival,'' a concert of new and not-so-new 20th-century music organized by the Morristown composer and trumpeter David Sampson, focuses attention on New Jersey composers, in addition to injecting some humor into the contemporary music scene.

title: PARRISH MUSEUM BECKONS TO WIDER AREA
description: ROCCO LICCARDI, a Bridgehampton artist, believes in spontaneity. So Saturday at about 8 P.M., he and a fellow artist, John McCaffrey, and Maureen Liccardi, his sister-in-law, will don white outfits - their canvas, so to speak - and proceed to drip paints all over one another.

title: THE UNION OF AKEEM AND RALPH
description: THE third lesson of what had already been a long and

title: U.S.F.L. TRIMS TO 14 TEAMS
description: The United States Football League moved closer to a 14- team league today through consolidation of six of its franchises into three and an apparent one-season vacation for a fourth.

title: BUCKLING DOWN THE SWASH
description: Michael Malone is the author of ''Uncivil Seasons,'' a novel. THE PYRATES

title: 'AGE ISSUE' A MYTH
description: If Ronald Reagan should again stumble in tonight's debate, the spurious ''age issue'' will be back with all its destructive potential. That the ''age issue'' was raised in the first place says more about our social prejudices than about the President's - or any other older person's - mental acuity.

title: POP: BRUCE COCKBURN'S BAND
description: Bruce Cockburn, the Canadian singer, composer and guitarist, writes vibrant impressionistic songs that combine Christian mysticism and leftist politics with illuminating flashes of imagery. Acclaimed in his homeland, Mr. Cockburn's work is too complex to have enjoyed significant commercial success in the United States beyond his one 1980 pop- reggae hit, ''Wondering Where the Lions Are.''

title: SKELETON UPSETS AN ANCIENT BIAS
description: A skeleton of a ''strapping'' young male was turning archeological heads last week, and changing some minds about the stature of our earliest ancestors. At an announcement of the discovery in Washington and Nairobi, fossil hunters said the collection of bones found near a lake in northern Kenya was 1.6 million years old and belonged to a Homo erectus that died at the age of 12 and stood about 5 feet 4 inches tall.

title: DEERFIELD (4-1)ROUTS INJURY-HAMPERED EXETER, 17-0
description: It was Parents' Day at Exeter yesterday and a large crowd was on hand at the football field to see the undefeated home team make Deerfield its fifth straight victim. But they had little to cheer about as the visitors (4-1) blanked their side, 17-0.

title: SUITING UP IN HONG KONG
description: MICHAEL SPECTER recently completed a year in Asia as a correspondent for the Far Eastern Economic Review on a Henry R. Luce Fellowship.

title: German Missile Protest Attracts Thin Crowds
description: Thin crowds turned out in West Germany today for demonstrations that tried to link the faltering antimissile movement with the issue of high unemployment.

title: SYNAGOGUE MARKS 125TH ANNIVERSARY
description: WHEN the year-long 125th anniversary celebration of Temple Anshe Emeth begins today, its members will be marking not only the birthday of one of the oldest synagogues in the state, but also their decision to remain here.

title: THE CITI SLEEPS AT THE SWITCH
description: I returned from a trip the other day to find that Citibank had bounced a perfectly good check I had written to the Internal Revenue Service. The notice included a phone number to call. I called.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''This is the end of the road for this group.'' - Jean-Michel Monod, head of the regional delegation of the International Committee of the Red Cross in Bangkok, Thailand. (1:5.)

title: 13 Food Outlets Cited by City For Violations of Health Code
description: The New York City Department of Health cited 13 food establishments last week for violating the health code.

title: THE DEBATE AND THE SPIN DOCTORS
description: Tonight at about 9:30, seconds after the Reagan-Mondale debate ends, a bazaar will suddenly materialize in the press room of the Kansas City Municipal Auditorium. A dozen men in good suits and women in silk dresses will circulate smoothly among the reporters, spouting confident opinions. They won't be just press agents trying to impart a favorable spin to a routine release. They'll be the Spin Doctors, senior advisers to the candidates, and they'll be playing for very high stakes. How well they do their work could be as important as how well the candidates do theirs.

title: Felt Design
description: To the Editor:

title: 30-SECOND POLITICS
description: Adam Clymer , assistant to the executive editor of The New York Times, is in charge of the newspaper's political polling. PACKAGING THE PRESIDENCY

title: RALLY BY RANGERS TOPS CAPTIALS, 6-5
description: The Rangers survived all the transformations this hectic game underwent tonight and, as a result, they claimed their first victory of the season. They beat the Wahington Capitals, 6-5, in a game that turned when Ron Greschner was struck by the blade of a stick.

title: HAILED IN NEW YORK If the Asante people no longer wield the power that once enabled them to dominate the so-called Gold Coast of West Africa, it was not apparent in the greeting accorded their tribal King,
description: Otumfuo Opoku Ware II , when he visited New York last week.

title: EXHIBIT OF CHINESE ART PORTRAYS LANDSCAPE ILLUSIONS;
description: The rain was steady and drenching one afternoon in Hangzhou on our trip to the People's Republic of China, the sort of day in which one might wish to stay indoors and contemplate a brush painting or two. But Tom Everett was not to be denied.

title: BARRIO HOUSING
description: A 107-unit apartment house is now going up at 127 East 107th Street in East Harlem, a part of the city where little residential construction has occurred in recent years. To be known as Lexington Gardens, the eight-story building is being developed as Section 8 housing.

title: FATHER WAS HARD TO BEAR
description: SAY GOODBYE TO SAM

title: Norm of 4 Days' Rest Limits Aces in Series
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Peace Corps Volunteer Is Killed in Philippines
description: An American Peace Corps volunteer on the central Philippine island of Cebu was shot and killed at his beachfront cottage during an apparent robbery this week, the authorities said today.

title: LATIN NAVAL HELP IS SOUGHT BY U.S.
description: The United States Navy has begun an effort to enlist Latin American navies in warding off what officers describe as a maritime threat from the Soviet Union, Cuba and Nicaragua.

title: UNION ACCEPTS G.M. CONTRACT
description: The outcome seemed iffy at times, but last week the United Auto Workers announced that its members had ratified a new contract with the General Motors Corporation.

title: HUNTINGTON REMAINS UNBEATEN
description: Huntington and Comsewogue remained undefeated atop the League IV standing yesterday as both registered narrow victories over strong league opponents.

title: FAMILY SERVICE, 30, CONTINUES GROWTH
description: FAMILY SERVICE of Westchester, the nonprofit agency that each year serves 6,000 people in the county, opened its doors in October 1954 with two employees - Irwin Stein, the executive director, and his secretary. The secretary is gone, but Mr. Stein is still executive director and he has more than a few memories.

title: THE DOOMSDAY MACHINE OF 1914
description: THE FATEFUL ALLIANCE

title: Arthur Schwartz Honored
description: A musical tribute to the composer Arthur Schwartz will be held tomorrow at noon at the Majestic Theater, 247 West 44th Street. Among the performers scheduled to take part are Tony Bennett, Ann Reinking, Jerry Ohrbach, Nelson Riddle, Dinah Shore and Bobby Short. Mr. Schwartz died on Sept. 3 at the age of 83.

title: BROWN TRIUMPHS
description: Steve Kettelberger carried 18 times for 128 yards, including a 55-yard touchdown run, as Brown handed Cornell its fifth straight loss, a 13-9 decision in Ivy League football today.

title: YOUNG COACH BIDS CHAMPIONSHIP SEASON
description: NEW ROCHELLE ''WHEN I became coach of our junior varsity football team here at Iona Prep last fall,'' said Rob Spence, ''I kept telling my players that no one was too young to learn. They must have heard me because they won eight straight after losing their opening game.''

title: CONSUMER RATES
Coetzee-Page Dec. 1
description: Gerrie Coetzee, the South African who holds the World Boxing Association heavyweight title, will defend it against Greg Page at the Sun City resort in Bophuthatswana Dec. 1, according to a hotel magnate, Sol Kerzner.

title: 1980 CUBAN REFUGEES GAIN ON CITIZENSHIP CLAIM
description: More than 125,000 Cubans from the 1980 refugee influx may become permanent United States residents under a 1966 law, the Justice Department has decided. But the action will not help thousands of Haitian refugees in the same situation.

title: 650 Traps Catch 3 Mice
description: Biologists set 650 traps baited with peanut butter but caught only three Perdido Key beach mice along the Gulf Coast, indicating that the threatened species might be even rarer than expected, the Federal Fish and Wildlife Service says. It is removing the mice from the path of bulldozers clearing the area while the Interior Department considers declaring the species endangered. ''The fact that we found only three mice tells us the population is low,'' Robin Fields, a biologist, said Thursday.

title: INSTALLING WEATHERSTRIPPING
description: EFFICIENT weatherstripping around windows and doors is one of the least expensive ways of cutting down on heat losses and eliminating cold drafts inside the house during cold weather. Unfortunately, some windows and doors have no weatherstripping around them at all. In many older homes the weatherstripping that is there has long since lost its effectiveness and should be replaced.

title: Carla Mangini Marries
description: Carla Mangini, a daughter of Jerome J. Mangini of Darien, Conn., and the late Suzanne Scheffer Mangini, was married yesterday to Randall Hugo Rolin, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth C. Rolin of Cocoa, Fla. The Rev. William D. Donovan performed the ceremony at St. John's Roman Catholic Church of Noroton in Darien. Mrs. Rolin's father, who is retired, was a vice president of Waldenbooks in Stamford, Conn. Mr. Rolin is a vice president of Dearling Ltd., a musical production company in New York, of which he is also director of music and composition. His father is president of the Design Machine Tool Company in Titusville, Fla.

title: AUTUMN RITES IN A MARSH
description: THE fiddler crab scuttles across the cold sand. Overhead, a gull leans on one wing. In the late afternoon's light, he hesitates, uncertain, while the crab wins shelter in the tall grass at the marsh's edge.

title: BEYOND HIBACHI, SERENITY OF SUSHI
description: LITTLE by little, the discovery of the joys of sushi, sashimi and other Japanese dishes is spreading through the state. The newest outpost is Kabuki, a combination Japanese steakhouse and sushi bar in Danbury. Lodged in a colonial-style house, the restaurant has been partly transformed into a touch of Japan. Two large dining rooms cater to the chop- chop, grill-grill, razzle-dazzle of cooking at the table, hibachi style. The smell of cooking oil in these somewhat cavernous rooms is oppressive, and better ventilation is needed.

title: Rival Factions in Chad Gather to Talk in Congo
description: Delegations from the feuding factions in Chad met here today for talks aimed at ending their civil war.

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: THE writer William Styron is one of the four winners of the Connecticut Arts Awards this year. Mr. Styron, who has lived in Roxbury since 1958, won a Pulitzer Prize in 1968 for his book ''Confessions of Nat Turner.''

title: COLD CLIMATE
description: Crested Butte, Colo., is a 9,000- foot-high former mining town in the Rocky Mountains whose modern-day mother lode comes in the form of winter skiers. Here, the cadence of life is measured not by the hour but rather by the number of slope runs made in a day. From Thanksgiving to nearly Easter, the tiny Victorian-style village becomes, in every sense, a nonstop winter carnival.

title: On theWaterfront.
description: Starring Marlon Brando, Eva Marie Saint, Lee J. Cobb, Rod Steiger, Martin Balsam. Written by Budd Schulberg. Directed by Elia Kazan. 1954.

title:
ANTIQUES;
WHEN THIS WAS THE 'CLOCK' STATE
description: AN exhibit of 18th- and 19th- century clocks, featuring 80 rare tall-case and shelf clocks, traces the transition between handmade examples and the first mass-produced shelf clocks.

title: Cable TV
description: A melodic treat this cable week is the batch of '30's and '40's ballads that flavor ''With a Song in My Heart'' (1952), a reasonably sensible drama with Susan Hayward, as Jane Froman, expertly simulating the vocals. (Wednesday at 8 A.M. and 6 P.M. and Saturday at 1 P.M. on MAX.) Hollywood ''ghosting'' is standard procedure but it's tricky, intricate business.

title: Party Leader Is Killed In Alberta Plane Crash
description: Grant Notley, leader of the New Democratic Party in Alberta, and five other people were killed in the crash ot their twin-engine plane, the provincial government reported today.

title: JACKSON'S ONE SURE LEGACY IS NEW VOTERS
description: It's harvest time, and both Esther Arroyo-Gonzales Buckley of Laredo, Tex., and Esther Mitchell of New York City are ready. Their tools will not be tractors, balers or combines, but telephones, van pools, lists of names and leaflets, to reap newly registered black and Hispanic-American voters.

title: HEAVY CASELOADS ARE SAID TO ENDANGER CHILDREN
description: TRENTON SOCIAL workers and administrators in the state's Department of Human Services are blaming the Legislature and each other for an increasing inability to care for the vulnerable children under their supervision.

title: Soviet Criticizes Bonn Plans For a Wider Military Program
description: The Soviet newspaper Pravda today criticized the West German Government's plans to extend military service and re- equip the armed forces, and said they posed a threat to peace in Europe.

title: 3 Are Hanged in Syria
description: Three men convicted of murder and robbery were hanged at dawn today in a public square in Aleppo, the Government newspaper Tishrin said.

title: THE MOST IMPORTANT PART OF A VCR SUFFERS THE GREATEST WEAR AND TEAR
description: In contrast to the voluble ebullience met elsewhere in the video trade, an aura of shy reticence surrounds one aspect of video cassette

title: Presidential Debate To Be Seen at 8 P.M.
description: The debate between President Reagan and Walter F. Mondale on foreign policy will be broadcast live at 8 o'clock tonight, Eastern daylight time, on the CBS, NBC and ABC television networks; on Cable News Network, on C-SPAN, the Cable-Satellite Public Affairs Network, and on SIN, the Spanish International Network, with simultaneous Spanish translation.

title: MUSIC: CHUNG LEADS PHILHARMONIC
description: Myung-Whun Chung, who continues his first New York Philharmonic engagement in the current brace of concerts, seems to be a conductor of lines, directions and rhythmic shapes more than one of textures and colors; in this he resembles many of his young contemporaries. Mozart's 28th Symphony, heard at the Friday matinee performance, emerged with point and clarity, convincing in its momentum, less than delicious (or in the andante, less than mysterious) in its character.

description: At Temple Emanuel in Andover, Mass., yesterday Robin Leigh Klinetsky, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Klinetsky of Atkinson, N.H., and Boca Raton, Fla., was married to Bruce Stephen Maier, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur I. Maier of Scarsdale, N.Y. Rabbis Ira Korinow and Harry A. Roth officiated.

title: DOMESTIC ISSUES ALSO GET THEIR DUE
description: Though President Reagan and his challenger, former Vice President Walter F. Mondale, spent most of the week prepping for their foreign policy debate tonight in Kansas City and beefing up their arguments as to who is stronger and who is safer, domestic issues were not ignored.

title: REPORT TO KEAN ON HUNGER SHOWS PROBLEM IS GROWING
description: Social workers say they are so overburdened that they are unable to provide adequate protection for abused and neglected children. Page 8.

title: Manila Raises Food Prices
description: The Government announced increases today of up to 27 percent in retail prices of rice, canned fish and canned milk. The announcement came a day after the Government said the prices of gasoline and petroleum products would be increased.

title: JONG SEES REVERSAL IN DIVORCE
description: IN all three books Erica Jong has published in the last year, divorce has figured prominently. In her fifth book of poetry, ''Ordinary Miracles,'' published last fall, an entire section was devoted to a marriage breaking up.
