title: KASPAROV ENDURES PRESSURE AND DRAWS A 93-MOVE GAME
description: Gary Kasparov stubbornly resisted all of Anatoly Karpov's prolonged efforts to wear him down and succeeded in drawing the 15th game of their world championship chess match in Moscow yesterday.

title: The Importance Of Seeing a Dentist
description: In the article ''Dentists Find L.I. Competition Fierce'' (Sept. 23), it was stated that as a result of the reduction in cavities, 50 percent of the population has not seen a dentist in more than a year and 25 percent in more than five years.

title: No Headline
description: SUNDAY, OCTOBER 21, 1984 International China approved a freer economy in which market forces will largely determine prices, competition will be stressed and plant managers will be given greater autonomy. The economic plan was approved by the Communist Party's Central Committee. (Page 1, Column 6.)

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption on the film page of the Arts and Leisure section today misidentifies the leading actor in ''Firstborn.'' He is Peter Weller.

title: PHYSICIAN URGES SMOKING CURBS
description: ASTHMATIC or allergic patients often tell me that they cannot go to a sports event or dine out because of fear of reaction to cigarette smoke.

title: Arsenal Wins to Widen Lead in English League
description: Arsenal opened a 4-point lead at the top of the English League First Division soccer standings today by beating Sunderland, 3-2.

title: New Storms Lash Texas; Death Toll Rises to Eight By The Associated Press
description: Waves of thunderstorms rattled the southern Plains yesterday after more than 18 inches of rain fell in parts of southern Texas, forcing more than 1,400 people from their homes.

title: Jazz
description: A distinguishing characteristic of jazz in the 1980's has been an interest in jazz of the 1950's as evidenced by the formation of groups that play the music by jazz composers who were at a creative peak in those years but are now dead. So we have the Mingus Dynasty Band to play the music of Charles Mingus, ''Dameronia'' to play the music of Tadd Dameron, Sphere to focus on the music of Thelonious Monk and, on records, a band led by Don Sickler that plays the music of Kenny Dorham.

title: CENTRAL AMERICA'S CHALLENGE TO THE US.
description: During the past month, new actors on the Central American stage have directly challenged President Reagan's policy of achieving peace in the region with the threat of United States military power. But more fundamentally, they challenge a 150-year policy that we have long taken for granted. We may now be at not only a turning-point for the Reagan Administration, but at a more profound historic turn.

title: SLEW O' GOLD WINS BY 9 3/4 FOR A $1 MILLION SWEEP
description: He missed by a neck last year and his father missed by a nose six years ago, but yesterday Slew o' Gold became the first horse to sweep Belmont Park's fall championship series with a 9 3/4-length romp in the $584,000 Jockey Club Gold Cup.

title: CHINESE ANNOUNCE SWEEPING CHANGES IN THEIR ECONOMY
description: China announced plans today for sweeping changes in its urban economy that will introduce capitalist-style market forces and reduce Government control.

title: ALONG THE GOLD RUSH TRAIL
description: To Alaska by ferryboat. The idea of steaming through the West Coast mists of the Inside Passage on a succession of ferries, past glaciers, forests and frolicking whales, grew out of a dinner conversation with my wife. Could the two of us, we wondered, now in our mid- 40's, spend a holiday traveling the way we once did when we had more time and less money? Could we plan a voyage in which chance encounters and spontaneous digressions would do more to shape our memories than three-star restaurants, stately hotels and shopping?

title: Miss Apple Plans Nov. 24 Wedding
description: Barbara Apple, a marketing director at the American Express Travel Related Services Company in New York, and William R. Sullivan, a senior vice president of Shearson Lehman/American Express in New York, plan to be married Nov. 24.

title: A GRAND JUROR TAKES HIS CASE TO THE GOVERNOR
description: A grand juror who contends that prosecutors hindered an investigation into the death of a 25-year-old Brooklyn man failed last week to get permission to break his oath of secrecy and air his allegations publicly. But the juror, Ronald P. Fields, was granted the chance to take his concerns to the top: Acting Justice Shirley R. Levittan of State Supreme Court ruled that Mr. Fields could meet with an aide to Governor Cuomo to discuss the case of Michael Stewart, who fell into a coma while in police custody in September 1983 and died 13 days later.

title: MANCHILD IN HARLEM
description: Claude Brown is not in touch with today's youth, either inside or outside of Harlem. How could any intelligent person, even with the slightest insight into the frailties of youth, expect to listen to the reflections of a few convicted felons and attempt to extrapolate not only the identity of Harlem youth but the identity of all black youth? LEO DEUSTER

title: 5TH DISTRICT RACE TESTS STRENGTH OF DEMOCRATS

title: North Sea Oil Prices Graph; WEEK IN BUSINESS; UNEXPECTED DROP IN THE PRICE OF OIL
description: Price War. Cuts in oil prices, starting in Norway and continuing in Britain and Nigeria, surprised almost everyone, and markets - ranging from stocks to currency - went into a tizzy. Although oil has been trading in the spot market at well below benchmark prices, the formal cuts acknowledged that the worldwide glut is beginning to affect oil producers' revenues. Britain cut its benchmark by $1.35 a barrel, to $28.65, and there was general expectation of a global price drop.

title: OUTDOORS ; Dressing and Skinning Deer
description: NEVER known for his reticence, Long Island's Joe DeFalco, who believes that he is this country's best-known deer hunter, will conduct his 17th annual hunting ''expo'' at the Adelphi-Calderone Theater in Hempstead, L.I., tomorrow night.

title: SEARCHING FOR MEANS TO COMBAT BEE KILLERS
description: The tracheal bee mite, a tiny parasite that preys on honeybees, was recently found to have traveled from Mexico across the Rio Grande and to have invaded bee colonies in six states. Federal and local agricultural authorities destroyed thousands of hives and hundreds of millions of bees to prevent the further spread of the mite.

title: MIME: AMERICAN COMPANY
description: As an art form in the United States, mime is still struggling to define itself. At the same time, it has attracted an amazing number of new young exponents.

title: Miss Harrison Becomes Bride
description: Maureen Ann Harrison, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert G. Harrison of Levittown, L.I., was married yesterday to Peter Lott Cruikshank, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Warren Lott Cruikshank of Maplewood, N.J. The Rev. Michael R. Ade performed the ceremony at St. Paul the Apostle Roman Catholic Church in Brookvale, L.I. He was assisted by the Rev. William K. Burns, a Methodist minister.

title: Big Country Live With Big Country and the Deysart and Dundonald Pipe Band. Music Media 75 minutes. $29.95
description: The Scottish rock band Big Country videotaped a concert before the best possible audience - at a hometown show in Glasgow last New Year's Eve.

title: FOLLOW-UP ON THE NEWS ; Cracking 'Glyphs'
description: One of the country's leading authorities on hieroglyphics received a $128,000 award in February to pursue any work he chose over the next five years. ''It's really a shock - still a little hard to comprehend,'' said the recipient, 18-year-old David Stuart of Silver Spring, Md.

title: BUSINESS IN SHORT ''DEAREST AMANDA . . .'': An Executive's Advice to Her Daughter.
description: In this collection of letters, Eliza G. C. Collins gently instructs an imagined 30-year-old daughter (Miss Collins is not married) in the ways of the corporate world and, not so incidentally, in relations between the sexes. To Miss Collins, a senior editor of the Harvard Business Review, success is a matter of managing the personal relationships that shape every workplace. Demonstrating her own mastery of ''this crucial human element of business,'' she guides the daughter, Amanda, through several private and professional crises, notably an unhappy love affair and an unfortunate corporate takeover. She teaches by example, using anecdotes from her own life as object lessons; a tennis match is used to show how to be appropriately subordinate to a boss without becoming subservient. Some readers, however, may find the author's lessons a bit pat, her tone somewhat cloying and her portrait of a mother and daughter too good to be true. In a disclaimer, Miss Collins notes that she has changed names and places in the interests of privacy and ''accurately portrays business behavior'' - not actual business people. But true or not, this book has some no-nonsense advice for working women. -

title: A MUSICAL THEATER BREAKTHROUGH
description: Frank Rich is the chief drama critic of The New York Times. ACCORDING TO BROADway lore, the impresario Mike Todd walked out of a New Haven tryout performance of the first Richard Rodgers- Oscar Hammerstein 2d musical, pronouncing its doom: ''No legs, no jokes, no chance!'' The year was 1943, the show was ''Away We Go!'' A few weeks later, under the new title of ''Oklahoma!,'' Rodgers and Hammerstein's self-styled ''musical play'' arrived in New York and changed the course of American musical theater.

title: HARNESSING THE WIND'S POWER
description: FRANCESCO A. GIANNINOTO, a retired industrial designer and marketing expert from Redding, has been in on the ground floor of many new ideas.

title: MAMMOTH MURAL

But about a decade ago, Richard Haas brought a new, architectural dimension to this urban art form with the first of his often whimsical trompe l'oeil designs that transform blank walls into what seem to be three-dimensional facades.

description: Before the largest crowd of her campaign so far, Geraldine A. Ferraro today helped set the Democrats' tone for the Presidential candidates' debate Sunday by condemning a Central Intelligence Agency manual on guerrilla warfare as ''more in the spirit of Stalin, not Jefferson.''

title: POETS WILL READ AT LIBRARIES
description: THE POET'S VOICE, a series of free readings at libraries by prominent American poets, will begin its eighth season today with Norman Rosten, an award-winning poet, reading from his work at the Westport Library.

title: COURT CALLING
description: Suing, or getting sued, in a New York civil court can cost thousands even before the matter comes to trial. That's because hourly fees mount up fast for lawyers who must fight through traffic to get to court, then often wait hours merely to argue a pretrial motion for a few minutes.

title: SKEPTICAL BUT OPEN-MINDED ON THE QUESTION OF U.F.O.'S
description: BEING one of the most skeptical journalists in the profession when it comes to the realm of the ''unknown'' and having gained a reputation as a ''debunker'' of popular modern legends, I have taken a good deal of time to accept that there is indeed something happening right now in and around my own home town concerning Unidentified Flying Objects. Using the jargon of U.F.O. enthusiasts, there is a ''flap'' occurring in and around Westchester and Putnam Counties, and it has been happening for more than a year now.

title: DALLAS MAYOR DEFENDS CITY CONVENTION COSTS

title: TEACHING AND A LACK OF TRUST
description: YOU have heard the one about the proud woman wheeling her grandchildren around the block who was asked their ages. ''The doctor is 3, the lawyer is 2,'' she said. You have heard it, but you did not realize it contained the crux of the so-called crisis in education. When, if ever, the woman says, ''The English teacher is 3, the math teacher is 2,'' we'll have no further crisis in education, at least of the same kind.

description: Harvard, helped by a fumble recovery on a third-period punt, did today what no Crimson team had managed to accomplish since 1978: It beat Dartmouth.

title: A FINAL TRIBUTE TO VON ZEDTWITZ
description: The last link with the birth of contract bridge was severed earlier this month when Waldemar Von Zedtwitz died in Hawaii at the age of 88. He was a legendary figure who, in a long career, had made a major impact on the game in several areas.

title: GALANOS AN AMERICAN ORIGINAL
description: IN TODAY'S FASHION WORLD, SUCcessful designers, particularly those in the United States, are more than mere manipulators of seams and silhouettes. Most of them are substantially involved in the finances of their often sizable businesses, overseeing the quality of their numerous licensees. Many are adept salesmen of their own products. Some own strings of boutiques and stores bearing their names. A few, by imposing their personal creative views on image, have influenced the advertising business itself. Designer names bounce off billboards, flash across television screens, repose above and below elegant, often provocative, photographs in magazines and newspapers. A good many are social celebrities, fodder for the gossip columns and guests for the talk shows. At least a few have reached the ''star'' status of movie, television or rock personalities, enjoying - or suffering - the same sort of mass recognition of being followed, stared at and pursued for autographs.

title: FIREFIGHTER HIT AND KILLED BY CAR AS HE ROLLS UP HOSE AFTER BLAZE
description: A firefighter rolling up a hose after putting out a blaze in an abandoned van was struck and killed on a street in Queens early yesterday by a motorist who was later charged with drunken driving.

title: ON THE RESPONSIBILTY OF THE COACH
description: HIGH SCHOOLS throughout our nation have the awesome responsibility of preparing youngsters to enter the adult world, either as college students or as part of the work force. Appropriate preparation requires not only the teaching of skills, but also the development of positive attitudes and ideals. The school endeavors to accomplish these objectives in many ways, including a variety of extracurricular activities, the most far-reaching of which is interscholastic athletics.

title: WEAPONS IN THE WAR ON WRINKLES

title: CREATIVE FESTIVITIES
description: Creative entertaining, like staging a symphony or a play, is far more than the sum of its parts. Certainly, each of the elements that comprise the finished production must excel if the result is to shine. But that is not enough. A play featuring a cast of egotistical, grandstanding actors - no matter how gifted the individuals might be - would quickly deflate under the pressure of excessive hot air. So it is with entertaining. A sensitive host or hostess does not try to overwhelm guests with his or her range and expertise. Perhaps Ernest Hemingway stated it best when discussing the craft of writing - sometimes the things that are left out are just as important as what goes in. Menus should be devised with logic and an awareness of setting in mind, not mere ostentation. The greatest challenge to a host may be to impart a sense of harmony and fluidity to an occasion, whether it is something as simple as an afternoon tea or as elaborate as a multicourse Brazilian feast based around the national dish, feijoada. These as well as the other celebrations described in these pages exemplify this delicate balance.

title: Elizabeth Henderson Bride at Harvard
description: Elizabeth Henderson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas James Henderson of Menlo Park, Calif., was married in Cambridge, Mass., yesterday to Daniel Cushing Esty, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John Cushing Esty of Concord, Mass. The Rev. Peter J. Gomes, an American Baptist minister, performed the ceremony at the Memorial Chapel at Harvard University.

Drefs of Stamford, Conn. The Rev. Augustine Giusani performed the ceremony at St. Anne's Roman Catholic Church in New Britain, Conn.

title: DOUBTS IN THE DELIVERY ROOM
description: YOU'RE DOING NATUral childbirth, aren't you?'' A friend asked me that question when my wife, Felicity, was two months pregnant. I hadn't given much thought to childbirth. I knew Felicity would go into labor someday, I would take her to the hospital and a baby would be born. It would be her show, not mine. I wasn't doing childbirth, natural or any other kind. Natural childbirth conjured up images of a midwife ministering to Felicity in the bedroom while I boiled water downstairs.

title: LOVERS AND MOBSTERS
description: -Times. ORGANIZED CRIMES

title: GREENWICH RALLY BEATS STAPLES, 28-22
description: Greenwich overcame a 14-0 first- quarter deficit yesterday and defeated Staples, which uses a pro-set passing offense, 28-22.

title: CANDIDATES POISED FOR DEBATE TODAY ON FOREIGN POLICY
description: With new foreign policy developments adding to an already charged political atmosphere, President Reagan and Walter F. Mondale today completed their preparations for a debate Sunday that both sides regard as pivotal in the Presidential campaign.

title: GLEN COVE ROLLS FOR 5 IN ROW, 26-12
description: Two touchdowns, a conversion and a strong defensive effort preserved Glen Cove's unbeaten streak as the Big Red downed Carey, 26-12. The Conference III game, played at Carey, was the Glen Cove's fifth straight victory.

title: MUSIC: MODERN WORKS
description: It was difficult to ascertain any philosophical connection between the seven works on the North-South Consonance Ensemble's concert at Christ and St. Stephen's Church on Thursday evening; instead, the listener was rewarded with a diverting sampler of some recent compositional styles.

title: BOOKS & BUSINESS BIZGAB TRANSLATED Lawrence S. Ritter teaches finance at New York University. HOW TO READ AND PROFIT FROM FINANCIAL NEWS    By Gerald Krefetz.  226 pp. New York: Ticknor & Fields. $16.95.
description: GERALD KREFETZ, a financial consultant and the author of ''The Smart Investor's Guide'' and other books, has written a concise but comprehensive handbook to the enormous quantity of information that appears daily in the financial and business sections of major newspapers. Books of this sort, devoted to explaining business and finance in language understandable to general readers, have become increasingly valuable as our financial system has grown in complexity. A dozen years ago, there were no options markets worth mentioning, futures trading was limited to professionals, and hardly anyone paid much attention to the Federal Reserve's weekly money-supply figures.

title: Q&A
description: Question:

title: 6 STORIES ON SPEC
description: The number of single-family residences built in Manhattan in the last two decades can probably be counted on two hands. And most of those went up at the behest of the wealthy individuals creating city homes for themselves.

title:
SPEAKING PERONALLY;
CHANGING TIMES FIND CHANGING MEN
description: I THINK that it was easier on men when they were

title: REVEALING THE PAINTERLY SIDE OF AN ECLECTIC ARTIST
description: At 84, Herbert Bayer is the last surviving ''teaching master'' of the Bauhaus, the short-lived but influential art and design school founded by Walter Gropius in 1919 at Weimar. And

title: ROBUST REDS OF ITALY
description: The great red wines of Italy come from the north, from Tuscany and the Piedmont. They bear old familiar names such as Barolo and Barbaresco and Chianti, and they bear new names such as Sassicaia and Tignanello and Carmignano. In America, even though we know a few of the names, we have yet to learn to appeciate the wines themselves.

title: MISKITO REBEL, BACK IN MANAGUA, SEEKS SELF-RULE
description: A Miskito Indian leader who has been allied with insurgents returned to Nicaragua this week after three years of exile and held talks with Government officials.

title: THE MUCH-ALIGNED U.S. TRADE GAP
description: NO economic statistic is reported more dolefully these days than the country's trade balance.

title: GUIDE TO THE STATE'S FALL FOLIAGE
description: AUTUMN foliage in New Jersey is spectacular these days. From rugged park regions to gentle farm country, and along major thoroughfares and secluded byways, the landscape is bursting with color: the yellows of elms, beech and maple, the bronze of basswood and the red and purple of sweetgum.

title: McGee's Lament
description: Buford McGee, the San Diego Charger rookie running back, now says that nobody offered him anything to go anywhere when he was a highly recruited college prospect, and that he never said otherwise. ''I haven't confirmed anything,'' McGee told a Mississippi newspaper, The Jackson Clarion-Ledger, after two papers had quoted him to the contrary.

title: AT 25, LINCOLN CENTER MAKES PLANS FOR A LIVELY FUTURE
description: The Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts is celebrating its 25th anniversary this week, with a gala party Monday night, the formal publication of a book about itself, ''The Lincoln Center Story,'' on Thursday, and finally a two-hour PBS telecast of highlights from its ''Live From Lincoln Center'' and ''Live From the Met'' series, Friday at 9 P.M.

title: PLAYING BY THE WRONG BOOK ON NICARAGUA
description: Publication of the Central Intelligence Agency's primer on guerrilla warfare in Nicaragua last week revived the national debate over whether the agency is operating out of control. Five investigations of the agency have been announced. The booklet, written for the anti-Sandinista rebels, provides advice on public executions of government officials, on arranging the deaths of anti-Sandinista colleagues so they will become ''martyrs,'' and on blackmailing Nicaraguans to get them to work for the rebels.

title: Violence Against Women
description: ''Under the Viaduct'' was the first title Pat Barker gave her new novel. But the final ''Blow Your House Down,'' from the child's tale of three pigs menaced by a wolf, more accurately reflects the story, she said.

title: Palace Music Captures Stakes at Newmarket
description: Palace Music, an 18-1 outsider, passed four rivals on the final turn and breezed to a record-breaking victory today in the $120,000 Dubai Champion Stakes. On the same program, the Irish Sweepstakes Race was won by a 40-1 shot, Tom Sharp.

title: OFFICIALS REFUSE TO ANSWER QUESTIONS ON C.I.A. CRASH
description: Officials of the Central Intelligence Agency are uncertain what caused the crash of a twin-engined surveillance plane in El Salvador Friday that left four agency employees dead, Senator Danial Patrick Moynihan said tonight.

title: Man With Gun in IRT Given a 15-Year Term
description: A 33-year-old Bronx man who was arrested last March for carrying a loaded pistol while trying to slip past a subway turnstile on an IRT line has been sentenced to a prison term of 15 years to life.

title: MOVING TOWARD THE MYTHICAL
description: Thomas Connors is a regular contributor to Ballet News.

title: A TASTE OF BRAZIL
description: ''Try one of these, they are very good, and good for you, too,'' beckoned Ricardo Amaral, who was vigorously crushing limes inside cocktail glasses as I entered the kitchen. ''This is caipirinha, the national drink of Brazil. You must try it''

title: LIFE AFTER LOSS
description: Alida Becker is a freelance writer and critic in Philadelphia. PERFECT HAPPINESS

title: THE IMPORTANCE OF SEEING A DENTIST
description: The article ''Dentists Find L.I. Competition Fierce'' gave the erroneous impression that one of the major reasons for reduced dental incomes is that ''the use of fluoride in toothpaste and drinking water, which the profession encourages, has reduced cavities 30 to 50 percent since the early 60's,'' and that the dental profession is putting itself out of business because of it.

title: BATTLESHIP IOWA ATTRACTS A CROWD OF BOTH SIGHTSEERS AND PROTESTERS
description: To the Rev. Jesse Jackson, it was ''a holocaust machine.'' To Benjamin Gross, it showed ''we are keeping our powder dry.''

title: Aide Says That Senate Panel Will Pursue Contempt Charge
description: The Justice Department has failed to meet a Senate subcommittee's deadline for producing subpoenaed records of an investigation of the General Dynamics Corporation, and an aide says the panel will pursue a criminal contempt citation.

title: HOW TO WIN SALES AND INFLUENCE ECONOMIC POLICY
description: IT'S rather bizarre. The economics profession is suffering a severe spell of self-doubt. The failure to deliver on its promise of effortless bounty has left economists dispirited and divided. Yet they are writing a seemingly endless rush of books proposing solutions to what ails. Even more bizarre, many of these books are finding an impressively large audience, and many economists are enjoying impressively high profiles. Once fusty academics are now hosts of television series, chat on late-night talk shows or pop up in People magazine.

title: HOSPITALS FIGHTING LIMITS ON FEES
description: HOSPITALS in the state, fearing financial problems and reduced quality of care, are seeking a system to have their charges surpass the inflation rate in certain categories.

title: LEGISLATORS ASK IF REAGAN KNEW OF C.I.A.'S ROLE
description: Disclosures this week of possibly illegal activities by the Central Intelligence Agency in Nicaragua have raised questions in Congress about how much the White House knew about the agency's actions, members of Congress and their aides said today.

title: PAPRERBACK BEST SELLERS Ocr. 21,1984 ; Fiction*1
description: THE AUERBACH WILL, by Stephen Birmingham. (Berkley, $3.95.) Three generations of a German Jewish family in New York. *2 BLOOD AND ORCHIDS, by Norman Katkov. (NAL/Signet, $3.95.) Four Hawaiian youths are accused of raping a Navy officer's wife. *3 FIREFOX DOWN, by Craig Thomas. (Bantam, $3.95.) A sequel about the theft of a secret Soviet warplane. *4

title: Judith Lanius Wed to Robert Sussman
description: The marriage of Judith Hidden Lanius, head of the exhibition and film division at the National Building Museum in Washington, to Robert M. Sussman, a partner in the Washington law firm of Covington & Burling, took place yesterday. The Rev. Robert L. Tate, an Episcopal priest, and Cantor Siegfried Rowe co-officiated at the Sulgrave Club in Washington.

title: THE HOARY TRADITION OF TOPPING-OUT
description: WHEN ironworkers hang an American flag on the steel frame of the 50-story Marriott Marquis Hotel in a ''topping-out'' ceremony on Tuesday, it will be both an expression of pride by the workers that the frame has been completed and a commercial message from the owners that construction of the Times Square hotel has advanced to the point that they are looking for customers.

title: PANEL ON THE DEAF CITES ACHIEVEMENTS
description: HARTFORD AS the State Commission on the Deaf and Hearing Impaired on Friday marked the 10th anniversary of its founding, its executive director pointed with pride to its legislative accomplishments.

title: Once Again, at Last, The Best Team Wins
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: MANCHILD IN HARLEM
description: Violence has become the norm in many segments of our society, but it reaches extreme dimensions under the hopeless conditions of our urban ghettos.

title: FictionOct. 21,1984 *1
description: 110 THE FOURTH PROTOCOL, by Frederick Forsyth. (Viking, $17.95.) A London jewel robbery leads to plots and counterplots behind the Iron Curtain. *2 23 GOD KNOWS, by Joseph Heller. (Knopf, $16.95.) King David describes his life in comic and anachronistic style. *3

title: 'THE GAMES'-SERIOUS SCIENCE FICTION ON STAGE
description: Defenders of science fiction as a serious genre often argue that sci-fi stories are not just fantastic accounts of technological wizardry, but parables about the way we live now and the shape of things to come. According to this definition, ''The Games,'' a multi-media collaboration by Meredith Monk and Ping Chong, most definitely qualifies as a theatrical example of serious science fiction.

title: KNICKS TRIUMPH
description: With Centers Bill Cartwright and Marvin Webster sidelined, the struggles of two fledgling Knicks last night became all the more important.

title: PLAN FOR CROWDED SCHOOL DISTRICT
description: The Board of Education has announced a plan to ease overcrowding in the city's most-crowded school district that calls for small, temporary structures for extra classrooms, two new permanent schools and the busing of students.

title: PASSAIC'S STREAK ENDED BY BELLEVILLE
description: Passaic's winning streak of 16 games, which began last Thanksgiving Day, was snapped yesterday when Belleville prevailed, 7-0, in a defensive struggle in Belleville.

title:
THE WORLD;
GRENADIANS GO ON TRIAL
description: A year after President Reagan's ''rescue mission'' corraled Grenada back into Washington's fold, life seems largely unchanged in the Caribbean nation - except for the 19 Grenadians who went on trial last week, charged with the murders that helped precipate the invasion.

title: STUDY FAULTS CITY'S HANDLING OF HOMELESS CHILDREN
description: Two 5-year-olds played on the escalator in the subway station because they had no other place to play. Other children were found lying listlessly on cots. Still others wandered in dark hotel hallways or were sent out to heavily trafficked streets.

title: Dissident Polish Priest Is Reported Kidnapped
description: The Polish press agency said today that the Rev. Jerzy Popieluszko, a prominent supporter of the Solidarity movement, was abducted Friday from an automobile near Torun.

title: EDUCATION TROUBLES HAUNT SOUTH AFRICA
description: In South Africa's recent history, there are phrases and utterances that recur, like nightmares out of a harsh, unburied past, haunting those in power at present who seek a softer focus on the policies of division.

title: A SOMERSET RAMBLE
description: A. L. ROWSE is emeritus fellow of All Souls College, Oxford, and the author of many books on Shakespeare.

title: 'I AM AT THE BOILING POINT'
description: Milton Rugoff's most recent book is ''The Beechers: An American Family in the Nineteenth Century.'' IN HER OWN RIGHT

title: Comings and Goings
description: Mark Herrmann, a quarterback who attended high school and college in Indiana, has been activated by the Colts for the game today with Pittsburgh in Indianapolis. The Purdue graduate had been on the injured reserve list with a fractured thumb. . . . Guy Benjamin, a San Francisco 49er quarterback who has been out with knee problems, was waived. . . . George Seewagen Sr., who has coached tennis at St. John's for more than 45 years - a record in the country for longevity, he believes - has been inducted into the university's Hall of Fame.

title: A'MUCH ADO' WITH A BIT MORE ADO THAN IT NEEDS
description: As I watched the visiting Royal Shakespeare Company's glass-and-gold mounting of ''Much Ado About Nothing'' at the Gershwin, I was reminded - rather forcibly - of my only quarrel with Peter Hall's fascinating ''Diaries,'' published earlier this year. Peter Hall was once the director of the Royal Shakespeare Company and, even though he's tranferred his allegiance to the British National Theater, it's extremely clear that he remains deeply interested in the activities of the RSC. As he remains deeply devoted to Shakespeare. Indeed, he remains so fervently devoted to Shakespeare that he never wants the curtain to come down on any one of his plays. The longer a production can spin itself out, the happier he is. And while he does not specifically mention midnight as the ideal hour for calling it quits and letting honest folk go home to their beds, he does do nip-ups on the page whenever he hears of a new production that runs for at least three hours.

title: WESLEYAN STUDIES ITS FUTURE
description: WESLEYAN UNIVERSITY, trying to improve its academic program, last week released a report running almost 200 pages, with a host of proposals.

title: LETTERS
description: MENTAL TEST FOR LEADERS

title: FOLLOW-UP ON THE NEWS ; 'Open Door' Jail
description: The new Travis County jail in Austin, Tex., cost $12 million to build, and it had an advanced electronic locking system. The locking system was integrated with other security equipment, and this created problems.

title: sarah kinsman Is Bride on Coast
description: Sarah Markham Kinsman, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Robert S. Kinsman of Encino, Calif., was married yesterday to Dr. Kevin Harry Olsen, the son of Edith G. Olsen of Glendale, Queens, and the late Wilbur N. Olsen. The Rev. Malcolm White, the bride's uncle, performed the ceremony at the Westwood (Calif.)

title: OF AL SCHACT AND A CRACKER-JACK AFTERNOON
description: AL SCHACHT, the Clown Prince of Baseball, died July 14. He was 91 years old, and pitched for the old Washington Senators for three seasons. He won 14 games, lost 10, threw 1 shutout and had a 4.48 earned run average. A bad arm forced Schacht off the mound in 1921, but he stayed with the Senators as third- base coach and developed what became baseball's first clown act.

title: LETTERS
description: -CONTROL CURE FOR MEDICARETo the Editor:

title: Mother Sentenced to 5 Years Over Shoplifting by Children
description: Barbara Lee, 33 years old, convicted of taking her four children on shoplifting sprees, has been sentenced to five years in prison by a judge who rebuked her for ''disgraceful'' behavior.

title: Insurance Evasion
description: A computerized campaign to get 500,000 uninsured cars off the roads was started in July by the Motor Vehicles Department in New York State.

title: STAGE: HUGH LEONARD'S 'POKER SESSION' REVIVED
description: Hugh Leonard is one of the most prolific and versatile of contemporary dramatists, a man who has seemingly written an original play or an adaptation in every genre. Last season there was a New York production of his bedroom farce, ''The Patrick Pearse Motel,'' and currently there is a revival of ''The Poker Session,'' which the author has described as having the elements of ''a comedy, a thriller, a tragedy, an allegory and a black farce.'' Three out of five of those categories are certainly applicable, as amply demonstrated in Albert Harris's production at Theater Off Park.

title: ennifer B. Rice Becomes Bride Of Gerard Berry
description: Jennifer Barnett Rice, a daughter of Julian Rice Jr. of Phoenix and San Juan, P.R., and Jane Ritchie Rice of New York, was married yesterday to Gerard Francis Berry, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Berry of Peekskill, N.Y. The Rev. Leslie Martin performed the ceremony at the Brick Presbyterian Church.

title: RIVALS FACE DEBATE DEEPLY DIVIDED ON APPROACH TO MOSCOW
description: With the campaign tempo accelerating and the race narrowing since their first debate in Louisville, Ky., President Reagan and Walter F. Mondale have etched their differences on foreign affairs even more sharply than their differences on domestic policy, especially on the crucial issues of the arms race.

INVESTING;
DIPPING INTO THE BANKRUPTCY STOCKS
description: It was not so long ago that companies filing for

title: EXPERTS EXAMINE NEW STRESS CAUSES
description: It wasn't always one big happy family, the gathering of thousands of family experts this week in the City by the Bay. Consider the debate on computers in the home.

title: EGYPTIAN OIL MINISTER ASKS PRODUCERS TO PREVENT PRICE CUT
description: Egypt's Oil Minister, who cut short a visit to the United States because of turmoil in the oil markets, appealed today to all exporters to cooperate in preventing a decline in prices.

title: NO DOLLAR GAP;
description: Of the 535 members of Congress, only 24 are women, and it has long been thought that a big reason is that women candidates have a much harder time raising campaign funds. Not any more.

title:
ART;
MONOTYPES AND COLLAGES YIELD SURPRISES
description: ARTISTS have painted flowers for many centuries and for many reasons. They held symbolic and decorative meanings for the pagans and iconographic significance for Christians and were emblems of prestige in 17th- century Holland. They represented sentiment during the Victorian era and symbolized nature's flux for the Impressionists.

title: THE PHILHARMONIC'S YOUTHFUL GAMBIT
description: Major musical competitions are often won by the young, sometimes the very young; the strength, fire, singlemindedness and razzle-dazzle panache of youth go over well with juries. The violist Paul Neubauer, for instance, won first prize in the Lionel Tertis International Viola Competition when he was only 17, in 1980. Last year he took the same place in the Mae M. Whitaker International Competition for Strings.

description: Justin Kaplan, who has written biographies of Walt Whitman and Mark Twain, is working on a book about Charlie Chaplin. HOME BEFORE DARK

title: HOPE FOR STABLE FOOD PRICES APPEARS BRIGHTER
description: With the autumn harvest nearing its peak, supplies of livestock and grain on American farms are larger than last year and the hopes for another three months of comparatively low food prices are brighter.

title:
GARDENING;
FALL IS THE PERFECT TIME TO SPREAD LIME
description: THE standard advice received from garden writers and other assorted horticultural experts and would-be experts is that the fall is a good time to apply lime to the soil. What is usually absent from this advice is the reason for applying lime at all.

title: TIME TO CALM DOWN
description: Headliners If age has taken a long time to work its mellowing ways on Emanuel Shinwell , it's probably because the job was such a big one. As he celebrated his 100th birthday last week, becoming perhaps the first active member of the House of Lords to do so, Baron Shinwell acknowledged that he might have been a bit too much of a firebrand in the early days of his career as a leftist Labor politician.

description: Mrs. Thomas A. Greene of Greenwich, Conn., and Richard D. Spizzirri of New York and Sagaponack, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Hillary Hale Spizzirri to Alfonso Herman Miguel Ossorio, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederic E. Ossorio of Greenwich. A May wedding is planned.

title:
ANTIQUES;
BERGEN TOURS TO ASSIST PRESERVATION
description: RIVER EDGE THREE HUNDRED years after the first scattered European settlements in Bergen County, the accelerating pace of urban encroachment and commercial development has been taking its toll on preservation efforts.

title: GREENWICH TO HONOR BORGE
description: THEY are throwing a birthday party for Victor Borge in Greenwich today. In celebration of his 75th birthday, the town where he has lived for the past 20 years will honor him with a parade and ceremonies at the high school.

title: Mary Kate Wold Becomes a Bride
description: Mary Katherine Wold, a daughter of Peter Bertram Wold of Bottineau, N.D., was married yesterday to Robert Peter Schreiner, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert G. Schreiner of Racine, Wis. The Rev. Stanley Cain performed the ceremony at the United Methodist Church in Bottineau.

title: BOSTON COLLEGE IS UPSET, 21-20
description: Doug Flutie, the magician, ran out of tricks today and Boston College went down to defeat for the first time this season.

description: COMMERCIALISM is not what regional theater is about, and the pressure to move to the mainstream should not be superimposed upon it.

title: A SHAKY START FOR STATE RENT REGULATION
description: LAST April, the New York State Division of Housing

title: U.S. AGREES TO PAY $5 MILLION IN SUIT ON DAM
description: The Federal Government has agreed to pay $5 million to settle the claims of a group of southern Virginia landowners who said an $87 million Government flood-control dam made floods in their area worse.

title:
BOOKS AND BUSINESS;
O BRAVE NEW INFORMATION AGE
description: Robert Lekachman teaches economics at the Graduate Center and Lehman College campuses of the City University of New York. His most recent book is ''Greed Is Not Enough: Reaganomics.'' MAKING THE FUTURE WORK

title: PERILOUS FLIGHT OF VIETNAMESE IS THWARTED AT THAI BORDER
description: Hundreds of Vietnamese who are unable or unwilling to risk fleeing their homeland by sea, or by using legal emigration procedures, are reaching the Thai border by an arduous overland route through Cambodia.

title: SUNDAY SPORTS Football
description: Giants vs. Eagles at Philadelphia. In their first meeting, the Giants won by a point, 28-27. (Television - Channel 2, 1 P.M. Radio - WNEW 1130 1 P.M.). Jets vs. Kansas City Chiefs, at Giants Stadium, 4 P.M. In their first meeting, the Jets won by a point, 17-16. (Television - Channel 4, 4 P.M. Radio - WABC 770, 4 P.M.).
