description: IN AN amended bill scheduled to

title: JERSEY JUDGE ORDERS LEAFLET DISTRIBUTION IN MALL AT ANY TIME
description: A Bergen County judge has ruled that nuclear-freeze advocates should be allowed to distribute literature anywhere in a shopping mall at any time.

title: MUSIC: PAPA ZAKA TROUPE
description: Papa Zaka, a 26-member Haitian- style music and dance troupe, seemed to have four unrelated programs for its show Friday at the Public Theater. The two better ones involved dance music.

title: EASTERN TITLE TO PAUL VI
description: Paul VI of Haddonfield, N.J., scored 89 points yesterday to win the boys' championship A race in the Fordham University Eastern States Championships at Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx.

title: Miss Peeples Weds in Rye
description: Daryn Stewart Peeples and Stuart Stratton Beringer were married yesterday at Christ's Episcopal Church in Rye, N.Y., by the Rev. Edward Johnston, assisted by the Rev. William H. Ralston Jr.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: THE DEATH OF CHE GUEVARA, by Jay Cantor. (Vintage, $9.95.) An Argentine physician, Ernesto (Che) Guevara invaded Cuba with Fidel Castro in 1956 and spent two years in the Sierra Maestra. In 1965 Che vanished and turned up in Bolivia leading guerrillas. The Bolivian Army killed him in 1967. In The Book Review last year, Michael Wood called Jay Cantor's ''The Death of Che Guevara'' ''profuse and powerful'' and described it as a ''convincing plunge into the intricacies of Latin American politics, a lucid, compassionate work that does not forget the pain and need revolutions are supposed to address.'' THE MOONFLOWER VINE, by Jetta Carleton. (Ban tam, $3.95.) This 1962 best seller covers 50 years of the Soames family - parents and four daughters. The daughters abandon the nest but each year visit their Missouri farm home. The characters are believable in Jetta Carleton's first and, so far, only novel. The woman characters - conspicuously feminine - are realized from inside out, through a woman's eyes. The men are real but seen from the outside.

title: FOR 60 YEARS, A COZY PLACE FOR STUDENTS
description: The hardest step, Kyungsoon Lee thought, was getting her student visa from the American Embassy in Seoul, South Korea. With her visa in hand, Miss Lee, a graduate student in communications, flew to New York and found a hotel room at a modest price. It was not what she had expected.

title: Camilla Robinson Becomes a Bride In Charlotte, N.C
description: Camilla Rodman Robinson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Russell Marable Robinson 2d of Charlotte, N.C., was married there yesterday to William Barnes Hauptfuhrer, a son of Mr. and Mrs. George Jost Hauptfuhrer Jr. of Huntingdon Valley, Pa. The Rev. Frank H. Vest performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church.

title: Beleaguered Steel
description: To the Editor:

title: A MOTHER'S MISSION ON DYSLEXIA
description: I felt every day was going to be a hurricane,'' said Carrie Rozelle, recalling the time years ago when her son Jack's severe dyslexia was making him violent. ''Because he couldn't read he developed emotional problems,'' she said. ''He had difficulties with his brothers. He took toys. He broke them. He would steal. His books were torn up. There were lots of tears, lots of shouting, lots of anger.''

title: A NAME FOR ALL SEASONS
description: A member of the family with an unnamed daughter wanted to know how I felt about girls being named Summer.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE;
description: SYMPHONIES GALORE

title: Laurey Gross Is Married
description: Laurey Beth Gross, a daughter of Joan Helene Gross and Laurence Neal Gross, both of New York, was married yesterday to Alden Ward Mauck, a son of Louise Gilbert Crimmins of Somers, N.Y., and Ward Laquette Mauck of New York. The Rev. Beverly Edwards performed the ceremony at the United Congregational Church in Little Compton, R.I.

title: MATTINGLY'S BID FOR $4 MILLION MAY APPEAL TO STEINBRENNER
description: THEY laughed, six months ago,

title: OBJECTS OF MUCH AFFECTION
description: AT FIRST GLANCE, THIS DRAWING ROOM LOOKS as though it were taken from those magical 19th-century watercolors of English life, those paintings that now are so prized by Anglophiles. The tomato-red walls, treated five times with a transparent glaze, have the depth and suppleness of buttery leather. There is a careful play of patterns between the wallpapered ceiling and the slightly tattered pieces of upholstery. And at night, when the brown candles in the Louis XIV gilt bronze chandelier are lighted, soft shadows encircle the room.

title: OTTAWA SHOWS WASHINGTON ITS WARM SIDE
description: ''The Americans are our best friends whether we like it or not,'' a member of Canada's Parliament said in 1911. His point seems simple and still valid: The two nations share the world's longest undefended border, and are by far the world's leading trading partners. Building on this logic and despite tips of the hat to London and Paris, Prime Minister Brian Mulroney and his month-old Government have given precedence to friendship with the United States since taking office Sept. 17. Mr. Mulroney has already visited the White House and sent his Defense Minister to the Pentagon. Last week, External Affairs Minister Joe Clark welcomed Secretary of State George P. Shultz here.

title: TEST DISKS HELP IN THE DIAGNOSIS OF AUDIO ILLS
description: The scariest image in Greek mythology is that of Kronos devouring his children. The notion of Time destroying all it engenders is frightening precisely because it is no myth. Things fall apart as they age, and sound equipment is no exception.

title: OIL PRICE-CUTTING CHALLENGES OPEC
description: World oil producers scrambled to rebuild their defenses last week after Britain, Norway and Nigeria broke through the price ramparts. The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries called an emergency meeting amid fears that the cartel could crack under renewed pressure to cut prices and raise production.

title: FINNS SEE COMMUNIST LOSSES
description: The deeply divided Communist Party, once Finland's largest political group, is expected to suffer a new setback in local elections Sunday and Monday.

title: Worker Sues on Loss of Leg
description: A construction worker who was credited with steering a falling crane away from co-workers at a Manhattan construction site has filed a $50 million suit in State Supreme Court in Orange County over the loss of a leg in the accident. The worker, Thomas O'Brien, a 45-year-old resident of the Orange County community of Highland Mills, was trapped in the cab of the crane in the Sept. 8 accident on West 57th Street next to Carnegie Hall. He is suing his employers, HRH Construction Corporation of Manhattan and Delro Industries of Englewood, N.J.

title:
THE WORLD;
NEW UNCERTAINTY IN AQUINO INQUIRY
description: The uncertainty clouding the 1983 assassination of opposition leader Benigno S. Aquino Jr. at Manila Airport thickened last week. A key witness recanted testimony that he had seen Mr. Aquino shot from behind in contradiction of the official account.

title: ARMY SENDS PENN TO FIRST DEFEAT, 48-13
description: Army's wishbone offense was back on track after an off week and produced a one-sided victory over previously unbeaten Penn today before 40,496 at Michie Stadium.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
GOLDEN ANNIVERSARY FOR A NOTED FAMILY
description: When most coin dealers speak about ''long- term developments'' in the market, they're referring to a period of 10 or 20 years, but Stack's of New York has a longer and broader perspective. The family firm has been in existence since 1858 and currently is observing its 50th anniversary as a dealership devoted exclusively to coins and related items.

title: Sports of The Times; 'O Set Him Up for K'
description: THE only world middleweight champion,

title: PROSPECTS
description: Inflation Engine Sputters

title: 2 Lawyers Granted $680,715 For Work in Civil-Rights Case
description: A Federal judge has awarded two lawyers a total of $680,715 for their work in a civil-rights suit against New York State involving mentally retarded residents of a state institution in Melville, L.I.

title: Nelson's 64-196 Leads Disney Golf by 2 Shots
description: Larry Nelson carded a 64 and took a two-stroke lead today in the third round of the $400,000 Walt Disney World Golf Classic.

title: MR. WARD'S INDISCRETIONS
description: ''To err is human, to forgive divine,'' Mayor Koch said last week. Not surprisingly, Mr. Koch characterized his role as the lofty one; the object of his compassion was Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward.

title: FUR JOINS FEATHERS IN HIS PAINTINGS
description: ARTHUR SINGER, one of America's noted bird painters, loved mammals before he loved birds.

title: EXCERPTS FROM CHINESE PLAN
description: Following are excerpts from the text of the ''Decision of the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China on Reform of the Economic Structure,'' which was adopted today by the Central Committee, as made public in translation by the Foreign Ministry:

title: THE HIGHLANDS
description: To the Editor:

title: IN MODENA, THE RIGHT STUFF
description: FLORENCE FABRICANT, who writes frequently about food and wine for The New York Times, is based in New York.

title: ; LETTERS ON TRAVEL; The Highlands
description: To the Editor:

title: MOSCOW DENIES IT VIOLATED ARMS PACT
description: The Soviet Union today denied American accusations that it had breached arms control agreements.

title: THE IMPORTANCE OF SEEING A DENTIST
description: In the article ''Dentists Find L.I. Competition Fierce,'' you have assumed the role of a forecaster of the overall health of the dental profession on Long Island. It is regretful that the dentists interviewed were not quantitatively or qualitatively diverse enough to use as a barometer for your conclusions.

title: CENSUS BUREAU REPORTS RISE IN FOREIGN-BORN
description: A flood of Asian and Latin American immigrants has sharply increased the number of foreign-born residents of the United States, a new Census Bureau study shows.

title: PIONEERS OF THE URBAN IMAGE
description: SILVER CITIES

title: A GRAND GESTURE FOR THE HOLIDAYS
description: I don't cook much anymore,' said my friend the gourmet recently. 'I don't like all the fuss about food there is these days, and franky, I just don't have time for those elaborate four-and five-course diners we all seemed to do so frequently once upon a time. No,' she said moodily, 'when I cook now, it's someting rare and very special. It's an act of love with me, a way of giving, of hsaring something splendid with my family and friends.'

title: HARVEST OF A COUNTRY AUTUMN
description: NORTH SALEM DRIVING the winding roads of this northern Westchester town, a city-weary traveler gets the taste, smell and sight of all the vivid reds, yellows and oranges of a country autumn. It is more than just the foliage on the sugar maples lining the dirt lanes here.

title: JORDAN MAKES PEOPLE WONDER: IS HE THE NEW DR. J?
description: AS the Chicago Bulls' preseason tour moved through provincial arenas in Peoria, Ill. and Glens Falls, N.Y., and metropolitan showcases like Madison Square Garden, Coach Kevin Loughery watched and waited, his gaze fixed on Michael Jordan, his enthusiasm barely contained.

title: 'ANDROCLES' AND THE SKUNK
description: ''MOM! Quick! Wake Up! Dad needs you.'' ''What?'' I mumbled. ''He went to play golf.''

title: THE FARM BANKS BATTLE TO STAY AFLOAT
description: WASHINGTONIn recent years, wheat farmers and

title: TALKING EQUITY LOANS ; NEW CREDIT FOR BOARDS OF CO-OPS
description: AFEW weeks ago, Citibank began offering the same sort of equity loans to co-

title: 9 ARE ACCUSED OF ROBBERY PLOT
description: More than 50 police officers, wearing bullet-proof vests and aiming shotguns, crouched behind cars on Midwood Street in Brooklyn shortly after midnight on Thursday. As a police spotlight beamed into a house, an eyewitness said, an officer read out a list of names and ordered those in the house to come out with their hands up. The orders were followed, as were similar commands shouted out in the early morning darkness at other homes in Brooklyn and Queens, at a Chinese restaurant and on a Manhattan street.

title: A VENERABLE ORCHESTRA VISITS NEW YORK
description: Most of the world's great orchestras lay claim to some kind of tradition - either through associations with great composers and legendary conductors, because of a performance style that has survived the turnover of individual players, or simply by virtue of longevity. So far as tradition goes, though, few ensembles have anything on the Leipzig Gewandhaus Orchestra. The oldest of Germany's orchestras, the Gewandhaus traces its history to 1743, and it has had ties (some stronger than others) with an impressive number of the composers whose works now make up the core of the repertory.

title: THE CRANBERRY: BEYOND THANKSGIVING AND CHRISTMAS
description: CRANBERRY sauce was invented by the American Indians. Long before the discovery of America, they were eating these tart, bright red berries that grew among sand dunes on creeping vines. By pounding them together with dried meat they also made them into something called ''pemmican'' - a product that had a shelf life to be envied by today's manufacturers of ''long-life'' food.

title: AUTUMN VISIONS IN A GARDEN
description: FOR the backyard gardener, autumn is both a sad and joyous occasion, that bittersweet mixture of human life.

title: BAIT FOR A KILLER
description: Katha Pollitt is the author of ''Antarctic Traveller,'' a collection of poems. BLOW YOUR HOUSE DOWN

title: PUERTO RICAN GOVERNOR SEEN AS HURT BY OFFICERS' ARREST
description: A six- year-old controversy surrounding the deaths of two young radicals at the hands of the police is causing problems for the re-election campaign of Gov. Carlos Romero Barcelo as it did in 1980.

title: PACT GETS MIXED RESPONSE IN CHILE AND ARGENTINA
description: Details of a Vatican-mediated border treaty between Chile and Argentina have been made public in the two countries, prompting mixed reactions.

title: U.S. Holds Battle Exercise
description: Maneuvers involving 33,000 sailors, 1,500 marines and five aircraft carriers are being conducted off the coast of California in one of the largest United States battle group exercises ever, a Navy spokesman said. Five Canadian destroyers are also participating in the maneuvers, which began Thursday and are to end Nov. 27.

title: THE PECULIARITIES OF 'IRMA LA DOUCE'
description: CRITICS ought to be unaffected by audience reaction. On opening nights, the responses are often synthetic, with friends, relatives, well-wishers and, in the case of commercial theater, backers, out front.

title: THEATER MAILBAG
description: WHAT'S RIGHT WITH CANADIAN THEATER

title: CRACKDOWN ON SPEEDERS SET BY O'NEILL
description: HARTFORD MOTORISTS take heed: The state is increasing its enforcement of the 55 mile-per-hour speed limit on its major highways. Governor O'Neill, saying he was concerned about two recent fatal accidents on the Connecticut Turnpike, said he called his Public Safety Commissioner, Lester J. Forst, last Monday with the following message: ''I want an immediate crackdown on speeding in the State of Connecticut - to start posthaste.''

title: ALUMNI TO MARK CENTENNIAL OF HOME
description: From the age of 8, Ralph S. Henry had 80 brothers. He slept alongside them, played, studied and worshiped with them, and together they discovered the magic of the voices that emanated mysteriously from a homemade crystal set.

title: Patricia O'Grady Bride Of T. Y. Green, Banker
description: Patricia Ann O'Grady, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James O'Grady of Framingham, Mass., was married yesterday to Travis Y. Green, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Green of Biloxi, Miss. The Rev. Christopher Dunn performed the ceremony at St. Patrick's Cathedral in New York.

title: READING ABOUT THE RICH
description: IN the spring of 1958 - 26 years ago - I was invited to give some lectures in Poland by arrangement of Oskar Lange, formerly of the University of Chicago and a noted figure in the economics of the last generation, who after the war had returned to a sometimes uneasy existence in his native land. It was only a couple of years after the fall of the Stalinist regime of Boleslaw Beirut. Perhaps there had been relatively safe, uncontroversial people - neurologists, internists, gynecologists, maybe even psychiatrists - asked to lecture there before; I was the first economist with no available Marxist credentials. John Kenneth Galbraith's most recent book is ''The Anatomy of Power.'' He is the president of the American Institute and Academy of Arts and Letters.

title: AS THE DAYS DWINDLE, A QUIET CAPE BECKONS
description: By August the year's tide-and-sunrise calendars languish in seaside gift shops and marinas, marked down by half. This means only that while merchants know pricing they do not grasp value.

title: OUT TOWN 1984
description: -winning journalist and author. His new book, ''Common Ground,'' the story of three families, will be published next year.

title: BIRTHPLACE OF MANY U.S. FREEDOMS TO BE A RIGHTS MUSEUM
description: IT is unlikely to be mentioned in

title: TRAVEL BOOKSHELF
description: Great Hunting and Fishing Lodges of North America

title: 'RIGHT TO DIE' DISPUTE FOCUSES ON CALIFORNIAN
description: William Bartling used to talk a lot with his wife, Ruth, about football and basketball, fishing and camping. Today the 70- year-old Mr. Bartling cannot talk at all.

title:
BOOKS AND BUSINESS;
CAPITALISM'S SOUL
description: Eliot Janeway is the publisher of The Janeway Letter. His most recent book is ''Prospects for Prosperity.'' THE SPIRIT OF ENTERPRISE

title: DAUGHTER IS FIRM IN IDEALISM
description: YEARS before her name became known to Nigerian authorities in connection with her mother's detention, Marcia McBroom Landess's face was known to millions of ordinary people in that country.

title: Koch Announces Action for Tenants
description: Mayor Koch held what he called a ''consciousness raising session'' yesterday in front of a Harlem apartment building that he said had 23 outstanding violations for lack of heat.

title: Lauda, Though 2d, Tops Prost for Title
description: Niki Lauda of Austria won his third world auto racing championship today, edging his McLaren teammate, Alain Prost of France, by a half-point despite Prost's victory in the Portuguese Grand Prix.

title: Relearning the Game
description: You'd think anyone who'd seen as much basketball as Fuzzy Levane has over the last 45 years would have learned how to watch a game by now, but when the National Basketball Association hired the former N.B.A. player, coach and scout as an official ''observer'' a few weeks ago, they made him go to school to learn how to observe.

title: Berg Birthday
description: The 100th aniversary of the birth of the Austrian composer Alban Berg will occur next February, and will be marked in November with a series of performances by the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center.

title: Chadian Rebel Group Shuns Talks for a Day
description: The Libyan-backed delegation from Chad's main rebel group refused today to attend a working session of peace talks among rival groups fighting for power in the African desert nation.

title: CONGRESSMEN QUESTION GRANTS MADE BY LEGAL SERVICE UNIT
description: Three grants recently awarded by the Legal Services Corporation have led to a controversy over whether money that Congress appropriated to support legal services for poor people is being given to groups more interested in promoting Reagan Administration policies.

title: KIRKLAND IN VAN ON ROAD WITH MONDALE MESSAGE
description: The local labor leaders nodded in agreement on Friday night when Lane Kirkland said, ''Republican flags and Republican jobs are all made in Taiwan.'' They chuckled when he made a joke about Vice President Bush. And they applauded when Mr. Kirkland said they should make ''the final scene of Ronald Reagan's last horse opera'' a victory for Walter F. Mondale.

title: CAIRO VOWS THE 'IMPOSSIBLE,': TO TAME CITY'S WILD TRAFFIC
description: ''I don't believe in the impossible,'' said Ahmed Rushdi, Egypt's new Interior Minister.

title: STAGE: 'ALONE TOGETHER'
description: With ''Alone Together,'' his new play at the Music Box, the writer Lawrence Roman returns to Broadway for the first time since his 1960 hit, ''Under the Yum-Yum Tree.'' Although Broadway has changed a great deal during the quarter century since then, Mr. Roman has not. ''Alone Together'' recalls those long- running, latter-day domestic farces, such as ''Never Too Late'' and ''The Impossible Years,'' that became obsolete once audiences discovered that television situation comedies offered the same goods for free.

title: IRAN AND IRAQ REPORT HARD FIGHT FOR HEIGHTS
description: Teheran and Baghdad today reported bitter fighting over the weekend for control of strategic heights just inside Iran overlooking the Tigris Plain 70 miles east of the Iraqi capital.

title: Connors Beats Lendl in Final
description: Jimmy Connors defeated an erratic Ivan Lendl, 6-4, 3-6, 6-0, today and won the $375,000 Seiko Super Grand Prix tennis tournament.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: ANOTHER VOICE

title: Arrests in Philippine Killing
description: The police arrested two garbage collectors today on suspicion of killing Charles Turner, an American Peace Corps volunteer, during a robbery in a seaside town in the central Philippines, a police spokesman said.

title: VIRGINIA TRYING TO UNDO HISTORY
description: The University of Virginia has never sent its football team to a bowl game. One reason is that it has rarely been considered for a postseason game. Another reason is that more than 30 years ago when the Cavaliers were good enough to get an offer, the university's officials refused to permit their team to go to a bowl.

title: U.S. CONCEALED GRENADA LOSSES, REPORT CHARGES
description: Two former military intelligence officers assert that at least 10 more United States servicemen than were reported died in the invasion of the Caribbean island of Grenada last year.

title: Of Amplified Sound And the Linden Tree
description: Loud rock music boomed from a welfare hotel, almost drowning out ceremonies the other day dedicating a neatly manicured garden that once was a tangle of rubble and debris.

title: 4 Treasury Auctions Scheduled
description: The Treasury Department is scheduled to go to the debt markets four times this week, holding auctions for a total of $32.45 billion in new bills, notes and bonds. The auctions are expected to raise about $13 billion in new cash.

title: Miss Lowenheim Weds a Physician
description: The Garden Jewish Center in Flushing, Queens, was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Sharon Lowenheim, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jerry Lowenheim of Forest Hills, Queens, to Dr. Robert H. Lustig, the son of Richard Lustig of Alexandria, Va., and Mrs. Myron Jenner of New York and Bethel, Vt. Rabbi Irwin C. Lowenheim, the bride's uncle, performed the ceremony.

title: The Sheikh: 5 Out of 15
description: -Sheikh saved the season for the Giants last year, a place-kicker who loomed as a pillar of near-perfection for a decade or longer. He even inspired some fans to appear at Giants Stadium wearing white cloaks with Arab headdress. But now it's as if an imposter were wearing his uniform. Ali Haji- Shank, as he has called himself.

title: CITY HALL IS VIGOROUS ON PARKING REGULATIONS
description: To the Editor:

title: SCHOOL IN CITY REMAINS FAITHFUL TO RUSSIA OF OLD
description: Camille Brown intently studied ''The Atlas of Our Motherland.'' Then, leaning over her exercise map, she wrote in Cyrillic letters, ''Chernoye More.''

title: Teacher Union Charges Foe Made Illegal Gift to Mondale
description: The National Education Association, turning the tables on the National Right-to- Work Committee, has accused the group of making an illegal contribution to Walter F. Mondale's Presidential campaign.

title: LAGERFELD LIFTS SPIRITS IN PARIS
description: Karl Lagerfeld lit the fire that ignited the spring and summer fashion openings here and briefly dispelled the doldrums that preceded his colorful, authoritative presentation. The sighs of relief were audible in the audience as the curtain was drawn and models in colorful sweaters and jackets wearing amusing hats were revealed perched on cafe stools, gayly chatting.

title: EMERGENCY FUND TO AID U.S.F.L.
description: The United States Football League, at the owners meeting that concluded here Saturday, created an emergency fund of $22.5 million to help pull the league through its next season.

title: MY KINGDOM FOR A SINK OR A SHOWER OR AN OVEN
description: In this city of power plays, status symbols are serious business.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Oct. 22, 1984: MONDAY Assocd Dry GoodsL & N Housing CorpAtlantic RichfieldLubrizol CorpBoeing CoMesa PetroleumGAF CorpMt Fuel SupplyHeck's IncSmucker (JM) TUESDAY Allied StoresPublic Serv New MexBall CorpPulte HomeBlack Hills P&LRichardson-VicksBrockway IncRorer GroupCentl Illinois LtRubbermaid IncConsol Edison NYSchering-PloughEdison Bros StsSheller-GlobeGannett CoSouthwestern Pub SvKennametal IncStandard Oil IndNewell CosThrifty CorpNorfolk SouthernTriangle IndusNorwest CorpUGI CorpOvernite TransportU S Life CorpPogo ProducingValero Energy WEDNESDAY Amer Elec PwrNUI CorpBaker IntlNatl Medical EnterprBelo (AH) CorpNorth Amer CoalButler IntlNorth Amer PhilipsCeco IndusPanhandle EasternCooperweld CorpPhilips IndusDu Pont (E I)Purolator CourierEaton CorpSFN CompaniesEquifax IncSealed PowerGolden West FinlSmith IntlHoughton MifflinSmith Kline BeckmanHughes ToolSquibb CorpInland SteelStandard-PacificLamaur IncSybron CorpMinn Pwr & LtTesoro PetroleumNCNB CorpTodd ShipyardsN L IndusU S Leasing IntlNorth Amer PhilipsWisc Elec Pwr THURSDAY Allied CorpHandy & HarmanAlltel CorpHexcel CorpAmer Home PrdtsInterstate PowerAmsted IndusLawter IntlAvery IntlLibbey-Owens-FordBeverly EnterprisesLuby's CafeteriasBurlington IndusMark ControlsCoachman IndusMorton-ThiokolConsol FoodsNalco ChemicalCurtiss-WrightNatl Distillers & ChemDonnelley (RR) Norton CoDravo CorpOlin CorpEastern Gas & FuelParker-HannifinEmpire Dist ElecPrdts Research & ChmEnserch CorpStandard Oil OhioEntex IncSun ChemicalEthyl CorpVeeco Instruments FRIDAY Armco IncMcDonnell DouglasCarter-WallaceMobil CorpDelta Air LinesMonsanto CoDexter CorpOmark IndusDyco PetroleumRaychem CorpFederal SignalRowan CosFerro CorpRyder SystemGATX CorpScotty's IncHarland (John H)Snap-On ToolsHolly SugarSun BanksKoger PropertiesTyler CorpLoctite CorpVulcan MaterialsManor CareWarnaco Inc

title: REAGAN AND MONDALE CLASH ON ARMS CONTROL AND C.I.A. IN DEBATE ON FOREIGN POLICY
description: President Reagan and Walter F. Mondale battled through a debate tonight that was marked by pointed exchanges on foreign policy and Mr. Reagan's competence.

title: Market Place; Stock Outlook: Diverse Views
description: AFTER weeks of humdrum activity, the stock market exploded late last week. On Thursday the closely watched Dow Jones industrial average surged 29.49 points in heavy volume of 149.5 million shares. Trading grew even more frantic on Friday as volume reached 186.9 million shares and advances outpaced declines by a 7-to-4 ratio. But the Dow edged up only 0.55 on Friday, to close at 1,225.93, a 35.23-point gain for the week.

title: JONES SETS WORLD RECORD
description: When the time had come to identify himself, Cpl. Stephen Jones of the Royal Air Force and Barry, Wales, said that he still considered himself a 10,000- meter runner. ''I'm not a marathon runner,'' he said today after he completed one for the first time and won the America's Marathon-Chicago in 2 hours 8 minutes 5 seconds, a world record.

title: WOMEN RAISING SONS ALONE CAN COPE
description: When a single mother is raising sons it often seems like an impossible task. How do you enforce rules, for instance, when your teen-ager has the build and biceps of a quarterback and you are barely 5 feet tall? Who will teach him to pitch a baseball and take him fishing or join him in other ''manly'' pursuits? Will he develop feminine characteristics because there is no man around the house? Might there be a greater tendency for him to be a homosexual?

title: JESSE JACKSON ON 'SATURDAY NIGHT'
description: Politics is hard, but comedy is harder. The Rev. Jesse Jackson, appearing as the host of ''Saturday Night Live'' the other night, did fine with the one but not so well with the other. He said what he wanted to say, only he wasn't particularly funny when he said it.

title: ROCK: PERSIAN GULF BAND
description: Persian Gulf's songs are as homely and sturdy as log cabins. The four-man Philadelphia band, led by the guitarist-singer Hal Shows, has applied the lessons of punk-rock - directness and economy - to riffs inherited from soul, rockabilly and the blues.

title: FROM G-MAN TO CURSOR-MAN
description: When the Federal Bureau of Investigation first considered buying computer equipment to organize the hundreds of thousands of documents needed in handling major cases, it decided to conduct a test, pitting selected agents against the electronic sleuths.

title: QUESTION BOX
description: QUESTION: With all the recent fuss over how long it's been since the Chicago Cubs won a pennant, isn't it true that Chicago's other team, the White Sox, went a longer time without appearing in a World Series?

title: Washington Watch; Fuel-Economy Cut Is Assailed
description: WASHINGTON

title: 9,200 Auto Workers Strike Mack Plants
description: About 9,200 members of the United Automobile Workers walked off their jobs today at four plants of Mack Trucks Inc. in Pennsylvania, Maryland and New Jersey over a contract dispute with the heavy-duty truck manufacturer.

title: DOLPHINS ROLL TO PERFECT HALFWAY MARK
description: Dan Marino and the Miami Dolphins continued on their merry way today, remaining as the only undefeated team in the National Football League halfway through the season.

title: Distinct Duffers
description: Pebble Beach is widely regarded as one of the world's greatest golf courses, which doesn't mean it attracts the world's greatest golfers. Except for the pros who play in the annual Bing Crosby National Pro-Am and other major tournaments at the picturesque course overlooking the Pacific on California's Monterey Peninsula, the 50,000 golfers who play the Pebble each year tend to be distinct duffers, according to the club pro, Steve McLennan.

title: Pakistan Protest Broken Up
description: The police used tear gas and nightsticks today to disperse students on the fourth day of anti-Government protests in the southern province of Sind, witnesses reported. Students said two people were wounded by tear-gas shells and two others arrested. There was no immediate comment from the police.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: MONDAY, OCTOBER 22, 1984

title: ADVISER SAYS REAGAN WILL DISMISS OFFICIALS LINKED TO REBEL PRIMER
description: The White House national security adviser said today that President Reagan would dismiss any United States official who developed or approved the Central Intelligence Agency manual advising Nicaraguan rebels to commit political assassinations.

title: A Retirement From Soo Line
description: Thomas M. Beckley, 62 years old, will retire as chairman of the Soo Line Railroad Company next April.

title: The Candidates Today
description: Walter F. Mondale leaves the debate site of Kansas

title: AUTO UNION IS STRAINED BY IMPACT OF CANADIAN STRIKE
description: Union officials contend that the five-day-old strike by 36,000 Canadian automobile workers against the General Motors Corporation is putting a strain on relations with members of the same union in the United States who now face layoffs.

title: RANGERS DEFEAT ISLANDERS
description: The latest installment in the Rangers-Islanders wars was near its end last night when John Tonelli of the Islanders crashed his stick against the glass in back of the goal. He had just missed a chance to score and he would not forgive himself.

title: ELDERLY MAY PLAY KEY ELECTION ROLE
description: If Walter F. Mondale has any chance of overtaking President Reagan by Election Day, Anthony and Frances Cornillo will have to help lead the way.

title: OF GROWTH, GRAPEFRUIT AND DYING
description: It's still difficult for people to think of Florida as a megastate. Tourism, its primary, $20 billion-a-year industry, always seemed ephemeral to people transplanted from regions where the steel industry, or the automobile industry, or waving fields of grain seemed more rooted in permanence than a packaged tour to Disney World or rabbit warrens of time-sharing condominiums.

title: NEWS SUMMARY;
description: MONDAY, OCTOBER, 22, 1984 International OPEC oil ministers began gathering in Geneva to prepare for their emergency meeting, called for next Monday after three countries cut oil prices last week. Several of the 13 members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries are expected to draft a plan to try to avert a price war. (Page A1, Column 1.) Twenty-six American employees of the United States Embassy left Lebanon in the last two days amid continuing security threats, diplomatic sources said. More are expected to leave today and the size of the staff will be set at about 30, a senior State Department official said. (A1:3.)

title: Congress Gets Ratings From Consumer Group
description: A consumer lobby has given 100 percent voting records to only two members of Congress, Representatives Charles Hayes, Democrat of Illinois, and Howard L. Berman, Democrat of California, who are serving their first terms.

title: Ellen S. Fisher Marries Steven Richard Kaplan
description: The marriage of Ellen Suzanne Fisher, founder of and principal in Design and Planning, an interior-design and architecture firm in New York, to Steven Richard Kaplan, deputy director of design for the New York City Department of Parks and Recreation, architecture division, took place yesterday at Bet Torah Synagogue in Mount Kisco, N.Y. Rabbi Yaakov Rone performed the ceremony.

title: PROTECTION FROM WRONGFUL DISMISSAL
description: After 32 years with See's Candies Inc., Wayne Pugh returned from a vacation to learn that he was fired. Even though he was a vice president (who had worked his way up from washing dishes), he was given no reason and told to get out that day. When he asked about the dismissal, he was told to ''look deep within himself'' for an answer.

title: CURRENT INTEREST RATES
description: Tax-Exempt Bonds*10.24

title: NEW ATTRACTION AT MIAMI ZOO WEARS SUIT AND TIE
description: An uncommon zoo specimen that survives on a diet of hamburgers, French fries and Coke went on display this weekend at Miami's MetroZoo.

title: REGIONAL COMPANIES BECOMING DEEPER AND WIDER
description: Regional theaters, especially those around New York and in nearby states, are looking backward with imagination. At the same time, they are continuing to offer first professional productions of new plays, as well as revivals of familiar classics. But the trend is towards diversification and deepening of the repertory.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on the Style page Oct. 14 about fashion in Milan incorrectly described Ariane Koizumi, a model known as Ariane. She is of Japanese and Dutch parentage.

title: AUTO STUDY CITES REPEAT OFFENDERS
description: About 30 percent of fatal automobile accidents caused by drunken drivers last year were committed by repeat offenders, according to a new study by the National Transportation Safety Board.

title: Leftist Guerrilla Chief Is Returned to Argentina
description: The former leader of Argentina's Montonero guerrilla movement was extradited to Argentina from Brazil early today in a secret operation apparently intended to protect him from assassination attempts, the semiofficial Telam press agency reported.

title: PARKING COSTS MOUNT WITH NO END IN SIGHT
description: In a red-carpeted showroom on the main floor of the General Motors Building at Fifth Avenue and 59th Street, the sticker price on a Chevrolet Chevette reads $5,508.

title: REDSKINS FALL TO CARDINALS
description: Neil O'Donoghue, making up for two earlier misses, booted a 21-yard field goal with three seconds remaining, lifting the St. Louis Cardinals to a 26- 24 triumph today over the Washington Redskins.

title: TIME TO TERMINATE FURTHER GENETIC EXPERIMENTS ON FARM ANIMALS
description: To the Editor:

title: MASTER OF THE MOVIES
description: The death in a Paris suburb yesterday of Francois Truffaut, at age 52, removes from the international film scene one of the masters of the medium who, with his early associate, Jean-Luc Godard, forever changed the way films look as well as the way we look at films. Unlike the more fiery Mr. Godard, with whom he later broke for reasons that had more to do with personality than with politics, Mr. Truffaut was a quiet revolutionary who worked in conventional modes to make most unconventional films.

title: SOPHIA LOREN IS A MOTHER IN 'AURORA'
description: The decline of the star is a show-business phenomenon waiting for the inevitable speculations of budding sociologists. With all of the razzle-dazzle publicity being devoted to popular culture these days, where is the glitter of old? Where is the Broadway musical's new Ethel Merman or Mary Martin, the stage's Katharine Cornell or the Lunts, the movies' Bette Davis or Gary Cooper? The true star didn't need a trendy director or momentous script to attract an audience. Merely appearing was enough, no matter the vehicle used for the occasion.

title: Poll in Minnesota Shows Mondale Leads Reagan
description: Walter F. Mondale has a lead of six percentage points over President Reagan in Mr. Mondale's home state of Minnesota, according to results of a poll published today in The Minneapolis Star and Tribune.

title: MONDAY SPORTS Football
description: Falcons vs. Los Angeles Rams, at Atlanta. This is the second meeting in three weeks between the N.F.C. Western Division rivals.

title: Pinhas Ben-Mazliah, 87, Dies; High Priest of the Samaritans
description: The high priest of the Samaritans, Pinhas Ben-Mazliah, died Saturday in in the Israeli-occupied West Bank town of Nablus.

title: Futures/Options; Insurers' Own Risks
description: AFTER lobbying successfully for the right to use financial futures and options for hedging purposes, a number of states, led by New York, finally agreed last year that life insurers needed their own insurance against lending and borrowing risks.

title: Gas Prices Up 2 Cents
description: Average gasoline prices in the United States are up 2 cents a gallon since Labor Day, while heating oil prices are down by the same amount in a reversal of the usual seasonal patterns, an analyst, Dan Lundberg, said today.

title: OUTDOORS: LESSON FOR AN EXPERT
description: ERROL, N.H.

title: A BITTER CONTEST IN A LAVISH SETTING
description: On downtown street corners, in hotel lobbies and near the Municipal Auditorium, the boxing poster abounded. ''The Main Event,'' the poster proclaimed, against a stark black backdrop with a set of worn boxing gloves marked ''Reagan'' and ''Mondale.''

title: Agency in Westchester Calls Child Unit a Fake
description: A child abuse agency in Westchester County yesterday charged that former state Senator Joseph Pisani set up a fake child abuse agency in Yonkers that illegally issued detective licenses and guns.

title: GRACE COMMISSION 'FINDINGS' ON CIVIL SERVICE RETIREMENT DO NOT WAH
description: To the Editor:

title: Small F.D.I.C. Surplus
description: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation had its worst year in many as far as helping shrink the Federal budget deficit, the results for the fiscal year 1984 will show.

title: NOTICEABLY GRACIOUS
description: The clouds were passing below, and America was somewhere underneath, and as Grete Waitz was on her way to another race, she was saying that one of the nice things about being back in the United States is that she is permitted to be a normal person again. The unfortunate part of being Norway's national heroine is that when her running clothes are put aside, she remains the figure that has been cast forever outside Bislett Stadium in Oslo.

title: Man Killed in Gold Mine Did Not Use Safety Gear
description: A man who died deep inside a gold mine filled with toxic gas had not attached a required safety line that could have been used to pull him to safety, the mine's owner said today.

title: Rachel F. Freedman and Daniel P. Rosen Marry
description: At the Westchester Reform Temple in Scarsdale, N.Y., yesterday Rachel Frances Freedman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul G. Freedman, was married to Daniel Philip Rosen, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Nathan Rosen. Both families live in New Rochelle, N.Y. Rabbi Jack Stern Jr., assisted by Cantor Joseph Boardman, performed the ceremony.

title: Jane Bachman Is Wed To S. I. Wulf in Boston
description: Jane Elizabeth Bachman, chief of reporters for Sports Illustrated magazine, and Steven Ira Wulf, an associate writer for the magazine, were married yesterday at the Old South Meeting House in Boston. James D. St. Clair, a justice of the peace and lawyer, officiated.

title: CONCERT: LA BRECQUE ON PIANO
description: No one could come away from Saturday night's concert by Rebecca La Brecque, Larry Newland and the American Composers Orchestra at Alice Tully Hall without the sounds of America ringing in their ears. Some of this music said things we might not have wanted to hear and said them in unappetizing ways, but the three piano concertos on this program had a flavor no European could have concocted.

title: EPISCOPAL BISHOPS, IN LETTER, URGE DEBATE ON MORAL ISSUES
description: A pastoral letter about religion and politics was read yesterday to Episcopal congregations around the country, asserting that their faith's ''moral imperatives'' required Episcopalians to address issues of human welfare and survival. It stressed that for Episcopalians such issues should take precedence over slogans, simple answers to complex issues, or one-issue politics.

title: Rebels Kill 13 in Raid On a Salvadoran Plant
description: Guerrillas armed with mortars and automatic weapons attacked an electrical installation north of the capital today, killing 12 soldiers and a security guard, a field commander said.

title: FRANCOIS TRUFFAUT, NEW WAVE DIRECTOR, DIES
description: Francois Truffaut, the exuberant film director whose depictions of children, women and romantic obsessions helped make him a leader of the New Wave group of French movie makers, died yesterday. He was 52 years old.

title: Girl Missing Since June Found Beaten to Death
description: A 16-year-old girl missing since June 1 was found slain Saturday in a heavily wooded area in Westchester County, the state police said.

title: BURDEN FOR BANK SHAREHOLDERS
description: Shareholders of the nation's major bank holding companies have begun paying, in some cases heavily, for their institutions' mistakes. These include enormous loans to energy, agricultural and real-estate businesses in the United States and to financially troubled countries in Latin America.

title: FOE OF SANDINISTAS SAYS HE WILL QUIT RACE FOR PRESIDENCY
description: One of the leading opposition candidates for President, Virgilio Godoy Reyes, said tonight that he would quit the campaign.

title: NEW ENGLANDERS PROTESTING LOSS OF FISHING AREA
description: The hardy people who live here on the granite-laced shores of Cape Ann like to recall an old saying about Gloucestermen: Their boats were made of wood and the men of steel.

title: Animated Films
description: ''The Best of Zagreb/Toronto '84,'' a selection of award-winning films from the International Animation Festival, will be screened Nov. 1-8 at the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West 53d Street.

title: OPEC OIL MINISTERS GATHER IN EFFORT TO AVOID PRICE CUT
description: Oil ministers of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries began gathering yesterday in Geneva to prepare for an emergency meeting called for next Monday after three countries cut their oil prices last week.

title: LARGEST STUBBS SHOW EVER OPENS IN LONDON
description: The reputation of George Stubbs as the premier painter of horses and as one of the finest of all British artists, regardless of category, was created in large measure by American collectors.

title: Youth Is Charged In Fatal L.I. Crash
description: A Nassau County teen- ager was killed early today when the car in which he was a passenger went off a road here and crashed into a tree, the county police said.

title: Thousands March in Japan In Protests on Nuclear Arms
description: Tens of thousands of people marched in Japan today to protest nuclear weapons, the police said.

title: STAGE: 'A NICE COUNTRY,' AT THE AMERICAN PLACE
description: In introducing the ''typically

title: All Along 4th in Upset TORONTO, Oct. 21 (AP) - Majesty's Prince, ridden by Laffit Pincay Jr., rallied in the stretch today and won the $600,000 Rothmans International. All Along, the filly who was heavily favored, finished fourth.
description: Majesty's Prince, a 5-year-old, was well behind the leaders for most of the one-and-five-eighth-mile race at Woodbine, but caught the 90-1 longshot Jack Slade to win by two lengths.

title: Advertising; 2 Agencies Cooperate On Beers
description: -BUSCH has proven that with the careful selection of two different ad agencies, two different TV commercial directors and two different music houses, you can make your advertising for two different products look and sound the same.

title: NETS SEEM STABLE
description: What a difference a year makes. In the fall of 1983, the major subject of conversation around the Nets' training camp was not Stan Albeck, the new coach, and what he might be able to do for the franchise after a successful stint at San Antonio. Nor was it Otis Birdsong, and whether he would be able to play an entire season without an injury, which was usually a hot subject.

title: NOVICE BATTLES INCUMBENT IN L.I. RACE
description: The Congressional campaign in the Third District on Long Island has drawn the attention of the national Democratic and Republican Parties, but the outcome may well depend on the district's large number of independent voters, according to officials of both parties.

title: Romance in Room 652
description: The bride wore a long, white, satin-

title: MEXICO CITY POLICE CHIEF ASSAILED FOR HIS FATALISM TOWARD CRIME
description: The police chief of this city has come under strong criticism from legislators and others for his response to complaints about sharp increases in the crime rate.

title: LONG, KEY HOUSE MEMBER ON FOREIGN AID, RUNS LOCAL MARYLAND CAMPAIGN
description: Representative Clarence D. Long, who controls billions of dollars in foreign aid, has an international reputation as one of the most severe critics of the Reagan Administration's policy toward Central America.

title: JETS DOMINATE CHIEFS, 28-7
description: It took the Jets half the season, but they finally controlled a game today, gaining a 28-7 victory over the Kansas City Chiefs in Giants Stadium.

title: WON'T SOMEONE IN NEW YORK CARE FOR THE MENTALLY ILL?
description: To the Editor:

title: New Executive At Geers Gross
description: executive creative director are

title: The New Republic at 70
description: What do Warren Beatty, Betty Friedan, Henry A. Kissinger, Lane Kirkland and Yo Yo Ma have in common? They will be among a dozen guests offering toasts at a black-tie birthday party at the National Portrait Gallery on Nov. 27 to celebrate the 70th anniversary of The New Republic, the weekly magazine of commentary published here.

title: A COMING-OUT PARTY FOR CITICORP'S REED
description: ONE banker in line murmured that he was waiting ''to kiss the ring.'' But John S. Reed, Citicorp's new chairman and chief executive, and the head of the receiving line, offered a firm handshake instead - and all the ebullience of a new homeowner. ''It's always more fun to have a party in your own house,'' he said.

title: These Are Hectic Days For Chevron Oil Trader
description: In a few minutes on the telephone, it is possible for J. Richard Perkins to make or lose millions for Chevron International. Most of the time his deals pay off, which explains why he manages Chevron's oil trading throughout the Western Hemisphere. But he is quick to acknowledge the risks - especially at a time like last week, when price cuts by some major oil exporters sent the oil market tumbling.

title: WRITERS UNION MEETING CRITICIZES PUBLISHERS
description: Book publishers and conglomerate owners came in for almost as much criticism as the Reagan Administration during a three-day conference on Censorship and Culture that ended yesterday afternoon.

title: Bridge:Al Roth Bringing His 'Solo' To the Metropolitan Region
description: A unique feature of some recent national championships has been the ''Al Roth Solo.''

title: Abigail Kelman Wed to Peter Ian Barg
description: Abigail Tobie Kelman, a daughter of Rabbi and Mrs. Wolfe Kelman of New York, was married yesterday to Peter Ian Barg, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Maurice Barg of Brookfield, Conn. The bride's father performed the ceremony at the Park Avenue Synagogue, assisted by the bride's uncles, Rabbis Abraham and Joseph Kelman.

title: People
description: * John H. Newhall named executive vice president and managing director of Campbell-Ewald, New York.

title: LIFE'S MAGIC OVERTAKES MISS OCEANA
description: Life's Magic, who has been dueling for the 3-year-old filly championship with Miss Oceana all year, took a solid lead for the title yesterday when she pulled away from her archrival at the top of the stretch and went on to post a decisive 3 3/4-length victory in the $218,000 Beldame Stakes at Belmont Park.

title: Cambodia Appeals for Aid
description: Cambodia has appealed for foreign emergency aid after recent floods ravaged vast areas of the country, killing 20 people and leaving more than 372,000 homeless or stricken by famine or disease, the official Vietnam News Agency reported today.

title: CLAMOR IS GROWING IN THE BAHAMAS FOR PREMIER'S RESIGNATION
description: In Parliament and at outdoor rallies under the swaying palm trees of this tourist playground, there are loud, insistent demands for the resignation of the Prime Minister, Lynden O. Pindling.

title: RIVALS DISPUTE AN AMBIGUOUS RECORD
description: President Reagan and Walter F. Mondale in their debate tonight disagreed sharply on some factual aspects of strategic arms and arms control, and the record on those questions seems to be ambiguous.

title: RESENTMENT GROWS IN SPAIN ON E.E.C.
description: Resentment is growing in Spain as negotiations for its entry into the European Economic Community, though tantalizingly close after seven years, still drag on because of the Common Market's inability to set conditions.

title: WE DEMOCRATS HURT MONDALE
description: A friend of mine, someone fairly astute about politics, recently said with anger about Walter Mondale: ''This was the worst campaign I've seen in years. He really let us down.'' ''Wait a minute,'' I argued, ''why put the blame on Mondale?''

title: Defensive Lapses Bewildering Islanders
description: Year after year, Stanley Cup after Stanley Cup, the Islanders prided their championships on defense. They are starting this season, their first in the 1980's not as reigning champions, as if defense were a forgotten word.

title: LA GUARDIA COLLEGE TO GET FORD GRANT
description: La Guardia Community College in Queens is among five of the country's two-year colleges chosen as model institutions for a $1 million program to encourage students to pursue their education through the baccalaureate level or higher, the Ford Foundation announced yesterday.

title: CORRECTION
description: A headline in some editions of yesterday's sports section gave the wrong winner for the Brown-Cornell football game Saturday. Brown won, 13-9.

title: Marianne Popiel Marries
description: At the Sutton Place Synagogue yesterday Marianne Popiel, a lawyer for the Chase Manhattan Bank, was married to Stuart D. Sender, an associate with the New York law firm of Shearman & Sterling.

title: ; GIVE FOUR-CORNER 'WALK' SIGNS A CHANCE
description: To the Editor:

title: MANILA'S NUCLEAR PLANS SPUR IRE AND REFLECTION
description: Of the many ambitious development projects started by President Ferdinand E. Marcos, the biggest construction venture of them all has been a $2 billion nuclear power plant here on Bataan Peninsula, overlooking the South China Sea.

title: TIES WITH ISRAEL URGED IN VATICAN
description: A group of prelates, most of them Polish, is said to be urging Pope John Paul II to grant diplomatic recognition to Israel.

title: You Can Call Him Francis
description: Since 1979 Francis Rizzo has been

title: AS NICARAGUAN WOES MOUNT, YEARS OF SHORTAGES ARE SEEN
description: Nicaragua's economic troubles are continuing to mount, and Government leaders are saying that shortages and other hardships will continue for at least several more years.

title: MODERN PROBLEMS SPUR CHANGES AT THERMOS
description: Edward L. Davis Jr., a construction worker in Hazelton, Pa., used to have to replace his glass-lined thermos every month. That was until he tried a steel-lined container and one day left it on the outrigger of a 50-ton hydraulic crane.

title: FINDING NEW METHODS TO RECRUIT FOR PRIESTS
description: ''If you're thinking of spending the rest of your life with Him,'' the advertisement reads, ''spend several months with us.''

title: CONCERT: NEW WORK BY ZWILICH
description: For the first concert of its regular subscription season yesterday at Alice Tully Hall, the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center put together a program without a weak link. Besides sharply honed performances of three familiar masterpieces, there was the world premiere of Ellen Taaffe Zwilich's Double Quartet for Strings, a work commissioned by the society. Although it kept fast company in its first appearance, Mrs. Zwilich's score not only held up its head but made a powerful impression throughout its 4-movement, 18-minute length.

title: OPPOSITION GROUPS IN INDIA MERGE TO FORM A NEW PARTY
description: Several Indian opposition groups merged to launch a new political party today and its leaders vowed it would unseat Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's ruling Congress Party in national elections due by January.

title: Oil Mileage for Reagan
description: President Reagan seems likely to benefit politically from the current round of price cuts by some oil-exporting countries, even if there is no noticeable reduction in gasoline prices at the pump before Election Day.

title: Arbed Steel Decision Due
description: One of West Germany's main steel companies, on which the economy of the Saarland region largely depends, faces insolvency unless it receives fresh aid, industry and political sources said.

title: THE USES OF A CAMPAIGN
description: BOSTON One of the wonders of American Presidential campaigns is their centripetal effect. Under electoral compulsion highly ideological candidates may subdue their beliefs and embrace the sweet reason of the political center. The Ronald Reagan of the 1984 campaign is a case in point.

title: 26 U.S. EMPLOYEES FLY FROM BEIRUT IN SECURITY MOVE
description: Twenty-six American employees of the United States Embassy here have left the country in the last two days in the face of continuing security threats, diplomatic sources said today.

title: Indian Point Plant Resumes Service
description: The Indian Point 2 nuclear power plant resumed operation today after being shut down since June for tests and refueling, according to the Consolidated Edison Company, which owns the plant. But a Con Edison spokeswoman, Pat Richardi, said the plant, which supplies electricity to Westchester County and New York City, would be taken out of service several times over the next few days for tests of nonnuclear equipment.

title: AUSTRALIAN WANTS TO REVIVE THE BLIMP
description: Alan Bond proved he has a taste for an unusual challenge when he sponsored the Australia II, the 12-meter yacht with the revolutionary hull design that stunned the world by wresting the America's Cup from the United States last year.

title: Man, 60, Charged In Killing at Dance
description: A 60-year-old man killed his former girlfriend and injured another woman at a dance here early today before turning the gun on himself, authorities said.

title: NELSON WINNER BY SHOT
description: Larry Nelson turned back Hubert Green's late challenge with a 2-under-par 70 and put a positive finish to his season with a one-stroke victory today in the Walt Disney World Golf Classic.

title: Common Stock
description: * Comstock Group Inc., Danbury, Conn., which provides engineering and construction services, announced an initial public offering of one million shares at $9.50 a share through Paine Webber Inc.

title: Storms and Tornadoes Rake 3 Gulf Coast States By The Associated Press
description: Fast-moving thunderstorms erupted yesterday over the lower Mississippi Valley, spinning off tornadoes and dumping rain on parts of Texas and Louisiana that already were saturated from waves of storms the day before.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: NOVEL WITH COCAINE. By M. Ageyev. E. P. Dutton. 204 pages. $15.95.

title: THE CALENDAR
description: Monday

title: RESULTS IN 3D QUARTER MARKED BY MODERATION
description: Reflecting a noticeable decline in the pace of economic expansion, largely moderate increases in corporate profits were recorded in the third quarter as industries exhibited a far more mixed record than in the first half of the year.

title: REAGAN COMES BACK
description: WASHINGTON To close the gap in the final two

title: LEMIEUX IS LIVING UP TO HIS NAME AND NUMBER
description: hockey in general, and Mario Lemieux in particular.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ; Another Officer Resigns at Warner
description: Warner Communications Inc. said this weekend that Caesar P. Kimmel, executive vice president and one of the company's founders, had resigned to pursue personal interests.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Oct. 22, 1984 GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: TRANSCRIPT OF THE REAGAN-MONDALE DEBATE ON FOREIGN POLICY
description: Following is a transcript of the televised debate between President Reagan and Walter F. Mondale sponsored by the League of Women Voters in Kansas City last night, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * First City Financial Corp. of Vancouver, British Columbia, told the Securities and Exchange Commission that it had increased its stake in First Executive Corp. to 2.88 million shares, or about 6.8 percent of the total outstanding.

title: Drive Now, Pay Later
description: At the request of Ford and General Motors, the Reagan Administration has trimmed back the fuel- economy standards for light trucks. The 1985 standard will be 19.5 miles per gallon rather than 21; the 1986 standard will be 20 m.p.g. rather than 21.5. The cutback is needed, says the Transportation Department, to let Detroit meet consumer demand for larger, more powerful vehicles - and since there's no energy crisis, it's not the job of government to tell consumers what they should want or get.

title: DEVELOPED THEORY OF ATOM
description: Paul Adrian Maurice Dirac, a physicist who won the Nobel Prize in physics in 1933 and worked alongside Albert Einstein and Robert Oppenheimer, died Saturday at home after a long illness. He was 82 years old.

title: Northwest Natural Gas Names New President
description: Garbage landfills, which have occupied much of Robert L. Ridgley's attention in the last 10 months, are expected to remain high on his list of priorities. Mr. Ridgley on Friday was named president and chief executive of the Northwest Natural Gas Company, which has the largest gas extraction plant on a landfill in the country and hopes to build many more.

title: Reform Talk Worries Bond Dealers
description: While executives from securities firms were basking here in the warmth of prosperity brought by strong public demand for state and local government bonds, they were also looking nervously over their shoulders at a vast cloud of uncertainty called tax reform.

title: Carter Bids C.I.A. Chief Quit
description: Former President Jimmy Carter echoed other leading Democrats on Saturday by calling for the resignation of William J. Casey, Director of Central Intelligence, because of the agency's preparation of a manual on guerrilla warfare against Nicaragua, including advice on how to kidnap or kill Nicaraguan officials.

title: OF BIRDS AND BERRIES: MOSCOW'S WINTER FORECAST
description: The first snow of the winter has fallen in Moscow, a month earlier than last year, but the old women on the city's park benches were not surprised.

title: GIANTS LOSE TO EAGLES, 24-10
description: For more than 52 minutes of their 60- minute game, the Giants and the Eagles battered each other today and were tied, 10-10. Then came two big plays, both by the Eagles, and they turned them into touchdowns and a 24-10 victory.

title: V.A. Rate Cut On Mortgages
description: The Government has lowered the interest rate ceiling on basic home mortgage loans backed by the Veterans Administration to 13 percent, from 13.5 percent.

title: Canadians Win
description: The Canadian national eight-oared crew, winner of the gold medal at the Los Angeles Olympics, reassembled its crew for the first time since then and continued its success, capturing the featured men's championship eights today at the 20th annual Head of the Charles Regatta.

title: Letter: On Criminal Justice
description: Easing the Grand Jury Dilemma

title: Student Killed, 30 Are Hurt In Arson Blaze at Fraternity
description: A smoky fire that the authorities said was deliberately set swept through a fraternity house at Indiana University early today, killing one student and injuring at least 30.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.

title: O'Connor and 3 U.S. Bishops Arrive for 4-Day Ulster Visit
description: Four Roman Catholic prelates from the United States arrived in Northern Ireland today at the start of a four-day fact-finding mission.

title: Wilson, From Poetry to Broadway Success
description: August Wilson is seated in the half darkened theater, alone. It is early in the morning before the box office opens. Only a couple of cleaning women are visible in the orchestra of the Cort Theater. The unrecognized playwright has had to identify himself to get into the venerable house. Here, his powerful play, ''Ma Rainey's Black Bottom,'' is reawakening audiences to the wonder and dimensions of drama. The stark set is in shadows, illuminated by a naked stage light. The unnatural quiet is interrupted only by the sound of his voice, recalling how it all began.

title: 'ON WAY TO FREEDOM,' TUTU TELLS PARISH
description: Bishop Desmond Tutu, preaching in an Anglican parish church for the first time since winning the Nobel Peace Prize, said today that blacks were ''on our way to victory, on our way to freedom'' in the struggle for equal rights in South Africa.

title: SOVIET SAID TO DEPLOY A NEW MISSILE
description: Western intelligence analysts say they have received reports that the Soviet Union may have begun deploying a new land-based intercontinental ballistic missile comparable to the United States Minuteman.

title: Federal Panel Approves Use of Funds by Ferraro
description: The Federal Election Commission has ruled unanimously that Geraldine A. Ferraro, the Democratic Vice-Presidential nominee, could use leftover campaign funds to pay the travel expenses of an aide who accompanied her to the convention of the National Organization for Women in Miami on June 30.

title: Melissa Cahill, Editor, Married to Timothy John de Fiebre
description: Melissa Cahill, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Cahill of Randolph, N.J., and Sand Key, Fla., was married yesterday to Timothy John de Fiebre, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Conrad W. de Fiebre of Worthington, Ohio. The Rev. Dr. Robert F. Streetman performed the ceremony at the Waterloo United Methodist Church in Stanhope, N.J.

title: Free Flight Enterprise
description: Look for the Civil Aeronautics Board, which meets Thursday, to approve, with some exceptions, the airlines' revised schedules for six major airports, including the three that serve New York City. The revisions were aimed at ending congestion and delays.

title: Terrorists Claim $7MillionRobbery
description: A Puerto Rican terrorist group has claimed responsibility for last year's $7 million robbery from the Wells Fargo Armored Service Corporation in West Hartford, Conn.

title: WON'T SOMEONE IN NEW YORK CARE FOR THE MENTALLY ILL?
description: To the Editor:

title: Shh!!!! Rehabilitation
description: The original Library of Congress

title: Walesa Expresses Rage At Priest's Kidnapping
description: Lech Walesa expressed outrage today over the reported kidnapping of a popular, pro-Solidarity priest and said the priest's abductors would bear ''a terrible responsibility'' if they harm him.

title: VANDALS RUN TRACTOR THROUGH JERSEY SYNAGOGUE
description: Vandals painted swastikas, scrawled anti-Semitic slogans and crashed a tractor through a recently opened synagogue in Manalapan Township, N.J., the police said yesterday.

title: The Trade Deal With Israel
description: The United States' prospective free-trade zone with Israel could be more than just a special deal for a special friend. If it persuades other major trading nations that America is serious about freer trade, it could speed the process worldwide. But if it only leads others to more one-to-one compacts, it will further damage the multilateral trade agreements now in place.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Brands has elected Howard E. Fraga president and chief executive of its Sunshine Biscuits subsidiary.

title: SNEAKY GASTINEAU OUTWITS THE CHIEFS
description: Mark Gastineau, even in disguise, was easily recognizable today as the best defensive lineman in pro football.

title: BANKERS SEE DROPS IN RATES
description: The nation's commercial bankers agree that interest rates are coming down, but there is not a clear consensus on how far or how fast the rates will move.

title: When Police Go to School
description: New York City's Schools Chancellor Nathan Quinones and Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward agree in principle to let undercover police make drug busts in schools. While the idea is welcome, much depends on how well it's carried out.

title: DANCE: ATLANTA BALLET IN BROOKLYN
description: The Atlanta Ballet breezed into the Brooklyn Center for the Performing Arts at Brooklyn College on Friday for an evening of works that showed off the dancers' fine, solid ballet training. All but one of the four dances were upbeat in mood, and the program got off to a light-hearted start with George Balanchine's ''Scotch Symphony.''

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY ; Paper Relics of a Fokker And Reagan the Actor
description: A 1928 orange-and-blue Fokker flew

title: Knit One, Purl Two
description: It may make you feel a little better

title: TOURING GYMNASTS ARE A HIT
description: Take the glossy showmanship of the Ice Capades, the clowning of the Harlem Globetrotters and the fan frenzy of a rock concert, sprinkle them with the red, white and blue glitter of Olympic stardom, and that is basically what the '84 Tour of America's Gymnastics Champions looks like.

title: Days of Wine and Art
description: The Corcoran Gallery of Art,

title: POP: DB's PERFORM AT THE RITZ
description: Around the edges of many pop-song sentiments, there are hints of unhealthy notions - love shading into obsession, loneliness that becomes utter withdrawal. The dB's, a four-man band, brings out the psychopathology of everyday pop; its songs are catchy but openly maladjusted.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article yesterday gave the wrong date for a musical tribute to the composer Arthur Schwartz. It is to be held tomorrow at noon at the Majestic Theater, 247 West 44th Street.

title: HELP! I'M A PRISONER IN A TAXI
description: The latest feat of high-tech wizardry is not a new microcomputer, a wristwatch TV, an intelligent oven or any of Pac-Man's video progeny. It is an electronic box that attacks passengers in taxis, flashing out commercial messages inches from their heads.

title: Pilgrim Group Account To Scali, McCabe
description: Scali, McCabe, Sloves Direct Response has become agency for the Pilgrim Group, a wholly owned subsidiary of the First Capital Holdings Corporation.

title: DIANE SAWYER HINTS AT HER '60 MINUTES' STYLE
description: By turns pensive and earnest, walking a line between sympathy and detachment, Diane Sawyer made her debut last night as a correspondent for ''60 Minutes,'' the highly rated weekly magazine on CBS.

title: Safer Hockey Nets
description: If you see something other than the puck sliding across the ice at National Hockey League games this season, don't be alarmed. It will probably be just the net.

title: A Star for a Night At Lincoln Center
description: In recognition of Lincoln Center's

title: RAIDERS TRIUMPH, 44-37
description: Even for the Raiders it was a wild game. Before the largest crowd to ever watch a Charger home game, Marc Wilson ripped apart the San Diego secondary for 332 yards and five touchdowns as the Los Angeles Raiders held on to defeat the Chargers today, 44-37.

title: Break in Main Floods First Ave. at 44th St.
description: A break in a 12-inch water main last night flooded First Avenue and sent water into the basements of several buldings in the East 40's.

title: WILSON, FROM POETRY TO BROADWAY SUCCESS
description: darkened theater, alone. It is early in the morning before the box office opens. Only a couple of cleaning women are visible in the orchestra of the Cort Theater. The unrecognized playwright has had to identify himself to get into the venerable house. Here, his powerful play, ''Ma Rainey's Black Bottom,'' is reawakening audiences to the wonder and dimensions of drama. The stark set is in shadows, illuminated by a naked stage light. The unnatural quiet is interrupted only by the sound of his voice, recalling how it all began.

title: GARMENT STUDY CRITICIZES PLANS FOR TIMES SQ.
description: The merchandise mart planned by the Urban Development Corporation as part of the Times Square redevelopment project would do severe damage to the garment business, according to a study by the Federation of Apparel Manufacturers.

title: TRANSCRIPT OF THE REAGAN-MONDALE DEBATE ON FOREIGN POLICY
description: PARTICIPANTS IN THE DEBATE

title: Albanian Leader Reappears in Public
description: Albania's Communist Party leader, Enver Hoxha, who had not been seen in public since May, has reappeared in public at a rally after months of speculation in the West that he was in poor health.

title: 600th Israeli Dies in Lebanon
description: Israel today announced the death of its 600th soldier killed in the war it launched into Lebanon 28 months ago. Alon Tsur, a 30-year-old corporal from the northern border settlement of Shamir, was killed Saturday in a rocket attack near the Zaharani River in southern Lebanon, the army said.

title: CREDIBILITY AN ISSUE FOR BOARD
description: Last month, after persistent rumors circulated here that pressure from the Government was delaying the report on the assassination of Benigno S. Aquino Jr., the chairman of the investigatory panel, Corazon J. Agrava, decided that a statement was called for.

title: Times Co. Net Up 39% In Quarter
description: The New York Times Company reported yesterday that its third-quarter net income rose 39 percent, to $20.4 million, or 51 cents a share, from $14.6 million, or 37 cents a share, in the period a year earlier.

title: CRANE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net losses after losses from discontinued operations of $12,613,000 for the quarter and $43,947,000 for the 9 months and a pretax gain of $29,809,000 for the 9 months which includes $26,775,000 from the sale of a long-term investment and certain quarry operations.

title: E.E.C. Jobless Rate Up
description: The European Economic Community's unemployment rate rose to 11.3 percent in September, from 11 percent in August, the community's statistics office, Eurostat, said today.

title: The U.N. Today;  Oct. 23, 1984
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: MARCOS TO CALL A SPECIAL COURT IN AQUINO KILLING
description: President Ferdinand E. Marcos announced today that he would refer the findings of the citizen's panel investigating the assassination last year of the opposition leader Benigno S. Aquino Jr. to a special court ''because military men are involved.''

title: MISSISSIPPI MATCH HAS A RACIAL TONE
description: Events on two recent consecutive nights in the municipal auditorium of this small Mississippi Delta city etched the stark contrasts in race and political philosophy that characterize the campaign in this state's Second Congressional District.

title: Conservatives Assail Harkin
description: The National Conservative Political Action Committee has said it will spend $50,000 to keep Representative Tom Harkin, Democrat of Iowa, from defeating Senator Roger W. Jepsen, Republican of Iowa.

title: Announcement By Kodak Due
description: The Eastman Kodak Company on Tuesday may introduce a high-capacity floppy disk for personal computers, according to Michael Ellman, a securities analyst for Wertheim & Company, a Wall Street investment banking firm. He also said Kodak might announce a powerful new disk drive as part of a move into the personal computer field.

title: DEBATE SETS STAGE FOR HARD FIGHTING ON TRAIL TO NOV. 6
description: President Reagan and Walter F. Mondale resumed their Presidential campaigning in key states today after a debate that strategists for both men said had not provided Mr. Mondale with the lift he needed to pose an immediate threat to the President.

title: CAPITAL CITIES COMMUNICATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including an extraordinary gain of $7,585,000 for the quarter and 9 months.

title: S.E.C. WILL STILL SEEK DISCLOSURE BY REPORTERS
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission said today that it intended to pursue the legal theory that news reporters have an obligation under law to publish certain information about their own financial dealings.

title: MOSELEY, HALLGARTEN, ESTAROOK WEEDER HOLDING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
LANE CO AND WOOL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Norway Gas Find
description: Statoil, the state-owned oil company, has discovered large quantities of natural gas on a field at the edge of the Barents Sea near the northernmost tip of Norway, a Statoil spokesman said today. The field, unofficially called Snow White, could hold as much as 400 billion cubic meters, almost double the size of Norway's current biggest gas field. Statoil also found oil traces in Snow White but not enough to make it commercially viable.

title: CLEVEPAK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a loss of $1,202,000 for the quarter and $3,441,000 for the 9 months from discontinued operations, a loss of $10 million for the quarter and 9 months on the disposal of discontinued operations and a nonrecurring loss of $450,000 in the quarter representing Hart & Cooley strike costs, partially offset by unidentified nonrecurring net gains. c-Net income after a loss of $1,099,000 for quarter and a gain of $237,000 for the 9 months from discontinued operations and gains of $3,259,000 for the quarter and $3,668,000 for the 9 months on the disposal of discontinued operations.

title: SHULTZ SAYS SITUATION OF JEWS IN SOVIET IS STILL 'VERY GRIM'
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that persecution of Jews in the Soviet Union appeared to be worsening and that Jewish emigration had come to a ''virtual standstill.''

title: COUTURE HOUSES SHINE IN READY-TO-WEAR
description: Valentino, the Rome couturier, showed his ready-to- wear collection for the first time in the tents in the Tuileries Gardens along with the French designers. He received a rousing reception because of his collection, which was a tour de force, and because of his inspired notion to set up a boardwalk and carpeting between the tent and the park entrance so his audience could avoid the mud.

title: Mondale Unsinkable Aboard the Midway
description: Walter F. Mondale is not in as deep water as President Reagan suggested he might be.

title: 3 DRUG MAKERS GAIN; 4TH FALLS
description: The Bristol-Myers Company and the Schering-Plough Corporation said yesterday that their earnings rose in the third quarter, while the SmithKline Beckman Corporation reported that its profits edged barely higher. However, another pharmaceuticals concern, the A.H. Robins Company, said that its income plunged because of the cost of litigation involving its Dalkon Shield intrauterine device.

title: Pollsters' Picks
description: Because this is a Presidential election year, polls are a part of everyday life. Or so it seems.

description: Central Intelligence Agency officials told two Senators today that no copies of the C.I.A. manual on guerrilla warfare were edited to remove advice on ''neutralizing'' Nicaraguan Government officials.

Every player on the court has a specific assignment and timing is of the utmost importance. It is a system that Brown has employed so long that many opposing coaches and players are as familiar with it as he and his team.

JULIAN MAYFIELD, 56, AN ACTOR AND WRITER ON BLACK THEMES
description: Julian Mayfield, a black American novelist, playwright and actor, died of heart complications on Saturday at the Seventh Day Adventist Hospital in Takoma Park, Md. He was 56 years old and a resident of Washington.

title: REAGAN, AT B-1 FACTORY, PRESSES ATTACK ON RIVAL
description: President Reagan, flush from what he considered a successful debate performance against Walter F. Mondale, stalked his rival from the shadow of the B-1 bomber today, saying the Democratic nominee had a ''frightening'' national defense record of ''hostility to a strong, secure America.''

title: Stargell to Coach
description: Willie Stargell, the Pittsburgh Pirates' career leader in home runs, runs batted in and extra-base hits, was named Pittsburgh's minor league hitting instructor. The 43- year-old Stargell, who retired after the 1982 season, served the last two years as a special assistant to Harding Peterson, the Pirates' executive vice president, working mainly as an adviser in the minor leagues. . . . Jim Bibby, who once pitched in their organization but found greater success at Pittsburgh and Texas, has been signed by the Mets as a minor league pitching coach. The club will assign him to a specific team later.
