THE U.S.F.L.'S GRAND DESIGN
description: More and more, the name of the game in sports is litigation. But by its nature, litigation often creates negotiation, which often creates a settlement. On that premise, the United States Football League has hatched a grand design that the National Football League surely should consider, especially given the N.F.L.'s tendency in recent years to lose the ''big ones'' in court.

title: Offer From Staley Accepted by CFS
description: The A. E. Staley Manufacturing Company announced today that it had reached a definitive agreement with CFS Continental Inc., an institutional food service company based in Chicago, to acquire CFS for $38 a share in cash, or about $350 million.

THREE HELD IN JERSEY KILLING AS INVESTIGATION CONTINUES
description: After a night of gambling in Atlantic City, Robert Marshall and his wife, Maria, were returning to their home in Toms River, N.J., early Sept. 7 when Mr. Marshall pulled his Cadillac into a wooded, unlighted picnic area in the median of the Garden State Parkway near Oyster Creek.

title: PERES SAYS ISRAEL WILL DEFER ACTION ON REPORTED U.S. OFFER ON DEBT
description: Prime Minister Shimon Peres said today that the Government had decided for now against taking up what Israel has described as an American offer to defer a $500 million debt payment.

International sales for the year-ago periods amounted to $451,373,000 for the quarter and $1,195,721,000 for the 9 months.

title: 3 Die in Sri Lanka In a Series of Blasts
description: Three people were killed and at least 15 wounded in a series of bomb explosions in Colombo and its outskirts today, Defense Ministry sources said.

title: MONDALE CALLS FOE 'UNINFORMED' IN BLUNTEST ATTACKS HE HAS MADE
description: Walter F. Mondale began the final two weeks of his campaign yesterday with his bluntest attacks yet on President Reagan, calling Mr. Reagan ''the most detached, the most remote and the most uninformed President in modern history.''

title: Poland's Church Says It Fears for Priest's Life
description: Poland's Roman Catholic Church said today that it feared for the life of a kidnapped priest who supports Solidarity, and a Government spokesman asserted that the abduction was an attempt to undermine the authorities.

description: PARIS The great foreign policy debate

title: Diduck's Day
description: Butch Goring, 35, and Billy Smith, 33, were sharing a laugh as Gerald Diduck, the Islanders' 19-year-old rookie defenseman, sat in the team's dressing room yesterday and politely answered a reporter's questions.

title: RECITAL: GRANT JOHANNESEN, AT TULLY HALL
description: GRANT JOHANNESEN played the piano at Alice Tully Hall Sunday night with the fastidiousness and good sense that have marked his 40 odd years of public performing. Schumann's Fantasy in C was a case in point - beautifully paced, involved and full of delicate details.

title: People
description: * Bart McHugh has been elected senior vice president, director of cable television at Doyle Dane Bernbach.

title: 11% OF STUDENTS CLAIM AN ALCOHOL ADDICTION
description: One out of every 10 high school and junior high school students in New York State questioned in a recent survey described themselves as ''hooked'' on alcohol, and some said they had even been drunk in class.

description: Dr. Belle Boone Beard, professor emeritus of sociology at Sweet Briar College, Sweet Briar, Va., and a leading authority on gerontology and the aging process, died Oct. 12 at the Virginia Baptist Hospital in Lynchburg, Va. She was 86 years old and lived in Lynchburg.

French Car Cuts Urged
description: The French automobile industry should restructure itself along Japanese lines to recover from its current crisis and remain profitable, the Government's national industry commission said today.

title: MUM'S THE WORD, AT LEAST TIL NOV. 6
description: The principal labor at the Department of Labor these days seems to be a rigorous effort to avoid getting into the news. Except for Daniel Benjamin's sailboating and Joe Scudero's hot pursuit of a reputedly rude motorist, the effort has been fairly successful.

title: Ex-F.B.I. Agent Pleads Not Guilty to Espionage
description: The first agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation to be charged with espionage and his two Soviet co-defendants pleaded not guilty today in Federal District Court.

title: BRIDGE: MAHMOUD AND ROSENBERG WIN OGUST-SCHENKEN EVENT
description: A special event in memory of two great New York players took place Sunday at the Cavendish Club on East 48th Street. It was the Harold Ogust- Howard Schenken Memorial Tournament, a Calcutta event to aid the Family Council for Abused Children.

title: ARGENTINE LEFTIST, EXTRADITED, IS FACING TRIAL
description: A decision by Brazil to extradite Argentina's best known former guerrilla leader on Sunday is expected to result in the first prosecution of leftist political crimes since President Raul Alfonsin took office last December.

title: REAGAN'S EFFORT TO CHANGE COURSE OF GOVERNMENT
description: Four years ago, Ronald Wilson Reagan captured the Presidency and, using his knack for firing the public imagination with short, symbolic messages, immediately signaled his intention to lead a political revolution that would redirect the shape and role of government in American life.

description: b-Includes a nonrecurring gain of $1,100,000, or 29 cents a share, relating to changes in the tax law. c-Net loss.

title: NICARAGUA PARTY FAILS TO STOP VOTE
description: Nicaraguan Government officials said today that the withdrawal of a leading opposition presidential candidate would not affect their plans to hold elections Nov. 4.

title: PROTECTING PENTAGON WHISTLERS
description: In recent weeks, even President Reagan has jumped on the bandwagon of military reform, joining Democrats and Republicans in complaining about wasteful Pentagon procurement programs. This is all to the good, but it doesn't make up for the Administration's shabby and hypocritical treatment of Pentagon whistle-blowers, who put their careers on the line to report the waste of taxpayers' dollars.

title: Chicago's Redistricting Plan Blocked by Ruling of Justice
description: Justice John Paul Stevens of the Supreme Court, acting at the request of the Chicago City Council, today temporarily blocked carrying out a voter redistricting plan designed to increase minority voting power in the city.

title: GOULDS PUMPS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Gewandhaus Orchestra In a Beethoven Cycle
description: For those accustomed to the tonal brilliance and easy virtuosity of America's major orchestras, the Gewandhaus Orchestra of Leipzig offers both a puzzle and stimulus for thought. The Gewandhaus is here with its conductor Kurt Masur to play all nine Beethoven symphonies in five concerts this month and next, and Sunday afternoon's affair at Carnegie Hall was the first.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ; 2 Executives Out, Equimark Reports
description: Two top executives have stepped down at the Pittsburgh-based Equimark Corporation and its principal subsidiary, Equibank, the financially troubled bank holding company said yesterday.

title: WALKOUT IN CANADA IS CAUSING LAYOFFS AT U.S. AUTO PLANTS DETROIT, Oct. 22 (AP) - More than 17,000 autoworkers in the United States were laid off today because of the nationwide strike in Canada against the General Motors Corporation.
description: The company put the layoff total at 17,470, with four of 29 assembly operations in the United States having closed. Six parts plants either stopped or curtailed operations, the company said.

title: THOSE CABLE SPECIALISTS
description: studiously choosing just the right computer, the perfect printer, the ideal modem and monitor - can still trip over one of the least-talked about frustrations in personal computing: the cable problem. All those meticulously chosen parts may not hook up to each other because the connecting cables required for each are different in size or design.

title: Long Pact for Langway
description: Rod Langway, considered by many the best defenseman in the National Hockey League, has signed what amounts to a lifetime agreement with the Washington Capitals. In keeping with club policy, the Capitals did not disclose details of the new pact, but General Manager David Poile described it as ''a series of options and revisions that, in essence, make it a lifetime contract.'' . . . Mike Bossy of the Islanders was named the N.H.L.'s player of the week after scoring 10 goals and making 10 assists in six games, the fastest start of his career.

title: Phones Disrupted By East Side Fire
description: Thousands of telephone lines on the East Side of Manhattan were knocked out yesterday morning when a fire broke out among cables in the basement of a New York Telephone building at 227 East 30th Street, near Third Avenue.

title: THEATER IS DEDICATED TO AUDREY WOOD, AGENT
description: Friends and former clients of the literary agent Audrey Wood arrived yesterday for the dedication of the Audrey Wood Theater. The theater is the smaller of two stages in the Jack Lawrence Theater at 359 West 48th Street. Mr. Lawrence has attempted to name the larger stage for Tennessee Williams, Miss Wood's most famous client, but the move is being fought in court by the Williams estate.

title: Wharton Producing Cable Business Show
description: The University of Pennsylvania's Wharton School, one of the nation's best known business schools, is about to launch a cable-television show on management topics.

Seabrook Court Action
description: The State Supreme Court today dismissed a request filed by a business group seeking to eliminate roadblocks to a major securities sale by Public Service Company of New Hampshire, the main owner of the Seabrook nuclear power plant.

title: NEWS SUMMARY;
description: TUESDAY, OCTOBER 23, 1984 International Eight oil-producing countries - six OPEC members and two nonmembers - began informal talks in Geneva in a joint attempt to curb oil production and prop up falling oil prices. But the meeting was dealt an immediate setback when it became known that the oil minister of Nigeria, which unilaterally lowered its oil price last week, would not take part. (Page A1, Column 1.) A race for computer supremacy is under way and could, some experts say, determine which country will dominate the world in economic, military and scientific fields in the next century. (C1:5.) description: Jordan has received $119.5 million from Saudi Arabia as the third and final installment of aid this year, official sources said today. Arab oil- producing states agreed in 1978 to give financial support to Arab countries that border Israel.

title: King Questionable
description: Albert King, the Net forward suffering from back spasms, will remain in traction at University Hospital in Newark for at least three or four days, according to a team spokesman. Thus, his status is questionable for the club's season opener Friday night against Atlanta at Byrne Meadowlands Arena. . . . To bolster the shooting in their backcourt after trading Butch Carter to the Knicks last week, the Indiana Pacers acquired Terence Stansbury, a high-scoring rookie from Temple, in a deal with the Dallas Mavericks yesterday.

title: 20 BILLION CANDLES FOR LINCOLN CENTER
description: There were, in effect, twenty billion candles, not even counting the hundreds on the dinner tables and the head-tall cake, or the 7,000 electric ones on the potted trees and the banners. But nothing seemed too extravagant for the birthday honoree, who had after all entertained over 72 million guests at some 45,000 gatherings of its own.

title: INJURY TO WINSLOW MAY END CAREER

description: New Jersey drivers and their front seat passengers would have to buckle their seat belts or face a $20 fine under a bill given final approval by the Legislature today.

title: Computer
description: The Computer Sciences Corporation said it had received a $14.1 million subcontract to provide the International Business Machines Corporation with services for the design competition phase of a Federal Aviation Administration advanced automation system program. During the 35-month phase of the program, an I.B.M. team and a team led by the Hughes Aircraft Company will develop competitive designs for a new, more automated computer system for air traffic control operations.

description: A SCRIBELIKE mentality seems to be evolving among software publishers. A number of them are now marketing programs for producing illuminated manuscripts, 20th-century style.

In those days the networks often bought a group of a studio's films before some of the films had even completed production.

title: Howe Rejoins Dodgers
description: Steve Howe , the relief pitcher who was suspended for the 1984 baseball season because of repeated involvement with drugs, has signed a one- year contract with the Los Angeles Dodgers. Howe, 26, spent the last month pitching for the Dodgers' entry in the Arizona Instructional League, and will continue preparation for next season by playing for the Dodgers' entry in the Dominican Republic winter league.

He sits with the press. He knows each reporter by first name. He laughs with them, and when the day's session is over he is very often standing outside the courtroom handing out documents.

title: South African Troops Seal Off a Black Area
description: SEBOKENG, South Africa, Tuesday, Oct. 23 (Reuters) - Thousands of South African troops and policemen sealed off this black township today in a predawn raid that the Government said was aimed at curbing ''criminal and revolutionary elements.''

title: Ramey at City Opera In Boito's 'Mefistofele'
description: Samuel Ramey came leaping, stomping, whistling and tumbling onto the stage of the New York State Theater Sunday afternoon, in the title role of Arrigo Boito's ''Mefistofele.'' This New York City Opera production, originally created for Norman Triegle, has been the property of Mr. Ramey for the better part of a decade now; Sunday's performance reconfirmed his status as one of the most dynamic singing actors of our time.

title: FONAR CORP reports earnings for Year to June 30

description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J.

A COURT TEST FOR AGE RULES
description: Harold H. Thurston lost his pilot's wings when he turned 60 years old, and now the Supreme Court must decide whether he should have been grounded completely or could have stayed on as a lower-ranking member of the flight crew.

description: The long-distance rivals of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, having attracted large numbers of customers by offering bargain prices in the United States, have begun to offer discounts on international calls.

title: 'STORE WARS' IN THE GINZA
description: At the rate of 200,000 a day, Tokyo shoppers are streaming into the Ginza to stare at two competing visions of the ultimate Japanese department store. And what they see are two competing versions of contemporary Japan.

title: Bronx IRT Train Jumps the Tracks
description: A 10-car subway train jumped the tracks in the Bronx yesterday, forcing the removal of 200 passengers and disrupting train service for nearly three hours, authorities said.

title: Suit Fights Listing Personal Finances
description: The New York City School Boards Association has filed a lawsuit in Federal court objecting to the Board of Education's new requirement that community school board members submit financial disclosure statements.

title: KEY TRONIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 22
Interest Cost Cut For Florida Bonds
description: A $72 million issue of water and sewer revenue bonds for Manatee County, Fla., was tentatively priced with a maximum yield of 10 1/4 percent for bonds due in 2009 through underwriters led by Smith Barney, Harris Upham.

title: LOUISVILLE GAS & ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Boesky Raises Midlands Holding
description: Ivan F. Boesky, the New York investor, told the Securities and Exchange Commission that he and companies that he controls raised their stake in the Midlands Energy Company to 777,800 common shares, or 9 percent of the outstanding shares of the oil and gas exploration concern.

title: Seasons' Meetings
description: A friend, just back from a month on the other side of the world, was moaning before she left about what she'd miss. ''Autumn's the best part of the year in New York,'' she said.

title: South African to Visit Israel
description: South Africa's Foreign Minister, Roelof F. Botha, is to travel to Israel next month on a visit that will be private but is nevertheless expected to include a meeting with Yitzhak Shamir, the Israeli Foreign Minister, Israeli officials said today.

title: Las Vegas Escort Operator Is Given Heart of TV Actor
description: The heart of the actor Jon-Erik Hexum, who died from a shooting accident on the set of his television series, has been transplanted into the body of a Las Vegas escort service owner who otherwise would have died within weeks, his cardiologist said today.

description: National Intergroup Inc. yesterday reported a 58.2 percent drop in earnings for the third quarter, while another steel company, Armco Inc., said its loss narrowed to $272.7 million in the quarter.

IMPROVED BUT NOT SATISFIED
description: The Giants have reached midseason with a 4-4 record, and their coach is not satisfied. Neither are their players.

title: REAGAN REMARK ON PHILIPPINES ASSAILED
description: Opposition leaders today assailed President Reagan's comments on Philippine politics, saying they showed that he had badly misread the situation.

title: Boeing Net Rises 14.7%
description: Third-quarter net income of the Boeing Company increased 14.7 percent, to $86 million, or 88 cents a share, from $75 million, or 78 cents a share, in the period a year ago, the company reported yesterday. Sales, however, eased 2.7 percent, to $2.2 billion, from $2.26 billion.

title: DECORATED WALDORF AND PLAZA
description: Ellen Lehman McCluskey Long, an internationally known interior decorator and founder and president of Ellen L. McCluskey Associates, the New York design concern, died of cancer Sunday at Doctors Hospital. She was 70 years old.

title: MAGAZINE PUBLISHERS GATHER
description: The opening session of the American Magazine Conference this morning was highlighted by an unusually statesmanlike message from the president of the Magazine Publishers Association and an examination of a different philosophy of growth by a young publisher.

title: CORRECTION
description: A Washington dispatch yesterday on points of dispute in the previous night's Presidential debate incorrectly described The Times's interview last Friday with Edgar Chamorro, a senior Nicaraguan rebel. Commenting on the rebels' use of a Central Intelligence Agency training manual on guerrilla warfare, Mr. Chamarro said that while his staff had torn two pages from some copies of the manual, it ''was already being distributed and we couldn't get all the copies back.''

title: 'CRUEL COVER-UP' ON JOB POISONS LAID TO U.S.
description: Ralph Nader accused the Administration today of a ''cruel cover-up,'' saying it had failed to notify 200,000 workers of health risks from toxic substances at their jobs.

title: Lloyds Bank Realigning
description: Lloyds Bank said today that it would form a new group to combine its own merchant banking activities and those of its international banking subsidiary.

title: A Computer in Every Class
description: The Mahalia Jackson School in Harlem will become the first in the city with a computer in every classroom, thanks to an anonymous donor.

title: NEW WILDERNESS PERIL: GROWERS OF MARIJUANA
description: Law-enforcement officials say many of the nation's most scenic and remote wilderness areas are increasingly dangerous for visitors because of violence linked to illegal marijuana cultivation.

title: THE ALLIES PREFER REAGAN
description: Western Europeans, who have an impressive stake in the outcome of America's Presidential election, had strong doubts about Ronald Reagan in 1980 but now are mostly in the Reagan camp because they find themselves in tune with his ideas, leadership style and policies.

title: GULF CANADA LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Mirella Freni Presents Group of French Songs
description: Mirella Freni opened Avery Fisher Hall's ''Superstars of Song'' series Sunday afternoon with a recital to warm hearts and soothe aching ears.

title: Japan Warns U.S. on Steel
description: A request by the United States that Japan voluntarily restrain its steel exports could hurt trade relations between the two nations, a top official in Japan's Foreign Ministry said today.

title: Florida Housing's Yield Set at 10.68%
description: A $133.9 million issue of Florida Housing Finance Agency single- family mortgage revenue bonds was tentatively priced yesterday with a maximum yield for interest-bearing bonds of about 10.68 percent for 10 5/8 percent bonds due in 2009 at a price of 99 1/2 through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

title: BRADLEY AND MOCHARY CLASH ON ECONOMY IN DEBATE
description: Senator Bill Bradley and Mary V. Mochary, his Republican challenger, clashed sharply yesterday over economic policy and the Reagan Administration's actions in Nicaragua.

title: Justice Rehnquist's Assurances
description: Justice William Rehnquist offers comforting words to those who worry that President Reagan, in a second term, would reshape the Supreme Court in his image. Presidents may try to bend the Court to their will, he says, but usually fail.

title: HBO Chief Executive Adds Chairman's Title
description: Michael J. Fuchs yesterday was given the additional title of chairman of Home Box Office Inc. less than two weeks after being named chief executive when Frank J. Biondi was asked to leave the top post at the Time Inc. subsidiary.

title: NIGHTMARES ARE LINKED TO CREATIVITY IN NEW VIEW
description: THE novel ''Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde'' was based on a nightmare in which Robert Louis Stevenson saw a dapper Englishman change into a hideous monster. Mary Shelley's ''Frankenstein'' was also based on a nightmare, as may have been Bram Stoker's ''Dracula.'' New research suggests that such links between nightmares and creative vision may be more than accidental.

title: LEE MAJORS IS COWBOY IN CBS FILM
description: ONCE ''The Six Million Dollar Man'' and currently ''The Fall Guy,'' Lee Majors is taking a break from weekly series in ''The Cowboy and the Ballerina,'' tonight's television movie on CBS at 9. Mr. Majors plays a cowboy named Clay who gets involved with a Russian ballerina named Natalia (Leslie Wing) as she runs away from her touring company in order to see her mother, a Soviet exile, in New York. Says she in her slightly accented English: ''I think you are most remarkable person.'' Says he: ''They ain't going to believe this.'' That's right, Clay, they're not.

title: EVANS & SUTHERLAND COMUTER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
EQUAL RIGHTS RULING FOR AUTO INSURANCE EXPECTED TO SPREAD
description: A Pennsylvania Supreme Court ruling that the state's Equal Rights Amendment prohibits insurance companies from basing their automobile rates on sex is expected to prompt new litigation in the 15 other states that have such amendments.

title: Christiana Stake
description: The Transamerican Capital Corporation, a San Antonio investment concern, and John Holmes Jr., president of Holmes, Ferguson & Company, a New York investment bank, told the Securities and Exchange Commission they had acquired 29.8 percent of the total stock outstanding of the Christiana Companies.

title: A TOWN DIVIDED
description: In its heyday, Huntington was West Virginia's star performer. It was economically diversified and, some said, more sophisticated than Charleston, the capital. One of its first buildings was an opera house. Its entrepreneurs built the glass, iron and steel factories, manufactured equipment to sell to the distant coal fields, retailed goods to households for miles around and banked the profits.

title: DANCE:'STRANGERS,' A NEW WORK BY DRIVER
description: THERE was a time when anyone looking at Senta Driver's choreography would have focused on the cerebral riddles that underly her work. Miss Driver is no less a conceptual choreographer but it is her movement range more than her ideas that now come strikingly to the fore. What her company dances and how it dances are what matters. Driver dancers dance differently - in the shape of their movement and the force that drives it.

title: N.F.L. OWNERS TO TACKLE ANTITRUST SUIT
description: The National Football League owners begin two days of meetings today in New Orleans, where a major topic is expected to be the antitrust suit filed against the league last week by the United States Football League.

title: A MATTER OF PRIVATE, NOT PUBLIC, MORALITY
description: To the Editor:

title: CONTINENTAL BANK'S STOCK
description: LOTS of stock market players want the big play, and with turnarounds such as Chrysler and International Harvester in mind, apparently they are now looking at Continental Illinois, the big Chicago bank rescued from failure last summer by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation. But some analysts think buyers are being premature in such enthusiasm, if not misguided.

title: KRM PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
PHOTO CAPTURES THE DARK RINGS OF URANUS
description: THE first clear photograph of rings around the planet Uranus has been obtained from an observatory in Chile, the Jet Propulsion Laboratory in Pasadena, Calif., has reported. Uranus is the seventh planet outward from the Sun.

title: Democrats Focus Effort
description: Walter F. Mondale and 50 Democratic members of Congress will give speeches Tuesday calling for negotiations to end the nuclear arms race, the House Speaker, Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., announced today. Mr. Mondale, the Democratic nominee for President, is to speak at the University of Michigan. Mr. O'Neill is to address a gathering in State College, Pa. Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts is to discuss nuclear arms while campaigning for the party ticket in California.

title: BRIEFING ; Calories and Curry
description: Losing weight in India can be an unforgettable and prize-winning

Isaac, the ageny's chairman said at a news conference yesterday at the annual convention here of the American Bankers Association.

title: 23 Catholic Bishops See Nuclear War as Top Issue
description: A group of 23 Roman Catholic bishops today criticized members of the church hierarchy today who they said had made abortion rather than nuclear war the foremost issue for Catholic voters.

title: Angola Foreign Minister, A Hard-Liner, Is Ousted
description: The President of Angola, Jose Eduardo dos Santos, has dismissed his Foreign Minister and temporarily assumed the post, the state-run Portuguese radio reported.

An ambitious new exhibition at Fraunces Tavern Museum, ''The Legacy of Lafayette,'' provides in document, illustration and artifact an account of his colorful life, 54 Pearl Street, at Broad Street (425-1778).

Martin, the director of the Bessemer Securities Corporation, was elected chairman of the board of governors of the Brooklyn Museum at the board's annual meeting last Thursday. Mr. Martin has been a member of the board of governors since 1948 and has been chairman of its acquisitions committee since 1976. The Bessemer Securities Corporation is a holding company owned by the descendants of the steel magnate Henry Phipps.

title: Truth on Trial - in India

Brahma Chellaney of The Associated Press was in the Punjab last June when Prime Minister Indira Gandhi ordered the attack on Sikh extremists occupying the Golden Temple in Amritsar.

title: Ford Recalls Small Trucks

title: Better Radiation Detector
description: A new system for detecting X-ray emissions, developed at the University of California's Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory, is expected to give scientists a quicker, less expensive and more sensitive means of measuring low-level radiation from plutonium or other radioactive material. The system should facilitate the examination of soil in areas suspected of radioactive contamination.

description: The two largest operators of 42d Street movie theaters filed suit yesterday against the $1.6 billion Times Square redevelopment project, charging that the city and state violated antitrust laws in their selection of operators for legitimate theaters being planned for the block.

title: Ethiopian Secessionists Capture Tourist Resort
description: Secessionist Ethiopian guerrillas seized an Ethiopian tourist resort last week and captured 130 people, including 10 foreigners, Western diplomats and rebel spokesmen said today.

title: Texas Western
description: Tamaron Oil and Gas Inc., based in Denver, said it planned to acquire all of the outstanding stock of Texas Western Inc. of Dallas for $1.2 million in a combination of cash, stock and the assumption of certain obligations. Texas Western, which has been operating under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code, owns and operates more than 80 wells on 15 leases in Texas.

description: The Yale School of Medicine will establish a liver research center with a $2.4 million grant from the National Institutes of Health, the school announced today.

title: MAYOR FAULTED BY COMPTROLLER ON WARD CASE

title: JONES STILL WITHOUT AN ANSWER TO 'HOW?'

''I haven't got a key to my own,'' Steve Jones said. The day after he completed a marathon for the first time and set a world record of 2 hours 8 minutes 5 seconds all in one historic run, he was beginning to realize that many doors could now open.

title: A 'Positive Shift' From Coffee Campaign
description: The pro-coffee effort created by Advertising to Women caused a ''positive shift among the target group,'' according to the National Coffee Association of the U.S.A., its sponsor.

title: HOW THE HOLLYWOOD STUDIO SHAKE-UPS ARE SHAKING DOWN
description: There have been more changes in Hollywood's executive suites in the last six weeks than during any similar period in the last 40 years. title: Bathhouses Are Kept Closed
description: The state's First District Court of Appeal refused today to reopen five bathhouses for homosexuals that were closed by a judge last week amid a drive by city health officials against the spread of AIDS, acquired immune deficiency syndrome. The court said the bathhouses could renew their requests at a later date.

title: THEATER:'ZELDA,' BY WILLIAM LUCE

The biography helped the public to see Zelda as an individual instead of a wraith living only in F. Scott Fitzgerald's long shadow. In William Luce's play, ''Zelda,'' which opened last night at the American Place Theater, the madness, but little of the romantic dream, overwhelms the story of her life.

title: TRIBUTE TO ARTHUR SCHWARTZ FILLS THEATER WITH HIS MUSIC
description: On the stage of the Majestic Theater a lone pianist played ''That's Entertainment'' as luminaries from the theater and Hollywood gathered to honor the composer Arthur Schwartz. His songs, which enlivened the musical theater for four decades, returned to Broadway in a noontime memorial program sponsored by ASCAP.

title: WEDNESDAY SPORTS Boxing
description: Livingstone Bramble vs. Edwin Curet, 10 rounds, lightweights, at Harrah's Marina Hotel Casino, Atlantic City. First preliminary 8 P.M. This is a nontitle bout for Bramble, and his first fight since wresting the World Boxing Association lightweight crown from Ray (Boom Boom) Mancini last June. Bramble, a native of St. Croix in the Virgin Islands, is 21-1-1 and has won 14 bouts by knockout. Curet is 15-3-2 with 7 knockouts.

DANCE:MOLISSA FENLEY AT THE JOYCE
description: MOLISSA FENLEY burst upon the dance world as a fresh spirit in 1979. There was much talk of her high-energy movement and the committed way with which she threw herself into that movement from dance to dance, with a little help from stamina-building running and weight training. It seemed no one had ever presented energy in quite so raw a way on the dance stage, with bodies bounding up and back into the earth like churning pistons.

title: No Headline
description: WEDNESDAY, OCTOBER 24, 1984 International The slaying of Benigno Aquino Jr., the Philippine opposition leader, was the result of a military plot, according to the five-member group investigating the 1983 murder. After a nearly yearlong inquiry, the panel unanimously rejected the contention of the military that Mr. Aquino had been killed by a lone gunman hired by Communists. (Page A1, Column 6.) The deaths of four senior Salvadoran officers was reported by an Army spokesman in San Salvador. He said the leading combat commander of the Salvadoran Army, Lieut. Col. Domingo Monterrosa, was among those killed in a helicopter crash in rebel- held territory. (A1:2.)

title: Unions Consider Frontier Buyout
description: Preliminary talks between Frontier Airlines' union representatives and management are contining on plans for the employees to buy out the financially troubled airline. The free- agent guard, who suffered through a miserable season with the Nets last year, has been sitting in his home in Columbus, Ohio, waiting for a call from his agent, Howard Slusher, saying that he and the team have come to an agreement.

After the Yves Saint Laurent and Kenzo shows tomorrow, the opening season will be over.

Ovett told The London Daily Mail that after initial tests indicated such an infection he rejected an exploratory operation to verify the diagnosis in favor of constant monitoring to see if the infection clears up.

title: Bay Shipbuilding
description: The Bay Shipbuilding Company of Sturgeon Bay, Wis., has agreed to build three freighters capable of handling up to 700 40-foot containers of cargo for the Sea-Land Corporation of Edison, N.J. Officials expect about 1,500 jobs to be created as the result of the $180 million contract. United States Transportation Secretary Elizabeth H. Dole said that the ships would operate between Tacoma, Wash., and Anchorage and Kodiak, Alaska. The first two are to be delivered in October 1986, she said, and the third in May 1987.

title: 2 Die on Spanish Freighter
description: Two stowaways, believed to be Moroccans, were found dead today in a ship's hold when the Spanish freighter Cava de Valldemosa arrived in Barcelona from Casablanca, Morocco. Port authorities said the men were believed to have died of suffocation.

title: WORK ETHIC WORKS AT T.C.U.
description: Coaches throughout the history of football have made players pay the penalty for mistakes in a game or at practice by sending them on numerous laps around the field late in the day as their teammates head for dinner and rest. But Jim Wacker at Texas Christian has a new version of the football punishment detail. He said he is making players run three miles at 6 A.M. if they miss classes or study halls.

description: ''WITH INTENT TO KILL,'' tonight's television movie on CBS at 9, is described by the network as a psychological mystery. Actually, it is a labored exploration of a sensitive point of law and should have been called ''By Reason of Insanity.''

title: HUSBAND SEEKS HEART TRANSPLANT
description: Mary V. Mochary, the Republican candidate for United States Senate, suspended her campaign today for three days to accompany her husband to the Stanford University Medical Center, where he expects to enter its heart transplant program.

title: Judgment in Manila Before Benigno Aquino ended his American exile and flew back to the Philippines last year, he was urgently warned to stay away - by the President's wife and sometime co-ruler, Imelda Marcos. Her message was succinct and prophetic: Your enemies will kill you.
description: Now a commission investigating Mr. Aquino's murder identifies those enemies as soldiers on the payroll of President Ferdinand Marcos. And since the elimination of his chief democratic rival, Mr. Marcos has been energetically arguing that the only alternative to his repressive rule is Communism - a false argument unthinkingly echoed by President Reagan in Sunday's debate.

title: Man Dies in Nevada Plunge
description: A man jumped or fell to his death from the roof of a 23-story hotel on the Las Vegas Strip today, crashing through a ceiling and almost hitting a Congressman, the authorities said. The man was identified as Vito D'Antoni, a 30-year- old hotel porter. Representative Harry Reid, Democrat of Nevada, and 60 other guests attending a fund-raising breakfast at the Holiday Inn Center Strip escaped injury.

title: Simmer to Bruins
description: The Boston Bruins, in an effort to bolster their offense, acquired the high-scoring left wing Charlie Simmer from the Los Angeles Kings for a first-round choice in the 1985 National Hockey League entry draft. Simmer, 30 years old, scored 44 goals and 48 assists for 92 points in 79 games for the Kings last season, leading the club in goals for the second time in his career. He scored one goal in five games with Los Angeles this season. . . . Brad Park , the Detroit Red Wing defenseman who hurt his left knee in a game against the Rangers last week, underwent arthroscopic surgery yesterday, but it was not immediately known how long he will be out of the lineup.

title: FOR HOLY-HINDU CITY, PILGRIMS, PROFITS AND POLITICS
description: Well before dawn, Hindus in loincloths and saris move quietly through the twisting six- foot-wide streets of this ancient city, heading for the stone stairs called ghats that lead down a sharp embankment to the Ganges - Mother Ganga, as it is known, the holiest body of water in the Hindu universe.

title: Stake in Murphy
description: A group led by the Minneapolis investor Irwin L. Jacobs told the Securities and Exchange Commission that it had increased its stake in the G. C. Murphy Company to 803,700 common shares, or 19.4 percent of the total outstanding. In the filing, Mr. Jacobs's most recent purchase was reported to have occurred on Oct. 17, when he bought 160,000 shares for $6 million. The investors said they could be expected to use their shares in favor of a takeover attempt of Murphy, a Pittsburgh- based chain of variety stores.

title: VON BULOW BID IS DISMISSED
description: -The state's highest court, the Court of Appeals, today dismissed an appeal by Claus von Bulow of a decision appointing of the Chemical Bank and C. Sims Farr to manage the multimillion-dollar estate of his comatose wife, Martha. Mr. von Bulow, who objected to the choice, was convicted in 1982 in Newport, R.I., of trying to murder his wife, but the conviction was overturned and he faces a new trial.

description: ''I'm talking about buying a minor league baseball franchise. Boxing is in a tremendous decline. It's an absolute travesty. The whole business smells.'' - Bob Arum, a top boxing promoter.

title: PILOT'S DEATH LEADS TO REPORT OF A SECRET LIFE IN THE C.I.A.
description: No one mentioned where or how Richard C. Spicer died when his family and friends buried him Monday in the undulating hills of northwestern Pennsylvania, some of the mourners said.

title: ABOUT NEW YORK
description: Carol Bellamy says she is not running. But she is walking awfully fast these days. At 6 o'clock on a Monday morning - certainly one of the week's most disagreeable hours - she walked ever so briskly to work across the Brooklyn Bridge at her usual, dark hour. One of her aides tried to drop a hint by wearing his bathrobe to an early morning meeting once, to no avail.

title: New Technique Found For Hip Replacements
description: Thousands of elderly people could be spared operations to replace artificial hip joints by a technique that eliminates bubbles in the cement holding the joints in place, researchers say.

description: The Security Council adopted a resolution tonight condemning South Africa's policy of apartheid and the recent wave of arrests and detentions.

title: The Soviet Soiree
description: The 67th anniversary of the Bolshevik Revolution is to be celebrated here Nov. 6, Election Day, by the Soviet Union. The Soviet Embassy has sent out invitations to a two-hour reception that afternoon, at a time when many residents of Washington will be casting ballots for a President.

title: AVOIDABLE DAMAGE TO THE C.I.A.
description: McCLEAN, VA. - The Central Intelligence Agency is in the headlines again. The most recent episode involves the distribution of a pamphlet advising Nicaraguan rebels how to ''neutralize'' Nicaraguan officials. A few weeks ago, it was a question of whether it was right for President Reagan to blame yet another security failure in Beirut on the deterioration of our intelligence-gathering capabilities before he came to office.

title: German Nuclear Data

description: SHOULD your wine cellar in England be overstocked with Lafite-Rothschild, you can always sell it at auction, along with the extra Bentley, Grandmama's diamonds and the castle in Spain.

title: OPEC PLANNING OUTPUT CUT
description: Representatives of six of the 13 members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries asserted today that they had reached broad agreement on a plan to cut oil production and bolster weakening prices.

title: 100 THREATS A WEEK ARE REPORTED AGAINST U.S. INSTALLATIONS ABROAD
description: Government agencies have been receiving about 100 threats a week against American embassies and other installations abroad since the bombing of the United States Embassy in Lebanon last month, Administration officials said today.

Results for the latest quarter and 9 months include a number of one-time events which include the sale of an office building in Los Angeles that amounted to a gain of 11 cents a share. The company said results for the latest and year-ago 9 months reflect unauthorized investment activities which occurred at the company during 1983 and the first quarter of 1984.

title: BUSINESS OFFERED AID IF THEY RELOCATE WITHIN CITY
description: The pressure of rising rents, particularly in downtown and midtown Manhattan, has forced an increasing number of manufacturing companies to find space elsewhere. Over the last few years, in an effort to halt the exodus to neighboring counties and states where rents are often cheaper, the city has put forward such incentives as tax abatements, job training and grant programs.

description: The Bonnier Group, the largest publisher in Sweden, with more than 20 magazines and newspapers, including ventures in other Scandinavian countries and elsewhere in Europe, has purchased a 50 percent interest in the Washington Dossier magazine for an undisclosed amount of cash.

title: A Couple Finds Glass In Child's Baby Food
description: Glass fragments were found in two jars of Gerber's baby food last night by a Brooklyn couple whose 11-month-old daughter had been fed half of one jar, according to the police. The child was taken to St. John's Episcopal Hospital where doctors said she seemed to be unaffected.

description: Commentators around the world, looking at the American Presidential campaign debate with varying degrees of admiration or contempt, agreed in large part that Walter F. Mondale failed to win a victory over President Reagan that could propel him to the Presidency.

description: The number of school bus accidents in which teen-age bus drivers are involved is causing concern in several states, officials say.

title: AFTERMATH OF DEBATE
description: The conventional political view among most Democrats this year has been that President Reagan enjoyed such wide popularity that the best political tactic for Walter F. Mondale was to challenge Mr. Reagan's policies but not to attack him personally. Mr. Mondale knew there was a risk, but he took the gamble Sunday night in the debate in Kansas City, Mo. Afterward, Reagan aides commented that it was bold of the Democratic nominee to strike at Mr. Reagan's strong suit by repeatedly questioning his capacity to govern.

title: Fullback Reinstated

Browne, who started the first three games of the season, resumed practicing Monday night after Judge Albert H. Burns of Brighton District Court adjourned the case until May 5 and indicated that the charge would be dropped if Browne stayed out of trouble.

''There will be no camping out this year,'' said the 20-year-old Pasadena City College sophomore, who will be crowned Thursday. She will preside at the parade New Year's Day and attend the Rose Bowl football game.

title: COUNT AGAIN; Closed Circuit What's special about the last weekend in October? The running of the New York City Marathon, the end of daylight saving time and, for drivers in the vicinity of Manhattan's Central Park, renewed all-day access to the park drive. For years now, from May to October, the Parks Department has closed the park circuit for several hours in midday and again in the evening. It assumes that the benefits to cyclists, skaters, runners and strollers outweigh the inconvenience of congestion in all surrounding streets.
description: Even if once valid, that assumption is now wrong. The number of cars in midtown sets new records each year.

title: TORPEDOING SALVADOR'S TALKS
description: Now that tentative talks are under way between the Salvadoran Government and guerrillas, both sides have begun to press for battlefield advantages that will translate into negotiating leverage. The terrible irony in this fight-and-talk strategy is that the Government's position is likely to be undermined by the $196.5 million in United States military aid approved for fiscal 1984. The new aid is likely to exacerbate the traditional weaknesses of the Salvadoran Army, threatening the prospects for negotiations and ultimately encouraging direct United States involvement in an escalating war.

title: Insurer Seeking Satellite Recovery
description: A London-based insurance syndicate, stung when two satellites launched from a United States space shuttle floated into the wrong orbit, has recruited the shuttle to get them back. Stephen Merrett, a Lloyd's of London underwriter whose firm led a group of three syndicates that paid $180 million for the lost satellites, said he signed a $10.5 million deal for the recovery and relaunch of the satellites.

The protesters were renewing efforts to have Senda Berenson , who wrote the rules in 1893 for the first women's college game, enshrined.

title: MCCARTNEY TALKS OF HIS FILM WITH STARR
description: THERE'S a bit of gray in Paul McCartney's impeccably styled hair these days, and when the most commercially successful ex-Beatle lifts his eyebrows to emphasize a point, his forehead bunches into parallel lines. But hand him a guitar, set him down in front of a camera, and suddenly he's as winsome as ever. His eyes roll heavenward, and with the apparent sincerity of a choirboy, he sings in the limpid high tenor that carried the melodies of ''Yesterday,'' ''Eleanor Rigby'' and his other contributions to the most popular band in the history of popular music.

They have turned to copper, stainless steel, aluminum or some combination. They contend that the nonstick coating inhibits heat transfer and that certain foods, such as steaks and chops, do not brown as well as on other surfaces and that omelettes tend to have a rubbery crust.

What is in question is whether she yet has the range of material and talent to sustain a night of theater. Don't be surprised if you leave the Lyceum feeling more enthusiastic about Whoopi Goldberg, the personality, than ''Whoopi Goldberg,'' the show.

title: Merger Is Near
description: Bill Tatham Jr. said the lawyers had got down to the formalities and that the merger of his Oklahoma Outlaws and the Arizona Wranglers of the United States Football League should be completed before the end of next week. Under the proposed arrangement, the Wranglers, now owned by Dr. Ted Diethrich, would be the surviving team and would remain in Phoenix. . . . Jeff Blatnick, who won a gold medal in Greco-Roman wrestling at the Olympics, may be wrestling opposing linemen next spring if the Wranglers' co-owner, George Allen , has his way.

description: Denmark's consumer prices rose seven-tenths of 1 percent last month from August and 6.2 percent from a year ago, the Government said today.

description: Representative Albert Gore Jr., chairman of the House Science and Technology Subcommittee on Investigations and Oversight, made documents public today that he said suggested ''an extensive pattern of misconduct and mismanagement at the highest levels'' of the Federal Emergency Management Agency.

description: Du Pont yesterday reported flat earnings for the third quarter, following two periods of sharp gains. Analysts said the company suffered from lower demand and prices for chemical products, weaker foreign earnings due to the strong dollar, and a slack market for refiners, which hurt its Conoco oil subsidiary. Three oil companies also reported quarterly results yesterday.

title: MARATHON MIXES IDENTITIES

Public expression of the linkage between intelligence operations abroad and human rights considerations is found in Section 2.11, ''Prohibition on Assassination,'' of Executive Order No. 12333 (1981): ''No person employed by or acting on behalf of the United States Government shall engage in, or conspire to engage in, assassination.''

Reckoning With Armageddon
description: The Book of Revelation last got a big press in 1976, when Hollywood used it as the basis of a little movie called ''The Omen.'' It showed any number of bad things happening to any number of good people because Satan, in the shape of a small boy named Damien, was back in town - and Armageddon was just around the corner.

title: A MODERN LOOK, A CLASSIC TOUCH FROM SAINT LAURENT
description: When Yves Saint Laurent sent the first nine models down the runway at the opening of his spring and summer collection wearing sober jump suits in wool jersey or cotton poplin, he took a quantum leap over the other ready-to-wear designers here. He was actually presenting simple clothes for modern women.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ; Co-op Bonds Offered For Seminole Electric
description: The first issue of an estimated $1 billion of tax-exempt bonds to be sold before year-end by rural electric cooperatives across the country was offered to investors yesterday.

title: HERS
description: THE patient has AIDS. Therefore, in obedience to the signs posted on his door, we are putting on gloves and masks. Finally we troop into his room and stand around his bed, our faces obscured by surgical masks, our hands encased in plastic skins. The resident looks down at the sick man in the bed, and suddenly sounds a little bit abashed. ''Um, this is hospital policy,'' he says. ''We're all wearing these masks because that's the policy when anyone has a serious infection.'' So the patient is questioned through masks and responds to the faceless doctors gathered around him, and then he is touched through thin plastic. Then we troop out of the room, strip off our masks and gloves and, one after another, solemnly wash our hands.

title: AQUEDUCT OPENS LONG SEASON
description: Horseplayers gritted their teeth yesterday and resigned themselves to spending the next seven months at Aqueduct Race Track. The city's offseason track, celebrating its 25th anniversary, opened on an appropriately gray day to a crowd of only 12,056, but those who turned out were greeted by a few bright changes.

title: INFORMATION RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
JUDGE ACTS TO EASE JAIL OVERCROWDING
description: A State Supreme Court justice, citing chronic overcrowding conditions at the Nassau County Jail, today directed the state to transfer its prisoners from the jail within 14 days of their sentencing. The justice, George Murphy, said the jail had been ''brought to the brink of violating the federally imposed maximum'' of 938 inmates and has been at 115 to 125 percent of capacity. The state failed to prove it was incapable of immediately lodging inmates who are sentenced to state prisons, he said.

Ten officers and two protesters were hurt when about 100 separatists, protesting court sentences against suspected Corsican guerrillas, hurled gasoline bombs at squads of riot policemen, officers said.

title: ADAPTING FURNITURE TO CONTEMPORARY USES
description: How does furniture designed and made with a specific purpose in mind adapt to contemporary needs and tastes? Perhaps the only furniture that can lay claim to useful continuity is those enormous wardrobes and sideboards beloved by the Victorians, but even they are often taken apart and their components recycled into smaller, tidier and more useful forms.

Miss Bruser studied at the Juilliard School and took a master's degree from the San Francisco Conservatory of Music.

Confession in Fraternity Fire
description: A former Indiana University student has admitted in a taped confession that he lit the fraternity house fire that killed one student and injured 30 others, the authorities say. In a tape played Monday in Monroe Superior Court, Jerry Scott Zook, 23 years old, of Indianapolis, admitted setting the fire early Sunday after a fight with some residents of the Zeta Beta Tau fraternity house. Judge John Baker entered pleas of not guilty to charges of murder and arson on Mr. Zook's behalf, and trial was set for Dec. 17.

title: SOFTWARE AIDS SMALL PROJECTS
description: THE spreadsheet, word processor and database manager have been best-selling computer programs because they can be applied to a broad range of workers in a broad range of industries. But the microcomputer software industry has been hard-pressed to find the next such mainstream product.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: NEARLY every homeowner or apartment dweller has to paint from time to time. Regardless of the size of the project, cleanup, from washing brushes to removing spills and smears, must follow. Much of it can be minimized or even eliminated by taking preventive measures while working and by using common sense in handling tools and materials.

title: LEADING NICARAGUAN BISHOP SAYS SANDINISTAS IMPOSE 'OPPRESSIONS'

title: BANTA, GEORGE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
THE SEAVER QUESTION
description: He's about to turn 40 years old, but the question for Tom Seaver is not whether he can still pitch. With a 15-11 record, he was the Chicago White Sox's best pitcher during the recent season; he needs only 12 victories next season to be a 300-game winner. The more curious question now is: Would the Mets have won the National League East if he had remained on their staff? And would the Mets be better or not as good next year with him?

title: REAGAN PRAISES U.S. DEAD IN GRENADA AND BEIRUT

title: CONCERT: Y CHAMBER
description: GERARD SCHWARZ and the Y Chamber Symphony batted 1.000 Saturday night, with a four-part program that was enjoyable in each. It opened with a bracing Handel Concerto Grosso and closed with springy, bright Prokofiev, with a New York premiere and a welcome return in between.

title: E.E.C. Prices Rise 0.1%
description: Consumer prices in the 10-nation European Economic Community rose five- tenths of 1 percent in September from August and 6.6 percent from 12 months before, Eurostat, the community's statistics agency, said today. Eurostat said Greece recorded the largest increase over the month at 2.8 percent, while prices fell one-tenth of 1 percent in Luxembourg, for the best performance.

title: Hinckley Is Unable to Vote
description: John W. Hinckley Jr., who was found not guilty by reason of insanity in the 1981 shooting of President Reagan and three others, will not be voting in next month's Presidential election. Norm Allen, the Jefferson County Clerk, said Tuesday that Mr. Hinckley, who requested an absentee ballot last month, had not responded and had missed the Oct. 5 deadline for registering.

title: CARTER ON RIGHTS-A RE-EVALUATION
description: The hero's welcome accorded to former President Jimmy Carter when he visited South America this month was a tribute to his identification with human rights. It is also an opportunity to re-evaluate the complaint, still heard with some frequency, that the human rights policies of his Administration damaged the strategic interests of the United States by alienating the military but governments of otherwise friendly and important allies. In fact, as Mr. Carter's visit showed, nothing could be further from the truth.

title: A QUEST FOR 'THE SPIRIT OF LIFE'
description: When Marjorie Acker Phillips arrived here as the bride of Duncan Phillips to make her home in the handsome Phillips family mansion near Dupont Circle more than 60 years ago, it was a very different Washington.

title: IN GRENADA, ONE YEAR LATER, MANY PLANS BUT LITTLE CHANGE
description: A year after the United States-led invasion of Grenada, American soldiers still patrol the streets of the Caribbean island and help to run the police stations and enjoy the same popularity as when they first arrived.

title: The Handicapped Thank Their Friendly Bus Drivers
description: Bus drivers who cheerfully load

title: Republic Tie With Pan Am Pan American World Airways and Republic Airlines announced yesterday that they
description: had made some reciprocal arrangements with their frequent

title: FORMASTER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net income.

title: Gamble, Lynn File For Free Agency
description: Oscar Gamble is doing it for the third time and Tug McGraw for the second, but Fred Lynn is trying it for the first time and he could emerge from the experience with more disappointment than money.

title: Gunmen Kill 10 in Uganda
description: Unidentified gunmen believed to be guerrillas opposed to President Milton Obote fired into a crowd in the village of Bubuubi, 40 miles north of Kampala, killing 10 people, a Catholic newspaper reported today.

title: PHIBRO-SALOMON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
F.B.I. MAY TEST COMPUTER INDEX FOR WHITE-COLLAR CRIME INQUIRIES
description: An advisory panel of the Federal Bureau of Investigation has recommended the limited Federal use of a computerized file that could allow criminal justice agencies all over the country to exchange the names of white-collar crime suspects and their associates.

title: JWT Group Earnings Up 23.1% in 3d Quarter
description: JWT Group yesterday reported record revenues and earnings for both the third quarter and nine months ended Sept. 30.

title: Copywriter Wins Nelson Algren Award
description: Peter Trachtenberg, a copywriter with the Book-of-the-Month Club in New York, has won the third annual Nelson Algren Award for a short story in the spirit of Algren, a novelist, short story writer and essayist.

title: TOXIC THREAT SEEN TO WATER SUPPLIES
description: The key Government program to monitor the contamination of underground water supplies by toxic waste is not working, according to a report drafted by officials of the Environmental Protection Agency.

title: Pentagon Scuttlebutt
description: Pentagon officials are spreading

title: A CHINATOWN MERCHANT PORTRAYED AS CRIME BOSS
description: Until Tuesday, Edward Tse Chiu Chan was generally regarded as a prosperous Chinatown entrepreneur whose largess in campaign contributions and lobbying efforts on behalf of Chinese- Americans had propelled him into the company of leading New York and national public figures.

title: DIAGNOSTIC DATA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
GREEN TREE ACCEPTANCE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
EXCERPTS FROM MAJORITY'S REPORT ON ASSASSINATION OF AQUINO
description: Following are excerpts from a report made public today by four members of the five-member commission that investigated the assassination of the opposition leader Benigno S. Aquino Jr. on Aug. 21, 1983. The report by the chairman of the commission, Corazon Agrava, was made public Tuesday.

title: ELCO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Girding for Ghouls
description: Georgetown is bracing for raucous Halloween celebrations this weekend. In recent years there has been considerable drunkenness, noise and general vulgarity, mostly by young nonresidents who cavort along M Street and Wisconsin Avenue, then spill over to side streets.

title: SULLAIR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
THE ERSATZ AGNEW
description: HOUSTON Fourteen years ago, Vice President Spiro T. Agnew was barnstorming the country on behalf of conservative Republican candidates for Congress. He inveighed lustily against permissiveness in child upbringing (''the Spock-marked generation''), the liberal media (''instant analysis''), and people not sufficiently upbeat about the Nixon- Agnew Administration (''nattering nabobs of negativism'').

title: Banks Face Dividend Restriction
description: Citing the deteriorating quality of bank loan portfolios, C. Todd Conover, the chief regulator of federally chartered banks, said yesterday that his office would restrict dividend payments by banks that did not maintain adequate reserves against possible loan losses.

title: Krupp-Kl"ockner Stake Purchased
description: In a major move into the European steel industry, Conzinc Riotinto of Australia Ltd., the giant raw materials concern, has agreed to pay $175 million for a 35 percent share in a new steel company, to be formed from a merger of the steelmaking operations of Kl"ockner-Werke A.G. and Krupp Stahl A.G..

title: PRENTICE-HALL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $900,000 on the sale of real estate.

title: MEI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
PERFORMANCE: TIM MILLER IN BROOKLYN
description: CONSIDERABLE claims are made for the few productions staged by a young performance artist, Tim Miller, whose mixed-media piece, ''Democracy in America'' had its premiere last night as part of the Brooklyn Academy's ''Next Wave'' series.

title: No Headline
description: THURSDAY, OCTOBER 25, 1984 International The Philippines' Chief of Staff gave up his command temporarily after he was named in the majority report of a panel investigating the murder of Benigno S. Aquino Jr. as being involved in a military plot to kill the opposition leader. The armed forces' leader, Gen. Fabian C. Ver, is a cousin and close associate of President Ferdinand E. Marcos. (Page A1, Column 2.) Nicaraguan leaders were criticized by a leading Roman Catholic bishop, who said they were not sincerely seeking peace and were imposing ''new oppressions.'' The prelate, Bishop Pablo Antonio Vega, said Sandinista ideology ''promotes and institutionalizes violence.'' (A1:1-2.)

title: INCREASE IN TV AD RATES RAISES CAMPAIGN COSTS
description: Crowds cheer when President Reagan talks of taming inflation and when he asks if Americans are better off than they were four years ago. But one place where reduced inflation is not helping the President, or Walter F. Mondale for that matter, is in paying campaign bills.

title: POLICE UNABLE TO REACH WARD IN MASS MURDER
description: The Police Department said yesterday that Commissioner Benjamin Ward was unreachable for about three days in the spring during the initial investigation into the largest mass murder in New York City's history.

title: LEGISLATOR, GOVERNOR, JUSTICE
description: Millard Fillmore Caldwell, a former Governor of Florida, state legislator, United States Representative, chief justice of the Florida Supreme Court and the nation's first Federal Civil Defense Administrator, died Tuesday at his home in Tallahassee, Fla. He was 87 years old.

title: BRIEFS ;  Debt Issues
description: Coca-Cola Co. is issuing $100 million of 11 3/8 percent four-year Eurobonds priced at 103.60 with the price including four-year warrants to buy a similar amount of seven-year bonds with the same coupon through Morgan Guaranty Ltd.

title: Nearly $6 Million Found In Auto at Coast Airport
description: Nearly $6 million in cash, gold and platinum has been found in the trunk of a rented Ford seemingly abandoned in the long-term parking lot of San Francisco International Airport, Federal agents reported today.

title: PHIBRO NET UP BY 1.7% IN QUARTER
description: Phibro-Salomon Inc., the big commodities and securities trading firm, yesterday reported earnings of $119 million for the third quarter, up 1.7 percent from $117 million in the comparable period last year. On a per-share basis, earnings were flat at 83 cents because of additional shares outstanding.

title: U.S. INTELLIGENCE CHIEF SAYS HE WASN'T ASKED TO FALSIFY REPORTS IN VIETNAM
description: The head of military intelligence in South Vietnam in 1967 testified yesterday that Gen. William C. Westmoreland never asked him to falsify intelligence reports and, if the general had, he would have disobeyed him.

title: DOW UP 3.42 ON MODERATE VOLUME
description: Stock prices edged up slightly yesterday in moderate trading, led by some energy and technology issues. The Dow Jones industrial average climbed 3.42 points, to close at 1,216.43, after dipping a bit on Monday and Tuesday,

title: SOUTHWEST WATER COMPANY reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
College Mark in Sight
description: Jim Jianette, a senior at the Wisconsin-Platteville, could set a collegiate soccer career scoring record tomorrow when his team faces Notre Dame. Jianette of Hicksville, L.I., tied the record Tuesday when he had two goals in a 6-1 victory over Cornell College of Iowa and brought his career total of 106, matching the mark set in 1970 by Charles McGinty of Erskine College, S.C. . . . Sean Shapert, a 17-year-old senior from Moon Area High School in western Pennsylvania, broke the national high school career scoring record with four goals in a 6-2 victory over Baldwin in a district playoff game Tuesday.

title: ARKLA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,481,424 for the quarter and $71,074 for the 9 months. c-Net income after a loss of $2,043,193 from discontinued operations. d-Including a gain of $489,226 from discontinued operations.

description: b-Including extraordinary gains of $3,794,000 for the quarter and $25,478,000 for the 9 months.

title: CONSUMER ADVICE ON ROOM HEATERS
description: IN 1982, the most recent year for

title: MUSIC: WORK BY ZWILICH
description: THE New York premiere of Ellen Taaffe Zwilich's ''Chamber Symphony'' provided the principal interest at the St. Luke's Chamber Ensemble's Tuesday evening concert at the Abraham Goodman House. This 18-minute composition is built on two contrasting musical ideas - a patina of stark, parallel octaves, and more lyrical contrapuntal passages.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''After five years of euphoric illusions, revolutionary myths and painful deviations, Nicaragua is now a living lesson for the entire continent.

title: Bridge:Game at the Lenox School Moving to the Beverly Club
description: Finding a location for a recreational activity in New York City is often a problem, as Nathan Detroit found out when organizing his ''oldest established permanent floating crap game.'' He was happy to settle for the Biltmore Garage, but bridge organizers do much better.

title: A BIG TEXTRON BID BY CHICAGO PACIFIC
description: Flush with cash only four months after emerging from the reorganization of the bankrupt Rock Island Railroad, the little- known Chicago Pacific Corporation offered yesterday to pay $43 a share in cash, or about $1.6 billion, for Textron Inc., the Rhode Island-based industrial giant known for such products as Bell helicopters, Homelite chain saws, Bostitch staplers and Jacobsen lawn mowers.

Union Proposal Rejected at Yale
description: The union representing striking whitecollar workers at Yale proposed today that a panel of professors settle the monthlong contract dispute, but the university rejected the plan.

title: PITNEY BOWES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $25,022,000 for the quarter and $30,725,000 for the 9 months.

title: P.&G. Profits Decline 18.3%
description: The Procter & Gamble Company reported yesterday that net income in the first fiscal quarter of 1984 dropped 18.3 percent despite record sales.

title: STANDARD-PACIFIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
NABISCO BRANDS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said results for the latest quarter and 9 months reflect a pre-tax gain of $15,000,000 on the sale to the public of 20 percent of the Canadian operations and benefits of $15,000,000, after taxes, to realign facilities and consolidate U.S. administrative operations. Nabisco said these nonrecurring transactions did not affect net income share earnings.

title: KNICKS ACQUIRE BAILEY
description: Several hours after placing Bill Cartwright on the injured-reserve list, the Knicks bolstered their frontline yesterday by obtaining James Bailey from the San Antonio Spurs for a third-round choice in the 1986 draft and an undisclosed amount of cash.

title: Auto Sales Fall 6.5%; G.M. Strikes Blamed
description: Sales of new American-made automobiles, held down by strikes at the nation's largest car maker, fell 6.5 percent in the Oct. 11-20 period, according to figures released today by the nation's six major automobile manufacturers.

title: IN IOWA, A NEGATIVE SENATE CAMPAIGN
description: Like many Iowans, Wendell Watson, who raises cattle, deplores the quality of the campaign for the United States Senate in this state.

description: To the Editor:

CONRAC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

Swiss Plan Insider Curb
description: The Swiss Government announced today that it would submit to Parliament by next spring a bill to make insider trading a crime.

title: RUMORS OF MURDER HAUNT TOWN SINCE DROPPING OF SEX CHARGES
description: Over the course of eight months, 25 of this town's 2,700 residents were charged with sexually molesting dozens of local children, including their own. Others had been implicated and were expected to be indicted.

title: Allis-Chalmers Credit Unit Talks
description: The Allis-Chalmers Corporation of Milwaukee, which makes agricultural equipment, said it had agreed with the Security Pacific Corporation to end the negotiations for Security Pacific to buy the Allis-Chalmers Credit Corporation.

title: JURY TO BEGIN DELIBERATINGTODAY IN JERSEY SLAYING
description: The jury in the trial of a Morristown man charged with the stabbing murder of 18-year-old Amie Hoffman is scheduled to begin deliberating Thursday, after hearing both prosecution and defense lawyers characterize the evidence in the capital case as circumstantial.

title: Strawbridge
description: The directors of Strawbridge & Clothier Inc., the Philadelphia retail chain, held their regular board meeting, but no new developments were reported regarding the Tuesday disclosure by one director that he and several investors may sell their 13.9 percent interest. Robert Strawbridge 3d, the company director who heads the investors group, attended the meeting. The company's board recently rejected his proposal that it go private and the founding Strawbridge and Clothier families have indicated that they do not plan to sell their 54 percent interest.

title: LEGISLATIVE COMMITTEE CITES DEFECTS IN CHILD-ABUSE LAWS
description: Day-care centers and public schools cannot adequately investigate the backgrounds of many employees because of loopholes in New York State's child abuse laws, a State Senate committee report said yesterday.

title: States Say White House Tried to Cut Vote Drives
description: Democratic officials from New York, Texas and Ohio said today that a White House official tried to curtail voter registration drives by raising allegations of impropriety.

title: OF PAPER TIGERS WHOSE JOY IN LIFE IS RED STRIPES
description: They are called ''action officers'' or ''worker bees'' or, sometimes, ''the iron majors,'' a term of obscure Army origin.

title: SALVADORAN CRASH REMIANS UNSOLVED
description: Salvadoran Government officials said today that they still did not know the cause of the helicopter crash that killed the Salvadoran Army's top combat commander on Tuesday.

title: HELPFUL HARDWARE ; EASING THE JOLTS OF RIDING A BIKE
description: -Soft Polymer, is now being used for bicycle seats, gloves, grips and other items to make cycling more comfortable.

FLIGHTSAFETY INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ASTERIX: ALL GAUL AND 25
description: It all started with the idea of creating a story and some characters that were uniquely French, that could compete in the American-dominated world of comic strips.

title: JUSTICE O'CONNER ADVOCATES CHANGES IN TRAINING LAWYERS
description: Associate Justice Sandra Day O'Connor yesterday called on the country's law schools to teach ''the consciousness of moral and social responsibilities'' in addition to technical legal skills.

title: Canandaigua Wine Buyout
description: Marvin Sands, president of Canandaigua Wine Company Inc., said that directors had given preliminary approval for sale of the company to members of management and some shareholders in a leveraged buyout. Mr. Sands and other members of the Sands family own about 61 percent of the 1.9 million shares.

title: HARRY J. McNALLY
description: Harry J. McNally, president of the Harry J. McNally Mason Corporation, which did masonry work at Lincoln Center and other prominent New York buildings, died of cancer last Sunday at White Plains Hospital. He was 70 years old and lived in Purchase, N.Y.

title: PUBLIC SERVICE CO OF NORTH CAROINA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
A FREEZE IS VERIFIABLE
description: Polls show that more than two-thirds of the American people support the idea of a nuclear freeze, a key issue in the Presidential campaign. Others, including the President, oppose it, calling its supporters naive, on the grounds that it couldn't be verified. The truth is that we could indeed verify the important provisions of a freeze and could certainly detect any violation that would significantly threaten our security.

title: SOME VINTNERS STRUGGLE, SOME SMILE, IN FACE OF A SALES SLUMP
description: The leaves in the vineyards are turning gold now. Their vines, heavy with grapes a few weeks ago, are stripped again after one of the earliest harvests ever in the Napa Valley.

title: Rafshoon-Ogilvy Tie
description: Rafshoon Communications and Ogilvy & Mather Public Relations in Washington, have entered into a agreement whereby Rafshoon will assist in providing advertising strategy an planning for O.&M's Washington clients on issues of public policy, advocacy and institutional advertising. Gerald Rafshoon, president of his own firm, was the architect behind the 1976 Carter Presidential campaign.

title: IN FOUR YEARS, REAGAN CHANGED BASIS OF THE DEBATE ON DOMESTIC PROGRAMS
description: More than any other President in nearly 50 years, Ronald Reagan has changed the terms of the national debate over domestic policy.

title: JONES TO PLAY AGAINST PATRIOTS
description: Johnny (Lam) Jones, the swift wide receiver, will rejoin the Jets this week and play against the New England Patriots on Sunday in Foxboro, Mass.

title: Trammell's Car
description: When Bill Duncan, the director of communications for the magazine Sport, handed the keys of a 1985 Pontiac Trans Am to Alan Trammell of the Detroit Tigers yesterday, it was the eighth time that Duncan has been the magazine's presenter of a new automobile to the most valuable player of a World Series, Super Bowl or National Basketball Association championship round.

title: SPAIN'S HATED GYPSIES STAY TRUE TO THEMSELVES
description: When city authorities here came up with a plan to build houses for Manuel Gabarre and his relatives, the people who would be his neighbors rioted.

title: COLECO CUTS PRICE FOR ADAM SYSTEM
description: Coleco Industries, the maker of the troubled Adam home computer system, said yesterday that it had, in effect, reduced the wholesale price of the machine to $475, from $650.

title: A FILIPINO ON THE SPOT
description: For Gen. Fabian C. Ver, who has been at the side of Ferdinand E. Marcos since the two were toddlers, the position of Chief of Staff of the armed forces was earned as a result of unquestioned loyalty to the President. The personal bond between the two men, who are cousins, became a nettlesome political issue for President Marcos today. General Ver was accused in the majority report by the panel investigating the assassination of the opposition leader Benigno S. Aquino Jr. last year as being part of a military plot to kill Mr. Aquino.

title: Fuji-Polaroid Talks
description: The Fuji Photo Film Company said today that it was negotiating to supply 8-millimeter videotape for the Polaroid Corporation to sell in the United States.

title: MIDEAST VIOLENCE WILL END WHEN JUSTICE PREVAILS
description: To the Editor:

title: ALZA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results for the latest periods include tax credits of $834,000 for the quarter and $1,891,000 for the 9 months. Results for the year-ago periods include tax credits of $256,000 for the quarter and $1,312,000 for the 9 months.

title: Salomon Brothers Wins GTE Bonds
description: Salomon Brothers won the competitive bidding for a $150 million issue of GTE Corporation sinking fund debentures due Nov. 1, 2014. The issue was reoffered as 12 1/4 percent debentures at a price of 99.60 to yield 12.3 percent.

title: ATLANTA PRISON LOCKUP OF CUBANS CONTINUE
description: Most of the 1,500 Cuban inmates imprisoned at the Federal Penitentiary here remained locked in their cells and under close surveillance today as a result of a series of noisy demonstrations that broke out Oct. 13.

title: FILIPINO GENERAL NAMED IN PLOT TAKES A LEAVE
description: The Chief of Staff of the Philippines armed forces relinquished his command today after the majority report of the panel investigating the assassination of Benigno S. Aquino Jr. named him as being involved in a conspiracy to kill the opposition leader last year.

title: 'THE GUARDIAN' ON HBO
description: ''THE GUARDIAN,'' a cable- TV movie starring Martin Sheen and Louis Gossett Jr., is a walloping puzzle. Made as a Home Box Office ''Premiere Film''-it can be seen at 9 tonight on the pay-TV channel-the project was assembled by Richard Levinson and William Link, the veteran producing/writing team whose distinguished credits include ''That Certain Summer'' and ''The Execution of Private Slovik,'' both of which also starred Mr. Sheen. The Levinson-Link imprimatur has come to indicate, at the very least, solid and intelligent film fare. ''The Guardian'' doesn't satisfy either of those criteria.

title: Carter Says Reagan Lacks Interest in Foreign Issues
description: Former President Jimmy Carter said today that President Reagan lacked the interest needed to negotiate on the world's problems.

title: Yugoslav Tribunal Sentences Nine Convicted of Espionage
description: Nine people, including Yugoslavs and foreigners, have been sentenced to jail terms ranging from 3 1/2 to 11 years for espionage, the Yugoslav news agency, Tanyug, reported today.

title: Riley Signed
description: Pat Riley , the first coach in National Basketball Association history to take his team into the league final in each of his first three years, has signed a longterm contract to continue as coach of the Los Angeles Lakers.

title: PAPERCRAFT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
