description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $17,000,000 for the quarter and $16,000,000 for the 9 months, and a reduction of approximately $20,000,000 for the quarter in income tax expense resulting from tax law changes relating to domestic international sales corporations. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $9,000,000 for the quarter and $11,000,000 for the 9 months. Results for the year-ago quarter reflect a pre-tax gain of $111,000,000 on the exchange of the company's investment in Natomas common stock. Year-ago results have been restated to reflect the discontinuance of the company's industrial heating and refrigeration equipment business. Results include the operations of Wheelabrator-Frye Inc. from the date of merger on Feb. 1, 1983.

title: MIXING TEXTURE AND SURFACE: A NEW APPROACH TO ROOMS
description: THERE was a time when the materials used in various decorating schemes functioned as an easy-to-read design shorthand. Wallpaper blooming with flowers implied a traditional approach, bare windows and gray-industrial- carpeted floors were synonymous with minimalism, and the all- white walls of many contemporary rooms forfeited surprise but spoke clearly of tastefulness and understatement.

description: Federal officials announced the indictment yesterday of ''the entire leadership of the Colombo family'' of organized crime on charges of widespread racketeering in New York City.

title: 9 FROM U.S. AMONG 17 DEAD IN PHILIPPINE FIRE
description: The authorities today retrieved the bodies of more victims of a blaze that swept through a luxury hotel and killed 17 people, nine of them Americans visiting for the 40th anniversary of Gen. Douglas MacArthur's return to the Philippines.

title: SHONEY'S SOUTH reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 5-for-4 stock split paid Oct. 1, 1984.

title: Dam's Operation Set
description: The world's biggest hydroelectric project, the Itaipu dam on the Parana River dividing Brazil and Paraguay, begins operating Thursday. So far, two 700-megawatt turbines have been installed but when work is finished in 1990 the dam will generate 12,600 megawatts, about a third of Brazil's present electricity consumption. The $15 billion project is a joint venture between Brazil and Paraguay.

title: LODGISTIX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a tax credit of $131,000 and net income reflects a pretax gain of $244,000 on the sale of 67 percent of Lodgistix's Singapore PTE. The 1983 figures were restated to reflect acquisition of Nevada Computer Services Inc. and March & Associates Inc., which were accounted for as pooling of interests.

title: N.F.L. IS CONFRONTED WITH DECLINE IN POPULARITY
description: In January 1982, the National Football League's most successful season ended with the San Francisco 49ers defeating the Cincinnati Bengals in Super Bowl XVI. Attendance for that season reached a record. Television ratings were never better. And in a few months, the league signed new contracts with the three major television networks worth $2.1 billion over the next five years.

title: OPERA: 'CLEMENZA DI TITO'
description: THE second performance of the Metropolitan Opera's new production of Mozart's ''Clemenza di Tito'' Tuesday night presented the complete cast that had been scheduled for the premiere the previous Thursday. In other words, Tatiana Troyanos, recovered from her sinusitis, was the Sesto, which meant that Ann Murray, who had sung Sesto the first night, reverted to the part of Annio.

title: Nabisco, General Foods Off
description: Two of the nation's largest food companies reported lower results yesterday while a third reported a slight increase.

title: C.I.A. Is Said to Tell Family About Salvador Plane Crash
description: A woman confirmed today that the Central Intelligence Agency said her nephew was killed last week in a plane crash in El Salvador, not a traffic accident in Florida.

title: Polaroid Sues E.P.A. on Secrets
description: The Polaroid Corporation has filed suit against the Environmental Protection Agency, charging that the Federal agency disclosed trade secrets about Polaroid's new chemicals.

title: MUSIC: MA WITH BOSTON SYMPHONY
description: EVERY musical instrument has its touchstone pieces, virtuosic works by which audiences measure soloists and against which soloists test themselves. For the cello, one of the great measuring rods is ''Don Quixote.'' As broad-scaled and technically demanding as any concerto, Strauss's ''Fantastic Variations on a Theme of Knightly Character'' demand that the soloist go beyond the boundaries of pure technique into areas generally reserved for music drama. In fact, the cellist who does not approach this score as if it were a small opera without words stands little chance of bringing it off successfully.

title: SEALED AIR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results include the operations of Cellu Products Co. which was acquired in October 1983.

title: Article 034974 -- No Title
description: About $6 million is expected to be spent this year on races for the State Legislature, but there will probably be no significant change in the balance of power in either house, legislative leaders said yesterday.

title: NEW PROPOSAL FOR A TIMES SQ. SITE
description: Two developers, saying they were dissatisfied with the roles they were offered in the proposed $1.6 billion Times Square redevelopment project, announced yesterday that they had applied to build their own building on one of the project's key sites.

title: THURSDAY SPORTS Football
description: Brigham Young at New Mexico . The Cougars have extended the nation's longest winning streak to 18 games behind the passing of Robbie Bosco.

title: Disenchanted Texan

A good place to begin may well be the House Plant Societies Show Nov. 2 at the Horticultural Society of New York.

title: DANCE:'MANHATTAN,' BY RINKER
description: ADVANCE publicity described Kenneth Rinker's ''Manhattan'' as being ''about people, relationships, places and spaces.'' All dances are, whether they mean to be or not. But ''Manhattan,'' a new, eveninglong work at La Mama E.T.C. through Sunday, brilliantly evokes a time, a place, and the people who move through them.

description: Ron Meyer, whose unpopular demands alienated players but who helped turn them into winners, was dismissed yesterday as coach of the New England Patriots.

description: Money Supply Up 1.8 Billion

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: IN person and on screen, Alec Guinness opened the Museum of Modern Art's British film retrospective Wednesday night. Sir Alec attended a black-tie dinner in his honor, introduced a screening of his 1949 film, ''Kind Hearts and Coronets,'' and said he was usually happy to stay home.

title: Charge Dropped for Lawyers Who Refused Indigent Cases
description: A a Federal antitrust charge against local lawyers who refused to accept indigent clients last year because of low fees was dropped today by Administrative Law Judge Morton Needelman.

title: FILM: DEPALMA EVOKES 'VERTIGO' IN BODY DOUBLE
description: BRIAN DE PALMA goes too far, which may be not only the most consistent quality through all his films but also the most important and, possibly, the most endearing. Each of his films is guaranteed to offend some of the people all of the time, including his staunchest admirers. He never leaves well enough alone.

title: THE SCREEN:'TERMINATOR,' SUSPENSE TALE
description: ARNOLD SCHWARZENEGGER is about as well suited to movie acting as he would be to ballet, but his presence in ''The Terminator'' is not a deterrent. This is a monster movie, and the monster's role fits Mr. Schwarzenegger just fine. He plays the computerized automaton of the title, sent from the year 2029 back to 1984 to assassinate a young waitress named Sarah Connor. Even if the movie had nothing else to recommend it, the sheer unlikeliness of this mission, and the teasing gradualness with which its meaning is revealed, would be enough to hold an audience's attention.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Sports Pages yesterday about the National Football League's problems included a figure based on a miscalculation by league officials, which overstated the attendance increase this year. It is 0.9 percent.

description: UAL Inc., holding company for the nation's largest airline, reported yesterday that third-quarter earnings rose 5.7 percent on a 10.9 percent increase in revenues.

title: UNIONISTS AS SALVADORAN SYMBOLS
description: While the eyes of the world focused on the historic meeting between guerrillas and Government at La Palma, another step toward national reconciliation in El Salvador went unnoticed - the release of the country's longest held political prisoners, 10 leaders of the hydroelectrical workers union. Yet the Government's decision to free these 10 trade unionists - and the prisoners' decision to choose exile over remaining in their homeland - is a reflection of both the process set in motion at La Palma and the many obstacles that lie ahead on the road to real peace.

title: Rucker Under Scrutiny
description: Mike Weisman, the executive producer of NBC Sports, says that Reggie Rucker, the pro football player turned analyst who admits that he did not quite speak the truth on the air during the Cincinnati- Cleveland game last Sunday, will not be disciplined but will be ''watched a little more carefully.'' Rucker said in Sunday's broadcast that he had dinner with Coach Sam Wyche of the Bengals the night before.

title: GUIDE TO CELEBRATING HALLOWEEN EARLY
description: The season of pumpkins, ghosts and apple bobbing has swung into gear, and between tonight and Sunday night nearly every hour could be filled with the stuff of Halloween - a haunted house in the Bronx, nocturnal walks on Staten Island, retracing the hoof prints of the Headless Horseman in Tarrytown, N.Y., and a tour of Greenwood Cemetery in Brooklyn.

title: Redgrave Describes Plea To Orchestra Officials
description: The actress Vanessa Redgrave told jurors today that she had tried and failed to persuade officials of the Boston Symphony Orchestra not to cancel her appearances as a concert narrator because of her political views.

title: BOARD ACTION ON JOBS TO AID HOMOSEXUALS
description: The Board of Estimate yesterday approved an addition to city contracts that provides job protection for homosexuals - much the same protection that was found unconstitutional when it was in the form of a mayoral order. The measure, a two-paragraph amendment to city contracts, was approved unanimously at 9:30 P.M. The board's vote applied to 61 city contracts, but the administration of Mayor Koch intends to extend its applications to any company or agency that provides goods or services to New York City. Last month, a State Supreme Court justice declared unconstitutional a mayoral order extending to city contractors job protection for homosexuals. The judge, Alvin F. Klein, found that the Mayor ''had impermissibly invaded the legislative domain'' by issuing the order. John P. Hale, a lawyer for the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York, which was among the parties to the lawsuit that led to Judge Klein's ruling, had contended earlier in the day that the board did not have any more authority than the Mayor to implement such an anti-bias measure. He said that if the board were to approve the measure, the archdiocese would sue the city again and seek to recover its legal expenses. The proposed addition to city contracts states: ''In addition to and not in substitution for any other requirement of this agreement, the contractor agrees that it will not refuse to hire or employ, nor bar or discharge from employment, nor discriminate against any persons in compensation or in terms, conditions or privileges of employment, because of age, race, creed, color, national origin, sex, marital status, handicap, sexual orientation and affectional preference.

title: CASTLE, A.M. & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
MONTEFIORE, IN ITS 100TH YEAR, LOOKS BACK AND AT ITS FUTURE
description: It is the place where New York City's first open-heart surgery program began, where the first heart pacemaker was developed and where the use of organ transplants and microsurgery were pioneered. It was the first hospital in the country to test tuberculin, to use insulin therapy for diabetes and to use radioisotopes to combat cancer.

title: M.T.A. AND UNION HOLD TALKS ON SUPERVISORS
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority and its largest supervisor union are negotiating over how many supervisors should leave the union to join management ranks.

title: Chevron Unit's $1 Billion in Notes
description: Chevron Capital U.S.A. is offering $1 billion of notes, with proceeds aimed at retiring part of the debt associated with the Chevron Corporation's acquisition of the Gulf Corporation earlier this year.

title: KASPAROV REFUSES TO COLLAPSE, AND THE DRAWS GO ON AND ON
description: Anatoly Karpov would like to win two more games of the world championship chess match in Moscow and thus complete a successful defense of his title. Gary Kasparov, his 21-year- old challenger, would like to make up the 0-4 score by which he is losing the contest. But the two Soviet grandmasters have drawn every game from the 10th to the 17th, which was played on Wednesday.

title: 'SIMPLE MISTAKE' IN BEIRUT BOMBING
description: A Senate Foreign Relations Committee report places blame for the car bombing of the United States Embassy near East Beirut last month on the ''tragically simple mistake'' of not blocking access to the road leading to the building.

title: IN BUSTLING NYACK, NEW-FOUND PROSPERITY COLORS THE PRESIDENTAL POLITICS
description: When Joseph Sutera moved here in 1920 to peddle fish off the back of a truck, he was ''too busy to get involved in politics or vote,'' his son, Charles, recalled.

title: RAMS' DEFENSE PRIMED TO STOP MONTANA
description: The first hint that the Los Angeles Rams' defense might be something special came a month ago in their game against the Giants. The Rams won, 33-12, and the Giants rushed for the remarkable total of 8 yards on 13 carries. No team in the National Football League has been held to fewer rushing yards in one game all season.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Activated Pete Rostosky, offensive tackle. Waived Gregg Garrity, wide receiver, who was picked up by the Philadelphia Eagles. NEW ENGLAND (AFC) - Dismissed Ron Meyer, head coach. Replaced him with Raymond Berry. Rehired Rod Rust, defensive coordinator, whom Meyer had dismissed the day before. ATLANTA (NFC) - Placed John Rade, linebacker, and Rodney Tate, running back, on the injured reserve list. Recalled Dave Levenick, linebacker, and Steve Haworth, safety, from that list. ST. LOUIS (NFC) - Picked up Randy Holloway, defensive end, on waivers from the Minnesota Vikings. ARIZONA (USFL) - Signed James Keyton, former offensive tackle at Arizona State, and Jerry Scanlan, former Washington Redskins offensive lineman. DENVER (USFL) - Waived 12 players, including Craig Penrose, the veteran quarterback, Mike Hirn and Victor Hicks, tight ends, and James Stewart and Derrick Taylor, cornerbacks. COLLEGES TEXAS CHRISTIAN - Offered Coach Jim Wacker a seven-year contract. BASKETBALL KANSAS CITY (NBA) - Waived Eddie Nealy, forward. ATLANTA (NBA) - Waived Stewart Granger, Bobby Parks and Walker Russell, guards. Signed Mike Glenn, free agent. Placed Randy Wittman, guard, and Scott Hastings, forward, on the injured reserve list. CLEVELAND (NBA) - Placed Lonnie Shelton, forward, and Paul Thompson, guard, on the injured reserve list. WASHINGTON (NBA) - Agreed to a multiyear contract with Greg Ballard, forward. Ballard has not yet signed the contract. Released Joe Kopicki, forward. UTAH (NBA) - Suspended Adrian Dantley, who led the N.B.A. in scoring last season with 30.6 points per game, for failing to report to training camp and his boycott of all nine preseason games.

title: Party to Commemorate Newburgh Landscaper
description: A birthday party commemorating Andrew Jackson Downing, a landscape architect who designed the first urban park in the United States - the public gardens on the mall in Washington - will be held on Sunday at 2 P.M. in Newburgh, N.Y., where he was born in 1815. The celebration will focus on the impact on him and his work of the Catskill Mountains, just west of Newburgh, and their subsequent inspiration for the Hudson River School of painters.

title: IRAQIS SAY THEY DESTROYED 4 SHIPS IN IRAN CONVOY
description: Iraq said that its navy attacked an Iranian naval convoy in the Persian Gulf today, destroying four vessels.

title: WILLIAMS OF NETS TAKES LESSER ROLE
description: The gym is nearly empty, the lights dimmed, and all of the participants in the Nets' practice are gone. All except Buck Williams, who remains on the free-throw line, gazing at the rim. Grasping a basketball firmly, he bends his knees, lifts his arms and shoots. The net snaps as the ball falls cleanly through.

title: CURTICE-BURNS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Washington Gets Another Game
description: Robert Kaufmann said that when he read about the controversy surrounding the George Washington High School football team, he thought that the players were being punished too severely.

2D BONN AIDE, TIED TO PAYOFF, RESIGNS HIS JOB
description: The Speaker of the West German Parliament resigned today after being implicated in a political payoff scandal.

title: Celltech Venture
description: Celltech, a British genetic engineering company, and Air Products Ltd., part of an international chemicals group based in Allentown, Pa., said they were setting up a company called Apcel to harness advances in genetic manipulation for industry.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Jim Palmer, the former Baltimore Oriole pitching star, will be the host of ''The Sporting Life,'' public television's first long-term series devoted to athletes. It goes on the air next spring. . . . Randy Holloway, the defensive end waived by the Minnesota Vikings, has been picked up by the St. Louis Cardinals. . . . Oscar Robertson and Jerry West, who played together on the 1960 Olympic team and against each other in the National Basketball Association, have been named honorary captains for the N.B.A. All-Star Game in Indianapolis Feb. 10.

title: U.S. AND NICARAGUA TRADE ACCUSATIONS DURING U.N. DEBATE
description: The United States said today that the present Nicaraguan Government could suffer the same fate as the Government of Anastasio Somoza Debayle, which was overthrown by the Sandinistas in the 1979 revolution.

title: PUBLISHING:REVIEW STILL SAID TO BE FOR SALE
description: REPORTS continue to circulate that The New York Review of Books is for sale, even though Robert B. Silvers said yesterday that a deal was not likely to take place soon. Mr. Silvers, co-editor of the bimonthly publication, acknowleged having had discussions with Rea Hederman, a member of the family that once owned newspapers in Jackson, Miss., but, he said, ''We do not see a sale taking place.'' Mr. Silvers added that the negotiators agreed the discussions would be kept confidential. Mr. Hederman, who now lives in New York, reportedly offered more than $5 million for The Review, which started in February 1963 in the midst of a New York newspaper strike.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Metropolitan Report on Oct. 5 about Western square dancing incorrectly described its status in New York City. There are indeed clubs - nine of them - in the city, according to the National Square Dance Directory.

title: FRIDAY SPORTS Basketball

title: Man Who Shot Floyd Dies
description: Chester C. Smith, the last survivor of the four small-town police officers who shot and killed the gangster Charles A. (Pretty Boy) Floyd in 1934, died Tuesday. He was 89 years old. Mr. Smith's death at East Liverpool City Hospital came just one day after the 50th anniversary of the shooting, an event he always described as the biggest in his 35-year police career. Floyd, sought in the 1933 shooting of four law- enforcement officers, was was killed in a cornfield in northeastern Ohio while fleeing a posse.

title: HOLTZMAN SAYS CARS OF DRUNKEN DRIVERS MAY BE CONFISCATED
description: District Attorney Elizabeth Holtzman of Brooklyn said yesterday that she would act to seize cars driven by drunken drivers in cases involving repeat offenses or serious injuries to others.

title: Ibrahim Performance
description: The pianist Abdullah Ibrahim, also known as Dollar Brand, and his septet, Ekaya, plus the guest singers Sathima Bea Benjamin and Johny Khumalo, will perform tonight at 8 at the Great Hall of Cooper Union, 41 Cooper Square at East 8th Street. Tickets are $10; information, 242- 1785.

title: EMPIRE DISTRICT ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BOB TELSON AND 'GOSPEL SYNTHESIZERS' AT THE JOYCE
description: ''GOSPEL SYNTHESIZERS'' is the intriguing title for the program Bob Telson is presenting tonight as part of the weeklong Sounds American series at the Joyce Theater. The 35- year-old composer, keyboardist and performance artist has won critical acclaim for his score for ''The Gospel at Colonus,'' the marriage of American gospel and Greek tragedy that became the hit of the Brooklyn Academy of Music's Next Wave Festival a year ago. But the audience tonight will discover that there's more to Mr. Telson than an accomplished blue- eyed soul composer. Musically he is a true man of the world who is on intimate terms with salsa, Afro-Cuban, European classical and gospel.

title: STUDY POINTS TO WEAK RACES AGAINST DEMOCRATS IN THE CITY
description: Republican, Conservative and Liberal leaders are often so hard pressed to field candidates in predominantly Democratic New York City that they sometimes nominate people who do not want to run and in some cases do not even know they are running, according to a new study.

West German Trade
description: West Germany's current account was balanced in September, in contrast to a revised deficit of 1.5 billion marks in August, the Government said today. Germany's current account - a measure of all international transactions in goods and services - posted a 700-million-mark deficit in September 1983. The mark is equal to 33 cents in United States currency.

description: When William F. Winter announced in February that he would run against Senator Thad Cochran, a first-term Republican, Democrats saw the race as one of their best opportunities to pick up a seat in the United States Senate.

description: THE director Michael Apted, who brought so much rural verisimilitude to ''Coal Miner's Daughter,'' creates an equally convincing suburban New York backdrop for ''Firstborn.'' That Mr. Apted was born and raised in England only makes his versatility more impressive.

description: The West German Government is in trouble. One respected commentator warns of another Weimar Republic, the ineffective democratic regime established after World War I that slid into chaos, making way for Hitler. A second writes of banana republics. A conservative politician says his constituents' mood is a Wagnerian Gotterdammerung.

title: STEINBRENNER SAYS BERRA WILL RETURN IN '85
description: Yogi Berra, the Yankees' manager during the 1984 season, no longer is the Yankees' manager-in-waiting during the 1984-85 off-season. The wait, which automatically goes with the job, ended yesterday when George Steinbrenner, the team's principal owner, announced that Berra, whose contract runs through the 1985 season, would be the team's manager in 1985.

title: Body Discovered in California Is Believed to be Brautigan's
description: A body discovered yesterday by the police in a house in Bolinas, Calif., was believed to be the remains of Richard Brautigan, a quixotic counterculture poet and writer, his publisher said.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ; 2 More Thrift Units Offer Commercial Paper
description: Savings and loan associations, looking for low-cost borrowings, are turning to the commercial paper market, which has long been a major source of money for major financial and industrial companies.

description: Tickets for the Metropolitan Museum of Art exhibition of paintings and drawings by Vincent van Gogh, ''Van Gogh at Arles,'' will be sold out within two weeks if they continue selling at the present rate of 14,000 a day, according to museum officials.

title: THE DEAD OF EL ALAMEIN TURN FOES INTO FRIENDS
description: Forty-two years ago today, as a full moon illuminated this vast expanse of relentlessly flat desert by the sea, the battle of El Alamein began.

title: U.S. Widens Payments To Citrus Producers

Ferraro, traveling to the heart of California's computer industry on her third straight day of campaigning in the state, declared today that ''high-tech industries face the same competitive challenge as our smokestack industries'' and would suffer under a second Reagan Administration.

title: ATLANTIC AMERICAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Home for the Holidays
description: John McEnroe and Jimmy Connors are apparently going to be able to face Sweden in the Davis Cup final next month and still put in a full holiday season with their families. The International Tennis Federation announced yesterday that the final will be held Dec. 16-18, the compromise dates that the Swedes had tried to extend to a ''flexible'' seven-day schedule ending Dec. 22. The Swedes, the hosts of this year's final, had originally wanted to play between Christmas and New Year's Day, but the Americans protested that the schedule would keep the players away from their families over the holidays. . . . Alycia Moulton, a 23-year-old player from Sacramento, Calif., has been named to replace the injured Kathy Jordan in the Wightman Cup tennis match against Britain next month.

title: Key Banks, Alaska Pacific
description: Key Banks Inc. has agreed in principle to acquire the Alaska Pacific Bancorporation, the fourth-largest banking company in Alaska, for $58 million, the two companies announced today.

But midway through the 1984 season, the Horned Frogs have a 5-1 record and have now won more games in two seasons under Wacker than they had in the previous six.

title: Sittler Has Surgery
description: Darryl Sittler, the high-scoring center whom the Detroit Red Wings recently acquired from Philadelphia, underwent surgery in Toronto yesterday for a fractured right cheekbone, an injury he suffered Wednesday night when he was checked by Jim Korn of the Maple Leafs. A spokesman at Wellesley Hospital said Sittler was expected to remain there a few days, but it was not known how long he would be away from his team. His father, Ken Sittler , was in fair condition at the same hospital after suffering a heart attack while watching the Detroit-Toronto game.

There were parents with small children, young people with backpacks, students with books and shoppers with bags in their arms, all coming together to form one of the largest collections of depressingly fit specimens in the world.

As a storyteller, he is a master, a joy to read, but, in this case, he carries the joke too far, to another medium where the punch line misses the wallop it should deliver.

title: RESTAURANTS
description: ONE of the most delightful traditions of Spanish cuisine, which for some reason has never taken root in this country, is the tapas bar. Food dictionaries usually describe tapas as ''an assortment of Spanish hors d'oeuvres,'' which is like describing the Prado as ''one of the many art museums in Madrid.'' Tapas embody an entire life style in the perpetually nibbling nation of Spain, and fortunately for New Yorkers an authentic Spanish restaurant with such a bar has opened in TriBeCa, called El Internacional.

title: Coleco Profit Jumps 65.2% WEST HARTFORD, Conn.,

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: FRIDAY, OCTOBER 26, 1984 International A Salvadoran union official lied last week when he asserted his son had been killed by a rightist death squad, he admitted in a meeting with journalists. The false account from the official, Alirio Montes, had led the United States embassy to denounce death squad violence last Saturday and demand an immediate Government investigation. (A9:1-2.) Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher denounced one of President Francois Mitterrand's bodyguards for planting explosives at the French Ambassador's home to test Scotland Yard's detection skills. While Mr. Mitterrand was in southwest England as part of his state visit to celebrate 80 years of Anglo-French solidarity, the French Embassy responded that the whole thing had been a ''regrettable misunderstanding.'' (A1:3-5.)

title: ART:2 SHOWS FEATURE LE CORBUSIER PAINTINGS
description: WHAT to think of the paintings of Le Corbusier is a problem that has taken many years to resolve. It was clear to anyone who called on the great man that although he did not begin to paint until he was 31 years old, he was as committed to painting as he was to architecture. Form was form, as he saw it, no matter whether it turned up in painting, in sculpture or in building.

title: Italian Folk Concerts
description: Two performances of Italian folk music - one of them free - will be presented this weekend by Musica Popolare, a group of Italian and Italian-American musicians.

title: MOLLIE PARNIS:A LIFE IN FASHION
description: Mollie Parnis opened her dress business in 1933. She's closing it at the end of this month. But that doesn't mean she's retiring.

title: SOUTHDOWN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
MONTANA-DAKOTA UTILITIES CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
GRENADA INVASION:ROOTS OF PURPORTED AMERICAN SHORTCOMINGS ARE TRACED
description: A strong desire to avoid a hostage crisis like the one in Teheran affected planning and operations in the invasion of Grenada last year, according to an Army military analyst. It also contributed to what some critics believe were military shortcomings. Some military analysts said a somewhat related desire to permit elements of a highly secret special operations group to show what it could do also left several major objectives of the Grenada operation unsecured for many hours.

title: TRIBUNE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 23
description: b-Includes a one-time gain of $8,000,000, or 20 cents a share, on the real estate sales.

EXPLOSIVE CAPER EMBROILS LONDON AND PARIS
description: British and French officials blamed each other today for an incident that has marred a state visit by President Francois Mitterrand.

title: Condemned Killer Opts For Death by Injection
description: Velma Barfield, condemned to death for murder, has chosen to die by lethal injection.

title: REAGAN FOREIGN POLICY: SHIFTING AIM
description: From the beginning, President Reagan's national security policy has been to talk loudly, act cautiously and construct a big economic and military stick.

title: HELMS IS ENDORSED BY 22 AMBASSADORS
description: Twenty-two United States ambassadors, all appointed by President Reagan, today endorsed Senator Jesse Helms in his campaign for re-election against North Carolina's Democratic Governor.

title: Afghan Diplomat Says French Reporter Is Free
description: The Afghan charge d'affaires, Abdullah Keshmand, said here today that Jacques Abouchar, a French television reporter, was released from prison today and was free to return home.

title: Four Jersey Men Die In Small-Plane Crash
description: Four New Jersey men were killed Wednesday night when their singleengine plane crashed in flames near a remote airport on Maryland's Eastern Shore.

description: To the Editor:

title: AVNET INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 28
WHAT IS THE AUDITED VALUE OF LIFE?
description: The value of human life has eluded poets, theologians and philosophers for centuries, but the Government has an answer. Rather, several answers.

title: PAPANDREOU CALLS JARUZELSKI A PATRIOT
description: Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou described the Polish leader, Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, as a ''patriot'' and criticized the Solidarity trade union movement as ''negative and dangerous''in remarks to reporters Wednesday night.

description: b-Including gains of $5,928,000, or 40 cents a share, for the quarter and $2,702,000, or 18 cents a share, for the 9 months from changes in the tax law.

MONDALE TACTICS ADOPTS SOME TACTICS FROM REAGAN
description: With 12 days to go before the election, Walter F. Mondale has dramatically shifted his campaign tactics, invoking broad idealistic themes and appearing in visually pleasing settings calculated to look good on television.

description: b-Net income.

title: GREAT RACE FOR RUNNERS AND SPECTATORS
description: -class runners will complete the New York City Marathon on Sunday in time for a late lunch, having earned thousands of dollars. The brave stragglers on the 26.2-mile course will reach the finish line at Tavern on the Green in Central Park after dark, rewarded with a medal, a long-stemmed rose and a high-carbohydrate snack.

title: MOBIL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes gains in LIFO inventory drawdowns of $19,000,000 for the quarter and 9 months, charges related to the acquisition of Superior Oil Co. of $40,000,000 for the quarter and $52,000,000 for the 9 months, and Mobil's net interest expense associated with the acquisition of $60,000,000 for the quarter and $72,000,000 for the 9 months. c-Includes gains in LIFO inventory drawdowns of $40,000,000 for the quarter and $95,000,000 for the 9 months. Net income for the latest quarter reflects Mobil's share of the $20,000,000 earnings of Superior Oil after estimated purchase accounting adjustments.

title: Berrigan Held in Protest
description: Twenty-one people, including the Rev. Daniel Berrigan, were arrested today when they blocked the northwest gate of the White House by kneeling and praying and denouncing President Reagan's policies. The organizers for the Community for Creative Nonviolence said the arrests brought to 101 the number of demonstrators taken into custody outside the White House this month.

title: COLGATE-PALMOLIVE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $11,095,000 for the quarter and $17,962,000 for 9 months.

description: b-There are no comparable year- ago 9 months figures because the partnership began operation in July 1983. Results for the year-ago quarter are for July 20 through Sept. 30, 1983.

title: SENATE CAMAPIGN COSTS FOR 1984 LIKELY TO DOUBLE THE 1978 TOTAL
description: Senate candidates appear to be raising and spending money about twice as fast as they did when this year's seats were last contested six years ago, Federal Election Commission records show.

title: Mechanical Failure Blamed In Salvadoran Copter Crash
description: A official investigation has found that mechanical failure caused the helicopter crash that killed four army commanders, official sources said today.

title: ADVEST GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income.

title: MOCHARY EXTENDS HER LEAVE
description: Mary V. Mochary, the Republican candidate for United States Senator from New Jersey, has extended her leave from campaigning to be with her husband while he awaits a heart transplant operation in California.

title: A Start for Young Workers President Reagan can do for the nation's youth what as Governor he once did for the youth of California - by signing the bill to create the American Conservation Corps.
description: The corps is patterned on the New Deal's Civilian Conservation Corps and later versions in California and other states. It promises productive jobs and invaluable training for thousands of young people not reached by other social programs.

title: ART:ANTES 'VOTIVES' AT GUGGENHEIM
description: -Expressionism rolled in several years ago, there was the German painter Horst Antes who had been exhibiting work of highly Expressionist persuasion in this country since 1967. His obsessive motif is a gnomish little figure - derived from Picasso out of Etruscan and more archaic art - of a man whose big-eyed, helmet-shaped head rides his legs without benefit of torso. This hieratic homunculus (sometimes it's a woman, a couple, several figures; sometimes it's normally shaped) gropes and gesticulates in a tight, claustrophobic cosmos where homey symbols commingle topsy-turvily with those of more poetic and spiritual allusion.

title: 3 Agencies Big Winners Of Ceba Awards
description: Burrell Advertising, Young & Rubicam and Chiat/Day were the big agency winners last night at the seventh annual Ceba Awards, given for excellence in communications to black audiences. Each agency got three awards, but only Chicago-based Burrell specializes in ethnic advertising.

title: Commissioner Ward, Out of Touch Most small-business owners stay in touch with the store when they go off on vacation. Why would New York City's Police Commissioner, Benjamin Ward, remain out of reach during three vacation days last April? What other patterns of behavior cast doubt on his approach to his job? That's the concern he needs to address, clearly and fully.
description: Mr. Ward left town last April, leaving no itinerary and never bothering to call. His aides could not find him to report about a mass murder in Brooklyn.

title: Lewis of Packers Ailing
description: Gary Lewis of the Green Bay Packers has been knocked out of action by a rare blood disorder that threatens his football career. The Packers said the ailment was not related to Lewis's work as a tight end and that they were therefore not required to pay him the remainder of his $190,000 annual salary.

title: ITALY SAYS 7 BULGARIANS AND TURKS WILL BE TRIED FOR PLOT ON THE POPE
description: An Italian judge has decided to order three Bulgarians and four Turks to stand trial on charges of taking part in a conspiracy to assassinate Pope John Paul II, Italian officials said today.

title: Crime Unit Backs Law On Money Laundering
description: A Presidential commission on organized crime, in a preliminary report, recommended new laws and administrative measures today to counter moves by criminals to conceal their sources of money.

title: By John Gross;
description: THE INTELLECTUAL FOLLIES: A

title: WARD TO INSTALL RADIO LINK IN CAR
description: Mayor Koch said yesterday that Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward had agreed to install a two-way police-band radio in his private automobile ''so that he can be reached when he is in transit.''

title: President Signs Bill to Help Some Exposed to Herbicide
description: President Reagan signed a bill Wednesday that would compensate certain Vietnam veterans exposed to the herbicide Agent Orange and create a commission to review the basis of claims of other Vietnam veterans.

title: NO 'CEILING' ON FIGURES, CBS CASE WITNESS SAYS
description: The military's chief negotiator at a high-level 1967 conference on the size of the enemy in South Vietnam testified yesterday that, with the ''blessing'' of Gen. William C. Westmoreland, he presented estimates based on the ''best'' intelligence available to him.

title: CONCERT:THE KRONOS STRING QUARTET
description: THE Kronos string quartet conducted its concert at Carnegie Recital Hall Wednesday evening like a survey course in modern languages. Each of the four pieces spoke in separate ways - using different vocabularies for different purposes, and one could only admire the fluency with which these young players moved from one to the other.

title: ART:12 ARTISTS SHOWN IN 'UNDERKNOWN,' AT P.S.1
description: ''UNDERKNOWN: Twelve Artists Re-Seen in 1984'' is a surprising show - surprising in that an institution is finally paying attention to artists who have worked lifetimes with little or no place in the sun; surprising in that the institution involved is P.S. 1 in Long Island City, whose definition of alternative art, to which it is committed, had previously been confined to experimental modes of expression; surprising because the curator of the exhibition is Henry Geldzahler, who remains far more identified with bright lights than with the patience and sweat of the long distance run.

title: CANADA ANNOUNCES CUT IN OIL PRICE FOR NOV. 1
description: The National Energy Board of Canada plans to cut the official price of the light crude oil it exports to the United States by about $1.35 a barrel, to about $27.50, senior Canadian officials said yesterday.

title: FUTURES/OPTIONS ; Soybean Prices Gain; Wheat Shows Decline
description: Soybean futures prices rebounded today on the Chicago Board of Trade as persistent rain continued to raise concern about damage to crops, particularly in the south central states.

title: Jurors Adjourn In Jersey Slaying
description: A Superior Court jury deliberated for nearly six hours today without reaching a verdict in the trial of an ex-convict charged with the stabbing murder of 18-year-old Amie Hoffman in 1982.

title: WESTCOAST TRANSMISSION CO LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Revenue figures for the latest and year-ago quarters were not disclosed.

title: Service for Orrin Reiley
description: A memorial service for the actor Orrin Reiley will be held at 3 P.M. next Monday at the Plymouth Theater, 236 West 45th Street. Mr. Reiley, whose stage appearances included ''Applause'' and ''Dear World,'' was seen most recently in the revival last year of ''You Can't Take It With You.'' He died Sept. 24. The service will include recollections by his friends and colleagues.

title: MEETING IN WESTCHESTER LOOKS AT YOUTH SUICIDES
description: More than a year ago, informal discussions were begun between educators and mental health workers on how to deal with a community's grief over the suicides of two teen-agers.

title: USLICO, RESTRUCTURED, CHOOSES A CHAIRMAN

title: NAVY DENIES REPORT ON SHIP MISSING TARGETS IN LEBANON
description: The Navy denies an officer's published comment that the battleship New Jersey's 16-inch guns fired inaccurately at targets in Lebanon last winter because of ammunition made in the Korean War.

title: Boston Globe Editor Retiring To Become Columbia Fellow
description: Thomas Winship, editor of the Boston Globe, will retire in January, the newspaper announced today.

title: U.S. Veterans Heading Home After Philippine Hotel Blaze
description: A group of American veterans of World War II were leaving for home today after a visit to the Philippines ended in a hotel fire that killed 25 people and injured 67.

title: McDonnell's Net Up 24.7%
description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation said today that third-quarter profit rose 24.7 percent on the strong performance of recently acquired units.

title: KEY BUILDER IN TIMES SQ. PLAN TELLS HEARING OF $1.1 BILLION LOAN BACKING
description: The developer selected to build the largest portion of the Times Square redevelopment project announced yesterday that he had obtained a commitment for $1.1 billion in financing from Manufacturers Hanover Trust.

title: BROADWAY
description: BACK in 1981, the London production of ''Total Eclipse'' was a critical success and, according to Charles P. Kopelman, a good many producers wanted to bring it to New York. Mr. Kopelman may be slightly subjective. He is one of the three producers who are indeed bringing the Christopher Hampton play to New York, and who plan previews in November and an opening Dec. 13. As to why he and his associates, Mark B. Simon and Gary P. Steuer of The Producers Collaborative, won out, Mr. Kopelman said without hesitation that their having the director John Tillinger in their package gave them the needed edge.

I.B.M. DEAL ON MEXICO PLANT SEEN
description: The International Business Machines Corporation has reached tentative agreement with Mexican officials on a plan to open a major manufacturing facility for personal computers here, according to sources in Government, banking and business.

title: GRACO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

title: REHNQUIST'S PARTISAN INTRUSION
description: Justice William H. Rehnquist's address on Presidential appointments to the Supreme Court is a blatant intrusion into partisan politics. The timing of the speech, the presumed impartiality of a Supreme Court source and the message - that Presidents have the right but not the ability to shape the Court - all further the Reagan cause. Not only does the speech implicity support the President's and the Republican platform's insistence that his judicial nominees oppose abortion (and perhaps other individual rights as well) but it reassures voters, who might be put off by such things, that a President really can't determine the Court's future rulings anyway.

title: POGO PRODUCING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After extraordinary charges of $420,000 for the quarter and $1,536,000 for the 9 months.

description: Share earnings have been adjusted to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split to be paid Nov. 16.

title: L.I. Woman Guilty Of a False Report
description: A 23-year-old former New York City police officer was convicted today of falsely reporting to the Nassau County police that she had been sexually assaulted in her home.

title: BUSH TAKES ON AUDIENCE QUESTIONS AT CAMAPIGN RALLY IN SYRACUSE
description: Vice President Bush had just finished answering a question on Social Security when another one came from the front of the audience.

description: William D. Ruckelshaus, Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, has accused Walter F. Mondale, the Democratic Presidential candidate, of failing to ''get your facts straight'' on the issue of toxic waste, but Mondale environmental advisers contend it is the other way about.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY ; Another Topic of Law: 'How to Avoid Probate'
description: More on lawyers: ''Don't be afraid of judges,'' says Norman F. Dacey. ''They're just politicians who were friends of the Governor.''

title: CARDINAL PRESSES CATHOLICS TO ATTACK WIDE RANGE OF SOCIAL ISSUES
description: Joseph Cardinal Bernardin of Chicago today called on Roman Catholics to make a broad Catholic attack on social ills that separates itself from both the fundamentalist right and a focus on such single issues as abortion.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ; Varian Associates Appoints President
description: Varian Associates Inc., an electronics manufacturer, yesterday named Jerome J. Meyer to the new position of president and chief operating officer. The appointment is effective Dec. 3.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: If you like pulling strings, you can cause a racket at the Citicorp Center, 153 East 53d Street. More than 50 marionettes, some as tall as 15 feet and almost all holding cymbals, tambourines, bells or other percussion instruments, will be in residence in the Atrium today through Nov. 9, attached by strings to a central control panel that the public is welcome to manipulate. Tongues will stick out, ears will wiggle and a ballerina will dance as the puppets are brought to life. They include clowns, a green-faced witch, a bride, a ballerina, elegant ladies, monsters and a 25-foot-long dragon. The creators are Ronnie Asbell and Glenn Paulsen. Free. Open Mondays through Fridays, 9 A.M. to 9 P.M.; Saturdays and Sundays, noon to 9 P.M. OLD BOOKS

title: 'Bells Are Ringing'
description: ''Bells Are Ringing,'' a musical comedy by Betty Comden and Adolph Green, will run through Nov. 18 at the Equity Library Theater, 103d Street and Riverside Drive. Shows are today at 8 P.M., tomorrow at 2:30 P.M. and 8 P.M. and Sunday at 2:30 P.M. Tickets are $7. Information: 247-0354.

title: Spending by Mondale Outpaces Reagan's
description: Walter F. Mondale's campaign had $5 million less left to spend than President Reagan's in the final month before the election, according to Federal spending reports.

title: WITNESS ASSERTS KY HEADS VIETNAMESE GANGS IN U.S.
description: A witness who said he had recently been a middle-echelon leader of a Vietnamese crime gang in the United States testified at a Federal hearing yesterday that his superior had told him that Nguyen Cao Ky, former Prime Minister and Vice President of South Vietnam, headed a Vietnamese crime organization in this country.

title: WINDMERE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Big Stock Filing From EQK Realty

The offering, through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers, would be one of the largest initial public offerings ever by a real estate investment trust.

title: DEFICIT OFF $20.1 BILLION FROM 1983
description: The Reagan Administration reported today that the Federal budget deficit for the fiscal year 1984, which ended Sept. 30, was $175.3 billion. This was $20.1 billion less than the record deficit of a year earlier.

title: BRIDGE: EVENT AT THE HARMONIE CLUB IS REUNION FOR TOP PLAYERS
description: The annual expert night at the Harmonie Club in New York Wednesday served more than one purpose. It not only provided an opportunity for members to meet their invited guests, many of whom had won national and international titles, but also served as a reunion for some experts who are virtually retired from serious play.

Economic Scene ; Federal Deficit And Indexation
description: With the rise in the Consumer Price Index by four-tenths of 1 percent last month, making an increase of 4.2 percent over the preceding 12 months, the Government has announced how much taxpayers will save on their 1985 income taxes to adjust for inflation. Starting Jan. 1, income tax brackets, the zero bracket limit, the standard deduction and personal exemptions will all be raised 4.1 percent.

title: SCREEN:'TERROR IN THE AISLES'
description: ''TERROR IN THE AISLES,'' which opens today at the Criterion and other theaters, poses as a serious exploration of the methods and effects of horror and suspense films. That it looks more like a feature-length trailer for almost 75 such films is not surprising - everyone who worked on it is associated with Kaleidoscope Films, one of the industry's most successful producers of trailers.

description: ''We may never have the kind of evidence that can stand up in an American court of law.

title: CAUSE OF HEPATITIS TRANSMITTED THROUGH BLOOD IS REPORTED FOUND
description: Margaret M. Heckler, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, said today that Federal scientists had succeeded in identifying the virus that causes the major form of hepatitis transmitted through blood transfusions.

description: Lyon Metal Products Inc. said the tender offer of $15 a share being made by KS Holdings Inc., a company owned by Irwin L. Jacobs and three associates, was inadequate and not in the best interests of shareholders. The board said book value of the stock is currently about $19 and a substantial increase is expected upon receipt of funds resulting from the recent termination of Lyon's shares. Lyon shares, trading over-the-counter, were bid yesterday at 15, up 37.5 cents from the previous day's bid.

description: Share earnings reflect a 5 percent stock dividend paid Oct. 1.

Young Assails Blacks Who Favor President
description: Mayor Andrew Young of Atlanta said today the only black votes President Reagan should receive are those of ''cold-hearted black millionaires who are probably going to hell.''

title: Budd Facing Decision
description: Zola Budd , the South African-born distance runner who became a British citizen to run in the Olympics, may not be returning to her new home, at least for a while.

description: The year-ago figures have been restated to reflect a change resulting from a revision of interim LIFO adjustment procedures made during the fourth quarter of 1983. The year-earlier share earnings were retroactively restated to reflect a 10 percent stock dividend paid in July 1984.

title: AIDES REPORTED TO SAY MONDALE SUPPORT EBBS
description: Walter F. Mondale has been privately informed by campaign aides of ''an across-the- board attrition'' of support for his Presidential candidacy in the last two weeks, Democratic sources said today.

title: Head of Rabbis' Group Endorses Mondale Bid
description: Walter F. Mondale was endorsed yesterday by the president of the major organization of Conservative rabbis, which represents more than 1,000 rabbis in the United States.

title: WORLDS APART (NOT FAR)
description: Partly because a diplomat's job is to understand and interpret national attitudes, I took a friend's advice and hired a car last summer, and as I drove across the mountains of Idaho and Wyoming and the great plains of Montana, I reflected on how geography shapes national attitudes.

title: ARCHITECT CHOSEN FOR GETTY COMPLEX
description: The J. Paul Getty Trust, concluding one of the most exhaustive searches for an architect any major institution has ever conducted, yesterday selected Richard Meier of New York to design an extensive new arts complex for a 700-acre site in Los Angeles.

title: CAMERA SMARTS
description: Michael Jordan has already dazzled the basketball experts with his precocious savvy and acrobatic, gravity-defyng moves. Now, it seems as if the versatile Chicago Bulls rookie is quickly extending his influence to other fields.

title: Reagan on Doonesbury: Not Always Amusing
description: President Reagan says he hass been following the return of the comic strip Doonesbury, by Garry Trudeau, but the President reportedly is not amused.

title: 9 Officers Hurt In IRT Track Fire
description: An explosion and fire in a lower Manhattan subway station forced the removal of about 100 riders last night and snarled West Side IRT service for half an hour, the Transit Authority said.

title: U.S. COURT UPHOLDS RESTRICTIONS ON PROTESTERS AT THE WHITE HOUSE
description: A Federal appeals court held today that ''the security of the President and the esthetics of the White House view'' justified Federal regulations limiting demonstrations on the sidewalk in front of the White House.

title: NEW LAWS TO PROTECT CONSUMERS
description: ''It was a banner year,'' said Stephen E. Mindell, an assistant attorney general for New York State, talking of the consumer legislation passed in the state during the last legislative session. ''It was probably the most productive year we've had in a long time.''

title: SYNAGOGUE BECOMES AN IMPRESARIO
description: One of Washington's major synagogues has taken on the role of impresario to stage an oratorio that will star the baritone Sherrill Milnes supported by a chorus of 175 voices and a 40-member orchestra.

title: Hicks Terminates Bid for Rangaire
description: The Rangaire Corporation announced that negotiations regarding the proposal from Hicks & Haas, a private investment partnership, to acquire Rangaire had terminated and that the proposal had been withdrawn.

title: LOS ANGELES FINDS 818 ADDS SOME EXCITEMENT
description: After three years of warnings and nine months of what the telephone companies called a ''permissive dialing period,'' 1.5 million Los Angeles area residents have been split off from 3.7 million neighbors as the area received its first new dialing code in nearly 40 years.

title: Dow-Morton
description: The Dow Chemical Company has expressed no interest in acquiring Morton Thiokol Inc., a Dow spokesman said today. The spokesman, responding to Thursday's comment by Morton Thiokol Inc. chairman, Charles S. Locke, that Dow may seek to increase its 7.96 percent stake in the company, said Dow had not changed its original reason for buying the shares, which was for investment purposes only. In New York Stock Exchange trading today, Morton Thiokol closed at 89, up 1/8.

title: HEILIG-MEYERS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
40 Laid Off by Asarco
description: Asarco Inc., a copper producer with headquarters in New York, laid off 40 more workers at its Mission Mine at Sahuaritia, bringing the number of copper workers let go this month to 120.

title: A NO-SWEAT ALTERNATIVE TO RUNNING THE MARATHON
description: For a little different perspective on New York's imminent marathon, we take you now to the La-Z-Boy recliner-chair store in Queens and Ralph Sansone.

title: INVOKING DEMOCRATIC HEROES: G.O.P. LURES WAVERING VOTERS
description: This is the season of the Presidential campaign when professional politicians watch the opinion polls closely to see how many Democrats who may have flirted with the Republican ticket will ''come home'' to their own party, and this year give Walter F. Mondale a crucial surge in the homestretch.The signs of battle over those Democrats and also over political independents, both of which constitute vital elements of President Reagan's support, emanate from practically every stop on the campaign trail.

title: CUMIN HAS A PLACE IN MORE THAN CHILI
description: Herbs and spices, like clothing, go in and out of fashion. Basil, after all, was in vogue for several years. It is only since this summer that cooks, who keep up with the latest fashions, began to talk of it as they once talked of the kiwi. ''I think if I see another kiwi...''

description: Carol Brandt, a longtime literary agent who represented Thornton Wilder, John Dos Passos, Vincent Sheehan and Marcia Davenport, died Thursday at her home in Manhattan.

title: Mexico Favors Curbs On Oil to Support Prices
description: The top energy official of Mexico said tonight that his nation was prepared to cut oil exports for the first time in its history, to help support sagging oil prices.

description: b-Including a nonrecurring gain of approximately $5.4 million from the forgiveness of debt and charges to operations of approximately $7 million which include a provision for expected losses on several construction projects and a reserve that will fund all future costs to the company involving employees who have taken an early retirement plan.

title: G.M. to Rehire Laid-Off Workers
description: The General Motors Corporation plans to resume a second shift at its North Tarrytown plant, offering employment to the more than 1,800 people laid off two years ago, a company spokesman said today.

title: CACI GROUP OF COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
RICHARD BRAUTIGAN, NOVELIST, A LITERARY IDOL OF THE 1060'S
description: Richard Brautigan, a literary idol of the 1960's who eventually fell out of fashion, was found dead Thursday at his secluded house in Bolinas, Calif. The Marin County coroner's office reported that the author of ''Trout Fishing in America'' and ''So the Wind Won't Blow It All Away'' apparently died of a self-inflicted gunshot wound four or five weeks ago. He was 49 years old.

title: GIANTS RETHINK PASSING
description: The Giants' running game this season has been terrible. The Washington Redskins, their opponents at 4 P.M. here Sunday, have the National Football League's second-best rushing defense and second-worst passing defense.

title: MONDALE ASSERTS PRESIDENT FAILED TO MARK DEATH OF 241 IN BOMBING
description: Calling his opponent a ''sunshine President,'' Walter F. Mondale today criticized President Reagan as failing to commemorate the first anniversary of the deaths of 241 American servicemen killed in Lebanon.

title: THANK YOU, MA'AM
description: The New York tabloids had a picnic this week with the Mayflower

title: MAN GUILTY IN FATAL STABBING OF YOUNG WOMAN IN JERSEY
description: James J. Koedatich was found guilty today of stabbing an 18-year-old Parsippany Hills cheerleader to death in 1982.

title:
PATENTS;
Screen Door Fastener
description: Raymond E. Smiley of Cranbury, N.J., was granted a patent this week for a way to fasten a screen door used in conjunction with a sliding glass door so that it does not fall off the track and stay open. Patent 4,478,267 provides for hinging the screen door to the nonmoving section of the glass door, allowing the screen to be easily shut. Mr. Smiley got the patent as an independent inventor, but handles more complicated devices as a patent attorney for the RCA Corporation.

title: MUST CRITICS EAT THEIR WORDS
description: Our lives could be made less manageable and enjoyable if the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals in New York does not overturn the rulings of a district judge that enabled a Chinese restaurant in Manhattan to win $20,005 in libel damages from a guidebook that unfavorably reviewed its cusine.

title: Alcan Seeking Delay on Smelter
description: The Aluminum Company of Canada, a subsidiary of Alcan Aluminium Ltd., asked the British Columbia government to postpone further review of its application for a $3 billion (Canadian currency) smelter project at Kemano, British Columbia.

title: CHEMICAL FABRICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Arab Envoy Wounded By Gunman in Rome
description: The Vice Consul of the United Arab Emirates was seriously wounded in the head and an Iranian companion was killed today when at least five shots were fired at the diplomat's car, the police said.

title: REAGAN WOOS JEWISH VOTERS ON L.I. VISIT
description: The President came courting today, so the rabbi's wife cooked, a neighbor protested by practicing drum rolls and another was forced to cancel her bridge game.

title: Mr. Helms's Foreign Legion Embroiled in a tough campaign for re-election, North Carolina's Senator Jesse Helms is boasting of endorsement by 22 United States ambassadors. To that startling, unprecedented partisanship by representatives of all the people, Secretary of State Shultz has made only mildly disapproving statements. He has reminded the ambassadors that their first duty is to the nation. In fact, their behavior is inappropriate in the extreme, even for non-career political appointees.
description: Mr. Helms held a press conference Thursday at which he distributed the endorsement by America's ambassadors to Mexico, France, Canada, Austria, Peru, Guatemala, Paraguay, South Korea, Barbados, Colombia, the Bahamas, Rumania, Switzerland, Jamaica, Madagascar, Equatorial Guinea and Costa Rica, plus five others to international organizations. Two of them appeared with Mr. Helms to extol his ''strong, close relationship with the Reagan Administration.''

BIRD INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including a tax credit of $525,000. c-Net income including a tax credit of $550,000.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY ; High-Voltage Candidate
description: In this season of Presidential politics

title: CELTICS TOP PISTONS AS BIRD SCORES 33
description: Larry Bird scored 8 points in the final 1 minute 56 seconds to help the Boston Celtics defeat the Detroit Pistons, 130-123, tonight.

title: BRITISH COAL STRIKE TALKS END WITH NO SIGNS OF ANY GAINS
description: The latest attempt to negotiate a settlement of the eight-month-old strike in Britain's coal mines broke up early today with no indication that any progress had been made.

title: REP. HANSEN APPEARS TO TRAIL IN IDAHO
description: Representative George Hansen has won seven terms in the House of Representatives by running against the Federal Government, but his chances for an eighth term in Idaho's Second Congressional District will depend largely on how he defends himself against his recent felony conviction for breaking Federal ethics laws.

title: MIAMI COMMISSION OUSTS MANAGER, STIRRING FUROR
description: The Miami City Commission dismissed the City Manager in a surprise 3-to-2 vote Thursday night, leaving politics in this ethnically divided city in turmoil today.

title: NEWS SUMMARY;
description: SATURDAY, OCTOBER 27, 1984 International Two gunmen wounded the Pope on May 13, 1981, not one, as the authorities originally assumed, according to an Italian judge. The disclosure by the judge, Ilario Martella, came at a news conference in which he formally announced that three Bulgarians and four Turks would be tried on charges of complicity in the attempt to kill John Paul II. (Page 1, Column 6.) Mehmet Ali Agca, the central figure in the conspiracy case in the attempted murder of Pope John Paul II, has partly recanted his testimony about another purported plot, to kill Lech Walesa, the founder of the Polish union Solidarity. But Mr. Agca's testimony included a wealth of details, many of which were independently corroborated by investigating magistrates. (1:4-6.)

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: PHOTOGRAPHIC MEMORY Wandering up and down Fifth Avenue's Museum Mile on a weekend, in the stretch between 79th and 106th Streets, one may windowshop on the artistic treasures of the world, from the mighty Metropolitan north to the Museo del Barrio. One may store memories in the mind, but human memory, even photographic, is, well, only human and not as durable or as communicable as those recorded by a skillful photographer. That is one reason to drop by the International Center of Photography, at 1130 Fifth Avenue at 94th Street (860-1777).

title: Berra's Night Out
description: On the day George Steinbrenner announced that Yogi Berra would continue as the Yankees' manager, Berra was torn between sports and culture. A fan of the New Jersey Devils, he wanted to attend their game against the Rangers at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, but he and his wife had committed themselves to going to the opera with friends.

title: Adolf L. Heck, Head Of Korbel Champagne
description: Adolf L. Heck, chairman of the board of Korbel Champagne Cellars of Guerneville, Calif., whose career in winemaking spanned more than 50 years, died Wednesday at a hospital in Sebastopol, Calif. He was 68 years old.

title: It's Only Natural . . .
description: Guess who's starring in a fund-raising event for A.S.P.C.A. animal- welfare programs at the Pierre Hotel next Thursday? ?

title: College Autonomy Approved in Jersey
description: Endorsing a free-market approach, New Jersey's Board of Higher Education today approved plans to give the nine state colleges greater autonomy and to spur competition in order to improve the schools' quality.

title: A Coca-Cola Bottler To Buy Wometco
description: The Coca-Cola Bottling Company Consolidated and the Wometco Bottling Company have agreed for Coca- Cola Consolidated to buy Wometco for $300 million, it was announced yesterday. Wometco is the Miami- based soft drink division of the privately held WEI Enterprises Corporation.

title: Fingers Files
description: Rollie Fingers of the Milwaukee Brewers, one of the original free agents in 1976, filed for free agency yesterday along with Dave Kingman of Oakland, Steve Trout of the Chicago Cubs and John Curtis of California. With one business day left for filing, 50 players have declared for the Nov. 8 draft.

title: Breaking Down A Stereotype
description: When Tony Paige, the Jets' rookie fullback, was sitting in classes at Virginia Tech, he noticed that some students looked at him differently.

description: Franco Zeffirelli's opulent, sometimes vulgar staging of ''La Boh eme'' at the Metropolitan Opera is a known quantity, as were all but one of the singers in these parts on Thursday night, when Puccini's most popular opera returned for the first time this season.

title: LEGISLATIVE ACTION ON FIXED SENTENCES THREATENED BY IMPASSE IN STUDY PANEL
description: A committee set up to draft a system of fixed sentences for criminals in New York State is sharply divided, and the dispute threatens to block any action on the issue by the State Legislature.

title: 'Bells Are Ringing'
description: ''Bells Are Ringing,'' a musical comedy by Betty Comden and Adolph Green with music by Jule Styne, will run through Nov. 18 at the Equity Library Theater, 103d Street and Riverside Drive. Shows are today at 2:30 and 8 P.M. and tomorrow at 2:30 P.M. Tickets are $7. Box office information: 663-2028.

title: EUROPEANS SEEK A MILITARY IDENTITY
description: Foreign and Defense Ministers from seven NATO countries met here today without the United States in an attempt to bring a more clearly defined European character to their military cooperation.

description: To the Editor:

title: Japan Output Up 9%
description: Production at Japan's factories and mines rose 9 percent in September from a year earlier, the Ministry of International Trade and Industry said today. Though production remained fairly strong, September's performance fell below the double-digit gains that had been recorded in each of the previous nine months.

title: EASTMET CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results for the latest third quarter reflect a charge of $1,425,000 from the reversal of a tax credit.

title: Bausch & Lomb
description: Bausch & Lomb Inc. said it took a $9 million charge in the third quarter to set up a reserve for divestiture of its industrial instrument operations. The company said it is in discussions for sale of facilities in Ottawa; Jamestown, N.Y., and Austin, Tex.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY ; The Uninvited Guests
description: Three caged chickens were squawking in the Sheraton Centre yesterday morning. The hotel security people called the United Jewish Appeal- Federation of Jewish Philanthropies Campaign, and officials there arranged for what they described as ''a safe home in the country'' for the chickens.

title: Florida Huddle
description: Howard Schnellenberger , still looking for a job after the aborted effort to place a United States Football League franchise in Miami, has met with Marshall Criser , the president of the University of Florida. The apparent reason for the get-together was to discuss the Gators' head-coaching post, which is being filled on an interim basis by Galen Hall after numerous intercollegiate rules violations led to the dismissal of Charley Pell earlier this season.

title: Taken as a Burglar, Officer Is Wounded
description: A police officer answering a call at a Harlem tobacco store was shot in a hand yesterday, apparently mistaken for a burglar, the police said.

description: Representative Christopher H. Smith Jr., a two- term Republican from the traditionally Democratic Fourth Congressional District, will be helped in his re-election bid by a court-ordered redistricting plan that cuts into Democratic strength.

description: El Salvador's leading army combat commander, killed Tuesday in a helicopter crash, was buried here today with all the ceremony of a state funeral.

Quake Felt in California

title: BRITISH TELECOM'S STOCK PLANS
description: The British Government today disclosed most details of its plan to sell just over half of British Telecommunications, the state-owned telephone company, to private investors next month. The proceeds are expected to make it the world's largest stock sale ever.

description: Officials of Le Bow Industries Ltd., the parent company of Sarah Coventry Jewelry, has said it would end the party plan concept of selling products to groups in private homes.

title: Air Via Going Public
description: Air Via Inc. said today that it had filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission covering an initial public offering of common stock.

title: The Village That Beat the Gun Lobby When the court battle began in 1981, few would have bet that the village of Morton Grove, Ill., could prevail over the national gun lobby. How could a few suburban trustees outmaneuver the determined, well-lawyered National Rifle Association to secure the nation's first outright ban on possession of handguns?
description: Last week the Illinois Supreme Court upheld the ban, virtually eliminating any chance of further legal challenge. The case made clear how easily heavily promoted gun lobby arguments crumble when subjected to scrutiny in court.

description: In one of the most brazen terrorist incidents here in months, a car bomb exploded today across the street from the main Government building, wounding four people and shattering dozens of window panes.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Metropolitan Report yesterday about a conference on teen- age suicide misidentified the lecturer who opposed romanticizing it. She was Ann S. Kliman, director of the Situational Crisis Service of the Center for Preventive Psychiatry Inc., in White Plains.

title: DR. STEPHEN KOSS, EXPERT ON HISTORY
description: Dr. Stephen E. Koss, a historian of British politics and professor of history at Columbia University, died Thursday at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center after heart surgery. He was 44 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: BUSH LABELS FOE A 'NEGATIVE GUY'
description: Before one the largest crowds of his campaign, Vice President Bush today assailed Walter F. Mondale as the ''Great Depressor.''

title: MIXED BLESSINGS
description: ''Half of Chicago is in ashes,'' a woman named Julia Newberry wrote in her diary. ''It is too awful to believe, too dreadful to think about.''

STABLER,38,RETIRES IN 15TH PRO SEASON
description: Ken Stabler, one of the most accurate passers in National Football League history with a completion rate of nearly 60 percent, retired tonight.

title: School's Pupils Warned Against Jackson Concert
description: A religious school that considers rock music sinful will discipline students who attend the Jacksons' Victory Tour concerts here next week, administrators said today.

title: HOWARD SAMUELS, INDUSTRIALIST AND POLITICIAN, DIES
description: Howard J. Samuels, who became a millionaire before he was 40 years old and then turned to a career in government and politics, died of a heart attack yesterday at his Manhattan apartment after complaining to his wife of chest pains. He was 64 years old.

title: TWO GUNMEN SHOT POPE IN 1981 PLOT, ITALIAN JUDGE SAYS
description: An Italian judge asserted today that Pope John Paul II was shot and wounded in 1981 by two gunmen and not one, as the authorities originally assumed.

title: RESOURCEFUL FLUTIE WORRIES RUTGERS
description: After West Virginia's success in stopping Doug Flutie last week, Boston College's remaining opponents might be expected to emulate the defensive tactics of the Mountaineers. West Virginia rallied in the second half to hand the Eagles their first loss of the season, 21-20.

title: CONCERT:'DESERT MUSIC,' A NEW WORK BY REICH
description: Steve Reich is like a carpenter who decides to build a house using only a hammer because he owns no other tools. The American premiere of ''The Desert Music'' at the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Thursday night was the latest demonstration of his ability to compose a large-scale piece with extremely limited resources. As with so many recent works in the Minimal style, its appeal is to an audience willing to embrace relentless repetition and glacial movement not only as musical devices but almost as an esthetic. A generation reared on the monotonously simple rhythms of rock music provides just such a public and therefore, despite its leanness of musical means, ''The Desert Music'' was received with enthusiasm by the Brooklyn audience. So too, justifiably, were Michael Tilson Thomas, the conductor, and his orchestra of Brooklyn Philharmonic members. They had to stay alert and count for 50 minutes, and they did so magnificently.

title: CUOMO PLANS TO APPOINT A NEW COMMERCE CHIEF
description: Governor Cuomo is planning to appoint a new commerce commissioner and put the current Commissioner in charge of economic development in the Buffalo area, his aides said yesterday.

title: A Tory Ploy on Plane Fares All the major airlines want to reduce off-season fares to Britain to as little as $310, round trip. Washington approves but the British Government has blocked the fare cuts from taking effect Nov. 1. The re'll be no reductions, says Britain's Department of Transportation, unless the Justice Department certifies in advance that the proposed fares are legal under America's antitrust laws.
description: What a touching concern for legalities. The Thatcher Government knows full well that there won't be any antitrust suit objecting to these fare reductions. Its real purpose is to show displeasure with the Justice Department's investigation of charges that British carriers helped drive low-fare Laker Airlines out of business in 1982. It may be too much to expect the British Government to support an American antitrust action in which British Airways may be one of the defendants. But surely the Tories can find a way to protest that is more consistent with their free-market principles.

title: MEETING OF AGCA AND BULGARIAN IS HEATED

title: Protest on Sittler Injury
description: The Detroit Red Wings have filed a protest with the National Hockey League, charging that Jim Korn of the Toronto Maple Leafs intentionally injured Darryl Sittler , whose cheekbone was fractured when Korn checked him during a game Wednesday night. Not only was no penalty called against Korn on the play, but Referee Ron Fournier assessed Sittler two minutes for retaliating. Sittler underwent surgery Thursday and will be out indefinitely.

title: Perjury Charges

The charges stem from Miss Parsons's libel suit against Sports Illustrated magazine over an article, published a month after she resigned under pressure in January 1982, that described her as having had a lesbian relationship with at least one of her players. The jury in the libel case decided in favor of the magazine, and now Federal prosecutors contend that Miss Parsons and Miss Buck lied at the trial in denying that they were lovers.

title: SKIRTS FOR MEN? YES AND NO
description: No one is yet certain whether it actually represented a significant breakthrough in fashion history or whether it merely provided comic relief from the boredom of the Paris spring collections which just came to a close. Nevertheless, the 1984 Paris showings, as well as those in London the previous week, will go down in the collective fashion memory as the time when men were first seen wearing skirts on the major runways of Europe. The phenomenon, as it was called, appeared primarily in collections of young designers who create clothing for both men and women: the Body Map show in London, the Jean-Paul Gaultier show in Paris. But even at Chanel, which does not make men's clothes and does not have a young designer, a man appeared in a Chanel suit. He did not, however, wear a skirt. He wore, for the sake of propriety, side-button pants. For some, the wearing of skirts by men became an important issue. ''It is the most important thing to happen in fashion in the past 20 years!'' announced Daniel Hechter, the French designer, at a dinner he gave one night in his apartment on Avenue Foch. ''I remember when it was scandal for women to wear pants,'' he declared. Mr. Hechter was one of the first to design pants for women. The Gaultier show caused the most controversy. Some of the male models wore plaid skirts and open-toed platform basketball sneakers. Other outfits pushed the phenomenon to its limits, with men wearing sarongs and tank tops or see-through harem pants.
