title: WHERE THE FOOD WENT Any help (for Jews) was cause for arrest of both the helpers and their families. . . . Despite these punishments, there were still a few people who helped Jews even after 1939. . . . During the earlier period, the most common form of help was the purchase of extra amounts of food, since Jews were no longer allowed to shop. . . . Herr Otto, still a grocer today, described how Frau Schmidt . . . ''suddenly one day asked for two pounds of butter instead of her usual one. I knew of course that the extra pound was for the Mandels who lived upstairs.'' The Jewish families, digging into their savings, paid for the purchased goods themselves. Later some of them began bartering household items and sold off their possessions as the financial need arose. Throughout the thirties, Christina and her brother Robert, owners of the bakery, continued baking challah on Friday, which she secretly delivered to Jewish customers late at night. She continued this practice until 1941 . . . whenever she could, so that ''they could still celebrate the Friday night meal.'' Frau Kramer described how her mother would buy extra rolls and when she walked by the homes of certain Jews, she would throw them through a window left open for that purpose.

title: FLICK'S GIFTS BEGIN TO TAKE THEIR TOLL ON KOHL'S PARTY
description: Like Watergate, the Flick scandal - which takes its snappy name from West Germany's biggest holding company - emerges in riveting installments. Leaked to the press every few weeks, revelations about Flick's political payoffs besmirch new names and claim new victims, edging ever closer to the center of power. And, like the scandal that dragged Richard Nixon down, the Flick affair appears to be having a profoundly corrosive effect, breeding distrust and contempt among the public for those who hold high office. In West Germany's sometimes brittle democracy, where the party system is in slow-motion upheaval, the imaginable fallout from the biggest scandal in its history makes people nervous.

title: WILL TOUGHER LABELS WORK?

title: A CHIP OFF THE DEFICIT

LONG ISLAND GUIDE;
 CHAIM GROSS AT 80
description: Although in his long career Chaim Gross has been intimately involved in the dormant art of wood sculpture - elevating it to outstanding art, critics say - none of his many international exhibitions have concentrated on this aspect of his life's work. That is, until now. For today, to mark his 80th birthday, the Nassau County Museum of Fine Art opens ''Chaim Gross at 80: A Retrospective of His Sculptures in Wood.'' With works on loan from such institutions as the Museum of Modern Art, the Metropolitan Museum of Art and the Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden and private collections, the exhibition, according to Constance Schwartz, the museum curator, illustrates how ''those exuberant many-dimensional studies have become synonymous with this unique artist.'' title: New & Noteworthy
description: COMPANY K, by William March. (Arbor House, $7.95.) In this World War I Army story that takes the reader into the trenches, the author lined up Company K's 113 officers and men and gave to each, round-robin fashion, a bit of his novel to tell. When ''Company K'' came out 51 years ago, Harold Strauss said in The Book Review that March had gone ''far beyond the confines of a novel; at a single stroke he invented and perfected a new form. No man could write the gigantic story that lies behind 'Company K,' but William March, by a brilliant refinement of form, has given us its essence and its broad sweep, flashes of its intensity and rich variety.'' THE ANATOMY LESSON, by Philip Roth. (Fawcett Crest, $3.95.) The third of Mr. Roth's novels starring the novelist Nathan Zuckerman - following ''The Ghost Writer'' and ''Zuckerman Unbound'' - was published in hard covers last year. Zuckerman by now is middle-aged, devoid of ideas, emotionally exhausted and in constant pain. Robert Kiely, our reviewer, said: ''Roth has written, not a contemporary defense of fiction or poetry, but of the writer as bankrupt. Bereft of ideas, subject matter and self-confidence, the writer is nonetheless bound to his profession as he is to his own body.''

(The final performance of this program takes place Tuesday night at Avery Fisher Hall.)

title: DANCE: SIN CHA HONG AND LAUGHING STONE
description: Sin Cha Hong, a Korean-born dancer and choreographer who lives in this country, offers a remarkable ability to combine the Minimalist esthetic of American experimental dance with the concentration found in Asian theater.

title: BUSINESS NOTES
description: -based First Jersey National Corporation, a $2.3 billion bank-holding company with 85 offices in 12 New Jersey counties, has announced plans to form a new subsidiary to be called the First Jersey National Bank/West.

title: Kennedy Center Reports $1.8 Million Deficit
description: The Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts has reported a net operating loss of $1,878,000 in the past fiscal year, the first deficit since its first season in 1971-72.

title: Japanese Stops Orioles
description: ''He beat us single-handedly,'' Manager Joe Altobelli said after his Baltimore Orioles opened a 15-game tour of Japan with a 1-0 loss to Kazuhisa Kawaguchi of the Hiroshima Toyo Carp in Tokyo yesterday. Actually, Kawaguchi used a bat to win, too, singling in the game's run in the second inning. On the mound, he allowed only six hits and struck out 10 in outpitching Mike Boddicker, Bill Swaggerty and Sammy Stewart before a crowd of 33,000 at Korakuen Stadium.

title: MAILBAG
description: TAKING ISSUE WITH NBC'S CHIEF

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;
RADIO FOR PROFIT: LISTENER BEWARE
description: TURN your radio dial. Hear all those stations? The AM and FM bands are filled from end to end.

title: ILLEGAL ALIENS DESCRIBE LIFE IN SOCIETY'S SHADOWS
description: To Hector and Maria, the major immigration bill that failed in Congress earlier this month was of little concern because their arrival in the United States was too recent to qualify them for its amnesty provisions.

title: NETWORK OF SUSPICION
description: A national file drawer of unproved tips and allegations - this time confined to white-collar crime suspects and their associates - is once again under consideration at the Justice Department.

title: DANCERS WHO PROBE THE DARK CORNERS OF THE MIND
description: TOKYO

title: CLEARED FOR FASTER TAKEOFFS
description: Starting this week, getting in and out of a half dozen of the nation's busiest airports might be a bit less frustrating. Under an agreement approved by the Civil Aeronautics Board last week, the airlines will make 1,300 schedule adjustments designed to reduce runway and boarding gate congestion, primarily in morning and evening rush hours.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY: ATLANTIC COAST VOYAGES, NEW TOKYO GUIDE
description: A Sea Cruise For Reliving Olden Days With her high pilot's house, her single smokestack and her streaming pennants, the Pilgrim Belle looks like a vessel from the past - one can almost hear the strains of ''Avalon'' drifting across the water from her lounge while flappers and philosophers, leaning against the sun deck railing, relive a Yale-Harvard game of the 1920's.

title: RIGGINS TO TEST GIANT DEFENSE
description: Bill Parcells remembers the first time he saw John Riggins.

title: HOW POLL WAS CONDUCTED
description: The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted Oct. 23 to 25 with 1,463 adults around the United States, excluding Alaska and Hawaii, of whom 1,068 indicated they were registered to vote.

title: AFTER THE PULITZER, THEN WHAT?
description: Barbara Jepson writes frequently about the world of music.

title: AMERICA GROWS OLDER, BUT WILL IT GROW WISER?
description: WHETHER

title: SANDINISTAS GET MROE REBUFFS
description: Things got a bit lonelier for the Nicaraguan Sandinistas last week as another opposition candidate dropped out of the election next Sunday and the Roman Catholic Church renewed its attacks.

title: THE 'REVOLUTION' OF 1881 IS NOW IN ITS 2d CENTURY
description: THE ''revolution'' of the cooperative apartment house, as The New York Times described it at its inception, began in 1881. New York then was a city of householders, and the upper and even middle classes considered apartments suspect. If you could not afford to buy a city house, you rented one, or lived in a boardinghouse or in New Jersey.

title: AMERICA'S BANKS IN CRISIS
description: Lester Thurow's analysis reflects the denial by all schools of economic thought (including his school, Keynesianism) that overcapacity and overproduction are the causes of our economic ills. He blames ''ignorance,'' ''stupidity,'' ''chicanery,'' ''bad management'' and ''bad regulation'' for the banking crisis, but he acknowledges that ''the rush to deregulate . . . has made the (banking) industry fiercely competitive and pushed banks to take extraordinary risks.''

title:
NUMISMATICS;
SILVER SELLERS PLACE THE ACCENT ON BEAUTY
description: Buying silver bullion is not just a matter of purchasing precious metal. Increasingly, buyers seem concerned not only with the weight and fineness of their bullion pieces, but also with their beauty. Major producers of silver bullion pieces - coins, medals, ingots and bars - have responded by enhancing the appearance of their products. Some have even given them numismatic overtones such as proof quality and limited mintages.

title: MONDALE FOR PRESIDENT
description: We're for Walter Mondale, even though Ronald Reagan has in some ways done a good job. America, the President says with permissible hyperbole, is back and he deserves credit because the country feels so much better than it did four years ago. Mr. Reagan has a gift for symbolism and salesmanship; when he salutes the flag and the troops, he embodies a wide renewal of pride in country.

title: Bangladesh Postpones Vote for Second Time
description: President Hussain Ershad today postponed indefinitely parliamentary elections that had been scheduled for December.

title: French TV Reporter Back From Afghanistan
description: A French television journalist arrived here today after being released by Afghanistan, which had sentenced him to 18 years in prison for having entered the country illegally with insurgents.

title: OFFERS OF AID FOR STRICKEN ETHIOPIA ARE POURING INTO RELIEF AGENCIES
description: The international effort to help famine victims in Ethiopia has accelerated dramatically in recent days, with governments offering food, transport planes and other aid, and thousands of ordinary Americans pledging contributions.

title: Nutley (4-2) Toppled, 15-13 Andre Yates scored two
description: touchdowns and ran for the

title: HARTFORD IS HOPING FOR DEVELOPERS' AID
description: A HARTFORD task force studying ways to link office development in the city to guarantees of jobs and housing for residents has taken a major step forward with the hiring of a consultant.

title: SUPPORT FOR PARENTS OF CHILDREN IN SERIOUS CONDITION
description: WHEN a child gets sick and requires hospitalization, many unpleasant and unexpected things can happen to his family. Parents are often immobilized with fear beyond seeking treatment for the child. Grandparents will often retreat, to deal with their own heightened anxiety, and friends of the family can be so threatened by the seriousness of the illness, that they feel too vulnerable to be of help.

title: 75 FOR E. 58th STREET
description: The Minskoff family has long been associated with the management and ownership of all sorts of buildings in Manhattan, including theaters.

title: Daphne H. Geary Is Married
description: At St. James Episcopal Church in New York yesterday, Daphne Harrison Geary and William Morrison Waggaman were married by the Rev. Hayse Rockwell.

title: Viva Main Street!
description: Someone please tell Russell Baker that Main Street is not dead (''Main Street, R.I.P.,'' Sunday Observer, Sept. 16). Though it has undergone changes over the years, Main Street is still very much the heart and soul of America.

title: KARPOV AND KASPAROV DRAW THE 18TH GAME IN CHESS PLAY
description: Why was Gary Kasparov desperate to make another draw in the 18th game of his match with the world chess champion, 33-year-old Anatoly Karpov, in Moscow on Friday?

title: A CHOICE OF TABLES
description: In the gloomy gray days of winter, when

title: Theater
description: If, for some reason, you've managed to pass up the Ridiculous Theatrical Company all these years, now is the time to make the pilgrimage to One Sheridan Square. In ''The Mystery of Irma Vep,'' the company's artistic renaissance man, Charles Ludlam, is in top form as playwright, director and star.

title: WHOOPI AS ACTRESS, CLOWN AND SOCIAL CRITIC
description: Whoopi Goldberg is a slight, sprite-like comic actress whose mind and body are inhabited by some of the drollest and most touching characters one is ever likely to encounter in a Broadway theater or on a city street. She has the face and personality of a wise child - with ingenuous eyes and a puckish smile. As she tells her tales of misfits and outcasts, and even as she offers wry satiric comments, she is consistently disarming. Bantering mischievously with the audience, she warms up a Broadway theater, winning us as her confederates.

title: Susan E. Holmes Is Wed in Capital
description: Susan Elliot Holmes, the daughter of Col. Frederick S. Holmes Jr. of the Army and Mrs. Holmes of Annandale, Va., was married yesterday to Matthew Benjamin Heller, the son of Mr. and Mrs. James H. Heller of Washington. The Rev. James R. Adams performed the ceremony at St. Mark's Episopal Church in Washington.

title:
DINING OUT;
LA MER IN ELMSFORD
description: THE dining room at La Mer is as attractive as ever. Intense shades of blue still make a fitting backdrop for the gorgeous chandelier, attractively appointed tables with silvery pepper and salt shakers only a little tarnished, and comfortable oval-backed chairs. The menu, unnecessarily complicated, has not changed much either; there are actually two menus from which a diner can put together a meal. All this familiarity is a good thing, for the food failed to remind us of the kitchen's past achievements.

title: Laura Bergmann Marries
description: Laura Ann Bergmann, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Lawrence Ward Bergmann of Bronxville, N.Y., and Franklin W. Roth 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. F. Waldo Roth Jr. of Plantation, Fla., were married yesterday. The Rev. James McNaull performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church in Orlando, Fla. The bride and bridegroom are graduates of Denison University.

title: Mary Hamilton Weds Charles Sprague
description: Mary Peyton Hamilton, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Milton H. Hamilton of Alexandria, Va., was married yesterday to Charles Wallace Sprague, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Wallace A. Sprague of Short Hills, N.J. The Rev. David H. C. Read performed the ceremony at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church in New York.

title: NUTRITION FOR PREGNANT TEEN-AGERS
description: THREE-YEAR-OLD Anthony Verderosa whips around the classroom, speaking to no one in particular, playing joyfully, unaware that his coos and shouts are a symbol of why everyone has gathered.

title: Miss Kenzie To Be Bride
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Ross B. Kenzie of Derby, N.Y., of the engagement of their daughter Rachel Langley Kenzie to John Patrick King, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Patrick Henry King of Pittsburgh.

title: CAMPAIGN IS 'MOVING,' FERRARO INSISTS
description: Geraldine A. Ferraro has dismissed bad- news polls with a gibe at the messenger, Walter F. Mondale's campaign chief.

title: THE TROUBLING ECONOMICS OF OIL
description: Kuwaiti sheiks, Saudi princes and Nigerian bureaucrats live mainly on hope these days - the hope that oil production will fall everywhere but in the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. And in fact there is substantial evidence that this is slowly happening.

title: Drug Test for Vikings
description: When it comes to drugs, Les Steckel, the coach of the Minnesota Vikings, does not fool around. That's the word from Randy Holloway, a former Viking defensive end, who says that the team has been giving players random drug tests, and discovering some users.

title: SUIT SHIFTS DELOREAN'S LEGAL TROUBLES TO DETROIT
description: A $100 million lawsuit accusing John Z. DeLorean of negligence and fraud has shifted the focus of legal actions involving the former automobile executive from California to Detroit.

title: America's Banks In Crisis
description: Lester C. Thurow's article, ''America's Banks in Crisis'' (Sept. 23), is provocative, but it minimizes the adaptive progress made by a financial system in transition. Banks have persevered through the vicissitudes of Petrodollar recycling, real-estate cycles, a depression in agriculture, boom and bust in the national energy industry and the changing credit of America's heavy industry, battered by global competition.

title: THE REAGAN ECONOMIC LEGACY
description: Washington

title: TAPE RECORDING CITED IN QUEENS RACE
description: Statements recorded two years ago during a midnight telephone call are playing a major role in a hard-fought campaign for the Assembly in the 25th District in Queens.

title: Accommodating The Disabled
description: The description of the University of Connecticut Law School's new campus (''UConn Law School Begins a New Era,'' Sept. 23) was inaccurate. It is true that the new facility is infinitely more esthetically pleasing than the old one. It is not true, as Dean Schatzski reports, that ''everyone is happy.'' As a second-year law student, I had eagerly awaited the long-delayed move. However, after my first day at the new campus, I began to wish that the move had been delayed even longer.

title: 'CLOUD 9' AN INNOVATIVE COMEDY
description: THE Studio Theater in Lindenhurst is known for presenting innovative, thought-provoking, often difficult plays and musicals. They have brought us ''Bent,'' ''I'm Getting My Act Together and Taking it on the Road,'' and ''The Runner Stumbles,'' among many others. Continuing this tradition, Studio has they opened its new season with ''Cloud Nine,'' an imaginative comedy by the British playwright Caryl Churchill.

title: CREATING A CIGARETTE THAT PUTS ITSELF OUT
description: A self-extinguishing cigarette?

title: A REWARD FOR ACHIEVEMENTS OF THE FUTURE
description: A Reward for Achievements Of the Future

title: KING GETS 34 IN KNICKS ROMP
description: The Knicks opened their season last night at Madison Square Garden with a 137-119 victory over Bernard King's favorite team, the Detroit Pistons.

title: TRIVIAL PURSUIT SUIT Where did the authors of the ''Trivial Pursuit'' board game get a lot of their information?
description: Fred L. Worth , a California freelance writer, thinks he can answer that question. Last week, Mr. Worth sued the folks who put out the hugely successful game, saying as much as a third of the material in some of its versions was lifted from his ''Complete Unabridged Super Trivia Encyclopedia,'' which he copyrighted before the game appeared. Mr. Worth asked a Federal court in Los Angeles to award him $300 million from Selchow & Righter of New York, Horn Abbott Ltd. of Canada and the game's three Canadian authors. Mr. Worth said mistakes in his book showed up in the game, along with a phony fact that he planted as a trap to catch plagiarists.

title: Legislator and 2 Bodyguards Slain on a Guatemala Street
description: Santos Hernandez, a 56-year-old member of the Guatemalan Constituent Assembly, and two bodyguards were shot dead Friday as they walked along a street in the southern part of the capital, fire officials reported.

title:
SPEAKING PERSONALLY;
LEARNING TO LIVE WITH MACHINES
description: ALTHOUGH computers never related well to me in the past, I am happy to say that they recently have become friendlier.

title: SHE PINCH-HITS FOR SYMPHONY
description: AS the assistant conductor of the Nassau Symphony Orchestra, most of JoAnn Falletta's work takes place offstage. It's her job to be there when musical director Kenneth Klein can't make rehearsals or performances, and in the three years she has served as his backup, she has pinch-hit only sporadically, putting the orchestra, which opens its new season Saturday, through its preparatory paces ''maybe 10 times a year,'' and getting to conduct in public only once - last summer when Mr. Klein was called away from a concert.

title: BRUINS TROUNCE ISLANDERS
description: The Islanders, their stars full of fortune for so long, now find themselves weak in almost every facet of the game.

title: Jeffrey Tyler Wed To Diane Turner
description: Diane Turner, a daughter of Dr. A. Jack Turner and Sylvia C. Turner, both of Huntsville, Ala., was married yesterday to Jeffrey Allen Tyler, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard D. Tyler of Rydal, Pa. The Rev. Carl Nelson performed the ceremony at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church in New York.

title: Hawks Fly Past Cape May
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: WOMEN'S SCHOOLS: SEXED, DESEXED AND RESEXED
description: Diane Ravitch is professor of history at Teachers College, Columbia University. Her latest book is ''The Troubled Crusade: American Education, 1945-1980.'' ALMA MATER

title: CLEANUP REVIVING RARITAN SHORES
description: WHILE much attention is now focused on the redevelopment of the Hudson River waterfront, there is another New Jersey river where a number of cities are pinning hopes for a revival on their own shorelines.

title: A 'LATE BLOOMER' AT RUTGERS
description: NEW BRUNSWICK

title: MONDALE PRESSING CAMPAIGN EFFORT TO WIN CALIFORNIA
description: Walter F. Mondale, following a strategy in which his hopes have narrowed to a few key areas, campaigned in California yesterday in an effort to erase President Reagan's lead in his home state.

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;
THE CAPTAIN VS. MULTIPLE SCLEROSIS
description: LOU ALBANO weighs 310 pounds, bellows when he talks, and wears three rubber bands dangling from a pin pushed through the flesh of his face. Jay Roth speaks in soft tones, uses spectacles for reading and has a gentle, scholarly demeanor.

title: Nuclear Blast in Soviet
description: The Seismological Institution of Uppsala University said today that it recorded a strong underground nuclear explosion, measuring 6.9 on the Richter scale, in the area of Soviet Central Asia where the Soviet Union conducts underground nuclear tests near Semipalatinsk.

title: Group Finds President 'Mediocre' on Spending
description: Big spenders in Congress did not change their ways much in 1984 and President Reagan's ''mediocre'' record on spending cuts got worse, the National Taxpayer's Union said Friday.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: '' THERE is an unprecedented level of interest in activity on behalf of children in the state,'' said Alexandra Larson , executive director of the Governor's Committee on Children's Services Planning. ''Consequently, many long-neglected problems are just now being uncovered and addressed.''

title: WHEN ART CAME OUT OF THE STUDIO AND MINGLED
description: It is a tale of 25 years ago that the exhibition called

title: Correction
description: A caption accompanying the London segment of ''What's New in Europe'' (Travel, Oct. 7) misstated the name of the building in which the picture was taken. The photograph was not of the Capital Hotel but of the lobby area of L'H^otel, two doors down Basil Street and owned by David Levin of the Capital Hotel.

title: Elisa DeCarlo Is Wed To Jeffrey A. Shames
description: The Lotos Club was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Elisa Lyons DeCarlo and Jeffrey Alan Shames. Rabbi A. Bruce Goldman officiated.

title: Driver is Held in Death Of Girl in Wheelchair
description: A teen-ager confined to a wheelchair was struck and killed early today by a car as she crossed Hempstead Turnpike near Hofstra University, the Nassau County police said. The driver of the car was charged with drunken driving.

title: DOES WITHDRAWING INVESTMENT HURT APARTHEID?
description: About 350 American companies operate in in South Africa, and many of them feel that their long-term future may be threatened by an intensifying campaign in the United States for withdrawal of investment from this racially divided nation.

title: THE VIEW FROM BEHIND THE HANDLEBARS
description: GWYN BALLARD is a professor of biophysics at the Rockefeller University.

title: KEROSENE-HEAT LAW GOES INTO EFFECT
description: A NEW state law regulating the sale and use of kerosene heaters has gone into effect. ''While it is possible to use kerosene heaters safely, the amount of care and prudence required is unusually high,'' said Lois Bryant, division chief in the Office of Product Safety of the state's Department of Consumer Protection.

title: CONNECTICUT ; RECLAIMED WATERFRONT AREALURES YOUNG PROFESSIONALS
description: JOSEPH CUGNO, a young Connecticut architect, described his 700-square-foot, $63,000 condominium above an art gallery in South Norwalk as ''the deal of the century.'' He paid 10 percent down on a 9.875 percent mortgage from the Connecticut Housing and Finance Authority and his carrying charges are $475 a month, including property taxes of about $600 a year.

title:
LONG ISLAND;
DORMANT SITE IS FERTILE GROUND FOR HIGH-PRICED DEVELOPMENT
description: WHEN planning began in 1980 for Harbour Point at Northport, a 66-unit town-house development now under construction, it started with a question.

title: PRACTICAL TRAVELER: GETTING CASH ON THE ROAD
description: It is a problem every traveler faces: How to get cash away from home. True, it is possible while on the road to have money wired from one's bank account or - if a merchant is amenable - to cash a personal check, but such services are generally available during business hours only. And although the number of hotels, restaurants and airlines honoring credit cards increases every day, merchants such as taxi drivers and launderers will probably never take plastic. If only for emergencies, travelers need a way to obtain cash day or night.

title: CITY OPERA: NEW CAST IN 'THE MAGIC FLUTE'
description: "The Magic Flute" is back at City Opera, on the whole a livelier, subtler show with its new cast Friday than it had been in the summer, and mostly thanks to a more involving pair of singers in the lovers' roles.

title: Oklahoma Is Upset By Kansas, 28-11
description: Dodge Schwartzburg made four field goals and Wayne Ziegler scored on a 63-yard interception return to give Kansas a 28-11 upset victory over Oklahoma (5-1-1) today. The victory over Oklahoma was the first by Kansas since 1975 and the first in Lawrence since 1964.

title: SENATE CONTEST IN QUEENS IS BATTLE OF YOUTH AND AGE
description: State Senator Martin J. Knorr, a Queens Republican, talks about his opponent's ''lack of experience.''

title: IN 1985, NO NEED TO FEAR THE BRACKET CREEP
description: During Congress's debate over the 1981 tax law, advocates of indexing - adjusting the income tax tables to account for inflation - argued that it would protect taxpayers' spending power by preventing their being lifted into higher tax brackets by inflation. After enactment, President Reagan became one of indexing's most vocal boosters; Walter F. Mondale says he is ''committed to the principle,'' with qualifications.

title: Louise Mauro Is Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Frank A. Mauro of Lynbrook, L.I., have made known the engagement of their daughter Louise Anne Mauro to David Michael Panek, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Panek of Rome, N.Y. Miss Mauro, a fiduciary accountant with the New York law firm of Seward & Kissel, graduated from Russell Sage College. Her fiance, who received B.A. and M.B.A. degrees from St. John's University, is an accountant with Peat, Marwick, Mitchell & Co. in Jericho, L.I.

title: LINCOLN CAPUTRES DIVISION
description: Clinging to a 1-point lead with two minutes left and the Brooklyn A championship at stake, Lincoln scored two quick touchdowns and defeated visiting South Shore, 21-6.

title: Allyson Dale Has Nuptials
description: The marriage of Allyson Ann Dale, a second vice president in the aerospace division of the Chase Manhattan Bank, to Earl A. Samson 3d, a second vice president in Chase's petroleum division, took place yesterday at the Reformed Church of Bronxville, N.Y. The Rev. Robert W. Bedingfield performed the ceremony.

title:
GARDENING;
FERTILIZER GIVES A LIFT TO OLDER TREES
description: ALONG with all the other plants in our lawns and gardens, our shade and flowering trees will often benefit from fertilizer application.

title: HEAD OF FORD FOUNDATION SEES THREATS TO EQUALITY
description: The president of the Ford Foundation told an audience at Columbia University last week that the United States had come to a ''critical time in its march toward equality'' and that the country's response could set an example for the rest of the world.

title: STAR DUO MAY SEE ACTION
description: When the Jets face New England today at Foxboro, Mass., they may get another hint of what might have been and what could be for the remainder of this surprisingly upbeat season.

title: A 'MORNING MAN' SIGNS OFF THE RADIO
description: ON and off for the last 43 years, Don Russell has been Stamford's collective alarm clock, using his ingratiating manner to coax Stamfordites out of bed as the ''morning man'' for radio station WSTC from 6 to 10 A.M. Monday through Friday.

title: REAGAN MAKES BID FOR YOUTHS' VOTES
description: President Reagan appealed today for the votes of the nation's young people, declaring that a victory for Walter F. Mondale could ''send many of you from the graduation line to the unemployment line.''

title: SOUTH AFRICAN MAZE
description: Charles R. Larson's books include ''The Emergence of African Fiction'' and ''Arthur Dimmesdale,'' a novel. CIRCLES IN A FOREST

title: 31 Food Outlets Cited For Health Violations
description: The New York City Department of Health cited 31 food establishments last week for violating the health code.

title: LOVE AFTER 40
description: Robert W. Creamer is a writer and editor at Sports Illustrated. His latest book is ''Stengel: His Life and Times.'' THE CHEAT

title: DEVICE TO HELP PILOTS AVOID COLLISIONS IS READIED
description: The long-frustrated program to develop anticollision devices for airliners is soon to enter an important new phase when the first one is put into cockpit use.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: POCANTICO TREASURE

title:
BUSINESS FORUM;
LOOK BEYOND THE 'PITS' FOR DIRECTORS
description: Supreme Court Justice William O. Douglas once asserted that self-regulation yields ''ethical standards beyond those any law can establish.'' This article of faith has been put to the test by both the commodities and securities exchanges, which are self-regulating and therefore subject to minimal government oversight.

title: CORRECTION
description: A review on the Recordings page of the Arts and Leisure section today misstates the number of recordings of individual operas from Wagner's ''Ring'' available before 1959. There have been two, including Wilhelm Furtw"angler's recording of ''Die Walk"ure.''

title: THE GRAND OLD MAN OF GERMAN STEEL
description: Essen, West Germany

title: STAGE: HARTFORD TROUPE IN SCHNITZLER'S 'ANATOL'
description: Mark Lamos has opened his fourth season as artistic director of the Hartford Stage Company with a sumptuous production of Arthur Schnitzler's ''Anatol.'' Tempting hubris, Mr. Lamos himself plays the title role, and for those of us who think of him principally as an innovative director, the performance is entirely serendipitous.

title: STATEN ISLAND GETS A FIRE-RESCUE UNIT
description: FOR THE first time since 1905, when New York City extended its paid firefighting force to Staten Island, the borough has its own full-time fire-rescue company.

title: IRISH HAND L.S.U. FIRST DEFEAT, 30-22
description: PETER ALFANO

title: Mary E. Pritchard Is Wed to Matthew C. Dallett
description: Mary Elizabeth Pritchard, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Franklin Pritchard Jr. of Liberty, Mo., was married yesterday to Matthew Clarkson Dallett, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis James Dallett of Villanova, Pa. The Rev. Julian L. Houston of Liberty performed the ceremony in the First Congregational Church of Essex, Conn.

title: IN BRIEF: RECENT FILMS ON CASSETTES
description: TERMS OF ENDEARMENT

title: STUDY FINDS A LACK OF FUNDS FOR JERSEY WATER TREATMENT
description: Millions of dollars are needed annually by county and local governments in New Jersey to construct facilities to collect and treat waste water, according to study group.

title: Data Bank; October 28, 1984
TARNISH ON THE HALO
description: Don Cook , the author of ''De Gaulle,'' is the European diplomatic correspondent of The Los Angeles Times, based in Paris. PETAIN: HERO OR TRAITOR

title: WEST BANK PRIMER
description: David K. Shipler was chief of the Jerusalem bureau of The New York Times from 1979 to 1984 and is now writing a book on Israel. A STRANGER IN MY HOUSE

title: MIAMI ; A CONCEPT OF LIVING COMPLETE WITH ROOM SERVICE
description: BUILDING a condominium, according to Tibor Hollo, is like flying an airplane: ''Check your instruments, check your gas and check the weather before you take off.'' Even though the climate in the luxury condominium market has never been more turbulent, Mr. Hollo, a successful developer in Miami since 1956, is roaring down the runway with the larg est condominium ever built in that city - a $250 million project called the Venetia that will contain 810 apartments, 152 hotel suites and more than 2 million square feet of space.

title: Sarah J. Richards Planning to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. George J. Richards of Far Hills, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Sarah Jackson Richards to Johann Friedrich Ernst Thalheim 4th, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Hans G. Thalheim of Old Greenwich, Conn. The wedding is to take place in December.

title: DEBATES: THE PROS AND CONS
description: IN ONE of their last face-to-face meetings of the campaign, the two candidates for United States Senator from New Jersey - Bill Bradley of Denville, the Democratic incumbent, and his Republican opponent, Mary V. Mochary of Montclair - debated taxes, environmental concerns and economic and foreign policy, as well as who could do the best job for the state's residents.

title: MAKING THE CASE FOR SERIOUS TELEVISION VIEWING
description: Serious attention is due any medium that presents within the space of a few weeks such first-rate productions as Tennessee Williams's ''Cat on a Hot Tin Roof,'' with Jessica Lange; Virginia Woolf's ''To the Lighthouse,'' with Rosemary Harris; Martha Weinman Lear's ''Heartsounds,'' with Mary Tyler Moore and James Garner, and, beginning tonight at 9 on PBS, a mini-series dramatization of Anthony Trollope's ''Barchester Chronicles,'' with Donald Pleasence.

title: The Kennedys and Castro
description: To the Editor:

title: FUND HELPS STATE SYMPHONY RETURN TO CARNEGIE
description: WHEN the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra presents a free concert at Carnegie Hall next Saturday afternoon, the cost - about $40,000 - will be underwritten by the Frank and Lydia Bergen Foundation for the Musical Arts, a Morristown- based charitable and educational fund established last April to provide grants to New Jersey musicians and nonprofit music organizations.

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS FUEL NEW YORK AREA MARKETZ
description: BROKERS and lenders in the New York metropolitan area describe the last nine months as a ''window.'' In mortgage- banking jargon, a window is an opening in the market through which buyers and sellers alike are tempted to leap, a definition that includes the assumption that all windows eventually close, at least part way.

title: A 'MINORITY SEAT' IN THE ASSEMBLY IS CONTESTED
description: THE 18th Assembly District was created by Albany legislators to give minorities a chance to elect a representative to the State Assembly, and two years ago both parties nominated black women for the seat.

title: GRAPES RISE
description: More grapes and fewer apples are being harvested in New York State this fall. Meanwhile, the potato harvest is down on Long Island, but higher upstate.

title: New Fishing Boundaries Are Reported Observed
description: Although patrol boats from both nations were on hand to settle any disputes, the new boundary line separating United States and Canadian fishing grounds in the Gulf of Maine took effect this weekend without reported incident.

title: Fraternity Hazing Punished
description: The University of Texas branch of the fraternity Sigma Alpha Epsilon has been suspended for a year because of a hazing incident that injured a student, university officials say.

title: FOR SOME, LOW ROAD IS THE ONLY WAY TO GO

But this year, in a phenomenon seen in Senate races in several states, they have become prime exponents of the school of slash and gash.

title: A DRAMA TAKING WING
description: A GERMAN comedy drama that has been compared with the cult film ''Harold and Maude.'' An experimental English play that employs film techniques, beginning with past reality and winding up as a futuristic fantasy. Another English work on the threshhold of its 25th anniversary, a proven success for which the well- worn phrase ''a mystery wrapped inside an enigma'' could have been invented.

title: Nancy Fetscher a Bride

Brunetti, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Albromo Brunetti of South Hadley, Mass., were married yesterday. The Rev. Donald W. Sneller performed the ceremony at the Community United Methodist Church in Massapequa, L.I. The bridegroom's previous marriage ended in divore.

description: On a day of big plays, computer- boggling statistics and back-and- forth scoring, Doug Flutie again dominated bigger players by throwing three touchdown passes and running for another in Boston College's 35-23 victory over Rutgers.

Plattus, an assistant professor of architecture at Princeton University, has been announced by Dr. and Mrs. Robert W. Berliner of New Haven, parents of the bride-to-be. Her fiance is the son of Mr. and Mrs. James L. Plattus of Louisville, Ky.

description: ON THE FACE OR body, a dusting of powder gives a smooth finish to the skin, covers blemishes and flaws, and absorbs perspiration and excess skin oil.

title: Six East Germans Quit Bonn's Prague Embassy
description: Six East Germans, who were among some 150 refugees at the West Germany Embassy in Prague, have gone home without assurance they will be allowed to emigrate, a spokesman for the West German Government said today.

title: THE CITY IS AGLOW
description: They're taking over again. Honked at by automobiles, chased by dogs, overlooked amid the political haggling and the competition for world-class talent, and misunderstood by those who cannot imagine how anyone could be driven to run 26 miles 385 yards, the runners will re-take control of the streets beginning at 10:45 this morning. They will come from 50 states and 73 foreign countries to follow the long, broken blue line - from the Staten Island side of the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge through the four other boroughs to Central Park - that will direct the pulse of the city.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION ;
THE CITY VIS-A-VIS THE ISLAND
description: TWO Long Islanders' interesting impressions of my poor, bedeviled home, New York City, were recently printed on the Opinion Page (''A Visit to the City Is a Real Tonic'' and ''But the Island Is Still Home,'' Sept. 16). In the interests of fairness, I'd like to offer some thoughts on my great suburban neighbor, Long Island. I hope these reflections will be accepted as one person's attempts to explore a way of life that is dramatically different from his own in all sorts of ways.

title: UNFAIR AT ANY COST
description: My name was missing from the Forbes magazine list of America's 400 richest people. It made me want to cry.

description: Patricia Trebay Brennan, a lawyer with Lawrence B. Kurland Associates in West Chester, Pa., and Louis Joseph Sirico Jr., a professor of law at Villanova University, plan to be married Dec. 29.

title: CHILDHOOD LOSS SHAPES A DIRECTOR'S LIFE AND ART
description: Fifteen years ago, the Hungarian filmmaker Marta Meszaros wrote an autobiographical scenario about an orphaned young woman in postwar Hungary who resists being adopted by her aunt - and by the Stalinist dogmatism that the aunt incarnates. But the ravages of Stalinism proved too touchy a subject at the time and, according to the director, it took 15 years before she obtained the approval to make ''Diary for My Children'' (''Naplo Gyermekeimnek''). It opens Wednesday at the Lincoln Plaza.

description: A Federal judge has granted preliminary approval to a $1.2 million settlement in a job discrimination suit against Cargill Inc., a company spokesman confirmed today.

title: JAZZ
description: It has been more than a decade since Marian McPartland, who built her New York reputation during long engagements at the Hickory House and the Embers, has played at a basic, hardcore jazz club. Instead, she has usually been heard in the cabaret atmospheres of Michael's Pub, the Cafe Carlyle and the now-departed Cookery.

title: Alison Clarkson, SP
description: Mr. and Mrs. William M. E. Clarkson of Albany, Buffalo and North Creek, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Alison Hudnut Clarkson, to Oliver Ramsdell Goodenough, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Ward H. Goodenough of Wallingford, Pa. A Jan. 12 wedding is planned.

title: 6-1 JOHN JAY REMAINS ON TOP
description: Mike Williams, a senior wide receiver, caught two second-quarter touchdown passes from the junior quarterback Chris Salvaterra yesterday to lead John Jay of Cross River to a 30-0 victory over Somers.

description: The afternoon had begun with a clearly stated objective: New Dorp had earned one playoff spot, so there was one left with three Staten Island Division teams eligible for it.

title: Poll Finds Reagan Leads Rival in Massachusetts
description: President Reagan has a 12-point lead over Walter F. Mondale in Massachusetts, and Ray Shamie, the Republican candidate for the Senate, is edging closer to John Kerry, a Boston Globe poll shows.

title: Saul Levine Dies at 61; Nuclear Safety Expert
description: Saul Levine, an authority on nuclear safety, collapsed and died of a heart attack Oct. 18 while lecturing at Northwestern University in Evanston, Ill. He was 61 years old.

title: The Dispute Bowie Kuhn Left Behind
description: WHEN the club owners and players were on the verge of creating free agency in its present form, the players' representatives were concerned that Commissioner Bowie Kuhn might interfere with the rights of some players, using his authority under the grievance section of the basic agreement. The Players Association asked for and Kuhn reluctantly agreed to write a letter stating he would take no such action.

title: International
description: SUNDAY, OCTOBER 28, 1984 Poland's Interior Minister said an officer in his agency confessed to killing a pro-Solidarity priest who was kidnapped eight days ago, but the minister, Gen. Czeslaw Kiszczak, said the confession could not be confirmed. He identified the officer as Grzegorz Piotrowski, a captain in the Interior Ministry. The captain and two lieutenants identified as accomplices were formally charged yesterday in connection with the kidnapping of the Rev. Jerzy Popieluszko. (Page 1, Column 3.)

title: A DREAM SHAPED LIKE A DOME
description: THE American Heritage Dictionary defines a geodesic dome as ''a domed or vaulted structure of lightweight straight elements that form interlocking polygons.'' A more simple and visual definition is the home currently under construction in the wooded northern fringes of Sagaponack.

title: WHEN MONEY WOES GET OUT OF HAND
description: He was the 45-year-old president of a $1 billion West Coast manufacturing company, pulling down $400,000 a year. But he was spending it as fast as it came in, had only $400 in savings and owned not one share of stock in his own company. The year before, he had paid a bank $10,000 to draw up a financial plan for him, but he never got around to implementing the suggestions because he was too busy running his company.

title: THE JOB BOOM IS CARTER'S
description: Ronald Reagan has been campaigning on the American economic expansion, and he has found eager listeners in Europe as well as the United States. It is true, as President Reagan says, that the United States has recently created far more new employment than any other developed country. But the employment boom is hardly a product of Mr. Reagan's ''opportunity society.'' It is, if anything, Jimmy Carter's boom.

title: Q & A

In July 1983, I signed a contract to sell my apartment and in October 1983, I bought a new condominium. I moved out of my old apartment before the closing and the prospective buyer moved in. At the closing, I bought and ''simultaneously'' sold. Is the profit subject to capital gains tax? . . . J. S., Queens

description: WHEN Judy Simet learned last Christmas that she had breast cancer, her surgeon gave her two options: A mastectomy, in which her breast would be removed, or a lumpectomy, in which the tumor and a small amount of surrounding tissue would be excised.

title: New Olympic Chief Faces Controversy
description: The United States Olympic Committee's executive board today named a General Miller to replace a Colonel Miller as executive director. And he immediately stepped into a controversy in the form of a proposal to give some surplus funds from the Los Angeles Olympic Games to third-world countries that attended those Games.

title: FINANCING IS AVAILABLE IN A VARIETY OF FORMS
description: FOR the buyer who wants to finance the purchase of a condominium or cooperative, the issue is no longer the availability of financing. Lenders are willing. Just like the purchaser of any single- family house, the buyer of the condominium has to decide among various mortgage products - fixed- rate loans or an array of adjustable-rates. The cooperative buyer probably will have less choice among lenders and among types of loans, although this may change over time as the secondary mortgage market makes it as easy for lenders to resell co-op loans as they have their condominium loans.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;
MOTHER AND SON: A TUG-OF-WAR
description: MOTHER birds have it easy. Their instincts tell them when to push their young ones out of the nest, when they can fly solo. My instincts confuse me. One part of me is clinging tightly to the memory of how it used to be. Another part of me is fantasizing about shoving with all my might.

description: PUMPKINS ON PARADE

title: SACHEM STREAK ENDED
description: Sachem, which had won 15 straight games dating to 1982, saw its streak snapped yesterday on its own field. West Islip, a 14-6 loser to last-place Northport last week, bounced back with a 6-0 upset victory over the Flaming Arrows. The loss was Sachem's first since a 10-0 playoff loss to West Islip two years ago, and it opened up the League I race that Sachem had seemingly wrapped up.

title: Manila Prelate in China
description: Jaime Cardinal Sin, the Roman Catholic Archbishop of Manila, arrived in China today and said he would visit relatives and discuss with officials the Chinese Catholic Church's 27-year-old split with the Vatican.

title: ANGLICAN SETS OFF A THEOLOGY STORM
description: A new theological storm brewed in the Church of England today after the new Bishop of Durham, Dr. David Jenkins, compared the Resurrection of Jesus to a ''conjuring trick with bones.''

title: ALTERNATIVE SPEAKERS DISPLAY THEIR MERITS
description: Omnidirectionalloudspeakers are such a small minority in the market that every new entry in the field invariably stirs interest. It is not only the merits of the particular new model that prompt discussion among the more avid audio fans; the whole underlying concept of omnidirectional sound spread is so controversial that a new speaker of this kind always rekindles dispute at the level of basic principles. It is as if each newcomer had to justify not merely its own existence but legitimize all its kin and ancestry. It is perceived as a deviant from the norm and plays to a largely skeptical audience.

title: ALCHOHOL ABUSE AND THE YOUNG
description: Although New York State's drinking age is 19, a survey released last week found that alcohol is still readily available to teen-agers and, in many cases, is consumed in alarming quantities. The report from the state's Division of Alcoholism and Alcohol Abuse said that more than 80 percent of the secondary school students surveyed had tried alcohol and more than half said they had been drunk at least once in the last year.

title: Mark Kac, 70, Mathemetician And College Professor, Dies
description: Dr. Mark Kac, a mathematician and college professor, died of cancer Friday at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles. He was 70 years old and lived in Los Angeles.

title: ART: PASCIN IN PARIS, PAINTER AND DRAFTSMAN
description: Julius Pincas was in his midteens when he left his home in Vidin, Bulgaria, for Vienna and then Munich, where he drew for the satirical magazine Simplicissimus. There is some disagreement over when exactly he changed Pincas to its anagram, but it was as Jules Pascin that he first became prominent in Paris, settling there in 1905 and, 25 years later, committing suicide at the age of 45.

title: TUTU ASSAILS U.S. ON PRETORIA TIES

The promise was for a well-balanced program of Mozart, Bartok and Mendelssohn featuring the Tokyo String Quartet, another string quartet made up of Y regulars and, finally, Hermann Baumann, the German virtuoso of the French horn.

title: CRIME

As the title suggests, it is about baseball, and Mr. Rosen knows his baseball. He is probably one of those types who can tell you who participated in the first- ever triple play, who had the most fouls in a season, who led the league in being hit by pitchers in 1904 and which left-handed pitcher who hit right-handed had the most broken shoelaces over a five-year period.

Depicted are dozens of knights in suits of armor. And all the robot-like, steel-wrapped figures look alike.

The guerrillas sabotaged electrical facilities, killing 12 soldiers in one pre-dawn attack. Gunmen in the capital assassinated a Salvadoran security guard employed at the United States Embassy.

title: TERRORISM ON THEIR MINDS

Last week, in the course of celebrating the anniversary with a state visit by President Francois Mitterrand to London, an uncordial moment testified both to the centuries of distrust between ''perfidious Albion'' and the ''frogs'' and to the unusual state of nervousness that terrorism has lately instilled in world leaders.

We are aware of the serious problems of black adolescents, so devastatingly portrayed in Claude Brown's article, but we are most concerned that the picture he paints runs the risk of reinforcing dangerous negative stereotypes.

ANTIQUES;
2,500 YEARS OF LIGHTING THE WAY
description: TIME and man's inventiveness have converged so speedily in the last 60 years that few whose memory does not go back before World War II can imagine country life without electricity. It is difficult to envision a time when ''early to bed and early to rise'' meant that daylight was necessary to work or read.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;
AFTERMATH TO THE SUMMER OF 1970: POLITICAL IDEALISM LIVES ON
description: TWO recent news stories have brought back to me a summer that has been fading from memory. One was a television story about a young stockbroker, Scott Higgins, who was heading a veterans' committee in New York City to raise funds for a Vietnam War memorial. The other was a newspaper article about Representative Ron Wyden, Democrat of Oregon, who had written an ''innocuous amendment'' to an ''obscure bill'' that ''would require the Department of Health and Human Services to study the best way to compare the cost and quality of health care and to make that research available to the public.'' In doing so, he incurred the opposition of the American Medical Association and the support of business, labor and consumer groups.

title: OPERA: VERDI'S 'ERNANI,'CHICAGO LYRIC COMPANY
description: It would be unfair to report on the Chicago Lyric Opera's ''Ernani,'' in which the company rather laid an egg Wednesday, without first noting that the 30th anniversary season under way here is, by most accounts, a flourishing one. Local opera watchers credit the new general manager, Ardis Krainik, with revitalizing the company artistically and financially, and there has been an impressive string of box-office successes under her stewardship.

title: IN SHORT
description: George Leonard's second novel is distinguished by its innovative plot and its power to evoke darkly ambivalent feelings. The hero, Mark Kessler, is a Long Island clammer, a loner in his mid-30's who has been disowned by his father, a successful plastic surgeon. After Kessler, in self-defense, kills a hunter who terrorizes birds on the marsh preserve, he finds that he is without remorse. Later, smitten by anomie and craving excitement, he begins killing for sport and his own curious sense of self-righteousness, taking five victims in all. As the bodies are discovered, a reward is offered and soon the police and a large group of bounty hunters arrive at Kessler's icebound retreat. With diving equipment and underwater weapons, Kessler descends to the topsy-turvy world beneath the ice of Great South Bay to make his last stand. His cunning and nature's inexorable process - a freezing wind and thin ice - defeat the bounty hunters and put them to rout. And then, by an act of will, Kessler seals his fate and decides who will get the bounty. Mr. Leonard's handling of the climax is superb; the imagery is sharp and brilliant; the writing is always economical and suspenseful. The major characters - Kessler, Ellen Smith, a girl of 14 whom he treats as a daughter, and her father, who is killed by Kessler for turning Ellen into a prostitute - are well- rounded and believable, and their behavior effortlessly and naturally propels the plot along its harrowing course. Mr. Leonard presents a vision of man as a natural hunter and killer, which is set against the novel's underlying theme of greed and retribution.

description: Walter F. Mondale's failure to attract broad support from political independents is blocking his efforts to overtake President Reagan in the homestretch of the political campaign, according to the latest New York Times/ CBS News Poll.

title: MAJOR NEWS ; HOW HIGH UP DID AQUINO'S MURDERERS GO?
description: The assassination of the Philippine opposition leader Benigno S. Aquino Jr. in August, 1983, was the result of a military plot, an investigative panel concluded last week. But the panel disagreed on how high up in the hierarchy the conspiracy went. The result was more tension and uncertainty surrounding the much-contested rule of President Ferdinand E. Marcos, an ally of the United States.

description: New Jersey's population is increasing at nearly twice the rate of the 1970's, according to the State Department of Labor.

title: Distilled Henry James
description: Can there be another book on Henry James for Leon Edel to write and two-finger type? The 77- year-old author of the James ''quintet'' says yes, now that ''Writing Lives,'' his doctrine of the New Biography, is completed. Was the subtitle ''Principia Biographica'' a reference to Bertrand Russell's ''Principia Mathematica''? ''I was thinking of Russell and the way the mathematicians set out their principles,'' Mr. Edel said by phone from Newfoundland, where he had traveled from his home in Honolulu to speak on the Canadian poet Edwin J. Pratt.

title: OTHER SIDE'S 'DIRTY WAR' A lot of Argentina's former military rulers stand suspected of participating in murder, torture and kidnapping during their ''dirty war'' against leftists in the 1970's. But recently, some critics of the centrist Government of President Raul Alfonsin have contended that all those who did wrong were not on the right. Mr. Alfonsin may be relieved of some of that pressure as a result of a Brazilian Court's decision last week to extradite Argentina's best known former guerrilla leader,
description: Mario Eduardo Ferminich . The decision is expected to result in the first prosecution of leftist political crimes since Argentina returned to a civilian Government last December. Mr. Ferminich, who led the Montonero rebel movement, is expected to be tried on kidnapping and murder charges.

title: Julia Fry Weds Beverly Landstreet 4th
description: At Grace Episcopal Church in New York yesterday Julia Nickerson Fry, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Morton Fry 2d of Wyomissing, Pa., and Watch Hill, R.I., was married to Beverly Walter Landstreet 4th, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Landstreet of Nashville. The Rev. Harold Elliott Barrett performed the ceremony.

title: SUNDAY SPORTS Football
description: Jets vs. New England Patriots, at Foxboro, Mass. Anchored by Darryl Haley, the offensive right tackle, the Patriots held Mark Gastineau without a sack when they beat the Jets, 28-21, in their first meeing, but Gastineau still leads the league in sacks, with 13 1/2.

title: CHINESE REFORMERS' TASK
description: The architects of China's latest revolution, economic reforms in the cities, are courageously attempting to deal with one of the nation's knottiest and most important problems, but they may not succeed because the freedoms they provide are too limited and because resistance from leaders who stand to lose from them is inevitable.

title: DIFFERENT 'FAMILIES'
description: After a slow start, the 15-month- old President's Commission on Organized Crime used its new powers last week to spotlight the little-publicized growth of Asian crime organizations in the United States.

title: THE PERENNIAL RANCH HOUSE IS REBORN AS CONDOMINIUM
description: TEN years ago, nearly all condominiums in New Jersey were uniform clusters of two- story town houses, usually finished in a colonial style with brick and clapboard and a grass-lined walkway.

title: FOR OXEN TEAM, SEASONAL LABOR
description: NOW that the fall schedule of agricultural fairs is drawing to an end, Bill and Fred are out to pasture, fattening themselves up for their winter work, pulling firewood and hauling Christmas trees.

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;
A NEED TO EXPLORE INTIMACY OF DEATH
description: WHEN my mother lost her father it was sad but not unexpected. He was 80 years old, had had that lingering kind of cancer that old men often get and there was plenty of time to prepare for his death.

title: THEATER: 'FIRST LADY' AT PROMENADE
description: After playing the road and making a cameo appearance at a White House reception this year, ''First Lady'' is at the Promenade Theater on Manhattan's Upper West Side. This modest little musical has nothing to do with the current political scene; its ''First Lady'' is the inimitable Eleanor Roosevelt.

title: A COMEDY MYSTERY COMING TO HARTMAN
description: WHAT are the important ingredients of ''Over My Dead Body''? A hanging noose. A bottle of pills. A pair of gloves. A sword stick. A gun. Some poison. And, don't forget, a gorilla suit.

title: ZIMMERLI SHOWING'EXOTIC' OBJECTS
description: SELECTION of decorative arts from the 1920's and 30's is on view through Nov. 26 at the Jane Voorhees Zimmerli Museum of Rutgers, the State University. This is the first time that the 42 objects from an anonymous New Jersey collection have been available for public viewing,

title: Carolyn White to Marry Philip Wallis
description: Mr. and Mrs. Samuel W. White Jr. of Tryon, N.C., have announced the engagement of their daughter Carolyn Day White to Philip Severn Wallis, a son of Mr. and Mrs. George R. Wallis of Bedford, N.Y. The wedding is planned for May.

title: TOUGHER POLICY AGAINST TERROR IS SEEN GAINING
description: White House and State Department officials said today that, despite continuing disputes, the United States was moving closer to the tough policy on terrorists advocated by Secretary of State George P. Shultz.

title: Sports of The Times ; Yank Man(ager) Bites Dog
description: In announcing that Yogi Berra

title: A NEW ROBUST ITALIAN IN DANBURY
description: THE influx of corporations to the Danbury area may be responsible for another influx as well - that of tempting new restaurants.

title: FRAUENHEIM LIFTS IMMACULATA
description: Mike Frauenheim ran for a touchdown and passed for two more and led Immaculata to a 34-6 victory over Roselle yesterday in Roselle.

title: WITH CONVERSION COMES HARD CHOICE FOR TENANTS
description: WHEN a rental building is converted to cooperative or condominium ownership, its tenants face the difficult decision of whether to buy their apartments. The obvious advantages - buying at a discount, enjoying instant appreciation in value and, in most parts of the country, avoiding the need to relocate - must be weighed against the cost of financing the investment and carrying a true share of the building's operating costs, a potentially expensive undertaking if the structure is not in good repair.

title: Watson's Predicament
description: A funny thing happened to Tom Watson in Japan this weekend. He captured the United States Professional Golf Association title as the top money-winner of the 1984 tour.

title: Arguing the Nobel Prize
description: To the Editor:

title: RECREATIONAL UNITS GAIN FOR FUN AND PROFIT
description: ON 95 acres of rolling countryside a few miles north of the picturesque Berkshire Mountain community of Stockbridge, Mass., three 80-year-old French Provincial farm structures are being converted into luxury condominiums less than a mile from the Boston Symphony Orchestra's summer home at Tanglewood.

title: FAILURE AT A PENNSYLVANIA REACTOR ESCAPED NOTICE
description: Federal inspectors examining the failure of an emergency shutdown system at a Pennsylvania reactor earlier this month have discovered that a similar failure occurred at the plant in June but escaped notice.

title: JOE MORRISON'S TEAM: 7-0 AND CLIMBING
description: BRIGHTLY lit Ferris wheels twirled against the peach-colored sky. In a building housing the South Carolina state fair's agricultural, commercial and fine arts displays, a straw vote on the best President of the 20th century showed Richard Nixon way ahead. Nearby, merchandise and sales in a booth featuring athletic paraphernalia were evenly divided between gear from the state's two major universities, Clemson and South Carolina.

title: MORE TOWNS TO AUDIT BUSINESSES
description: IN 1980, Windsor became the first town in Connecticut to undertake audits of its businesses,

title: Thornell Jones Is Wed To Jane Tillman Irving Jane Tillman Irving, a reporter for WCBS Radio, and Thornell Tobias Jones, a computer marketing specialist for the International Business Machines Corporation, were married yesterday. The Rev. William N. Poe, a Methodist minister, performed the ceremony at the Hudson River Chateau in Yonkers.
description: Dr. Dolores M. Franklin and Joycelyn Braaf attended the bride. Edward F. Jones was best man for his brother.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: A year ago students at Setauket's Ward Melville High School took a day off from classes to talk about an issue of growing concern to them - the nuclear arms race. The success of that discussion, which attracted several Government officials, has prompted this year's ''Moral Issues Day,'' scheduled for Friday. Dr. Lewis Thomas, University Professor at the State University at Stony Brook and author of such books as ''The Medusa and the Snail,'' will be the keynote speaker at the all-day symposium.

title: POETRY TURNED TO AFFECTING SONGS
description: Edward Schneider writes frequently about recorded music.

title: SOUTH AFRICA SENDS IN ARMY
description: South Africa's 22 million blacks may be ''on their way to freedom,'' as the Nobel Peace Prize winner, Bishop Desmond Tutu proclaims, but last week that destination still seemed out of sight. Cracking down after sabotage and rioting that have left more than 80 blacks dead, the white-dominated Government sent the army into three black townships near Johannesburg.

title: CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: Classic Clothing In Chappaqua At the Old Colony Shop in Chappaqua the larger portion is stocked with classic women's clothing and a smaller area is devoted to children's wear. Old Colony routinely offers discounts of a full 20 percent on preticketed hosiery, lingerie and leotards, and varying discounts of up to that amount on everything else, with seasonal clearances shifting the markdowns to as much as 70 percent. Women's sizes are 4 to 16 and to l8 for some pants or blouses, and special orders are accommodated.

title: MCGINLEY IS CITY HALL'S INTERNAL COP
description: Patrick W. McGinley, New York City's Investigation Commissioner, is rarely the life of the party. ''At social functions, people politely shy away from me,'' he said with a smile. ''When I go to a party, I have to bring somebody along. Otherwise, I wouldn't have anyone to talk to.''

title: GROWING TIES TO SCHOOLS SEEN AS AID TO BUSINESS AND YOUTH
description: Support from the private sector of the economy for the nation's public schools, in the form of volunteers rather than money, is increasing sharply as educator and businessman alike see a role for the corporate world in public education.

title: Article 042505 -- No Title
description: Officials of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, the world's largest Gothic cathedral, will begin an $80 million fund-raising campaign today to complete the 92-year-old edifice and endow its social and artistic programs.

title: SWEATING IT OUT IN AN ILLINOIS DISTRICT
description: With the Congressional elections only 10 days away, Ken Brock voiced a concern that worries dozens of Democratic candidates across the country: ''There are only so many ticket-splitters in the world.''

title: A 'MA RAINEY' QUARTET PLAYS ITS OWN SPECIAL MUSIC
description: They hadn't worked together before they met, slightly more than two years ago, in the bucolic surroundings of Waterford, Conn. There, at the Eugene O'Neill Theater Center, the four were chosen to play the musicians in ''Ma Rainey's Black Bottom,'' and there the quartet developed an almost immediate sense of ensemble.

title:
BOSTON ;
DESIGN THAT ACCOMODATES TRADITIONS OF A NEIGHBORHOOD
description: OVER the last 10 years, residents of the Half Crown area of Cambridge, Mass., Boston's nearby neighbor, have defeated a number of developers' efforts to introduce nonresidential projects into the community, including a plan backed by the Kennedy family to build the John F. Kennedy Library and Museum.

title: Cornell Triumphs
description: Tony Baker carried 24 times for 146 yards and one touchdown, and Frank Farace intercepted two Mike Caraviello passes to lead Cornell to a 13-10 victory today over Dartmouth.

title: CHANGES IN TERMS OF OFFICE AND GAMBLING ON BALLOT
description: Voters in New York State will decide next month whether lawmakers should be allowed to increase the terms of office for certain elected officials and raise prize and betting limits on games of chance run for charitable purposes.

title: ARTICLE ON DOWNING OF JET IS DISPUTED
description: An article in a recent issue of The Nation suggested that the United States probably tracked the flight path of a South Korean passenger airliner as it entered Soviet airspace last year, but failed to warn the pilot that he was off course before the plane was shot down, killing 269 passengers and crew members.

title: BALLOT BATTLE IN WASCO COUNTY
description: If Bhagwan Shree Rajneesh really hopes to use the voting rights of thousands of the nation's homeless to help his sect take over Oregon's Wasco County, as many old-time county residents suspect but his followers deny, he has lost some ground.

title: Dr. A. V. Granata, Dr. Claudia Dinan Are Wed at Yale
description: Dr. Claudia Dinan and Dr. Attilio V. Granata, both graduates of the Yale University School of Medicine, were married yesterday at St. Thomas More Roman Catholic Chapel at Yale. The Rev. Richard R. Russell, assisted by the Rev. Gerald P. Cohen, performed the ceremony.

title: LETTERS TO THE CONNECTICUT EDITOR
description: Medical Tests And Courtesy Within a day of reading ''Bedside Manner Still Counts'' (Sept. 30) about Dr. Howard M. Spiro, who teaches Humanities in Medicine at Yale, I talked with a woman who had just been treated very disagreeably by the local medical profession.

description: Lisa Levison, a daughter of William Levison Jr. of New York and Vera James Levison of Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y., was married yesterday to Barry D. Peters, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry L. Peters of Ambler, Pa. The Rev. Victor Gruhn, a Lutheran pastor, performed the ceremony at the Wayside Chapel in Prospectville, Pa.

title: EXCERPTS FROM SUMMATIONS
description: Following are excerpts from the summations offered by Senator Bill Bradley, Democrat of Denville, and his Republican opponent, Mary V. Mochary, former Mayor of Montclair, in their debate last Monday at The New York Times: BRADLEY: I think I've achieved a record of accomplishment for New Jersey (by) bringing more Federal dollars to our state, remaining sensitive and responsive to my constituents and trying to develop an agenda for the future.

title:
FOOD;
THE GREAT WHITE TRUFFLE QUEST
description: Paul Chutkow is a journalist based in Paris.

title: AN AMATEUR MARRIAGE
description: Steve Tesich's article was typical of the attitude many men have toward marriage. He may not ''work'' at his marriage, but I'll bet his wife does. In fact, whenever any man who has been married more than a year boasts of not ''working'' at it, it means his wife is putting in all the effort. SUZANNE HAILE

title: TAKING THE TRAIN AROUND TAIWAN
description: WALTER WAGER is a writer whose novel, ''Otto's Boy,'' is to be published by Macmillan next March.

description: Fuzzy Indicators

title: DANGER TO GRENADA STUDENTS IS STILL DEBATED
description: The morning after Prime Minister Maurice Bishop was killed and a Revolutionary Military Council took control of Grenada last year, the new leader, Gen. Hudson Austin, paid a visit to the head of the American medical school here, the chief official at the school, Dr. Geoffrey H. Bourne, recalled this week.

title: Sports of The Times; New League for Women
description: FOR three years, she spent thousands of hours in the gym, making behind-the-back or bounce passes, blind or lob passes, but like the sound of a tree falling unheard in the forest, her passes went ''unrecorded by history.'' This fall, Nancy Lieberman and other top professionals rejoined history in a modest six-team Women's American Basketball Association, based in Chicago, Columbus, Ohio; Norfolk, Va.; Dallas, Houston and Atlanta.

title: L
description: The marriage of Leslie Ellen Kivitz, an associate in the Washington law firm of Linowes & Blocher, to Dr. Andrew Seth Greenberg, a medical staff fellow at the National Institutes of Health in Bethesda, Md., took place yesterday at Old York Road Temple-Beth Am in Abington, Pa. Rabbi Harold B. Waintrup performed the ceremony.

title: T. J. Maier, Reporter, Weds Joyce McGurrin
description: Joyce Patricia McGurrin, a financial analyst with the General Foods Corporation in White Plains, and Thomas J. Maier, a reporter for Newsday in Melville, L.I., were married yesterday. The Rev. James Flynn, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Fordham University chapel.

title: UNBEATEN HOFSTRA WINS, 35-32
description: Tom McLaughlin threw five touchdown passes, including the game-winner of 13 yards to Emil Wohlgemuth with 1 minute 37 seconds to play to give undefeated Hofstra its eighth victory, a 35-32 decision over Albany State yesterday at Hofstra Stadium in Hempstead, L.I.

title: GIANTS CATCHER IN 30'S
description: Gus Mancuso, a former catcher who played on three pennant-winning New York Giant teams in the 1930's, died Friday at a hospital in Houston. He was 78 years old and since leaving baseball had been a newspaper columnist and beer distributor there.

title: HONORS IN MRS. ROOSEVELT'S TRADITION
description: FIFTEEN Long Island women active in community work on the South Shor are to be honored at a luncheon this week for service in what Assemblyman Arthur J. Kremer called 'the spirit of Eleanor Roosevelt.'

title:
MUSIC;
CONCERTS, UNUSUAL RECITALS AND A REUNION CROWD THE SCHEDULE
description: AS full as the Connecticut music calendar has been this month, it is about to become more bountiful still with the opening of at least six additional concert series this week, not to mention several unusual recitals and a benefit concert marking the first reunion in 10 years of the New Haven Symphony with its music director emeritus, Frank Brieff.

title: Laurel C. Murray Is Wed in Darien
description: Laurel Clare Murray, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John H. Murray of Kewanee, Ill., and Robert Wilmore Hubner Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Hubner of Darien, Conn., and Edgartown, Mass., were married yesterday. The Rev. Claude Peters, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Hubner home in Darien.

title: Mrs. Mondale Predicts Pollsters Will Be Wrong
description: Joan Mondale told hundreds of cheering supporters here Friday that pollsters would be proved wrong on Nov. 6.

title: MOVING THE STORY ALONG
description: A question for Richard Yates: After eight books - two short story collections and six novels, from his first, ''Revolutionary Road,'' to his latest, ''Young Hearts Crying'' - is it getting any easier?

title: THE C.P.I. COOPERATES
description: Last week's Consumer Price Index, the Government's most widely followed measure of inflation, amounted to another serving of good news for the Administration. The Labor Department reported that the index rose four-tenths of 1 percent last month and that in the 12 months through September the index rose 4.2 percent, a bit more inflation than in 1983 but a lot less than in 1980, when the yearly rate was 12.4 percent.

title: HARD TIMES FOR A SIGNIFICANT ORCHESTRA
description: When the history of 20th- century American culture is written, one orchestra will stand out above all others for its devotion and commitment to the music of our country and of our time. Since its first performance in 1937, the Louisville Orchestra has commissioned dozens of orchestral works, played first performances, and then recorded them. It was founded by Robert Whitney, who conducted it for many years; Lawrence Leighton Smith has recently been appointed music director.

title: DEADLINE SET FOR STATE BILL ON RECYCLING
description: STATE environmental and energy officials and an advisory group have been working on a statewide mandatory recycling measure that, in the next two to three years, could radically change the way New Jersey households and businesses dispose of their garbage.

title: Farrell's Runners Win After taking the title in the New York Catholic High Schools Athletic Association sectional championships yesterday at Van Cortlandt
description: Park in the Bronx, the Msgr. Farrell squad stood about with long faces.

title: PRINCETON MEETING TO HONOR NORMAN THOMAS, CLASS OF '05
description: Princeton University was never a hotbed of socialism, but it did produce one of America's most prominent socialists, the late Norman Thomas.

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: WITH the emphasis in business on computer use and high technology, State higher education officials had projected that an increasing number of adults would be returning to school part time for retraining. However, part-time enrollments has dropped unexpectedly this year in public two-year colleges where adults were previously seeking continuing education.

title: Newspaper Spurs Calls To Rockefeller Campaign
description: The campaign office of Gov. John D. Rockefeller 4th, who has spent more than $9 million in his bid for the Senate, was flooded with telephone calls after a newspaper urged supporters to seek their ''fair share'' by asking for cash.

title: A FRENCHMAN FREED
description: For a while it looked as if French television correspondent Jacques Abouchar was facing a grim future. He was detained by Soviet forces after he entered Afghanistan with a group of Afghan rebels last month, and was subsequently sentenced to 18 years in prison for espionage.

title: LETTES TO THE LONG ISLAND EDITOR
description: Support for Lilco Divestiture A bipartisan group of Long Island legislators, along with a growing number of local organizations and ratepayers, now support the ''Lilco Divestiture Program'' as the solution to the problems surrounding rising Lilco rates. It is important that readers who have been following your ongoing series of articles on the Lilco situation be aware of this proposal.

title: AMERICA'S BANKS IN CRISIS
description: Lester Thurow should be commended for detailing the operating transition currently facing the banking industry and the potential problems this could have for the American public.

WHAT'S NEW ON THE CIGARETTE FRONT;
CUTTING CONSUMPTION BY RAISING TAXES
description: Both the cigarette industry and the anti-smoking lobby - along with academic and government observers - agree that higher taxes could reduce cigarette consumption.

title: HIGH RATES SLOW SALES IN MANY MARKETS
description: -defined local demand continue to sell well, condominium sales have slackened considerably across the country since April, when increasing mortgage interest rates began to take their toll on all housing sales. The slowdown has caught developers in many parts of the country with a large unsold inventory, mostly of units in the $100,000-plus range.

title: T. F. List 2d Engaged To Cynthia Holtzman
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard E. Holtzman of New Canaan, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Cynthia Holtzman, to Thomas F. List 2d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas F. List of New York and Southampton, L.I. A February wedding is planned.

title: Solo Voyage Is No Cruise
description: One would think that sailing alone around the world would be enough of a task, but when Ty Techera headed out to sea last Thursday for the start of his 27,000-mile voyage, he had far more to think about.

description: Two of the few remaining cast-iron structures in Connecticut, both in New Haven, are being restored and partially converted into commercial condominium units.

description: BRUCE PORTER is director of journalism at Brooklyn College.

title: ERICK HAWKINS TRANSFORMS AMERICAN FOLK THEMES
description: The Erick Hawkins Dance Company's recent New York season was billed as Mr. Hawkins's 50th anniversary as a dancer. Unusually, but aptly, it laid considerable emphasis on the kind of American folk themes associated with Mr. Hawkins's beginnings as a choreographer.

description: CONSTRUCTION is finally under way on the $1.3 million State Veterans Cemetery in Middletown, a project conceived in the late 1960's and proposed to the General Assembly in 1971 by Governor O'Neill when he was a State Representative.

title: BABOON'S HEART IMPLANTED IN INFANT ON COAST
description: In a bold surgical effort that could have a wide impact on the treatment of failing hearts, a 15-day-old girl received a baboon's heart in a five-hour operation Friday and was reported ''doing fine'' yesterday at Loma Linda University Medical Center in California.
