title: WEST EUROPEANS RESTRUCTURE ARMS POLICY PANEL
description: Seven NATO allies, meeting here without the United States, announced plans today for enhancing a specific ''European identity'' in the areas of disarmament and weapons procurement policy.

title: BEST MANAGEMENT OFTEN IS DO-IT-YOURSELF
description: SMALL cooperatives, those with fewer than 25 or so member families, have long known that the members often can better and more economically manage their financial matters and maintenance chores. Now medium-sized and larger cooperatives as big as 600 apartments are increasingly foregoing professional management services and doing part or all of the job themselves.

title: MARCOS REJECTS REAGAN VIEW
description: President Ferdinand E. Marcos, responding to a comment last week by President Reagan, said today that there was no chance his Government would fall to a Communist insurgency - or, for that matter, to the moderate opposition.

description: Paul Kresh writes frequently about recordings of spoken word.

title: JUDGES GIVER FREER REIN IN CASE IN ARGENTINA
description: Nine members of former Argentine juntas accused of murder and torture will be tried under unusual legal procedures that will open the proceedings to the public and allow judges freer rein in ruling on evidence, the chief judge in the case says.

title: PARIS: AN ABUNDANCE OF ACCESSORIES
description: There was nothing subtle or low-key about the accessories at many of the spring and summer ready-to-wear collections presented here in the past week. They often overwhelmed the clothes. Only Yves Saint Laurent had the confidence to let his fashions speak for themselves. Other designers resorted to elaborate special effects, unwilling to send their models out on the runway unadorned for fear of losing their audience. Often the fear seemed justified.

title: Leslie L. Neumann Weds D. G. Stack, Fellow Artist
description: Leslie Lang Neumann, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur F. Neumann of Sharon, Conn., and Mount Pleasant, S.C., was married yesterday to Daniel Grant Stack, a son of Mary C. Stack of St. Petersburg, Fla., and the late Vincent Stack.

title: Layoffs Related to Strike At Mack Truck Increase
description: The number of strike-related layoffs at a Canadian plant of Mack Truck Inc. rose today to 446 as the contract dispute between the United Automobile Workers and the heavy truck company entered its seventh day. Contract negotiations continued into the night, however.

title: FOR MONDALE, TRYING HARDER IS THE ANTIDOTE TO GLOOMY NEWS
description: SANFRANCISCO AFTER a day of campaign stops that didn't end until late evening, an obviously tired Walter F. Mondale stood before an Urban League audience in Chicago on Tuesday night. With the Presidential race at last in its final stage, with polls showing him lagging at least 10 points behind President Reagan, the Democratic candidate set aside his standard campaign speech. Speaking quietly, even wistfully, he said, ''My enemy isn't Ronald Reagan. My enemy is apathy, despair and cynicism.'' Mr. Mondale then raised his voice. ''My enemy is to be found in that attitute that there's no way trying, there's no point in trying, you can't succeed, politicians are all bad, politicians never make any difference.

description: The Senate Intelligence Committees hopes to hold a hearing next week on the origins of a primer on guerrilla warfare developed by the Central Intelligence Agency for use by the Nicaraguan rebels, a committee aide said tonight.

description: Leslie H. Gelb is The Times's national security correspondent, based in Washington.

BUSINESS FORUM;

title: PENN DOWNS YALE FOR 4-0 IVY MARK
description: Coach Jerry Berndt of Pennsylvania took aside his quarterback, John McGeehan, just after the team completed its pregame breakfast at Weightman Hall this morning. He gave McGeehan the first three plays he planned to call in the game against Yale at Franklin Field. McGeehan smiled in surprise, and several hours later smiled more broadly after he had thrown a touchdown pass on the opening play in leading the Quakers to a 34-21 victory.

description: A key OPEC Oil Minister said tonight that a consensus was developing in the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries that only the richer members of the group would cut their production of oil to prop up sagging world oil prices.

title: SUBURBAN RENTALS
description: As cooperative and condominiums conversions and construction projects continue to dominate residential development in Westchester County, the stock of medium-priced rentals grows more and more scarce. David Bogdanoff, a Westchester developer, aims to ease the shortage a bit with his 90-unit rental project now under construction in Jefferson Valley, in the north part of the county just below the Putnam line.

description: The holiday season came early this year. On Wednesday night, Musica Sacra's Basically Bach Festival concluded with a performance of the ''Christmas Oratorio'' under the direction of Richard Westenburg.

description: Efforts to cool the heated oratory in the race for the United States Senate in Texas have quickly fallen apart, and the two candidates, Lloyd Doggett and Phil Gramm, have gone back to sniping at each other.

Tuesday, at Danny's school. Mary J. Layton, assistant postmaster general for public and employee communications, will be the principal speaker.

title: Man Found Hanged in Cell
description: A 26-year-old Ledyard man being held at the Montville Correctional Center was found hanged in his cell Friday morning, the state police said today. The man, James T. Burton, was awaiting trial on charges that included reckless endangerment and criminal mischief.

title: DOWNTOWN PARKING: SEEKING SOLUTIONS
description: DRIVERS seeking parking in many downtown areas confront tow-away zones that can change from one day to the next, parking lots replaced by office buildings, and only rare instances of legal spaces in front of their favorite stores. In many communities, only if motorists are willing to walk several blocks can they find places to park.

title: WEAKENED OPEC FIGHTS TO HOLD THE PRICE LINE
description: OPEC oil ministers did their best last week to persuade outsiders and each other that a general drop in oil prices could still be averted. Industry analysts were skeptical, however. Reflecting the downward pressure, Canada said it was cutting the price of light crude oil exported to the United States by $1.33 per barrel. And Mobil Oil Corporation contributed ''one more domino,'' as an expert described it. Mobil, a major factor in the market, said that in view of a pattern of discounting, it was cutting 75 cents from the price it pays at the refinery for much of its American domestic crude oil.

title: TRIALS ORDERED IN ATTACK ON POPE
description: Mehmet Ali Agca's culpability in the 1981 shooting of Pope John Paul II was clear from the start. Not so his sometimes contradictory later assertions that he had Bulgarian and Turkish accomplices, one of whom also shot the Pope. Last week, after a two-year investigation, an Italian investigating magistrate ruled that Mr. Agca's allegations were sufficiently cogent to warrant testing in court.

title: STADIUM PLAGUES BASEBALL'S GIANTS
description: A quarter-century after they abandoned Manhattan and the Polo Grounds, the baseball Giants may be destined to move out of San Francisco.

title: CHAMPAGNE TAKEN BY FOR CERTAIN DOC
description: The Champagne Stakes for 2-year- olds has been won in recent years by Seattle Slew, Alydar, Spectacular Bid and Devil's Bag. Now, it has also been won by For Certain Doc.

title: FOUNDRY CASTS FOR THE AGES
description: BUSINESS is usually brisk at the Renaissance Art Foundry in Bridgeport, one of a handful of casters in the country equipped to handle monumental sculptures as well as small items. The concern, in its 24-year history, has served innumerable sculptors of various esthetic stripes, casting their works or, as in the case of Henry Moore's ''King and Queen'' in the Hirshhorn Collection, restoring them.

title: LONG ILSANDERS ; HIS BOYHOOD LOVE OF SCIENCE PAYS OFF
description: At about 6 o'clock on a Thursday evening last month, 40- year-old John J. Dunn received a message at the Brookhaven National Laboratory in Upton, where he has worked for the past dozen years: Call the Department of Energy in Washington.

title: TALKING
description: BETTERMENTS

title: First Woman Takes Her Seat In the Parliament of Andorra
description: A 43- year-old owner of a television and radio shop was sworn in as the first female member of the Andorran General Council, or Parliament, in a ceremony at the city hall of the Pyrenees mountain principality.

title: Rangers Beat Nordiques, 5-2
description: Play after play, Glenn Hanlon squared himself to face the puck. By night's end his standup saves seemed routine, but at the start they startled his opponents and, almost certainly, propelled his teammates.

title: U.S. TO BEGIN TRIAL OF FORMER MAYOR
description: Michael J. Matthews, the former Mayor of Atlantic City, is to go on trial in Newark tomorrow on Federal charges of extorting bribes for favors and conspiring to use his office to benefit organized crime.

title: HOW TO RUN FROM THE PRESIDENCY
description: Bill Bradley, the candidate for re-election to the United States Senate, keeps bumping into Bill Bradley, the prospective Democratic candidate for President in 1988, as he makes his campaign rounds across New Jersey. Although he disavows any interest in the Presidency, as a candidate in his position must, Mr. Bradley constantly hears about the possibility from the public, from prominent party officials and even from his Republican opponent for the Senate, former Montclair Mayor Mary Mochary.

title: Kathleen Troia, Defense Aide, to Wed
description: Kathleen Troia, the principal Deputy Assistant Secretary of Defense for Public Affairs, and Alan Roberts McFarland Jr., a general partner in Lazard Fr eres & Company, New York, plan to be married this winter, her parents, Mr. and Mrs. A. J. Troia of Pewaukee, Wis., have announced.

title: 5-1 BELLEVILLE POSTS ANOTHER UPSET, 7-3
description: Steve Kimble's interception in the second period set up the only touchdown drive of the game and helped Belleville (5-1) score a 7-3 upset victory over Clifton yesterday in Clifton.

title: BEST SELLERS Oct. 28, 1984Fiction*1
description: 1 THE TALISMAN, by Stephen King and Peter Straub. (Viking, $18.95.) Two parallel worlds and a young boy who can travel between them. *2 111 THE FOURTH PROTOCOL, by Frederick Forsyth. (Viking, $17.95.) A London jewel robbery leads to plots and counterplots behind the Iron Curtain. *3

title: BUSH ASSAILS FOES ON ANTI-SEMITISM
description: In the Republican ticket's second overture to Jewish voters in two days, Vice President Bush today attacked the Democratic leadership for not adopting a plank in the party's platform condemning anti-Semitism.

title: AN AUTUMN RITE: LOOKING AT COLLEGES
description: AMONG the football players, leaf rakers, cheerleaders and shoppers seen around the county last weekend, there were two groups notably absent.

title: MORE TOWNS SEEK URBAN-RENEWAL AID
description: IN 1981, when the Windham Community Redevelopment Agency

title: THE HARTMAN PUTS A MYSTERY ON STAGE
description: WHAT are the important ingredients of ''Over My Dead Body?'' A noose. A bottle of pills. A pair of gloves. A sword. A gun. Some poison. And a gorilla suit.

title: BRAZIL OPPOSITION LEADS IN RACE FOR PRESIDENCY
description: Despite the vocal disapproval of Brazil's departing military Government, new defections from the governing party have confirmed the opposition nominee, Tancredo Neves, as the strong favorite to win the indirect presidential election next year.

title: INSIDE THE WORLD OF BIG-TIME FRED LEBOW
description: FRED LEBOW and his entourage

title: An 'Open Mind' On Willets Farmhouse
description: In the Long Island Journal on Sept. 30, there was an item stating that officials of the Village of North Hills ''have agreed not to demolish the old I. U. Willets farmhouse'' and that the trustees ''agreed to finance a feasibility study on rehabilitating the historic house.''

title: PACED BY CALABRIA, COLGATE WINS, 35-16
description: The Giants double-teamed Steve Calabria yesterday, which is probably what Columbia should have done with the Colgate quarterback.

title: Sri Lanka Extends Alert
description: The Sri Lanka Parliament endorsed a presidential order on Friday extending for another month a national state of emergency that was imposed in May 1983.

title: CHRISTY KAUFFMAN IS THE BRIDE OF ALAN J. VALENTINE
description: Christy Banks Kauffman, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Garth E. Kauffman of Salisbury, Conn., was married there yesterday to Alan Joseph Valentine, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William E. Valentine of Niagara Falls, N.Y. The Rev. Gary Lizardo of the Niagara Falls Christian Fellowship Church performed the ceremony at the Kauffman home.

title: A RALLYING POINT FOR ANIMAL RIGHTS
description: AT first glance, Agenda looks like a typical news magazine filled with movie listings, record reviews and ''life styles'' features.

title: FOUNDER OF A FASHION HOUSE
description: Jerry Silverman, who used his knowledge of the dress business and the needs of American women to create a successful fashion house, died of cancer Thursday at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 74 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: THE SOVIET FARM STILL PRODUCES SHORTAGES
description: MOSCOW AT a special meeting of the Central Committee last week, Konstantin U. Chernenko read out an impressive array of agricultural achievements. Output of milk has been growing by 7.4 million tons a year, of meat by 1.4 million tons, of eggs by 4.6 billion. Farmers have more televisions. The flow of people to the cities has slackened.

title: THE BEACHES AND BEYOND
description: To many travelers, a visit to the Caribbean goes beyond lying on golden sands under constant sunshine, splashing about in warm sea and alfresco dining. Each island, large or small, has an identity of its own and in most cases offers a great deal more than the beach life. Each one possesses special attractions, some of them obvious to most visitors, others - often off the beaten track - that are frequently bypassed and should be sought out. The Danish architecture of St. Croix, the old forts of Martinique, the bright plumage of Trinidad's birds absorb many visitors. Some vacationers are occupied by sailing and other sports, shopping and simple strolling in unfamiliar surroundings.

title:
DINING OUT;
A PLACE FOR SPECIAL OCCASIONS
description: FIVE years have passed since John Foy's Le Delice was reviewed in this space and given three stars, and so the time seemed right for an update. After several recent visits, it is encouraging news indeed that this Morris County restaurant has retained its successful three-star mix of graceful atmosphere, polished service and fine food.

title:
CHICAGO;
GRAND VIEWS AND AMENITIES ON A 45-FOOT SLICE OF LAKEFRONT
description: well, skinny. The 29-story building squeezed onto the last 45 feet of Lake Michigan frontage along Chicago's Gold Coast hardly looks brawny enough to be the premier development of the man who introduced condominium housing to the City of Big Shoulders.

title: LETTERS
description: THE FLUSHING Y

title:
CAMERA ;
ON THE ADVANCES IN FLASH PHOTOGRAPHY
description: George Schaub is a freelance photographer and writer.

title: Irradiating Food
description: The wide use of ionizing radiation to kill bugs in fruits and vegetables and to keep food from spoiling was proposed by the Federal Government in February. ''Irradiation,'' the Food and Drug Administration assured consumers, ''will not make the food radioactive and thus cannot expose the consumer to radiation.''

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title: NASSAU TO VOTE ON CHEAP POWER
description: FOR years, as Long Island electricity consumers watched their rates increase, upstate municipal utility users, under contracts signed decades ago with the Power Authority of the State of New York, have shared in cheap hydroelectric power coming from dams, reservoirs and generating plants on the Niagara and Saint Lawrence Rivers.

title: GEORGIA TROUNCES KENTUCKY BY 37-7
description: A day after hobbling into Commonwealth Stadium with the help of a cane, Kevin Butler made three field goals and four extra points today as Georgia trounced Kentucky, 37-7.

title: DAILY LIFE IN THE REICH
description: Sabina Lietzmann, New York correspondent for the Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung, is the author of a book in German about New York, ''The Magnificent Catastrophe.'' VICTIMS AND NEIGHBORS

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;
ON HIS OWN
description: OUR son just took the 8 o'clock from New Haven. It is not his first trip to New York City. When he was small we went as a family to see the Christmas windows. Then there was his first trip in without an adult. It was the summer of his junior year in high school. He and a friend boarded the train one hot morning, carrying a map of the city, money secure in several pockets. They returned to my waiting car at 6 P.M., each bearing records, T-shirts and a brand new air of independence.

title: Dr. Timothy Corey Weds Jean Elizabeth Hoysradt
description: Jean Elizabeth Hoysradt, a vice president of the First Boston Corporation in New York, and Dr. Timothy James Corey, a dermatologist in Ridgewood and Oakland, N.J., were married yesterday at the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest in New York. The Rev. Elliott Lindsley performed the ceremony.

title: GROWING JOB PROBLEM: FINDING PEOPLE TO WORK
description: There are help-wanted signs in the windows of shops and restaurants throughout this fast-growing Atlanta suburb, and the managers of a new shopping mall here have begun soliciting local churches in an effort to find workers.

title: HER VISIONS WERE OF THE HIGHEST ORDER
description: DEEP SONG

title: ARGUING THE NOBEL PRIZE
description: To the Editor:

title: Elionora van Tyen Wilking Is Engaged
description: Dr. and Mrs. Leo F. J. Wilking of New York and Nantucket, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elionora van Tyen Wilking, to John Walter Silbersack, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Roy Silbersack of Sands Point, L.I. The wedding is planned for June.

title: IN 'THE KILLING FIELDS,' A CAMBODIAN ACTOR RELIVES HIS NATION'S ORDEAL
description: During ''The Killing Fields'' - a film about friendship, separation and reunion set against the Khmer Rouge's genocidal revolution in Cambodia - the central character, a Khmer Rouge captive named Dith Pran, grows a small tomato plant. Its feeble fruit is part of survival amid rice gruel and endless labor. Then, as Dith Pran watches in impotence, a girl soldier of 12 or 14 rips the plant out of the earth.

title: JET TEAM VYING IN 'WAR'
description: TYNDALL AIR FORCE BASE, FLA.

title: GREENWICH ROLLS
description: Greenwich overcame a 21-6 fourth- quarter deficit yesterday to defeat Norwalk, which has not won a game, 25-21. The Cardinals (6-2) were led by Rusty Warren, a senior halfback, and Drew McFadden, a senior wide receiver, each scoring two touchdowns.

title: SHEDDING INHIBITIONS
description: JANE O'REILLY is the author of ''The Girl I Left Behind'' (Macmillan).

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: REPRESENTATIVE James J. Howard, Democrat of Spring Lake Heights, says that the state's Department of Environmental Protection has tried to violate the Federal Clean Water Act by proposing an ocean discharge permit for the Ciby-Geigy Corporation's Toms River plant without first knowing all the chemical pollutants in the waste water.

title: Elton John Concert Canceled at the Garden
description: Elton John, whose album ''Breaking Hearts'' is at the top of the rock charts, canceled a performance at Madison Square Garden Thursday 45 minutes after it was supposed to start.

title: BOOM HASN'T ENDED SHIPBUILDERS' TROUBLES
description: America builds lots of ships, but they're not the kind that carry newlyweds down to Bermuda or oranges up from Brazil. The vast majority are warships, very expensive single-customer items from a domestic industry that long ago priced itself out of the world's commercial market.

title: IS IT O.K. TO BE A LUDDITE?
description: As if being 1984 weren't enough, it's also the 25th anniversary this year of C. P. Snow's famous Rede Lecture, ''The Two Cultures and the Scientific Revolution,'' notable for its warning that intellectual life in the West was becoming increasingly polarized into ''literary'' and ''scientific'' factions, each doomed not to understand or appreciate the other. The lecture was originally meant to address such matters as curriculum reform in the age Thomas Pynchon's most recent book is ''Slow Learner.'' of Sputnik and the role of technology in the development of what would soon be known as the third world. But it was the two-culture formulation that got people's attention. In fact it kicked up an amazing row in its day. To some already simplified points, further reductions were made, provoking certain remarks, name-calling, even intemperate rejoinders, giving the whole affair, though attenuated by the mists of time, a distinctly cranky look.

title:
GARDENING;
FERTILIZER GIVES A LIFT TO OLDER TREES
description: ALONG with all the other plants in our lawns and gardens, our shade and flowering trees will often benefit from fertilizer application.

title: REDGRAVE SUIT CENTERING ON ART AND POLITICS
description: The trial of Vanessa Redgrave's lawsuit against the Boston Symphony Orchestra, which resumes Monday,has gone beyond a simple breach-of-contract case and turned into a battle between two artistic forces over the proper mix of art and politics.

title: LUXURY TOWN HOUSES AIMED AT THE WEALTHY EMPTY-NESTER
description: -room Spanish castle complete with turrets, towers, private chapel, formal gardens and pools is a $4 million development of 107 clustered town houses targeted for sale to a precise demographic niche that has emerged along Philadelphia's Main Line.

title: HALL AND OATES TOUR NEARS HOME
description: NEXT year, Daryl Hall says, he and John Oates might finally take some time off. But with 1985 already one- third scheduled, Mr. Oates responds to his singing partner's statement with a disbelieving frown.

title: 80 AMATEURS FULFILL DREAMS IN TIME-TRIAL AUTO RACING
description: Poised behind the wheel of a 1975 silver BMW, 24-year-old Clayton Aulbaugh adjusted his crash helmet, revved his engine and waited for the green flag to release from him a caged passion.

title: DANCE: NIKOLAIS/LOUIS
description: Choreographers and performers who once studied or performed with Alwin Nikolais and Murray Louis got together on Friday at the Nikolais/ Louis Dance Lab to pay tribute to their past. It was a nicely varied evening, and a revelatory one at that.

title: On Language; Banned Words
description: ''Fascist ,'' reported The Associated Press from London, ''joined the list of words that members may not call each other in the House of Commons. Following an acrimonious debate . . . Speaker Bernard Weatherill ruled that the word was taboo from now on.''

title: KEAN SIGNS BILL TO END BIAS IN STATE SALARIES
description: Governor Kean has signed legislation intended to eliminate pay discrimination against state workers who are women or members of minority groups.

title: IS 'THE GODS MUST BE CRAZY' ONLY A COMEDY?
description: W atching Jamie Uys's ''Gods Must Be Crazy,'' the hit South African comedy that is currently the longest running movie now in New York first-run, one might suspect that there were no such things as apartheid or the Immorality Act or even South Africa. To be perfectly correct, most of the film takes place not in South Africa but just to the north in Botswana, the independent republic where blacks and whites live on equal terms.

title: CORRECTION
description: An item in the Sept. 9 column about an alliance of corporations that has proposed a privately financed cleanup of the Lone Pine landfill in Freehold Township was incorrect. Exxon is not a member of that alliance.

WESTCHESTER OPINION;
WRONG NUMBER? GET EVEN
description: IT'S 6:30 A.M. You've had one sip of hot

title: C.I.A., TOO, MAY BE HURT IN NICARAGUA
description: The Central Intelligence Agency's three-year association with Nicaraguan rebels has turned into a nightmare for many officials at the agency. With indications last week that middle-level intelligence aides in Washington may have approved a C.I.A. manual instructing guerrillas in the ''neutralizing'' of Nicaraguan Government officials, the agency seemed precariously close to losing its bipartisan support in Congress. ''The handling of the manual, the conduct of the whole covert program against Nicaragua, raise very serious questions about the credibility and ability of the agency,'' said Senator Patrick J. Leahy, a Vermont Democrat and member of the Select Committee on Intelligence. ''The seriousness of this goes way beyond the question of the manual.''

title: DENG'S GOALS FOR CHINA:PRAGMATISM AND PROFITS
description: PEKING WITH his drab attire, diminutive stature and rasping Sichuanese peasant accent, Deng Xiaoping would not be a politician to shine in American-style television politics. Yet Mr. Deng, who turned 80 years old in August, has attracted world attention by his attempts to shift China's course without the violence and upheaval that have too often heralded change here.

title: NEW JERSEYANS
description: THE new president of the New Jersey Society of Architects, Eleanore Pettersen of Saddle River, says that, although the field is traditionally a male domain (of 1,200 members, no more than a dozen are women), she has no difficulty holding her own.

title: Marion Wood Marries R. E. Covey in Chicago
description: Marion Biddle Wood, a daughter of Mrs. Daggett Harvey of Chicago and Clement Biddle Wood Jr., of Water Mill, L.I., and Spetsai, Greece, was married yesterday in Chicago at the home of the bride's mother to Roger Ecard Covey by the Rev. Wilson Reed, an Episcopal priest. The bridegroom is a son of Cynthia Evans- Covey of Evanston, Ill., and Robert E. Covey of Chicago.

title: CHANGES FOR LEAGUE OF WOMEN VOTERS
description: JUST as Presidential candidates turn to the League of Women Voters when they need a moderator for their debates, so too do Westchester's candidates - yet despite the league's prestige and importance, changing times are reducing its membership and altering its makeup.

title: ELDERLY LEARN HOW THE STATE CAN HELP
description: CONNECTICUT residents aged 62 and older are entitled to free tuition at public colleges and universities and free passes to state parks. Those at least 65 years old can obtain free hunting and fishing licenses.

title: Arafat and Hussein Discuss Convening Palestine Council
description: Yasir Arafat, chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, left here on Friday after talks with King Hussein over the convening of the Palestine Liberation Council, the Palestinian parliament in exile.

description: Irwin Stern, who teaches Portuguese and Brazilian literature at Columbia University, is co- editor of the forthcoming ''Modern Iberian Literature.'' JUBIABA

description: The marriage of Nancy Gwen Ghriskey, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Williamson Ghriskey of Greenwich, Conn., to Daniel Baugh Brewster Jr., a son of Mr. Brewster and Carol Leiper Brewster, both of Baltimore, took place yesterday. The Rev. Richard Van Wely, assisted by the Rev. Harold Bassage, performed the ceremony at St. Barnabas Episcopal Church in Greenwich.

title: THE TRIAL OF WITCHES IN MT. HOLLY
description: THE Salem (Mass.) witch trials of 1692 comprise a famous and bloody chapter in American history. A good-deal more obscure - and a lot more harmless - was a witch trial that took place in Mount Holly, then a Burlington County village, in 1730.

title: ANNETTE BANKS AND LARRY S. CANDIDO ARE MARRIED
description: Annette Banks, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Alexander Reynolds of New York, was married yesterday to Larry Steven Candido, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Salvatore F. Candido of Pelham, N.Y. The Rev. William Roberts performed the ceremony at St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church in Manhattan.

title: THE JARGON OF CO-OPS AND CONDOMINIUMS
description: People entering the cooperative and condominium field for the first time are often puzzled by some of the terminology they encounter. To assist them, the following glossary was prepared by Richard Siegler, a partner in the firm of Stroock & Stroock & Lavan, where his practice includes cooperative and condominium law.

title: SYRACUSE TOPPLES ARMY
description: Mike Kmetz, a third-year sophomore quarterback for Syracuse who had never played a down of varsity college football, became an instant winner today when he was forced into the lineup after injuries felled the two leading quarterbacks, Don McPherson and then Todd Norley.

title:
ART;
WINNERS IN PARRISH BIENNIAL
description: THE Parrish Art Museum's 30th Juried Exhibition, reinstated on a biennial basis after artists and others protested its cancellation in 1982, is now on view in Southampton. As anticipated, the show has attracted as many entries as ever - nearly 600 this year, 77 of which were chosen by the three- person jury. The only hitch in the proceedings was a misunderstanding over the size requirement that caused several artists' entries to be disqualified.

description: Susan M. O'Leary, president of the Easthampton (Mass.) Concrete Company, and Timothy P. Mulhern a partner in the Springfield, Mass., law firm of Shatz, Schwartz & Fentin, were married yesterday.

title: JAPANESE WELCOMED OFF MONTAUK
description: WHEN Walt Whitman strode the docks of Long Island talking to the fishermen of over a century ago, he called it ''fish- shaped Paumanok,'' drawing on its ancient Indian name. Today, the Island remains linked to the sea and fishing and, though the methods of today's commercial, offshore fishermen haven't changed much since Whitman's day, recent developments in marketing and technology have been helping to transform the industry into a more modern and efficient business.

title: Devils Collapse And Lose to Flyers
description: The Devils were again outplayed in the final period tonight and lost, 4-2, to the Phiadelphia Flyers.

title: THE PRIME RATE DROPS AGAIN
description: For the second time in as many weeks, major banks cut their prime lending rates. But this time, they were able to agree on a level. Morgan Guaranty led the way by cutting its by rate half a point, to 12 percent. Bankers Trust, which had settled at a 12 1/4 percent rate in the last round of cuts, joined in at the 12 percent level, and other big banks quickly followed.

title: ATHLETES: OLDER BUT FITTER
description: Alex Ward is the editor of The New York Times Living section.

description: The marriage of Janis Eileen Jones, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore F. Jones of Carneys Point, N.J., to Donald Davis Wear Jr., a son of Mr. Wear of Harrisburg, Pa. and the late Mrs. Wear, took place yesterday at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church. The Rev. Carl Nelson performed the ceremony.

title: MARVIN D. McQUEEN
description: Marvin D. McQueen, president of Ackerman & McQueen, an Oklahoma advertising agency, was killed in a traffic accident Oct. 18 in his hometown of Superior, Wis. He was 70 years old.

title: DISCOVERING THE HEART OF MODERNISM
description: ''' Primitivism ' in 20th Century Art: Affinity of the Tribal and the Modern'' is an immensely important show. The relationship between modern and tribal art is so loaded that trying to sort it out means asking the most charged questions about 20th-century art and life. Whatever its weaknesses - which include a perspective on contemporary art that can not account for the glut of totemic imagery in recent painting and a renewed interest in direct carving - this is a show that leads into the heart of modernism and beyond, toward impulses and aspirations that may be shared by art in general.

title: A Talk With Helmut Schmidt
description: Helmut Schmidt claims that the Russians escaped responsibility for the crackdown in Poland because General Jaruzelski, who according to Mr. Schmidt doesn't really like the Russians, did what the Russians wanted, but out of a sense of patriotic duty - patriotic duty to Poland, that is (''A Talk With Helmut Schmidt,'' by Craig R. Whitney, Sept. 16). In effect, Mr. Schmidt comes off as an apologist for this ''I will be a milder hangman'' argument first disseminated by Polish and Soviet disinformation channels at the outset of martial law.

title: HISTORICAL CLOTHING, PLAIN AND FANCY
description: '' THE point that we like to make is that we hope to encourage other small museums to do what we've done. There can be just as important historical clothing found in a small museum as in a large museum, and it's important to encourage small museums to have a dress collection, because things are fast disappearing. It's very hard to find 18th-century clothing now, and soon it's going to be just as hard to find 19th-century clothing.''

title: GANDHI FOUNDATION
description: In 1836, Aaron Burr, one of the more prominent figures of the Revolutionary era, died in a Staten Island inn where Richmond Terrace and Richmond Avenue now meet.

Princeton Beaten by Harvard
description: The Harvard running game was better than the Princeton passing attack today as the Crimson edged the Tigers, 17-15, before 24,234 at Palmer Stadium.

title: NEW AND OLD MIX FOR THEATER SEASON
description: THE season's novelty prize might well go to the McCarter Theater in Princeton for having commissioned seven playwrights to create their versions of the seven deadly sins in an adaptation of ''Faustus in Hell'' by Nagle Jackson, the theater's artistic director.

title: SOLTI'S 1959 'RHEINGOLD' WEARS WELL IN ITS CD INCARNATION
description: There is something fitting, the closing of a circle, about London Records' re-release of the Georg Solti recording of Wagner's ''Ring des Nibelungen'' on compact disks. The new project begins, as does the ''Ring'' itself and as did this recording venture, with ''Das Rheingold'' (414 101-2, three CD's). The other three ''Ring'' operas will follow this winter, and the set is also being re-released on digitally remastered LP's.

title: MANAN CLASSIC ENDS IN TIE FOR TOP SPOT
description: The Grand Manan Fall Classic Tournament, held in North Head, on Grand Manan Island, in New Brunswick, Canada, ended in a tie for first place between the grandmasters Yasser Seirawan of Seattle and Anatoly Lein of Jersey City. Each scored 6 1/2-3 1/2 in the six- man, double round-robin invitational sponsored by the Marathon Inn.

title: THERE IS A DIFFERENT MOZART AT THE MET
description: Maybe it is always the best and worst of times. How else to account, in a period that is not likely to be remembered for its refined musical taste, for the phenomenal popularity of Mozart's music, which is inimical to all that is cheap, brutal and mindless? Why, to get down to specifics, should even those two unlikeliest of candidates for modern popularity, ''Idomeneo'' and ''La Clemenza di Tito,'' now find themselves in the repertory of the Metropolitan Opera for the first time in the company's 100-year history?

Roosevelt, Harry Truman, John F. Kennedy and Lyndon B. Johnson - a tradition of bipartisan consensus whose first political priority was a deep concern for national security.

He said the fire was reported shortly before 5 A.M., and it was brought under control an hour later.

description: At least 15 people were killed and 45 were wounded Friday in a gun and machete fight between truck drivers and peasants who blocked a highway in eastern Bolivia, Interior Minister Federico Alvarez Plata said today.

title: REAGAN FINDS REFRESHMENT IN A FOUNTAIN OF YOUTHFUL SUPPORT
description: WASHINGTON EACH well crafted stop in these final days of President Reagan's campaign for re-election invariably is laced with a salute by Mr. Reagan to the young people in the audience, a cozying up to joyous throngs who hardly seem to need all that much partisan prompting.

title: CORRECTION
description: A chart last Sunday depicting voter approval of President Reagan's handling of foreign policy, as measured by New York Times / CBS News Polls, misstated the September 1983 figures for men and women. Forty- five percent of men approved and 32 percent of women.

description: Leicia Sharon Osborne, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Barry Osborne of Chappaqua, N.Y., was married yesterday to Michael Anthony Milano, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John A. Milano of Sea Cliff, L.I. The Rev. Patrick Keleher performed the ceremony at St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Church in Bedford, N.Y.

title: 75 Pounds of Cocaine Seized As Police Arrest Man on L.I.
description: A major cocaine dealer in Nassau County has been arrested and 75 pounds of the drug, worth an estimated $15 million to $20 million on the streets, has been seized, the police said today.

description: Walter H. Taylor is a man of God in the world of Wall Street.

title: Quoting Mr. Mondale
description: Who says the Republican Party doesn't take Walter F. Mondale seriously? With only a week left in the campaign, the Republican National Committee has published a 202-page paperback of nothing but quotations from or about the Democratic candidate, none of them intended to endear him to voters.

title: TEACHER UNION RAISES CAMPAIGN AID FOR MONDALE AND OTHER DEMOCRATS
description: Four years after it watched a majority of its own members ignore its advice to support the re- election of President Carter, the National Education Association has substantially increased its activities in behalf of Walter F. Mondale and other candidates for local, state and national offices.

title: WITNESSES TESTIFY ABOUT MAFIA LIFE
description: The witness seemed calm and relaxed. He leaned forward and spoke in a soft voice as he described a violent world of organized crime and the final moments in the life of a man he said he had killed in a desperate struggle for survival.

title: FOR A LIMITED MISSILE DEFENSE
description: On June 10, 1984, a Minuteman missile with a dummy nuclear warhead was launched toward a target more than 4,000 miles away. Before it got there, the Army fired another missile that intercepted the Minuteman 100 miles above the Earth and spread a 15-foot- wide, cone-shaped steel mesh that snared the incoming missile like a huge, nuclear butterfly net. At a collision speed of more than 14,000 miles an hour, the impact smashed the warhead into harmless debris. We proved that a nuclear warhead can, in fact, be disintegrated in outer space - with no nuclear explosion and without even using conventional explosives.

title: Accounts
description: Keyword Office Technologies and the Paladin Software Corp. to Chiat/ Day, San Francisco.

title: Kirkpatrick's Guerrillas
description: Word has arrived from Latin America that several hundred rebels fighting to overthrow the Sandinista Government of Nicaragua have named themselves the Jeane Kirkpatrick Task Force. The men are members of the Nicaraguan Democratic Force, the largest guerrilla group, which has received millions in covert aid from the United States and words of praise from Mrs. Kirkpatrick, the chief United States delegate to the United Nations.

title: STAGE: BUDDY HOLLY REVUE
description: ''Innocents,'' an affectionate musical tribute to the rock- and-roll pioneer, Buddy Holly, is a failed attempt to capture the essence of an elusive musical personality. The 26-song revue, which is playing at Cafe La Mama, features a studio band that performs many hits by the Lubbock- born musician who ranks just behind Little Richard, Chuck Berry and Elvis Presley as a seminal 1950's rock-and-roller.

description: The chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority said yesterday that he would seek to set up a magnetic fare-card system in the city's subways over the next four years.

description: Although the Russians are not admitting it publicly, all signs point to one of their worst grain harvests since 1975. Their misfortune is increasing American hopes of selling them more corn and wheat.

title: WHERE ARE WE GOING?
description: Underneath the noise of the campaign there are real issues for the American future. I see three at least that may profoundly affect the kind of country we are: the place of religion in our politics, the role of law, the militarization of our culture.

title: A Manhasset Wedding For Eileen C. Bortner
description: Eileen Carol Bortner, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Allen Bortner of Albertson, L.I., was married yesterday to David Edman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Edman of Los Angeles. Rabbi Abner Bergman officiated at Temple Judea in Manhasset, L.I.

title: OPEC Never Was the Enemy
description: OPEC's chickens appear to be coming home to roost. According to common belief, greed caused the cartel to raise the price of oil tenfold in a decade, triggering two world recessions. The same conventional wisdom now assumes that the recessions and widespread conservation have sent OPEC into retreat, allowing consumers to look forward to a long period of stable, lower oil prices.

title: No Headline
description: MONDAY, OCTOBER 29, 1984 International A cut in oil production by all 13 members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries was recommended by the group's oil markets committee to prop up sagging prices. The key committee also urged the group to address some basic problems in its oil price structure. But the proposals, to be be considered in an emergency OPEC meeting in Geneva today, were dealt a setback when Nigeria refused to cut its oil production or raise its discounted price. (Page A1, Column 6.) An economic crisis in Israel has come to preoccupy the nation more than any immediate military threat for the first time since its founding in 1948. The crisis, economists say, arises not only from military burdens but also from the structure of Israel's political system, the economic restraints of Zionism, and years of living beyond the nation's means. (A1:2-3.)

title: Trawlers Fight It Out In a Gale Off Ireland
description: Four trawlers tried to ram each other and cut each other's nets in a raging storm off the Irish coast overnight, Irish maritime officials said today.

description: A buoyant Walter F. Mondale brushed aside public opinion polls today and said with a grin, ''We're going to surprise them.''

title: Suicides Won't Help Ill Aide, Indians Told

title: Carole Susan Ziffer Married to Michael B. Bieber

Rabbi Alan Kalinsky and Rabbi Lawrence Ziffer, a cousin of the bride, officiated.

title: DOCTORS SAY BABY WITH BABOON HEART IS DOING 'REMARKABLY WELL'

description: Ahmad Jamal's primary distinction as a jazz pianist has been in his use of dynamics and coloristic effects. He established this musical identity almost 30 years ago when, leading a trio that included the superb bassist, Israel Crosby, and the drummer Vernel Fournier, he made subtle and sometimes dramatic use of silence and of Mr. Crosby's exquisite touch on bass.

title: CORRECTION

title: RECITAL: CAMERON GRANT AND JAMES WINN, PIANISTS
description: Cameron Grant and James Winn, who together make up the duo-piano team of Grant and Winn, presented an audaciously unusual debut concert at Alice Tully Hall Thursday night. Eschewing the flashy, kaleidoscopically busy material that makes up most of the duo-piano repertory, Mr. Grant and Mr. Winn offered Brahms Third Symphony (in the composer's own transcription) and the New York premiere of Karlheinz Stockhausen's ''Mantra.''

title: Alfred Mayer, 81, Dies;Head of Overlook Press

title: CANADIAN PIPELINE AIDS WASH. STATE

It isn't easy to get to some of the places Cougar recruiters have gone in midwinter to find future players.

description: On draft day, last June 19, Eddie Wilkins appeared to be a sixth-round draft choice with little chance of making the Knicks' final roster.

Chittick has fired off an angry letter resigning her membership in the Republican Business Women of New York and saying she was ''outraged'' by the group's use of the initials E.R.A. to stand for ''Elect Reagan Again'' rather than the proposed Federal equal rights amendment to the Constitution.

description: To her coach, Terry Dixon was a fighter who spent the first seven years of her life confined to a hospital but went on to win two silver medals for wheelchair sprints in the International Games for the Disabled last June.

title: 'SHATTERED VOWS,' WITH BERTINELLI
description: Aided and abetted by the title, the ads for ''Shattered Vows,'' the NBC TV movie tonight at 9, hint at some scandalous doings between a nun and a priest. If your expectations lean toward the lurid, forget it. Based on Mary Gilligan Wong's biographical book ''Nun,'' Audrey Davis Levin's script tells the story of a young woman who enters a convent in the early 1960's and, following the subsequent ''opening of windows'' changes dictated by the Second Vatican Council, gradually begins to question her vocational calling. The treatment is occasionally naive, and no opportunity is missed to suggest ''will she or won't she'' guessing about the character's virginity, but sensationalism is for the most part avoided.

title: FEW SCHOOLS REDUCE FIRST-GRADE CLASSES TO SIZE CITY WANTS
description: A $12.3 million New York City effort to reduce the size of first- grade classes to an average of 25 pupils this fall has succeeded in only a handful of districts, according to teachers and administrators. Those districts that have met the goal, set in an agreement among Mayor Koch, the City Council, the Board of Estimate and the Board of Education, did so at the expense of other programs, their officials say. The financing, a result of last spring's negotiations over the city budget, has led to small reductions in first-grade class sizes throughout the city. But school officials acknowledge that they have not met their own goal of bringing first grades - where most children learn to read and often need individual attention - down to a district average of 25 students in each of the 32 community school districts. ''Reduced first-grade class size was something everybody agreed to,'' said Stanley Litow, an official of the Educational Priorities Panel, a civic group of parents and educational organizations. ''The reality is that though it got reduced, it didn't happen in the dramatic way everybody expected.'' He and other critics blamed top school officials, saying that the officials sent mixed signals to community school districts and handled budget negotiations last spring in an unsophisticated fashion. Schools Chancellor Nathan Quinones cited a number of factors, including lack of space for more classrooms in some districts and a larger number of first graders than expected.

title: Albert Nicolas Wed To Thelma L. Mann
description: Thelma Leah Mann was married yesterday at the home of her parents, Cantor and Mrs. David J. Mann of Valley Stream, L.I., to Albert Nicolas, a son of Mrs. Alexander Joseph Nicolas of Brooklyn and the late Mr. Nicolas. Rabbi Simon Resnikoff and the bride's father, the cantor at Temple Gates of Zion in Valley Stream, performed the ceremony.

title: QUESTION BOX
description: QUESTION: With his team down by 2 points and only a second left in the game, a pro basketball player is fouled and awarded two free throws. He misses the first one, but just after he lofts his second foul shot, one of his teammates lines up along the foul lane, leaps, snares the ball in the air and puts it into the basket before he touches the floor. Is the basket credited to the teammate, and if so, is it worth 2 points instead of 1, thereby tying the score?

title: U.S. MAY SEEK THRIFT UNIT CURBS
description: Worried that a new wave of failures of savings and loan institutions could exhaust the Government fund that insures their deposits, the chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board says the agency is likely to propose new limits on the growth of thrift units.

description: The author of trivia books who has filed a $300 million suit charging copyright infringement against makers of the Trivial Pursuit board game says he is investigating other games to see if his material has been used.

title: Economic Meeting in Cuba

President Fidel Castro will head the Cuban delegation at the three-day meeting, which opens on Monday and is the first of the group's annual meetings to be held outside of Europe.

title: Kicking for Research
description: It's known as a ''closet disease'' - one whose victims consider it too embarrassing to discuss - and that, according to those who are seeking a cure for the afflictions of ileitis and colitis, is too bad. Such an attitude, they say, helps sustain the ignorance that allows many cases of the chronic digestive diseases to go undetected and hinders the effort to find a cure.

title: TOOL ORDERS ABOVE LOW '83 MONTH
description: Orders for United States machine tools surged in September, with an increase of 83.7 percent from the depressed levels of September 1983.

title: A SHTETL CUTOUT BOOK TO BE PUBLISHED

A small-scale model of the shtetl, the small East European town inhabited largely by Yiddish- speaking Jews in the old days, will soon be at your fingertips, a past that can be recalled with a scissors.

title: CARDINALS' RALLY STOPS EAGLES, 34-14
