title: International Airway Profit
description: Scheduled international services of the world's airlines are expected to show a profit this year for the first time in six years, according to the International Air Transport Association.

title: Diane Spitz Is Married to Rabbi Mark R. Raphael
description: Diane Spitz, a daughter of Theodore R. Spitz of Franklin, Mich., and North Miami Beach and the late Evelyn Kahn Spitz, was married yesterday to Rabbi Mark Ross Raphael, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Raphael of Woodbury, L.I., and Highland Beach, Fla. Rabbi Melvin Kieffer and Cantor Marvin Savitt performed the ceremony at Congregation Tikvoh Chadoshoh in Bloomfield, Conn.

title: REAL SUPERTERRORISTS WOULD PREFER SUITCASE NUKES
description: To the Editor:

title: Financial Corp. Facing Hurdles
description: LOS ANGELES

title: Marriott to Sell Essex House
description: The Marriott Corporation has agreed to sell the luxury Essex House hotel at 160 Central Park South, near Fifth Avenue, to Nikko Hotels International, the hotel division of Japan Air Lines.

title: Reward Offered in Killing
description: Carl Dobrzynski and his wife, the parents of 27-year-old Ray Dobrzynski, a biologist killed in violence that followed the victory of the Detroit Tigers in the World Series, are offering a $2,000 reward for the killer's arrest.

title: Mexico Envoy Disavows Endorsement of Helms
description: The United States Ambassador to Mexico, John Gavin, said today that he had not authorized the use of his name in an endorsement of Senator Jesse Helms, Republican of North Carolina.

title: Five Killed Off California As Boat Strikes a Buoy
description: A speeding motorboat carrying nine people slammed into an unlighted buoy and broke apart early today in darkened Anaheim Bay, killing five people aboard and injuring the other four, the authorities said.

title: Your Game in Lights
description: When business is slow, there's nothing like a little government contract to help a company over hard times, which is why officials of the Musco Mobile Lighting Company of Oskaloosa, Iowa, are looking forward to the Army-Air Force football game at West Point, N.Y., next Saturday night.

title: INDIA'S LOWEST OF THE LOW START TO CRY 'ENOUGH!'
description: The 50 or so people who live in one small cluster of mud-walled houses in this village in the heart of India's lush Ganges plain call themselves simply, in Hindi, ''Hum log'' - ''We people.''

title: Ben Aronov Plays Solo Jazz Piano
description: Ben Aronov, a pianist who is well established as a sideman in jazz groups and as an accompanist to singers, launched himself as a soloist last week at Hanratty's, Second Avenue near 92d Street. Mr. Aronov has played solo gigs in the past but, as he points out, the requirements were simply for background music.

title: THE CALENDAR
description: Monday

title: Guatemala College Dean Slain on Way to Funeral
description: Attackers with machine guns killed a university dean on his way to the funeral of a slain colleague Saturday, bringing the number of assassinations in the last three days in Guatemala City to at least five, the police said today.

title: DANCE: 'SHEER ROMANCE,' AMERICAN BALLROOM THEATER
description: Some of the smoothest dancing one could ever hope to see was on view Thursday night when the American Ballroom Theater presented ''Sheer Romance'' at the Bessie Sch"onberg Theater. What made ''Sheer Romance'' unusual was the fact that all the items in this revue choreographed by John Roudis were based upon ballroom dance styles.

title: Harry Eisenberg of I.R.S. Marries Gail Joy Steinberg
description: At the Kingsway Jewish Center in Brooklyn yesterday, Gail Joy Steinberg, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Lawrence Steinberg of New York, was married to Harry Eisenberg, the son of Rabbi and Mrs. Emanuel Eisenberg of Lake Worth, Fla.

title: MORRIS GETS GIANTS MOVING ON GROUND
description: The Giants gained 424 yards today against the defending champions of the National Football Conference, the Washington Redskins, 294 by passing and 130 by rushing. It was the rushing figure that was bedazzling, because the Giants, by fact and opinion, had been so feeble at the basic, the running game.

title: Rah-Rahs For the Political Teams
description: Political cheerleading grows.

title: ABOUT BOSTON
description: The ''Mammoth.'' That is what The Boston Globe is called in a new novel about Boston politics, ''A Saving Grace,'' by Ken Hartnett, a crusty former reporter and editor for both The Globe and The Boston Herald.

title: Tabou Combo Appears At Sounds of Brazil
description: Tabou Combo, Haiti's leading dance band, came to Manhattan Wednesday, leaving Brooklyn's Caribbean community for its first engagement at Sounds of Brazil.

title: MANILA OFFICERS SUPPORT CHIEF MANILA, Oct. 28 (Reuters) - About 60 senior Philippine military officers, including the heads of the army, navy and air force, today declared ''unwavering loyalty and support'' for Gen. Fabian C. Ver, the Chief of Staff of the armed forces, who has been linked to a plot in the killing of the opposition leader, Benigno S. Aquino Jr.
description: In an advertisement in the Manila newspaper Bulletin Today, the Philippines' biggest English-language daily, the officers said: ''We are deeply saddened to learn that Ver, who is unquestionably an advocate of the rule of law, is implicated. We are morally convinced that he is innocent of the dastardly crime attributed to him.

title: On the Aisle With Pablo Picasso
description: Picasso the playwright?

title: LOW INFLATION STIRRING OPTIMISM
description: For nearly two decades, rapid economic recoveries generated higher inflation. But Government figures on growth and inflation in recent days confirm that the nation's economy has passed through the fast-growth phase of another strong recovery, and this time inflation barely budged.

title: SAMUELS IS EULOGIZED AS MAN OF COMPASSION
description: Howard J. Samuels, a self-made millionaire whose dream of becoming governor of New York was never fulfilled, was remembered by several of the nation's leading political figures yesterday as a friend and a man of compassion.

title: MUSIC: AT MERKIN HALL, PAGANINI'S 'CAMPANELLA'
description: Concerts Plus held another of its popular evenings of music and talk at the Merkin Concert Hall Thursday night. First, we heard - and heard about - two versions of Paganini's painfully familiar ''La Campanella.''

title: A REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: THE JARGON OF CBS TRIAL
description: A. FARBER

title: BUSINESS DIGEST MONDAY, OCTOBER 29, 1984
description: International

title: Town Celebrates
description: News of Orlando Pizzolato's victory in the New York City Marathon today stirred a wave of wild celebrations in his hometown in northern Italy.

title: THE REGION;
description: A 20-year-old Long Island woman who was partly paralyzed two years ago when a nail was fired through a wall and pierced her brain has won at least $5 million in a settlement with 15 defendants.

title: ANTI-SEMITISM STAND CLARIFIED
description: Walter F. Mondale's press secretary said yesterday that the Democratic Party had strongly condemned anti- Semitism in a policy statement after the Democratic National Convention, but not in the party's platform.

title: ITALIAN OUTLASTS MARATHON FIELD
description: Overcoming the most difficult conditions in any of the 15 New York City Marathons, little-known Orlando Pizzolato of Italy ran to victory yesterday after pain in his stomach and legs forced him to stop eight times.

title: FAUST LOVES THE JOB, BUT HOW LONG CAN HE KEEP IT?
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind.As lunchtime approached, Gerry Faust dug hungrily into a bag of popcorn, stuffing handfuls into his mouth the way a boy does when he thinks his older brother is about to ask for some. What he did not finish, Faust tucked into a desk draw with his important papers, a bit of housekeeping Felix Unger would understand.

title: TEACHERS AIM HIGH AT SPACE CAMP
description: Forty teachers from around the United States spent this weekend experiencing weightlessness and flying a mock shuttle mission at a space camp here, hoping the experience would give them an edge when the first private citizen to fly in space is chosen by the space agency.

title: C.I.A. MANUAL IS LINKED TO VIETNAM WAR GUIDE
description: A manual on guerrilla warfare prepared for Nicaraguan rebels by the Central Intelligence Agency was drawn from material used to train United States Special Forces troops during the Vietnam War, Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan said today.

title: Pascale Ogier, Actress, 24;Won Venice Festival Award
description: Pascale Ogier, a French actress who won the best actress award at the Venice Film Festival this year, died Thursday night, her agent said Friday.

title: THEATER: 'FEATHERTOP,' AT THE WPA
description: Although ''Feathertop,'' the new musical at the WPA, is lifeless, it's not unprofessional. Bruce Peyton, the librettist, and Skip Kennon, the composer-lyricist, clearly know the textbook rules and techniques required to write a conventional book musical. What ''Feathertop'' demonstrates is how useless such craft can be when it's applied to a project that has no compelling reason to exist.

title: Kenyon & Eckhardt To Acquire Cinamon
description: Kenyon & Eckhardt, a subsidiary of Lorimar Productions, announced Friday that it had signed a letter of intent to acquire Cinamon Associates, a 14- year-old direct marketing agency in Brookline, Mass.

title: The Candidates Today
description: Walter F. Mondale takes his Presidential campaign to

title: A CHINESE 'ANNA CHRISTIE' IN PEKING
description: The theater curtain rises to reveal a wine shop in old Shanghai, where a sea captain from Fujian is reunited with his daughter from the Manchurian city of Harbin, only to have their bliss interrupted by a shipwrecked Cantonese sailor.

title: Wall St. Veteran Moves Up
description: The offices of Albert Frank-

title: Nicaragua Convention Broken Up by Youths
description: Chanting youths this evening broke up a convention at which members of the Democratic Conservative Party appeared ready to vote to quit the electoral campaign.

title: Walter Woolf King Is Dead;Leading Actor and Singer
description: Walter Woolf King, a leading actor and singer on the stage and screen from the 1920's to the 1950's, died Wednesday of a heart attack in Beverly Hills, Calif. He was 88 years old.

title: Mochary Is Due Back By Wednesday
description: Mary Mochary is expected to return to New Jersey from California tomorrow or Wednesday to resume her Republican challenge to Senator Bill Bradley, a campaign aide said yesterday.

title: Addendum
description: * Time magazine increasing its advertising rates 6.7 percent with the Jan. 7 issue.

title: STATEGIES OF SELLING 'SOLDIER'S'
description: ''A Soldier's Story'' is, in the jargon of the movie industry, ''a tough sell.'' The problem is not only that the movie is about black characters. Worse, it is a serious movie about black characters. Yet, so far, ''A Soldier's Story'' is holding its own nicely at the box office.

title: 2 Nepalese Mountaineers Die Looking for Body on Everest
description: Two experienced Nepalese climbers died on Mount Everest trying to recover the body of a German who died descending the 29,028-foot peak in 1979, the Nepalese Tourism Ministry said today.

title: ISRAEL AFFIRMS STAND ON TALKS
description: The Israeli Cabinet voted today to pursue negotiations through the United States for a security arrangement in southern Lebanon that would enable Israel to withdraw its forces.

title: ARAB DIES AS JERUSALEM BUS IS ATTACKED 3 JEWS HELD FOR QUESTIONS
description: Unidentifed terrorists fired an antitank rocket at a crowded Arab bus in central Jerusalem today, killing one Arab youth and wounding 10 other passengers.

title: HALLOWEEN: A CHANCE TO SCARE
description: Anne Grasso was shopping for

title: 30 YEARS OF PIONEERING IN SEX THERAPY
description: This is a big anniversary year for one of the most celebrated and controversial research teams in modern medical history: Dr. William H. Masters and Virginia E. Johnson, who are being feted in St. Louis on Thursday.

title: JANE N. BANCROFT
description: Jane Northrop Bancroft, who participated in charitable activities for many years, died of lung cancer yesterday at Sharon (Conn.) Hospital. She was 70 years old and lived in Millbrook, N.Y.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Oct. 29, 1984: MONDAY Airborne FreightGeorgia-PacificArmstrong World IndKentucky UtilsBrown & SharpeKoppers CoBurndy CorpUnion CampFoster Wheeler

title: DECENTRALIZED DECISION-MAKING PLAGUES YOGOSLAV ECONOMY
description: Here, in the capital of Yugoslavia's Macedonia Republic, as in the rest of this mosaic of a country, the watchwords these days are restructuring the economy and getting rid of its chronic losers.

title: Reagan Leads Mondale In Three Opinion Polls
description: President Reagan shows a decisive lead over Walter F. Mondale in three polls made public over the weekend.

title: Husband Turns Up Alive After Faking Death in '70
description: When John K. Tidswell vanished during a sailing trip 14 years ago, Kathleen Tidswell thought she had become a widow.

title: BRITISH MINE UNION SAYS IT TALKED WITH QADDAFI
description: Arthur Scargill, head of the National Union of Mineworkers, said today that union officials had met with Libyan Government officials to discuss the eight-month-old coal strike.

title: October Life, and Death
description: October has 19 fine days, according to an old saying - a better than average month, in other words, as this one has been. Hickory, beech and butternuts are on the ground, and geese are flying over us now, often at night, yelping softly to each other like heavenly hounds. Male crickets fiddle with their wings (the right held over the left as the fiddler's bow) to produce the cheeps and chirps the female hears with ears located close to her front knees. It's an appropriately cheerful sound, though soon after their mating season a frost will kill them both.

title: WAITZ AND PIZZOLATO TAKE TOP PRIZES IN MARATHON
description: While the stifling heat and humidity of an unseasonably warm autumn day reduced the men's competition in the New York City Marathon to a battle of attrition yesterday, Grete Waitz, the overwhelming favorite among women, had other problems with which to contend.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on the Style page on Sept. 8 about New York State's new-car ''lemon law'' misidentified the manager of the owner-relations and service-development division of the Ford Motor Company. He is Ned A. Smith.

title: Another Judicial Election Farce
description: One of New York's hardiest myths is that electing judges serves the popular will. It serves the selfish ends of the party leaders who decide which minions go on the ballot.

title: CROSSING THE LEBOW LINE WITH A $1,000 KICK
description: Deirdre O'Farrelly was not thinking about money as she turned into the park. She had no idea whether she was near the cutoff point between a $1,000 prize and no prize at all for finishing yesterday's New York City Marathon - the notorious Lebow Line between 20th and 21st places for the women.

title: POLITICS SETS FERRARO'S NEIGHBORS AT ODDS
description: When someone tore down his Geraldine Ferraro banner and ripped some of the molding off the outside of his card shop in Forest Hills, Queens, Paul Klotz defiantly hung the banner inside and taped two anonymous letters next to a Halloween window display.

title: HOUSING OFFICIAL SAYS HE MIGHT QUIT CABINET
description: Samuel R. Pierce says he might not accept a second term as Secretary of Housing and Urban Development for personal reasons.

title: SAVE FOR VIETNAM WAR, MONDALE BACKS RECORD
description: In 12 years as Senator and four as Vice President, Walter F. Mondale compiled a record that forms the basis for his Presidential candidacy.

title: THOUSANDS OF POLES AT MASS FOR PRIEST
description: A crowd estimated by church officials at 50,000 people attended an outdoor mass today for a pro-Solidarity priest who the Interior Ministry said was kidnapped and possibly killed by three ministry officers.

title: TO REGULATE, TO DEREGULATEOR, NOW, TO REREGULATE
description: In the 1970's, when many of the nation's major industries appeared to be on the skids, they attacked Government regulation as a main cause of their ills and a major impediment to recovery.

title: J.J. Walter Will Head U.S. Preservation Trust
description: J. Jackson Walter was named Saturday as president of the National Trust for Historic Preservation, a national nonprofit private organization chartered by Congress to encourage preservation of national sites and buildings.

title: WHERE ARE PESTICIDES IN SOIL ENDING UP?
description: To the Editor:

title: No More Rocky Road
description: In a notable act of baseball noblesse oblige, the San Diego Padres are surrendering a strategic territorial advantage that may have been a key factor in their successful drive for the National League pennant - the rock-hard infield at Jack Murphy San Diego Stadium and its tufted, bumpy outfield that made many a visiting fielder look silly during the 1984 season.

title: FLICK STRONG DESPITE SCANDAL
description: Politically, the affairs of Karl Friedrich Flick, the 56- year-old industrialist who is at the center of a political storm sweeping West Germany, could not be worse. But business - at least to the extent that it can be separated from politics - could hardly be better.

title: ASSESSING OPEC'S MEMBERS
description: Only a few years ago, oil exporting countries had more money than they could spend, and petroleum seemed an elixir that would keep them strong. Now, as somber oil ministers confer in Geneva at an emergency meeting of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, declining world demand for oil and rising production have changed the picture.

title: Hopes Wane in Mack Strike, A Company Official Asserts
description: Contract talks in an eight-day United Automobile Workers strike against Mack Trucks Inc. continued today.

title: Reagan Praises Zionism As Aspiration of Jews
description: President Reagan, in a letter to the Zionist Organization of America, has praised Zionism as ''a fundamental aspiration of the Jewish people.''

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''If you had the opportunity to see this baby and her mother it would help convince you of the propriety of what we are trying to do here.'' - Dr. Leonard L. Bailey. (A15:2.)

title: New Dances to Open Series
description: Two premieres by Stuart Pimsler Dance and Theater will mark the opening of a dance series on Nov. 3 at 8 P.M. at the Emanu-El Midtown Y.M.-Y.W.H.A., 344 East 14th Street.

title: Successor to President Designated by GATX
description: J. Warren Samborn will become president and chief operating officer at the GATX Corporation, the company announced.

title: JUDGE SUGGESTS A BYSTANDER SAVED POPE
description: The judge who investigated the purported plot to assassinate Pope John Paul II was quoted today as having said that an unidentified spectator may have saved the Pope's life by shoving the arm of the Turkish gunman convicted of shooting him.

title: THE SOUL OF FOREIGN POLICY: RIGHTS
description: Any debate about foreign policy has to address what our nation is striving to achieve. In that light, human rights ought to be the soul of United States foreign policy.

title: Party Post to Nakasone; Premiership Is Assured
description: Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone was chosen today by senior officials in his ruling Liberal Democratic Party for a second term as head of the party, assuring that he will be the first Prime Minister in more than a decade to serve for more than two years.

title: CONCERT: SYNTHESIZERS AND GOSPEL
description: Bob Telson, whose score for ''The Gospel at Colonus'' represents an impressive stylistic cross-section of the last 30 years of gospel music, showed off the broader range of his composing skills at the Joyce Theater on Friday in a program called ''Gospel Synthesizers.''

title: Mortgage Lending Off
description: Mortgage lending at the nation's savings institutions dropped 28 percent in September to $11 billion, the lowest level since last February, the United States League of Savings Institutions announced yesterday.

title: Dr. David Rabin Dies; Studied Contraception
description: Dr. David Rabin, an endocrinologist working on development of a male contraceptive, died Friday of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, known as Lou Gehrig's disease. He was 50 years old.

title: Bridge:At Olympiad, Not All Action Occurred at the Card Tables
description: The seventh World Team Olympiad began here at noon today, with some major clashes at the card tables and a small political problem away from them.

title: TITLE TO TOM WATSON
description: Bill Kratzert completed a 5-under- par 66 with birdies on three of his last four holes and scored a two-stroke victory today in the Pensacola Open, the last official tournament of the 10- month PGA Tour.

title: U.A.W. Canadian Head In Spotlight for Strike
description: Robert White, Canadian director of the United Auto Workers, has in his hands the future of more auto workers than the 36,600 who work for General Motors of Canada Ltd.

title: Figure in Landmark Decision Gets 12 Years in Molestation
description: Danny Escobedo, whose murder conviction was overturned in a landmark 1964 Supreme Court decision requiring that defendants be advised of the right to an attorney, has been sentenced to 12 years in prison for molesting a child.

title: Futures/Options ; Approach Of 'Farm Options'
description: If, as expected, the Commodity Futures Trading Commission approves the ''second wave'' of options on futures today, trading in options on soybeans, cotton, live cattle and several varieties of wheat futures will begin tomorrow for the first time on domestic exchanges.

title: MUSIC: THE MONTREAL PERFORMS SHOSTAKOVICH
description: The music of Shostakovich wraps itself in grief as no music ever has before. The last quartets manufacture their own private despondency; but in the ''Babi Yar'' Symphony - which the Montreal Symphony under Charles Dutoit brought to Carnegie Hall Saturday night - the composer has found public unhappinesses reaching far beyond his own, in the persecutions of the Jews.

title: ; FUEL EFFICIENCY BY TAXING BIG-CAR BUYERS
description: To the Editor:

title: RICH BREEDERS' CUP MAY BE HARD TO FILL
description: The seven Breeders' Cup races at California's Hollywood Park Nov. 10 are filling up slowly, and unless there is a flurry of late entries before a deadline tomorrow, there may not be full fields.

title: HAMLET OF NATIONS
description: -white-and-blue

title: THE COMPUTER IS A HIT AT THE COSMETICS COUNTER
description: The computer is the beauty industry's latest toy, and women seem to be responding to it as enthusiastically as children to the latest doll.

title: NBC NEWS PLANNING VISIT TO VIETNAM
description: Buoyed by the recognition it achieved for a series of programs from Moscow last month, NBC News has begun discussions with Vietnamese officials about originating some of its broadcasts from Vietnam for a week next April in conjunction with the 10th anniversary of the American withdrawal from Vietnam and the fall of Saigon to Communist forces.

title: BROOKLYN STRIKES UP SPIRIT
description: The band. Everyone on Clermont Avenue wanted to know where was the band, as if a New York City Marathon without the Bishop Loughlin High School band playing the theme from ''Rocky'' for five hours was a naked event.

title: PATRIOTS BEAT JETS
description: The Jets and Patriots played a hard, bitter game today that was decided in part by events the players seemed to have no control over: the bounce of a ball, a coaching change, another coach's decision near the goal line and injuries.

title: Required Reading The New Vice Presidency
description: The title has not changed, but the job certainly has. The Vice Presidency has become - at long last, against all odds - a very good place for a political figure to be.

title:
MUSIC: NOTED IN BRIEF;
Camerata Bariloche, Argentine Ensemble
description: The Camerata Bariloche, a string ensemble from Argentina that has appeared here previously, came to Goodman House on Wednesday night to perform works by Mozart, Suk, Skalkottas, Juan Zorzi and, with Guelfo Nalli as soloist, Cherubini's Sonata No. 2 for Horn and String Orchestra.

title: BRONCOS TRIUMPH
description: Rich Karlis, getting a second chance, booted a 35-yard field goal as time expired in overtime today to give the Denver Broncos a 22-19 victory over the Los Angeles Raiders.

title: On Pumping Iron And Eating Bagels
description: Very few came from the New York

title: HARSH ASSERTIONS MARK MINNESOTA'S SENATE RACE
description: Coming together on the occasion of the grand opening of a bank in Duluth, Minn., the candidates brimmed with issues.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Oct. 29, 1984 GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: INCREASE IN GANG KILLINGS ON COAST IS TRACED TO NARCOTICS TRAFFICKING
description: After several years of declining gang violence, Los Angeles is experiencing a wave of killings that officials say is a result of narcotics trafficking.

title: CUOMO TRIBUTE TO ARCHBISHOP
description: Governor Cuomo and Archbishop John J. O'Connor, who have recently been sharply at odds over issues of abortion, religion and politics, last night traded compliments, jokes and muted jibes at a Broadway gathering held in the Roman Catholic Archbishop's honor.

title: Defused Phone Fight?
description: The volatile communications battle over monthly access charges for residential telephone users may be in the process of being defused. It has been a major stumbling block this year to getting local and long-distance rates restructured.

title: BRZEZINSKI ASSAILS U.S. OFFICIALS
description: Federal officials have been ''unwitting or in some cases, perhaps, even witting tools'' of a Soviet campaign to divert attention from a purported plot to murder the Pope, Zbigniew Brzezinski, national security adviser to former President Jimmy Carter, said in an interview broadcast today.

title: Tax-Change Difficulties
description: WASHINGTON

title: Topics; Out of the Past
description: Witness

title: POLICE SAY ARRESTS ON COAST HALT BID BY ORGANIZED CRIME
description: An attempt by organized crime to take over $1 million-a-week bookmaking operations here was cut short today with the arrests of 20 people, including the reputed leader of organized crime in Southern California, the police said.

title: MUSIC: VOCAL ARTS ENSEMBLE AT TULLY HALL
description: Rescuing valuable musical artifacts from the past is a splendid enterprise, but finding the right place to put them can be a puzzle. Almost half of Saturday afternoon's concert by the New York Vocal Arts Ensemble at Alice Tully Hall simply did not belong where it was - the madrigals, part songs and solos from Tudor England and Classical Vienna, crying out for small rooms to hear them in and equally small voices.

title: INTEREST IN LEARNING FOREIGN LANGUAGES RISES
description: Interest in foreign languages is reawakening in the nation's schools and colleges after an era of neglect, paving the way for what educators hope will be a breakthrough in resistance to learning a second language.

title: CREDIT MARKETS ; Speculation on Rate Increase;  Fed Action In Question
description: The sharp decline in interest rates this month caught many analysts by surprise, but it has not silenced a chorus of predictions for higher rates by the end of the year and during 1985. Indeed, credit market participants are now debating whether the decline has already run its course.

title: CARRIAGE INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Ivy League Poll Gives Mondale a Clear Lead
description: Students on seven Ivy League campuses give Walter F. Mondale a 19 percentage point lead over President Reagan in Presidential preference, according to a survey by the schools' student newspapers.

title: JOSEPHSON INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
A POET LAUREATE'S MUSE: NO FLIGHT OF FANCY,SHE
description: Miss J. Hunter Dunn is as familiar a figure to lovers of middlebrow English poetry as is J. Alfred Prufrock to lovers of highbrow English poetry.

title: STEWART INFORMATION SERVCES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes an after-tax provision of $1,100,000 relating to a settlement of a lawsuit over the ownership of certain properties.

title: Swedish Trade Deficit
description: Sweden's current account deficit widened to 1.6 billion Swedish kronor, or about $184 million, in August, from 300 million kronor in July, Sweden's central bank said today. It said August's current account deficit had narrowed from 4.4 billion kronor a year earlier. The current account measures trade in goods and services.

title: SCOTT INSTRUMENTS CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
UNDERGROUND RIDE TO FINISH
description: The strangers met at the Lafayette Avenue subway

title: AN X-RAY LASER IS DEVELOPED AT LIVERMORE
description: SCIENTISTS at the Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory announced yesterday that they had created the shortest wavelengths ever with a laboratory laser. The achievement comes nearly a quarter-century since the first laser was developed.

title: Top Executive Chosen For Lone Star Steel
description: Northwest Industries Inc., which said yesterday that it had entered into a definitive agreement to be acquired by an investor group for $1.2 billion, has named a top officer for Lone Star Steel, a subsidiary that will be spun off.

title: REEVES COMMUNICATIONS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income.

title: Service for George Chaffee
description: A memorial service for George Chaffee, a ballet dancer, teacher, author and collector, will be held at 2 P.M. Saturday at the Church of St. Mary the Virgin, 145 West 46th Street. Mr. Chaffee, a leading dancer with the Metropolitan Opera Ballet in the 1930's, amassed a major collection of dance memorabilia and taught dancers including Alicia Alonso and John Gilpin. He died Oct. 20. The service will include reminiscences by colleagues.

title: BIBB CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 29
description: b-Including a tax credit of $530,000, or 39 cents a share, from the reversal of deferred income taxes provided on undistributed earnings of the company's domestic international sales corporation. c-Net loss.

title: CHAMPION WRITE-OFFS ON TIMBER
description: The Champion International Corporation intends to take write-offs in the areas of timber-cutting contracts and building materials that will reduce this year's earnings by $120 million to $150 million, the forest products company has disclosed.

title: Levy, Flaxman Adds Playboy Assignment
description: Levy, Flaxman & Associates has been named to do the trade advertising for Playboy magazine.

title: STELCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss. There were no share earnings after preferred dividend requirements. The company is listed on the Toronto and Montreal stock exchanges.

title: Price of Glory
description: Exuberant fans at West Virginia's Mountaineer Field cost the university's athletic department a total of $4,500 over the last two football Saturdays, but Coach Don Nehlen chuckles when he says, ''I guess we can afford it.''

title: TUESDAY, OCTOBER 30, 1984
description: International

title: Iran Hangs Drug Smugglers
description: The newspaper Ettelaat said today that 33 drug smugglers, found guilty of handling about 70 tons of narcotics, were hanged yesterday in the town of Zahidan in eastern Iran. It said they included 17 Afghans and one Pakistani.

title: Article 045815 -- No Title
description: The Dayton Hudson Corporation, the nation's fifth largest general merchandise retailer, said yesterday in Minneapolis that it will invest $3.2 billion to expand during the next five years.

title: Chevron-Sohio
description: The Chevron Corporation and the Standard Oil Company of Ohio said they had signed a contract for Sohio's acquisition of the Gulf Corporation's refining and marketing assets in the Southeast for $340 million.

title: DUQUESNE LIGHT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
RESEARCH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a one-time tax benefit of $361,900, or 22 cents a share.

title: R. J. Reynolds Tender Offer R. J. Reynolds Industries
description: Inc. said its board had authorized a tender offer for as many

title: EFFECTS OF CRIME HEARINGS
description: The President's Commission on Organized Crime last week treated the galleries to the melodrama of which gangster B movies are made.

title: HARPSICORD'S OF 1700'S INSPIRE A CRAFTSMAN
description: Walter Burr is worried.

title: Players In Surgery
description: Surgery is scheduled later this week for Keith Stanberry and Andre Johnson, two members of Oklahona's defensive secondary, who were injured in an automobile accident hours after the second-ranked Sooners were upset by Kansas on Saturday.

title: OPERA: 'MANON LESCAUT'
description: HARD to believe, but it is more than 20 years since Mirella Freni first appeared in this country and immediately reached every susceptible operagoing heart with her Mimi and Marguerite. The big-name Italianate sopranos at that time were Maria Callas and Renata Tebaldi, whose voices are now cherished memories. Miss Freni, however, is still a major singer and an even more major singing actress, as she proved once more last night when she returned to the Metropolitan Opera in the title role of the season's first ''Manon Lescaut.''

Roger Smith, G.M.'s chairman, said total investment would come to $60 million. G.M. and Daewoo each would put in $10 million, with the remainder coming from loans, he said. G.M.'s Delco Remy division and Daewoo Precision Industries will turn out cranking motors, alternators, ignition distributors and ignition coils at the plant in Nongong, about 200 miles southeast of Seoul, G.M. said.

title: KANSAS CITY LIFE INSURANCE reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
WHY YOUNG VOTERS ARE ALIENATED FFROM MONDALE
description: One of the most amusing ideas of the political season is that the move of young voters to President Reagan is a ''gold rush'' based more on a narrow view of their self-interest than on new, long-range policies the President has to offer for the whole nation's future. Actually, what has driven so many young peoPaul N. McCloskey Jr., former Republican Representative from California, challenged President Richard M. Nixon in 1972 Republican primaries after breaking with him over his Vietnam War policy. ple to register as Republicans is the Democrats' embrace of the ''old'' politics of Walter F. Mondale. What hope is there for young people in a Democratic Party headed by one of the remaining ''old pols'' of our time - a traditional Democrat who thinks his first obligation is to leaders of organized labor and his second obligation to every entitlement program conceived by Lyndon B. Johnson's ''Great Society'' crusade of the mid-1960's - programs for which Mr. Mondale was an enthusiastic co-author in the Senate and that now account for more than half the Federal deficit? These programs, with built-in incentives for profligacy, waste and idleness, have perhaps mortgaged the future economic security of young Americans more than any other age group. These voters can listen to Mr. Mondale's campaign promises with certainty that booming budget deficits could only increase under his leadership.

title: Talk, Talk, Talk
description: Meanwhile, many, if not most, Washingtonians are convinced that President Reagan will be re-elected, so talk of the campaign has dropped off considerably. Rather, people are talking about the weather, which has been hot and muggy for weeks, and the Redskins, who have lost two straight.

title: M.T.A. AND UNION REACH REPAIR PACT
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority and the largest union it bargains with have agreed to a major reorganization of the way in which subway cars are fixed, Mayor Koch announced yesterday.

title: JO SULLIVAN SINGS
description: SINCE Jo Sullivan resumed her singing career in 1976 after 16 years of retirement, she has been doing occasional cabaret programs that focused on the songs of her late husband, Frank Loesser. His songs are still a major part of her performance now that her program has been expanded to a two-hour production called ''I Hear Music . . . of Frank Loesser and Friends'' at the Off-Broadway Ballroom Theater, 253 West 28th Street. But Miss Sullivan, who once seemed to be primarily a vehicle for the presentation of her husband's songs, has now switched roles to emerge as a versatile and charming performer whose personality dominates the evening, with or without Mr. Loesser's songs.

description: b-Net loss. Results for the latest quarter include a pretax gain of $5,582,000 from the sale of the company's remaining investment in Renishaw PLC net of $1.3 million of nonrecurring costs from the consolidation of certain British operations.

title: LAWYER ASSERTS ANTI-BIAS EFFORT IS LEGALLY VOID
description: Catholic agencies can renew their contracts with New York City because a recent addition to those contracts - job protection for homosexuals - is legally worthless, a lawyer for the Archdiocese of New York said yesterday.

title: HOUGHTON MIFFLIN CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ; Coast Thrift Unit Sets $235 Million Offering
description: The Far West Savings and Loan Association, of Newport Beach, Calif., said yesterday that it would offer about $235 million in collateralized mortgage obligations. Lead underwriters are Merrill Lynch Capital Markets and Drexel Burnham Lambert.

title: FROM PARKS AND SIDEWALKS, 410 HOMELESS SIGN UP TO VOTE
description: Using such addresses as a sidewalk, a park bench, the post office steps, Pennsylvania Station and Central Park, 410 homeless people have registered to vote in next Tuesday's elections, the New York City Board of Elections reported yesterday.

title: STUDY SHOWS RETAIL INDUSTRY IN CITY GAINS IN EMPLOYMENT
description: New York City's department stores, restaurants, boutiques, grocery stores and other retail businesses have joined the city's economic recovery, according to a Federal study released yesterday.

title: Insurance Merger In Canada Set
description: The Manufacturers Life Insurance Company said it had agreed in principle to buy the Lincoln National Life Insurance Company's 89 percent holding in the Dominion Life Assurance Company for about $157.50 (Canadian currency) a share, or about $140.2 million.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ; Farah Resignation Surprises Analysts
description: In an announcement that jolted industry analysts and stock traders, the Farah Manufacturing Company said yesterday that Ray Williams, who had served as president and chief operating officer since 1978, had resigned.

title: CHILE, MOVING TO BLOCK PROTESTS, BANISHES 140 INTO INTERNAL EXILE
description: Chile's military Government sent 140 people into internal exile early today as it moved to crack down on protesters calling for a swift return to democratic rule.

title: BORDEN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including a gain of $5,776,000, or 22 cents a share, for the quarter and 9 months from the sale of property. c-Including a gain of $11.7 million, or 40 cents a share, for the quarter and 9 months from the sale of property and net proceeds of $16,982,000, or 59 cents a share, for the 9 months from the settlement of a disputed contract.

title: Children Petition U.N.
description: A delegation of children today presented the United Nations with a petition, signed by 13,000 children from all over the world, calling for an end to the nuclear arms race.

title: DIVERSIFIED ENERGIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including an extraordinary gain from the sale of an energy center.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: FAMILY DANCING. By David Leavitt. 206 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $13.95. BRIGHT LIGHTS, BIG CITY. By Jay McInerney. 182 pages. Vintage Contemporaries. Paper. $5.95.

title: TIME TO QUESTION GENETIC ENGINEERING IS NOW
description: To the Editor:

title: BRITON ASSAILS LIBYAN TALKS
description: The leader of Britain's labor federation today condemned a meeting between Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader, and a representative of the National Union of Mineworkers, whose members have been on strike for seven months.

title: CENTURY PAPERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SURGEONS DEFEND THE EXPERIMENT
description: Doctors removed Baby Fae's name from the critical list today, three days after she was given a baboon's heart.

title: Posey, Parry & Quest Gets New Accounts
description: The people at Posey, Parry & Quest are bursting with pride over the recent influx of accounts and their portent for the bottom line. And since none of the business had a previous agency, this means happiness for them without the usual heartbreak for others.

title: DRIVE BEGINS ON DALKON SHIELD
description: The maker of the Dalkon Shield, an intrauterine birth control device that was withdrawn from the market after users complained of infections and spontaneous abortions, began a program today to persuade women still using it to have it removed.

title: RESEARCHER AS AGENCY THERAPIST
description: ROBERT J. WERLIN equates an advertising agency with the human mind.

title: LOVE CANAL: A LOOK BACK
description: Love Canal, a name that has become synonymous with toxic waste disaster, burst upon the nation's consciousness in 1978 with the discovery that a whole neighborhood of Niagara Falls, N.Y., had been contaminated by chemicals at an old dump site, posing untold dangers to residents.

title: 'NOVA' DOCUMENTARY EXPLORES YELLOW RAIN
description: '' NOVA'' explores tonight a scientific puzzle with international political complications: yellow rain. What is it and what is its source? The provocative one-hour documentary, ''The Mystery of Yellow Rain,'' will be seen on Channel 13 at 8 P.M.

title: NEW LEADER IN DETROIT WHO FOCUSES ON DESIGN
description: Donald E. Petersen vividly remembers the day in 1949 when he and a slightly senior executive of the Ford Motor Company met with the company's chief engineer to suggest that the product planning department they were establishing should get involved in designing future car models. ''Well, after I picked myself up off the curb and brushed myself off, I told my boss that we had some convincing to do,'' he said, recalling the incident.

PUBLIC THEATER NAMES SUSAN STEIN SHIVA UNIT
description: The New York Shakespeare Festival last night dedicated one of the six theaters in the Public Theater complex to the memory of Susan Stein Shiva, a member of the festival's board of directors for more than 15 years.

title: 2 Charged in Slaying Of Girl to Undergo Tests
description: A man and a woman charged with killing her 4-year-old daughter by burning her in an electric oven must undergo psychiatric examinations, a State District Court ruled today.

title: Endorsement Agonies At The Miami Herald
description: The Miami Herald's endorsement on Sunday of President Reagan for a second term prompted the newspaper's editor to resign because The Herald's publisher had overruled an editorial board decision to endorse Walter F. Mondale, according to Jim Hampton, the editor.

title: Japan Videotape Sales
description: Japan exported a record number of videotape recorders in September, the Electronics Industries Association of Japan said today. Exports totaled 2.2 million units, up 10.4 percent from August and 49.8 percent from September 1983.

Two-Fight Feature
description: Gerry Cooney, the heavyweight contender, will fight 32-year-old George Chaplin Dec. 8 in a televised doubleheader that will also feature a featherweight title bout between Wilfredo Gomez of Puerto Rico and Azumah Nelson of Ghana. The heavyweight fight will be at the Arizona Coliseum in Phoenix; the Gomez-Nelson fight will be held in San Juan.

title: Stocks Decline; Dow Off 3.54
description: Stock prices continued to weaken yesterday in slower trading after dropping sharply last week. The biggest movers were issues responding to specific news developments.

title: HEAT MINIMIZED IN RACE DEATH
description: While officials of the New York Road Runners Club minimized the relationship between the unusally high temperature and stifling humidity Sunday and the death of 48- year-old Jacques Bussereau, the race's medical director acknowledged that the conditions could have contributed to the first fatality in the 15 years of the New York City Marathon.

title: YUPPIES ARE LOOKING FOR ACTIVIST LEADERS
description: To the Editor:

title: A Blast at Arms Dump In Indonesia Kills 25
description: A marine corps munitions dump blew up near here tonight, sending tons of bombs, mortar shells and other explosives raining down on villages and urban neighborhoods.

Seagram's Note Sale Is Planned
description: Joseph E. Seagram & Sons said it would offer $125 million of 11 3/8 percent notes due Nov. 1, 1986.

title: The Betting Is On
description: One of the better campaign anecdotes reaching Washington comes from a confrontation that occurred minutes after the Presidential debate in Kansas City. Among the Republicans who immediately told reporters that Mr. Reagan had won the debate was Lee Atwater, director of the President's campaign in the South.

title: WACKENHUT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $300,000 resulting from changes in tax law and a gain of $441,000 from the sale of a building.

title: FERRARO DEPLORES REMARK BY REAGAN
description: Rebutting remarks made by President Reagan in a Long Island synagogue last week, Geraldine A. Ferraro said yesterday at a Manhattan synagogue that she would not accept Mr. Reagan's ''base implications that my party is soft on anti-Semitism.''

title: G & K SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 29
NAKASONE PLEDGES CONTINUITY IN HIS SECOND TERM
description: Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone, winning a second term as head of the governing conservative party, said today that there would be ''stability and continuity'' in Japan's pro-Western foreign policy and tight domestic spending programs.

title: LOSSES AT ASARCO AND PHELPS DODGE
description: Asarco Inc., hurt by substantially lower prices for silver and copper, yesterday reported a loss of $10.1 million for the third quarter, reversing a profit of $2.9 million in the 1983 period.

There was a long hiatus after television came in and took up space at NBC at 30 Rockefeller Plaza, at 49th Street and Avenue of the Americas, but within the last year the tours have resumed.

description: This may be the offseason for baseball games but not for baseball theater. Two plays about baseball currently are on off-off-Broadway stages and a musical about the game is scheduled to open in December.

BRITISH QUEST TO GROW HAIR IN LABORATORY
description: RESEARCHERS at the University of Dundee in Britain suggest the possibility that a harvest of hair cells grown in a laboratory could be implanted on bald scalps. They have been testing the procedure on rats.

title: FOUND: HISTORICAL HEAVEN
description: For nearly 20 years, Raymond W. Smock was just another Capitol tourist, admiring the old building's friezes and frescoes, gazing at the array of marble statues, listening for those historic whispers of long ago.

title: Indian Village Is Unearthed
description: Archaeologists digging at a suburban construction site have unearthed the remains of an Indian village believed to be more than 3,000 years old.

title: CAPTURING THE DRAMA OF THE MARATHON
description: It's hard to imagine that a nutty thing like 18,000

title: WISCONSIN ELECTRIC POWER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
U.S.-China Talks Disclosed
description: The United States and China have held talks on the possibility of United States Navy ships visiting Chinese ports, a spokesman for the Seventh Fleet said here today. Comdr. Julius Graw said that top-level negotiations about the possibility were held a few months ago, adding that details of the talks could not be disclosed.

title: First-Year Rises in Pay At 2.5% for Unionists
description: Labor contracts negotiated for 1.4 million unionized workers in the first nine months of 1984 produced first-year raises of 2.5 percent, on the average, the Federal Government has reported.

title: HUNTER PRESIDENT, IN SPEECH, URGES CHANGES IN CITY'S SCHOOLS
description: Dr. Donna E. Shalala, the president of Hunter College, said yesterday that the New York City school system is a ''rotten barrel,'' and called for drastic change.

title: AROUND THE NATION ; Judge Blocks Release Of a Kennedy's Pictures
description: A Federal district judge issued a temporary restraining order today that prevented the publication of any photographs of David Kennedy taken after his death from an overdose of drugs last April in Palm Beach.

title: SEDCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
LAROUCHE TRYING AGAIN, IN 19 STATES
description: Of the assorted minor-party candidates for President this year, few can boast as many or as contrasting political incarnations as Lyndon H. LaRouche Jr., who is running in 19 states as an ''independent Democrat.''

title: MIXED RESULTS FOR 2 COACHES IN DEBUTS
description: Raymond Berry and Marty Schottenheimer made their debuts as head coaches Sunday. Berry made very few changes, and his team won. Schottenheimer made several changes on offense, and his team lost.

title: NEW HOSPICE TO SERVE CHILDREN NEAR DEATH
description: Dr. Burton Grebin said he would go to his grave feeling cheated by a hospital regimen that once prevented him from remaining at the side of a dying 14-year-old patient who begged him to stay with her until the end.

title: 10-WEEK-LONG STRIKE ENDS AT RKO STATIONS
description: RKO General Inc. announced yesterday that a 10-week-old strike by members of the National Association of Broadcast Employees and Technicians at some of its broadcast operations in the New York area had been settled.

title: DEFENDANT ADMITS GUILT IN AN ATLANTIC CITY PLOT
description: An Atlantic City union leader, facing Federal corruption charges with former Mayor Michael J. Matthews, pleaded guilty today at the start of their trial.

title: PROFESSOR AND ART AUTHORITY
description: Howard Hibbard, a professor of art history at Columbia University and an authority on Italian art of the 16th and 17th centuries, died of cancer yesterday at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 56 years old and lived in Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: Lebanon Warns Ships On Using Illegal Ports
description: The Government today issued strict instructions to all ships entering the 12- mile territorial limit to call only at legitimate harbors and to avoid illegal ports operated by private militias.

title: HERNANDEZ FILES FOR TRADE
description: Willie Hernandez, whose near-perfect relief pitching was instrumental in Detroit's championship season, filed a demand to be traded yesterday, the last day players could demand trades or declare themselves free agents.

title: Jordan Gets 37 To Stop Bucks CHICAGO, Oct. 29 (AP) -
description: Michael Jordan, playing in

title: DAWKINS STATUS QUESTIONABLE
description: Darryl Dawkins would like nothing more than to prove to the Philadelphia 76ers that the Nets' stunning upset of the defending world champions in the first round of the playoffs last season was no fluke. But he may not get the chance - at least not yet.

title: AMERICAN HOIST & DERRICK CO reports earnings for 17 wks to Sept 22

title: C-I-L INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including a special gain of $1.5 million for the quarter and 9 months. c-After special charges of $439,000 for the quarter and $1.6 million for the 9 months.

title: SAVORING A 'RECKLESS' SUNDAY
description: Joe Morris had just played the best game of his three-year professional football career. And so, when the Giants' locker room was opened to the news media minutes after the 37-13 upset of the Washington Redskins here Sunday, there was a mad rush for his locker. But it was too late. Morris had dressed and left through a side door.

title: BRIDGE: U.S. WOMENS 2d AT OLUMPIAD BUT OPEN TEAM IS STRUGGLING
description: When the World Team Olympiad continued this afternoon, the United States women's team moved into second place by winning twice. But the open team struggled: It lost to Belgium 10-20, and then had a bye round.

title: Peace Corps Volunteer Is Slain in Guatemala
description: A Peace Corps volunteer in Guatemala City was shot in the head and killed early Sunday morning several blocks from the Peace Corps office and his residence, Peace Corps officials said here today.

title: Healthcare Link
description: Continental Healthcare Systems Inc. said it and the Primark Corporation had agreed in principle for Primark to acquire all of Continental's common shares outstanding for $6.75 a share, or about $21 million. Continental, based in Overland Park, Kan., is mainly a supplier of computer information management systems to the health care industry. Primark is a holding company involved in several businesses, one of which is telecommunications service for the health care industry.

title: Public Radio Poll Shows Large Lead for President By United Press International
description: President Reagan holds a 58 percent to 41 percent lead over Walter F. Mondale, a new National Public Radio-Harris Poll, completed over the weekend, indicated yesterday.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: Deere Outlook
description: Deere & Company said it expects that its financial results for the fiscal fourth quarter, ending Wednesday, will be ''worse'' than last year's, when the company earned $58 million, or 85 cents a share. A spokesman said the company plans to take an aftertax charge in the quarter of about $10 million to $15 million to cover costs associated with cutting its salaried workforce. Deere, which make farm and construction machinery, also said it would take a smaller charge in its fiscal year 1985 first quarter for a similar reason, but a spokesman was not more specific.

title: UNC Stake Cited
description: Maxxam Group Inc., MCO Holdings Inc. and the Federated Development Company, three companies controlled by Charles E. Hurwitz, told the Securities and Exchange Commission that they had purchased 1.2 million common shares, or 6 percent of the total outstanding, of UNC Resources Inc. UNC, based in Falls Church, Va., produces uranium ores and concentrates and is involved in oil and gas exploration and production. According to the filing, the group purchased the shares for investment purposes, but they said they may seek representation on UNC's board. On the New York Stock Exchange today, UNC closed at $10, unchanged.

title: EDWARD E. SLATTERY JR.
description: Edward E. Slattery Jr., for many years head of public information for the National Transportation Safety Board, died of a heart attack Sunday at a hospital in Washington, D.C. He was 73 years old.

title: HIGH COURT TO DECIDE INSURER SUIT
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether Federal law permits states to require health insurance plans for private employees to cover specific types of medical care.

title: Today Is Yuppies Day
description: House Democrats are unabashedly appealing to ''yuppie'' voters in behalf of the Mondale-Ferraro ticket.

title: The Fingerprints on Agca's Gun It may take months before an Italian court tries three Bulgarians and four Turks now charged with plotting to kill Pope John Paul II. But the existence of a plot no longer seems conjectural. A wealth of detail suggests that Mehmet Ali Agca did not act alone, as he originally claimed, when he shot the Pope in May 1981.
description: Ilario Martella, an Italian magistrate known for his caution, formally charges that the accomplices included Bulgarian officials as well as Turkish terrorists - a charge that translates into a crime of state bearing Soviet fingerprints.

description: * Walter Carlson is joining Doyle Dane Bernbach International as senior vice president/director of communications.

description: Nine artists won $25,000 fellowship grants from the National Endowment for the Arts today for outstanding talent in photography, sculpture and art crafts.

description: DANIEL F. Heffernan concedes that the Principals Academy he directs is a hip-pocket operation, quartered in borrowed space at the University of Rochester and dependent for its paperwork on the goodwill of the secretaries at Brighton High in Rochester, where he is principal.

For Congress From New York Our Incumbency Principle holds that public officials who are performing creditably deserve re- election unless challenged by demonstrably superior opponents. That principle favors three incumbents in three warmly contested races for Congress in New York City and Long Island.
description: 15th District (Manhattan East Side): Probably no incumbent has better earned re-election than Bill Green, the moderate Republican seeking a fifth term in a district now two-thirds Democratic. He's one of the smartest lawyers in Congress and has delivered for his district and for the city. He has used his Appropriations subcommittee post to increase public housing funds, including about $140 million for the city. He rescued Federal crime insurance, which strongly benefits the state, and sponsored a sensible anti-car-theft law.

description: Mayor Winfield Moses Jr. was indicted today on charges of violating Indiana election law. The Mayor said the charges involved nothing more than bookkeeping mistakes.

title: CANDIDATES' RETICENCE ON SCHOOLS
description: PREDICTIONS that education would be a major issue in the Presidential campaign turned out to be wrong. Despite an outpouring of school reform proposals and much public concern, the candidates, preoccupied with deficits and ''star wars,'' skipped over education or dealt with it in the most general terms.

title: CORRECTION
description: We regret referring yesterday to New York's Century Association as having ''tax-exempt'' status. Like other clubs, the Century pays real estate taxes, sales taxes on food and drinks and social security taxes on its payroll. The issue that some who object to its exclusion of women sometimes raise concerns the tax-deductability of business expenses at the club.

But he isn't, which becomes tragically apparent when he kills himself by driving his car over a cliff. ''Silence of the Heart,'' tonight's television movie on CBS at 9, uses the fictitious story of Skip to explore the very real phenomenon of teen-age suicide, now reported to claim at least 5,000 victims each year out of 400,000 attempts.

BLACKS' INTERESTS IN THE PRESIDENTIAL ELECTION
description: Recent polls suggest that President Reagan may receive less than 20 percent of the black vote. The indications are that blacks will continue their 50-year practice of supporting Democratic candidates. Since Oscar De Priest was defeated by Arthur W. Mitchell, an Illinois Democrat, in 1934, a black Republican has not served in the House, and, except for the tenure of Edward W. Brooke (1966-1978), no other black Republican has been elected to the Senate in this century.

description: TUESDAY, OCTOBER 30, 1984 International

title: Haskell to Weiss
description: Haskell of Pittsburgh, maker of office equipment and furniture, has assigned its advertising to Weiss/Watson of New York. The billings, according to the agency, should come to about $1.5 million, most of which will be spent in business-to-business promotion. The advertiser has not had an agency for about four years.

title: COORS AGREES TO USE $300 MILLION TO AID HISPANIC-OWNED CONCERNS
description: The Adolph Coors Company said today it would spend $300 million to aid Hispanic businesses.

title: RELIABILITY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
MUSICAL: JEWISH JOURNEY
description: '' THE GOLDEN LAND,'' which will be playing weekends at the Norman Thomas Theater on East 33d Street, is a new and buoyant musical, a cavalcade that retraces through 50 songs of the various periods the path of Jewish immigrants from Yiddish-speaking Eastern Europe. This is a familiar route but this English-Yiddish production romps through it so delightfully that even dej a vu takes on a freshness that turns it into love at first sight.

title: DEATH PENALTY ORDERED BY JURY FOR JERSEY MAN
description: A Superior Court jury today ordered that a man they had convicted of the murder of a high school cheerleader be executed by lethal injection.

title: VARIAN ASSOCIATES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a nonrecurring gain of $2,800,000, or 13 cents a share, from the sale of a minority interest in a French company.

title: FAULT OF THE DEBATE LAY IN THE QUESTIONS
description: To the Editor:

title: BUYOUT EFFORT AT DIVERSIFOODS
description: PAN pizza turned out to be trouble for the Godfather's pizza chain and its parent, Diversifoods Inc. The chain rolled out the new product - some call it deep dish pizza or Sicilian pizza - earlier this year with inadequate market research, according to some analysts, and the new dish was poorly received by pizza fans.

title: BUSH BEGINS A LOW-KEY G.O.P. DRIVE IN ALABAMA
description: Vice President Bush began the final week of the Presidential campaign today in a low- key manner, urging the election of Republicans to Congress.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''His last years before his death were bitter ones for the great singer.

title: PERFECTDATA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $42,000. Year-ago results are restated to reflect the March 1984 acquisition of International Data Automaton Ltd.

title: BOOKS: FAULKNER SCRIPTS FOR FILM ON DE GAULLE
description: In the summer of 1942, during the dark days of World War II, William Faulkner composed a moving tribute to man's indomitable spirit. ''Oppression and suffering come upon mankind and even destroy him as individuals,'' he wrote. ''But they cannot destroy his immortal spirit. That endures.''

title: Davenport First in Line
description: The San Francisco Giants will name a new manager today, according to Tom Haller, the team's general manager. Haller declined to identify the team's choice, but newspapers in the Bay Area speculated that Jim Davenport would get the job, and last night The Associated Press, quoting an unidentified team source, also reported that Davenport was the choice.

title: EX-CHIEF OF LEHMAN GETS POST
description: Lewis L. Glucksman, who was ousted as chief executive of Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb last April when the investment bank's board agreed to sell the firm to Shearson/American Express, yesterday got a vote of confidence from the new company.

title: FASHION IN EUROPE: A MIXED BAG
description: The European spring and summer ready-to- wear shows for 1985 have passed into fashion history. The three weeks of intensive showings in Milan, London and Paris will be followed by spring openings in New York this week and next, when final evaluations will be made. But so far, there have been more strikeouts than hits. There will be new names on the labels of designer clothes sold around the world and some established designers will have even wider representation.

title: TECHNOLOGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid in July.

title: A Rough Day For the Giants
description: When the Giants stopped the Washington Redskins Sunday at Giants Stadium, they paid a price - concussions to Lawrence Taylor and Bill Currier.

title: UNION GAS LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: There were no share earnings for the latest and year-ago quarters because preferred dividend requirements exceeded net income. The company is listed on the Toronto Stock Exchange.

title: PALESTINIAN STUDENTS RIOT IN BETHLEHEM
description: Palestinian students at Bethlehem University, angered by a rocket attack Sunday on an Arab bus in Jerusalem, stoned Israeli vehicles in the West Bank today. Israeli soldiers dispersed the students with tear gas and warning shots.

title: Avon Plans Cuts
description: Avon Products Inc. said it would reduce the number of field sales supervisory positions in its Beauty Products Division by 393, or about 15 percent, to 2,100, during the next four months.

Reactor Restarted After an Overhaul
description: The Oyster Creek nuclear reactor was restarted today after a 20-month, $180 million overhaul that is expected to extend the plant's lifetime to the year 2004, officials said.

title: 100 ON A FERRYBOAT ARE REPORTED LOST IN PHILIPPINE STORM
description: More than 100 people were reported missing today in the sinking of a ferryboat in stormy seas.

title: POINT, COUNTERPOINT AND NEEDLEPOINT IN ROOM 318
description: Katherine Stevens Van Deusen Westmoreland - ''Kitsy'' to her friends - is certain she will finish the evening bag she is needlepointing before the trial her husband brought against CBS is over.

title: President of Bolivia Ends Hunger Strike
description: President Hernan Siles Zuazo ended his hunger strike in its fifth day today, saying he had succeeded in ''creating a climate of reflection and peace'' in Bolivia.

title: TV MOVIER PARALLELS SLANDER TRIAL OF RATHER
description: Bob Franklin, star correspondent for the weekly television magazine ''Hourglass,'' is on trial. He is being sued by Edward Lucas, a physician who contends that Mr. Franklin libeled him when he displayed on camera, before millions of ''Hourglass'' viewers, a bogus prescription drug form supposedly signed by the doctor.

title: DANCE: BOSTON TROUPE
description: EVERYTHING was choreographically neat and tidy in the program that the Danceart Company of Boston brought to the Merce Cunningham Studio on Sunday night. But one would gladly have sacrificed some of this decorum for a little more passion.

title: Justice Dept. to Take New Joint Venture Stand
description: Charles F. Rule, a Justice Department antitrust official, said yesterday that the department's antitrust division would soon announce a major new policy concerning joint ventures.

title: GRANTS AFFECT FEW IN CHOICE OF SCHOOL, STUDY SAYS
description: Special scholarships for top students induce fewer than 20 percent to choose one college over another, according to a study made public yesterday by the College Board.

title: VIETNAM AIDE SAYS POLITICS CAME UP AT TALKS ON ENEMY STRENGTH
description: Under relentless cross-examination, a witness for Gen. William C. Westmoreland in his libel suit against CBS testified yesterday that political and public relations concerns had been injected into a high-level 1967 discussion on enemy troop strength in South Vietnam.

title: POLICE SEAL OFF 2 AREAS AS CROWDS GATHER
description: Prime Minister Indira Gandhi was assassinated today by two gunmen who opened fire on her near her home.

COLONEL DISPUTES CBS DOCUMENTARY AT LIBEL TRIAL
description: A top military intelligence officer in Vietnam testified yesterday that CBS was wrong when it reported he was ''fired'' in 1967 because he wanted to report higher North Vietnamese infiltration than the official rate.

description: The Zero Club, one of hockey's more exclusive cliques, is not looking for new members. Everyone in the club talks about it and everyone is obsessed with becoming a nonmember.

A NIGHT FOR BLACK MAGIC AND OTHER OLD RITES
description: ''No way,'' said John Angelo, a strapping building tradesman - no way he was going to be the Princess of Wales this year to his wife's Prince Charles.

title: O, COME ALL YE CATALOGUES
description: ROGER HORCHOW found me, even crouching as I was back by the refrigerator. Reaching all the way from Dallas on Oct. 10, he aimed a catalogue at me through my front door. ''Last Minute Gift Ideas,'' it said, like an accusing finger, and it did not mean daughter-in-law's birthday. It meant the Big Event. Christmas. The episode set off a Jell-O-like frisson of panic.

title: MONDALE, AT CHICAGO RALLY, SAYS 'TIDE IS TURNING, IN '84 ELECTION
description: Walter F. Mondale marched through downtown Chicago tonight in a rousing torchlight parade, and then told thousands of buoyant Democrats that ''the tide is turning'' in the Presidential election.

title: Vanessa Redgrave Ends Testimony in Boston Suit
description: The actress Vanessa Redgrave, who says the Boston Symphony Orchestra dismissed her as an opera narrator because of her support for the Palestine Liberation Organization, testified today that she favored a peaceful end to the Middle Eastern conflict.

title: ANGST ON AUTOBAHN: WOULD SLOWDOWN AID TREES?
description: It is a classic German dilemma, a choice between two beloveds - fast cars and the forest.

title: ENDO-LASE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net losses.

title: Track Tour to Offer $542,000
description: Track and field officials formally announced yesterday the creation of a 16-meet international grand prix competition that will offer more than half a million dollars in prize money next year.

title: 3 Utah Students Die on Hunt
description: Three University of Utah students found dead in a cabin in remote northeastern Utah apparently died of carbon monoxide from propane heaters, the authorities said today. The three, Steven F. Tilley, 22 years old; Farrell Stien, 22, and Bryce H. Wursten, 22, were found in the cabin Monday by Mr. Tilley's brother.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: CERTAIN foods are almost a trademark where the restaurants in New Orleans are concerned. These would include shrimp remoulade and trout Marguery and, of course, gumbos and oysters prepared in any number of ways, including oysters Rockefeller and Bienville. One dish is on the menus of almost all the ''classic'' restaurants of the city - pompano en papillote.

description: SWALLOW. By D. M. Thomas. 312 pages.

title: MARIE LAUFER SNYDER
description: Marie Laufer Snyder of Palm Beach, Fla., and Hewlett Bay Park, L.I., died Saturday at the age of 94.

title: 89,000 TREES ARE CANKER RISK
description: Home gardeners today were urged to destroy more than 89,000 citrus trees purchased from certain stores as officials tried to halt the spread of a tree- killing canker in Florida's billion-dollar citrus industry.

title: No Headline
description: WEDNESDAY, OCTOBER 31, 1984 International The body of a missing Polish priest was found by police frogmen in a Vistula River reservoir 11 days after he was kidnapped by three officers of the state security police, the Polish Government announced. Lech Walesa, the founder of Solidarity, appealed for calm, and there were no reports of disturbances after the announcement that the pro-Solidarity priest, the Rev. Jerzy Popieluszko, had been murdered and his body recovered. (Page A1, Columns 3-4.) OPEC agreed on a general formula to distribute cuts in oil production among its 13 member countries in the organization's effort to bolster sagging prices. But industry analysts said the action was unlikely to change oil prices or output in the immediate future. (A1:5.)

title: Hibernia Bank Account To Henderson Friedlich
description: Henderson Friedlich Graf & Doyle, a New York agency with experience in financial advertising, is about to gain even greater expertise in coast- to-coast air travel, having been assigned the $2 million account of the Hibernia Bank of San Francisco.

title: Kerr-McGee Net Slides
description: The Kerr-McGee Corporation, a diversified petroleum producer based in Oklahoma City, said that its net income plunged 45.6 percent.

title: Home Depot
description: Home Depot Inc. said it had agreed to acquire Bowater Inc.'s Bowater Home Center Inc. unit for about $40 million in cash and a convertible subordinated debenture. Home Depot said the purchase would provide it with ''an immediate opportunity to enter the Dallas market with a significant number of stores and sooner than we had originally anticipated.'' Bowater Home Center has nine stores; Home Depot operates 22 retail warehouse stores.

title: Coach's Solution
description: Add Johnny Majors, the Tennessee football coach, to the list of those who believe that one way of keeping college players from accepting money illicitly is to make the payments aboveboard. ''I think they should be given at least $50 a month,'' Majors said in a speech in Atlanta. ''It wouldn't cut out the cheating altogether, but it may help minimize it.''

title: MIDCON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SCHOOL IN QUEENS SALUTES ITS ARTIST IN RESIDENCE
description: There were jack-o'-lanterns in the windows and witches on the bulletin board at Our Lady of Perpetual Help Roman Catholic School in Ozone Park, Queens, yesterday. But in the auditorium it was definitely Christmas.

Jacobs in Filing On Avco Stake
description: An investment group led by Irwin L. Jacobs, of Minneapolis, told the Securities and Exchange Commission that it ''might at some point and under certain circumstances consider seeking control'' of the Avco Corporation. The Jacobs group said it bought 1,487,100 Avco common shares, or 6.5 percent of the total outstanding, ''to obtain a substantial equity position.''

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: A $120 million issue of bonds by the Health Facilities and Services Administration of Puerto Rico was priced for public offering, according to the lead underwriter, Prudential- Bache Securities.

title: POLL FINDS EUROPEANS DIVIDED ON U.S. PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATES
description: Europeans frequently say that, given America's world role, they should have the right to vote in elections in the United States. But a New York Times/CBS News Poll has found that half the West Germans and French and a third of the Britons say they do not care who wins next Tuesday.

title: CHESS TITLE: 10TH DRAW IN A ROW
description: Anatoly Karpov and Gary Kasparov agreed to a draw yesterday without resuming play in the 19th game of their world chess championship match in Moscow. The draw was the 10th in a row, the longest stretch without a victory in over a century of world title contests.

title: STAGE: WOOSTER GROUP
description: THE Wooster Group borrows, bends and, in some cases, tries to trash dramatic works of the past. In previous seasons, the company has taken a cold- blooded approach to such plays as ''The Cocktail Party'' and ''Our Town.'' In its current ''L.S.D. (. . . Just the High Points . . .),'' it performs radical Wooster Group surgery on ''The Crucible.''

title: WEDNESDAY SPORTS Basketball
description: Nets vs. Celtics , at Boston. Having played one power in the Philadelphia 76ers last night, the Nets have to come right back and meet the National Basketball Association's defending champions.

title: STEVENS FOCUSES ON COMPUTERS
description: THE Stevens Institute of Technology might be one of New Jersey's best-kept educational secrets. Overshadowed by its better known counterparts, the venerable Hoboken, N.J., engineering school is nonetheless one of the most highly respected in the country.

description: The question whether the police may use deadly force to stop a fleeing suspect, one of the most disputed issues in law enforcement, was argued before the Supreme Court today.

description: The village police began to enforce a new local ordinance today intended to limit bus traffic in this southern Westchester County community to one bus every 15 minutes.

title: THEMES AND VARIATIONS FOR COOKING THE BOUNTY OF FALL
description: The first three recipes have been adapted from an old, out-of-print cookbook, recently discovered: ''The Gentle Art of Cookery'' by C. F. Leyel and Olga Hartley, published in Britain in 1925. The recipes are an example of the kind of careful, thoughtful cooking, with a deep respect for ingredients and fresh, natural flavors, that was characteristic of English upper-middle-class households. title: ILLEGAL BLOCKING TECHNIQUES CRITICIZED
description: Many college football coaches are teaching illegal blocking techniques, and that's one reason for the increase in rushing yardage this season, according to David Nelson, the secretary of the National Collegiate Athletic Association's football rules committee and former football coach and athletic director at Delaware. His assessment is finding support among game officials.

title: 'CERTAIN THINGS, PHIL, ARE PERSONAL,' FERRARO SAYS
description: Phil Donahue, the television host whose program is widely watched by millions of women at home, leaned across the table, searching for an answer from Geraldine A. Ferraro.

title: LTV, Union Talk On Alabama Plant
description: The LTV Corporation said it and the United Steelworkers Union Locals 2176 and 4382 had begun preliminary talks on the operations of the former Republic Steel mill and coke batteries at Gadsden, Ala.

title: HOSPITALS IN STATE WELCOME GUIDELINES ON BRAIN DEATH
description: Hospital administrators, doctors and lawyers responded with relief yesterday to the State Court of Appeals decision establishing a new definition of death in New York.

description: Marcus Allen, a Heisman Trophy winner in 1981 at Southern California and the most valuable player in the last Super Bowl, is not his family's only football star.

title: EXPANSION AT TRADE CENTER
description: WHEN Silverstein Properties, a Manhattan real estate investment development concern, was selected by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey in 1980 to develop the last part of the World Trade Center project, plans called for construction of an office tower that would rise 47 stories without setbacks and contain a million square feet of space. It was to be built over a Con Edison substation on a trapezoidal-shaped lot across Vesey Street from the twin towers.

title: Norway's Trade Gains
description: Norway's balance of payments surplus more than doubled during the first eight months of the year from the year- earlier period, the Government said today. It said the surplus grew to 19.8 billion kroner, or about $2.24 billion, from about 8 billion kroner.

description: Canada's new Progressive Conservative Party Government today put at least $1.6 billion of state-owned companies up for sale in the clearest sign yet that the Tories intend to give private enterprise freer rein.

title: Scene 2, Sidewalk 5
description: While the District of Columbia government revels in the number of motion pictures being shot on location here, foreseeing economic gain for the larger community, residents of Georgetown remain unsatisfied. Their small, manicured quarter of Federal and Victorian houses more often than not provides the film makers' backdrop, but all the neighbors receive in return is enormous vans blocking their parking and driveways and curiosity-seekers trampling their front flower beds.

In town were the Philadelphia 76ers, the team they eliminated in dramatic fashion in last season's playoffs, making their first appearance here and seeking revenge.

description: President Reagan spoke today of the possibility of a ''historic electoral realignment'' next Tuesday in which a large number of voters would, for the first time, shift their long-term loyalties from the Democrats to the Republicans.
