Mondale bought a quarter-page advertisement in today's issue of The New York Times to say Mr. Reagan's suggestion ''that his record was in the tradition of Roosevelt, Truman and Kennedy'' was ''a flagrant distortion of reality to serve his own political purpose.''

description: New York State's highest court ruled yesterday that a person may be deemed legally dead when the brain has ceased to function, even if the heartbeat and breathing are being maintained by artificial means.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: BEFORE 1970, when Dr. William H. Masters and Virginia E. Johnson, the pioneering sex therapists from St. Louis, revolutionized the treatment of sexual problems, this common area of distress had either been ignored by the medical profession or had been approached only through long psychotherapy, which often resulted in personal growth but might effect little improvement in sexual functioning.

title: OGILVY & MATHER INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
PRICE IN 'FORZA' ON PBS
description: ''LA FORZA DEL DESTINO,'' Verdi's dark-hued tragedy of vengeance and honor in 18th-century Spain, will open this year's ''Live From the Met'' series tonight at 8 on Channel 13 (simulcast over WQXR-FM). It was taped at the Metropolitan Opera last March 24, during a series of ''Forzas'' that did not exactly meet with rapturous critical acclaim at the time. But it shows the Met doing about as well by mature Verdi as is done by the great opera houses these days, and it offers one of our century's greatest singers in one of her greatest roles. No soprano has emerged to wear her mantle as becomingly as Leontyne Price still wears it. For her, this should not be missed.

title: Envoys Criticized on Helms
description: Dante B. Fascell, Democrat of Florida, chairman of the House Foreign Affairs Committee, joined Monday in criticizing the United States ambassadors who endorsed Senator Jesse Helms, Republican of North Carolina, for re- election. Representative Fascell suggested the ambassadors' endorsement of Mr. Helms over Gov. James B. Hunt Jr. threatened the bipartisanship of foreign policy.

title: Bulls Fine Dailey
description: Quintin Dailey, the Bulls' star guard, was fined ''substantially'' yesterday after he failed to appear for a game in Chicago Monday night and then missed a team flight to Kansas City yesterday morning. Dailey took a later flight and rejoined the club in time for last night's game against the Kings, but his absence Monday night marked the second time in his two years as a pro that he had missed a game without permission.

title: BRITISH AUTHOR OF 560 BOOKS
description: Ursula Bloom, one of Britain's most prolific romantic novelists, has died at the age of 91. The author of 560 books, Miss Bloom died at a nursing home Monday in Nether Wallop, Hampshire, 62 miles west of London.

title: OPERA: 'MANO LESCAUT' AT THE MET
description: HARD to believe, but it is more than 20 years since Mirella Freni first appeared in this country and immediately reached every susceptible operagoing heart with her Mimi and Marguerite. The big-name Italianate sopranos at that time were Maria Callas and Renata Tebaldi, whose voices are now cherished memories. Miss Freni, however, is still a major singer and an even more major singing actress, as she proved once more Monday night when she returned to the Metropolitan Opera in the title role of the season's first ''Manon Lescaut.''

title: Copland Song in Recital
description: ''Alone,'' an unpublished song by Aaron Copland, will be performed by the singer Jan DeGaetani and the pianist Gilbert Kalish at a joint recital on Dec. 4 at Carnegie Hall, Seventh Avenue and 57th Street.

title: Reagan and Rockefeller
description: Ronald Reagan, as he himself acknowledges, has been one of the most adjustable figures in American political life, shifting over the years from the stance of an ardent New Deal Democrat and labor union activist to that of an apostle of unfettered capitalism and the Republican right wing.

title: NEW WAYS TO APPRECIATE AUTUMN VEGETABLES
description: AUTUMN vegetables have a charming sort of plainness. Potatoes and onions, squash and pumpkins, cabbage and the other brassicas like brussels sprouts and broccoli, turnips, carrots, beets and parsnips - these are vegetables meant to be stored in attic, barn and cellar, to strengthen and sustain us through the long, dark days of winter. As such, they have an undeniably homely appeal.

Warner-Lambert Gain
description: The Warner-Lambert Company said today that its net income for the third quarter rose 12.3 percent, to $56.6 million, or 71 cents a share, from $50.4 million, or 63 cents, in the quarter a year earlier. Sales increased 3 percent, to $798.5 million, from $773.2 million. The income gain resulted from an improvement in the company's tax rate through Federal legislation enacted during the period, and by strong performances by its prescription drug and confectionery businesses, the company said.

description: A shift to a flat Federal income tax, with all taxpayers paying the same rate, is endorsed in the Republican platform. Curiously, this radical proposal has been ignored in the campaign while Walter F. Mondale's progressive tax plan has been scrutinized and condemned by the Republicans.

description: In an attempt to spur interest in its struggling electronic mail system, the Western Union Corporation said yesterday that users would soon be able to converse on their computers, rather than merely send electronic letters.

description: WHEN John J. O'Connor was installed as Archbishop of New York in March, he promised to learn Spanish to communicate better with the 800,000 Spanish-speaking Roman Catholics in the archdiocese. Five months later, before 10,000 people in Haverstraw, N.Y., he proclaimed: ''Yo mismo he escrito estas palabras, incluso los errores'' (''I have written these words myself, including the errors'').

description: Hortense Fuld Kessler, a lawyer who was a former president of the New Jersey Board of Public Utilities, died Sunday at her home in East Orange, N.J. She was 85 years old.

title: Military Contracts
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation received $256.8 million in Navy contracts for nuclear propulsion components and for design, development and manufacture of Trident II missile launcher equipment, the Defense Department said. In addition, TRW Inc. was awarded $67.9 million in Navy and Air Force contracts and a Martin Marietta Corporation subsidiary received $52.7 million in Army contracts, the department said.

title: U.S. STEEL HAS SHARP EARNINGS GAIN
description: The United States Steel Corporation, showing slightly better than break-even results on its steel operations, reported yesterday a hefty third-quarter profit gain aided by its pension-plan accrual changes and the sale of coal properties.

title: THE BENEFITS FROM LOWER INTEREST RATES
description: One of the most encouraging developments in the economy this year has been the sharp decline in interest rates over the last five months. Although the drop coincided with a weakening in the economy, lower rates have put new life into the stock market, where prices have rebounded from the summer lows, while also holding out hope that the economy will not slide into a full-fledged recession.

title: JAPANESE TRADE PANEL LETS FOREIGNERS TESTIFY
description: In a step that may lead toward greater foreign participation in the advisory councils that help shape Japanese industrial policy, foreign businessmen were allowed today for the first time to testify before a council of the Ministry of International Trade and Industry.

title: U.N. Calls on Vietnam To Leave Cambodia
description: The General Assembly called on Vietnam today to withdraw its troops from Cambodia and let the Cambodian people ''determine their own destiny.''

description: Five weeks into the television season, ABC is having its share of troubles in the prime-time ratings. It appears to be stuck in third place after five years as a solid and sometimes close second to CBS. For the moment, NBC, for years the also-ran, holds first place in the ratings for this season, although most network officials expect that within a few weeks it will slip behind CBS.

title: Bakeries Sold
description: The Interstate Bakeries Corporation said it had sold its Western operations to GSFC Inc., a closely held concern, for $40.1 million in cash plus certain assets for a total value of about $55.1 million. Under the agreement, Interstate will hold accounts payable and liabilities at closing totaling some $7.5 million and GSFC will assume liabilities valued at $636,000, Interstate said. The purchase price could be reduced by $6 million if Interstate decides to retain title to its Glendale, Calif., bakeries, under certain circumstances, Interstate said.

title: Burundi Bus Plunge Kills 43
description: Forty-three people were killed and 18 seriously hurt when a bus carrying 60 passengers and the driver fell into a ravine on Friday 55 miles of here. The police said it was the worst road accident in the history of Burundi.

title: Samsung in G.M. Deal
description: The Samsung Precision Industries Company said today that it had agreed to join the General Motors Corporation to produce gas turbine engines for light aircraft and helicopters. Samsung will manufacture engine compressors, ignitors and other parts, while G.M.'s Allison gas turbine division will provide technical help, Samsung said.

title: SMITH, SANCHEZ: OFFBEAT NOTES
description: SPRING fashion openings in New York started on an offbeat note as Willi Smith staged a vernissage instead of a runway show and Fernando Sanchez mingled lingerie and dresses in his individual sexy-but-casual style.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ; Pepsico President Going to Harvard
description: Pepsico Inc. said yesterday that Andrall E. Pearson, its president and chief operating officer since 1971, would retire Jan. 1 to join the faculty at the Harvard University Graduate School of Business Administration as a tenured full professor. However, he will retain his seat on Pepsico's board.

title: SURVIVAL RECORD IS SET BY HEART-IMPLANT BABY
description: A thriving Baby Fae today became the longest surviving human recipient of a transplanted animal heart.

title: Prudential Insurance
description: David J. Sherwood, 13th president of the Prudential Insurance Company of America, will retire Nov. 9, a company spokesman said today. Jim Longo, manager of public relations for Prudential, noted that the company announced the retirement of Mr. Sherwood, 61 years old, in August but did not give the date at that time. Joseph J. Melone, currently executive vice president, will succeed Mr. Sherwood, Mr. Longo said.

description: The International Business Machines Corporation, four months after it cut prices as much as 23 percent on its Personal Computer line, has started a three-month sales promotion that could effectively cut prices an additional 9 percent on its machines.

description: Despite the wettest October in Texas history, officials say the moisture is not enough to end the drought that has plagued farmers and cities around the state for more than a year.

title: Gallup Poll Sees Reagan With a Lead of 17 Points
description: The newest Gallup Poll, next to the last before the election Tuesday, gives President Reagan a lead of 57 percent to 40 percent over Walter F. Mondale, the Gallup Organization reported yesterday.

title: Ready for Election Night
description: At that, there's more than one way to view the end of a long campaign. A key female operative from Mondale headquarters was spending a long lunch hour at one of Washington's smarter dress shops, selecting leather slacks, a silk blouse and other pricey accouterments. ''This outfit will really knock 'em dead at the Election Night party,'' she announced optimistically.

title: INDIRA GANDHI, SKILLED IN USES OF POWER, DOMINATED INDIA FOR TWO DECADES
description: She was sometimes called the Empress of India and sometimes a dictator and sometimes Mataji, the big mother. Whatever the epithet, Indira Gandhi was clearly the dominant figure in India for two decades, a woman who attracted controversy and was skilled in the uses of her vast power.

description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: PRESIDENT SIGNS PLEDGE TO SEEK SPACE COOPERATION
description: President Reagan today signed a Congressional resolution pledging to seek cooperation with the Soviet Union in a broad range of space activities.

title: ENVOY CALLS '82 MIDEAST PLAN ILL-TIMED
description: The United States Ambassador to Israel, Samuel W. Lewis, said today of President Reagan's 1982 Middle East peace initiative that ''the timing, in my opinion, was abysmal, the tactics of presentation worse and the outcome, so far, nil.''

title: SEX-ORIENTED STORES SUE TO BLOCK TIMES SQ. PLAN
description: The huge Times Square rebuilding plan was designed to fill 42d Street with ''restaurants, cabarets and other evening entertainment facilities,'' including bookstores and shops ''carrying merchandise for a variety of income levels.''

PAPAL PLOT MAY HURT U.S.-SOVIET TIES
description: Reagan Administration officials said today that if Bulgarians were found guilty in Italy of conspiring to assassinate Pope John Paul II, the United States would face the issue of whether to go ahead in seeking improved relations with the Soviet Union.

title: Four Maturities For Canada Bonds
description: The Canadian Government's Finance Department announced the pricing on its new $1.05 billion issue of noncallable bonds. The issue will come in four maturities.

ARSONS PLAGUE DETROIT IN PRE-HALLOWEEN OUTBREAK
description: An apartment building was set ablaze and flames from fires in abandoned buildings leaped to occupied houses tonight as increased police and fire forces battled the traditional ''Devil's Night'' Halloween Eve arson spree.

title: NIAGARA LANDFILL'S OPERATOR ASSERTS WASTE ISN'T LEAKING
description: The company that operates a Niagara Falls disposal site containing toxic wastes excavated from the nearby Love Canal and other dumps yesterday contested a report from the Federal Environmental Protection Agency that the site might be leaking.

title: No Headline
description: WEDNESDAY, OCTOBER 31, 1984 International OPEC agreed on a general formula of production cuts to shore up prices, but analysts predicted the plan would be ineffective. Few details were released, but various sources said that while the 8.57 percent reduction would be divided equally among the 13 members in theory, in practice the wealthier members would make cuts for the poorer ones. The meeting is likely to adjourn today without addressing problems in OPEC's pricing structure. (Page A1.) Foreign businessmen in Japan participated, for the first time, in a meeting of a trade ministry council that helps shape industrial legislation. An American urged cooperation in research. (D1.)

title: WINE TALK
description: PERHAPS 75 percent of all wine sold at the retail level is bought a bottle at a time. ''Pick up a bottle of wine for dinner'' is the way most purchases start. Smart consumers soon learn, of course, that buying by the case is more convenient and cheaper - fewer trips to the store and, often, a 10 percent case discount.

title: FORMER STEELWORKERS' INCOME FALLS BY HALF
description: The average income of workers laid off from the United States Steel Corporation's South Works in the last five years has been cut almost in half, according to a study of the effects of the layoffs.

title: Davenport Named
description: Jim Davenport, as expected, was named manager of the San Francisco Giants yesterday, replacing Danny Ozark, who had filled in on an interim basis after Frank Robinson was let go at midseason. Davenport, 51 years old, was the first regular third baseman the Giants had after their move from New York to San Francisco in 1958, and he remained in the organization as a minor league manager after he retired as a player in 1971.

title: Feldstein Sees Tax Increase WASHINGTON, Oct. 30,
description: (Reuters) - Martin S. Feldstein, the former top economic

title: Lakers 144, Warriors 110
description: Mike McGee scored 28 points, and Byron Scott added 26 to help Los Angeles t its first victory after two defeats. The Lakers led at halftime, 62-53, and broke it open in the third period by outscoring the Warriors (0-3) by 39- 20, with Scott leading the way with 8 points.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Phil Simms of the Giants, whose 339 yards passing paced the Giants' upset of the Redskins, was named the offensive player of the week in the National Conference. . . . Joe Danelo, the place-kicker who had a long career with the Giants before being displaced by Ali Haji-Sheikh, was waived yesterday by the Buffalo Bills, who signed Chuck Nelson to replace him. Danelo had made only 8 of 16 field-goal attempts this season, only one from beyond 40 yards. . . . Jay Roulier, a 39-year-old Denver real estate developer and one-third owner of the United States Football League's Houston Gamblers, has purchased the financially troubled Los Angeles Express. Roulier, who was announced as the new owner at the league's recent meetings in Florida, said he has put his interest in the Gamblers up for sale. . . . Tom Penders, the basketball coach at Fordham the last six season, has signed a new, five-year contract with the school. . . . Billy Costello will defend his World Boxing Council superlightweight title on Saturday against Saoul Mamby instead of Leroy Haley, because Haley has a hand injury.

title: Ross Roy Gets Ameritech Account
description: Ross Roy Inc., in Detroit, has been named to do advertising for Ameritech Publishing, the Yellow Pages subsidiary of American Information Technologies, one of the results of Ma Bell's break-up.

title: ESTIMATES SINK FOR EARNINGS

title: MOCHARY STRESSING LINKS TO REAGAN

Coach's Warning
description: The continuing quarterback controversy on the Dallas Cowboys has led Coach Tom Landry to warn his players that further public criticism of teammates or the coaching staff will result in suspensions and $1,000 fines, according to The Dallas Morning News. Landry's comments, the newspaper said, came in a meeting Monday and were prompted by remarks by some players last week after the coach announced that Danny White would return as a starter, replacing Gary Hogeboom , who won the starting job during the exhibition season.

title: RAISING ALL-NATURAL BEEF: HARDY FEW DELIVER GOODS
description: WASHINGTON BETWEEN the pastures of Gwynn Garnett's farm near Culpepper, Va., and the dining tables of the Tabard Inn in Washington, beef leads an exemplary life. The Garnett cattle have space to amble about, free from the claustrophobic conditions of many feed lots, and old tires to nudge for amusement. They eat organically home-grown corn and alfalfa, supplemented with seaweed imported from Norway, an organic enzyme that enhances digestion and unrefined salt.

description: After twice barring him from the United States in the last four years, the State Department yesterday agreed to give a visa to Dario Fo, the controversial Italian dramatist whose play ''Accidental Death of an Anarchist'' opens on Broadway on Nov. 15. A senior State Department official confirmed the department's decision and said a public announcement would be made this morning.

title: Gypsy Patriarch Dies as Clan Visits Hospital to Honor Him
description: Frank Mitchell, leader of a gypsy clan, died Monday as his followers lined up in a corridor of Baptist Hospital to honor him.

description: Sales of new homes in September soared 21.9 percent from August, with the growth fastest in the South, the Government reported today. The monthly increase was the biggest in more than four years.

title: 'GHOST DANCE'
description: ''GHOST DANCE,'' an experimental film by the British director Ken McMullen, is notable for its very leisurely pace, its occasional bizarre humor, its near-perfect opacity and the presence of two striking individuals: Jacques Derrida, the French linguistic philosopher, and Pascale Ogier, the late young actress whose doleful, mature face and mischievous manner held forth such great promise of a remarkable screen career. ''Ghost Dance,'' which mixes these two, Karl Marx, Sigmund Freud, Jacques Rivette and a couple of exceedingly weird supporting players, opens today at the Film Forum.

description: The Louisville Cement Company said today that it had agreed to be acquired by the Coplay Cement Company for $72 a share, or $112.5 million.

title: DOZENS OF SUSPICIOUS DEATHS CITED IN POLAND

description: The Sudan's Moslem Government has reached a provisional peace treaty with separatist rebels who have been fighting the imposition of Islamic law in the Christian south, the Sudan press agency said today.

title: Goalie's Big Test
description: Tom Barrasso's short National Hockey League career has been meteoric. At the age of 18 he came out of Acton Boxboro High School in Massachusetts to become the starting goalie for the Buffalo Sabres and went on last season to win the Calder and Vezina trophies, the first emblematic of the league's best rookie and the second its best goaltender.

title: PRICES MOVE SHARPLY HIGHER

Contributing to the rally were further signs of discord among members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries in their efforts to shore up crude oil prices.

description: China predicted today that its grain and cotton harvest for 1984 would reach record levels as a result of its contract farming system. A harvest of 400 million tons of grain this year, up 3.3 percent from 387.2 million last year, was forecast, along with a cotton crop of 5.5 million tons, up 20 percent from 4.5 Million tons.

title: THE POP LIFE

GEILS BAND began playing rock and blues in Boston in the mid-60's and built an audience the hard way - touring year after year and turning in powerful, energized performances almost every night. By 1981-82 they had reached the top. Their album ''Freeze Frame'' (EMI), and hit singles like ''Centerfold'' that were issued from it, hit the top of the charts and sold millions of copies, making the J. Geils Band the stars their loyal live audiences had long believed them to be.

title: Financial Corporation

A spokesman for the company said Mr. Darr was unavailable for comment. He added that Mr. Darr, who is 40 years old, had accepted a position with another financial institution. Mr. Darr was elevated to a new, three- man office of the president and named co-chief operating officer days before Charles W. Knapp resigned under pressure on Aug. 28 as Financial's chairman and chief executive.
